reviews.review: Wow. Unbelievable opulance and wealth spent on the house and gardens. Fountains, of course, were a real highlight and all done without pumps.

beautiful place, to many people. Second time in St Petersburg, so we had to see Grand Palace. Experienced before, that in Russia you have to buy tickets on advance or you have to wait for a long time. Did not have option for Grand palace. We took boat, very nice trip, but only if good weather. avoid wind and waves. Arrived in fantastic place, no wonder why Tsar have chosen this place. Pity, there was many people like me, means to crowded. Wanted to see place inside, there was very, very long queue. believe it or not, after 1,5 hour standing, suddenly tickets office closed. I never found out why, in the middle of a day. About 1pm. Maybe staff went for lunch and they do not have enough employee??? More then 150 was still waiting. This is probably only possible in Russia, even difficult to understand. believe Russians are experienced to queue up.......

Brief tips for The State Hermitage. As it is one of the biggest art museums in the world, it's impossible to be seen in full in 1 or even in 2 visits. Thence there are 2 main reasons to see it: First - to get the general impression and feeling of the Russian Emperors' official Palace residence, including all its beauty and unparallelled richness; and Second - to get the pleasure of seeing art objects at your choice. My definite advice is that you pre-plan what you would like to see there, in advance. Otherwise you are at a risk of having your brains overloaded. For individual visitors: get the entrance ticket (open date) online and skip the huge que.

Incredible day!. It is obviously a must visit when you are in St-Petersburg. Our best photos came from this place! This is a very interesting sight. It is not just a park. It is a park complex with lots of fountains that you can explore! You must go inside the Peterhof Grand palace. It gives you the feel of old times! Overall a great place to visit on a dry day in St-Petersburg.

This was over the top grand...and the gardens in the back will delight you. This palace is the most grand I have seen....but nothing less for Peter the Great...the palace had a lot of add on buildings over time. The gardens are the most breathtaking...and I saw more gold than in a jewelry store! Lots of walking, but so much to see....try to schedule the hydrofoil ride to or from the Palace. It is a real treat! There are also some food concessions out near the docks. I would highly recommend a guided tour as you will hear all about the details and history of this Grand Palace.
grand. beautiful place. must see. a little bit crowded but not more than expected. easy to reach by public transport.

grand palace with a stunning view of the sea. This seaside palace is unbelievably well maintained. The interior was beautiful, but the spotlight has to be the massive garden. The garden was amazing, with fountains that were really cool. This place is definitely a must-go, you can see palaces, fountains, bridges, beaches, and the mesmerising blue sea in one go. The only downside is that it was really crowded.

The gardens. We visited the gardens on our 2 day Alla Tours Faberge excursions ex Cruise Terminal. They are wonderful. Nothing like gilt statues, sun and water to crown off the walk! We did not go inside because we went inside some other barque buildings instead. Eg The Hermitage and St Catherine's Palace. We were told the ones we saw inside were similar or better.
Amazing. Take your time there, walk the gardens, not just the palace. Wonderful place to spend a day (or two) in a summer

Wonderful . We visited as part of a Viking sea cruise. The palace is spectacular the grounds are astonishing. The daily fountain displays are not to be missed. These people knew how to live and spend money.

Grand Palace Indeed. This is indeed a Grand Palace. Peterhof is a forty minute drive from the centre of St Petersburg.This has been called the "Russian Versaille" – the palace that Peter The Great built. The building was built by 1721.You need to wear plastic protectors for your shoes so that the floor is not affected. You are not allowed to take any photos or videos. There are ladies in each room who ensure that nobody breaches this rule. They also regulate the number of visitors in each room. You barely have time to listen to what the guide says before you are ushered on to the next room.The staircase leading up to the upper floor is very ornate and “dripping with gold”. I was awe struck by the Ball room and the Throne room in particular. Other rooms were magnificent too. They are all lavishly decorated. At times I felt they were over the top with some of the decorations. Opening times are from 10.30am to 7pm. On Thursdays the closing time is 9pm. Admission prices are 550 Rubles (equivalent to about GBP7 Aug 2016).I would recommend visiting this Palace. It should be among the top three places to visit in St Petersburg.

Grand Palace with Grandeur views. If you have at least half a day to spare travel to this sea side Palace and park by bus or by hydrofoil. Must buy a ticket to palace park at Rub 700.00 each, then line up for tickets to Grand Palace at Rub 600.00 each. You are in a totally different world. The lavishly decorated with gold leaf and mirrored walls with oak paneled floors, beautiful chandeliers and grand rooms for various occasions give you an insight to the glory days of Great Tsars. All the trouble to go up their and buy tickets disappear once you are inside. The master plan to create this masterpiece with rows of fountains overlooking the gulf of Finland is only summarized with one word as MIRACLES performed by Peter the Great.

Beautiful. As someone who grew up during the cccp period in western europe, it seems unbelievable to see the riches of Peterhof, stroll through the beautiful gardens, and admire the water fountains. Feels like Versailles in France, and we especially liked the "natural" gardens and the view by the ocean.We took a private tour from St. Petersburg and combined it with a visit to Catherine's palace and a tour to some of the beautiful St. Petersburg metro stations. A day well spent!

Oh Oh Oh So Grand. The abundance of wealth accumulated by the 300 year reign of the Czars is once again evident in the Grand Palace. The palace was originally laid out by Peter the Great. Photos are not permitted within the palace. The opulence rivals the Hermitage. Overshoes are worn to protect the oh so intricate patterns. The palace was re-constructed after WW2, following destruction by the Nazis. The workmanship is so good, that it appears to have been finished only yesterday. We visited in Autumn, without crowds. It is likely a mad house in summer, as the visiting process is linear, and one can be held up by gawking large groups. A guide is essential, if you really want to learn something about Russian culture and history.

Go by hydrofoil!. We took the hydrofoil to the Gulf of Finland on our way to the Palace at Peterhof. This is a GREAT way to go. We saw completely different sides of St Petersburg on the way including noticing the old docks and the extensive civil engineering work that is being undertaken. The ride was a thrill. It is windy on the dock on arrival but we had the sun at our backs. The walk along the canal to the fountains is simply wonderful. The fountains are a marvel. The Palace itself is small compared to Versailles and the Winter Palace but the richness of the display is almost dazzling! If you go to St Petersburg is would be a huge shame to miss this Palace and its fountains and gardens!

Beautiful every area. I visited in fall season and it was stunning everywhere with colored leaves. Don't miss the fountain at 11:00 am and get yourself warm because it's near the shore so this place is really windy.

The most beautiful palace and fountain gardens that I have ever seen. The Peterhof museum complex is indeed the most beautiful palace and fountain garden complex I have ever seen. Versailles, San-Soussi or Vienna Belveder have nothing to compare. It's better to visit Peterhof in summer or in early autumn to see it in the most beauty.

Wonderful place, great water features. This is an hour or more outside St Petersburg depending on traffic. it is actually a reconstruction as the Nazis burned the original to the ground on leaving after WW2. We went past a few dachas en route including Putins. The interiors have been amazingly reconstructed and the guide told us how much more the originals would have been. The gardens are very pleasant.

Spectacular Fountains. I arranged a Private Tour through Marina Wilson Private Tours. We did not visit the inside of the palace because it is said to be similar to Catherine Palace we had already visited that day. However the fountains and gold painted statues are really worth a visit. It is truly amazing the quality of the renovations that have occurred and are on going.

unmissable. A fabulous place to visit - we went by boat (/hovercraft?). The grounds alone are superb - particularly beautiful in autumn, with the leaves just turning, and red squirrels everywhere - and we also had a lovely lunch on the terrace of one of the restaurants in the ground (the one we found was Chinese pagoda-style).

Great in summer. The best time for visiting is 17-45 on weekdays. It's the cheapest and you catch the last scene of the main fonduing, with their anthem and all music. Afterwards you will have time to stroll in the park. If you are interested in excursion, then you have to be there earlier. The best is after 14-00, as all organised group excursions are finished by that time.
beauty and big. It's beside gulf of Finland and very beauty...Many jets of water are there and it's will amaze you when you know that these jets work without any pumps!

It's Grand alright!. No photography is allowed inside the Peterhof summer palace, but in my opinion it's the grand cascade and gardens that impress most. The Tsar wanted a 'Russian Versailles' and I have to say (having been to Versailles) he outdid the French when comes to the gardens. Much grander than Catherine Palace, it is the most carefully designed and perfectly manicured gardens you'll ever see. If you arrive by coach and take the hovercraft back to Saint Petersburg, allow a good 10-15 mins to make your way down to the jetty by foot.

Beautiful, even in the rain!. We were looking forward to visiting this palace as we had read lots about it while researching our trip to Russia. We had organised an English speaking tour guide through 'tsar voyages' and she was amazing. She came to meet us at our hotel and had organised the time for the hydrofoil and throughout the tour she told us so much.This is an outstanding building, incredibly busy, but so worth the trip. It amazed us that so much renovation had taken place since the Second World War and you can see photos of the restoration on the way out.It was a very wet day when we visited but it did not spoil our enjoyment of this incredible place.

Take a guided tour. Reading a selection of recent reviews I'm glad I came here on a Guided Tour organised by Silversea, whose cruise ship I was on. It's evident the tour companies are given priority with early access before the Palace is officially opened to the public. But there are still vast numbers of people visiting here just like the Hermitage and Catherine's Palace so it makes these visits all a bit of an ordeal even when you do get in early. Apart from the obvious extravagance on display which is on a truly grand scale and which is truly amazing, what is even more astonishing is finding out what you've looking at is the painstaking reconstruction after the near total destruction of these beautiful palaces by the nazis by a lot of very talented and dedicated people. Well worth the visit despite the numbers who you'll have to share it all with.

No photoes allowed. We went to see the lovely fountains and gold statues and they were as expected magnificent. But in the end we decided to pay for the tickets to go round the building while we were there and what a good decision that was. Having been to the Winter Palace we weren't really expecting to be impressed; but Peterhof surpasses the Winter Palace in gold ornate decoration; the ball room is just wonderful...what a life those people lived (although you can see how the mood for a revolution grew). We went there by hydrofoil from St Petersburg and that was such an easy and pleasant way to get there...but we aware these are sometimes cancelled due to weather. One tip, if you don't want the fast food options dotted around the gardens, there is a charming little cafe/restaurant down some steps hidden away on the eastern side of the grounds.

BEAUTIFUL!. We were only able to explore the grounds of Peterhof (and not the interior) due to the time constraints of having only one day here. And the exterior is DAZZLING! The fountain, statues, and architecture was all SO BEAUTIFUL! I can definitely see why Russia is so well-known for its architecture due to masterpieces like this!
Sasi. I like to much park tree, apple tree good and enjoy and good view and relaxing for me and good view for my photo at sea see you next year
A must see. We took a boat from St Petersburg to get here. The site is very wonderful specially the fountains. Explore the lower garden there are a couple of things to see

Simply and absolutely stunning. I find it difficult to express how much I adored this place. I would simply recommend it. It has a charm which allows you to escape everyday life and return you to a place in which your ancestors once roamed. Atmospheric and thoroughly delightful

WOW. Just incredible!! its a must-see location! the palace is mesmerizing and the gardens are perfect!
It stays about 40mins out of St P and on the shores of the Baltic sea, really worth

Peterhof palace and gardens. . We've made a guided tour true the palace and it's garden full with fountains.
Inside the palace there is such a great history to be seen.
The amount of gold used to decorate it with is to much one can handle.

Beautiful gardens and fountains that can take a whole day to visit. we took the hydrofoil at the pier in front of the Hermitage Museum. We had bought a St. Petersburg card, so we just had to pay for the return. With this card it allowed us entrance to the gardens. The trip to Peterhof takes around 45 mins. I would recommend that you come on a guided tour with a russian translator here as practically nobody speaks English. We came on the day when there was a fountain festival and fireworks. It was bedlam , so disorganised. When we finally got through to the garden and up to the grand fountain and Palace we were told that the palace was now closed. Total shambles, no organisation and this is not the place that can take tourism. shambles. However, we then decided to wander around the estate with its beautiful gardens and elaborate fountains. there is an exhibition showing the restoration work on the property after world war 11 and the destruction by the Germans. Certainly a lovely place to visit.

So much already written...... Another one of the ‘must see’ destinations. You will do much better with a guide or on a tour, unless you have days to explore on your own.It is extravagant. Beautiful. Billed as the Russian answer to Versailles. The building is smaller than you might expect, but the grounds are remarkable.

Badly managed establishment. This has to be my worse tour experience...1) you pay for each entrance to different parts of the grounds (restaurants is outside lower garden, palace is and pier is within lower garden)2) they restrict ticket sales to foreign visitors after 230pm3) there ZERO English staffs on the ground able to articulate clear how to get into the palace- beautiful place / horrible management--- either join a tour or go in the afternoon.--- last hydrofoil leaves ~530pmSuggested itinerary- car ride to peterhof, upper garden, lunch, palace, lower garden, hydrofoil

Ambiguous ticketing time n waste us 2 hours. We arrived at 11:30am and they suddenly said thats lunch time to close the museum. Then at 1pm, when we saw all russians are getting tickets, they said tourist can only get ticket from 14:30. Without english instructions and descriptions at the site nor at their website, the staff just threw us all around to different offices for buying tickets. What a waste of time and it s completely lack of systematic handling!
A Must. This is quite incredible and can be rated as equal to if not better than Germany and France, Plan for a full day at this location. Do not forget your camera. Perhaps a second day.
Versaille of Russia. Amazing palace, with wonderful gardens and a beautiful ocean view. Go at sunset to see a spectacular one.

STP CITY TOUR. It's about hour from STP city and it's worth visit to Grand Palace. Nice interior and the palace is quite huge. During my visit, that's a fountain ceremony. Outside the palace you need to walk to the garden and sea front.

Beautiful Must See Palace and Gardens. Locals and our guide book call this the Peterhof Palace. It is spectacular. Out front are fabulous extensive formal gardens, better than, but in the style of formal European gardens. This was originally vegetable beds and fish ponds in 1725. In the rear is an extensive private park with incredible tiered step fountains down to the sea channel. In 1730 the Samson Fountain was installed depicting Samson defeating a lion. This represents Russia's victory over Sweden in the Great Northern War...There are dozens of fountains on the grounds including several trick fountains that are designed to soak unwary guests. Of particular interest is the fact that all fountains are gravity fed from an elevated lake on a nearby mountain without any pumps. The palace was occupied by the Nazi's in the second world war and the palace treasures, the palace building and most of the fountains were largely destroyed. Restoration began in 1947 and some of the treasures that had been hidden were returned and restoration continues today. On our interior tour about half the building has been restored to its original glory and similar art and furniture has been brought in to replace that which was lost and to supplement that which was saved. This is a truly memorable palace to visit and although a little expensive, you should be comfortable knowing all the money today goes toward upkeep and continuing restoration.
A vast expanse.. This is a big place and you need transport to get there. I went on a organised tour, where many single young beautiful Russian ladies also went on.

My most expensive day in Russia!. This gigantic and beautiful palace was pretty far from the city center and there were only 2 ways to go there, by expensive hydrofoil (boat) and bus. It took about 40 mins by hydrofoil, cost about 1400p roundtrip) from the pier behind the Hermitage to the pier at Peterhof. And it'd take more than one hour and a half from the city center to the upper garden of the Peterhof. So I took the hydrofoil as well as so many of tourist. Anyway, if you've full day for this place, I recommend you to take the bus to Peterhof and take the hydrofoil back so it's cheaper and you can enjoy both upper and lower gardens. Here's why; I had to buy the ticket for entering the palace and lower garden at the gate near the hydrofoil pier, and if I got out of the palace to the upper garden, I couldn't use the same ticket to came back to the lower garden even though I had the hydrofoil ticket back to town. That's kinda nonsense for me. :-( So if you wanna enjoy both lower and upper garden (which may not be so different), you'd better enter the Palace from the upper side which is impossible if you go there by hydrofoil. Anyway, I spent about 3.5 hours only in the lower garden and then time's up! I didn't even get inside the Palace so I can't tell anyone about it. But the garden was great a big enough to took you whole day. There are one or two little palaces beside the main building that I had to pay more if I'd like to have a look inside. So the 400p ticket I paid for getting into the Peterhof didn't include the entrance of other palaces inside. That's why it's the most expensive places for me in Russia. Anyway, the summer fountain and the garden were nice and beautiful. :-) I'd recommend whoever have more than 2500p to spare to go there. But if you're on a budget, a tight budget, I don't think it'll impress you much compared to the money you've to spend.

spectacular fountains . we just walked and toured outside, the garden and the fountains were just so amazing we spent all the time out there admiring the beautiful architecture and design of this place and taking great photos. Yes it makes you think of Versailles if you want to compare but it is just SO beautiful that you can forget About elsewhere while you are in here!
Peterhof. The most beautiful fountain I have ever seen in my entire life. Versailles garden is no longer a big deal after this one.

Wow. As a tourist you need to pay 700 rub to just visit the palace garden. ... which is magnificent. .... gorgeous. ... waw...... a must see.... a must visit You can take bus 404 directly to here worh only 70 rub.

Awesome place !,,. Fantastic, incredible....you I'll need to take a boat to arrive there, but they work very well and you are able to know St. petersbourg from the channel. The palacio is amazing and unique.

Impressive. Not quite as impressive inside as Catherine's palace in Pushkin, but pretty impressive nonetheless. Apparently the reconstruction from WWII damage was only completed relatively recently, and our guide pointed out that you could see the difference between the original statues and the replacements (the new ones look, well, newer), The fountains and cascades outside, however, rate a big "Wow". Rivaling Versailles. A must see.

Stunning. Absolute must see for anyone visiting StPetersburg. Beautiful gardens with the most delightfully stunning yet eccentric fountains!We went by boat as didn't fancy hours on a coach, more expensive but worth it for time saved, don't bother booking on an excursion it's very easy to make your own way.

Just walking around was grand. We just walked the gardens and the grounds. The fountains and buildings were fabulously beautiful. Take some great pictures looking down the fountain mall to the water from the terrace in front of the palace. Well worth a visit.

Marvellous. Our guide had arranged an early entry for us so we were able to avoid queue to enter and visit the Palace and its collections. Each room has a history of its own. Outside, the water works, working on gravity and not using ang motorised equipment is a marvel. The water works, fountains ,beautiful manicured lawns, the statues, work in gold everywhere inside and outside the palace is very charming.
Garden splendour. Fabulous I loved the gardens the best. The place was immaculent and the views were very nice. Shame about the hoards of people.

This was a sidetrip of a Riveboat Cruise.. This is a very beautiful place with a lot of stairs and/or climbing. One of our friends could not make the entire circle and had to be helped back to the entrance.

A beautiful palace that is even more beautifully managed. This is the famous Grand Palace of Peter the Great. The palace is glitzy and a must visit place when you visit St. Petersburg. I was more impressed by the way the crowds were managed. The groups were taken by appointment and no photographs were allowed which prevented people hanging around to take pictures. Every room had an alarm which sounded if the room was overcrowded. And we had to wear overshoes inside. I thought the visits were well regulated I do wish they do the same to Hermitage Museum.

Stunning and historically jam packed. I could have spent all day, if not two days visiting this place. Totally heartbreaking to see the state it was in after World War 2 and now restored in all it's glory. The gardens, waterfalls and fountains alone are worth a visit. Gold leaf is featured everywhere but then we went into the cottage palace where Peter the great actually lived and it was very plain but with views of the river Neva from most rooms as Peter was a sailor. If you love history, grand buildings and beautiful gardens, then you must visit this place. Look out for the tricks in the gardens

Uncomfortable visiting experience. I went there during early September in the morning, and there were many Chinese groups doing the guided tour inside the Grand Palace. I was a solo visitor, and I didn't rent the audio guide...which was a big mistake.Because I didn't have the audio guide, I could only read the brief description set in each room, and I wanted to spend time appreciate those rooms. But there were many Chinese groups, and sometimes the staff thought I'm one off them, and pushed me to stay with them (since they need to do volume control), but those Chinese groups knew I'm not one of them and asked me to stay away from them. Sometimes I only wanted to read the description carefully, but I was forced to move alone since I was standing at the spot where the Chinese group wanted to stay and they didn't want me to hear their introduction for free.God....I had no intention to eavesdrop their introduction, but I had nowhere to go, since I was stuck among 3~4 Chinese groups at once.Really awful experience....and in the end I had no impression what I saw in that palace, except tons of Chinese people.Maybe the Grand Palace can have better idea to ensure both group and individual visitors have nice visiting experience.
Grand as the name suggests. Grand place. As the name says, its really grand. The architecture, the landscaping, the history. Its all so beautiful that you would want to be back again

Amazing!! Not to be missed!. So happy we went here...it is crowded but so beautiful...We were lucky to be there on a sunny day so the gardens were lovely! The fountains were grand! Note if you use a walker or other assistance you will need to use a wheelchair. Also you have to wear booties so not to damage the floors.
Very grand indeed. Superb initial rooms but take time to enjoy the gardens as they are very tranquil when you leave the main walks near the canal.

A must See. It's an amazing place. The grandeur of the fountains are simply amazing. The technology of the water coming out of the fountain without any pumps is astonishing. The gardens, the marble statues and the amount of gold they have used to cover the things there is a must see. If you are staying in the city centre it's more than an hours drive through different parts of St Petersburg which is quite interesting.

Fountain-ful fun place. We took the first hydrofoil and reached just in time for the fountain show at 11am. There were already a crowd there so I could get the best view, but it's still breathtaking. We then wondered around the grounds without much fun till we reach the trick fountains and were awestruck and forgot the time to leave. The food trucks in the park sells decent snacks too.
AMAZING PLACE. Another place a must see ...huge and very grand and the turning on of the fountains is the highlight of the day, beautiful as is the gardens

What a Place!. I was amazed and appalled by the amount of gold the families of the czar. People on the outside were poor, very poor and the family had everything you could imagine, even a beautiful wood burning furnace from Norway. I understand why the poor rebelled. It has beautiful landscaping. A place you have to see.
Must see. Amazing palace surrounded with gold status, definitely a must see palace nice walk, beautiful palace 👌

Some palace!. The rooms are certainly amazingly decorated - not a relaxing environment in which to live but making a definite statement. The quality of the workmanship is outstanding.It was a little difficult to see everything as we were not part of an organised group and there were plenty of these doing the rounds. Also the room descriptions given in English were rather limited.Having said that, we wouldn't have missed it!

What an incredible array of fountains!. I've been over much of the world and very few places were as impressive as the Grand Palace of Peterhof. The Czar built quite and impressive compound for himself and I guess all the resources went into this instead of the starving peasants populating the region. No wonder there was a revolution. Still 100 years later it makes a great tourist attraction. Enjoy!

Dazzling experience!!. Fascinating, and wonderful.............crowded with other tour groups but still amazing experience. Make sure you look down as well as up as the floors are mind-blowing with the intricately worked wood and detail and variety of designs. Would have loved to have longer to browse in each area............this was possible in the grounds which were also beautiful and with wonderful views of the fountains and palace itself. We had a lovely sunny September day too.

can only say WOW!. At this venue (Alla Tours) we were only able to visit the gardens briefly....but WOW.! It wet the appetite enough that I for sure want to go back and meander those gardens and visit the palace. It was surely spectacular on the outside and very interesting history.

A must see in St Petersburg. Take the ferry from the ferry station beside the Hermitage. It's about 900 rubles round trip. Takes just over 30 min. You need to allow 6 hrs at least if you want to see all the palaces, gardens and fountains. Ticket sales are very disorganized and you can get into long lines. Don't miss this one a must see in St Petersburg

More expensive for non-russians. Big area and good for a walk. Unfortunately it costs more for non-russians than it does for russians.You can reach it very comfortably via boat bus from near the Eremtage, but it is quite expensive.Pick a day with good weather as it is all outside!

A Grand Palace Indeed. The summer home of Peter the Great can not be missed. Plan a full day, there are two hundred acres of gardens and fountains and history to explore. There are restaurants on site. They offer guided tours in various languages.
The gardens were mesmerizing!. Have to say, the gardens around the peterhof palace were mesmerizing, were serene and tranquil. Must visit. Atleast once in your visit to Russia

Gorgeous Grounds on Ocean front. This place is fit for a king....wait, it was made for one! You'll feel the majesty and splendor of this property. The architectural design was well thought out and still-operating fountains operate on gravity, not pumps! What a feat! You'll love the ocean breeze lapping around you as you stroll through the park and near the fountains. Don't miss!

Beautiful, but ruined with the cheesey stage setting. I have been here before and the first time I went, the fountains were breathtaking.This time we went, there was some event going on. Most of the fountains were shut off because they put a stage on it. The "show" was a bit bizarre and the music loud. The event clearly did not fit in the Peterhof setting. We came by Peterhof Express (hydrofoil). The express lands you in the "lower fountains". You cannot go around to the front. I am not sure who designed the entrances, but clearly designed to rake in as much money as possible. It costs 700 rubles to enter the "Lower fountains". The upper gardens is free. There is supposed to be a beautiful fountain in the upper garden. However, once you enter the Lower fountains, you have no in/out access. This means if you want to see the upper garden, you have to pay another 700 rubles to re-enter. Found that quite annoying. Access to the palace is 600 rubles. You are NOT allowed to take photos and they make you put on little booties.I don't understand why you cannot take photos, because both the Hermitage and Catherine's palace allows it. Again, it is probably to increase revenue. My recommendation is to take a bus so that you can access the upper gardens first before entering the Lower fountains and palace. The trip would take longer, but well worth it. I would also recommend joining a tour. We went on our own. No one speaks English and we spent a good 20 minutes confused about where to enter and where on the grounds we actually were. Having a guide also helps with the explanations of each of the roomsStill is definitely a place to visit at least once in a lifetime.

Amazing Grounds. Our tour did not enter the palace, but the fountains and grounds were incredible. Entering by hydrofoil was also great as you could walk up the boulevard to the castle, passing the fountains and statuary.

Extensive and sumptuous palace gardens and fountains. This is the showpiece of Peter the Great - a palace built facing the sea with extensive gardens. The main attraction is the range of fountains located throughout the gardens. At the top of the main steps you can have a photo taken with royalty in full costume. The golden fountains are quite spectacular and include stairways and classical buildings. The entrance and huge pathway overlooking the fountains is quite crowded but after you go down the steps it becomes more open and tranquil in places.

Grand Palace at Peterhof.. Grand Palace. Great place to visit. The opulence, the grandeur of both inside as well as outside is amazing. One thing though. BEFORE you take the steps to the palace, be sure to be done with the toilets etc. at the lower level. There are no WCs on the higher level. However, those are available on exit after the palace tour.Be prepared to spend about an hour to buy the tickets and get inside. Photography inside the palace is not allowed.

Indeed it is GRAND!!. A shame no pictures were allowed during our tour of the interior of the palace but it is really spectacular. The exterior grounds are just as beautiful and impressive. All the fountains, golden leaf covered statues and gardens are so grand and well kept. Definitely worth visiting and having a tour guide will be very enlightening. We used Marina Wilson Tours and it was great.

Gardens and Fountains. This is a UNESCO World Heritage site for the numerous beautiful fountains that do no require any pumps due to natural water flow patterns. The sense of humor of the creator was evident in locations where unsuspecting tourists would trigger a fountain to begin spraying. Many steps, but some ramps as well for accessibility. Use restrooms inside park - those on the outside require payment and are poorly maintained. Great place for photos of groups and individuals.

Great Palace. This palace offers the perfect image of Czar life stile and it was a great life stile indeed. Each palace's room shows sumptuousness. Walls, ceilings, furnitures, paints, tapestries and ornaments are just overwhelming you with their preciousness, but a part this overwhelming feeling you cannot avoid to appreciate the beauty of what you are admiring and the ability of the creator of that piece of art.

Day Trip to Grand Palace. You can actually visit the Grand Palace and Catherine's Palace in Pushkin on the same day, but many people prefer to take these one at a time. We only had a day, so we did both. It was a lot of walking, and I was tired by the time I returned to the hotel, but it was worth the trip. Grand Palace grounds are stunning on the Baltic Sea. Many fountains, trees, including one supposedly planted by Peter the Great himself, statues, and flowers. We only toured the grounds because you need to purchase palace tickets well in advance. Catherine's Palace was built for daughter Elizabeth who built 5 palaces on this one spot before the 6th was to her liking. We toured the palace -- everything you'd expect to find is there. Beautiful state rooms, paintings, antiques, etc. The grounds are not all that interesting.

Unbelieveable Opulence. Although the origional palace was captured and destroyed by the Nazis, the Soviets rebuilt it back to its origional Opulence. The hundreds of fountains (no pumps, just gravity fed) with gold leafed figures are a sight to behold as is the immensity of the building. Once you experience the incredible life style of the nobility and consider that many of the peasants were surfs, it's easy to understand how communism came into being.
BEAUTIFUL. Its a beautiful place - quite breath taking and a great photo stop. I didnt quite expect the place to be as well maintained as it was. Everything about the place was just beautiful

The Tzars knew how to live over the top. This was an amazing property to visit. The interior was ultra lavish with lots of gold leaf and carved panels. When you think the top was over the top you exit to the fountains on the canal leading to the Bay. Brilliant gold statues shining even on the gloomy gray day we visited. Then we wandered through many more gardens blessing the property. We definitely could have spent more time here had our schedule allowed for it.
Tourist trap.... We visited just the Lower gardens, which were great, but each attraction needs additional tickets making visit to Petehof very expensive...

Guided tour. Impressive tranquil, interesting park and gardens, as well as individual cottages. Great collections fountains. Recommend arriving in time for the fountains to be turns on, together with playing of anthem.Well worth a visit
Wonderful visit . The gardens are stunning, and it is a wonderful place to visit. If you do not speak Russian you really need a guide or audio guide as there are no other signs whatsoever.

Amazing beauty and a pleasant garden.. We took a hydrofoil to Peterhof otherwise known Grand Palace. Always best to have your own guide. Easier to view all the rooms as they can get in before the groups and know how to miss the crowds. The day we went it was very crowded and one cannot spend time in each room as he attendants push you through to control all the groups. However our guide managed to show us areas crowds were not able to see. The pipes for the fountains the inside of the basement where the visitors arrived . And inside the actual fountain area.The splendour the palace was amazing and leaves a lasting impression.The grounds are beautiful. The forest area as the fountains in the garden are special, Peter the Tzar enjoyed having fun with his fountains. You sit on a bench and a fountain starts raining over you. Or you walk on a stone and another pours down on you. Fun for children and adults alike. There is a restaurant and food stalls etc so you can make a day of it. Well worth a visit

Peterhof is unbelievable!. The scope and beauty of the palace and grounds are truly amazing. The fountains and Peter's personal place by the water were highlights. Be sure to take the hydrofoil home to SP!

PETERHOF: VISIT FOR THE PARK AS WELL AS THE PALACE. Peterhof Palace and Park complex was built as a Summer home for the Russian Tsars on the Gulf of Finland to honour Peter the Great. The briliant features of the Park are its cascades, water jets and fountains and the most noteable fountain, the Samson Fountain, was to celebrate the Russian victory over the Swedes in 1709. Look for the Great Cascade, the Roman Fountain, The Dragon Fountain, the Lion Fountain, the Adam and Eve Fountains spaced apart for symmetry,and the Spring Fountain designed to look like the petals of a flower. Please also be aware that the Fountains are turned off in September. The Palace is the only one to not allow photographe inside and do expect large queues in high season of up to an hour. You will be impressed by the Chinese lobbies in the Great Palace as the Tsars would have expected you to be, but perhaps not by the behaviour of the hoards of chinese tourists!

See it to believe it!!. This magnificent palace called the Peterhof has to be seen to believed. The grounds and gardens are very well kept . Gardener were busy taking care to keep it immaculate. The gold fountains and waterfalls were spectacular, but to truly appreciate the Peterhof be sure that your tour includes a visit to the inside of the palace? You must check your coat and any large bags, you must wear paper slippers to cover your shoes. Best to visit as part of a tour or hire a guide. what you will see will have you amazed. There is gold everywhere. There are also new clean restrooms no charge. Do not miss the Peterhof!
A must see if in Russia. The Hermitage is one of the best museums in theworld. It has over three million works of art and historical items.
Don't miss!. Fountains, fountains, fountains! Get there early and spend the whole day! By hydrofoil is best. Russians call it "Petergof".

Visually stunning and historically interesting. I went there with a Marina S. Wilson private tourguide which was well worth it.If you don't fancy history, this place is still incredibly and visually stunning. Truly lovely to look at, parks, palace and interior of Peterhof. However, you are not permitted to take photos inside so they can make more money by selling photobooks in the gift shop. Which is disappointing if, like me, you love photography. (Outside in the park you can take photos and it's lovely and beautiful. But even on a nice sunny day it can be windy, so beware.)If you do fancy history, a tourguide is probably a good idea. We got a lot of background to Peter the Great, his daughter Elizabeth and Catharine the Great out of Sergej and lots of little jokes and stories and myths about the palace and everything inside and around it. I really loved this experience!

Gorgeous!. On a sunny day of the last week of August we visit this wonderful piece of architecture. We were lucky, the sunny days are very rare (only 60 days in one year). Every day, at 11am. the water coming far away through a mechanism with out pumps, gushing from Triton fountain and the fountains show begin. Everything is breathing of refinement and splendor!

Beautiful. The palace is beautiful inside and out. We arrived via the Peterhof express in time to see the fountains being turned on at 11am. The gold statues were gorgeous. We went inside the palace, the ball room dripping in gold was my favourite as well as the bedrooms and Peter the Great's study. The gardens were lovely too. There was free wifi. The admission was very cheap for students.

Absolutely breathtaking architecture.. Pitergof was a beautiful place. The sea was gorgeous and also all of the park. The golden fountains were just absolutely beautiful though.The radiating golds of this park are extremely mesmerising.I would recommend Pitergof to anybody.
Wow! Talk about opulence!. Great palace and great formal gardens with a fun collection of different fountains. Golden everything!

Impressive but you can get caught out. The palace is truly impressive from the outside but be aware that opening hours for individual visitors (those not on group yours) are severely restricted and it was totally closed the day of our visit. Check ahead! Also people arriving by boat are forced to pay 700 rubles upon arrival to enter the lower park AND you can't leave the lower park and get back to the boat without paying another 700 rubles! This is really bad. Perhaps there is away around this if you speak Russian--but we don't.

Breathtakingly Beautiful!!. This palace's front gardens and rear gardens/fountains are unbelievably gorgeous.Many have said it resembles Versailles in France. The rear fountains flow into a canal which flows into the sea which you can see from the upper tier of the back of the palace. This is a must see!
Nice. First of all make sure of the opening days and times othervise u just can enjoy the garden witch is beautifull by itself
Impressive. Grand Palace is a must when visiting Peterhof. The architecture is really nice and the palace is open through winter as well

mesmerising fountains and statues. We have been to Palace of Versailles recently, after which the Grand palace is said to be designed, but the fountains and statues are awe inspiring here. They are more majestic and better maintained. We had just enough time to see the gardens and fountains, but that itself is a must do, once you are in St Petersburg. The drive from the center of St Petersburg was smooth, no traffic by road, as we had feared. The place is not to be missed
September 2016. Nicely restored in the 20th century after utter devastation during WWII. It is worthwhile getting a good guide who may take you here and Catherine's Palace in the same day.

Interesting and beautiful. Go as early as possible as this place can get very crowded. Found the history that this place was used by the Germans during WWII very interesting. Much of the place got destroyed during the war and was rebuilt. Only 19% was saved. What an amazing restoration of both buildings and gardens!!!

Absolutely stunning! . We were lucky enough to be the first tour group of the day to visit the palace and it was an amazing experience. The opulence and the grandeur of the different rooms. We were there for the fountain ceremony @11am but you need to get in early to get a good spot. The gardens and the other fountains are just as beautiful. When Peter the Great built this after his visit to Versailles, he definitely achieved his goal to do better! I've been to many palaces and castles and this is definitely one worth visiting!

Just Okay. To be fair, I must admit that we made the mistake of going to the Hermitage on our first day in the area. We went to Peterhof Grand Palace on day three, and it fell completely flat. Sure, the gardens are beautiful, and if you understand that the fountains operate by gravity only, that is impressive. But the place just seems run-down and unmaintained. Use some of the huge tourist revenue to keep this place up! Fix what is broken! Touch up the paint! Make it more visitor-friendly! We were unimpressed. (Important tip - take Uber there. Definitely the least expensive way.)

A must visit on list of things to do.. We booked a 1/2 day tour through BA. It's about 50 mins from SP centre - and you pass some interesting places on the way.The palace is a wow when you see it and the amount of gold it has . When you go- don't take a big bag . There are restrictions. You have to wear covers on your shoes, all costs have to be handed in to cloakroom as with any bulky bags. You are not allowed to take any pictures or video inside the palace. Hide any water bottles or these will be taken from you. It s well worth the visit as guide gives you a great insight into what all the Rooms were used for.On a lighter note - I had to giggle when I saw the extravagant chandeliers as the only fools and horses sketch came to mind!!'From the palace you walk through the gardens.?Unfortunately between sept and may you won't see the fountains on as its end of seasonThere are various outbuildings I would have liked to have looked round but being on a tour did not get opportunity to do this. You also when booking he an option to return by hydrofoil - may be quicker than return by coach so worth thinking about. Out of season - take a cardigan or coat as your near the sea and is very windy. There are loads of statue fountains to see such as " Adam and Eve" and a surprise one where you go to walk round and you get a soaking.( they do warn you 1st) Toilets are limited - either go before or after the palace tour which takes about an hour. I am glad I went for the experience and the historical value. There is a souvenir shop on site.warning: outside in the gardens , especially in the more sought after photo places, pick pockets are rife .

Grand Palace Tour. Visited the Grand Palace on an SBP tour while in St Petersburg in July 2016. What a beautiful place, majestic gardens and gorgeous surroundings. The Palace is a magnificent building and abounds in history. Would recommend this place be on any touring itinerary.

Dream Vacation . I have waited 44 years to visit St. Petersburg Russia and the Grand Palace. It was worth the wait.Absolutely breathtaking and mind boggling at the same time.If you went before 2001 you should go again. They have done an astonishing job in bringing it to its former elegance.
The fountains are absolutely stunning. The fountains and grounds at Peterhof are absolutely stunning. You could spend a few hours just wandering around the gardens.
OMG. This summer palace needs to be visited to enjoy and appreciate the power of science during those days. Wonderful fountains all around. A whole day activity. simply splendid

Splendid place. Even though we were not allowed inside the palace, the gardens are an experience itself. The golden sculptures and fountains are magical. It is such an enchanting place. It is about 30 minutes from St Petesburg

Grand palace to visit. The palace and fountains are a must see. Make sure the timing for fountains is right (around 11 AM) and you may have to stand near the main fountain some 15 minutes early to get a good view.

Peter the Great palace. More housing than ever possible by anyone today. For me main reason for visit has to be the extensive gardens with unbelievable fountains. There are even trick fountains that are delightful to the kid in us if you don't mind getting wet. Must allow several hours for visit as it is hour drive from St Petersburg center.

Better than the pictures.. Even though you might have seen pics, this is even better. The gardens are huge, but there is a multi people gold cart is you can't walk that far. I caught the hydrofoil there from the back of the Hermitage. 1300R return. You have to nominate your return time. Entry was 700R. There were a lot of other options to pay, but it was not in English and they did not speak English, so I just went with the entry, which I was glad because the queues to the building was massive.If in front of the palace facing the fountain, I found the right side more interesting, some fun things for kids and the chess board fountain. Be prepared to walk a lot.
Simply stunning. A must for anyone visiting Saint-Petersburg! Gorgeous place full of history. Take a boat from the pier outside of the Hermitage and enjoy your day!

Make the trip. Located a little outside of St Petersburg, it is certainly worth the trip. We arrived by hydrofoil boat. Everything is so grand from the entrance on through the gardens. One beautiful site after another

Fascinating place!. I visited here with relatives and friends recently. We loved the hydrofoil ride to/from the palace and we loved the gardens. The drawback to our visit was that it was a rainy day, which was unfortunate, so we got very wet while touring the magnificent gardens - but on a sunny day it must be even more breathtaking. We decided not to go inside the palace, as this was an additional ticket/cost and the queues were very long. However it's worth a visit just to see the fountains and gardens and the building from the exterior!
Spectacular. Beautiful gardens and many beautiful fountains. A lovely walk on a sunny day, perfect for all the family.
visist to Grand Palace. It is to the South of St Petersburg and takes time to get there. Another amazing palace and the waterfalls are incredible engineering.

Don't miss it!. You need some time to visit this place. You can do it independently by tacking a boat from St. Petersburg (close to the Hermitage). It takes about 40 minutes one way, so plan accordingly. Once you arrive there you have to buy a entry ticket to get into the gardens (Bath) and a separate one to get into the Palace. It is beautiful inside but not as much as the Hermitage (Don't miss it!). The visit inside should not take too long, but during the summer the lines are long to buy the tickets, and they close at certain times, so, try to go straight, see inside and then spend a good amount of time in the gardens, it is gorgeous!
WOW. This is a garden walk that is unimaginable. Over 100, gravity flow fountains surrounded by beautiful gardens. And the Hydrofoil ride over is really fun too.

Mind. Blown. This place is amazing! I'd avoid it from June - end August though, unless you like someone's selfie stick shoved in your face! Hopefully they'll ban those there soon.It's pretty crowded when I went in early September but it apparently is worse in June and July.The gardens are beautiful and well maintained and the gold statues down the terraces are out of this world.

Beautiful!! Incredible palace. So beautiful and ornate. The interiors were fabulous as were the beautiful gardens. By the water. We came by bus, but others came by boat. So beautifully kept ups. A true gem in this beautiful city.
Water castle for fresh summer. Water castle to be dresh during summer. With a forest and beach view. Can do fishing or just take a walk in the garden. Worth to go and pay the biat to cross

Amazing palace and incomparable gardens. A very richly decorated grand palace depicting the luxurious and opulent lifestyle of the Russian dynasties. The enormous garden with all the sculptures and fountains was even more impressive. Leave enough time to walk around the garden and appreciate the sheer scale and visual impact of the palace.

WOW. We took the hydrofoil from behind the winter palace which docks at the beginning of the walkway which leads up to the fountains. As you walk up, the view becomes more and more magnificent. The fountains are just beautiful as are the grounds of Peterhoff. We did not go into the palace.
must see. If you are in Peter and do not visit - you have lost a lot of fun. I'd recommend taking a water "rocket" to get here, as its more fun that way. Plan to spend a full day here.

Fabulous early access group tour. Our Cruise line organised an early access group tour which meant we were among the first into the Palace which avoided the worst of the crowds and is well worth seeing. It also gave us time to view the gardens before the main event as the fountains gradually come to life through gravity feed reaching the central fountain at 11 am by which time it was very crowded although the crowds eased after half an hour to get better photographs. We were there for just over 3 hours which gave time to tour the Palace, walk the grounds and get some less crowded photos of the fountains and their gold leaved statues.

Amazing place. This is also a must see in St. Petersburg. What a beautiful place to see. The gardens and the vast amount of fountains was just spectacular. It was cool the day we visited, but really enjoyed the sites.

Spectacular. The lower garden and gravity-fed fountains (apparently designed by Peter the Great) are absolutely beautiful. The interior is also worth seeing and historically very interesting but it is busy and you have to wear overshoes that make the wooden floors a bit of a skating rink. The place is an absolute must see when you are in St. Petersburg.
Part of 2 day TJtravel tour. Very interesting but large crowds in a big place. Must see when they turn on the fountains at the beginning of the day
Amazing, but way too crowded. This is a must see place on a visit to St Petersburg, but it is way too crowded, and the food offerings are a bit mediocre.

Peterhof Palace is worth the visit. We took a tour by a local tour guide, Best Guides, they can get you in early before opening time which gets you ahead of the crowd and that is nice. We chose to go and return to the central city by Hydrofoil, approx. 30 mins. each way vs. 1 hr drive with limo. We were pressed for time and cut our tour of the gardens short. The palace shop was nice with plenty of Amber jewelry.The fountains out front of the palace are spectacular.

Beautiful palace. The palace itself was a dream. The tour was pretty long, so it's definitely worth it. The lower park and all the different fountains were also very beautiful. The only negative thing I can mention is that it's really not worth it to pay all the other entrance fees to see the different museums, they were pretty small most of the time, and definitely overpriced. A one day ticket would be way more comfortable but I guess they prefer to get as much money as possible from tourists.

Beautiful daytrip, not when raining!. Dont go when its raining! the gardens and fountains are the main attractions.We took the hydrofoil boat, a 30min ride to the Finnish gulf at great speed, tickets and departure at the waterfront behind Hermitage. Great alternative to a complicated public transport ride.You first buy a ticket for the lower gardens, it is enormous. I regret not taking one of the trainlike carts that take you around, we walked around for a few hours but saw only a small portion of what the grounds have to offer as it turned out. the train would have allowed me to see so much more especially as it was the end of my vacation and my tired self wasnt moving so fast anymore. We did go inside the palace as well, you pay a seperate entrance fee. it was worth it in my opinion. Really grandiose, the whole thing was built to outdo Versailles. Accomplished.

Very impressive and worth the visit. This is a beautiful and very impressive palace set in splendid grounds full of fountains and worth a visit in their own right. The interiors are well appointed and there is a lot of history to the decor; however, you need a guide (in fact I think you have to have one), as there is no information to read and certainly nothing in english. We did find that the rather severe russian women positioned in every room tried to move us on too quickly, as they try to keep the flow of visitors moving smoothly. There were an awful lot of people shuffling through in a very regimented way and I would suggest you try to join the smallest group possible to avoid feeling like you have been processed through a sausage machine!

What a beautiful place to visit.. There is a beautiful long walk in up by a long pond with all the gold glittering from the fountains from a long distance. All the water falls by gravity (no pumps) from a source over 30Km away. There is gold everywhere and trick fountains to wet an unsuspecting tourist. We spend half a day outside in the gardens and did not get time to go inside

Fountains galore! great gardens. A wonderful tour of an amazing garden and all the gravity run fountains. The gardens are extensive and the winter palace looks amazing. We went up the river with in a hydrofoil and spent the morning her with a TJ Tour.
Grand Palace, Peterhof. Such a magnificent building surrounded by these wonderful gardens and fountains. Speechless at the amount of gold.

Lovely!. A beautiful garden, fountains, & gorgeous palace; these are the things that you can see them here. I really had a nice time & enjoyed it very much. The garden is designed in a very beautiful way.

INCREDIBLE !!. I've stood at the gates and looked at Buckingham Palace in London and thought that it was a magnificent building. This place makes Buckingham Palace look like a small country house!The incredible interiors are well worth visiting, even if it is very busy and you get hustled from one room to the next quicker than you would like.The fountains are all gravity fed and are unbelievable with their amazing decoration.Don't miss this and be prepared to spend a day here. If you are spending a few days in St Petersburg, I'd suggest going on a sunny day to get the full impact of the gardens.

Impressive. It is an impressive palace with its fountain park and magnificent building. Went there by a boat and on our return we took 'marshrutka'. If you are going with kids, do not miss 'Shutiha' fountain.
Not may places I'm left speechless. This is..... Utterly beautiful Palace with gardens. I've never seen anything like this in my life. Worthy of a day trip from St Petersburg.

Can Do on Your Own, Take the Hydrofoil. Peterhof Grand Palace is a huge complex of stunning palaces and gardens in the suburb of St. Petersburg 50 km west of St. Petersburg accessible by hydrofoil speed boat, train and bus. It used to be the summer palace of Peter the Great, a Russian Tsar and Emperor (1672 - 1725) known for his massive reforms. Changes continued throughout the 18th - 19th centuries by the following emperors including major restorations done after the second world war which caused massive damages.We can easily spend the whole day in this "Russian Versailles" exploring the different buildings, gardens and admiring its 147 shiny fountains supplied by natural springs, a technology state of the art. Claim the best spot if you want to see the turning on of the fountains at 11 am (summer only; shut off during winter).Be prepared for a long walk, put on comfortable shoes and protective clothing against the summer sun. Since it's such a popular place, arriving early is advisable (and still expect long lines). Pack you lunch and have a picnic here or eat at Shtandard restaurant in the park with reasonably priced food (separate reviews).Taking the hydrofoil (meteor speedboat) was not only fast (30 minutes) but an experience in itself. You can buy tickets and board at the pier in front of Admiralty building (Admiralteyskaya) or the jetty of Hermitage museum which are close to each other. The boats leave every half an hour. Combined tickets were available (boat + entry to palace/garden) to minimize queuing in Peterhof.Lastly, if you go on your own (no guide), read the history and background stories of the different buildings and have a map so you can appreciate things better and make the best use of your time. Please note that all buildings are open and all fountains work only during summer, May to October (visited in June a few years back).

The 18 kt gold leaf was overwhelming so don't miss going inside. It really does take your breath away as you walk through more than 30 rooms that have been restored inside the palace. The 18 kt gold leaf moldings, statues, chairs, etc... are overwhelming. Equally impressive are the hand laid wooden floors, each room a different pattern. Unfortunately photo's are not allowed to be taken inside :(.Most people just see the gardens but you miss so much if you don't pay to go inside. The garden's are beautiful but the palace is opulent.

magnificent. Shame It was raining when we visited but the place is beautiful. Packed with people i bet this place is packed all year round. couldnt visit any other time because I was with a tour group.

Amazing. The garden fountains are incredible. The grounds are vast and well maintained. An absolute wonder. My wife and I wandered around the gardens and lost ourselves. We wish we would have had more time to enjoy - but we were on a day trip from our cruise ship so time was previous. An absolute must see,

Just beautiful. Be sure not to miss this spot while you travel! Breathtaking gold inlays on EVERYTHING! Great history on Alexander the First and his wife, company. Also, be sure to get a good spot outside at 11am for the fountain show. Very beautiful!

Beautiful grounds at Peterhof Palace. We visited as part of SPB Tour of St Petersburg, the grounds are beautiful, bright gold statues everywhere, trick fountains, lovely gardens and waterfalls, so many lovely things to see, and the 11am musical display of the fountains is a must - very unusual and beautiful. The fact that it was a sunny day made our photos all the more stunning. Definitely worth a stop here, we didn't go inside, just the gardens which you could spend hours in.

Long lines, but worth the wait. Getting is was really tiresome, first you have to wait in ticket line. Then in line to get in, then to give overcoat and then it had at least 3 or 4 ticket checks, plus the actual entrance machine.
But oh boy, was it all worth it. Definitely would go through the troubles to visit it again.

Amazing palace but very, very busy & watch out for pickpockets!. Had a great morning out (arranged vis Celebrity Cruises), the palace is an amazing sight and beautiful inside (though we were not allowed to take photos) and the fountains were fabulous.Do beware of the pickpockets though, as mentioned by our tour guide they are rife and we saw one in operation during our visit.A great place to see which I would definitely recommend, however please be advised it was very busy, they rush parties through pretty quickly and if you want to see the fountains there's a fair bit of walking if you have elderly people or children in your group. It's definitely worth seeing if you're in the area though.

Day to remember. What a place, wonderful place to visit as a must see in the citySt peter has a lot to give, and this is only one,,,, check all the other place, spend the time and enjoy the view,,,St peter is part of heaven,,,, u need at least 7 days if ur in a hurry.Enjoy it, love it, and embrace

Russian Opulence & Gilt Glory. If you love Versailles, then you'll be right at home at Peterhof. Think gold. Think lavish. Think lux. Think over the top. The site draws crowds, so worth working with a private guide to get an early morning visit before the palace opens to the public. No elevator...so be prepared for stairs and to slip booties on over your shoes to preserve the floors. Ensure you save time for the fountains, which are really the star.

Must see in Saint Petersburg. Grand Palace was a summer residence for all Russian tsars starting from the first part of 18th century. It is a remarkable masterpiece for Barocco architecture and located in Peterhoff (Petrograd), one of the main districts of Saint Peterburg. It will take 40-60 minutes to get here by bus or speed boat. If yo plan to visit the Grand Palace together with fontains, palaces and parks it will take you at least 5-6 hours and better choose the Sunny Day from May to September for your visit, as it's the most beautiful time to visit the Palace.

A little far off but very interesting place. The drive seemed pretty long but once we reached there we realised it was worth the effort and time. It is actually very grand and you get a close look at how the kings lived and the luxurious lifestyle they had

Absolutely Stunning!!!!:-):-):-). I do not know how to articulate the absolute awe I felt as I explored the Grand Palace Peterhof & gardens approx 40 minute coach journey outside St Petersburg. The warm sunny morning of my visit showed this magnificent tourist attraction in all its splendour:-):-)The queues are very long & its very crowded from early but it moves pretty quickly.The fountains are unlike anything I've ever seen & as you walk through the gardens you reach the summer residence which overlooks the Gulf of Finland truly breath taking!!!! As a suggestion take the hydro foil back into St Petersburg. I didn't so I'm unsure whether you can arrive at the pier or if you need to prebook it in advance. In any case if ur short on time in this magnificent city definitely put the Grand Palace on your list.The opulence will render you speechless:-):-):-)
Stunning backyard. They have foundation show at about eleven something, and like millions of people come to admire the fountain.

Crowded, But For Very Good Reason. It's pretty telling that what is really one attraction has been divided into three (the palace, fountains, and grounds) on this site, and yet they are #1, 2, and 3 in the rankings. This palace is not as well known in the west, but it's one of the very best in all of Europe and likely the world.Peter the Great, who built Peterhof, visited Versailles before becoming tsar and was so taken that he hired the same architect and largely asked him to improve upon the original. He was helped in that endeavor by the fact that St. Petersburg was basically built on a swamp and there are ample springs and rivers to supply the many, many fountains, a luxury Versailles did not and does not have.Peterhof is not as well known outside Russia as should be in part because was in the Soviet Union, but also because the Nazis dynamited the central structure during their retreat from Leningrad. It has, however, been wonderfully restored to its original brilliance.Peterhof is magnificent. The exterior is gorgeous. In the interior you go from one impossibly ornate room gleaming with gold to another. Every detail is beautiful, from the floors, to walls and ceilings, to furniture, to decorative items. The nearest rival is the Versailles, but both are almost overwhelming in their grandeur.One note: They don't allow photography inside the palace (outside is fine) and they'll ask you to leave your backpacks in a locker.As you exit the palace, you come upon the extensive fountains. These likely have no equal anywhere. The water cascades down steps lined with gilded statues of mythological figures into a large pond down to the Gulf of Finland.From there you go to the extensive gardens, themselves filled with fine views, a variety of fountains, and various decorative structures. One fun area has fountains that were once secretly manned to turn on to surprise visitors. These now are filled with excited children and even the adults had fun as well.This attraction has few peers.The downside of all this is that it is a major attraction for tourists and locals and can get very crowded. We really don't like the crowds but, truthfully, this is one attraction that is likely worth the occasional wait and having to put up with them. In any case, as you leave the palace the gardens are so large that they are very much dissipated.Our recommendation: Come here, recognizing that you won't be alone. Make sure it's a nice day, though, so you can get the most out of your enjoyment of the fountains and grounds.

Stunning even in the rain!. We took the hydrofoil and arrived in the rain but even so the first sight of this palace is beautiful. The gardens are magnificent and you need to leave time to explore them. We didn't get in to see the palace as the queues were huge. Probably better to arrange tickets before hand through your hotel. There is a beautiful cafe in The Orangerie which serves lovely food and reviving coffee. Take a "golf buggy" ride round the gardens if you are flagging. The commentary is in Russian however. And then the rain stopped and WOW...the onion domes sparkled in the sunshine. Oh and there is the secret garden where hapless tourists get soaked with water jets...have fun!

Russian beauty. We were fortunate to be able to enjoy the park area and fountains until it started pouring rain! Then we went inside to see all the splendors of the palace. A must-see in St. Petersburg.

Gold, gold and more gold. We visited as part of a 3 day tour with SPB Tours having arrived in St Petersburg on a cruise. We were allocated a time slot and after a pleasant drive to the grand Palace arrived mid morning. It was a freezing cold day and raining so queuing to get into the building was not enjoyable. All those queuing behind also wanted to be inside, so there was a lot of pushing and shoving the closer we got to the entrance. Wearing rain gear we were told it would have to be taken to the cloakrooms where it was also very crowded. We had an enjoyable tour around the palace but because of the crowds, we were constantly being told to move along before our guide had time to tell us about the particular room we were viewing (This happened at every venue we visited so became the norm). After our allotted time inside we were taken out into the gardens which are quite something with all the statues in the fountain/waterfall being gold. We had a little time to wait as the fountain is only switched on late morning, We walked around the extensive gardens and saw many unique and very unusual/interesting water follies. There is a train available to take you around if walking is a difficulty. We walked down to the shoreline with the norweigan sea, and could view St Petersburg across the bay. When the time came for the fountain to be switched on, the world and his wife were there taking advantage of any photo opportunity. It was a very interesting place to visit but what spoiled it for me were the crowds of people and the freezing cold weather. It was Russia Day so there were a lot of individual Russian families taking the opportunity to visit and possibly the passengers from the other 6 cruise ships docked that day. Maybe on a warmer day I would have enjoyed it more. It is definitely a must place to visit.

The Russian Versailles. Out of words. This summer residence for three Russian Kings and Queens will amaze anyone. Nice interiors and outstanding gardens and fountains. Pictures are not allowed inside the palace, you'll need to wear fabric shoe covers which are given inside. Worth to be in the garden's main fountain at 12pm to see the fountains start and listen the Russian hymn.

Gardens are amazing. Go for a stroll in the gardens of Peterhof. to get there u need to either take the fast boat (Meteor) or the buss. The gardens are beautiful the fountains are amazing. They have the biggest system of fountains that work without pumps.

Never seen anything like it. This seems to be the place that people remember about St Petersburg. Though the palace was closed on the day we arrived, the gardens were full of visitors from all over the world. Aside from the very impressive fountains, the grounds offer a beautiful, green walk and a sea view from the pier. The service at the neighbouring restaurant (outside of the grounds) is very slow, so we didn't bother waiting. Instead, we opted for Russian pancakes at one of the stands.

Stunning palace and huge gardens. The palace was very beautiful inside. They have a good system in place for the volume of tourist's that visit. I wish I had more time to explore the gardens. A lot of beautiful sights to see!
Must be seen to be believed. The gardens and water fountains are amazing, but just like the Hermitage the crowds make it very difficult to enjoy the palace itself.

Just another palace. If you're coming from the USA or America, it may be worth a visit. On a sunny day, its gardens are definitely a perfect way to spend a couple hours, everything is so green! However, the palace as such may not be worth a visit if you are in a rush. It is really crowded, badly organized, and access is only granted with a guide and to the second floor.

A visit to remember forever. This outstanding palace is a must to visit for all tourists and is a part of the national heritage of Russia. Do not get annoyed by the waiting times, your patience will be rewarded, this place is unique in the world!

Beautiful Park, Fountians and stunning architecture. We arrived here via the Hydrofoil which is by far the fastest way to get to the grand palace. It was certainly worth the journey. The gardens are beautiful and the fountains spectacular. THis is a MUST for your St. Petersburg visit
Stunning. You need to be there at 11am for the starting of fountains, the gardens are magnificent. Just a stunning place.

Beautiful palace beware of the queue. As everywhere in Russia the q's are long and boring but if you are with a couple of friends then you can switch and take advantage of the waiting time to visit the Palace gardens. We did not have a very nice experience with the museum in the sense that after waiting to buy the tickets for more than one hour, we payed foreign tourist prices but when we were about to start the inside tour we were told that there were no more audio-guides in English and that we could not enter if we were not part of a bigger tour. So they just kept us waiting in the anti-chamber without any explanation or place for diplomacy. In the end they gave to my friend who understood Russian one audio-guide in Russian and they told her to translate for us.

A tour with military precision. We visited this magnificent building as part of a pre arranged tour. Thank goodness for that as the queues for those who had not were very long. As it was we still had to wait to access the building but having done so were well pleased with the visit. There are no photographs allowed in the building and the tour groups are moved on by the staff in every room who use timing devices to ensure no one lags. As expected the opulence of the tsars was on show.
Totally deserves!! . I'm only gonna say that this was the most amazing thing I've seen in the whole month I've spent in Russia!

Plan Ahead to fit it all in. Leaving about 9 am from downtown StPetes by minibus (we took K404 from Baltiskaya stn but there are several options) is best way to go. Trip is about 45 mins, only a few mins more than the hydrofoil, but you enter at the top of the grounds and get to enjoy the upper gardens and fountains (free) before approaching the palace and buying ticket to Lower Gardens if you wish to catch the "Grand Cascade" fountain startup at 11 (when we visited this simply amounted to turning on the fountains to a short piece of music -don't know if that is what the grand cascade normally amounts to but don't feel desperate to get there by 11 am for that if it is and if you are coming in high season, as everyone rushes to the palace thereafter). We bought our palace tickets around 1030 am when there was no lineup - they can be used at any time during the day. There was no "1030 to noon" or "230 to 4" time restrictions for individual tourists as I have read elsewhere on tripadvisor, the tickets were usable all day. We then spent the afternoon in the lower gardens - there are multiple satellite museums that can be visited. The trick fountains are a joy to watch. Easy to imagine Tsar Peter offering his guests a seat in a gazebo or on a bench only to see their finery drenched. Today kids giggle prancing thru them. MY ONLY BLACK MARK AND WHY THIS IS 4 STAR VS. 5 RATING -- GET RID OF THE BIRD INCARCERATION!! Its so 19th century. The tragic screeching and squawking of our feathered friends doomed to grip tiny bars in barren one foot square cages in the "aviaries", as they stare out at the sky that they should be flying across, is sickening. Zoos are over, guys. If you must insist on having tourists see a couple parrots in a cage, kill and stuff two or three of them and that's good enough -- don't doom live birds to a lifetime of torture! Tourists, please don't buy an aviary ticket. There are more than enough other highlights of this Palace to see anyway. We enjoyed the "Special Treasury" (crown jewels/other objets), for example - small but impressive exhibit.
Rates a "10" on the Wow Factor!. Sure, electricity has enlarged the fountains and gold-coloured paint has enhanced the human figurines, but the overall effect is still mind boggling! What a site!

Breathtaking!. The summer residence of Peterhof was amazing. It's hard to imagine that someone actually lived like this. The fountains and gold statues were beautiful! Be careful as our guide said that Peterhof was a bit of a prankster. There are a few sculptures that are more than what they seem. I got wet a few times while taking a picture. It was fun though. Go all the way to the top and you get an amazing shot of the entire grounds!

Fountains and Grandeur. Took the Hydrofoil from St Petersburg and on arrival purchased tickets into the Lower Gardens. As we did the trip on our own and had booked one of the latest Hydrofoils back we had about 6 hours, so decided to go and get our tickets to enter the Grand Palace. Had to queue for about 25 minutes and were able to enter straight away. The interior of the Palace is amazing, room after room of gold and chandeliers breathtaking. Most people were with tour groups but we were able to linger a little longer. No photographs allowed inside. the visit lasted about 45 minutes. we then went in search of food and found the cafe and restaurant which was very good. The rest of the afternoon was spent discovering fountain after fountain after fountain in beautiful garden settings and I know we didnt find them all !!!!! Glad we could spend the whole day there.
