There are plenty of refreshment stalls around to buy ice creams, drinks and snacks. Top Tip try and have the correct change, to pay at the stalls. Souvenirs can be bought in the Grand Palace shop, and on stalls outside, we didn't go into any of the other 'museums' around the park but there is plenty to see and do.

Fountains. Very nice visit, make sure you are there at 1100 and outside when they turn on the fountains it is really worth it. Inside the palace is ok a lot of reproductions but the outside and park are very nice, does get crowded around the time of the fountains being turned on.

Felt very rushed!!. We decided to do a cruise ship tour here as we had an extra day in St. Petersburg. It looked a very impressive building but it was reconstructed after WW2. We got in there quite early but it got crowded very quickly. We were rushed through and all the palace attendants tell you to move on if you stop for more than a moment!! Even our tour guide was told off for taking too long in a room. So I didn't feel I got good value for money at all so was a bit disappointed. You can't take photos inside but you can in the gardens. But when we got there it had started to rain so we didn't stay very long.
Gardens not to miss!. Very crowded when the main fountains start up, but otherwise a very beautiful place not to miss. The interior is beautiful as well but you are unable to take pictures.

Bling and then some. Beautiful palace to enjoy and just admire and reflect on how the Russian Royals lived. The tour through is well directed but will be busy and you will be required to wear some paper overshoes in an unattractive shade of brown!! If you have a larger bag or coat you will be required to check this in and this can be quite a busy and chaotic experience as when retrieving you will be in the mix with those checking stuff in. Having negotiated the Palace we then moved through to the gardens and waited on the terrace for the fountains to commence their display which starts at 11am and is accompanied with music. The gardens themselves are extensive and a great area to walk around and to also escape the crowds of the palace and fountain areas and were modelled on Versailles. Stunning place to visit and enjoy some splendour.

Tourist trap. After having visited many nice places in Moscow and Saint Petersbourg, the only thing that really impressed us in Peterhof palace is the crowd. This place is organised to park tourists arriving at the rate of one full foiler boat every 15 minutes and sell overpriced ice creams. Not worth the trip.

Impressive - but can be crowded . Spent a few hours here - impressive both inside the palace and out (the fountains). The lines can be long - and the number of people creates bottlenecks at times within the palace, more so than other attractions in the area. Our group arrived before opening thankfully ; later groups spent significant a amounts of time outside waiting to enter. The groups are staggered by a few minutes thus there is not a great deal of time spent in each room. Hydrofoil transportation was available from the grounds back to downtown St Petersburg - transit time about 25 mins.
Stunning. Not to be missed- Peter the Great wanted to surpass Versailles , and he succeeded- the fountains and statues in such a wonderful setting are quite amazing

Impressive, but photography not allowed inside. Every morning the fountains start at the same time, which means if you arrive by hydrofoil (you can also drive there) you can see the fountains being set off at just the right time.The queue to go inside can get quite long and any bags will have to be stored before you can go around. Like most buildings in the area, this one was reconstructed after it was destroyed by the Nazis, and you have to wear covers over your shoes to protect the floors.Outside you can take as many photos as you want and there is plenty to photograph around the gardens, inside the palace however it is forbidden.

Beautiful, but be prepared to be rushed through. Stunning palace and gardens. We were part of a tour and arrived early. We visited inside the palace first. It was overcrowded and you are rushed through and have no time to enjoy the beautiful rooms or read any of the information. The palace attendants wave their fans at you if you stop too long and push you along. This was my first introduction to Russia and I wasn't impressed! We were outside by 1050, just in time to wait for the fountains to be turned on. This was stunning. We then explored the gardens which were lovely. The gardens are beautiful but the palace was not worth it.

Some old Russian habits never die. Some old Russian habits never die. Like queues. If you arrive by boat you line up for the entrance for the lower gardens (700 roebel), if you visit the upper gardens, but need to reenter the lower gardens as your boat is leaving at the bottom, you line up once again and pay once more. Visiting the Palace is another queue, on a sunny day like ours of about an hour. The question "any chance for a combined ticket?" is answered by another old Russian habitual NJET. The fountains are nice though. If you can stand the bureaucratie and the feel of a rip off.

Summer palace. Peterhof is about 70 K. M. outside Moscow and was summer palace of the Czars. The fountains are attractive and well maintained. The interiors are impressive but there are separate ticket queues for each part.
Amazing Fountains and Gorgeous park !. Amazing Fountains and Gorgeous park ! This is most beautiful set of fountains that I know in the Europe !

Ubered from Hermitage to peterhof. Uber fare - 1,000 rubles one wayDuration - 45 minsUber was a great way to get to peterhof - easy, short and safe. Restrooms are a bit difficult to find and they are a bit far apart from each other (if u are in a hurry).Make sure to check uber periodically to see the availability of cars for the return back to spb. City around peterhof does not have too many uber drivers.

Stunning. To describe the Palace as beautiful is such an understatement. Our group had a cloudy and then rainy day, but it did not matter. We walked among the beautiful gardens and fountains and the brilliant architecture was captivating.

Amazing Fountains and Gardens. The fountains and gardens are just jaw-droppingly beautiful. The ceremony for starting the fountains at 11 a.m. each day is worth the wait. Did not go into the palace, but the outside alone is worth the trip.

Peterhof review. Very nice place to visit, definitely you need to visit early in the morning to have the time to enjoy all gardens area. best boat trip from Sankt Petersburg ( the boats can be rented from the Hermitage area) .. very nice place to see.Tip: pack some sandwiches, water and juices. from my perspective the food served on the restos from the island is not wow! and an umbrella as in Russia the weather is tricky !

Fun. Took a boat trip over to Peterhof (about 30 minutes). Didn't know what to expect. When you get there you then need to buy a ticket to enter the grounds where you will be greeted by a majestic building and fountains. To go into the palace requires another ticket. We just strolled the grounds and had great fun admiring the gardens and fountains and playing in some of them. It was like being a kid again. Prepare to get wet if you want the full experience.

Beautiful Garden. We were following an excursion tour from cruise, and stayed there for about 2 hours. About 1 hr inside and 1 hr outside. I m sure the garden outside with all the fountains is the highlight of the Palace.

Amazing Fountains. I had seen photos of the fountains here before but looking at the real thing on the ground is still a shock - this must be the most beautiful set of fountains on Earth. Worth going. Just go.

The gardens aand all the buildings are amazing.. We took one of the local mini buses to the Grand Palace. It was about 1 euro for both of us to get there. We strolled through the upper garden and enjoyed the fountains and the garden but our jaws drooped after we walked through the gates into the lower garden. To say it is beautiful is an under statement. There are statues and gold to be seen everywhere you turn. We spent about 4 hours walking through the garden before taking the hydrofoil back to St Petersburg from the lower end of the garden.

Nice church. Very nice cathedral - interior is amazing despite the hordes of impolite and irritating Chinese tour groups. The artwork and architecture is fantastic. If you want to go up top for a look - definitely worth it but be prepared to be annoyed by the crowds - it's kind of cramped up there and everyone wants to stop for a photo so you get stuck in those photo traffic jams. View is not so interesting either in my opinion. But you won't believe this or know this until you've paid the 150 roubles and climbed the 250 steps yourself.

Amazing! Breathtaking.. It is definitely the Versilles of Russia. Opulent and the gardens are breathtaking. Picture moments everywhere. This is a must see. Try to book with Guide Guru (Anna). If possible.
Peterhof. The Palace and grounds are awesome. Hard to believe how people lived back when it was built. Another very crowded place.
Sensational palace. The grounds on Peterhof are beautifully laid out and manicured. The architecture and opulence is something to behold

Highlight of St Petersburg. This was by far our favourite stop in St Petersburg. The palace itself is gorgeous and beautifully kept. The gardens are huge; so allocate enough time for this visit. Cameras are, unfortunately, not allowed inside the palace, but the gardens make for some great pictures.

Overwhelming. We visited with TJ Travel via a thirty minute hydrofoil ride from St Petersburg.We were very lucky in that the weather was beautiful and this was the icing on the cake.The place is so vast and stunning that it is almost too much.The fountains, the parks the buildings are all fantastic. We did not go inside the palace as the crowds were vast but the trip with its history was a special experience.Try the cobbled stones and see if they get you. My wife suggested that I Volunteer and I got wet!Watch out for pick pockets.Clean and free toilets.Highly recommended.

Illustrious & Grand. Try to get there a little early to beat the crowds and before the fountains go on so you may see the grounds and then the fountains start up. We took a guided tour and the people working there keep the guest moving and behaving........
WOW! for these fountains. This is worth a visit for the fountains alone. They are many and varied and beautiful. We loved visiting Peter the Great's small palace along the Gulf of Finland as well.

Good to take a walk around but not worth buying a ticket and going in. The place is nice to take a walk if it isn't drizzling. But based on some feedback we got, didn't find it worth going inside and checking different rooms with artefacts. Short walk from Isaac cathedral so worth seeing it. Also close to the river.

Gardens spectacular. We visited as part of a guided tour and only visited the gardens. We travelled out by coach which let us see the country holiday homes of the locals, but back on the hydrofoil which was cool. The palace, fountains and gardens are beautiful.
A happy day. Very beautiful gardens and impressive palace. Take the metro and then the bus. The boat arrives further away to the palace than the bus and is much more expensive.

Tick list experience. Well worth a visit just to see how the tiny minority lived in Russia while everyone else starved but I guess it did provide a lot of employment. The house is extensive but it is the magnificent gardens that are well worth a stroll through trees, to the beach, past many a golden fountain and golden statue. More than a bit touristy but not tacky, lots to see and great fun. Some basic food available. Spend about half a day here, possibly take a picnic. Fantastic views and great for photos.
Come here!!!. This is a real one off. Don't be put off by the boat ride. The fountains take your breath away! Come for the day bring a picnic and enjoy
Sooooooo Beautiful!!!!!!!!!. The Palace is absolutely beautiful and the gardens are breathtaking!!! I'm glad we took the time to go see it. Probably my very favorite place on our trip to Russia!

Absolutely stunning.... Peterhof Grand Palace is so grand and is a special place to be. It's been so well preserved inside and is ridiculously extravagant! So much gold around with so much character! The artefacts still in the palace are stunning. Our guide was so helpful...otherwise, we wouldn't have known what we were looking at or the significance! The morning is the best time to go IMO as it is less busy, especially outside in the gardens. There is a ceremony at 11am each day during the summer where the fountains are turned on! This is a spectacle and makes this place even more special...

Don't bother going in the palace. The grounds are lovely, but as a non Russian speaker trying to figure out how to get into the palace was an effort. There was a small queue with a lady letting people in at her discretion (or so it seemed), to the ticket office which is inside the palace entrance (nothing tells you this in English). Trying to then walk round the palace was a chore, there is one lane around and a million tour groups to squeeze past, I have no idea why they don't open the rooms up a bit more for people to move around (like the Hermitage). Not a hugely enjoyable experience.

Grandeur at it's best. Visiting the Summer Palace was a treat. It reminded me very much of my visit to Versailles many years ago. It's amazing how much restoration was put into this palace after it was significantly damaged during WW II. Many people only visit the gardens, but we were able to also see the interior of the Palace. If you can, do visit the interior it is well worth the wait. There has been a lot of care put into retaining the magnificence of the numerous rooms. We had to wear shoe covers to protect the floors. I have been in several palaces over the years, but have never seen the intricate inlaid floors like I have seen in Russia. I know it's easy to look up, but make a point to also look down, you won't be disappointed.

Stunning Architecture. I came here on a horribly rainy and windy day. The lines were long to get inside, and for good reason. Everything was just beautiful. Be aware that you have to purchase a ticket to enter the garden outside, then purchase a second ticket to enter the building. Every room on the inside was so exquisitely designed. True royalty. You could tour the building in a group or on your own, and I chose to enter on my own. You can peruse the rooms at your own speed. The outside was equally beautiful, with the fountains and the layering of the grounds. Being so close to the river was nice too.

Peter the Great masterpiece. Peterhof Grand Palace is the most popular attraction and best palace in St. Petersburg. The idea of Czar Peter to built is outstanding even though at the end he prefered to stay more of the time at the other smaller palace at the same complex in Peterhof. This palace rivals only to chateau of Versailles in Paris. Gardens are also the other attractions you can spends hours to enjoy in Peterhof.

Nice to walk and do a picnic. I went by hydrofoil and only visit the lower garden and the fountains. I would say that it's expensive. Huge garden where you can get lost and spend the day. You can leave the lower garden without paying. Be sure to take money because it's complicated to find atm machines. The food in the restaurants are a bit expensive.

Timing is everythin!. To see the real spectacle get there at 11.00 in the morning and go down to the bottom of the stairs so that you can look up at the palace. That is when the fountains are started up for the day to a thundering serenade so you get the full effect - no fountains then a cascading symphony of fountains shooting water into the air.
Three days in St Petersburg. St Petersburg's Versailles!! Amazing gardens and fountain show. Beautiful -- one of St Petersburg's top attractions.

worth your while,. This is a beautiful palace, and you certainly should visit it if you have the time.
Drawback; as a non-russian you only have a limited possibility of visiting it (14h30, is one of the only slots) and the indication as to how, and where to buy tickets is non-existant.
Wow!. This place is so grand! The fountains are amazing and the grounds beautiful! This was part of our SPB tour after our hydrofoil ride. Lots of walking.
True to its fame. Don't forget to explore the garden thoroughly-there are so many fun fountains and playful structures. Flowers and plants are planted beautifully as well.

Don't go on a weekend!. We made the mistake to visit Peterhof on a Saturday. We left our hotel in St Petersburg and took the boat to get there around 10.30am. There was a big queue for tickets with no explanation in English. Apparently this first ticket is only for the gardens. Then we had to stand over an hour for a ticket to the main palace, and then another 30min wait to get in. In the palace there were far too many groups, all guided in Russian only. The audio help was only available in Russian and there was hardly any information in English. It took us most of the day for a very disappointing visit.

Gold, gold and more gold. So this place is amazing, breathtaking and opulent. It's defiantly worth a visit.But guys get your tickets and tourist friendly signs up please. There is no other way than to describe getting in to the buildings and separate parts of the palace.So when you arrive via hydrofoil you queue. at the jetty to buy your ticket to get into the grounds. The ticket you get is grounds only and is single entry. The grounds are beautiful and you can wonder for ages. The view of the grand palace and fountains is second to now. The place has been restored to its pre 1920's glory.You eventually walk up to the grand palace which has different entry times for different parts and depending on what you want to visit you then pay extra for that. We did the grand palace centre muse am with all the state rooms. They were amazing and every bit the palace of the Tzars. However, on the Saturday we went it was packed and so full of tours you could not move. Some of the staff were also not cold friendly. My daughter touched the guide rope, did not touch anything she should not have and was shouted at...... Totally pointless.Defiantly worth a visit if you can face the queues!
beautiful garden. The place is 20 minutes drive from city but its must visit place. Its beautiful place and vast garden and fountains well maintained.

Spectacular!. The Peterhof Palace is a series of palaces and gardens, sometimes referred as the "Russian Versailles", located in Petergof, Saint Petersburg. The Palace along with the city center is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.We were fortunate to be inside the Palace: it’s pouring (raining) outside at the time we visited. We were totally immersed ourselves in this spectacular view: elegant halls, exquisite collections (most in gold), grandiose display, gigantic building… not paying attention to what happened outside the Palace.Peter the Great in 1714 began construction of the Monplaisir ("my pleasure") Palace, his Summer Palace, based on his own sketches of the palace that he wanted close to the shoreline. He later expanded his plans to include a vaster royal château of palaces and gardens further inland, on the model of Versailles. Peter the Great completed his project by 1725. Following tsars magnified on the inland palaces and gardens of Peterhof. Afterwards the Alexandrine Park and Upper Gardens were constructed so as the Samson Fountain and its massive pedestal installed in the Sea Channel. And finally, the Grand Palace was elevated to central and eminent status.Peter the Great designed the Summer Garden in 1704, with the assistance of the Dutch gardener Nicolaas Bidloo and Jan Roosen. Later, French architect Jean-Baptiste Le Blond added French style/flavor into it, mimicking Versailles. The Garden was completed in 1719. Near 250 (now less than 90 left) allegorical marble sculptures lined the walks. The fountains (near 30), the oldest in Russia, were the main attraction. Interestingly, Peter the Great personally acquired the fountain machinery from Britain.The Park was truly spectacular!

Bit of a trip out of town. I could not wait tom see Peterhof Palace. It is very regulated and you are moved quickly thru the Palace. Definitely worth seeing. The gardens and fountains are beautiful. Need plenty of time to wander the gardens. Though the main fountains only go on at 11am it is worth seeing. I loved it. It is about and hour out of the main city by bus. We were on a Cruise tour.

If you love Versailles, you will love Peterhof!. Peterhof is amazing. They have over one hundred fountains. You could spend half a day walking around seeing all the beautiful fountains. The coolest part I thought was the "joke rocks", If you step on certain rocks, you get hit with water. My daughter had fun with that. The main difference with Versailles and Peterhof is at Versailles you walk around and stare at beautiful fountains. At Peterhof your kids get to run through some of the fountains and enjoy a beautiful day.

Do the gardens !!. Was there early in the morning (9 ish) Buy tickets for the gardens (2 parts : lower and higher) and if you have a lot of time you can buy separate tickets for the Palace. The main fountain (Samson fountain) will start at 11.00 am. The others ones were already "on" at 9.30 . You can go by boat (expensive) and by bus (long trip) or Taxi which is reasonable priced. With the taxi you see also some parts of St Petersburg without the glimmer and glamour. If you want a drink or another refreshment go to the "Bolshaya" orangerie which is near the Samson fountain and not so crowded.

On a Level with Versailles!. Much of the palace is the same as others....exquisite and posh! However, the fountains in the surrounding park are the best part! Cleverly done with hidden tricks, they are really well worth the visit; so, spend time seeing as many as possible (and maybe getting wet in the process)!

Plan to spend more time outside than in. Peterhof is phenomenal! Be prepared for LOTS of people and crowds as you visit the interior of the palace. Worth doing. HOWEVER, the grounds are spectacular and there is more room to spread out so it does not feel as crowded. Make arrangements to see the Grottos, the inside workings of the fountains, very special. Easy to spend all day here if the weather is nice.

Amazing. Really needed several more hours to take it all in, but even in our half day visit, I was overwhelmed by this place - beautiful palace, even more beautiful and interesting gardens - and those fountains! Wonderful!

Terrific place. One of St. Petersburg's most famous and popular visitor attractions, the palace and park at Peterhof (also known as Petrodvorets) are often referred to as "the Russian Versailles". Wonderful gardens include famous system of fountains that enrich to its best.
Russian Versailles. An outstanding palace in a unique location. Take the speedboat from the hermitage dock, a quick ride to Peterhof palace on the Baltic see. Impressive and magestic.

Lower gardens. We went on a day when the palace was closed ( Monday) but just seeing the lower garden was worth it. The fountains are spectacular. We spent several hours wandering around. I asked for a map from the information booth and they only have them in Russian, but it was good enough to follow and find all the highlights.We caught a bus out to the palace and it was very easy. We also got to see some of the outskirts of the city.

Wow. You just go from one beautiful room to another! I especially love the parquet flooring, its different in every room, and of course you need to allow quite a bit of time for the gardens and fountains

Beautiful inside and outside. We went on a rainy day but still were able to appreciate the magnificent gardens and fountains. What a breathtaking sight.The inside of the palace was amazing too. There is so much to see, it is overwhelming. I am so glad we were with a great guide.Great gift store as well as you cannot take photos inside.Would highly recommend
Stunning. Monoplaisir palace, in particular, was lovely.Our guide was competent and we saw nearly anything. Would love to see it in the snow :)

The Russian Versailles. They call it the Russian Versailles and once you are there it is to easy to see why. I have visited both and these Gardens are beautiful. In particular it is the fountains that are so beautiful. We did not go in the palace or the church as we did not have enough time, but we did walk out to the Bay of Finland which is a must see as you can see St. Petersburg off to the right from the dock. You could certainly spend the entire day or afternoon and picnic and walk on a beautiful day. There are vendors with food and souvenirs both inside the ticketed area and outside.

Don't miss the palace & gardens. This, with the Fabergé Museum, was probably my favourite sight on our visit to St Petersburg. We were lucky to be the first group into the palace so although it got busy later, we had a pretty untroubled visit. The palace interiors combine the magnificent public rooms with more intimate, though still grand, private quarters. After a little over an hour inside we headed out to the gardens. By that time there were crowds waiting for the fountains to start up.. The best spot to get photos is from the bridge half way down the canal between the Palace and the Gulf of Finland but you'll have to be quick and pushy to get to the front.You have to wear overshoes as you walk round and can't take in backpacks or large bags - it is better to go prepared so you don't have to leave things in the cloakrooms. Note also that you can't take photos inside.
Absolutely Beautiful. The palace is amazing. I would recommend walking the grounds as they are beautiful. If you can be on the grounds when they start up the fountains it is truly spectacular.

Spectacular. The fountains and gardens here are wonderfull,there is so much to see,not only are there the main fountains but many more throughout the gardens.You can also catch the hydrofoil back to Sr Petersburg
stunning. fabulous place, would like to have stayed for hours, walked around the gardens with our guide, fab fountains, watch out for the man in the hidden floor fountain, he will soak you!!

Must see while you in St.Petersburg. A lot of gorgeous fountains, charming park zones and the palace. Very calm atmosphere. Explore the parks - there are fountains going from the ground where you can get a lot of fun with.Take hydrofoil boat "Meteor" from St.Petersburg to Petergof - great experience and views.

Beautiful!. If the weather is fine Petergoff (Grand Palace) is a must! Simply walking there is great. Walking and enjoying all the buildings and wonderful fountains and gardens. The entering price for non Russian visitors is about 10 euros and it's worth it. You make take a guided tour as well or just walk around by yourself. Fascinating fountains.

Grand Palace, Peterhof. Wow comes to mind, we arrived by hovercraft and the walk from the ocean is stunning , gold everywhere, it's so vast you could spend a week viewing all the different buildings and gardens.A very busy place, we had tickets in advance so were able to avoid the queues due to our guide, a handful of rooms were opened a lot is still being refurbished, the great Amber room is to die for, absolutely stunning in all the rooms you have to just walk through as so many people are visiting you are actually told to move on in Russian! Certainly a visit and we will certainly visit again, fountains everywhere no cost has been spared!!

Wonderful!. Russian Versailles. If you are in St. Petersburg and do not know if its existence then there is something wrong with you holiday planning... Must see, hands down one of the major attractions in the city!

Beautiful Garden. In my opinion here is the most beautiful place in St. Petersburg . You should go there even if you haven't gone anywhere else in this city, but unfortunately it's full of tourists so your photos can't be as good as you think; If the weather is sunny you might see lots of brides and grooms here.

Definite Highlight... Fascinating Fountains. The tour of the grounds outside the Grand Palace was fascinating. The grounds are huge and the fountains are amazing especially considering they are naturally "powered". We took a coach to the palace and then the hydrofoil back to St. P. It's very crowded in the summer. We were on a tour got us in quickly and that was probably a good thing.

Mind blowing luxury, rude staff. Incredible park and buildings. Worth the visit.
Staff not speaking English at all and they charge double for fireigners where I felt no reasoning or logic behind just discrimination.
Grand Palace. Impressive destination. The gardens full of fountains are simply beautiful. I strongly recommend visiting it.

Grand Palace Peterhof. It was a shame that we had such bad weather this day. On a fine day, it would have been wonderful to see the gardens in sunlight.The guide was very stoic and braved the rain in order to show us the gardens and fountains. Really enjoyed this experience of opulence and wealth - no wonder there was a revolution!!

Another stunning St Petersburg palace. After visiting The Winter Palace and Catherine Palace and then this I was definitely feeling palace fatigue. The opulence was numbing and unrivaled. The gardens and fountains, spectacular. It was a bit of a drive from the city center, but so worth it. I don't know if a boat is a better option than driving. After reflecting on all of this over the top beauty/excess/decadence, and on the ultimate demise of its owners, I had to pause and consider the current state of our world.

Book ahead. We joined a Russian group with a guide to be able to get the tickets to the palace at the last minute. Since it was a joint trip with transport we were stuck with the group even though we did not understand anything & the guide didn't even make an effort to explain the basic instructions or try to get through with us. The trip was for almost 6 hours including the travel time with no break for a snack or food. There is not much inside to also feed you except for some snack joints here & there which had long lines. Being with a group that does not stop and with hungry kids it was not that pleasant. The palace itself is beautiful but wish we had a little more flexible plan. Carry snacks & water.

Recommend. the palace is so very beautiful inside and outside, you can't take pictures inside the palace and in order to buy tickets to get in you need to buy tickets for the park first and then buy another ticket for the palace. the palace itself is an amazing place, with more then 10 rooms to see, it even has pieces from Peter the first era, that were managed to be saved during the WW2.There is a nice souvenirs shop at the end of the tour.
Gardens. fountains and vistas are wonderful!. Try to get there for the 11am fountain start. The Gardens themselves are worth a visit even if you don't go into the Palace.

Grand!. Interesting to travel outside of St. Petersburg through rather bleak suburbs. Suburbs filled with high rises, relics of the 70's and 80's Soviet era. Once past the suburbs, you enter a quant little town. The palace is in this town. The palace is lovely and so are the gardens. There were a few mosquitos, not too bad. I highly recommend visiting this palace!

Maintenance day. Disappointed to be here on the day maintenance staff limited fountain display, I do not know if this is regular maintenance or just a one off, our guide, very experienced had never encountered this.

Beautiful. Very good and very large place. I was tired finallyand decided to return but the place was so beautiful and I couldn't come back! It is better to go here by train and come back by hydrofoil if you have enough time. Just check train times from SpB to Peterhof before going there.

Beautiful Grounds. We took a hydrofoil (boat) to get out to the palace which was fun. The grounds are beautiful. There are a ton of fountains and places to run around. We didn't go into the house (there are only so many lines I could stand on in 1 trip and this one didn't make the cut). It's a lovely way to spend an afternoon.
Amazing fountains in Lower park. Another Soviet Era wonder with large fountains operating with out any electricity or pump..Amazing!!!!!!

beautiful palace. we loved everything about it ! the palace, the gardens, the fountains and the Standart restaurant all well worth visiting ! Only problem was to know where to stand in line for the tickets. We took the group ticket office because the ticket office for individuals was for Russian only !

Amazing palace. It takes quite a lot of effort to get to this place, but it is well worth it. We took the hydrofoil from near the mounted statue of Peter the Great (1300 roubles return). On arrival you queue again and pay to enter the park. From here you can see the fabulous fountains which are worth the trip in themselves. We then had to queue and pay again (an hours queuing!), before finally getting into the palace. The rooms were lavishly furnished and decorated and really took the breath away - worth all the hassle of getting there. The signage is very poor in English and we ended up tagging along on a Russian tour (rather than wait again for an English one). This wasn't too much of a problem as most rooms had English explanations. However better explanations of the whole system and better queue management would have improved the whole experience.
Must see in St.Petersburg. Astonishing palace and it's interiors. Breath taking parks and fountains. Besides Tsarskoe Selo, another must see in St. Petersburg

A must see. Another first class visit, the restoration work after the second world war was excellent. Of course if possible be there so you can see the fountains being turned on at 11.00am. Crowded but managed to get a good viewing position. The palace itself is also outstanding.

One big Palace. Amazing.. We traveled by Hydrofoil to Peterhof,the Palace of Peter the Great, what met us you would not have expected, the Place was amazing and the surrounding Gardens were out of this world , waterfalls everywhere and gilt gold statues. You have to visit Peterhof whiel in St Petersbeg.

Stunning, haunting, mesmerising. This is, by far, one of the finest palaces in Europe. It is even more remarkable when one realizes the effort made to restore this palace to its original glory. Best approach is by hydrofoil from St petersburg. With kids make sure to visit the trick Fountains

True Russian Beauty. I visited Peterhof with my mom today. The entry ticket seemed to be different for each nationality, since me and my mom are Russian we payed 900 rubles. I was truly amazed with beautiful palaces, parks and gardens that it had. But, I was a little disappointed with the prices that we had to pay for example, for the grand palace the price is 600 rubles, the church wing is 400, special collections is 500 rubles and so on. The only price which seemed to be included with that 900 ruble ticket was the upper garden. Of course many of these places are worth to see but, just be aware of the prices for them so that there will not be any surprises when you're there. Also, take in mind that Grand Palace and other palaces, museums are not opened everyday. I really recommend to visit this place for everyone:)

Worth the boat ride. You can take the Meteor speed boat to reach this place. It is less grandiose than Villa d'Este in Tivoli and a bit of the Schönbrunn Palace in Vienna. But still worth visiting to get away from the busy center of St. Petersburg. Boat services are regular so you can always go back when you're done with your promenade, which was what we did.

Visit to palace and gardens. This is the most amazing and stunning place to see the palace is opulent it gives you an idea of how these people lived and the gardens are breathtaking with so many gold statues and fabulous fountains
Great palace. Use a hydrofoil and visit this pasterpiece. Amazing palace, great gardens. There are problems to some parts of it

So much to see in so little time!. This palace is jaw dropping and there is so much to look at and admire. However, they keep you all in time and usher you as quickly as possible due to the huge number of tourists flocking to this place. Make sure you go early to avoid the long queues.

Excellent visit. The grounds have one admission fee and are spectacular to walk around. Once you enter the grounds, you can go to another line to purchase a ticket to get inside the palace. I thought the grounds were unique and the buildings along the water were worth visiting.
Something to enjoy on a nice summer day.. A sumptuous and opulent Tzar's summer residence with little Russian influence. These guys certainly knew how to live in style.

The fountains are more magnificent than those at Versailles.. The beauty of Peterhoff Palace and grounds is stunning. The amazing fountains have no pumps and the water is gravity fed. Be sure to visit trick fountains in the summer for a chance to cool off after getting splashed with water.

Amazing Place. We visited Peterhof Palace as part of an organised group with guide. We gained entry reasonably quickly through the large crowds waiting to get in.It is such a lovely and interesting building with all rooms lavishly decorated. Outside you can look over the opulent fountains with magnificent views facing the Baltic Sea. The gardens are a joy to wander around.Our tour organised by "Alla Tours" was led by our excellent and knowledgeable guide Natasha (driver - Pavel). She explained in great detail the history of the Palace as well as other places of interest during our 2 day tour of St Petersburg.We would highly recommend this tour company.
Just Beautiful!!!!!. Excellent for a morning trip!!!You can go visit the palace and then the garden. We took the high speed hydro boat back and was excellent. Go visit with the kids.

Great palaces and parks, miserable organisation . My four star rating is only based upon the exquisite grandeur of the palaces and parks. Everything has been really thoroughly renovated, since I was there before Saint Peter's jubilee. However, bear in mind that you'll have to queue to obtain tickets to the grand palace and the ticket availability is limited to 600 per day. As in many tourist attractions foreigners have to pay more than Russian citizens, but it turns out that you can also be put into an only Russian speaking group, which can be quite an issue when you're supposed to help and translate at least the gist of the explanation to your non-Russian speaking friends. Moreover, you're forced to rush through the different rooms of the palace. You don't even have the time to read the explanations in English, because another group is on your heels and you're literally pushed into the next room. To make things even worse, the guide was being utterly rude to some of the foreign tourists, who apparently and luckily didn't understand what she was saying. Embarrassing...Conclusion: make sure to have your tickets in time and be in the right linguistic group ;-)

Be there at 11am to see the fountains turn on. We took a private tour of Peterhof with Ulko Tours, with Julia, an English-speaking Guide. It began with a hydrofoil into the Gulf of Finland to arrive at Peterhof at the jetty - this is the best way to arrive, as the palace reveals itself as you approach it the same way that Peter the Great himself did, along the Sea Canal.When we got there, just before 11 am, the place was packed solid as at 11 am every day, they open the valves to start the fountains to the tune of Peter the Great’s anthem - a truly magical moment and quite possibly the most beautiful sight I have ever seen (and I have seen a lot).All the fountains in the park are gravity-fed – there are no pumps at all.The colours of the gilded statues glowing in the sunlight, coupled with the green tiles of the Grand Cascade is truly memorable. Up to the Palace itself. Photography is, alas, forbidden in any of the palaces.Peter originally only had the central part but after his death, Elizabeth had it enlarged – as she seemed to do with every palace !! It had a mixture of baroque and classical designs, as well as several Chinese rooms with a dragon motif in one and a phoenix in another – in Chinese mythology, the dragon represents the Emperor and the Phoenix, the Empress. The kitchen contained pots and cups which were a gift from the Chinese Emperor.Our next stop was the Monplaisir Palace. This was Peter’s home and it was decorated much more sedately with his study and bedroom small and oak-lined to resemble ship’s cabins. On the water-side is a balustraded terrace that looks directly onto the Gulf of Finland, with St Petersburg visible on a fine day.The Chessboard Hill Cascade, Adam and Eve Fountains, the Lion Cascade, Roman Fountains, the Sun Fountain, the Triton Fountain, the Hermitage Pavilion that Catherine had built to “get away from it all” – she had the whole second floor to herself with a pulley system to raise a table up from the ground floor where it had been set by servants so she literally did not have to see or hear from anyone. The Pavilion is even surrounded by a moat. There is so much to see and admire amongst the extensive grounds.The Marly Palace – only eight rooms and another private pavilion near which is the Golden Hill Cascade, at the top of which is a beautiful view over the Gulf.Keep an eye out for the trick fountains that turn on unexpectedly to catch unsuspecting visitors.Our tour lasted from 09:30 - 16:30 and there was still so much we didn't see.It poured rain for part of the time we were there, but even that could not dampen my enjoyment of this place.The hydrofoils leave from the Palace Embankment throughout the day and entrance to the park grounds is free so on a fine day, this would be a fabulous place to just hang out and explore. Room for the kids to run amok and they will love the trick fountains.A supremely beautiful place.

A must on any trip to the St Petersburg Area. The Peterhof summer estate is around 30 / 45 minutes from the cruise terminal , where the excellent ALLA TOURS picked our group up from , listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site , rebuilt & restored after the ravages of the WW 2 .So much to see apart from the spectular fountains , the palace is a treasure trove ,and with all the visitors you can still find some space in the gardens to reflected on the beauty wealth etc , WEAR COMFORTABLE SHOES a lot walking & steps

The most beautiful place. There are several ways to get to Peterhof: bus, train or boat. The most convenient - even expensive ($17- adult and $13-child - two way) - is by boat, because it complements the impression of a visit to park and palaces. The park is open from the morning, and the Grand Palace from noon. You have to stand in the qeue well before. But that is worth it. Very beautiful palace and the park. Fountains start tp operate at 11 a.m. There are also funny fountains for kids, not far from Monplaisir palace. All in all, one can spent a day in Peterhof.

Splendid. You will love the palace interior and the garden. Can easily be reached by boat departing from the Erimitage Palace or by local train and bus. Best way to visit and easiest way to tour the palace is to travel with a tourist group organised by a local travel company. You will find the travel organisors in the city center or in hotels.Can be difficult at times to buy tickets to tour the palace if a private group.

the summer palace. this is the palace where the czar resided in the summer time.it is surrounded by nice gardens and vast green belt around it.the water sprinklers and gilded statues makes it thrilling place to visit.one of the best attractions of the great city of st.petersburg.
I see why they call this Grand. Again so many pictures taken at this hot spot. It is very busy but our guide knew all the right spots and we were all so impressed.

Stunning architecture. It's a beautiful place with the place of Peter the Great surrounded with endless amount of fountains, flowers and trees. Everything is very well kept and rich decorated. Outstanding classical style in sculptures and buildings. Convenient connection by the ship to the city center of St. Petersburg.Great place to spend non rainy day.
Turist. Luxury, history, impressive, huge, amount of details, must go with a guide to tell you all kind off history storys and details

Beautiful Peterhof. Peterhof was on our itinerary, and we are absolutely thrilled to have seen such a outstanding and wonderful place, it really took your breath away, the beauty and elegance we beyond words, the fountains and gardens are just magical, all the domes and fountains are made of gold and are one of the most fantastic sights we have seen on our travels around the world. We had a slow stroll thought the manicured gardens and then got a hydrofoil back to the ship. I day which stand out in our minds forever.

Not to be missed. This place is magical. The grounds are beautiful and felt like in a fairy tale. The cascading fountains. Beautiful gardens. Sculptures. So much to see. Had a guided tour of the palace inside and did not disappoint. Incredible. So much history. Every detail thought of in the decor of the palace. A must see.

Beautiful Gardens and fountains at Peterhof Grand Palace. Our group of 6 people visited the Palace and gardens as part of our 3 day tour of the city of St Petersburg. The entrance hall and state rooms were golden and opulent here and will long be remembered. We really loved the fountains and the gardens and were lucky to have a sunny dry July day for our visit.We also really enjoyed the drive out of the city seeing the building and towns along the way.
A spectacular place. Very impressive architecture. The only downside was too many people at all time. Struggle to take a picture if you want to be in it. Amazing view to the sea.

Beautiful Fountains Everywhere!. The palace grounds are worth a few hours to just take in the scenery, landscaping and fountains...absolutely beautiful. I visited in April the day after they turned on the fountains for the first time this year. If you visit during off season you may want to make sure the fountains are running.The palace itself is much smaller than the winter palace,but equally beautiful. Spending 4-5 hours at the palace is a great way to spend the day. Highly recommend visiting.

Come in the Summer!. We visited in the Spring, and the fountains were not yet in service. Heck - late April, and the canal was still blocked with ice. But it was a fascinating day - we got a lot out of it because we had a private guide. Because of that, it was a great visit.

Feel like royalness. The perfect summer walk. Even though it's far from the city, it's definitely worth going there. The place is gigantic and feels like a passage through time. I was feeling like a queen walking there alone. That's another tip, since it's really full on summer, you can arrive early to avoid crowded pictures and lines. Remember that on mondays the Peterhof castle is closed, but the Peterhof gardens are not. Inside the gardens there are many other spaces to (pay) and visit, some of them are really delightful to appreciate.

Must visit place in spb. It's the Russian version of the French palace of Versailles. It's much better arrive by boat and never forget your umbrella! At 11am the switch on the fountains, a good show. You also get free wifi in some areas. The bad point is that it is too touristic, a big crowd. Anyway, as I said before it's the Versailles style by Peter the great but If you come to spb you can't miss it!

Fountains nice. Honestly, if you visited Vesailles, Sanssouci or any other european palace of this type you will not be blown away, at leas I was not. Ok, so there are some gilded statues, but still I cant see what is the hype, in the end it was "one million people" there, huge lines for everything, the place looked as if under invasion, just frustration buildin up. This was a day trip I could have done without. It is the high season though maybe off season it is better.

Come by boat, leave by train! . If you come by boat, that's nice. But if you also leave by boat, you cannot leave the park area without paying again if you want to enter again. Even if you just want to reach your boat back. My recommendation: get there by boat, it is a cool experience. Go back to St Petersburg by train. Then you also get to check the small city of Peterhof. The museums you can visit there all require an extra ticket to buy there. Line up for each separately. The whole complex was terribly organised. No information anywhere about how to enter which museum and when. No information about exits and entries. People speak little English but don't explain you anything. "wait here for 15min" we were told, but why? And what's going to happen? We don't know. The park itself is just a park with bushes, trees and grass. Not a special garden. Fontaines are nice.
Museums. Shuffling along. I appreciate that my timing was right in the middle of season, but the abattoir-esque feeling as you are shuffled along does detract from the experience

World class palace and gardens. The gardens and fountains at Peterhof are just exceptional. Every inch of the grounds are beautiful and there are over 150 fountains. It's great to be there right at 11 AM when they turn on the fountains each day. You should allow a number of hours to tour the grounds. There are reasonably priced cafés on the grounds so you don't have to bring your own food. The view of the Gulf of Finland is quite nice as well

The grounds alone are worth the visit. We chose to only visit the grounds and viewed the grand palace from the outside and toured an adjacent property instead, which was Peter the Greats' personal residence. This was a highlight of our two day tour, and the "smaller" residence reflected Peter's personality and desire for more intimate residences. It contains a number of artifacts that belonged to Peter, and was a wonderful contrast to the extravagance of the Catherine's Palace and the Winter Palace that houses the Hermitage.

Stunning Fountains and Gardens. The palace was crowded so we only had time to visit the gardens. The fountains are amazing and worth the visit on their own. You cannot image their opulence without seeing them.

St Petersburg. We visited this palace as part of our 2 day tour of St Petersburg. However, we visited the gardens and not the palace. The fountains here are amazing, they are all sourced naturally, no pumps etc This palace and gardens are out of the city, so after we had walked around the gardens we caught the hydrofoil back to the city centre This took approx 30mins

beautiful palace, very impressive inside. This was a bit of a day trip, especially as we left st Petersburg quite late (around 14:00). The grand palace is on Peterhof (a separate location from St Petersburg). The fastest way to get there is by boat (30 min). You buy the ticket to enter the location with the gardens as you get off the boat. This ticket will only give you access to the gardens. To get in the palace you will need to buy another ticket. Between 14:15 (or maybe it was 15:15) and 16:15 this ticket counter for the palace is closed. And once it open the line is already very big. Chance is you could stay about 1h in line. We were lucky as a couple of wonderful Russians stayed in line and got us the tickets while we just walked around the gardens. As we got in the palaceall russian people were grouped and they got a guide who explained to them what each of the rooms was about. There was no English guide so we just wondered around reading the notes in each room. The rooms were absolutely gorgeous! I tried to buy tickets online before getting there but i did not find the way to do so. If you manage this, more power to you! :-)

Awesome Rebuilding. This was a great excursion outside St. Petersburg. The grounds (fountains) and Palace are beautiful. When you see the photographs of the devastation following the war, you realize what miracles have been performed to regain the splendor of these palaces. The rooms are so beautiful and they are continuing to fix more. The floors are fabulous in the different designs. You get a feel for Peter the Great and his desire to bring Russia out of its stagnant ways and into a modern European style city.

Lovely park and gardens with fun fountains. Visited on a nice sunny day, had a lovely walk through the park and had fun daring each other to walk through the random fountains. Entrance fee was confusing, we paid 700 roubles but not sure of difference to 200 ticket because every museum was an extra charge anyway. Food stands a bit tacky for such a nice place, basically theme park food (hot dogs/burgers). Got there on the hydrofoil, which was fun in itself.

Russian version of Versailles. The beautiful palace of Peter the Great. 2 admission fees - one for the park and one for the palace. This for the palace is with immense waiting line, unfortunately there was no option to buy tickets online (to July 2016). The garden is beautiful, but not so many flowers like in Paris or Vienna, due to the rougher climate in St. Petersburg.
Another Stunning venue. Inspiring and interesting - Shame it was a damp day when we were there but it didn't detract from the sights - Greta grounds and tremendous fountains
Spectacular. A must see. Could easily spend all day in this wonderful place. Luah gardens, fountains everywhere, amazing views, and the palace itself is marvelous. Recommend it to everyone.

Best Palace ever visited. I haven't been to all palaces but I've been to El Grand Palacio (Spain), Versailles (France) and a couple of other much smaller, and I can tell you this place is magnificent. Don't miss it. You can take all the pics you want of the outside but the inside is a whole other story and don't even try. They've got these Russian ladies in each room monitoring visitors and ensuring no one is taking pics. I can tell you they take their job seriously. The outside and gardens are beautiful and the one thing not to miss is when the water is turned on and all the fountains come to life. I would suggest taking a video of this is the way to go. You will not be disappointed.

Must visit... Reach before 11am. There is a beautiful opening ceremony which starts the fountains, begins exactly at 11am, A MUST WATCH... The cold breeze of the Baltic Sea is fun. All in all... Peterhof is a must visit in St. Petersburg.

Peter the Great Won!. According to our French guide in Versailles, Louis (14th/15th?) had a rivalry with Peter the Great. According to our Russian guide, Peter was "inspired" by Versailles for his own get-away palace. But Versailles was built in the middle of farmland and Petergof was built overlooking the Gulf of Finland. While both are over-the-top grand, Peter's fountains and real estate make him the clear winner. It's a must if you are visiting St. Peterburg! We took a hydrofoil from the Winter Palace embankment and spent a fabulous day. First boat over is 9:30 & last back is 6:30. We especially enjoyed the yacht museum and the Peter & Paul church where the last Tsar's children were baptized.

Worth the line. It's not the first time we come there, and it's in my opinion the best, cosiest and most interesting palace in St. Petersburg. The line is huge, the number of tickets is limited, but the spaces are so small, it's inevitable, so come early. We also love the excursion microphones, you can walk around and still hear the guide.

Great. We were on a group tour from a cruise ship. We went in July when it was hot. We ended up waiting in a line to get in. Once we were in we were in another line to get thru palace. There were a lot of people, mostly different group from various tour companies. I remember a lot of pushing and shoving. You go from room to room and there are always people wanting to cut in front of you. Our tour guide is usually on a time schedule and I would find it hard to keep up with my group due to people butting in front. I didn't want to get lost from them and found it somewhat stressful. I would recommend going on off season from tourist. It might be more relaxing.

Simply fantastic. Words are short of expressing how amazing the space is. Beautiful gardens, great fountains, setting is dreamy and architecture is overwhelmingly impressive. another must see and visit. Our visit was disrupted with heavy rain but nonetheless we enjoyed it.

Golden statutes in stunning fountain. A first class experience derived from detailed care and restoration following WW2 destruction a metaphor for St. Petersburg and a lesson in public funding for sculpture.A great day out using gardens as well as palace, but better buying tickets ahead although queuing was good way to meet people

A couple of hours is not enough. Went as part of a tour and only had time for the gardens.Incredible how they have been restored back to their former glory.The fountains are absolutely wonderful, so much variety in their design. Peter the Great was a bit of a prankster as you will discover!Well worth visiting!!
Nice place. Very nice place with many fountains, Do not forget to describe the Gulf of Finland.and take a pictures alot.

Amazing!. It is busy during this time of the year. We visited the palace with a private guide, but it was hurried by the palace staff. It has nothing to do with your guide. Get your tickets ahead of time or book a travel guide which we did. The upper and lower gardens were beautifully maintained. The fountained were spectacular and pay attention some of them may cool you off. Upper gardens are free, but lower gardens require admission tickets. The admission is fairly priced. If you buy your tickets in Russian, they are less expensive. There are not so many places to eat, but there are snack stands and we were able to find one small cafe for lunch.
Cruise shore visit. A massive wow , very nice very good on the eye if not a little bright with all the gold leaf of the Baroque style in the palaceLovely grand gardens tooWell worth a visit
Amazing!. To think that all of these fountains are gravity fed and constructed hundreds of years ago. It is a beautiful and grand achievement!
Spectaular. The grandeur of the Grand Palace is spectacular. You can see what an opulent an extravagant lifestyle they lived.

A beautiful place, BUT....... The Grand Palace is undoubtedly a beautiful place. However, it was so incredibly busy that it spoilt our visit. We had a Russian tour guide & were a small party. As soon as our guide paused to explain something she was told to move on. As a result, we were listening to her commentary of a room two ahead of the one we were in, hence it made little sense. She tried to protest but it just became a heated argument with the staff in the rooms. The fountains and the gardens are also beautiful, and absorbed the crowds more easily. However any spot that provided a good photo opportunity literally became a scrum. In all my years of travelling I have never experienced anything quite like this. Our guide actually said that the gardens were quiet during our visit - when more cruise ships are in, it is considerably worse.On a positive note, there are plenty of refreshment outlets and toilets - although you might have to wait a while. My advice to anyone planning a visit is to go out of season. I would also advise that you know the history of the palace before you visit - then you know what you're looking at & are not reliant on the commentary (something I wished I'd done). However it is definitely worth a visit providing you can get to see it!

Spectacular Palace and Fountains. The Grand Palace is located in a town about 45 to 60 minutes away from St. Petersburg. The palace and gardens is segregated into the Upper and Lower Gardens. You’ll have to pay an entrance free for the lower gardens, which includes the Grand Palace and the Grand Cascades, whereas the Upper Gardens are free to all visitors. Visitors to the Grand Palace will have to wear shoe covers before entry, and the security is quite strict about the rules; e.g. guests cannot bring water into the palace. Also note that if it is raining outside, you’ll have to remove your outer coats and keep it in the cloakroom. Photography and other forms of recording are prohibited inside the palace. Photography however is allowed outside on the palace grounds, and you should really go all out to take as many as you can because the Grand Cascades are really beautiful with all the different ornate designs. The fountains are turned on each day (from mid-May to October) at 11am so head on down early to grab a good spot if you wish to capture the moment. The piping systems of the fountains function purely by virtue of gravity, so it is really cool to see how such a simple design (and I don’t mean it in a derogatory way) can produce something so magnificent.
Do not miss Peterhof!. A beautiful place to visit, both the palace and gardens are spectacular but don't miss going into the grottos for the best views of the Grand Cascade.

Grandeur beyond Imagination, A shame that it was obscured by tourists.. The Peterhof Palace is one of the most amazing places I have ever been to. Nothing compares to the glistening gold coupled by the unmistakable whiff of old Tsar grandeur. In my mind it was better than Versailles (either due to the gold or my dislike of the French) as its fountains and remarkable survival across the more checkered part of Russian history. It just adds to how timeless it is. It was as if I had graced the courts of Catherine the Great. The only difference being that the silk of royal dresses were replaced with high white socks and kharki. Having a Russian take you round really does give you a great perspective on the art, and how the Russian royalty may have lived. Yes I suppose that its quite hypocritical to say that I didn't like the crowds, especially because I was part of them myself but still the crowds were beyond belief. Tour after tour after tour. The court of Catherine the Great was quite dense but could not compare to a room stuffed with tourists desperately trying to take a photo of a royal chamber pot. One cannot deny the amazing things on show, the rooms, the grounds, it all. However it doesn't matter how shiny your gold fountain is, it counts for nought if all the view you get is of a middle aged Americans combover. My advice, go when the winter makes them fly west and marvel at the sheer beauty on show.

Fountains, and even more fountains. I didn't go in any of the buildings while I was there, I just took in the gardens and fountains. Just after I went through the ticket entrance I came to the top of the terrace that looked down onto a view of stunning beauty. There fountains in some manicured gardens and of to the side view where fountains went down in terraces to the fantastic Samson fountain. Every single fountain (although I have to confess, I didn't see them all, as there are 150+) was lovely in its on way, whether by its looks or its location.I was there on a day when the ' trick' fountains were a popular way of cooling down.There is 1 'trick' fountain that is situated along a walk way and it is turned on at certaintimes of the day, I think it was 3pm when I was there for the turn on along with the crowd that tends to gather at such times.The view from the canal up to the buildings on top of the terrace is spectacular

Eyeful. Took the high speed hydrofoil from Petersburg - these are worth seeing on their own.We only did the gardensWhich are hugeAmazing waterfalls and landscapingWith extensive tree planting Worth the trip
Amazing!. Grand palace at Peterhof is amazing!! Very elegant surrounded by beautiful gardens, with over 200 fountains. Love the place.

Don't miss it. Excellent, the fountains are amazing and the park is gorgeous. Spent a beautiful day out of St Petersburg.We went by boat, expensive but nice. Not a must do.We came back by the bus: very easy and cheap, highly recommended. Gives you the chance to see the real life out of the historical centre.Most buses go to a metro station of St Petersburg. No need to speak Russian: Just exit the park (south side), cross the main road to go direction left, and check with any mini-bus driver “Metro?”. Exit the bus when you see everyone else going out, you’ll see the M sign of the station.

Definitely worth a visit. We visited the gardens and were able to view the amazing exterior from there. Apart from the more commonly visited area between the palace and the sea, we also walked round from the car park to see the road-facing side - which we found was well worth doing.Another amazing restoration!

Magnificent Palace. The Palace is as beautiful inside with all the art collections, paintings etc. but it is equally beautiful outside with its multiple fountains,manicured grounds, garden and cascading waterfalls. Truly a marvel of architecture and design which will leave you breathless

Breathtaking. A must visit on st petersburg tour , much has been already written about it , only thing i want to share is that mini rail ride is avaiable inside but nobody guides you about it . While you are standing facing the main fountain in the lower garden , turn left and you will find it . Rail ride doesnt add much to your experience , just gives you an idea of the vastness of the property .
Awesome!. Great! Wonderful history. Interesting world site where you can see the ruby room, great collection of Fabergé Eggs, interesting how you can touch art. Great bookstore.

Beautiful fountains, gardens. We did not actually go inside as we were planning on going to Catherines palace in Pushkin. Beautiful grounds, trick fountains, A highlight is the little moated building where dinners were hosted with a table that had mechanical place settings eliminating the need for servants in the room.Extra tickets required for the tour that demonstrates the plating proceedure, tour guide in Russian language only.
just visited gardens and grounds. fantastic, worth visiting. we went on hydrofoil which i loved. we were there at 11am for fountains being switched on, all gravity fed. spectacular
Grand Palace AMAZING!. SPB TOURS - Provided us an impeccable view of ALL of the St. Petersburg museums & cathedrals! GREAT!

Wheelchair accessible. I was very worried before I went to Russia that I would not be able to manage the long staircases and large museums but was pleasantly surprised to find that many of them are wheelchair accessible. At Peterhof we were able to use a ramp off to the side to go down into the gardens and see the fountains. Wonderful experience.
Fabulous. Even on a rainy day the gardens, fountains and the palace buildings were colourful and impressive . A must!
just gorgeous!!!. a beautiful relic of the days gone past..a storehouse of history ...a simply beyond imagination 'gorgeous'palace

Great on the outside . It is a magnificent place especially from a distance... Disappointing close by and very un-pleasant tour due to crowds with guides. The gardens, water front and the outside are truly worth the trip. The walk in the garden was relaxing away from the crowds. It is s long distance away and if you are short of time you should skip this one. I think.

Beautiful gardens!. We spent hours here and only toured the gardens. Gorgeous! Take time to walk all around - you are right on the Baltic and the view of the palace from the shoreline is awesome. The fountains are wonderful! We missed the fountain ceremony though. Be careful of pickpockets here - they are everywhere.

Beautiful gardens and fountains. It was quite far from St. Petersburg. About one hour with a taxi. It was raining but the place is amazing. Authentic living palace. Beautiful gardens and fountains. It has a problem with only one accessible toilet. the sink almost fell when I held my self on. it should be stronger in an accessible bath room.

Impressive palace and gardens. We were lucky with a lovely sunny Sunday so it was pretty busy. Every attraction seemed to carry a separate cost but the restored palace was lovely even though you were ushered through to keep the crowd flow. The gardens were splendid, the water fountains and falls amazing in all corners! You need to allow a near full day to cover all aspects given it is an hour away from Saint Petersburg. Cafeteria good too.

Totally fascinated by its fountains. I saw photo of the Grand Cascade before but didn’t realize its scale and grandeur until visit first hand. I also didn’t know there were many other fountains at the estate. I am more amazed by all its fountains than any other royal garden I have been to, including Versailles. BTW, don't miss all the trick fountains which were designed to surprise its royal guests. When we were there, Samson Fountain (middle fountain of the Grade Cascade) started splash at 11am, so probably no reason to be there earlier. We walked around the lower park for about an hour but didn't visit the museum/palace as part of our tour. I bought a Petrohof booklet (~ $2) on the hydrofoil there (~50 min ride from Hermitage), now I can reference the names of the fountains and statues and learn about the places I didn't get to visit. Take a break from the city, this is a definitely a must-visit at St. Petersburg.

Beautiful Gardens!. We were fortunate to see the fountains activate at 11 AM. It was a beautiful, sunny day, and the gold on the statues shimmered brightly. The gardens overall are gorgeous. Very crowded, but it didn't diminish the beauty of the grounds.

My favorite. Fell in love with the palace. It was elegant yet not ostentacious. The grounds were breathtaking. We waited for the fountain ceremony which personally I think was a little overrated and difficult to see at so many people pack into a small space for a great view (with many people pushing and shoving).

Amazing!. I could easily spend all day here and I only walked outside the grounds! The fountains are amazing, your right by the Baltic, and the grounds are perfectly manicured. There are snack places throughout so you can easily walk, snack and relax!

The gardens are amazing. The main feature of the site is the extensive palace which is difficult to access. But what is memorable and the focus of most peoples visit is the landscaped gardens with their water features. All powered by gravity, the numerous fountains and cascades are found all over the site and there are some modern ones as well; such as sculptural trees that spray water. Sited at the edge of the Baltic Sea there are boats to take visitors to and from St Petersburg. What is amazing is to see the photos that show how the place was destroyed by the Nazis and rebuilt after World War II by the communist government. Pray for fine weather though, there is nowhere to shelter if it rains.
The summer palace!. This is a not to be missed stop on your visit to St. Petersburg. The great number of fountains and sculptures are really over-the-top!

Private Tour with 4 couples with Ivan of Tailored Tours. The Palace was spectacular in its wealth of art and exhibits that would take years to go through if you would stop to observe every item. I would rate it as a must do in St. Petersburg and comparable to the Vatican Museum.
Did not meet my expectation. When i read other review i have high expectation regrading this grand palace. However, there are limited area that you can walk and audio guide is needed

Picturesque Palace and gardens. Part of a 2-day tour with TJ Travel, we didn't have time to visit the Palace but walked through the gardens, down past the beautiful cascades, fountains and statues, alongside the canal to the Gulf of Finland before boarding a hydrofoil.
Worth a visit.

Astounding exteriors. We only had a few hours there and didn't get the opportunity to go inside, but we were happy with seeing the outside amazing scenes. It's part of a two day tour from SPB Tour. We understood that we had a lots of things to see.

Breath taking. Another wow moment in St-Petersburg. This park is one of the loveliest that I have seen in my life. We spent an hour in the park and loved every minute of it. It is simply magnificent. And knowing that the waterfalls are powered naturally made it even more beautiful.

Very beautiful. We took an organised tour to the palace and gardens and despite the rain which cut our visit very short, we loved it. Unfortunately we could not fully explore the gardens as my mother was in a wheelchair and in a rainy day it is a big disadvantage.

Opulant palace, with beautiful gardens and cascade of fountains. Called Peterhof, it is built by Peter the Great during Russia' imperil expansion period in early 18th century. It is sometimes called the Russian Versailles. It is a UNESCO World Heritage site. The palace has decorations that commemorate Russia's victory over Turkey, and over the Swedes (Samson Fountain). The most amazing part is the cascade of fountains, built without pumps and driven entirely by elevation differences. At the end of the garden, you can save some time and see a different scenery by catching a high-speed hydrofoil to go back to the city center. Definitely visit the Peterhof Grand Palace.

Rainy day but still excellent. Many of the SPB area palaces are over the top intricate and opulent, but the gardens around Peterhof are worth spending time in. It was raining off and on so we didn't get the pictures that some do, but it kept the crowds down a little - but there were still a LOT of people. The airboat ride was fun both ways but choppy on the way back. If the boat you're on offers a business class upfront (instead of open seating as our first one did) and anyone in your party suffers from motion sickness, spring for the upgraded tickets.

Peterhof. There is a very nice Hydrofoil boat ride from town to Peterhof. It takes about 45 min. Once at the Palace plan on walking no less then 4 miles around the beautiful grounds. An interesting fact is that the fountains have no pumps. They are all fed by a natural spring.

Fantastic place. If you are in Saint Petersburg then you should visit this wonderful place. It's about 1 hour road in bus. But it's fantastic, beaut, bright, colorful and interesting place on the shore of Gulf of Finland.

Wow!. Even though the Grand Palace is some distance from the centre of St Petersburg (we went there by hydrofoil), the effort in getting there is very much worthwhile! A quick browse of the photos online will show you why.........

Self guided independent tour visit - yes its possible. I decided to try this without a guide and wanted to recall a few pointers before I forget.I just walked to the boat docks directly behind the Hermitage. They want cash (1300R for round trip) but NOT a 5000 note. Everyplace I went seemed to be low on 100's so they are looking for them. Bring 1000, 500 and 100s if you can. The hydrofoils seem to be running before 10 (which is the start time I have read). There were 'ticket booths' selling the hydrofoil tickets (on the side of the Hermitage) but I was worried there would be different companies and I would then have to search for the correct boat dock, so I just qued and purchased directly there, After purchasing your ticket, you get in line for a hydrofoil. Tour groups get priority loading from a slightly different gangplank, but it is the same boats. I just missed the 9:30 boat and got on the one that left at 10:00. If possible, pick a day that has a good weather forecast, as they will cancel the hydrofoil if it is raining too hard, etc. It might help that you have looked at a metro map so you have an idea what your 'back up' plan is if need be (heard story from another tourist this happened to and it was a bit of a nightmare for them). The journey in NOT really scenic but it was smooth the day I went. I get seasick so this was a blessing. I was fine, even tho the wind had picked up for the return. When you get off the hydrofoil you walk a fair amount down the dock and come to the ticket booth. This is only the booth to get into the lower harder (700R). In fact, there is no where you can buy a combined ticket. Each 'attraction' requires its own ticket purchase. I decided to get into line right away for the Grand Palace (missing the 11:00 start of the big fountain which is supposed to be a bit of a highlight).The line for groups and foreigners is directly up the fountain steps. The line opened before 11 which is about when I entered. The line for Russians is further down to the right and I believe their palace access starts at 12. So my ticket was not really time stamped but they wanted you to enter the palace directly. WC is on the left of the ticket office and the somewhat mandatory but free cloakroom is to the right. You stop and pick up shoe covers just before entering the palace. No photos are allowed in the palace, I think to keep the groups moving. As an individual, you often have to squeeze by the slow moving groups. The guides do not seem to make much of an effort to corral their groups to allow a 'traffic' lane. The palace is spectacular and a bit like a mini-Hermitage (I've not been to Catherine's Palace yet, but rom the photos the decoration style also seems similiar). It takes under an hour to flow through. There is a description in English in most of the rooms and there were many English speaking guided groups going through. Having read a fair amount about the family, history, etc. I did not feel I missed much from what I could hear the guides saying. As for the rest of the grounds. I took the little train (running Russian commentary) to get a sense of the scale of the park. The train goes out of the lower garden park bounds past the farm palace and gothic cathedral). Makes a loop on that side of the grounds. It was 350R and I am glad I did it just to save steps. I did not go into any of the other palaces as they seemed fairly small. True restaurants are a bit hard to find. There is one all the way at the 'golden cascade/MArly palace' end that is not on the map. The main one is on a diagonal path shortly after you would be approaching the fountain steps from the boat dock (right side). The rest are little kiosks selling hot-dog type food and snacks. As is everything in Russia, a lot of walking is required. I saw a few golf carts (Russian commentary) but I think they have to be arranged in advance. Even though I am now trying to walk as little as possible (because my legs are tired from day after day of 18,000- 23,000 steps a day, this was another 20,000+ step day (about 10 miles). I think most of the group tours only cover the palace and the main fountain. If you want to save steps and time, this is enough, I was a little underwhelmed by the rest of the gardens/fountains. It is a nice day if you want to get out into nature and can bring your own food. Also, look at the upper gardens from the palace windows, because it is my understanding you can not really enter them (even though they are 'free') as it would involve an exit from the lower garden. According to the signs, you would have to pay another 700 to re-enter the lower garden for you return hydrofoil trip.I was in line with russian speaking americans who had heard you could show your return ticket and get a stamp from the administration building. They asked the lady selling the tickets about this.
