She said no, I have seen this 'free re-entry' scheme referenced on other web sites but without language skills, I think it would be nearly impossible to negotiate. Also, I did not see here any automatic ticket booths anywhere, you stand in the line to purchase the ticket then pretty much directly proceed through the rest of the 'process' to enter the palace. On the hydrofoil return, I could see one that was getting ready to depart, so I just went to that one (even though it was not the same as the one I cam on in terms of the exterior branding). There were people queuing for other hydrofoils. When I returned (3:30) there was no line for the tickets or the hydrofoil, so you may want to consider leaving later in the day. Hope this helps!

Peterhoff Was Amazing. We only saw the gardens, but what an amazing sight. Wear comfortable walking shoes and see as much of the gardens as you can. To think that the fountains were constructed in the 1700's using only gravity in mind boggling.

Lavish. We took an organised tour to the palace and gardens and despite the crowds and the rain, we loved it. To see how lavishly the Romanovs lived was eye opening to say the least! Definitely take an organised your- don't try doing it yourself. We were pleasantly surprised to have free time to browse the gardens ourselves. They were beautiful even on an overcast and rainy day. The hydrofoil back to the city afforded great views of many city sites. Would recommend the palace visit for sure. We coupled this with the Peter and Paul cathedral and fortress due to the Romanov link but would not bother with that. Instead, go to the Spilled Blood cathedral and do the inside - that is our one regret! If you are on a cruise as we were, we would recommend you organise your own visas and a private guide to tour what you want. That way you can stop off at the arty areas as well and see St Petersburg by night- it is magical.

Take time to enjoy the inside and gardens and fountains. The inside wonderful, the outside superb, the experience priceless. If stuck for time don't use the restaurant as service is painfully slow. If limited for time or have mobility limitations or just tired, there's a land train to take you around the vast gardens. The fountains are wonderful make sure you take a selfie.
Beautiful palace. A beautiful palace. Well worth the drive. After seeing photos of what it looked like after WWII, it is an amazing restoration. A must see treasure.

Gorgeous gardens and fountains. We did not go into the palace, instead spent time walking around the stunning grounds. Had lunch in a nice cafe there as well. You can take a hydrofoil directly from a dock near the Hermitage - fun too

great, amazing. plan more than 2 hours for this attraction. there are everyday tours to the place from the center of Saint Petersburg. Amazing park and attractions. You can go back on the boat, that came just near the Hermitage museum.

Stunning fountains. The fountains of the Grand Palace are so beautiful. The gold gild sparkles in the sunshine and the gardens are beautiful too. Small cafe at the entrance with average food. We did not go inside the palace as it was closed

Do not go on Monday. Firstly, the 'hydrofoil' from St. Petersburg isn't worth the fare - certainly not my idea of a hydrofoil, barely got above the water: go on the bus for 1/20th price. Peterhof itself is fabulous but we went on a Monday so only got to see the grounds and fountains which are spectacular. All the buildings are closed Monday's (many attractions are) so choose your time better than we did. Well worth a day out

amazingly opulen palace!. A must visit if in this part of the world. Gives an insight into the wealth of the czars!Very beautifully designed palace & gardens. We took a boat from the winter palace pier to get there, although it was very stormy & windy that day.But the views are breathtaking!

Very expensive. You need tickets for each attraction eg house, etc. A lovely place. Beautiful gardens great views, lots of people and queues.
Mosquitos in the gardens, take repellent. We traveled by boat and had to go for the business travel which cost a great deal more, because boats were full, book in advance!
Great. Very nice. If you are lucky and get there in a sunny weather you will see even more colours and details. Lots of people there. Good to take a boat trip on your way back to St Petersburg.

Beautiful . . . Even in the Rain!. We were on a cruise and had no choice about the day we visited . . .which turned out to be rainy. The gardens and fountains were still beautiful and definitely worth the visit! The bath house was especially interesting.

Like fountains?. Then this is the place for you! Challenge of the day - try and get a photo without any other visitors in it! Good luck
Locals like to dress in old garb and have professional photos and most were happy to have an amateur one with us!
Great place.

Tribute to Russia. Great palace.. A lovely afternoon spent walking the grounds of a great palace. Beautiful grounds full of trees and acres of flat lawns teaming with birds, squirrels and tourists.Truly a tribute to a great era with amazing architecture and an eye for conserving things of beauty from the past.Plenty of places to grab a bite to eat and that romantic couple photo together.Well worth the effort to get there and recommend avoiding a tour group if you wish to make it a full day as there is plenty to see and do.
Better than Versailles?!. What an amazing place! The wonderful plaza in front of the palace is a great welcome before entering what a beautiful place. Do not miss this place!!!

Breathtaking. Ensure you set aside lots of time to wander through the rooms and gardens of Peterhof. It is very crowded, like so many of the places in St Petersburg but is a definate must see. You can take a hydrofoil back to the city, which stops near the Hermitage.

The fountains outshine Varsailles. The first reception hall at Peterhof simple zaps you with its grandeur. Sadly photographs are not allowed inside. The fountains with golden figurines are definitely very pretty. It is also less crowded though one must admit the gardens at Versailles are far better.

Beautiful palace and grounds. We visited here on a private excursion with guide and was glad we did as it means you go to the front of the queue (the queues were extremely long!) well worth a visit though.

Go! Better in a sunny day. Monumental and completely oversized, it is beautiful. You should definitely take a tour to the underground part where you can see the pipes and hidraulics that made those fountains work 300 years ago. Unbelievable.

Grand Palace lovely whatever the weather.. Even in the rain these gardens are beautiful. Magnificent waterfalls form the centrepiece and were key features throughout the beautiful grounds. The gardens provided a refreshing change from the information overload of the palaces and museums of St Petersberg, so give a good balace / variety to the day.

Absolutely gorgeous!!!. This palace and the gardens were absolutely gorgeous. I would suggest visiting with a private guide to avoid a tiring and less pleasant hop-on-hop-off experience. It was completely surprising just how beautiful this palace was given the fact that it is not better known world wide.. The gardens, the interiors, the entire palace was just exquisite. You need 2-3 hours at least. There are a lot of reasonably priced eating places too if you need lunch after.

Amazing!. My experience of Peterhof was being part of a tour group. It took about an hour to get there by bus from St. Petersburg. Even though we did not go inside, the gardens are not going to fail. For our group, tickets to the palace and gardens were separate, both were paying. If short in time, visit the fountains. They are spectacular! Makes for some exceptional photos.

One of the most beautiful places in St. Petersburg suburbs. A must see for any visitor of St. Petrsburg and its suburbs. The guides are real professionals and the place is wonderful. Its a masterpiece of art.

Opulence personified. Spectacular interiors with nothing left ungilded. Shame you can't take photos as you can in Catherine Palace. The real treat though is the extensive gardens and water features. Expect big crowds, especially for the turning-on of the fountains at 11am. A must see and given the distance from St Petersburg probably best seen with a tour group.

Choose a sunny day and spend your time wandering the gardens and seeing fountains. We lucked out and got one of the sixty-something sunny days per year in this region when we went here. Honestly, it's a place to see when it's warmer and the sun is shining, because otherwise, you'll be wandering through huge grounds in the rain. We also got lucky in that we used Google Maps to drive here from St. Petersburg, and it took us directly to a remote (not the main) entrance that wasn't very busy. We found street parking right across from the entrance and were set. It's not too expensive to go inside of the grounds, which gives you access to many acres of gardens (sometimes just trees and grass, sometimes roses and other flowers) and a multitude of fountains. The fountains are honestly the coolest part of this whole place. They are gravity fountains, like at Versailles. They have been operating for hundreds of years, with some refurbishment of pipes and whatnot, but they work exactly the same way as they did when originally designed - which is pretty darn amazing. They basically use varying sizes of pipes (wider or narrower diameter) to get different height/strength flows. We saw a fountain that had many jets creating a pyramid, some fountains that have cool statues in the centers of them, simple fountains with cherub-like babies with split scaly, fish tails, the terraces of fountains in front of the palace, and the cool trick fountains (that kids LOVE to play in). There are some signs directing you down lanes in the gardens to fountains, but we found the online maps to be better...if you know in advance you're going here and won't have internet access, I'd find the maps before going and take screen shots of your phone. We also paid to go into the main palace. The ticket line only sells tickets during certain hours, and be prepared to wait in a line for an hour or longer if you want a shot at getting any of them. Bring an umbrella to block the sun, and I absolutely would have died without my fan. Once you pay, follow the hoardes of people. If you have backpacks, you'll have to check them. No photos are allowed inside, but I would recommend you keep your nice cameras or other pricey valuables on you rather than leave them at the coat check if possible. They will make you grab shoe covers to wear in the coat check area, be sure to grab yours and put them on or you're not going in. Next, they will hand out these really convenient receivers for people to hear their tour guide. They were awesome because the tour guides didn't have to raise their voices at ALL for their group to hear them, so you could be around multiple groups and everyone would be pretty quiet, listening to their guides. Now, unfortunately, they didn't have any English speaking tour guides when we were there! But, that meant we were able to wander through the palace (it all flows in one direction from room to room), reading the signs at various spots in the room, which they conveniently had in both Cyrillic and English. Sometimes this was great because when a smaller room would get too crowded, we would gently work through the crowd on the edges and move ahead or lag behind so we had room to breathe. There are a couple of rooms that you must continuously walk through (no stopping!), probably because they're too narrow to allow for people to block the areas. As long as you keep slowly moving forward, you can take a minute to glance from side to side to take in the decor and furniture. There are murals, awesome glass/crystal chandeliers, cool pieces of furniture and awesome parquetry on the floors. After a bit, you'll feel immune to the opulence of the palace, and get the message - we're rich and can do whatever we want! But the crowds, small rooms, and lack of air conditioning can put a real damper on your level of enjoyment, depending on how sensitive you are about those things. Definitely take a fan with you. As you walk out, buy a nice soda from the gift shop, and it'll be a great boost to your energy levels.Personally, while it was a fantastic palace and a sight to see, I would have been just as happy to stay outside in the gardens, enjoying the fountains and air.

Amazing day in the park. This park is located outside of town and you need to take either a bus or a speed boat. I toke the speed boat, if was nice and fast and if you book business class you get a drink and a snack. Best beginning for going to this amazing park. You can spend hours walking there and observing the details but also the people there. The castle is also very impressive. At 11am they turn on the fountain with very dramatic Russian classical music.

Very rich, very pompous, very golden. Didn't visit the castle. To visit it you as a foreigner tourist have to be very, very early, cause every now and then the entrance is only for Russians. When we have been there the entrance for foreigners finished at 14:00. To go there by the Meteor (the boat) you have to be early at the Point of Lions or book it a day earlier. Turned out, could be booked. But highly recommend to go by boat cause the view from that side is worse it. Anyway the garden was beautiful and the views amazing. Even the garden only is a must see in St. Peterburg.
Knocks the socks off Versailles. I was amazed at the size and beauty of both the inside and grounds of this amazing Palace. In my mind it is better the the Palace of Versailles.

Not. We went to the lower gardens, they are nice but not super special. After we for lunch, next to the entrance of the gardens. When we wanted to go into the Palace we were told we needed to enter the gardens again in order to enter the palace. We were not allowed to enter with the ticket that we bought the same day, we needed to buy a new ticket for the gardens if we wanted to go to the palace! A couple overheard this and told us they also went to have lunch next to the entrance-exit of the garden and wanted to go back because they were with the boat. They were also not allowed back in with the ticket they purchases that same day! So to go back by boat to the center of St, Petersburg they needed to buy a new ticket for the gardens! We didnt enter the palace... however the gardens are ok.

Amazing Gardens. The 150 or so fountains all working by gravitational force are a master of engineering done in a period where there was no computers to plan and no sophisticated machinery to execute.Each fountains is unique and depict mythological figures. The surrounding gardens are so beautiful and all this going all the way down to the bay of Finland.Don't miss the pranks that were spread around rage grounds, this is clearly a fresh breeze from all the seriousness of that epoques.Unfortunately this palace was looted by the Nazis in WW2 , and who knows where the originals are hidden waiting to be found...

Best Palace. We saw many palaces but this was my favorite. Beautiful drive to Peterhoff. You need an afternoon to get the full effect though. Walk all the grounds and view the other homes, trick fountains, etc. Wear comfortable shoes!
Unbelievably beautiful buildings, grounds and fountains. Not to be missed stop on a St Petersburg visit. Impressive gravity fed fountains everywhere and immaculate grounds and gardens.

A stunning display of fountains.. The Grand Palace does not look all that grand as you approach it but as you enter the gardens you begin to appreciate the size and grandeur. Unfortunately the day we visited was very wet and blustery, but even so this is something not to be missed. Stunning!!

Beautiful Gardens and Natural Fountains. This is one of the Most Beautiful and Well Planned Gardens.The Fountains are AMAZING and there is NOT ONE PUMP - They are all Natural Gravity fed which is Truly Awesome.

Very busy. This is a very popular attraction so prepare for the crowds and decide what you want to see. The gardens are lovely and a good guide will make it even more interesting. Check the times of the fountain show.

Russian Verssailles. the palace is nice, but the garden is superb. with its 100 or so water fountains is something you don't see everyday. and because it was inspired by Versailles gardens in France it has a lightness untypical to Russian palaces, which tend to be a little 'heavy.' it's crowded at all times, but it's huge so there is room for everybody

Exquisite. We took a boat for like 5 euros from the centre of St Petersburg. The boat was very fast and pretty. The Palace itself is grandiose, stunning. Especially with the fountains and the gardens, it makes for a very good walk. A must if you are in Russia.

Gorgeous!. This is a beautiful place to visit . The gardens are spacious lawns but not as many floral gardens as I anticipated. Lines to get on the hydrofoil boats can be long so try to que in early like 10:00. You buy the boat ticket separately. When you get there you buy an entrance ticket to the gardens. Ticket to go into palace is an additional charge.
Grand views !!!. We toured the Small Peterhof Palace and gardens and fountains.So lucky to have a sunny day that day. Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful !!!

2nd most popular site in St Petersburg, you must visit. The palace is very historical, what is disappointing is the amount of damage done by WWII. It was looted and they are in the process of renovation in several rooms. There is still a lot to see. You will need a guide to see the palace without the masses. So much history, make sure you walk the gardens.

A MUST SEE!!!!. The Peterhof gardens are absolutely spectacular! One of the best sites in the city! Make sure you have a few hours to spend. Get a ticket to go to the "caves/grotto" it allows you to go closer to all the waterfalls - the tour is only in Russian but you can still go and see it!

My Favorite Fountains in The World. THere is nothing quite like the amazing fountains here. they are breathtaking. The size and scope and details are remarkable. I would recommend you spend your time outside because it is a unique sight.
Big green Park. The park is huge with many different water fountains and gold statues. Lots of people even in a rainy day.

The witching hour. At 11 am the theme for St Pete is played and all the fountains start simultaneously. The park is a wonder to walk through, yhou need to be with a guide to be aware of the Czar's sense of humor to insure you stay dry. Highly recommend SPB tours
Amazing fountains. It is amazing how all the fountains work without the use of any pumps. Beautiful grounds. It was rainy the day we went but great visit nevertheless.

Impressive . Unfortunately it was raining when we visited but that didn't take anything away from the beauty of the gardens and magnificent fountains, they left us breathless. There are just so many of them adorned with gold figures and cascades, they are truly beautiful. The public areas of the palace are not as grand as the winter palace and it was rather chaotic with tourists but the gardens are definitely worth visiting.

Gorgeous palce. I took the hydrofoil over, which is a nice ride and alternative to the drive. The place is huge, and of course very busy with tourists. Despite that, it is incredibly beautiful and large enough to spread out so you don't feel crowded. You should allow at least 2-3 hours for the grounds. I did not go inside, our guide said that the rooms aren't in great shape, and our time is better spent at Catherine's summer place.

Glamorous. This UNESCO World Heritage Site is a glamorous palace but a very busy place to visit. Herded from room to room like cattle. Not a pretty sight. Best done with a tour group with an early access. The gardens has the world’s largest system of fountains and are spacious and beautiful. A wondrous site to see is the daily opening of the fountains with the music playing (11:00 AM) . This unique fountain system was designed in the 18th century and doesn't require the use of any pumps to operate the fountains. Marvelous!
Great place to visit. Very nice place to visit and a must-see when in StP! Unfortunately, I had a rainy day, still very nice and good for a 2-5 hour visit.

Best part of our trip!. My family all agreed we loved this fountain park the best out of our Baltic Sea trip. You will not see anything quite like this place. It was rainy the day we were there, yes it rains in June! We had rain coats so make sure you always have one or an umbrella ready. The good thing about the rain is there were not as many people there. The Hermitage was packed that day as we later leaned from a fellow cruise passenger. So we had a great time despite the rain.

Fantastic Pakace. A fantastic place to spend a few hours walking and enjoying the well-kept parks and imaginative fountains. We have not visited the palace but only its parks and fountains.Place deserves to be visited.

Peterhof palace. The gardens of the Peterhof are the real treasure, the palace is rather narrow and one ends up being herded through with barely enough time to look at anything. I thought that it was a waste of an additional 600 Roubles and extra queuing. It was all over in 30 minutes, whilst we were able to enjoy the gardens for six hours even on an overcast day with wind and drizzle. I will never visit the palace again, but will definitely go to the lower gardens again.

Wow! Definitely a must see. We were in St. Petersburg two days from a Cruise ship. Day two we visited the Peterhof Palace and gardens. This is an extraordinary palace with grand fountains and gardens that are quite spacious. The palace itself is beautiful and gives quite a glimpse into the times of imperial Russia. Honestly it took my breath away! Our guide was very knowledgeable and able to answer all sorts of questions. The gardens are expansive and absolutely beautiful with elaborate fountains found nearly at every turn. Several "trick" fountains can also be found on the grounds so be careful where you decide to sit for a spell. Apparently Peter the Great was quite the trickster ! Hopefully you have time to stroll at your leisure there is so much to see - the main fountains are turned on at 11:00 and its spectacular. All the fountains on the property are fed by gravity there are no pumps involved - that in of itself is quite remarkable !

Water water everywhere. We only visited the park to see the gardens, cascades and fountains. Less than keen to have further close encounters with officious staff meant that this was a pleasing alternative despite continual rain. Dressed appropriately the weather did not deter although it was a challenge when it came to lunch. We overcame this by purchasing street food we could eat whilst standing and holding an umbrella as there was little chance of a seat inside a food outlet. Although some distance from St Petersburg this is a must visit site. Be there in time for the display of the fountains to music accompaniment which in our case was 11:00am.

Peterhof and it's magnificent fountains. Beautiful Peterhof set by the sea and renown for it's magnificent fountains. Wrecked during the last war, it has been painstakingly restored to its gilded glory.

skip the palace in favour of the fountains. The gardens at Peterhof with their numerous fountains are worth a visit, if the weather is nice. Sunshine does make the gilded statues look more interesting.However I visited as part of a group tour and ended up shuffling through the palace first. Unless you get there at a time with no groups (almost impossible) it is definitely not worth going inside. You'll just be stuck among large groups of other tourists, slowly making their way through narrow pathways in each room. Hard to escape if you want to move faster - and even harder to take a closer look if you are interested in something. Most of the rooms are overloaded with gilded stuff in 'rokoko' style and you are not allowed to take photographs. Some people were close to fainting because of the sticky air and there is no place to rest until you get out again. Go to Katherine Palace instead, which is more roomy, so you can get away from the crowds - and you can photograph as much as you like.Take the Hydrofoil back to Hermitage - much bigger than bus or car.

Spectacular. Amazing place based on Versailles created by Peter the greatThe water features are stunning, the steps down and the fountains are a sight to behold. The golden domes and glittering palace in the background make it truly beautiful. Watch out for pickpockets while taking photos!

A beautiful glimpse into the life in Imperial Russia. I loved Peterhof. The house was spectacular and the gardens and fountains were spectacular. It was a great visit to see how the rulers of Imperial Russia lived. We were om a tour from our cruise ship. wish we had had more time to enjoy the gardens.

Beatiful palace and gardens. The Palace, fountains and gardens are both beautiful and impressive. It is a must see and you should plan giving the gardens plenty of time.However, as stated elsewhere, you are herded through the part of the Palace that is open too quickly and the crowds can be terrible.

Fantastic....... Probably the one of the greatest fountain displays in the world, with one of the greatest backdrops. However, also one of the busiest, esp when there are a few cruise ships in, but you still have to go. but there is so much else to see in the park. The emmensity is staggering, all the fountains use gravity not pumped, and the gold is just beautiful in the sunlight. there is also many other things to see in the palace grounds, dont miss the surprise trick fountains

Stunning. This is a must see if you are in St Petersburg. The gardens are lovely ,(it helps if it is sunny) but when the fountains go on it is pure magic. We was lucky as we got sun and a music group was performing. Lots of gold and colour in garden, there are places where you can get away from the crowds and take a quiet walk.

Well worth the visit. We visited the Grand Palace as part of a tour from a cruise ship. As a result the time was limited, but the upside was the early entry prior to the crowds being let in. The viewing within the Palace was quite good, but was a tad too fast to take it all in. Rules are that you cannot take photos inside, so its just memories and the books that you can buy.The gardens are well worth a visit, but again we did not have enough time to really take it all in. The 'turning on' of the fountain is a high light, but unfortunately there is a lot of pushing and inconsiderate actions by other tourists to take the edge off the viewing. If you want a clear photo/video of the fountains best to wait 30 to 45 minutes after the fountains are turned on (ie take a walk through the gardens in the meantime), and return once most of the tourists are gone and plenty of great photos without others in the pic are available.Definitely worth a visit.,

Arrival by Hydrafoil sets the theme. We took the Hydrafoil from the city to the palace.From arriving the walk up beside the Chanel to the fountains in front of the palace just got better as we got closer. The fountains come on at 11 am each day accompanied by music. Get there early to get a good photo. Watch you pockets and bags in this area as it is very busy.After the music has finished the crouds disperse through the gardens. The gardens have some interesting surprise so it would be wrong of me to tell you so go ahead and explore. It's a must to have a guide here as you need to understand the place.It's beautiful walking is easy there are steps but there are ramps for wheel chairs etc.

The Palace of Palaces. I don't even particularly like palaces. I probably wouldn't have even gone here if we hadn't been on a small tour of friends. Yet, I was amazed. Not only is Peterhof beautiful in its architecture, including the outdoor grounds and fountains, but it is also one of those select buildings that Russia has chosen to perfectly preserve. No doubt more are coming but clearly Peterhof was among the first.In fact, it may be the case that one of the reasons this building is in pristine form is that Prime Minister Putin, at a time when he was in the lower echelon, was put in charge of renovating it. No doubt it has remained close to his heart, even today. Indeed, some of the gold leaf is covered with Lucite to guard it. Visitors need to remove their shoes and wear paper slippers to protect the floors. Photography is forbidden here (you can't even pay to do it), so I had to purchase a book.Each room has a clear theme. Most incredible was the Amber Room. Wow! Having been to places such as Versailles and the Schonbrunn Palace, I have to tell you that Peterhof is in that class and beyond. Try to make it on a sunny day, so that you can also enjoy the grounds and the spectacular fountains.Our group had a guide and, given the crowds and hectic confusion, I would highly recommend hiring one. Despite the chaos, our guide managed to get us in, around, and out onto the grounds with excellent dispatch. I really don't know how you could do without it. Since we had a van and driver at our disposal, we drove out here rather than taking the hydrofoil.

Amassing garden and Fontaine . If you visit St. Petersburg you should go to Peterhof palace. Just the garden is amassing. You can really imaging being in the tzars time.The fountains and the luxurious garden definitely worth the visit.Take your time and enjoy the relaxing atmosphere.
grand palace. Beautiful, ornate, and luxurious and worth the visit. But lots of tourists and felt like I was herded through like cattle. Would like to have spent more time.

Staggeringly beautiful, but get there early. Peterhof has been covered by many TV programmes but nothing can prepare you for the breath-taking opulence of the place. My wife and I both commented " you can see why there was a revolution". We visited as part of a cruise ship tour, so only scratched the surface but what we saw touch our breath away.But...get there early. We were lucky to be one of the first groups to arrive but by the time we had finished the palace there were quite literally thousands of people there. Gardens are beautiful with dozens of fountains but Kodak moments are rare due ot the sheer number of people milling around to get 'that' picture.Gift shops take $ and Euro ( I think they would take you grandma if she was valuable) so local currency is not critical). They also take credit cards although I personally would use mine outside of the official Peterhof shops.

Extraordinary . Beautiful lower gardens with innumerable gilded fountains (which seemingly use the natural flow of water and work without pumps ) were amazing..though the place was extremely crowded, we enjoyed our walk right upto the edge of the lake....the upper gardens are also a must visit, espacially because there are no tourists there and you can sit and enjoy the grandness of the creator's vision
Breathtaking . If you have just one day in Saint Petersburg, pick this attraction in a private tour. You might need 3 hours to really enjoy the experience there.

Long hot line ups but absolute incredible inside!. The amount of gold, mirrors, silk walks, paintings, etc are overwhelming. Hot both inside and out but worth it!!No photos are allowed and everyone abides by this. They give you slippers to put over your shoes and all bags are checked. There are several types of tickets: one for the ride there on the hydrofoil, one for the garden area, one for inside tour, etc, etc so best to plan ahead.

Great day trip from St Petersburg - book boat in advance. Book the boat in advance to ensure you have the timings you want. Allow 5 hours round trip which is enough to explore the gardens and house. The audio guide is a long winded and the display boars in each room are adequate. The staff keenly usher you through each room and in places you do not have much time to linger and marvel.Beautiful setting and the main fountain is captivating.Thanks for the vote if you found this helpful.
Amazing fountains. The garden with water fountains is amazing. We did not visit the palace as our guide said it is not worth a visit unless you have a particular interest.

It's a queuefest. All the other reviews will tell you what the place is like. Totally overboard, but spectacular.What spoiled it for us was the organistion. Every part of the place is a separate ticket and a separate queue. Actually, two queues, one to get the ticket and one to enter. You literally arrive on the jetty and have to queue to buy a ticket even to get off the jetty. Then another ticket for the main palace, and so it goes. We literally spent 30% of the day there in queues.The palace is spectacular, but we were caught time and time again behind or in tour groups. The roped in walkway is so narrow that you cannot get past them and the experience is like being in a crowded metro train the whole way round.On balance, we would not have gone if we knew what the experience is actually like. Perhaps out of season, of with an orgznised tour, the experience is not so negative.
Great Parks and Best of Quility for the time.. Great for history and to see only the best items aro7nd the world were used for each room.. lovely parks to rest. Take a lunch and enjoy.

Beautiful . Had a guided tour around this and the gardens. You need to make sure you leave yourself plenty of time. The palace is very beautiful and interesting history. Just one word of warning. When we went it was a warm day and inside the palace at times it was stifling so just be prepared. Certainly worth going to see.

Beautiful in the summer!. What a grand palace this was! I couldn't believe all of the gold statues. It was very rich looking and I felt completely transported to a different time. There is so much more to the grounds so go in the summer and spend a few hours walking all around.

Gorgeous Palace and Grounds. We went to Peterholf Gardens and the Palace. We went inside the Palace which was Gorgeous but Bummer they would not let us take pictures brought the Book and the Grounds were Gorgeous too. A must See.

Typical Granduer overboard. The whole palace and grounds is another example of granduer overboard. It is however lovely to walk through the grounds and view the large waterfalls displays and the grand setting of the palace at the head of the waterway and atop the hill. A lovely trip if you go by hydrophoyal

Magnificent. Visited Peterhof on an organised tour. It took about an hour to get there from Saint Petersburg as the traffic in town is horrendous. We arrived just before 11 am in time to see the fountains switched on. Nice to see but not an essential part of the trip. The house is magnificent and the scale of the wealth is obscene given the poverty of the people of Russia at the time. Some of the rooms are so over the top that they are almost ugly but still magnificent. Lots of pillars, walls and ceilings are covered in gold. The collection of Faberge and other jewels are superb. I would recommend going on an organised tour as it makes getting tickets so much easier. If you go on your own please have a guide in the house or you will miss so much.
The Grand Palace visit. Such a beautiful and well maintained National Treasure, in my opinion more breath-taking than Versailles!
Amazing palace!. Absolute must-see! The ballroom was the first thing our tour group went into and it's just amazing!!

Absolute marvel !. Give yourself 3-4 hours to explore this majestic piece of architecture. The lower ground with the beautiful fountains is spectacular. The upper gardens are also no less. The scale and intricacy of landscape design and also of architecture is a sight to behold. If possible try to use Hydrofoil to reach the destination. Its too far to take a cab ride, or any other mode of transport.

Spectacular when the fountains are on. Peterhof is also known as the Summer Palace. The inside is as grand as you would expect. However when the fountains are put on at 11 a.m., they are quite a show. They come in sizes as huge as an acre or as small as a patch of cobblestones where fountains are hidden and when a person steps on the right stone, water would shoot out unexpectedly! The gardens are spectacular especially on a sunny day.
Beautiful palace and gardens!. The palace is unbelievably ornate and exquisite. Each room is unique. The gardens and fountains are equally beautiful

A dream come true. We spend an undoubtedly worthwhile day with Helen ( our guide) away from the city in Peter’s Versailles, overlooking the Gulf of Finland. The driver of the Jaguar town-car dropped us off at the VIP gate of Peterhof palace after an hour and that was just the beginning. The grand cascades leading from the palace down to the sea, are flanked by dozens of water spouting gilded statues and the gardens were more than I could have ever imagined. Peter the Great loved and lived for surprises, in form of sudden ‘showers’, or otherwise.
Grand Palace and Gardens. This is a must see but once again go with a guide. There is so much to see that it requires a further visit. The gardens and fountains are a must on a sunny day.
Over the Top. Stunning Palace, but the most impressive in the palace is the Amber Room and the history behind it..

Just fantastic. We visited out of season and the fountains were turned off for the winter. However on arrival the fountains were being testedbso we got the benefit. This was just as good as the other main attractions
Beautiful Palace, Good Food Park. After visiting The Grand Palace, we were very hungry. It has many foods Kiosk, parkfood there. Help us a lot. Good taste...Value for money

Great palace, beautiful fountains and grounds, and bureacracy like you've never seen it. The Peterhof Palace and it's fountains and grounds are a must do---absolutely beautiful! The fountains come on at 11am, and you'll want to see them running. Lots of different fountains, and since it was early May when we were there, plenty of pretty flowers. You can easily spend hours just seeing the fountains. There are other little buildings to see besides the main Palace, but most where not open for the summer yet, so you'll have to check the open dates for extra stuff. You don't see that many rooms inside the palace---but the ones you do visit are really opulent and lovely. Getting There: You can do this on your own, you don't have to pay a tour company. You can catch a boat right by the Winter Palace for a 30 minute ride to Peterhof (we did), or you can catch a bus. The price for our boat tickets was pretty reasonable. The boat drops you off at the end of the Lower Park, then you walk through it up to the Palace. I think the buses must drop you off at the Upper Park--we never saw where they stop, and I don't know how long the bus ride is.Good luck getting your tickets! This is were the bureaucracy goes crazy. The Peterhof is split into the Lower Park, the Palace itself, and the Upper Park. You have to buy a separate ticket for each thing---and frustratingly, you buy then from separate ticket booths so you get to stand in line multiple times. PALACE TICKETS: THEY DIVIDE THE DAY INTO TIMES WHEN THEY SELL ONLY TO RUSSIANS, AND TIMES WHEN THEY SELL ONLY TO NON RUSSIANS (different pricing). Don't get in line at the wrong time! The signs are useless, they don't explain this. We waited for one hour in the Palace line (a single person in a single ticket booth sold tickets to hundreds of people). When we got to the front of the line, the guard outside told us they were only selling to Russians in that time slot. Fortunately, when we said how long we had waited she let us and 2 Germans behind us in. But then the woman at the ticket counter almost refused us---in the end she sold us just the Palace ticket, but she wouldn't sell us special collection tickets or any of the other extras. And the Upper Park is, from what we could tell, impossible to visit if you came from the Lower Park first. There is a high fence all around it. The turnstiles let people from the Upper Park go through to the Lower Park as long as they show there ticket, but we could not enter the Upper Park there. They wouldn't even tell us where to go to buy a ticket. I actually had a woman minding the turnstile scream "Nyet!"at me and turn away from me like I wasn't there anymore. So we never got to see anything in the Upper Park.All that said, as frustrating as it was trying to get tickets and never seeing the Upper Park, what we DID see at the Peterhof was totally worth it and I would do it again. What a beautiful setting, and man those fountains were spectacular!

We only saw the fountain park.. This palace was beautiful, however the statues and fountains were more than outstanding. Tours go on even if it is raining and it was the day we were there. But that didn't spoil the beauty of it all. The golden statues were spectacular, especially when the sun peeped out following a windy stormy fountain park. Loved the park too. Do make this one of your stops as it was one of our favorites.

If you're visa-free, maybe pass this palace up.. We went to SBP visa-free, which only allows 72 hours in the country. Peterhof was spectacular and gorgeous, but it takes a lot of time to get there and to explore the grounds. We went by hydrofoil boat which was really fun. It was a beautiful experience, but there's just so much to do in SPB with a limited amount of time, and Peterhof requires at least half the day to really enjoy it. There are lots of other palaces and fountains in the city, though not hardly as grand. If seeing Peterhof is a priority for you, definitely go, but if there are lots of other things on your list, Peterhof can be for your next visit!
The Gardens are worth a visit. Created by Peter the Great the fountains are amusing. Some of them are even tricks. Engineering marvels. The palace itself is a modern reconstruction.
One of our favorites!. We could've spent 4 hours walking around this incredible Palace. The history of the fountains and the beauty of the grounds made this a highlight of our trip.

Amazing waterworks.. Another day, another line-up. Spectacular when the fountains come on at 11.00 am.- very tiring tour though. Be prepared to get wet if it rains or if the wind is blowing when the fountains come on! Expect to have to buy a book about the Peterhof if you want to show anyone the interior of the Palace as picture-taking is not allowed.

A Beautiful Palace. This palace is spectacular. It is about an hour from downtown St. Petersburg but well worth the trip. We were on a tour lead my TJ Travel. E visited the grounds first, toured the inside, the walked through the park with many fountains the to the waterfront for our trip back to the city via hydrofoil.This is a must visit when traveling to St. Petersburg
GORGEOUS!. Worth the trip out of the city to see this summer palace, fountains and gardens. Beware of crowds. Lovely day
A sense of time and place. You really get a sense of Peter the Great and his court here. Beautiful and peaceful gardens and water features on the Gulf of Finland. Do not miss.

Be sure to get return ferry ticket. 3 rating because who knew that 8 ferries could be full for 2 solid hours. I was stuck there and almost missed my all my classmates leaving from the hotel in the late afternoon. So be wary if you have timed plans. But this place is beautiful. Get lost in the gardens, starring at the water fountains and people watching for hours. Worth every ruble. If you're a student they have student discount.

Make time to see it.. Well worth the trip. I'm only going to write a short review. While the online stuff I read tells you to only come by boat to experience the best presentation, I think that arrival by car would be fine too. Yes, seeing the palace growing bigger as it is approached is pretty cool, but Uber would be a lot less than the boat, and you can always save the approach part until after you've explored the grounds and are walking back to ground transportation. We needed another few hours at the place to do it justice, but we simply didn't have the place to add any--we had some issue come up earlier in the day. Still, the 3 hours spent there didn't feel too rushed. Our daughter may disagree. I'm afraid to investigate what spectacles we missed...Something needs to be done to make this place more efficiently run with the ticketing process. I get the concept that there are those who only see the grounds, but to have multiple ticket booths and vouchers that need to be wchsnged for tickets is unnecessary. We were amused by the booties we had to put over our shoes. Slippery walking. This shows how revered this place is. Haven't ever seen that in the States. We were disappointed that the audio guide in English wasn't available. My wife is blind, and was hoping to get more from the time than just a walk on my side while I read the signs while Russian language groups ushered us along.I gestured toward an item while trying to describe it to my wife. This was unintended; I speak with my hands, I guess. Anyway, I set off a motion detector alatm when my hand went too close (it crossed beyond the rope). The place is run by retirement aged women. Two of them escorted me to the next room, reset the system and that was that. Tone was assertive, not angry. I have no idea what was actually said.Gold, lacquer, silk, parquet, porcelain and grandeur. Portraits of important dead people who lived lives clearly without any knowledge of how everyone else lives. Learning that Catherine the whatever-th would be painted into pictures of Minerva was cool. I loved the woodworking.We'd go again should the opportunity present itself.

Overwhelming. We arrived at the Grand Palace by hydrofoil and so the first part of our visit was to the palace grounds and the extraordinary fountains which are both beautiful and fascinating in their variety. On a sunny day you could spend at least four or five hours just in the gardens.The palace itself is grand and also overwhelming with too many highlights to mention here.

Unimaginable Opulence. I've been to Versailles, Schonbrunn palace, and other palaces around the world, but this place out did them all. From a tourist 's eye, it was truly a sight to behold, but at the same time I could not but to think about what it cost to the rest of the country. It must have been like the whole country served one family while they were starving... But that's another story. The palace, the fountains, and the gardens are magnificent. We were in a group and did not have to wait much at all which I was very glad. There was a long line of people that came by themselves waiting to get in. Paying a tour guide that has the fast track should be a must to see this palace.

The Fountains Are Breathtaking. The highlight of this tour is the fountains and gardens. Try to pick a sunny (non-windy) day to enjoy them at their best. Be prepared for long lines during the palace tour. It is extremely busy and some of the rooms seems to get backed up. In addition, they require you to check large back packs and bags...which backed things up as well. Otherwise, it was a terrific tour that our family really enjoyed.

Of Course A Must St. Petersburg Visit. It was a rainy day and did the indulgence of a personal guide/driver become a great decision. It's best not to travel in large groups and watch out for your photo options being overshadowed by our friends from the PRC. Opulence, splendor, more gold, statues and the impressive engineering behind the water fountains. A sheer delight visit even on a rainy day.
Riviera Travel Tour. A must see when in St. Petersberg. Arrive before 11:00 to see the start of the fountains in the gardens - well worth seeing.
The Peterhof Palace. It's the same as Peterhof Palace with so much to see and do Easily spend your full day there .It's Stunning .
Wonderfull . The palace is very very nice especially fallingd system of the water around the palaca need to see they did it by mechanic not use any electric or motor

Lovely gardens and amazing amber room. Be sure to walk through the gardens as well as visiting the palace. Daria from TJ Travel managed to get us in few minutes before the crowd as we had two wheelchair users in our party. It made such a difference being able to view the exhibits without having to negotiate hundreds of other tourists trying to see the same thing at the same time. There is a wheelchair accessible rest room and a lift to get you to the right floor. The amber room is an amazing sight. Not necessarily to modern taste but it's been lovingly and expensively restored.Please note only wheelchairs with white/grey tyres are allowed in the palace and protective shoe covers are compulsory for those walking.
Don't miss. All the buildings in St Petersburg are impressive. Amazing that they were not destroyed by the Communists. Gold is still on the walls.
A fest for the eyes. Very very special place. One moves back couple of centuries and it is fantastic. I particularly enjoiyed the garden and the tzar's dinner table arrangement.

Amazingly well restored Palace, pity about the lack of information and huge queues. When you see the pictures of the devastated Palace after WWII and compare it with this beautifully restored Palace you can but be amazed. For this I would give Peterhof an excellent rating, but for our overall experience, it would be closer to poor, mind you the dreadful weather did not help and this was mid June.We arrived to get tickets for the Hydrofoil at 0915, but the first one available was at 1100 so we decided to book for 2 days later at 1000 with Astra. We arrived to join a small queue but as we went to get on the boat we were held back until all the window seats were taken. They pointed to something on our ticket that said we could not board until the end of the queue, we never figured out what it was. Also there was a business class cabin but we had not been offered this. A good start to the day!We arrived at Peterhof at 1030 to heaving seas, it took 3 men to heave one of the larger ladies onto the quay!!As another contributor has said you then pay 600 roubles pp to get into the grounds, but cannot pay for any of the other places at this point. It was now drizzling unpleasantly so we walked towards the main building to get tickets. On the way up was found crowds of people waiting to see the fountains start at 1100, so decided to wait with them. My husband and a Russian entertained those who were bilingual in the crowd, with a conversation in their own languages, the only common word being vodka!! The view up to the Palace was awe inspiring with all the gold statues and fountains. Sure enough the fountains started at 1100 but we couldn't work out why everyone had waited as they then stayed on all day!!At 1115 we joined a queue to buy tickets for the main Palace, ticket office opens at 1030 said the signs. After 20 minutes the queue had not moved and a young Beleruss man explained that the office did not open until 1200. As 1200 neared just about every Russian in the queue had friends or relatives join them so the queue in front got longer and it took a while to start moving! We were given tickets that were valid for 1430 whereas the Belerussians got in straight away. We foolishly thought that this must be because there was an English guide at 1430.Having stood in the queue for so long I now needed the lavatory, we followed the WC signs and an obviously desperate American girl only to find the biggest queue I have ever seen. My husband went off to the gents, and then came back and waved to me. The desperate American girl was just coming out of the gents and 3 large Russian ladies and myself went in. It was perfectly decent you just had to walk past a line of men facing the wall, however by the time I came out there was a female cleaner who prevented any other ladies from entering.By now it was starting to rain quite heavily so we jumped on the train. We should have bought tickets but my husband gave the 700roubles to the ticket checker chap, he accepted reluctantly. The train went into the lower park and past about 3 buildings, one a farm, there was a continuous commentary in Russian. Other than wasting time until our Palace tour it was not worth 350 roubles each. On a nice day it would have been great to walk there and get away from the crowds.We then went for our Palace tour. We just had to fight our way round amongst the groups. Maybe we should have got a private guide but the holiday had been last minute and we had not been able to get the tours we wanted on the days we were free.The weather was deteriorating, but the Bath House had been recommended on Tripadvisor and at least it was out of the rain. it was another 350 roubles each or maybe 300. The first building was not that interesting, the Japanese Garden OK and the Bath House with its communal shower about the only thing that made it maybe worthwhile.We decided to try to get an earlier hydrofoil back, at 1700. However Astra hydrofoils had stopped running altogether, due to the weather and we had to book and pay again with another company, their next tickets were for 1800. Astra would not give us a refund as we had the tickets but the coupon was missing. It turned out that the maid in the Hotel had put it in a drawer so I had not seen it was missing. we did eventually get the refund.There was a tented cafe near to the dock so we were able to take shelter whilst we waited.In summary - a great place magnificent Palace but they need to do better at managing the crowds, providing maps and more information (ideally in languages other than Russian as well) and provide more toilets.

A favorite for Russians and foreign tourists alike!. You won't find a Russian telling you they didn't like this park / residence. I recommend taking an hydrofoil (meteori in Russian) to go there, ~30 min from the center. If you're Russian, take your ID with you for a discount.

Take the boat to see Peterhof!. You must take the boat out to see Peterhof, and it's worth the trip, including a stroll the gardens, and the water fountains. Prepare to get wet, you'll get surprised by some hidden fountains! This is reminiscent of going to Versailles in France.

Peterhof Palace. There were more crowds here than at the Hermitage. Once inside be prepared to place cloth booties over your shoes before going through the palace. These booties make your footing slippery so watch making sudden movements especially on steps. Be aware that there's no photography inside the Place and because of the crowd size you won't be allowed to linger in any of the rooms. The grounds are amazing and definitely worth wandering around. We used Allah Tours and I can highly recommend using them to tour the St. Petersburg area.

Overrated, overcrowded, overpriced, incomprehensibly organized.. This was a big disappointment! We had looked at the website for information and found what we could. We knew of individual times for entry. We were not allowed to purchase tickets to the palace on-line, however. Why? We had no idea. We took the hydrofoil and arrived at 11:30 am, to complete chaos. First, we had to pay park entry. One can purchase no other tickets at the entrance. But, the confusion and lack of information is staggering. We were provided no map, nor could we find one anywhere we asked. Once we purchased the park entry ticket we went straight to the palace to purchase the entry ticket for it. The line was two hours long and that was the only window of time until later in the day. So, we wandered the park only to find many other options of buildings to see, all requiring a high fee, especially the church. We inquired about how to purchase a combined ticket but no one speaks English anywhere. The best we could figure out is that there is no combined ticket. Everywhere we went we saw people trying to figure out what to do and not paying a separate entry fee for the other buildings because the fees are exorbitant. So, we entered none of these buildings and came back to get in line for purchasing tickets for the afternoon entry time. We discovered the on-line information to be incorrect and found a line for individuals that was allowed in with the groups. We chatted with a Russian in this line who complained that even he had not been able to figure it out. He had waited in the first line for an hour and a half and not been allowed to buy a ticket. It is inexcusable but we finally realized that only groups are welcome here. Entry for individuals is made as difficult as possible in order to discourage them. And, to top it all off, the “free” upper gardens are not free at all. Once you have entered the lower gardens you cannot leave and return. But, the only way to see the upper gardens is to leave. So, no one who takes the water route can see them without paying two entry fees. Ridiculous! Yes, there are fountains and nice grounds, but they were not worth the trip. Neither was the palace. Once you’re inside, it is overcrowded; you are squeezed through along with large guided groups so you can hardly get a chance to see anything, though the wholly re-created interiors are splendid. Even the tour groups looked bored, and were going so quickly through the palace, that they could not have enjoyed the harried experience either.Save your sanity and go to another palace.
Gardens and fountains are great. The Grand Palace is a nice place to visit. There are some stairs required to get to the main garden area. It will take 60 to 90 minutes to walk the grounds.

Breathtaking gardens and palace premises. A visit well worth it! It is far from St Petersburg and at least half a day has to be budgeted. Though some rooms are out of bounds now, there is enough of attractons to see and witness the life styles of the Czars!One can go by Taxi and return by Hydrofoil straight to St Petersburg Hermitage jetty. The gardens lead straight to a jetty on the sea.
The Lower Gardens. Take the hovercraft (1200 roubles roundtrip) and pay 700 roubles for the lower garden. Worth even penny. Jawdopping gold statues.

Wonderful grounds. We took the hydrofoil and spent a beautiful sunny day wandering the grounds. It turned out the palace was closed (last Tuesday of the month) but there is so much to see in the gardens that we did not miss the palace tour. (We saw Katherine's palace earlier in the trip, and they all start to look alike anyway.)

Hydrofoil - Not as cool as I thought. I thought I could avoid the queue and save time by purchasing the Lower Park entrance tickets online in advance, but the queue for hydrofoil (the more popular mean of transportation from winter embankment to Peterhof during summe time) caught me by surprise. I waited for more than one hour before I could board the hydrofoil. On the other hand, queue at Lower Park was short. Despite many of the reviews I read recommended taking hydrofoil during summer time, I personally think metro + bus / mini bus is not bad too (I tried this mean for my return trip), because it's cheaper (R105 vs R750 per head), much shorter waiting time, plus there's actually not much scenery along the sea route to Peterhof.Lower Park and the fountains are beautiful.
Make it happen...one of the best if not in the world.. Witness the expectacular fountains of Peterhof. An engineering marvel? The buildings and the grounds are superb . Jawbreaking....

You'll never believe your eyes. Jaw Dropping beautiful!. We landed here by chance. After having a long walk to look at amazing collection at hermitage, we thought of relaxing on the boat ride which was right across the exit. The boat ride was wonderful and after 40 minutes we were dropped at a pier where we were asked to buy tickets and enter a park. We had no clue that we have reached Peterhof which we had striked off our list because we were told that it's too far. We bought the tickets and assuming it to be a garden, thought of just strolling for a bit. When we were closer to the beautiful golden fountain, our walking pace increased as we were just dumbstruck with the beauty of the fountains. The place was highly clean !! and the sculptures were shining gold... as if they were just made. A must visit!

Most romantic and beautiful palaces. Most romantic and beautiful palaces out of plenty in st petersburg. The usp is fountains and huge park. The architecture and restoring the various rooms of the palace os praiseworthy
Peterhof palace. Wow this his is one amazing palace, you have to see it to believe it I recommend a tour by Alla you will not regret it it was amazing
NOT JUST ANOTHER PALACE. In a beautiful City full of history the Grand Palace stands out from the restStunning design with some unique artefactsIncluded on our tour and a delight to visit

Russians Love Gold. The Russian noble certainly know how to flaunt their wealth. This palace's best feature however is the massive fountain features, all of which are driven by gravity instead of pumps. Even in the rain we enjoyed walking the grounds. It is worth a trip if you are not already burned out on palaces.

Golden Age.... Peterhof or the Grand palace is a must visit when in St petersburg, You can reach the palace by taking a boat in front of the hermitage museum ... the architecture of the Gardens and palace is a small replica of Versailles palace in France. The gardens and fountains are spectaculars, everything is immense ... even you can rent costumes from a shop located in the garden and walk around.

Outstanding must do when in St Petersburg. Overawed by the size and splendour of Peterhof. We didn't really know what to expect as it was part of a tour from our cruise ship but were so glad we chose to visit. You could spend hours.
A Must Do. Yes it's a little drive, but SOOOOO worth it. Be sure not just to see the palace, but the grounds, gardens and fountains too. See it all!

My Favorite. The Palace sits above a beautiful park. It contains a suite of thirty halls and rooms decorated with gilded woodcarving, stucco, paintings and mirrors. The palace is beautiful and worth seeing but the show stopper is the Lower Park which covers a huge area between the shore of the Gulf of Finland and the terrace with the great cascade.We were there when they turned on all the fountains in the park and it is spectacular seeing the fountains come to life. When you explore the park make sure you see the Chessboard Hill and Golden Hill cascades and watch out for the trick fountains.

Golden gardens. If you are in St Petersburg take a hydrofoil out to the Peterhof Palace. leave plenty of time to stand and gasp at the gravity feed water cascade, and to walk around the extensive gardens and fountains. Unforgettable!
Waterfall and harbour . I love the Fountains collect a few pictures and also got one print The bunches of tree The birdsWe're adorable Food was very expensive and the entry ticket for 600

One of St. Petersburg's most famous and popular visitor attractions. The palace and park at Peterhof (also known as Petrodvorets) are often referred to as "the Russian Versailles", although the comparison does a disservice to the grandeur and scope of this majestic estate.

Stunning. This is located around 40 mins from St Petersburg in the district of Pushkin. Be careful of the huge crowds and pick pockets. Make sure you have plenty of batteries in your camera as you will use them. You normally go in and out the same way so if travelling with other people and you get separate, just meet back at the exit turnstile by the palace.
Peterhoff Gardens. Wow Bigger than thought. a must do trip. I did my tour with Marina WilsonTours. Easy to book online. Too hard to get to on your own.Pay the extra, get a guide.

Arrived on the hydrofoil just in time for the fountains to turn on with music. It was lovely. Only visited the grounds including the gardens, sculptures and fountains. It was a hot, sunny day so we were glad to be waking mostly in the shade of the beautiful trees much of the time.

Great Visit!. The grounds of Peterhof are simply the best thing in St Petersburg in my opinion and if you're going all the way out there you can't skip the palace! It's a quick tour through the building, we did it in about 45 min, but you can also tour the back gardens as well. Don't be fooled by the line outside, the ticket deal is inside to your left once you get in.

Magnificent Palace. It was great to travel by boat to our destination.As we later travel one and a half hour by road.The palace is most magnificent. The cascading fountains are engineering genius.The expanse of the ground is not for those who detest walking! The view from the top at Palace level is awesome.As you exit the ground,there is a reasonable cafe to have refreshment and food. Convenient available. Rubles is the currency.Or credit card is accepted.
Really amazing!. Nothing to say: you have to visit!Fountains and stairs and gardens and squirrels and ...Just expensive for tourists, tickets are much cheaper for russians.

We visited for just the gardens and fountains. We had seen Catherines Palace and Pavlovsk Palace and felt we did not need to see another palace.We arrived by hydrofoil which was very easy to catch and enjoyed the ride out to Peterhof. We had trouble communicating we only wanted a ticket for the gardens and ended up with a ticket for both. The gardens and fountains were very worthwhile and enjoyable. The crowds at the main fountains disappeared after 15 minutes of the fountains starting.Beware of the invisible fountains that go on a special times!

Trickery fountains. The facade to this palace is beautiful with the domes and the yellow color. The gardens have several dimensions including the trickery fountains from the humor of Peter the Great. Most of them have some connection to other famous areas such as the Vatican and Versailles. It sits on the Baltic Sea and the day we were there the winds were up to 50 mph and it was cold and rainy. It was still worth it and I would definitely recommend it amongst the site to see while in St. Petersburg. I would also recommend a tour guide. We had a very good one and she was very knowledgeable on the history and the traveling. It also allowed us to bypass the large groups.
Make sure to visit the grotto, since the water works are quite unique.. The grounds of this palace are astounding, but it was the water works that power the fountains that blew us away.

Russian Versailles. Petrodvorets palaces, fountains, and gardens are very beautiful. Hige territory to walk around. You can spend the whole day there especially if you will not buy tickets in advance, you will spend a lot of time in the queue, so advising to buy at least entrance ticket to the territory (Park) through the internet.

Worth the trip!. My friends and I traveled to Peterhof palace by boat. Costs 750 rubles for a 30minute enjoyable boat ride down the Neva river. From the boat it costs 700 to get into the grounds of Peterhof. They have many gardens and fountains around the palace and you can go right up to the palace. We saw Hermitage and Peterhof the same day so we were recommended to not go inside the palace because the Hermitage was the better one to see.. And we were done with palaces for the day.. the backyard at the palace is stunning. To get back into the city we went out to the bus stop across the street from Peterhof and took the bus to the metro. 35rubles a person on the little buses. And 35 rubles on the metro.

Glorious, glorious, glorious. Despite the swarms of offensive Chinese tourists, this is another absolute must see in St Petersburg. Not even the horrendous crowds could take away from its glory, and I was blessed with a sunny day.I would be inclined Ned to skip the interior and focus on the fountains and gardens - upper and lower. You can't take photos inside,mthevtour therevisvrushed to get the crowds through, and the guards watching for sneak photographers are like gulag relics. But the outside is just glorious - one of the world's great sites and sights..

Gorgeous!!!. If you go to St. Petersburg, you have to visit Peterhof. A gorgeous palace with a stunning fountains and large garden. Just a sight of the fountains and the garden alone will take you at least an hour to walk and enjoy the view. The best way to get there is by hydrofoil which run every 30 minutes from the pier with lions.

Fountains, beauty and elegance. The whole grounds and other buildings and fountains make this a truly interesting place to visit. We took a hydrofoil to get out there and that itself was fun. There are so many fountains and it was amazing to learn that water pressure from flowing water higher up outside of here drive them via gravity.
Grand Palace. The grounds on this property are amazing with its gold statues and spectacular fountains. We did not go inside the palace, but were in awe of the manicured grounds.

Incrediblely Beautiful. This was Tsar Peter the Great's summer palace located on the coast of the Gulf of Finland. It was part of the total rehabilitation of St. Petersburg for the 300th anniversary of the city. You find it hard to believe the amount of gold covering building and fountains.

Beautiful Gardens and Palace. The day we visited we bought our Hydrofoil tickets in St Petersburg for the trip to Peterhof. On arrival we had to then buy tickets to the gardens, (very cheap). Sadly the day we visited the palace was only open to Russian citizens. No-one thought to mention this when we were been sold Hydrofoil tickets. The gardens and fountains are spectacular and we spent several hours walking round those

STUNNING - TAKE YOUR TIME. I was not prepared for my jaw to drop. No wonder there was a revolution. It is beyond fabulous and the gardens are nothing short of spectacular. Wearcomfy shoes, bring snacks and prepare for any kind of weather even in summer. There are tickets for lower level and main palace. Beyond extravagant andtruly a must see while so far from home. I recommend you take time to google this before your trip because there is alot to take in and will help to plan your visit here.

Grand Palace, Dismal Service. My wife and I waited for two hours in line in order to buy tickets to go into the palace. Not only were we subjected to numerous line jumpers, but the attendant closed the door to the ticket office for lunch after we had waited patiently in line. Very disappointed. The attendants should have told us much earlier that he was going to close the ticket office. If he had done this, we could have spent more time in the fabulous gardens.

Russia's Rudest Staff at an Outstanding site. Do not let the staff get you down here. The ladies that work at the Peterhof Palace are famously rude. Our guide warned us before we arrived. He said they were a bit moody. We found them to be a bit worse than that. It was almost comical. Don’t let some cranky communist era ladies get you down.....   This is a must see site. The fountains were so beautiful and history so rich. Travel friends my biggest tip would be to watch out for pickpockets. A man on our tour lost his wallet to one. So photographers bring you’re “A” game but secure your wallets.

Palace Grounds are Beautiful. We did not visit the inside of this palace. We did however walk about the palace grounds and gardens. It is quite spectacular and the fountains and grounds are a sight to see. This area has signs to be aware of pick pocketing, so do be aware of your surroundings.

Fabulous. We only had chance to walk around the gardens to see the fountains but it is so beautiful but busy. The Russian people have done a marvellous job of rebuilding and restoring the palace and gardens since it was destroyed in the Second World war.

day trip. If you want 1st hydrofoil of day book day before, then join a rugby type scrum to buy 1st ticket so you can go to lower park ( note if you want to visit cottage place you have to buy second lower park ticket as one use only). Then head towards main palace for second ticket (join a long line -but once in side moves well with aid of Russian ladies ensuring you don't stop too long!If can bring own food and drinks as either over priced or poor quality. Got mini bus back, avoid going back as park closes unless you are confident in a scrum to get on. Bus 424 fished up at metro.....a great end to lovely day as was able to stop at each metro station to see the amazing stations.
Breathtaking!. Superb group trip from our cruise. Fantastic tour of stately rooms decked with gold & famous art. A not to be missed experience.

Very nice palace. It is renovated summer palace of tzars. Wonderful fountains and gardens for few hours walking. We travelled from St.Petersburg by quick ship (meteor) and it is recommended for solo travellers.

The real deal is outside rather than inside. The fountains and parks outside are just spectacular. Hard to believe they are all gravity fed and there are no pumps involved. We also went through the Palace, but it is not as impressive as other restored Russian Palaces. Sort of a smaller, more crowded version of Catherine Palace.
Very picturesque. We travelled by Hydrofoil to this beautiful palace. Amazing grounds and fountains. We did not go inside this palace but enjoyed the gardens and water features.
Great palace, rainy day. The grand palace is a good tour but unfortunately the day we booked the tour it rained and we could not see everything but we enjoyed the trip anyway.
mesmerising place. this place is in out skirts of st .petersberg,beautiful palace and the palace inside is so beautiful that you get lost in the beauty of gold.
Must See. If you are in Saint petersburg for a day or two, this should be there in your list of attractions. More than the interiors I would suggest to take a walk around park and the fountain.

Just Amazing. It is impossible to describe how grand this palace is. The time, effort and money spent to restore this historic treasure is easy to see. Even the grounds with their gravity feed fountains are spectacular.

Petergof palace. Took water taxi to (meteor) to Petergof. Great palace with well kept grounds, a lot of territory. Plan to spent there pretty much all day of you like to see most of it. Took little tour and it was helpful to know more about history of this place as it took many years to complete and rebuilt it. Every royalty added something too it. Just remember if you leave park you need to buy tickets again.

Unique get away.. After a few days in Saint-Petersburg we decided to escape the city and took an Uber to the Grand Palace. The Uber X are very affordable (1000 rubles, one hour drive), although the best way to get to the palace is by hydrofoil. Unfortunately these only run between June and mid-October. Peterhof is amazing, the gold, the fountains, the park, it's the best way to get calm and relax a bit.

Must see!!!. It is a very beautiful place. You can go there by train or taxi and return by boat which is half past after every hour. However from my point of view restaurants over there are nothing special.

Fabulous even if you just walk the grounds. My son and I visited on a cool, sunny June day, with the sun sparkling off the ever-present gold. We'd originally intended to go inside the palace as well as tour the grounds, but skipped the palace visit due to the crowds. We'd come by boat from St. Petersburg, and the views of fountains and palace are spectacular as you make your way from the water and proceed eventually up the hill to the palace level. You can explore the Lower Gardens at your own pace, discovering additional fountains, smaller structures, and different views of the palace. Even on a busy day, many parts of the gardens are not too crowded, and feel very relaxed, in an imperial park way. I will say that there wasn't very much easily on offer in the way of food, so be prepared for a "grill dogs"/burgers/ice cream lunch from one of the stands, unless you bring your own food.

Opulence. Every corner looks scenic and be prepared , make sure to bring a fish eyed lens, spare battery and mermory card for your camera or phone if you are fans of photography.I just realise I might have done something wrong, some reviews here say no photo in th palace but there were lot of us taking pictures when I visited.

The FOUNTAINS !!!. The most important part of the palace is the impressive web of hundreds of fountais....and what is even more interesting is that they all run on the principles of gravity and without any motors !!!

Bit Confusing getting into the Palace. We obtained tickets for the grounds but were told the tickets for the palace were available in the palace. Unfortunately we stood in the queue for group tours but someone kindly let us in. It was confusing due to the lack of English but eventually we found the Palace ticket booth and saw the palace. Lovely place.

Outside Was Enough. There is now some access to the restored museum rooms, which we did not pay extra for and visit.Three hours was needed to stroll the gardens and fountains, find the trick water features, look across the coast and have something to eat and drink. Tip: use the self-serve place that's al fresco - the selection is good and prices reasonable, unlike the overpriced restaurant.The central fountains are a masterpiece of engineering, if not artistic achievement. All a bit crudely over-the-top to be aesthetically pleasing, but impressive, none the less.

Bonkersly blingy Peterhof!. Very beautiful and impressive fountains. Ferocious guards at the palace itself and an insistence on wearing overshoes (like some swimmimg pools use). I advise taking them off before you come down the stairs as they ask you to do so at the bottom of the stairs anyway. NO PHOTOS allowed inside. It's very beautiful but ruined by the aggressive attitude of the staff. We had o wait quite a long time to get on a hydrofoil from St Petersburg for a pretty non descript journey. A taxi would have been quicker and cheaper with 3 of us travelling.

Must see!. Huge area! Plan one full day for visit and try to choose sunny day if possible. Beutyfull fointanes without pumps with thousend of figures and few museums to visit. Must to see if you are in St.Petersburg. Nothing more to add.

After 4 years, this place still amaze me!!. First time been here about 4 years ago on April, the fountain wasn't on function, then back to here again on May 2016, The fountain is all working. This place still amaze me after 4 years, beyond beauty. Must visit places when you are in Petersburg!

National Treasure for Sure. It's so hard to wrap your brain around these magnificent palatial compounds. The French influence is immediately recognizable. Expect your tour to be fast paced and quite crowded. There will be KGB looking workers in every cubby hole spying your every move and barking broken English orders - but they seem like sweet people just doing their jobs. The property grounds are massive and stunning to the eye as well as your camera. If you came all the way to Russia - this is a MUST.

You cannot miss the fountains!. The Palace is great, but do not miss the fountains in the gardens. That's the highlight of this Palace for me. Make sure to walk all the way through to the Baltic sea for great views!

A lot of walking and stairs, beautiful but requires effort. We were part of a tour group who visited.
