It's quite pricey and they won't let you go to the palace unless you buy the ticket to the gardens too (500 RUB for the gardens and 550 for the palace). Renting an audio guide will cost you another 500. It seems expensive to me even though it's beautiful and the fountains on the garden truly amazing.
Butiful place. It was cold but we had sunshineBeautiful placeBig and wel reservedYou can comper it to Versaii Paris

Gardens Galore. The MOST fascinating thing about the Grand Palace is the gravity-fed fountains and water cascades. Absolutely worth a visit. You could easily spend the day walking around the gardens. Great views and engaging water games.

Just when you thought you couldn't be more impressed!. Oh my goodness - we had just come from Catherine's Palace and I thought that nothing could astound me more but I was wrong. The interior is fantastic but the grounds! We had been to Versailles and I felt nothing could compare to those grounds and fountains - well Peterhof gives them a damn good run for their money. The fountains and cascades are just beautiful and there are plenty of tricky fountains you try to get though without being drenched, they add an extra layer of fun.

Breathtaking palace and parkland. This was a stunning place to visit in autumn, when there were less crowds and when the trees were changing colour. The palace is beautifully decorated and the park behind is filled with various fountains, including a few hidden ones that may soak an unwary visitor! A peaceful place to walk and to enjoy the surroundings. Absolutely worth visiting.

OVER THE TOP VS. VERSAILLES. SPECTACULAR is an understatement. Thought that I have seen so much that I couldn't be impressed with grandeur. However, this meets, exceeds, and is over the top! The fountains and cascades were incredible. The playful "sprays" were also lots of fun. Would have liked to see an evening light show with music and, perhaps, fireworks. Book ahead to see the interior, which is more impressive than the exterior, which is saying something. Catherine's palace, however, if you are pressed for time is the ABSOLUTE must see near St. Petersburg. Come in September when the crowds are less.

Amazing park!!. Got there by metro then minibus (that will stop in front of the palace), it wasn't that hard to get to the site!The Park is magnificient! the fountains are magical, the weather was awesome! everything was perfect (there were no queues for buying tickets, we didn't visit the palace so we payed 500 rub/pers for the park entrance)PS: there's free wifi near the palace

Mini scale Versailles. On last days of August we have visited the garden of palace during good weather. If you have already visited the Versailles palace, it is not a breathtaking scene,although the unique fountains of palace make it worth the visit. Don't forget to walk under them, very tricky enjoyable game.There's also several people in the costume of king and queen so you can take photo for considerable price.As you walk into the garden your will reach a bay, from there you have nice shoot of Saintpetersburg, also you can take ferry to the city.

Crowded but fabulous. We loved the outside fountains and cascades, also the palace itself, but very crowded, be prepared for several hours waiting in queues. Worth the visit, but maybe not early in the morning as we did,.

Best place to visit if you go to St. Petersburg.. This place is incredible. It is really breathtaking to look at. The gardens are magnificent. I didn't get inside the palace itself because it was monday and closed. But the trip to the outside was worth it. In my view, if you are visiting St Petersburg, this is the must-do tourist attraction. Obviously if you are museum buff, the Winter Palace is the place. But if you like visual stimulation this is the place. Take the hydrofoil boat to get there. Don't pay for a business class seat on the boat. It's a joke.

Grand Palace. The Grand Palace and it gardens are spectacular, and you can spent most of the day, wandering the garden. Best way to get there is via the Hydroifoil from the Palace Bridge beside the Hermitage. Expect long queues to get into the Palace as there are always lots of tourists, pick a dry day, and bring a packed lunch with you!
Wau!. Like a postcard. A must see in the summer when fountains are working. One of the best palaces I have ever seen.

Beautiful gardens. Whilst I found Hermitage more impressive as a palace, Peterhof was also incredible but the gardens was the aspect for which I gave it 5 stars - especially with the beautiful colours of Autumn. Again depending on your interests you could easily spend a day in the gardens alone - countless fountains, cascades and tranquil places to sit. Also had a guide which makes it more accessible and highlights facts and stories you might otherwise miss.
True to its name..... A must visit in St.Petersburg. True masterpiece of Soviet achitecture. Beautiful gardens and fountains. The Grand cascade is not to be missed.
Good . The staff were friendly and helpful, nice smiles. Restaurant looks amazing and attractive, the dishes was good enough. Cocktail was extremely good and the waiter is attentive listener.

Beautiful statues/figurines around the fountain and stair way. This is a prime example of the grandeur of those times. Richly decorated and sprawling gardens and fountains. We had a relaxing and enjoyable time

The Majestic Grand Palace in Peterhof, St. Petersburg, Russia - stunningly beautiful!. It is majestic with all the opulence of what a grand palace is. It is in Peterhof, in a beautiful location overlooking the gulf of Finland. Peterhof is the Russian equivalent of the French Versailles, and I think even better because of its location, adjacent to the ocean. The Palace is replete with history and rich historical artifacts that belonged to the different royalties that once ruled Russia. It is astonishingly impressive and breathtaking, a must to see if you are in St. Petersburg, Russia.
Breath taking views. So beautiful only wish they let you take pictures. Required to put on booties on shoes. Very popular so crowded. The gardens are amazing. So many different fountains

Beautiful gardens. The palace is rather stifling, full of organised tours, but of interest to the history buff. The gardens and fountains are stunning. Autumn is the time to visit - mild weather with just a few colours in the leaves. Amazing fountains!

Large and lovely . The grounds are very large. The views stunning. The fountains magnificent. E spent a few hours wondering the ground and looking at the grand palace. This is a ace you don't want to miss.

Russian's Versailles only fresher and more beautiful. Yes Versailles has much more fame but I'm much more impressed by Grand Palace. Inside the Palace is a smaller version of Winter Palace but same grandeur and splendor! It's well maintained and kept unlike Versailles, which looks worn and full of dust. Grand Palace overlooks Gulf Finland which gives it such a special geographical wonder. All fountains are running by natural forces. Russian palaces are at the top of the world when it comes to splendor and artistical design taste. I can only say WOW!

Peterhof. Big line up to get in, no photos allowed, if you have visited the Catherine Palace with the Amber Room you could give this Palace a pass and enjoy the grounds and enjoy a leisurely lunch at the Summer Terrace restaurant.

The ultimate water fountain show!. One's respect and admiration of the many facets of Peter the Great's abilities and accomplishments are highlighted when the Grand Palace is visited. After visiting Versailles Peter wanted to create his version of it on the Baltic Sea and he certainly did. The gardens are splendid and the design of the main fountains and in garden areas throughout the grounds are quite fabulous. The trick fountains still work and it is fun to be present when the water is turned on about 11 in the morning. If you get there on a tour bus it is possible to take a hydrofoil boat back to St. Petersburg landing nearby the Hermitage and is a nice experience.

Well worth the excursion!. Be sure to arrive by boat or hydrofoil from St. Petersburg, a very fitting way to arrive. I didn't go inside the palace, just the gardens with its myriad fountains. And the bath house - very worthwhile seeing!

Great palace . Beautiful building surrounded by musicians and dancing fountains. The history of this place is so absorbing that I spend 4 hours there and didn't realise it.Totally worth the time.No food or coffee outlet there.A long staircase and long long waiting line.
Beautiful views. so many photo-ops. The fountains are mesmerizing. the sea looks great and the hydrofoil is a fun way to get back to the city. the gardens are a must visit.

A must not miss attraction. Peter hot Grand Palace with its beautiful state rooms, filled with magnificent furniture and paintings is an absolute must see. A stroll in the huge park with its magnificent flower displays, it's guilded statues and its stunning fountains, must not be missed. The magnificence of the palace defies accurate description. Ideally you should choose a sunny summer, spring or autumn (fall) day. It is not the place to visit on a rainy day.

Mind-blowing fountains. This may have been one of my favorite sites in St. Petersburg. The grounds are beautiful but the fountains are like nothing I've ever seen. More impressive fountains than Versailles. Do not miss this.

a palace to impress. best to visit as part of a tour, very interesting and every room in the palace impressive. the fountains outside are beautifully decorated with gold statues but disappointed with the display of water when it came on, more of a dribble than fountain, but remembering no mechanical pumps used I should have expected it.

Gotta get in with a tour or you will wait for hours in peak season. We had early entry since we were on a tour. Upon leaving (a few hours later) we saw the line...holy moly, would take hours to get in!The fountains are fun to see. Beware of the pickpockets (as in most tourist places in Russia)!

3 type of sightseeing in one place ,historical mansion ,beautiful garden. master of art building with a large garden near Finland gulf .amazing golden fountain so you have 3 type of sightseeing in one place ,historical mansion ,beautiful garden and also gulf shore .you have two way to get there one by subway and after that van and exciting way is by hydrofoil (boat) that there are near hermitage museum (it should take around 30 mins )

Certainly Grand!. One of the most beautiful outdoor attractions of our Baltic cruise. The grounds are spectacular. It is amazing that all the fountains operate from pressuring water and no mechanical pumps.
Must see. Astonishing interiors, russian Tzars dolce vita in action. A lot of art as well. Best to come as early as possible to avoid crowd.

Lovely if it is sunny. Went with a tour guide who explained the origin and recreation of the gardens and fountains and a bit about the science that made the fountains unique. Yes, this is not restored but a re-creation of this 18th century site, as there major damage and lack of maintenance over the years after the 'glory days.'done. There is lots of walking (and 100 stairs) in order to view properly. However, it is amazing to see the fountains sparkling on a sunny day - probably the most spectacular array of gravity-fed water systems in the world. Rather unique display, we think.
Foubtains. The fountains of this amazing landscape far outweigh the palace itself. There are many various themed fountains that at flowing from April to October.
Lovely gardens. We visited the gardens only. These are spectacular and bring Versailles to mind. Definitely worth visiting.
Wonderful fountains. I suppose this place is better known as Peterhof rather than Grand Palace. A must visit site in St.Petersburg. All you need to receive positive memories is good weather.

perfect example of the greatness of peter I. what a graceful interior. especially the chapel of peter and paul (the children of nicholas II were baptized here). magnificent taste the tsars had. peterhof is an outstanding example of the greatness of peter I.

Everything should be payed:). We were very surprised to know that boat tickets to peterhov even don't include park entry to price which costs 900 rub roundtrip for students!Boat tour is very nice. You can go upstairs and see the city during a tour which takes 30 minutes by fast ship "raketa". By arriving you have to pay also to enter the garden where is grand palace etc. To enter grand palace you must also pay pay pay and everything must be payed. We've decided its too much for peterhov (payed 2500 but not yet seen even anything) and we just walked in garden which has many fountains.For this excursion you'd needed proximitly 3h.

Beautifully restored palace is a must see!. The palace was heavily damaged during the war but has been reconstructed to it's former state, including a replica of the famous amber room, and is breathtaking. Take time to walk the grounds and don't miss the 11:00 show when the music is blasted through the speakers outside and the grand fountain comes to life!

An enchanting Palace and Garden complex. This is one of the most beautiful palace gardens I have ever seen. The fountain they say took 100 years to build. It is quite popular among locals and tourists for a full-day trip. It is a 45 min boat ride away from Petersburg. The palace and its grounds with the vast number of fountains is enchanting.
Grand Palace St.Petersburg. This was fabulous, especially the fountains and gardens as well. Be sure to be there when the fountains are playing.

A 'must' if you are visiting St Petersburg.. It is very crowded but still worthwhile. So beautiful. So well preserved. The grounds are also wonderful. Will take a lot of time to see the whole place. the waterfall will be amazing.

Peterhoff Palace is grand. Be sure and go early. If possible start your tour before the crowds with a pre opening tour. That made our time quiet and enjoyable. We did it through Viking cruise lines who took care of everything. Much like Versailles, but with gilded statues. I had read about the Amber room but thought it was mostly hype until I saw it. The detailed art work is impressive.Like most Russian palaces, it is impressive how the Russians rebuilt their palaces from rubble and historical records after the Nazis destroyed them.

Another amazing attraction.. If you have time to travel outside the city, this is a must see attraction. I can only imagine how beautiful during the summer season as I was there early September and it was beautiful. Unfortunately closed when I went on Monday. Still enjoyed the beautiful gardens and fountains.

I nice outing, but crowded and a brilliant copy. My fault, I should have realised its a copy.. but being fair, a very well executed one, and the contents genuine.What I mean is that the whole thing was re constructed post war, not refurbished, but as I understood it virtually re built a s a copy of the original. Lots of the contents and pictures had been squirrelled away during the war and are now in situ, and the gardens of course are gorgeous. The other thing is the regimentation. It is very popular and therefore busy, and you have to move rather like on a conveyor belt

PETER HOF - tickets / restaurant. Go by hydrofoil - tickets from boat yards either side of bridge behind the Hermitage - tickets cost 500 roubles and you can book for the return as well, naming the time of the return boat. Boats run every 30 minutes but check in case of changes and when standard tickets( fro middle and back of boat run out) they charge 1,500 roubles for "Business Class" seats in the front -WHO DOES BUSINESS IN PETER HOF? Trip take 30 minutes.Beautiful fountains and palace.To eat - nice outdoor restaurant and café to right side of arrival quay about 200 m - don't bother with others
Peterhof. spend more time within the garden than the palace. Catherine palace is much nicer than Peterhof. if possible be there at 11:30am when they start/open the fountains.

Worth a good rating, but this is not available.. I would rate this as a three and a half score - between average and vg. We were lucky to have an excellent English-speaking Russian guide . Be prepared to cope with crowds, long queues ( which seem to be dealt with illogically by extremely authoritarian staff). You are rushed through certain areas by the staff who seem to consider throughput the most important factor. We had already visited The Hermitage so perhaps my opinion is clouded by this far superior attraction, but the Palace at Peterhof seemed over ornate. The saving grace were the enormous gardens and extensive fountains,switched on at 11.00 a.m, together with the cascade to the sea. They are reminiscent of Versailles- but not quite as good.A tented cafe/fast food facility is outside the gate. We spent half a day here-quite enough!
Grand palace as named. Beautiful both the building and the garden.Very strong wind at the dock that you may able to see Helsinki land.
Peterhof trip. summer residence of the tzar family is a must see. check out the palace and the park. have comfortable walking shoes.
Gorgeous. This place is amazing.luxary does not look as a show up.front part is free to enter the complex you pay 500r if im not mistaken.totally worth it,even cheap compering the things you see

Definitely a 'must see'.. Perterhof is truly an exceptional sight. The palace is majestic with its exquisite fountains and gold statue décor. The grounds from above with their maze-like motif are equally impressive. Although there really isn't much more to see, it is still worth the hydrofoil ride over. When you get tired of walking you can always take the mini train tour which doesn't really show you anything of interest, other than the massive grounds, but it does give your feet a break. Between the boat ride and walking around the sites, it takes about half a day.

Palace great, gardens fantastic. Another great St Petersburg Palace that was rebuilt after WW2 and it treasures restored, or at least many of them. The fountains are amazing and you can spend hours walking round the gardens if that is your taste.

A Superb Palace. As part of our tour from SPB, we took the Hydrofoil in the Gulf of Finland to arrive here to see acres upon acres of beautifully manicured gardens, forests, statues, birdhouses, and, of course, the gravity-fed fountains – The Adam Fountain, the Sun Fountain, the Dragon Fountain, and the magnificent Grand Cascade.What a gorgeous setting outside with so much ability to awe and dazzle the visitors. From the above balcony, near the Palace, you get a superb view of the Grand Cascade tumbling down among gilded Statues, and nicely planned terraces and gardens, -- and even a view of that expanse of the Baltic Sea. There are great photo ops from above and from below. There is so much gold, so much opulence, and so much grandeur that we were certainly awe struck. Unfortunately, we did not have time to see the inside the Palace.The Gardens were constructed to outdo the ones in Versailles. The Germans destroyed the place after World War II, but an extraordinary restoration has brought the place back to its original glory.There are hidden motion-activated water jets all over the property that can spray all of a sudden. Actually they are timed to go off at specific intervals. Our guide helped us to steer clear.There is a large number of tourists, but you do not feel crowded because everyone is dispersed all over those massive grounds. The walk in the park, through the gardens and around the beautiful statues was sheer delight.One of the most beautiful and unique places we have ever seen. Well worth a visit.

The Peterhof is Indeed Grand. Wow .. & Wow inside & out. Gold everywhere. But, my favorite was when they turned on the gravity fed fountains. Our guide told us to get good views early. Be there at least 45 minutes before fountain time. It will be several layers deep when the fountains start up. Very beautiful sight. Get there EARLY!!! But, early or not, you must see this Grand Palace.

Time it right!. Peter the Great's summer palace is certainly impressive and the restoration that has been done since it's destruction during the war is meticulous. Whilst the interior is magnificent the outside cascading waterffall and surrounding gold statues are a real sight. We arrived for the 10.30am opening but there were already crowds queuing then. Try to avoid big tour groups of you can, small groups of under 3 get to jump the queue (as long as with a guide). Security does push the traffic through the palace quite quickly so you don't get too long to linger in any rooms. The walk through the gardens is nice, don't miss the "surprise" fountains. The orangery is nice for lunch too.

Unbelievable grounds!!. Inside was "ok" for me, I was there to see the fountains and gardens. The place is amazing...all the fountains are gravity fed. The landscaping was gorgeous. A must see if in St Petersburg.

Makes Versailles look like a shed. Absolutely stunning palace with massive gardens. It's overwhelmingly large so be sure to wear sturdy walking shoes. BRING WATER AND SNACKS - the on site cafe serves hugely overpriced greasy food. Make sure to allow enough time to see all the gardens - a few hours should do it. We didn't go in to the museums but there's plenty of them here, be aware that there's a 300rubles charge into each one, as well as an extra charge into the Upper Gardens.

The best - Put on the walking shoes. My second visit here and loved it just as much as the first. Totally impressive Palace and gives a great insight to the life of the Zars. The gardens and fountains are not to be missed. Take plenty of time here, in fact you need at least 3 hours to see everything.

Wow, wow, wow!. The palace itself is absolutely gorgeous inside and out. But wait until you stroll the grounds and see the fountains! One is more beautiful than the next and some are whimsical and funny--fountains that look like pine trees in a grove of pine trees for example or those "tricky benches". A must see!

GREAT VISION. travelled by catamaran from St Petersburg and you get an amazing view of the palace from the water and the canal entry. Gardens are spectacular and water canon display well worth waiting for the opening time. Small palace gives an idea of living conditions of the day which were clearly quite basic which only adds to the magnificence of the main palace. A well worthwhile visit.

Must do. Impressive park and fountaints. Visit main palace is worthwhile, although when it's full workers almost push you to speed up. That's why i don't recomend paying for the audio guide. Just reading wall messages and hearing group guides literaly stacked to your back is enough
stunning. my favorite spot in st. petersburg. just stunning grounds and fountains . make it a point to go and see this place.

Impressive water fountains, statues and gardens. Peterhof or Petergof ("Peter's Court") is famous for its palaces and gardens - laid out on the orders of Peter the Great and sometimes called the "Russian Versailles." The area was extensively damaged during World War II during occupation by Nazi Germany. Reconstruction efforts began almost immediately following the war, and are still continuing. Nevertheless, what you see is breathtaking. Visitors arrive by hydrofoil from St Petersburg, in roughly 45 minutes. It is the fastest and most expensive way (about 700 Rubles) to get there. Show begins exactly at 11 am when all fountains start - all operating under gravity, no pumps.The gardens are well manicured and fountains are all around - small and large, some are gimmicky and will get you wet when you are not watching. A small canal from the gulf all the way to the steps of the palace is symbolic of Peter the Great's victory over Sweden, and then returning to his palace by boat. Fountains on both sides of the canal as well as the gilded statues and fountains at the steps of the Palace are a sight not to miss (and take pictures of.) Did not visit the palace - short on time and long lines. Then again, there is Catherine Palace and Hermitage to more than make up for it.

Versailles-gorod on the Gulf of Finland. Peterhof in Summer, crowded with visitors of course, we went primarily to see the Lower Park, so passed on getting tickets for inside the Grand Palace (although it is a very splendid looking building from the outside). From the top of the bluff the gardens & fountains are a great sight, all classical golden statues, chequerboard floor & a channel opening out into the main fountain. Looking back up from the bottom, the Grand Cascade is an impressive vision with the Palace as backdrop. The Chessboard Cascade with its dragon motif certainly attracts the young visitor. Well worth a look also is the horizontal Monplaisir Palace & the garden & fountains of the Orangery. The Trick Fountain seems a bit gimmicky to me even if it was Peter's own idea. However it should be said that it does amuse (& cool down) the horde of people who gather round the gardens. What wasn't impressive was the inadequate & disgusting toilet facilities at the entrance, a row of portaloos (insufficient in number for the amount of visitors) with the nauseating smell of raw sewerage piling up.

Very impressive especially the fountains. Visited this as part of a guided cruise tour and was not disappointed. The palace is truly amazing and another example of outstanding restoration work after it had been mindlessly blown up in WWII.It was extremely busy when we went, so had to queue outside for a while but the wait was worth it. Also, we were rushed through each room because of the volume of people but it didn't detract from the experience.Most important, do not try and take pictures inside the palace!When you come out of the palace, there are expansive grounds to walk through and of course, the beautiful fountains and water cascades, which when you learn how they work, are truly amazing.Would definitely recommend being part of a tour.

Wonderful!!. A wonderful palace with incredibles gold statues in front. Pretties gardens with flowers and fountains. Beautiful place to stay all day long with family or for a romantic date. Is easy to go there by hydrofoil, kind of 30 min. Cause the weather was very bad when I was there unfortunately I had to leave earlier then planned. So the weather is a concern if you are planning to go by hydrofoil. Anyway is possible go by bus (but it will take 1 hour..)

Worth the trip from St. Petersburg. The gardens are worth the (small) trip from St. Petersburg. You will see very impressive fountains spread all across the gardens. Dont forget to walk all the way down to the Baltic Sea coast. There is a small cafe in the area where you can sit for a while and have a light snack or a coffee.
Gorgeous!!!. Grand Palace was gorgeous. So much beautiful places around the palace also. It was really hot day but the Petergof was great place to spend hot day. So much to see for everyone.

Stunning Fountains and a wonderful garden. The fountains are absolutely fabulous. Unlikely to be seen anywhere else in the world barring Versailles near Paris.Best way to travel to Peterhof is by hydrofoil. Be aware of people who line up outside Admitaltyskaya Metro Station and offer help in buying the boat tickets and also will escort you to the boat. They charge 1200 roubles for the return journey when in fact the boat companies charge only 900 rubles. The boats can be seen alongside palace embankment and admiralty embankment. The ticket offices are there.alongside.

An over-the-top must see with vast grounds. Part of Russia's go-big-or-go-home chronicles. While you'll feel like tourist cattle as you're prodded alongside thousands of groups, it's still worth going inside to see the opulence. The great news is when you come out of the palace, there are expansive grounds that will allow you to escape the crowds. Seriously, it's like they built Central Park just for themselves. You can easily enjoy a picnic by yourself up in the wooded area, or sitting overlooking the water (and, of gourse, see all the fountains, gardens, gazebos that everyone else is visiting). Just lovely. I spent nearly 4 hours just enjoying the grounds. And, yeah, Peter did water really well. Took the hydrofoil there and back (i didn't exit the "lower grounds" because I didn't want to have to pay to get back in just to take the hydrofoil back. So I must have missed something spectacular. But I certainly felt like I had an incredible time even without seeing the other grounds. The palace is included in the lower grounds. As others have said, food is ridiculously expensive here, so bring your own food and enjoy a little picnic on the grounds.

Fantastic & gold!!!!. We arrived and did a guided tour of the palace which was great! We then approached the rear of the building to the gardens where the gold statues and fountains seemed to go on forever!Our guide told us that the fountains started at 11:00am and we were not disappointed, it was some display! and all to music which is apparently the anthem of the Peterhof area.

Great Place to Visit.. We were in town on a cruise ship for two days and toured this establishment with Alla Tours. It is a very interesting palace and you must visit it with a guide, to be able to explain things to you. The gardens and fountains here are amazing....especially the fountains with all the gold statues in the water. A great photo opportunity.

Peter the Great's Palace. We initially approached the palace from the rear and although it appeared large, it was not what we expected. Then we went to the front and found that it had multiple stories and was absolutely beautiful. Took a tour of the interior and the gardens in the back. Highly recommended.

Jewel in the Crown. On a previous visit we did not have time to view the inside of the palace as we spent so much time viewing the spectacular fountains and grounds. On this visit however we queued for around 1.1/2 hours to purchase tickets to view the palace and it was certainly more than worth the effort. The restoration of this palace is nothing short of miraculous considering the total devastation which occurred during the second world war. A guided tour of the palace brought the previous inhabitants to life and showed the great opulence and extravagance they enjoyed. The craftsmanship and luxurious finish is totally outstanding with beautiful antique furnishings displayed throughout. This was certainly the highlight of our visit to St Petersburg. The best means of transportation to Peterhof is the hydrofoil which is very fast, efficient and reasonably priced.

Take your food with you. This is a " must to visit " if you stay in St. Petersburg for more than 1 day. Taking a hidrofil is rather expensive however a convenient and fast solution to go there.We tried to have launch there in Orangery which I do not recommend to anyone! Better to take some sandwiches with you and have a picnic on the beach or in one of the several rest places next to an old tree.
Nice. We didn't get into the palace, only saw it from outside, several nice pic opportunities there for sure.

Lots of decorating tips for home.... Ha! The only way you'll be able to copy this decor at home is if you are a billionaire with access to a huge palace. Each room is grander and more ornate that the previous one. Whether you are staring at the staircases, the floors, the ceilings, the walls or the furniture, you will be awestruck. But don't worry, if you end up standing in one spot and staring at the decor for too long, an old Russian lady will soon shoo you along into the next room. There are written plaques describing many of the features, but it would be better to join a guided tour or get an audio-guide for all the important info. Go early or late to avoid the big crowds.

"A must go place". I went with my husband on our own, by boat - 30min trip - the best way to go. We bought a ticket to the garden when arrived. The ticket to visit inside the palace we had to buy in a office near the palace. I suggest to go early and start the visit for the palace, before the queues (one to buy and another to enter in the palace) become great. After, you can visit the gardens in your time, there is no queue for that . At the end, there is restaurants near the sea. If you want save money, there is a lot of "food truck" selling hot dog and ice cream around the garden. I prefer not describe the place, you must see by yourself.
Imperial style. The palace was closed because we went on a Monda, but we really enjoyed walking along the huge park with its beautiful fountains

turist attraction. We get lucky with the weather and we can visit Petergof all afternoon.
Just exceptional view and design.
But a lot of tourist. and very complicate to make good picture

Peterhof Palace and Fountains - Excellent. The Peterhof Palace and Fountains are about an hour coach journey from the Cruise Terminal, on the Southern Coast of the Gulf of Finland. There are extensive buildings including the Grand Palace that can be visited.Although the Palace grounds were very busy, the organisation within the buildings was excellent. The Room Officials ensured that only one Group at a time entered each room - so no mixing of Groups and the beautiful rooms could be easily viewed. One downside was that no photos could be taken within the Palace,The Gardens and the Fountains were truely magnificient - the water is piped from lakes many miles away and no pumps are used to feed the multitide of fountains. I was impressed by the beauty and the engineering.

Unbelievable - not in a good way!. You cannot believe this: you arrive at Peterhof pier, queue with your SPB card at the SPB card queue - only you now notice that they accept everybody in your line not only with the card, but the cash-payer guests as well. OK, swallow big, get your ticket - only you will be avare that this is valid only the lower garden.Oh, and you cannot buy ticket to the Grand Palace, no. You have to queue again a very long one above! Well, we did not.The second point I gave is because the lower garden and the artificial waterfalls are stunning, beautiful, and the garden itself is too.Be careful, read, and arrive early, and maybe you will be lucky to see the Palace, I have heard that it is really beautiful!

Impressive but expensive food. Took a hydrofoil from St Petersburg. Straight forward and saves us time from taking the train and and buses. The architecture is impressive and grand as per other grand palaces in St Petersburg and Moscow. However, food is expensive. 1 magnum ice cream and a 2 scoop ice cream cone cost 10 euros. 3 sandwiches cost 15 euros! Better to pack your own food.

Almost the same as Versailes. This place i superband perhaps best reached by river boat. The grandeur, fountains, scale of planning are staggering. Its very much in the style of Versailles near Paris and Schonbrunn in Vienna. Great day out.

Amazing waterplays, lovely nature to relaxed: must see in Saint Petersburg,. Take the 30-minutes speed ferry from outside of Eremitage in the city center that costs RUB 1200 for the return ticket. You should arrives BEFORE 6 pm cause the water fontaines were shut down at this time. Its amazing that all this water fontaines works without any electrical energy, just out of a reservoir that gets filled again during night from the next river. The buildings are great and you can also relaxed in the widespread garden. Better is to avoid it during the weekend and come during the week. Reserve minimum three hourse included the 30 minutes ride to PeterhofCan strongly recommend it

Beautiful place with amazing Gardens. We visited Peterhof after one of my colleagues recommended me to go there. First we started with a tour inside the summer palace which was very impressive. Later we visited the gardens which are very beautiful with all the different kind of fountains, statues and beautiful flowers. Unfortunately we had not that much time for the gardens but I am sure if you are not in a hurry you can spend hours wandering around without getting bored.I can recommend visiting Peterhof and would go back to the gardens if I ll be in St. Petersburg again.

Beautiful Palace, gardens and fountains. Superb Baroque Palace and lovely gardens with an amazing variety of very impressive fountains. We arrived early with a group from our cruise ship but it was already very busy with visitors. A beautiful sunny and warm day provided the perfect setting for our visit. Our Russian guide was very informative and helpful.

Tips and Tricks at Peterhof. Tips and Tricks at Peterhof. If you know how to queue up, well-done. In case you don`t, here we go. You arriving by ship, which you can pre book a day before. Return by ship, can be tricky, because you must know your time when you want to go back. Best slot is around 4pm if you arrived at 10-11. If you are leaving the lower garden for the upper garden you must pay again if you are travelling by ship. So do all the tings you want to do first. The tickets for the main exhibition are sold in the central building (lower garden) till 12 and from 2:30 pm. Between 12 and 2:30 are only for Russian visitors. It will be a wasted of time to start queuing at the ticket office on the right hand side, it is only for Russian. For the Amber room you should be very early, the queue is growing very fast. I hope this was helpful to organize you perfect day.

An amazing palace. Take the fast cat from St Petersburg to this palace and it's fountains. We went as part of an excursion with SPB (as we were on a cruise). This is an amazing palace with gardens and fountains worth a mention. It is a shame you can't see the inside as it is being renovated (very slowly!)The fountains and outside are stunning, said to rival Versailles and it's true they do (as I have now seen both). Worth a good couple of hours to stroll around, but a fairway outside of St pete's therefore if time pressed could take out half a day.

The fountains are truly amazing. Yes the staterooms are gorgeous but nothing will compare you for the magnificence of the fountains. They are, as everyone else states, simply stunning. Be sure to take a tour with a hydrofoil ride back into the city, it's a great way to make your way back.

An interesting excursion. We caught the hydrofoil out to Peterhof which was the royalty's summer palace. Peter I modelled it on Versailles, and it is very striking when you first set eyes on it with the amazing fountains and all the gold. However, it is quite small and not nearly as grand as Versailles in reality. We had a private guide who managed to organise to take us around in between two large groups of people so we weren't overcrowded but I can imagine the experience being a bit unpleasant with so many tourists. We then drove back to the centre of the city which was interesting as we could see how real Russians live (a lot of high rise apartments) in contrast to the grandeur of all the tourist attractions!

Nice Gardens and Beautiful Fountains. We rode the metro to Avtovo. After exiting the station, we took the underground passage to cross the street to the minibus stop. You won't miss it as the buses come one after the other with big signs "Peterhof" at the front (#424, 424A, and maybe other minibuses as well at 60 RUB per person). Our minibus stopped outside the upper garden, and quite a few people got off. We followed others and walked through the upper garden and exited on the left to the ticket booth. We only visited the lower garden with fountains, not the palaces. Lovely weather, nice gardens, beautiful fountains, grand palaces. Only the Adam and Eve Fountains are original; the others were reconstructed after WWII. Very crowded in mid-June, and I think Versailles is artistically more impressive. I also prefer the more serene, less contrived parks of Catherine Palace.

OMG, Those FOUNTAINS!!!. The fountains are a sight to behold--so nice that l gaze at their pictures and it brings me back and puts a big smile on my face. The gardens are also peaceful, beautiful, and memorable. It is definitely worth the travel time to experience this very special place.

Amazing Garden with Beatiful Fountains. The palace inside is nice but nothing extremely great compared to other European palaces. The gardens outside are amazing though and well worth a visit. Great area to walk around. Few sites to eat lunch, several snack stands with ice cream was a plus for the kids. Walk to the end of the gardens to view SPB from across the bay.

Place tour and fountains/garden were excellent. While Peterhof is an hour's drive from the center of St Petersburg, it is well worth the ride. The Palace, with less rooms, rivals that of Catherine and the grounds are meticulously maintained. The parquet floors are truly beautiful and to assure that they don't get scratched, you are required to wear protective 'socks' over your shoes.The Palace was built by Peter the Great and nothing was spared in its construction.The Fountains are unique in both their looks and operation. There are no pumps to power the fountains, only gravity. If you do go to Peterhof, be sure to be there at 11AM as this is when the fountains are turned on while the St Petersburg Anthem is played. The best pictures of the fountains can be taken from the lower gardens with the palace in the background.So go to Peterhof, enjoy the palace tour, the gardens and views of the lake, and of course the fountains. It is a day well spent.
Luxury to the max!. These palaces are amazingly beautiful. The luxury is rather overwhelming especially in the sight of the extreme and obvious poverty everywhere else. I had a hard time with this.

SO BEAUTIFUL. This was almost a magical experience seeing the beauty of the fountains.What a Grand Estate. If you are near and you appreciate architectural beauty do not miss the Grand Palace of Peterhoff.

BEAUTIFULL PALACE AND GARDENS. Another one remarkable attraction of Russia that is a must for tourists. Actually is a copy of Versalies at Paris both Palace and Gardens. There is an admission to enter the Palace, Gardens are free entrance.We had a guide tour explaining the history and that made the tour more interesting. Although the day of our visit was some rain, we enjoyed walking in the gardens with the attractive fountains.Recommended !

Awesome Just to Walk Around. Went for about a half day with a group of Russian friends (I am American expat). We just walked around and checked out the grounds and all the fountains. While some construction was going on, mostly everything was working and it was truly spectacular. Loved seeing all the fountains and the view of the coastline from the property. Some of the fountains were "interactive", where people would walk under them for a picture and they would suddenly power down, soaking the person, which I thought was hilarious. I did not take a tour, although I would suggest doing so, as I am sure there is much history behind the palace that would have made the experience even more enjoyable on a cultural and historical note.

Truly Breathtaking. Spectacular, grandeur that has to be seen to be believed. The Palace, the gardens, the fountains, there are not enough words to describe it all. Being on a guided tour with SPB Tours we were able to bypass all the queues and had easy access and ample time to explore it all.
Include this place in your itinerary. If you are touring St. Petersburg you really should include this place in your itinerary. Well worth seeing if you like Russian history and architecture.

If you like palaces and gardens.. We were there early in the morning since we specifically ask our tour operator to get us early entrance tickets. That kind of ticket allows you to get in before the official opening hour, but I do not think you can get those if you buy your ticket yourself. But this is a must if you do not want to be stuck in a big crowd and it will allow you to see a lot more in a lot less time, allowing you to see more of the other wonders of St.Petersburg.Many call this place the "Russian Versailles". In fact if you already visited Versailles you will find that the comparison might be good about the gardens, but the Perterhof Palace cannot really be compared with the Versailles Palace. Peterhof is quite small in comparison. Yes it is still a pretty big place, but nothing to compare to Versailles.The gardens are really beautiful and the stories related to the different alleys are interesting. (Ask about the triky fountains!) And it is fun to see that the main fountains are still turn on manually (around 11h) just in front of the Palace.The Palace is interesting but you can see most of it within one hour.If you never saw Versailles I definitely recommend Peterhof. But if you did see Versailles I would still recommend to see Peterhof, but do not have to many expectation. Go for the history, not the Palace.
Very memorable gardens. The fountains are like nothing I've seen before. The gardens are lovely, and we had a wonderful day to enjoy. I would have liked more time to simply enjoy and wander.

What a chaos. We were there at 11:45 to find out that we have to wait 2 hours for the time slot reserved for foreigners. We were lucky we found out right away, but the Spanish couple we met said they waited in line for 1.5 hours until they were told at the booth that it was the line for Russian citizens. No signs, only the staff selling the tickets speak English, staff walking outside where you can ask questions about where to line up to buy tickets speak only Russian. When we finally figured out where to line up with sign language with one of the staff, another one came after 10 minutes and moved us with 15 other people to another line. Then the two staff members started yelling at each other. Once we were inside, it was very nice but because of all the tours and crowds and the guides wanting to keep you moving fast like a herd of sheep, we were not able to enjoy the inside as much as we would have liked. If you are visiting St/ Petersburg during White Nights, I would skip Peterhof and spend more time in Hermitage.

Research before you go. I went on this trip on the spur of the moment which probably wasn't the best idea; nobody speaks any English (why would they?) and signage is only in Russian so it was difficult to work out what to do. You get the hydrofoil from pier 4 opposite the Hermitage. Tickets are 750 and you can only buy 1 way. Keep your ticket to buy the return from kiosk 2, note you can only buy the return ticket when you are ready to go back -boats go from pier 3&5. Return is discounted to 550, they take credit cards and cash.When you get off the boat it is a very long walk up to the palace. You have to buy a ticket to the park at that point and it is only 500 roubles which is amazing value - keep the ticket as you need it to get out. - again cards and cash accepted. I later learnt that you can buy tickets (kacca) to get inside the palace at the same place.There is a free toilet stop just by the boat, clean but a long queue.The fountains are immediately in front of you and are spectacular, (there are a lot of signs warning of pickpockets so beware). There are also acres of gardens to either side which are equally impressive. There are buggies for hire which are 700 roubles and well worth it. There was also a small road train but it only went out into an undeveloped area and not around the main fountains.There is a cafe which served a strangely pleasant meal, it is quite rundown but the staff are friendly and food was tasty.Sadly I didn't get inside as I ran out of time, I would recommend a whole day there, take plenty of food and drink, hire a buggy and make sure you know the opening time for getting in the palace.A tip about the hydrofoil, the return journey was a bit frightening as the sea was very choppy, the boat dipped quite violently side to side, it seems this is normal so don't be alarmed!

One of seven wonders of Russia. Peter the Great planned Peterhof as the summer residence of a sea king. He needed access to the Baltic and wanted to create something better than Versailles of France. It was opened at his presence in August 1723. The most famous feature: The fountains. TheTsar himself contributed to the unique engineering system that supplies water to them, without a pump. The Great Cascade has 64 fountains and more than 250 statues and bas-reliefs. Peterhof (Russian Versailles) represents every style of the past and the special taste of the Russian monarchs. At the beginning it was called "Upper Chambers" and owed the name and the decor to Peter the Great. But the Baroque style transformation of the Palace was made by Bartolomeo Francesco Rastrelli during the reign of Peter's daughter, Empress Elizabeth in the 18th c. During WWII it was almost destroyed and it took decades for its restoration which continues even now. It's a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1990. The Museum complex covers 500 hectares. The Fountains of the Lower Park and the Upper Gardens have won the title "Capital of the Fountains" and "One of seven wonders of Russia". 11 o'clock every morning from May to September the show of the Fountains starts and the Marly bridge has the best panoramic view, if you are lucky to find some space quite early. Inside the buildings no photos are allowed, only in the endless gardens. Important notice: Returning to your coach is a difficult adventure as tens of coaches arrive non-stop and change parking places. Your best option is to remain close to your guide!

Feast your eyes.... This park is simply amazing. Most stunning one I've visited.Starting with the grand staircase and fountains, you really kick off the experience! wander down the steps and explore the sheer endless park with it's paths. Find the big pool of water with the nice house on the other end, find the shoreline of the finnish bay, find the stray dog who will accompany you for hours.The single most romantic walk I ever had happened in this park!Especially worth the visit for couples in autumn, when all the trees are incredibly colourful!

Absolutely stunning palace!. Main palace surrounded by intricate fountains and beautiful parks and being located right by Finnish Bay is absolutely stunning. It rivals those in France. Absolutely a must see!

Highlight of my trip to St Petersburg. this palace is spectacular, inside and outside. We booked a tour and the guided visit was very strict. The whole group had to stay together at all times and only 30 people were allowed in any room at any time. The gardens have amazing fountains and I wish we could have stayed longer to see more of it. If I had to do it again, I would go via hydrofoil from downtown. On a clear day, I think this must be much nicer than the road route.

Nice day trip!. Peterhof is a must when visiting St. Petersburg!The garden area is huge and offers a lot to discover. The beautiful set-up with its fountains reminds a lot of "Palace of Versailles".The tour in the Great Palace is definitely worth the additional fee, but attention: guided tours are in Russian only, but there is an English audio guide which you have to ask for at the cashier!

An amazing must do experience. . Taking the hydro foil from down town St Petersburg to Peterhoff is a great experience leading to a magnificent palace and palace gardens. The fountains and ornamental canal are awe inspiring the renovations have been superbly done. The splendour of the place is beyond compare , easy to get around with good access and facilities.

Simply stunning. Peter the Great had a problem. He was the ruler of Russia, but he didn't have a Versailles to show off.So he built one.That's the story behind Peterhof, one of the great palaces of the world.It's a huge complex, as you'd expect, although the building itself isn't overwhelming in size - only 30 rooms or so. But they are decorated nicely. Ahem.Peter died in 1725, and daughter Elizabeth picked up the ball from there. The structure didn't survive World War II well, but has been rebuilt since then. It's a top tourist attraction and deservedly so.By the way, photography is not allowed inside the building. That might make a purchase of a book or DVD worthwhile if you are particularly impressed by it.

Highly recommend you visit the Grand Palace in Peterhof. The most amazing palace and one that was restored with great care and precision, as well as loving craftsmanship after the Nazis destroyed most of it when they were chased out of Russia at the end of WW2. The destruction they did to this palace and other historical sites throughout St. Petersburg really shows the evil nature of the Nazi regime. I was completely blown away by how wonderful a restoration job the Russians did to remove and cover up the war damage. It is truly a wonder of the world that everyone should add to their bucketlist. I've seen it and would love to go back to see it again, that's how impressed I was. I would also recommend hiring Anna at TJ Travels to be your tour guide cause she can explain all the history and other important information about the Grand Palace and other sites of interest, which really adds great value to your visits.

You have visit this palace. Great palace, incredible feat of restoration. The halls are splendid. We had to stand in a short line to get the tickets, but is was relatively quick. I recommend going during the week as it gets very crowded on the weekends.Coming from the hydrofoil- "meteor"- gives a wonderful perspective from the water ad you approach the palace.
A must see. Simply put,you have to see it to believe it. The grandeur, the wealth, it must be seen to better understand!

Magnificent!. The visit to St Petersburg is not complete without Petrrhof, the summer residence of Tzar. Exceptional park, fountains, sculptures, magnificent palace , exterior and interior.Take a time to walk the park grounds and enjoy the splendor of the place

Terrible experience too crowded with very rude attendants. I agree this palace is beautiful, the experience of seeing it is NOT. The. Crowds are crazy, the visitors taken up by massive tour groups and overwhelming for a small group. We were pushed and I mean pushed through rooms without getting a chance to even read the spiel on each room. It doesnt help that the plagues are placed as you go out the door and not at the beginning of the room. The attendants are extremely rude and bossy and move you on in the seething crowd before you have had a good chance to look at the room,they even abuse you for talking too loud, as do the tour guides for other groups. Our group of 4 family members found this to be an unpleasant experience and not one we will ever do again. Seriously there are nicer things to see in St Petes where there are people that are less rude and accommodating. Don't waste your time and money during busy periods. We found it to be a beyond average experience. This was awful.

Piece of history. a must see site in Saint Petersburgh. loved the place, you have to visit at least once for the experience. will be joyful for family with different ages, mentalities you are going to love it anyway....

The name 'Grand' is appropriate.. Spectacular inside. Statutes & Fountains at front also Magnificent. Acres of gardens through which you can wander. Interesting history particularly particularly around the invasion by the Nazis & how they were able to protect doe of the treasures seen in the palace today.Only down side was the queues for tickets & crowds inside given it was the high tourist season.

Splendid. The Palace is set up high over the gardens so there are steps to manage to see the palace from below with the magnificent garden full of fountains. gold everywhere - inside and out.You will be told to stow any bags bigger than a standard sized handbag and coats too so pack wisely and wear a zipped up light coat rather than anything too heavy. Flat shoes required. Even these have to be covered with slip on paper covers which tend to split so take an extra pair from the pile at the entrance to change into especially if you have large feet (eg mens size 10+).When you see how little of the palace was left after the Nazi's decimated it in WWII you cannot believe what is in front of you. the Russian people buried and hid artefacts and after the war came out in droves to rebuild and preserve. It is an amazing achievement all over again to see the palace rebuilt.The gardens are delightful with terraces of fountains reaching down to a canal at the end of which you can catch a hydrofoil across the Gulf of Finland to St Petersburg City centre. Normally takes about 30-45 minutes but doesn't run in bad weather. There is a gift shop in the palace at the end of the tour and plenty of rest rooms. cafes and in the gardens small stalls selling very reasonably priced ice creams. Only roubles taken throughout (or credit cards).You can comfortably see the palace in about 90 minutes but expect as long a wait to get in by mid afternoon.

Best Royal Palace in the Venice of the North. Peterhof's Grand Palace is definitely one of the must sees in St. Petersburg, Russia! The fantastic looking architectures of the palace generate very royal, wealthy family thought in our minds. Then the fountains that should be on in the morning also features the royal castle type of theme that most of us truly would dream to be a prince or a princess. Then again, you have to pay a significant large amount(5000 or more to visit here) because transportation by the boat can be around 3000, then you'd need food to stay here for 4-5 hours! Even longer than the Terra Cotta Warriors in Xi'An! Visited in Oct 2012.
Beautiful. Incredible grounds and fountains, interior is equally stunning a photographers dream - note of caution - Beware of big crowds though and watch out for pickpockets

Great palace, terrible & expensive food!. Amazing palace and gardens. Great music at the gardens. This attraction is a must when in St Petersburg. Just make sure to bring some food from outside as you'll spend most of the day down there; we bought some terrible and expensive hot dogs and nachos at the stalls (don't do that!)

Incredible . This attraction is well worth the hour drive out of St. Petersburg. This palace is still being restored after the Nazi army completely destroyed it. We were there when they turned on the fountains at 11 A.M.. There Were THOUSANDS of people standing around to watch the event take place, yet we didn't feel crowded at too much.

MUST!. This place is a MUST while visiting St. Petersburg!The palace is amazing, the fountains are incredible, and the gardens are beautiful!I would recommend considering no less than 5 hours for this site. You have to take a 45minute boat to get there.
simply amazing. this was summer palace of peter.the garden and the fountains are awesome.probably taking half hour in palace and half hour in the gardens.

300 year old, breath taking summer house and gardens. This attraction is known as "Versailles By The Sea". This masterpiece of opulence combines spectacular gardens and water features with Peter's Grand Palace. There are also a number of delightful little palaces built for the tsars. Make sure you are around to witness the music and fountains in action around 11am. During summer months be prepared for enormous crowds and very poor availability of toilets. We did overcome these issues to a large degree by paying extra for a private tour originating from St Petersburg.

Magnificent. From the time you arrive everything is on a grand scale from the palace to the gardens, inside the palace is so stunning from the painting to the furniture and everywhere you look, you are watched like a hawk from the Russian woman on duty, no water is allowed to be taken into the palace, on the day we went it was very hot with all the crowds of people plus there were hardly any windows open.The gardens are lovely to walk around and with the fountains on both sides of the steps leading up to the palace are wonderful to see.
grand palace and the fountains. Totally fascinating and beautiful. The gardens were also beautful. it was lovely to walk and very relaxing.

Not bad for your summer house. This was the summer palace of Peter the Great and is sometimes referred to as the Versailles of Russia. The palace is much smaller than the hermitage and winter palace and you go round it in a circular route, probably taking about an hour in total to view all of the rooms and hear from the guides a little about the furniture and artworks in each room. Afterwards try and make time to have a walk round the beautiful gardens which border on to the water, and time your visit to see the fountains in action. At the end of our visit we took the hydrofoil back to St Petersburg which was considerably quicker than travelling all the way by bus as that took us about an hour to get there.

My Favourite Palace in the WORLD!. This palace is just plain awesome! No palace in Europe & Asia (sorry guys!) is as grand as this place; the palace grounds are just beautiful! As soon as you disembark the boat, you can buy tickets to the palace ground and the palace (separate price for each - 500 rubles each)... It will take u close to 4-5 hours at least to view this beautiful palace and palace grounds.. I suggest to do the palace first as there are long queues to enter the palace and the last queue to enter is at 4:45 pm. You will be amazed when u see this palace.. there is nothing like it.. everything is so well kept..Beautiful!

Peterhof Gardens. A must see when in St. Petersburg. Great for children. Bring a towel and be prepared to be soaked!!! Spending several hours touring the grounds, viewing the Bay of Finland and watching people makes for a most delightful day.

The gardens are a must see. Yet another cruise excursion, but for the gardens only. I wish I could have seen the interior of the palace as well, but...The palace is immense, the gardens are beautifully laid out and everywhere you look takes your breath away all the way down to the Bay of Finland.

Beautiful Palace but long queues. We've heard a lot about Petergof complex so wanted to see it very much. Everything was great indeed, the park, fountains, the palace itself! The only disappointing thing was that we planned to cover it within 2 hours but had to stay 30 min in the queue to the the interiors of the Palace, so it took a little bit more time. But it was worth full! If you have at least three spare hours it's really good decision to visit it.

An amazing visit! One of my fav pl!. Our tour took us there as a day trip and we loved the visit. This has to be one of my fav places. The weather was fantastic and it was a sunny day! The place was packed with visitors and we had to go through a security barrier, like in the airport, before we could enter the ground. I was told that no water or bags larger than A4 size etc.. There was no air con. I was so glad that I wore a summer dress so I was not sweating. Inside it was packed with tourists and we had to queue to enter one of the many great halls. I was surprise by the length of time it took, over 15 minutes! But it was worth it! I particularly enjoyed a walk around the garden and fountains where all the dazzling statues stood. A breath of fresh air was greatly appreciated. I was mad with taking photos and video! Wow it was a brilliant trip and I wished that I could back soon for more photo shoots;)

A wonderful palace . The gardens are just lovely as was this palace of the czars. They really loved gold and ornate decorations. This palace rivals Versailles. You can walk all around the gardens if a nice day too. Again the Russians allow too many vendors here as in other historical sites that can be annoying but well worth a visit.

Must see this. Peter the Great's stunning palace and grounds are not be missed. The gardens and fountains are incredible. The interior speaks of imperial greatness. Impressive inside and out. Few places on earth like it.
Fantastic. I though we had seen some sites till I saw this and you have to see it to believe it. You couldnt expalin to anyone in words whats it was like - go and see it for yourself.

" Take time to smell the flowers". On a two-day packed tour, we took the hydrofoil to Peterhof, only touring the vast gardens and fountains. Seeing the outside of the palace, I would have loved to visit inside, but that was not on our schedule. There was quite a lot of walking with so many photo opportunities, it was quite a morning. A local Russian guide had many many stories to tell, knowing her history of Peterhof very well made it very interesting. We had nice weather so we really enjoyed the gardens and fountains. Speaking of fountains, this has to be the most fountains on an estate that I have ever seen or even heard of. They are really something to see, how beautiful everything was planned and the timing of when they are on and off is fascinating. Strolling the grounds, it takes one back to only imagine what it was like to have enjoyed all of that back in the day, and on a regular ordinary day, every day after day. Very relaxing, allow a good amount of time to appreciate the beauty and take time to smell the flowers!

The best of Russia. This was a Top 3 sight in on our Baltic Cruise. As part of our tour of SPB we took a hydrofoil ride in the Gulf of Finland to get here. Incredibly windy, so be prepared for that. We ate a quick lunch in the little food tent out front, which was inefficient and overpriced. But who cares? Because these gardens are what we came for. And they did not disappoint. Acre after acre of beautifully cared for gardens and forests, wonderful old palaces and cottages, and of course fountains galore. I've never been anywhere like this in my life, and I'm sure I won't go anywhere else like it again. This was my kids' favorite spot because they could run in and out of tree lined walkways and play in the water fountains. And all the adults loved the sheer beauty, magnitude, and history of the place. Do make sure this is part of your itinerary when you come to St. Petersburg. Amazing.

Too quick. We had to be part of a tour due to the visa requirements in Russia. This was a very rushed tour and as no photos where allowed inside the staff pushed the guides along quickly. Iv read people say they are rude but Im afraid its their way. We had a 10am entrance booked. Once inside and after visiting the restrooms and getting on the cover shoes we went around the palace. It only took us 30 mins at most. Such a shame, we were fortunate enough to be at the front but those in our group at the back where still in the last room whilst the guide was talking about the next. The fountains are turned on at 11am and we were there to view this grand scene. The walk around the grounds was with the guide so again no time to spend on our own. We paid £58.25 each travelling by coach from a cruise ship. Total time out 5 hours. we would have loved to have had free time but this appears not to be allowed. Im glad that we went and it is truly is grand

Yes, the Grand Palace Is Truly Grand!. I’ve read many reviews from TA contributors disappointed that they spent hours queuing to enter various sites in St Petersburg and ended up seeing very little once they got in due to time constraints. If you’re visiting St Petersburg during summer, especially during the white nights, you must hire a private tour company that will obtain queue jump tickets. Our guide not only obtained queue jump tickets in advance; but she knew that staff at the Peter Hof and we were off and running in less than five minutes leaving the other tourists in the dust. If you want your memories of St Petersburg to consist of long queues and little else, then either organize your own tour or go on a group tour. If you want to see as much as possible in the least amount of time, then hire a private tour company. TA lists many for St Petersburg. They aren’t cheap. Think of it as an investment, something you cannot afford not to do.After jumping the queue, we had a leisurely tour of the Peterhof. Although the Grand Palace is most remarkable, I was especially impressed with the grounds, they were perfect for strolling as it was a beautiful summer’s day. One word of warning is that the hourly fountain display is not that impressive. If you have to wait more than ten minutes, skip it. I also recommend taking the hydrofoil from the Peterhof to the Winter Palace as it provides great views of the Gulf of Finland and St Petersburg.
splendid and gorgeous. Grand Palace is a must go place in Peterhof. It is better to arriving there in about after 3 or 4 pm as there are too many tours and russian lining up.

Expensive Trap. If you are not Russian you will be have to wait for all the Russians to enter and then you have to pay double to get inside the palace or get audio guides. The staff is really rude if you do not speak Russian; tourists are packed in the rooms of the small palace, where no one is allowed to take pictures, sit down or stay longer than 5 minutes. The gardens are really pretty, but you cannot go inside anywhere except the gardens without having to pay. Moreover, you can't leave the park because you will have to pay to get in again. I think that you will only like this place if you are a Russian with a lot of money to spend, besides that, don't even bother going to this place. I really don't understand why this is the #1 place to visit. I was so glad to leave the place.

Magnificent Palace that Rivals Versailles!. The Grand Palace and Gardens of Peterhof in St. Petersburg, Russia is a magnificent setting for a full day of historical touring. The Palace took almost two full hours to see, splendidly restored and preserved. Spend another hour walking through the gardens and strolling to the sea to get a different perspective of the palace. Do NOT miss this attraction - well worth the one hour drive from the port in St. Petersburg!

Glory of times past. Splendid room after splendid room, this palace is certainly worth your while. While the golden opulence and unrelenting tourist groups might wear your patience a bit thin, visiting here gives you a great sense of history and what it must have been like to live the rarefied life of the rulers of Tsarist Russia. Make sure you visit the park and the seafront to enjoy the view onto the bay of Finland.

A must See. Peterhoff Palace in Saint Petersburg, Russia is a must see.We took a minibus from one of the metro stations and it took about 40 minutes to get there. you need at least two hours to get around the palace and the specially the gardens and fountains down the palace to the Gulf of Finland. Russians were friendly. The garden and its fountains are very very beautiful and amazing.

Stunning. Would that I could have poked around there without all the people hustling us through. We were here with a tour and we had to move fast through most of the place. We got to see the fountain show start up which was cool, but show up early if you want a prayer of being able to see anything in this sea of humanity. Keep in mind when you visit that the palace was burned down to the studs during WWII so almost nothing in here is authentic from the 17th century, and much of it dates from the Soviet era, so the Soviet pschye creeps in a bit from time to time. If you have time wander the gardens they are worth it. They say this place is a rival to Versailles, i don't know in my Mind Versailles is still a nicer place.

Impressive . My wife is from Peterhof so off course we had to visit the Grand Palace. I was very impressed with it. The gardens were very impressive with all its beautiful fountains and hidden palaces. It is like Versailles but with less tourists (beginning oktober) making it more relaxed to stroll around.

Beautiful Gardens. The Palace was closed the day we visited Petershof, but perhaps it was just as well, as it was a beautiful May day and the gardens were amazing. After having visited the Hermitage and other palaces and churches in the city, it was a good opportunity to spend time outside in the sunshine, wandering around the amazing gardens and seeing the spectacular fountains all fed by gravity and not pumps. There were beds and beds of tulips in flower and many tree lined paths to wander through. We were fortunate to have a very informative guide. We had an enjoyable ride back to the city on the hydrofoil. Sadly there is never enough time to really appreciate all there is to see in places like this.
Amazing gardens. Well worth the trip just to see the gardens - amazing. Hydrofoil from near the Hermitage is the quickest and easiest way to get there

In before the Public. We came on a tour organised from our ship, this allowed us entry prior to the site being open to the public. we therefore had a tour of the building which is magnificent, with restoration and furnishings adding to the overall building. we were able to see the gardens before the fountains being turned on and then after, what a difference, the fountains are Fantastic. We had sunshine glinting on the golden statues which was magical. A must see when visiting St Petersburg, the Hermitage is grand, however, Peterhof is more manageable and you get to see everything.

Beautiful inside and out. We arrived early which was perfect as we had time to tour the palace before the fountains started spouting. Peterhof was actually damaged badly when he Germans occupied it during WWII and then they blew it up when they retreated in 1944. Rooms are all spectacular but the guides rush you through pretty fast. The gardens though are thoroughly relaxing and there are plenty of them including some designed for kids. We waited down in the lower garden for the fountains to come on rather than the balcony which was packed solid with people trying to catch a glimpse. There is a flea market by the bus parking area full of touristy junk. The shops in the museum have much higher quality as well as pricey items.
Wonderful. Once again steeped in Russian history the pictures and decorations are lovely it is a very interesting place to visit only wish we had, had more time there.

Do Not Miss This Palace!!. We've been to many palaces and this one tops them all! I liked it so much better than Versailles. The inside was interesting, but it's the outside with it's fountains and gardens that really make it spectacular. I'm not a garden person at all but THIS WAS STUNNING!! It was actually exciting! We loved this place and do not miss it.

Wonderful grand finale to a visit to St. Petersburg. The palace has been lovingly restored and is spectacular. Nevertheless it is overshadowed by the wonderful gardens and the Grand Cascade. Built to outdo the brilliance of Versailles, it is perhaps a bit too shiny and glittering from the restoration to evoke as much old world charm, but it is still wonderful. The Grand Cascade empties into canal and thence into the Gulf of Finland. A wonderful sight. Wander the gardens at your leisure here. Enjoy the well tended plantings, water features and vistas.

Miss it at your own loss !. To experience this place completely and properly - the palace, the heavenly gardens and the beautiful fountains there - keep a full day aside - and incase you're looking for some place to visit with your loved one - keep this one in high consideration.We went there through speed boat from Winter palace embankments in St. Petersburg, enjoyed that ride too, gardens were mesmerisingly beautiful.So wanna go back there again....(minus the kids if possible :-) )

Beautiful but maybe not worth all the trouble. We visited the lower park and the grand palace only. They are definitely worth a day excursion from St Peter (we went by train and walked 20 min from the station). The park is lovely and the main foutains are gorgeous. But there is a BIG issue with organisation here. You can buy tickets for the park online but not for the palace. To visit the main palace you have to queue at specific hours (from noon to 3pm for us) to buy your ticket than queue again to enter the palace as they form groups of 30 people. If you want an audioguide, queue again. In total we waited over two hours. And of course the tickets quickly add up. Fortunately i was with a russian so we could get all this information but i pitty other tourist as almost none of this wierd organisation was explained and staff didnt seem too keen to help in english. Once inside, the palace is beautiful do to its very good preservation but you have to stay with your group and the guide went too fast through the rooms. The visited lasted maybe 30-40 min. Of course we didnt feel like visiting other buildings in the park after that (extra ticket each time). SoSo take your ticket for the lower park online, inform yourself as soon as you get there when is the ticket office for the palace open and plan your day depending on that. Take sandwiches as there is limited options for lunch.

Fantastic day out. Just an extraordinary place, painstakingly restored to its original glory. Don't forget to look at the boards showing how it was at the end of WW II. If you can afford it, hire a private guide in a small group ~4 ish, as there is a story to everything, little things to be pointed out, and best viewing points to be found. Additionally you can move quickly through the house, and spend more time enjoying the fountains and the young (and young at heart) getting soaked by the practical jokes.Keep an eye out for the red squirrels on your journeying.

Must go place in St Petersburg. I love the stunning bronze statues surrounding the Grand Cascade (the main fountain) of Peterhof. Great photo opportunity. Look out for the rainbow at the fountain. The gardens are lovely and tulips were blooming when we visited in May. Watch out for the hidden water jets that will suddenly spray when you walk past. I enjoyed my visit to Peterhof. A pity that our tour guide rushed us through this place and we didn't have time to take many photos, especially at the main fountain.

One of the most beautiful palaces in the world. The Peterhof Summer Palace is probably the most beautiful palace in the world. The rooms are very well preserved and clean and in some of the rooms they have air conditioning. Unfortunately nowadays photos are not allowed inside the palace.

Most Impressive. Apart from massive tourism, it is still worth a visit. I would highly recommend a travel guide who can organise the tickets ahead of time that you do not have to wait for hours in front of the ticket office. You need at least 4 hours to view the park grounds and the luxury interiors and decadence of the Tsars.

Worthy >2 hours of walking. Great place for couple tourists to go in Saint Petersburg. Great place for walking and taking pictures.The entrance of the garden cost 500 Ruble for adult and 2XX for students, and cost extra to get inside the museum. It takes around 1 hour and 20 minutes to go there by Metro and bus (I think minivan is much faster), BE AWARE that fountains are closed at 18:XX on weekdays, so make it earlier.

Stunning Gardens and Gilded Fountains. Set in 300 Acres, this stunning garden is really beautiful. The Grand Cascade, has 3 waterfalls,64 fountains and 37 gilded statues. Walk down the waterway to the private beach, where boat tours are available. Although unable to visit inside the Palace the grandeur was for all to see. Again extremely busy.

Don't miss visiting Peterhoff - spectacular!.
