On our last day in St.Petersburg we travelled with our private tour guide out to the Finnish Coastline to visit the stunning Peterhoff Grand Palace & Gardens. It was a fitting way to end our trip to this part of Russia. The palace was what we have come to expect here - opulence on a grand scale, but it was the fountains & the views back to the palace from down the canal that will always stay in my mind - just stunning - ensure this is on your list!
Peterxof 2015. I visit in June 2015 ,lovely garden with many fountains and huge park.You must visit the museum to see how they lived at that time the great Peter!!!
Beauty. Good palace and park....must see if visiting petersburg. Have booked tour for 1700 ruble from nevisky prospect..and they drove us to palace. All inclusion of tickets.

Spectacular Palace with fountains to match!. This was our very first stop in St.Petersburg. We arrived by cruise ship and booked a private tour with Marina's tours.....and so glad we did!! It is about a 30-40 drive from the city. The grounds are extensive and the palace truly spectacular. Even though we arrived early there were already many people and a long queue, however, private tours just go through! You are not allowed a bag/ backpack although a small handbag is allowed. We checked both our jackets and bags in and then you have to wear overshoes to protect the wooden floors. No photography is allowed.We spent a little while in the palace and then when the fountains are switched on we headed out to the grounds. Marina had organised a buggy for us so we saw a lot more of the grounds and fountains than many people....even seeing a half red and half grey squirrel!! From the shore we took a hydrofoil back into the city.

Just some random park but dozen time bigger. Generally, the park is a nice place to stroll and take pictures ( if you don't mind posing in massive public). Most people love going to the small beach at the end of the park, but coming from a country with lots of sandy beaches and warm sea I was not amused. It would take you almost half a day to walk the whole park. It is big so the fee is worth it. However, I'm not sure why the guards there doesn't allow visitors to sit on the grass.

Grand Palace. The entrance to the main staircase was adorned with gilded carvings which led to beautiful decorated staterooms. The Lower gardens feature a 300 acre park with spectacular system of fountains which includes cascades and 173 fountains.

Without a doubt the most spectacular palace!. This place tops any palace in the world, including Versailles! It is so grand and spectacular. There is a reason it is the #1 thing to do in St Petersburg. One could get lost in the grounds alone. We got there in the am and did an inside tour. It was very quiet because the fountains don't start until 11am. That's when the crowds come. Go see the inside before that and then head out a little before 11am to see them come on. It really is a show. I only wish pictures could be taken on the inside. But outside is what is important!

Louis XIV to the 9s. Grand, is to small of a word. Amazing, will not bring the vision to light. Impressive, to say the least. Beauty, Rich, Opulent, Gold, Gardens, Fountains of Cascading Water, The Floors, The Ceilings. It's all to much for words. Come and see for yourself. After the Grand Palace at Peterhof you do not need to visit anymore palaces.

Wow. Visited for the second time and the place has lost none of its ability to awe. Took a guided tour of the palace and gardens. The palace tour was a bit rushed as it was a busy Sunday, but the gardens are just outstanding. The main cascade and the sheer amount of gold is unforgettable. It's really worth paying the extra for a guided tour as the anecdotes especially regarding the trick fountains are fascinating.We had planned to take the hydrofoil back, bit unfortunately an approaching storm on the Baltic meant that all boats were cancelled which was a shame. But this is among the most impressive sights you'll ever see and allow a full day. You won't regret it.
A must see place in St-Petersbourg. The Grand Palace is a must see, for its splendor, and history. Take a guide, or a bus tour, and plan a half day minimum for the visit.

A must see outside St. Petersburg, true beauty. We visited Peterhof and the grand palace with our tour guide while in St. Petersburg for two days on our Baltic cruise. We had not heard much about it so we didn't have any expectations. We were amazed. The palace itself is gorgeous but it's the grounds of the palace that you'll really want to see. I could have stood at the main fountain area for hours. The fountains are below the palace making for great pictures and all the fountains are a beautiful gold color. When you have a sunny day like we did, words cannot describe it. Then make sure to have a walk around the many acres of grounds. Beautiful landscaping and more fountains everywhere you turn. Make sure to also head to the very back of the grounds for some great panaromic views of the Baltic Sea.If you're in St. Petersburg for more than one day, make sure to make the 30 minute drive out to Peterhof.

Absolute opulence!. Wow, we could not believe the opulence in this Palace. We got to Peterhof by hydrofoil from St Petersburg - it was a lovely, comfy ride. Then the walk began - up the gardens to the Palace. Unfortunately there were masses of people which certainly doesn't make for a comfortable visit, but our tour guide Dina of TJ Travel was a gem. She took us where she could away from the crowds of tourists and she was a wealth of information. I would highly recommend her and the company! A feature in the gardens - the fountains were absolutely amazing. All gravity fed, there had never been a water pump involved with these fountains. Peterhof is a MUST SEE!

Magnificent - Plan it for a sunny day to get it all. Plan your visit on a sunny day to better grasp all the magnificence of Peterhof; The luxurious gardens, the fountains, time off for a lunch, the fountains, the breath taking landscape, the fountains - and yes, so many, fountains and in so many different shapes and fashions that you may be led to believe you have seen fountains for the rest of the year.One can reach Peterhof either by speed boat, or by public transport; Eventually both ways have their advantages, and being among russians in a public transport and different landscape on the way, was part of the spirit, thus I really enjoyed it.If going by public transport you want to reach the Avtovo metro station; When there spare some time to appreciate the beauty of this metro station where the Station Hall is stunningly beautiful. Once on the street there are vans departing every two minutes to Peterhof, thus no hassle at all. A public regular bus line also runs and costs pretty much the same. At Peterhof there is a 10 usd cost to enter the gardens, then additional cost for each attraction. Better off visiting on a bright sunny day, plenty of mood to appreciate the gardens, courtyards and the many, many fountains. Spare a whole day for this attraction.

Do Your Homework First. My wife and I had a wonderful day at Peterhof recently. The gardens, fountains and buildings were extraordinary! However, a word of warning. There are no maps or brochures at Peterhof (only a few signposts) and the ticket booths and signs at the entrances to the various buildings are in Russian only. We stood in line for almost an hour at the palace only to find out we had not purchased the correct combo ticket, even though our ticket looked exactly the same as all the other tickets, and we had to come back later in the day. The Peterhof website English page explains the various ticket combos with prices, and maps of Peterhof also can be downloaded from the Internet (but not the Peterhof website). We could have saved ourselves some frustration and time by doing more research first. A guidebook with maps would be useful.

Nice garden, gorgeous palace. I was sceptic after I paid 550RUB to enter the palace but it is definitely worth. It is a very nice palace with a very beautiful entrance and ball room. Definitely a good choice.We then had a walk around the garden. The garden is also nice and worth to see. Some details:Transportation: We took the metro to the Awtowo station (very beautiful station) and then you take a minibus from there. All in all costs 91 RUB/p. and around 70minutes from Newski.Garden cost: 500 RUBPalace: 550 RUBIn total you can calculate 1 day for the visit. There are some other small museums which you can visit, we did not...

Magnificent Gardens and Fountains. It's so easy to get to Peterhof that it would be a great shame for any visitor to St. Petersburg not to go there. The hydrofoil leaves from the quay right behind The Hermitage. The trip takes just over 30 minutes and you arrive just a very short distance from the entrance to the Park. Get there before 11.00 am in order to see the magnificent fountains in front of the palace entering service. A walk in the park is a delight. There are several fountains to admire and enjoy. Peterhof is not an inexpensive destination, taking into account the cost of the hydrofoil and the separate entrance fees for the park, the palace and the other buildings there. You don't need to see and do everything but don't miss Mon Plaisir. So, read your guide book and decide in advance on exactly what you want to see and do there. You are very unlikely to be disappointed.

Extraordinary. All of it was magnificent. We liked the gardens and fountains the best and had a front row seat when the turned on the fountain cascade at 1100. Beautiful grounds. It was very crowded when we were there but manageable.

Grand Palace indeed... . Grounds and rooms in palace are truly stunning. I walked thru the palace myself without a guide and didn't take long if you're able to pass the other groups. Don't shop there. The most expensive prices I saw all trip.

As grand as it can be. Having visited the Catherine Palace, we weren't very keen on doing Peterhof, especially knowing both were built by the same architects. However, we went there for the fountains.We were pleasantly surprised by the amount of exhibits in the palace. Very similar to the Catherine Palace with double the amount of materials. Lots of paintings and furniture from neighbouring China too. Grand halls were amazing!The highlight has to be the fountains! Originally there were 300 of them, today 150 remain. We had lots of fun going through each one of them and followed the flow to the Gulf of Finland. The tricky fountain was especially fun for kids. Flowers were blooming and apparently squirrels were residents of the garden too.

Quite grand ma-lady, visit bathroom first. So much gold, so much opulence, so many fountains. A stunning grounds and building. Tour groups can get annoying. I went to find the sturgeon fishing but it didnt seem to be open.
Beautiful. Like all the architecture of government buildings and palaces, it is splendid from facade to interior. Views of this building's exterior are more complete from canal boats. Recommend.

Amazing!. Overwhelming opulence. Now I understand why the peasants revolted. If Russia cashed in the gold used here, they would be the wealthiest nation around...thank heavens they have not done that!

Dazzling!!!!. Oh my GOD!!!this is a dazzling place!!!First..i admire the great attention they give to that place...you should wear overshoes coverings so as not to harm the floor!!No smoking allowed...No photo taking allowed...You just cant find words to describe the beauty of the place...the paintings...the rooms...the things and antiques!!The water fountains are just amazing...The gardens...the decorations inside and outside!!!This place is a miracle..

A Must see in Russia. Went on a tour to see this. It is beautiful to see and full of history. Pictures do not do justice. Our trip to Russia is one of my favorites and this is just one of the places that you will not regret touring.
Voucher. Get your vouchers from the Hotel, it's much quicker and, you go straight to the front of the Que ................................................

Beautiful beautiful beautiful . Fountains everywhere!!! One of the beautiful places in Saint Petersburg. My family enjoyed the visit to this place. My son was very happy to see the pigeons around him 😜

History Russian royal decadence!. I visited here in May of 2015. I just stuck to the outside of the palace and strolled through the gardens and fountains. This was one of the most beautiful and unique places I've ever been.

Luxury of the oldies!. another palace with many details of gold and all the luxury of the tsars! You are stanished before your entrance because the golden statues in the yards and the canals are showing what will follow!

Amazing park . 1.st of May in Peter.We catch the small busses out the metro Автово, with 60 roubles you reach the entrance of the park in 30 minutes. On the way you can see the government palace where Putin use to invite his foreign guests.The entrance of the park is amazing:golden onions shining in the sun under the Russian flags. Ticket 400 rubles. Spend inside 2hours minimum and enjoy the relaxing and peaceful places and fountains.the main one is impressive. From the main balcony u see the sea side 800 metres away.. Walk around and discover the " Adamo and Eve" fountains. Look for the lions fountain. Walk along the coast and reach the "Mon plesire " garden. The tricky fountains are all around. take care: you will be wet by the water tricks .Reach the Roman fountains and enjoy the chess falls.End your visit with the last pics at the "Neptune" fountain and give the last look to the main stairs full of falls and the biggest fountains.

Magnificent!. This palace is the grandest in St Petersburg. We made the trip during poor weather and weren't disappointed. The palace is set amongst the most stunning and manicured grounds. The fountains get more elaborate and grand as you make your way down through the palace. The palace museum is just magnificent. We opted for the audio guide and found it was very informative. Walking along the park be on the look out for the hidden water jets. These are pranks setup to get you wet. Avoid lunch on the grounds of you'll be paying seriously inflated prices.

Excellent (best) half day trip from St Petersburg. Wow. I've been to Versailles, the Schonbrunn, la Alhambra, the Doges and I think the Peterhof tops them all. Every room is amazing, the grounds are beautiful. Best to try avoiding the guided tours and get here on your own. Not too bad taking the metro to Avtovo then Bus 200 or 210 or metro to Baltiyskaya and then Bus 404. Buses cost around 55 Rubles. Hotel organized tours to Peterhof cost 3,000 Rubles. In the summer, the hydrofoil is supposed to be easy and fun, although the cost is about 10 times that of the bus. Don't miss the Peterhof, worth a morning or afternoon of your time.

One word, BEAUTIFUL. One word, beutifull. Grand palace of Peterhof.Don't miss it. Just one thing to remember, it might be more crowded in the summer but the palace is nothing without the garden and it's fountains.

Amazing. This is absolutely the most gorgeous place in Russia. The trip there takes about 45 minutes from the city of Saint Petersburg, but it is worth every second of it. An absolute treasure. Wag I was there during summer time as it most be even more gorgeous.

Catherine's Summer Palace?. I'm not sure of the title, but if this Grand Palace is Catherine's Summer Palace, it's a MUST! Your eye will hurt from seeing so much gold leaf. Furnishings and paintings are gorgeous.
Nice place to visit. If you go to Sint Petersburg it is very nice to visit a few nice places and the Grand Palace is one of them

Save it to go on a hot sunny day. If you like palaces that might be one hell of good place to visit.But the real "gold" there it it the gardens, and that it is for sure.Golden statues which are so bright that reflects the sun, plus the fountain/staircase/waterfall makes it more beautiful, all that surrounded by green from the garden around it. The staircase with water goes until the sea which makes it more especial! But the thing is go in the spring/summer other wise you will fell how Russian + sea can be could besides the fountain/staircase/waterfall is off. I went it in the beginning of the russian spring and was freezing cold and it was off, but is nice tho

most beatiful palace... it s a magnificient palace with the view,garden and fountains.You can not say that i stayed in st.petersburg without visiting this palace.The garden is not only a garden,it is a kind of art forest,after every there you explore new historical art objects like sculptures,figurines,copper,brass,bronz fountains..It is a heaven on earth..you sould go and spend one whole day in the garden and palace..

You must see it!. The Grand Palace was originally a rather modest royal palace designed by J. Braunstein and Jean-Baptiste Le Blond. When the palace became the center of attention for Tsar Peter, the Tsar himself presented his visions for the grounds and palace to the architects. The palace was built in "Petrine Baroque" style and due to Peter’s enthusiasm, a massive amount of work in the landscaping and expansion was carried out during the years 1714-1725.The work resumed during the years 1745-1755 by architect Francesco Bartolomeo Rastrelli, on behalf of Empress Elizabeth (Peter’s daughter), on the model of Versailles - the so-called mature Baroque style. The view of the facade of the Grand Palace, especially from Lower Park, is impressive but the palace itself is quite narrow and not as big as it looks. One of the most spectacular interiors of the palace is the Grand Staircase, which impresses with its gilded wood carvings. The most magnificent interior of the palace is the Ballroom; a sea of lights reflects the endless mirrors and gilded wood carvings. The most famous of all rooms - The Chesma Hull, bears its name is in memory of the battle Chesmen of 25-26 June, 1770 in the Aegean Sea. In this battle the Russian fleet achieved a decisive victory in the Russian-Turkish war of 1768-1774. Catherine II, who received the news of the destruction of the Turkish fleet, ordered a series of paintings by the German artist Jacob Philipp Hackert. Visitors should also pay attention to the Chinese Cabinets and Picture Hall.

Most Beautiful Fountains and Gardens. A definite must see if you re in Russia and St Petersburg! The fountains and statues look incredible in photograph, they are even better in person. It really was a dream come true to visit this palace, the home of the Romanov family and birth place of Anastasia the grand duchess! You can really spend a good part of the day just strolling through the amazing gardens and admiring the many fountains scattered around. Not to mention Its also a photographers paradise. How to describe the grand palace in one word... GOLD.

Worth a day trip. A great day-trip away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Even without the fountains working (we visited in mid-March), the gardens were fun to explore and provided some great views over the Baltic. Free toilets in the grounds were very clean, and plenty of benches dotted around the gardens and fountains provided a much-needed rest when wandering the grounds.The Palace itself is a real pleasure to visit, even after the opulence of the Winter Palace. Our one complaint would be that no photography of any kind was allowed inside, despite the 550 ruble entrance fee for adults.Top tips: Flash your student card for a discount on entry - 300 rubles instead of 550.Do a little research and take the local minibus to the site. We got the metro to Avtovo, crossed over to the other side of the road, and hopped on one of the minibuses with a 'Peterhof' sign in the windscreen. The journey lasted around 30 minutes and cost 55 rubles each - really easy to find the right bus stop for the journey back, too.

Nice place but Visit during Summer, not winter time.. We took the metro to Avtovo station and change to the K buses that goes to Peterhof. The buses per trip is 55 rubles. Its about 20mins bus journey and briefly know where to stop. The drivers do not really speak english except 1 word, Peterhof. We stopped outside the lower gardens and slowly make our way to the palace. The ground is massive. However, visit it during summer. In winter, a lot of the places within the palace were closed for re-furbishing and the fountains were not turned on. It was a pity but nevertheless a very good experience we had.

Badly damage during the War - and they are still repairing it.. I am sure I read that thousands of serfs died during the Russian winter while digging out the 200 metres of 'See Channel.' And we would like to thank the German soldiers who lived here for three years during the war for their parting gesture of partially 'blowing up' the palace and leaving it to burn. !!!Of the 30 rooms I loved the floor of the Throne Room - Russians excel at parquetry .Overall Peterhof reminded me of Frederick the Great's palace at Potsdam. It was very nice but not particularly spectacular compared to comparable places. However, full marks for the front fountains, absolutely superb.Brian, from Perth. W. Australia.

Don't miss this. This was everything it was described as - the scale, grandeur and opulence is like nothing we've ever seen before. It's impossible to see everything but we managed quite a lot over two days although you not only get sore feet from walking so much but also a sore neck from looking up all the time at the amazing ceilings. The Egyptian museum section is incredible. I'm sure you know that entrance is free on the first Thursday of the month but we still chose to book on line and pay for our ticket which we were thankful for as the queues were enormous all day long.
Astonshing palace!. At first it leaves you with the mouth open, then whilst enjoying, it makes you feel relaxed. Fun afterwards with the big gardens and the playful fountains!

Great destination. A popular tourist destination and a must-see in St. Petersburg! Loved the impressive palace and massive garden. The fountain show was what everyone was waiting for, so be sure to get yourself a good spot!

Great place to see, but.... Although the Palace is stunning, in the summer it can be quite hot and there are 50 zillion tour groups all trying to go through at once! It IS very popular and beautiful, just be prepared for the crowds. Also, definitely see the fountains come on... simply spectacular!

45-60 minutes away from downtown to phenomenal formal gardens. The picture shown for the attraction is actually what appears to be the estate manager's home. The palace itself is much, much bigger. That being said, the star of the show here is the formal gardens surrounding the palace. Within them can be found an array of huge, unusual fountains as well as various pieces of statuary. Personally, I thought the palace itself and artwork within it to be underwhelming after visiting the Heritage state museum. However, the formal gardens are a wonder. Be sure to verify the fountains are operational. Because of the potentially freezing temperatures, there's a limited time that they're filled and functional.
Waste of time. Nothing special... everything is dirty... everyone is rude. It was a pain to be there... nobody spoke english. Just a waste of time.. very disappointing

Breathtaking Gardens. We toured the gardens at Peterhof during the summer, and it was most amazing! I don't even think I have enough adjectives to describe it. We were in St Petersburg for 2 days, and visiting the Peterhof gardens was part of our 2-day tour. The gardens and especially the fountains are so impressive. The sheer enormousness of the grounds was overwhelming. We ate at a small pectopah (restaurant) in the gardens. Our lunch was traditional Russian fare and very tasty. It was well presented & served. The beauty of Peterhof is something to behold if you are visiting the area. I'm uploading pictures that I think others may not have added. I certainly recommend a visit here!

Summer palace. The summer palace of Peter the great is a majestic and fabulous place. You can find golden statues, lakes, waterfalls and gardened parks. Be carefull, because the waterfalls aren't working all year round.

Peterhof. The Summer Palace of Peter the Great is one of the most amazing sites one can visit in SPB during summer period, putting together the great history of the palaces and their interior, the glamour of the fountains and the beauty of the nature and the gardens. A MUST SEE for whole family and as a full day excursion.
Very well preserved. It gives the feeling that you are back to XVIII century. You can have a very good idea how the czars lived.

Not sure I rated it as highly. Let's put it this way - if you go to St P in the summer to experience white nights then this particular palace is probably up there but in January it's just kind of gloomy and unspectacular. So I'd say it's a purely seasonal attraction

Magnificent Peterhof. After a short trip from St. Petersburg, Russia on a hydrofoil, the beautiful Summer Palace of Peter the Great comes into view. Even the walk from the dock, on the Bay of Finland, is thrilling. During the summer months into very early autumn, try to time your arrival shortly before 11 A.M. At 11 the magnificent fountains are turned on to the rousing tune of the overture to a Russian opera. A great experience! Aside from the sheer opulence of the palace itself, the surrounding gardens and statuary are breathtaking. A trip to St. Petersburg should not be considered complete without seeing Peterhof.

plush. it was a grand palace a place where russian royalty lived and it was so majestic from the outside and in the massive courtyard , then in the inside there were some of the most amazing paintings and collection of russian opulance

The grandeur!!. The best time to visit this fabulous place is in the Summer. The fountains operate only during the summer. One of the most beautiful places in St. Petersburg, your visit is not complete without paying homage here.

Amazing place. We visited this a private tour of St Petersburg. The opulence of the palace and gardens was amazing. I especially loved the spring flowers. The actors in period costumes were a nice touch.
Looking across the gulf towards Finland ... was incredible to think it was so close.
I recommend this as a must do in Russia

beautifull palace beautifull visit. if you go to saint petersburg , i highly recommand to go outside of the city and to visit the beautifull Peterhof Palace : nice place, nice garden, close to the sea, in winter you will have the snow to do very nice pictures of the palace with the snow, with christmas trees, very nice winter holidays

Toooo short. Some info panels were written just in русский not English. The place is just amazing. Original and reconstructed rooms from XVIII century. There are very strict rules, allowed only to watch and breath. There are dozen of women starring at you like you are a thief eager to steal everything

The Russian Versailles!. The Peterhof Palace is located outside in Peterhof. We went on a bus tour. It is accessible by train as well. Peterhof is charming! The great palace was built by Peter the Great. The palace is breathtaking. There are rooms to see with furnitures : bedrooms, dining halls, staterooms, etc. it is beautifully preserved and gives us a glimpse of how the Tsars lived their lives.The garden is simply breathtaking and beautiful. The series of fountains are stunning with golden colors and looks very regal.i it is a beautiful walk and one can walk to the seashore. Worthwhile visit!!

Awesome palace. History buffs will find the Great Palace a feast for the senses as guides point out and highlight how this building and its occupants have shaped Russian history. Prepare for crowds...because this is one of the must see's in St. Petersburg. It does NOT spoil your enjoyment because the building is on such a scale that you can navigate in between the surges and still see items very close up. A truly wonderful experience.

Beautiful gardens. Part of the charm of the place actually comes from the beautiful gardens and the gilded statues all around. Visiting the place on a good weather when all the foliage and the flowers are at its beautiful best will make you appreciate its beauty. The guided tours will give access to certain rooms and news inside but it was not that impressive as much as the exteriors were. This I believe is an active residence and hence have lots of restrictions and rules.
Masterpiece. One of the best cultural and historical institutions in the world! Make sure you explore enough Russian section.

Fabulous fountains. The fountains, flowers, and grounds are not to be missed in summer if the trip from St. Petersburg is by hydrofoil, and one has only two days in that city. The palace is an extra charge, and crowded, and is overshadowed by the landscaping outside. The trick fountains add a little fun to a visit.

Stately and Overpowering. The power of the heads of state are evident here. Vladimir Putin still stays here when he is in St. Petersburg. It is a large outdoor space with a lot of room to roam, but there are not a tremendous amount of places to visit on the inside.

Must see in St. Petersburg. It is very impressive historical place. You haven't been to St. Petersburg if you didn't visit Great Palace. Tip: tickets are cheaper for Russian speaking tourists, so ask someone who speaks Russian to get a ticket for you in case you don't need a guided tour and just want to stroll around ;)

amazing fountains. Visitors will love the spectacular grounds at Peterhof. The fastest way to travel to Peterhof is via hydrofoil from the Hermitage embankment. If you would enjoy running through the fountains, please note that they are not close to the entrance and you may wish to bring a change of clothing if it is a chilly day. Children will greatly enjoy the trick fountain run by a man sitting on a bench reading the newspaper - he took pity on my 3 year old son and only got him a little wet at first, and soaked him on his fourth run through the fountains. The grounds of Peterhof are an enchanting visit for travelers of all ages.
Russia trip before the revolution. Just beautiful. Inside the palaces but also the park outside. We visited by accident, during the day the fountains were switched on after the winter

Impressive day out. This was a great day trip from our stay in St Petersburg in the summer.The fountains are the real highlight especially in front of the main palace complex.Go with a picnic and spend the day there, especially in the hot summer months.

No crowd in december. although the fountains are switched off, it is still worth to visit Peterhof in December. Entry is 550 Rubles for the big hall only. Take a Marshrutka from line 1 Metro station Avtovo, eg nr. 300. This costs 55 rubles per person and is for sure the cheapest way. But without Russian it can be difficult. Attention: no ships going from Eremitage to Peterhof in Winter, of course, due to the ice.

A symphony of Fountains in a beautifully landscaped Garden. The sheer size of the Great Palace of Peterhof is magnificent. It is actually a series of Palaces united together. The wonder and splendor of the architecture, inside and outside is awe inspiring. The interior has so much gold lining the walls that it is hard to believe that such workmanship exists. The floors are also works of art in the way they are designed. It is hard to take it all in during one visit, but a lot of fun trying.The gardens are beautifully landscaped and there are soooo many fountains. There is an upper garden and a lower garden, with gardens within the gardens. One of the lower gardens has some trick fountains that challenge you to get past them without getting wet; good fun! We were fortunate in October, the fountains were still running and are they ever impressive, WOW!Jon Lefeber
Do not miss. In my opinion, one of the most beautiful churches in the world both inside and out. The mosaic work is out of this world.

Too crowded. Gardens and views on the palace are fantastic. And maybe we should have been happy with the stroll and the pictures... Getting inside was just a nightmare. There seems to be no control on the number of people, so each room will be filled with tourist groups. You will not be able to walk or move - even breathing becomes challenging! Not that much to see inside anyway. Unless you are a big fan, I would skip it. I still rate it with a 3 since the outside area (gardens, fountains) is amazing.
Great huge and memorable. A must see you just cannot imagine how good people were in architecture considering technology at that time

Beautiful but unfriendly staff. We visited this palace while on a cruise. It is absolutely breathtaking and the fountains around the grounds are beautiful. However the staff is rude and less than welcoming. It was drizzling the day we were there and no one was allowed to keep their coats. This is difficult when using the pockets to keep money, passport, camera, etc. but they would not hear of it. At least one couple choose not to go through the palace which was sad as the tour was expensive. I would still recommend this to see but try to go on a dry day!

Perfect if you visit this early morning and read this….... A trip to St Perersburg visiting the Great Palace as well as the Hermitage is a great combination. Here you must arrive as early as possible for opening as it becomes quite manic as the day moves on. Also……make sure before you leave that if you have family….especially children…you get in a "loo" visit because once you leave the souvenir shopping area where the loos are…they will not allow you back in and there is nothing else nearby.Also…if it is a hot day (very likely in the summer) and you want to buy drinks or ice-creams from the many vendors in the grounds…….you MUST have roubles. They don't tale US dollars or credit cards.Best way to visit is by water.

Beautiful Gardens and Fountains. About 20 miles from St. Petersburg it is well worth the trip. The palace is situated on a steep hill overlooking the Baltic. The best part of this visit were the massive gardens with beautiful fountains and cascading water from numerous gold sculptures. Be sure to visit at a time when the music and fountains are activated.

Peterhof without seeing Fountain. I went to Peterhof this begin of winter(mid October).Fountains were not opened.Upper and Lower Garden all trees were without any leafs.A little bit disappointment,Build and architectural,sculpture are beautiful and amazing.Museum in the great palace are fabulous.Next time to St.Peterburg I will plan to go better duration(from spring to mid september is suitable duration).

Fabulous. This was from an amazing place to visit.I would highly recommend. You simply cannot be in the Syria not take the truck to this palace. The tragedy is that it was essentially destroyed during World War II and what's seen today is an extensive reconstruction and restoration of the original palace made an earlier post war Soviet days.I have to say, the Soviets did it right. I suppose they wanted impressive visitors.The dancing water fountains were great. Everything was marvelous.
Massive place. Go early in the morning is you are walking around and taking photos. Hardly any crowds but as the morning progress the tour buses show up ready for entry into the Palace.

Peterhof Palace. Gem of St.Petersburg-one can spend whole day there-the Garden fountains are the highlights. Better than any eurpoean palace. Grounds are huge. The Palace is probably better than Versailles.

A MINI VERSAILLES. If time permits, take the ferry from St Petersburg. Time was not on my side so I took a car, driver and English speaking guide. OK, it was not cheap, but it was well worth it. We approached by walking from the town side along a very long drive past one or two fountains to the main house. It appears to be massive, but in fact is a long thin building, mainly one, but on occasions two smaller rooms thick. However, the State Rooms are magnificent. There is an abundance of gilt and mirrors with of course chandeliers. The rooms were well furnished. The decor is very lavish and it was a joy to visit. What really wanted to see was the view of the house from the other side - ie as if approaching from the Gulf of Finland. The Grand Cascade is modeled on the one built for Louis XIV at Chåteau Marly. It is spectacular, all those fountains with the house behind. The view from the House's terrace is also good. I enjoyed walking round the grounds with smaller but very creative fountains, formal French gardens and of course smaller palaces. My only regret is that we dis not have more time. We left St Petersburg at 1.30pm and returned at 7pm. It deserves a full day. and then you won't see it all. Although it was early October, the fountains were all working - the highest has a jet of 20 metres and none is operated by a pump!

Absolutely extravagant, and a must see. A nice boat ride from St Petersburg and you arrive at one of the most extravagant homes you can imagine. The water fountains and the extensive lawn area was my favorite, though the palace itself is not to be missed. There are food and drink vendors as you get off the boat so you stroll for awhile, have a snack or a drink and get back to it. It makes for a pleasant experience, and you get to see what wealth the Czarist leaders had.

Beautiful place, awful people. We are not all russians, we don't speak russian but we would like to visit your palaces and museums! If you let us!!So, please put some signs in latin letters!!! We don't understand anything! You should go to Russia only if you speak or intend to learn russian! They don't speak english and everything is written in chirilic letters! Good luck!

A Must See. Take the ferry from downtown St Petersburg to this palace and gardens with wonderful fountains.
It truly is a great experience and gives you an insight to how the Russian nobility lived.
We had a guide with us and it added to the experience. Don't miss making the effort to going there.

NO.1 ATTRACTION IN RUSSIA!. No words can describe this wonderful place , near the beautiful gulf of finland and a canal runs through the great place from the gulf to the palace,wonderful gardens around and fountains , please visit if you are in st.petersburg ,never miss visiting this .

Grand and Beautiful. We were lucky enough to reach before the start of the fountains at 11 am, which is accompanied by the music of their national anthem I think. Beautiful gardens and Gold statues are enhanced with the fountains. Church and the large park behind the palace is also beautiful. Well connected by road and by sea. Could reach by Ferry, train, bus etc.

Stunning. Situated by The Gulf of Finland and approx 20 miles from St Petersburgh this is a must place to visit,the palace is not that big but makes up for that by the decor absolutely breathtaking especially the main staircase and the ballroom both with fantastic ceilings,you should take your time in all the rooms as they all have something to offer.The fountains are switch on at 11am,The great cascade fountain must be one of the best in the world with the sculptures covered with gilded gold with jets of water shooting high,there are a number of working fountains all over the gardens and some play a trick on you be prepared.To finish the day take the hydrofoil back to St Petersbugh it takes you to the quay in front of the Winter palace

Spectacular and Extravagent. I am very impressed by the splendor of this palace. It gave us an indication of how powerful Russia was during the reign of Peter the Great. Yes, they used a lot of gold. It was very extravagantly built.

Too much gold!!!!!!!!!!!!. I learned a lot about queen Elizabeth the daughter of Peter the Great. She was very egotistical and if she were not maybe all the money she spent on herself and the Palace would have gone to better causes.

Great gardens. The extensive gardens are great for a stroll. The palace itself, on the other hand, is not that impressive.On a sunny day the stroll in the park is particularly pleasant, allowing great pictures of the many fountains.Go with one of the buses that depart from Avtovo metro station and don't miss that metro station, an attraction on it's own.

Gold everywhere - Kitsch castle. Arriving by boat gives you the amazing view on the beautiful fountain installation with the mega castle in the back. An absolute perfect setting for such a castle. The fountain is over the top with its 1000 golden statues. A walk through the park is absolutely recommendable as it gives a good feel for the size of the palace and its surroundings. You an also discover smaller installations in the far corners, where there are significantly less tourists.The golf carts are annoying and they should be separate from the pedestrians. Most of the people on the carts would benefit from a bit more exercise...An absolute must visit. It gives a great pictures of the wealth and power of the tsars.

A sight to behold. The former tsars of Russia certainly knew how to live.And one of the best places to see the opulent luxury they enjoyed is by visiting Peterhof Palace in St Petersburg.This magnificent Great Palace was conceived by Peter the Great and dubbed the Russian Versailles.Fortunately for us, the incredible cascade of fountains was in full working order, and I could have stayed there for hours gazing at them, but we had the rest of the grounds - and city - to explore.You need a visa if you want to explore St Petersburg on your own. But we got over that by booking shore excursions as part of our Baltic cruise with Fred.Olsen Cruise Lines.It meant we had two full days to explore the magnificent palaces of St Petersburg, using our ship, the Braemar, as our hotel for the night.So, we were also able to visit the fabulous Hermitage Museum which boasts works by Leonardo da Vinci, Rembrandt and Michelangelo among its collections. And also enjoyed a trip to the palace of Catherine I, with a night time boat trip on St Petersburg's waterways thrown in for good measure.

Indescribable. The wait to view the palace was long, but definitely worth it. In short, this was my favorite attraction in our twenty-one day visit of the Baltic region. The ensemble of gold fountains with water cascading down terraced steps was mesmerizing. Backpacks and jackets must be checked prior to touring the palace. Not wheel chair friendly. Wear comfortable walking shoes.

Great indeed. There is gold everywhere and this is a very grand place indeed. Ther gardens are very good with the water features very prominent. The guide tended to rush everyone through it but it is a fine attraction.

Star Attraction Of St Petersburg. St Petersburg is a fascinating city with so many attractions that you sometimes need to get away from the centre of town. What better way to do it than drive down to Peterhof Great Palace in Peterhof about 30 minutes drive south of the city. This is by far the most entertaining of all the attractions on offer and steeped in tons of history. In particular Peter the Great and Katherine the Great. This is a great rival to the Palace of Versailles in Paris and the Schoebrun in Austria. I think this one outdoes them both with the spectacular fountain displays. You would have no chance of smuggling anything in to the place. Everyone is treated as a potential terrorist with intentions of stealing Russias Crown Jewel collection. All the guards are middle aged women (affectionately known as ''The dragons'') and there is not a smile among the lot of them. You can't get a heavy coat or an umbrella past the dragons. It was the summer holiday resort for the royal families right through to the Bolshevik Revolution. The contents of the palace are spectacular and the rooms are dripping in gilt. The best attraction though is the beautiful gardens and the spectacular golden fountains. There is a cost in getting there but it is worth it. Don't even attempt it without a knowledgeable guide. It is built on the Baltic Sea with distant views back to the city. This is by far the best attraction in SP and it would be a pity to go all that way and miss it.

A must-see but cleverly designed to milk tourists of every penny. To think this palace was resurrected from near-ruin to its past glory is beyond impressive. As Americans would say, 'It's awesome.' Fantastic attention to detail. It's one of the few attractions I've been too around the world where I sensed a really positive vibe and community spirit from all the visitors. Lots of Russians visit as well as foreign tourists. It's so impressive everyone walks around in awe. You can quite easily spend days here. There are queues to many of the attractions within, and I did feel like you pay to get in and then you pay again and again to see discrete areas within the grounds and main complex. But it will have cost 100s of millions to restore and someone has to pay for it. So it falls on the tourist, which is fair enough. I think locals pay less than foreigners.The grounds are as impressive as the palace. A tour through the water-system that drives all the fountains is fun and fascinating. The idea that little children, in centuries past, went up the 22 kilometres of pipes to clean them is a scary thought but apparently true, according to our guide. English is spoken but patchy. The grounds are wonderful to walk through. Of course opulence on a grand scale. Some of the summer houses by the sea are fun - with features that in their day would have been as cool as an iPad is to us today. Unfortunately we could not take photos inside those caringly restored buildings, so none to share. If you are staying in St. Petersburg I would recommend taking the hydrofoil out to Peterhof. It's a quick journey across open water, and it adds to the drama of the day. If you are not able to walk long distances, the only downside with the hydrofoil is, there's a bit of walk from the dock (albeit a very impressive walk up a canal with fountains) to the main palace. A coach or taxi might park you closer to the main palace in that sense.
beautiful. Beautiful square, huge with great view of the Hermitage and russian young people playing with skateboard, motorcycle, a nice place to start your visit

Without doubt a great summer palace. Built under the direction of Peter the Great, this Grand Peterhof Palace positioned up in a bluff facing the ocean in a distance is without a doubt a great summer get away for Emperors and Empresses ( name was changed to Petrovorets meaning Peter's Palace in 1944 and then restored to the former Peterhof in 1997 ) . One would definitely be impressed looking out from the front landing of the Palace proper the long stretch of gardens and fountains dissected by a sea channel right in the middle all the way to the ocean front. The view was breathtaking and indeed fit for a King. We walked along the sea channel all the way to the coast and the view of the Palace from the other end was equally impressive. This part of the compound I believe is called the lower garden and there were plenty of walkways in the park on the two side of the channel for one to explore if you have got your walking shoes. The Samson fountain positioned between the Palace and the Sea Channel shoots a jet of water sky high and story was told that Samson pulling apart the jaws of a lion represents Russia's victory over Sweden in a bygone era. One interesting thing about the fountains in the Palace is I was told they operate without pumps, using merely elevation difference to create pressure to drive the water. The Palace itself is a rather narrow strip of building and unfortunately photography was not allowed inside. There is the lavishly gilded grand ballroom with ample glittering chandeliers on the wall, the Throne Room that houses only one elevated red chair probably for the Emperor, an elegant white Dining Room, a hall that was adorned with many large paintings of the Battle of Chesma - a war between Russia and Turkey (our guide told us that since the painter had no experience of war at sea, Catherine II arrange for the explosion of a frigate so he can get some idea as to how to paint) and a stateroom that hung hundreds of canvas portraits of women of difference ages, appearances and attires ( said to be drawn with the same model). One interesting fact about this palace is the floors are superbly finished and patterned parquet floors with different designs for different areas - can imagine how the prince and princess glided when they waltzed in the Ball Room. We did not have the time to tour the upper garden but from a distance, it was far less spectacular than the lower one. This Palace being dubbed the Russian Versaille is a must go place when you visit St. Petersburg.

Takes your breath way!. We took the hydrofoil from behind the Winter Palace, and within a little over 30 mins we were disembarking at the jetty. The first view of the palace, from along a canal literally takes your breath away. The gardens and house have been lovingly restored and maintained (after the destruction of 1943). The fountains, golden statues and achingly beautiful palace must not be missed.Top Tip 1 - Take a pair of comfortable shoes, you will need them.Top Tip 2 - Take plenty of money, if you want to visit any of the other exhibits, the main entrance only grants you access to the gardens.Top Tip 3 - Obtain a plan of the gardens (and look out for the red squirrels)

Best attraction in St. Petersburg. Seems like you can walk here forewer. Fountains are creative and beautiful. When you buy ticket for the boat, you need to tell them your return time. 3 hours is fine.

AN INCREDIBLE PLACE IN RUSIA. This is a place that you must visit if you go to Saint Petersburg, Rusia. The gardens and the palace are amazing. If you visited Versalles and you liked it, you are going to enjoy Peterhoff. The fountains shows a clever system to use the water; the decoration inside the Palace make you feel in the czar's Rusia. On the other side you have chance to enjoy the nature walking through large gardens with different kinds of flowers and trees. And the statues are a special sample of an exquisit taste!

A must in your visit to Saint Petersburg. This stunning place is absolutely a must if you are planning to visit Saint Petersburg. It was the summer palace of the Tsar (Russian emperor) family, and the golden fountains that inundate the site are so beautiful. The Sanson fountain let you shocked, and the big garden that surround the palace is perfect to have a relaxing and fresh walk. If going from St Petersburg, take the tube until Baltiyskaya station (red line), and then take the bus 404 during around 45 minutes.

A must to visit in Russia !. There are so many places to visit in Russia you could spend several days here in St Petersburg and not see everything ! There are many palaces to see ,the Great palace ,The Farmers Palace , The Cottage Palace .the Winter Palace are just a few of the many on show ! They are all very spectacular and well worth seeing !the Peterhof park and Gardens and all the very varied fountains are really lovely to see ,the park covers over 300 acres and is really spectacular !During the 1939 - 1945 war a lot of the treasures were buried in this park to ensure their safety and were restored again after the war ended !

Awesome fountains. We visited Peterhof as part of a 2 day tour of St. Petersburg with a Russian guide. We arrived by hydrofoil and visited the Lower Gardens only which was a little disappointing but we were told the Palace inside was very similiar to Catherine Palce which was our next visit. The grounds themselves are absolutely fantastic and the fountains enormous and amazing. To stand on the balcony by the Palace and looking down at the fountains, gold statues and the water was breath taking.Please note if you are only visiting the Lower Gardens there are no public toilet except in the cafe for visitors using this facility.

place where you must go. Everthing in Peterholf is amazing and wonderful. Their beuatifull garden, palace, water font. It´s worth to go there and take a look of everthig there . Nice to stay all day there, because they make many activities for adults and chilldren along the day.
amazing. Was really amazing to visit this palace. Beside the architecture you also have the gardens. It was quite something to walk here.
The great palace. A wonderful place with great chandeliers all the gold around everywhere certainly a place to visit it's hard to imagine anyone living there it's so glittery

Tops Versailles!. The palace itself is opulent & huge. Even more impressive were the gardens and the hundreds of fountains contained in them. The grand scale of everything was just amazing. Definitely a must see. Not wheelchair friendly....shoes had to be covered with booties to protect the beautiful wooden mosaic floors.

A must!. This had to be the #1 highlight of our 7-day trip to the Baltic countries. The history of the Romanov stars is fascinating and the lives they led were opulent and indulgent. To see the Peter the Great Grand Palace at Peterhof is to wander through the rooms imagining the lavish lifestyle and what it must have been like to live so extravagantly amid such spender. The rooms are adorned with much silk and gold, and it was painful not be be able to photograph. The grounds are gorgeous, adorned with 200 fountains, most of them shiny gold leaf. Try to be on the bridge crossing the canal that runs between the palace of the Gulf of Finland at 11:00 to witness main fountains coming to life, set to music. If you do nothing else in St. Petersburg, this is the one to do!

Nice palace. The palaces are impressive, and the garden with all it's fountains worth a visit. We had a five hour guided tour that, for some reason, was only in the lower park. We were a bit disappointed to be back at the buss without even seeing the front of the palace or peeking inside. Make sure to check out what is actually included in the tour.

Greatest Palace in Russia. There are few palaces which will take your breath away - For me its the great palace and the palace of Versailles. The gardens are a marvel and sight to behold. I recommend taking a camera and lots of available memory.

The Gardens outdo the Palace, which isn't easy to do. The Peterhof Palace is itself spectacular, having been beautifully restored following the devastation of WW II. (As with the other palaces in the region, all of the interior furnishings were moved to Siberia for safekeeping at the beginning of the War, and returned afterwards.) However, the gardens, with literally hundreds of fountains of varying degrees of intricacy and size, are truly amazing. It seems that flowering plants are constantly installed seasonally and everything is manicured to a T. There is even an open aviary with exotic birds. believe I read in one of Rick Steves's books that one need not travel to both the Catherine Palace and also Peterhof (which are in opposite directions from St. Pete), but I disagree. Each is well worth the trip.

Peterhof has been so heavily restored that most of it looks virtually brand-new. The drive to Peterhof was beautiful. Wide avenues are lined with huge trees. In between the trees we had glimpses of grand buildings and palaces. Peterhof is the huge summer estate of Peter the Great. It is set in a park that features numerous palaces, summer houses and pavillions. Peter the Great visited Versailles in 1717, which inspired him to build a palace "befitting to the very highest of monarchs." The occupying forces of the German army destroyed most of Peterhof during WW II. The palace was partially exploded and left to burn. Restoration work began almost immediately after the end of the war and continues to this day. Peterhof has been so heavily restored that most of it looks virtually brand-new. Our guide has the attitude that the palace is "even better than it was!" Most Russians feel this way about their restored heritage. They lost so much, how can they feel otherwise? For me, the shiny gold leaf and brightly painted walls made the palace look too much like a movie set. I did get to see some furniture and porcelains that were "of the period."

Grandeur, gardens and fountains at their finest.. A day is not enough to explore all that it has to offer, but any time spent admiring the palaces, grounds and fountain will be extremely rewarding. We were lucky enough to have a private guide that was extremely knowledgeable, and passionate, about the history and significance of the many rooms, fountains, and grounds, that it truly brought it alive for us.

Peterhof the quintesential imperial visit. Get on the hydrofoil and go--fast! This place is everything you've dreamed of -- gold, green and majesty. Who cares if you can't remember which Romanov ruled when. Recommended to view Peterhof YouTube videos before you go for background. The fountains start at 11am but hurry; it is all over at the end of sept! wifi on site but maps and english difficult to find!

The Peterhof Palace. If the "Great Palace is the Peterhof; it is beyond belief. The gardens, fountains, and waterfalls are superb. The inside of the palace is grander than anything we have seen in Western Europe and we have lived here for over 30 years. The Hydrofoil boat ride back to St. Petersburg is not to be missed!!!

Nice Place but an absolute trek to get to. First things first. We were here out of season so there was no boat to take, we had to get the bus. It took an hour and a half to get out there and the same back. That does not seem to be long but when you add three hours or more to adequately see the palace and stroll about in the gardens you have basically spent the whole day out there. You really have to decide whether you want to sacrifice a day of your trip to one sight where there is so much to see in St Petersburg itself. The Palace itself is quite beautiful, and was luckily saved from the Nazis by the Red Army, which seemed to gut the place in their retreat to save the interiors and furniture. The interior is much like other European Palaces that Peter the Great would have sought to emulate, with gaudy and ornate gilting and cornicing everywhere. There is a lovely chinese lacquer board room and Peter the Great's personal study is fantastic (though its in such amazing condition it seems hard to believe its all original). The place is adorned with paintings of the Russian fleet (given its importance to St Petersburg) and portraits of the Romanovs. The gardens are also very nice to visit and one can walk down to the Baltic and see the city in the distance, its quite beautiful.As stated before however, you'd want to think about it. You would really have to have a thing for Palaces!!

Great venue but return boat access has unexpected costs. Great gardens and palace. Be aware that if you go by return boat you will have to exit to see the upper garden and then purchase another entry ticket to re-enter for your return boat trip. We checked with four venue staff because the arrangement seemed so unusual. All just laughed and said yes two entry tickets.

A magnificent palace, fantastic engendering of fountains!. The palace and gardens are beautiful the eye catcher and a sight to behold are the fountains. This is a must see when one is visiting St.Petersburg. One could just imagine the magnificence of how the royalties lived in those days.

Make sure that you have 3 hours for enjoy every moment of this place. Palace with huge elegant gardens and a lot of fountains and figured statues... Don't expect to see beautiful sea and beach there but it's good enough to walk along them while walk across to another side of palace.

Spectacular. We had the opportunity to visit Peterhof palace when our cruise ship docked at Saint Petersburg. We had seen Catherine Palace and Hermitage on day one.This palace was amazing inside and glittering shine was awesome. The architecture is just great and no photography is allowed inside the palace. The gold cascading fountains outside provide excellent view with the baltic sea in the background. The fountains are generally operating during the day. We then strolled through the gardens and also passed through the trick fountain. It is definitely worth a visit and not inferior to the Varsailles palace. You must try to take hydrofoil to get to the other side of the sea which is a great ride in Saint Petersburg to get the glimpse of the Russian architecture as you pass alongside big buildings.

The best for last. Without knowing it , we saved the best for last! We did the Hermitage, Hermitage Storage facility and Catherine's Palace and enjoyed each one more than the previous. Peterhof has been compared to Versailles but I found it more light (and gilded - not necessarily a good thing). If they haven't got every portrait of every Romanoff somebody goofed - and I don't think they did. Wonderful parquet floors which is why you have to put covers on your shoes. Even has lovely gift shops. The gardens are enormous and beautifully laid out. Many fountains, thank heavens it didn't rain!
Peter the Great. Go there at the time of day that they turn on the fountains. It is quite a spectacle. Then stroll through the gardens looking at all of the water features.

worth every min. Plan on spending the day here just meandering around the gardens. Everywhere you turn is another amazing view and photo op. Go early to avoid the endless drove of people and again. Take your time. Amazing Palace!!

A Magical Fairytale. The Peterhof Palace , it is just beautiful . On a recent visit to St Petersburg ( a beautiful breathtaking city ) we had the opportunity to visit the Summer Palace and gardens . We were not prepared for the breathtaking , beautiful spectacle this palace is . A Fairytale in every way . As we descended from our coach a band greeted us playing our National Anthem , which was friendly and amusing . We were guided through to the side of the building were we stood waiting in the glorious sunshine , the gold glimmering on the white building . We looked straight ahead to the gardens with gold cascading fountains , and beyond , the Baltic Sea . It all seemed unreal , like a dream , groups are allowed in in the mornings , individuals in the afternoons , I recommend you book . The regime is strict , no large bags , no overcoats , there is an orderly guide and safe place to leave your things . On entering you will understand why .Catherine the Great features widely in the history of this marvellous treasure of a building , and it really is . Peter the Great must have had great vision for what he created is a worlds special treasure . It is a mini Versailles , but more beautiful , it glitters and takes your breath away , we walked around in a dream , it is beautiful now , imagine what it would have been like to live there during the summer in days gone by . To walk out on to the glittering balcony and look out beyond the gardens to the sea . The gardens are just lovely , the fountains knock Chatsworth House for six , not a patch on these at The Peterhof . We strolled down the steps imagining days gone by ,. We stood at the end of the garden and looked out to the sparkling sea . Our heads full of the history and knowledge conveyed to by our very friendly knowledgable guide Vera (who was with us throughout our days in St Petersburg ) . Vera's enthusiasm and exiting historical stories bought the palace and city to life , she loves her city , it was a privilege to have Vera guide us around this amazing building , she brought it to life .This treasure The Peterhof Palace , it was a privilege to experience , undoubtably , visit if you can .

Amazing Gardens!!! Peter's Sense of Humor Wasn't Nice, Though. While the palace is beautiful, the gardens and fountains are amazing. Peter the Great's sense of humor comes through in the Trick Fountains---- fountains that suddenly drenched innocent guests. Yeah, funny, right? It's amazing that he had any friends left. The grounds are beautiful, though.

Beautiful, but go with a tour and beware if you are physically disabled. Yes, it's beautiful, iconic, and something you simply have to see. But the crowds are suffocating, panic-attack-inducing; the unsmiling (dare I say morbid?) women who guard each room rush you through, and you better stay away from the guard ropes or else risk their wrath! You must go with a tour from what I saw, and happily, we did, as otherwise there is no one who is going to help you, no signs you will be able to read. From a people-flow perspective, it's a nightmare - unless you come with a group with a Russian guide - from what I saw, that is a must, as you will spend so much time trying to figure things out, and your frustration will color your experience. The gardens are stunning! Be sure to get there for the ceremony when they are turned on in the morning at 11am with Prokofiev music booming from the speakers, quite lovely. You can't take any photos inside the palace, which was a great disappointment - NO photos, or one of the Russian women room guards will be all over you! Another warning is if you are physically handicapped, as a member of my family is, ohhhhh, you're in for a bad time! The single lift is on the opposite end of where you need to be, no one is going to tell you where it is even though you obviously need it, it's just not pleasant! BUT, you must go, I'm glad we went, it's something we will never forget!
Crazy place!. A great trip to get out of the city! Take the hydrofoil and go see the AMAZING fountains and waterfalls and enjoy tea or beer or whatever if your poison at the Orangerie! Great day out.

Russian delight. Very impressive place to visit and far better IMO than Catherine Palace and The Hermitage.Gardens are superb, with impressive fountains all over the garden. It would take a while to walk all round the gardens so if you want your kids to sleep, this is the place to go!Plenty of places to shelter if the sun is too hot ( or it rains).

Peterhof Summer Palace. Even weekend gardeners will enjoy the gorgeous setting of this summer palace. With all the pools, waterfalls, fountains, topiaries and plantings, it is a feast for the eyes. And, of course, there are more gilded onion domes!

Fabulously ostentatious gardens. Peterhof is around the bay from St Petersburg city. We used the hydrofoil to get over and I think this is the better option as the roads are very busy and slow.We only visited the gardens and didn't go into the palace buildings. The gardens are fabulous examples of regal displays of wealth and power - extremely ostentatious.As a tourist spectacle they are a must-see sight and provide some compelling evidence for a peasant revolution!We had a guide in St Petersburg and her advice was to spend time in the gardens here at Peterhof but that the palaces in town and at Pushkin and the Hermitage are much better examples of building interiors and collections. Unless you particularly want to see every possible palace in St Petersburg, I think her advice was sound.
St Petersburg highlight. Absolutely the highlight of our two days in St Petersburg. Wonderful gardens, fountains and of course the Palace!

Stunning but don't go with Viking. This is an expensive excursion through Viking (79 Euros per person) - 30 min. (or less) in the palace and we felt rushed through it, then 25 min. to use the washroom and visit the gift shop, then an hour guided tour through the gardens which are pretty, and ending with the ceremony where the Cascade fountains get turned on for the day, then 45 min. to wander the gardens some more. It truly is the Versailles of Russia. Lovely gold leaf and restoration. But no pictures inside, and if you touch some of the ropes by accident, an alarm goes off, and the Russian museum ladies are watching like a hawk - it feels uncomfortable to be watched like that - it was less obtrusive at other sites. Only 500 rubles to get in (about $15 Cdn). The good thing with Viking was getting in before it opened, with no crowds. Apparently it's crazy in the summer. We were there Sept. 1 (first day of school) and it was cloudy. Much less crowded than usual, the guide said. In the books in the tourist shop there were other rooms we didn't see. Not sure if they are usually part of the tour or if we got the entire thing.

excellent garden. i recommend you to go there. it is very beautiful with awesome water fountains that don't work with electricity and magnificent trees and plants. it is located near the bay of finland and it's only about 45 minutes to city by boat.

Wonderful gardens, best place to visit in St. Petersburg. The palace, the gardens, just beautiful. The "tricky" fountains, the layout, on a sunny day like Versailles but more interesting, more gardens, canals, fountains etc. Don't miss this attraction.

Stunning. The Palace and Gardens are a must see on any visit to St Petersburg.The Palace interior is largely rebuilt but still stunning. It does get very busy and the unsmiling room attendants are very keen to keep you on the move. No photography is allowed in the Palace.The Gardens are large and well kept but the prime reason to visit them are the numerous fountains. These are switched on and off at regular intervals but very well maintained and worth the walk around to see.

Peterhof Absolutely Amazing. Visited Peterhof on our SPB 2 Day Deluxe Tour. It was so beautiful and amazing. We absolutely loved it. We only wished that we could spend more time there, but unfortunately not possible on an organised tour.Leonie and Bob

What a great place - but what a lousy welcoming. First a train - which turned out not to go in the right direction, then a bus. And there it was ... Peterhof. Went to join the queue - which after standing in the pouring rain for one hour, turned out to be the queue for groups. Individuals need to go around the palace, pay their entrance to the park (in the pouring rain) and go queue again at the back of the palace in order to get in. Stood there for another our to an hour and a half, finally got in, bought tickets to visit the palace, followed the crowd to a cloakroom, and were subsequently crushed against the entrance doors as they would only let members of groups in (the members of which were scattered all over the cloakroom). Angry staff, pissed off visitors answering in other languages, and finally ... we got past the entrance doors. From the onwards, it was a pleasure to the eye. Beautiful palace! By the time we ended the visit it had even stopped raining and we were able to walk through the park for a while, before heading towards St-Petersburg again.
Must see. When visiting St Petersburg you must visit all the churches and palaces all have connections to Peter the Great and Catherine the Great, the opulence is mind blowing.

the place to see. this place is a must to see but be there at( in our case 11 am) as this is when the most amazing gravity fed fountain system is activated..allow plenty of time totally worth the effort.

A must see - Versailles times 10!!!. Take the boat, go and see this amazing place filled with immaculate gardens, incredible palaces of Peter the Great and his daughter, Elizabeth1. Full of baroque influences and grandeur and whimsy, courtesy of Peter's amazing sense of humour. Check out the Umbrella fountain and the Chair fountain etc. Too fun! I fell in love with this place and got to imagine another time and how much "Russia's gateway to Europe" this place truly is!

Lovely gardens. Having Peterhof Palace previously, we restricted this visit to the gardens only. The Gardens lead from Palace down to the shore of the Gulf of Finland consisting mainly of formal wooded areas, with the spectacular fountains, smaller museums (set in Palace outbuilding) and more formal gardened areas. The centre of the gardens are the fountains and water features that lead from the front of the palace which have been beautifully restored, particularly with the Palace as a backdrop. The Gardens are well worth a visit and although the entrance fee is a little expensive, it is a enjoyable 2-3 hours plus.
Peterhof palace and gardens. This is spectacular and a must see while in St Petersburg, the rooms get crowded and at times you just shuffle along. The gardens and fountains are spectacular

Boattrip. Take a boat from in front of the Winterpalace in St. Petersburg at the river Neva and have a fantastic half an hour ride to the Peterhof. This is a beatiful sea ride and it is warm inside or fresh outside.

Gardens tour. I saw only the gardens with a tour guide which was helpful to have a guide to show the highlights. Very large gardens with so much going on and some cute areas that were explained very well. There are small kiosks for eating a variety of food. It was well worth a visit.

Day visit to Peterof Palace and Gardens. If you ever get the opportunity of visiting St Petersburg, try and fit in a visit to the Peterhof Palace. This is often referred to as the Russian Versailles and does not disappoint. Overlooking the Gulf of Finland you can enjoy a stroll down from the palace admiring the many fountains. The highlight is probably the turning on, at eleven o' clock, of the Grand Cascade fountains which feature Samson prying open a lion's jaw as water flows down the terraced steps.

Magnificent. Peterhof is a must-see if you are visiting St. Petersburg, and is a welcome break from the city. The palaces and gardens are magnificent, and deserve a full day visit. You will appreciate the sights fully if you take the time to read about Peter the Great and the history of Peterhof before your visit. Go early in the morning to see the opening ceremony when the fountains are turned on, and plan to stay all day if you can.

Beautiful gardens and waterfalls. We didn't go into the palace, just around the gardens. What a beautiful place. The gardens are stunning and the various water features are just superb. We spent about thee hours there and could have stayed much longer. A definite must-see if you are in St Petersburg

Make time to see this place. This place is stunning inside and out. The gardens, especially the fountains are amazing. It is hard to absorb all of the styles and just to understand the complexity of the lives of the tsars and the environs in which they lived. But it is truly magnificent to behold and to try to imagine daily life in a place such as this. A guided tour is a great idea to get the most out of the visit. A guide will point out the important highlights and provide historical perspective; in particular which tsarina, Elizabeth or Catherine, was responsible for which style, etc. Allow time to walk through some of the gardens to see the fountains.

Fountains are the highlight. Must see.. We had a very nice tour on the inside. Plan to spend 1/2 day there if you want to tour the fountains and grounds. So many places for a photo stop. Make sure you have a good guide to explain the grounds and inside to you

Very pretty fountains and a pleasant stroll but better parks elsewhere. St. Petersburg's equivalent of Versailles with wonderful fountains and beautiful setting for a walk, yet would say that the park is better in Pushkin (Tsarskoye Selo) while once you take a photo of the lion fountain, there isn't that much more to do. So probably only worth visiting if you have 4 days in the city, if you only have 3, would plump for Pushkin instead.

Wet Wet Wet. Arrive by hydrofoil and then had to pay to leave the pier and enter the gardens, all other sections had a fee. The day we went was very wet so it didn't matter when the spray from the fountains got us wet and there are lots of fountains set in the large parklands.

Get there early. Peterhof is one of my favorite places to visit around St. Petersburg. If you can, get there early before they turn on the fountains in the morning. The ceremony of turning them on is fantastic. Also, take a tour! It is really interesting to see how all the fountains work and some of the fountains that are hidden. You can easily spend a whole day here. Pack a lunch or buy a snack there.
Beautiful. Great fountains. But we were not lucky and came there when weather was bad and was raining. Otherwise is a must visit place.
Peterhof Palace and Garden. Amazing place, both inside and out! Every step you took brought you to a cache of history surrounded by beauty.

Czarist Russia at it's finest. The opulence of this palace is stunning! We were allowed to photograph throughout the tour. Words alone cannot convery the magnificent display of architecture and decoration the exists in the palace. Our tour included a short interlude of Champaign and chamber music. Absolutely wonderful evening.

Make the time to see this Palace. We drove out there but you can catch the hydrofoil from the city centre. A must to go and see the state rooms, gardens and fountains. Hugely impressive and probably my favourite place we saw while in Russia.

A spectacular feat of 18th century engineering. This location contains the fountains installed by Peter the Great. It consists of a system of gravity powered fountains combined with beautiful statuary. The gardens are impeccable. Given the location was destroyed by the Germans during The War the Russians have done a spectacular job of bringing the gardens and fountains back to their (probably) original glory. This is worth a visit just to appreciate the engineering and history. During the siege the building fronting the Gulf of Finland were used as a German fire base.

Great fountains. Visited today this needs a full day to visit the gardens (massive a large park) and the Palace.We only visited the gardens make sure you get a map as you could waste hours walking around , the main fountains are just below the palace.Lots of lovely fountains to visit, 500 rubbles entrance for an adult and 250 for a student.We got the metro red line 28 rubbles to Baltiskaya station then the bus 404 55 rubbles to Peterhof, on the return we paid 55 rubbles to Avtovo metro station on a mini bus which is waiting, stop off at every station for the next 3 stations they are all fantastic and great photo opportunities.

Gold reflected through Water. Recently visited the gardens at the Peterhof Palace, the fountains and buildings are not to be missed, this should be one of the highlights of any tour to St. Petersburg in Russia. Friends have been amazed at the slide show I produced, the sight is amazing. So many gold figures when viewed through the falling water of the fountains and watching it as it flows down the steps and gently along the canal out to sea. The Palace is pretty amazing as well, certainly should not be missed.

Peterhof Palace and Garden. What an amazing property to see on a bright sunny day. The gardens are exquisite and the fountains are the best I have ever seen. Palace and environs are well worth the visit.

'A must see" and worth spend a day. It is well worth coming for a day. It is gorgeous. All European palaces including Versailles pale against Peter the Great`s residence including the Grand Palace and its park with fountains. It is better to go there by boat (from Hermitage pier or Admiralty pier) and it will take you only 40 min. Buy tickets to both ends to avoid staying in the queue in Peterhof. You will enter through the Lower Garden and will be able to see all the beauty of the Grand Palace and cascade of fountains in front of it.
