So don`t rush into the sightseeing, I would recommend to take an excursion around the park by small electric mobile (similar to golf cars). You can order and take it at the first souvenir stand. It is a 40 min excursion with audio guide so you will be able to see actually everything and then make your own plan how the best to see and explore the place. It is huge and you may spend the whole day wondering around. Then go to the Grand Palace`s tickets office for a ticket (note that it is open only for 2 hours in the morning and 2 hours in the afternoon) to see the palace. I will recommend you to see also the Monpleisir Palace. It is small but cute. The tickets are sold near the entrance. It is better to go at the day when the weather is nice and not raining (not possible) or not pouring as some museums and palaces are closed in rainy weather. You can’t enter museum in wet shoes. And also before middle of October (I think) as afterwards the fountains are not working.
A must-do in St Petersburg. Unbelievable & fantastic all at the same time! we loved the trick fountains and the gardens are breathtaking!

Versailles in St Petersberg. The magnificence of this palace rivals Versailles and the gardens and series of fountains is really breathtaking. You could spend a day here and still not see it all. Not to be missed

Worth the visit for the fountains alone. Palaces abound all over Europe, but Peterhof sets itself apart from the others for the amazing fountains. They are not just an amazing architectural delight but an unbelievable engineering feat. The fountains, which numbers in the dozens, are all gravity fed from springs in the mountains. The water strategically flows from the higher fountains through a system of pipes that feed each fountain until they empty into the river. The fountains range from large majestic to whimsical "tree" fountains that trap you when you sit on a bench under the "tree", to fountains hid in benches that spray you as you unsuspectingly sit on the bench. The palace itself is nice though far from the opulence of a Versailles in Paris. Of the many palaces I have visited, this is a personal favorite because of the beauty of the grounds. It is an excellent shore excursion if you arrive by cruise ship in St. Petersburg. If you have to choose between Catherine's palace or Peterhof, pick Peterhof.
Seaside Tzar Palace. Wonderful garden on the Gulf of Finland. I would recommend to get there by hydrofoil (about 30 min.). Beautiful fountains in the summer and romantic place where to be.
Highly decorated and well preserved. This Palace is highly decorated with gold leaf and is very well kept. It's gardens are a good as any you will see. It is highly recommended.

Amazing fountains and gardens. We arrived by hydrofoil. What an entrance to an amazing site. We were there for the opening ceremony when the fountains are turned on. Again, amazing. You are rushed through the palace and you need to pay to take photos [in advance]. The gardens and fountains are incredible. Definitely a must-see.

Gorgeous Palace and grounds. The beautiful Peterhof Palace is a boat trip away and it is well worth coming here for a day. The whole area is a magical scene of palace and gardens. There is a lot of walking so comfortable shoes are a must. Also take an umbrella for sun/rain as there is not much shelter.

Beautiful palace, gardens, fountains. This place was one of our reasons to travel to St. Peterburg. We didn't know wheather to take organized tour or hydrofoil or bus, but at the end we took a train from St. Peterburg Baltivskaya train station to Peterhof, the ride take approx. 45 minutes. At the station you can easily get on one of the lokal buses or marshrutkas that go to "Fontanke". Bus drivers tell you when you have to get off the bus to go to the palace and upper gardens. From there you reach also the lower gardens and the breathtaking cascade fountains and many other beautiful spots. It is up to you how much time you want to spend there and explore the palace and gardens an fountains and other sites. You can go back to the city also on a boat that leaves from the shore facing the palace. It also takes about 45 minutes but is much more costy than train/local bus. In any case it is well worth seeing it.

Fountains and fountains. A place to be seen in summer time. The fountains are exquisite and the palace and its surroundings deserve a long visit. Wear your most comfortable shoes and be prepared to walk. You will enjoy every minute of it.

A must see when in St Petersburg. We visited Peterhof on a gloriously sunny summer's day. The gardens were spectacular without feeling too prissy. The fountains, palaces and gazebos were stunning; at times breathtaking....Enough to keep teenagers from their natural cynicism. The toilet facilities were clean and free....unless you want to dry your hands after washing.....the attendant wants to be paid before switching on the power to the hand dryers. We arrived by coach and this afforded us a good look at the suburbs where the real St Petersburg folk live. We travelled back to the city by hydrofoil which felt like a great adventure.
Amazing!. it is so amazing that Royalty had so much and lived in such elaborate places while most people were poor and deprived. No wonder a revolution eventually took place.

Wonderful Gardens and Fountains!. Nice trip from St Petersburg to Peterhof Palce with Hydrofoil, about 30 minutes, through Neva river where you can also see many corners of St Petersburg that otherwise you wouldn't have been able to see. The Palace is Amazing, it's seems to jump in the Past with thie ancient Buiding so well preserved.Gardens and Fountains are really enjoiable, to spent some hours in quite and good contest.

A MUST SEE. While some do not like tour groups and prefer to navigate on their own, we have found in our travels that this is the best way to see some places. Peterhof Palace is a perfect example of this. We visited with a Viking River Cruise on a Sunday. This excursion costs us approx. $105.00 each. We arrived at 8 am and waited about 30 minutes to be let in. We were told that tour groups had special early entry before the masses arrived. We had earphones and our English speaking Russian guide led us through Peterhof flawlessly. Having read the three star reviews I would say this is the best way to visit. I would not recommend doing this on your own, since others had so much trouble with entrance fees, museum employees, and the crowds. Peterhof is breathtaking, you must see the palace and be lead by a guide. Our group moved along easily with an adequate explanation of each room. It is true that the women guards take their jobs very seriously. They did not crack a smile and don't even think about getting your camera out! We purchased a book in the gift shop that fully explains the palace and pictures every aspect of the museum with images you could not capture with your camera anyway. The gift shop prices were reasonable. I purchased an amber bracelet which will always have a special meaning for me, along with some other souvenirs.We then had a couple of hours in the gardens on our own. The fountains are an engineering marvel and the gardens are beautiful. At 11am the main cascading fountain begins to go off set to music and builds to a crescendo. Don't miss this sight. There are over 100 unique fountains and statues throughout the grounds. By the time we left around 1:00 the crowds were dense and we were thankful we arrived early and our visit was perfect.Be informed, you are not allowed to enter with backpacks and bottled water must be kept out of sight. You will slip booties on over your shoes when you enter to protect the wonderful flooring. Do not have your cameras visible. Use the restrooms when you are inside the building. The outdoor facilities are scarce and you have to pay. As with any foreign country, be respectful of the people, their treasures and their customs.In a nutshell, do the palace and gardens! Especially if this will be your only opportunity. Don't expect friendly Russian natives. The only smiling happy Russians we dealt with on our entire trip to Russia with were ones that were dependent on our tourist dollars. And if you can, go with a tour group to get the full benefit of this marvelous palace.

Beautiful gardens and palace!. A sunny day added to the beauty of this place. The gardens are vast and the fountains are beautiful. You can easily spend couple of hours there. We didn't see the palace itself, but the gardens alone are well worth the visit!

Power and politics on the Gulf of Finland. Peter the Great wanted to make a statement when he had this place built. He wanted to own the waterways and this was a fierce welcome to anyone who would defy that. The gardens and fountains make a carpet of power folding out toward the sea. Peterhof is magical! Don't miss it!

Very Impressive. This stop was part of a 2 day guided tour. I knew nothing about Peterhof prior to our stop. Boy were we pleasantly surprised. The grounds are huge and very beautiful. It is definitely a must see if you are visiting the St. Petersburg area.

An awesome place, a wonderful visit. The palace is situated on the shore of Baltic sea. The palace is divided into two parts - the lower garden and the upper garden. The lower garden, being the main attraction of the palace, requires entry fee whereas the upper garden is free of cost to visit. You should plan to spent a day in the place.It is little far from the St. Petersburg city, so you need to take a taxi, or ride metro. Metro ride will save a lot in terms of money. Depending on your location, you might need to change the train once or more, and then get a bus/minivan from the Novyi station. The ride is seamless, and you shouldn't have any issue reaching the palace. However, the most attractive choice would be the cruise from St. Petersburg which will take you directly to the lower garden of Peterhof, little costly option though.In the upper garden, there are couple of fountains on the canvas of the palace building. The garden is decorated with many trees and sculptures. Once you pass through the upper garden, you will have the gate to lower garden. It starts with a big stair case on both sides of the palace with the main fountain in between. You can take the stairs to get down in the garden which extends till the shore of Baltic sea.Overall the place is breathtaking, with the mixture of history, art and natural beauty. For us, it was the best part of our St. Petersburg tour.

A real memory. It is worth visiting on a tour - we were so glad we did as we misse dlong queues and had a guide to explain the history and stories. We paid 4500 roubles each and this included travel, entry the lot for 5 hours. We walked the gardens to see the fountains and did not stop taking photos even in the rain! The palace is beatiful and shame as you cant take pics inside.
Amazing. We were delighted to see so much luxury and art and learn about the history of Peter the GreatThe Fountains and gardens are a feast to the eyes

Take a day!. Getting to and from Peterhof can be slightly difficult when going the cheap route, but it's worth it considering how expensive it can be after paying for both entrance to the Lower Gardens and the palace itself. Take the red line to Baltiskaya Station for 28ru and then bus K404 for 55ru which stops at the entrance of the Upper Gardens. Don't forget your student ID as the prices vary greatly for students and adults. The Lower Gardens cost either 250ru for students or 500ru full price, and the Grand Palace is either 300ru for students or 550ru full price. Bring water as it can cost about 80ru for just 0,5l and you will get thirsty walking around especially on a hot day. As for the gardens and palace itself they are both extremely worth the trip. Your breath will be taken away by another example of European monarchical opulance. It's easy to spend an entire day here and with varying times for Russian and foreign visitors to enter the palace you should be very flexible in your schedule. But it is yet another must do while visiting St. Petersburg!

Golden Wonder. We were fortunate to get to tour the gardens of Peterhof on a perfect day with crystal clear skies and gentle breezes. Unforunately, I think every other tourist in St. Petersburg had the same destination in mind. Biggest crowds of any of St. Petersburg's attractions yet. We chose not to tour the palace and came just for the gardens and they were simply amazing. One ceases to wonder why the Russian people rebelled when you see how much gold was used. The fountains are inventive and sometimes quite silly and all over the top in opulence. We grabbed a quick bite at the Orangerie in the gardens and then went back to the city on the hydrofoil.

Stunning. We went as part of a cruise tour and were not disappointed in what we saw, but only in the huge crowds. It was even difficult to get to the toilets! Stunning both inside and out. There are over 100 fountains, we were told, and they are switched on about 1100, so try to be around to see this. We just didn't have enough time inside to truly appreciate the rooms and their contents. Try and visit when the cruise tours aren't in!

More information in English would be helpful.. We took the hydrofoil as suggested by many reviewers and it was a good option. Be aware, though, if the wind gets up in the day, they can cancel sailings.We paid to enter the gardens/grounds of the palace and to enter the actual palace. The palace was very beautiful and as it's Rocco style, very ornate. We started our tour alright but as the tour groups caught up with us, it became unbearable and I couldn't wait to get out. Thank you to the tour groups that consider others and use head phones and just seem to glide through, unlike the other groups that create such noise pollution! The palace watchdogs kept everyone moving through the 'Chinese' decorated climate controlled rooms but were OK otherwise. Once we had completed the tour of the palace we knew there were other options, ie the grotto, but do you think we could find information or help to buy tickets? NO! So, we decided to walk around the gardens and fountains and try to chill out after our experience. Husband decided to treat himself to an ice cream and we couldn't believe when the shop assistant came around to the freezer and unlocked it, picked out the wrapped ice cream he wanted and re locked the freezer. We have a lot to learn about life here:-)

Another must see in St. Petersburg!. You can do this in the same day that you do Catherine's summer palace. The grounds are just as impressive as the palace and the engineering of the water fountains from the Gulf of Finland are truly a feat of genius.

More Bling than Bulgari. Staggering place. The gardens, with fountains everywhere, are just amazing, and the Palace s quite jaw-dropping, with gilt decorations everywhere. You have to experience it to believe it!
Amazing - a Must See!. Fountains, Gold, and History - Wow. And right on the Baltic Sea. The restoration from war damage is amazing.

Its worth to see it. If you are lucky and the weather is good you will make most of it.We thought the best way would to take a bus from metro Baltiskaya (40 mins), go through the upper gardens, approach the palace and than purchase tickets to get to the lower gardens, walk through them and get to the boat to St Petersburg.The point is, if you get there by boat from St Petersburg, you will be asked to buy tickets to visit lower gardens and if you want to see those free of charge upper gardens - you will need to buy tickets again when returning to the lower park. Nonsence, but here you are.We went on Monday and it was a good weather and lots of crowds. But we were told that normally these gardens see more people.... so, be ready for this.

Unforgettable. I was lucky enough to be offered a very special visit to this fantastic place. The welcome reception to the congress I was attending, was held at the palace. We arrived in the evening and the palace was open only for us. After a guided tour of the palace, there was a cocktail in the gardens, and we got to see the fountains at sunset. Spectacular!

A delightful day trip. The palace itself is very ornate. Your eyes cannot take in all the beautiful objects and decorations at one go. The views onto the gardens outside are a delight. Walking in the gardens is full of surprises, funny, pretty, wonderfully designed walks, every so often coming across another fountain, each one a joy to look at, amazing views from every angle. A great day.

Must see. Great views, great park and fountains. much easier to get there than Tsarskoe Selo.If you have the choice between Catherine Palace and Peterhof, go for Peterhof. Make sure to take the speed boat as most convenient and good view from the water of Peter.

Wonderful outdoor sites. Beautifully restored palace.. This palace has beautiful gardens with many many (20+) fountains and sites in it's gardens. It's been amazingly restored as a lot of it was burned by the Nazi's in WWII. Very lovely to walk around and around and the many, many sites in the front gardens. ADVICE: The line up to get inside was very long. We were given advice ahead of time; don't bother to wait in the line, just see the gardens as there is a lot more sites here outside then inside, and so we didn't go inside and still had a great time!

The Versailles of Russia. Peterhof is the majestic and expansive estate of Russia's tsars located some 20 miles west of St. Petersburg. The Grand Palace and beautiful fountains are the main attractions. There are several other smaller palaces dotted throughout the estate that can be visited, but if your time is limited, it would be best for first-time visitors to focus on the Grand Palace, fountains, and immediate surrounding gardens. Taking the hydrofoil to Peterhof from near the Hermitage is the best way to get there and taking it back to the city is easy enough from Peterhof. Be aware that on busy days, you might not be able to get the first hydrofoil available.

An expensive mistake. Let's be clear. St Petersburg will do everything it can to extract money from tourists. There is absolutely no let up. You pay up to 3 times what the locals pay; you are charged to take photos in museums; audioguides comes at a premium price; combined attraction tickets are a rarity and prices are top dollar. Even the toilets are not free. Peterhof delivers in each and every one of these categories. You pay to get into the park; you pay to re-enter the park if you want to visit the town; you pay to enter each site on the estate; you pay to walk behind the fountains to visit the grotto. If it's any consolation, the toilets are free, but since you need to shell out for the hydrofoil, this will provide scant compensation. Worst of all, most of it is fake. Or, to be precise, it was reduced to a ruin by bombing during the war (allegedly by the Russians, themselves) so what you see inside and out is a recreation, largely from the soviet years. So, in effect, an imperial theme park.We spent 3 hours there and got more entertainment out of watching the vain princesses preening themselves for incessant photographs than entering any particular building. We were booked on the 6pm return sailing but begged to be allowed back on the 3pm. After some ritual humiliation and suffering the pretence that we might be turned away, we were given our wish and we were delighted to depart this ghastly waste of time and money. Novgorod too was rebuilt after the war, but we bitterly regretted not going there instead to see the collection of icons and open air museum. It couldn't have been less disappointing.

Exceedingly Beautiful. We were fortunate enough to be here on a full, sunny day. Upon arrival, you will view beautiful gold domes with crosses atop. Wander through the front buildings and marvel at the opulence. Once you cross into the gardens, you will be amazed as Peter was attempting to duplicate the most extensive gardens in Italy. HINT: Leave yourself plenty of time to view the gardens, they are well worth the time. When you head back up to the main palace, you will find the cascading steps and fountains breathtaking. There are great photo opportunities both from the bottom of the fountain and from atop the steps looking down over the reflecting pool. Gorgeous place. ANOTHER HINT: Watch out for pick-pockets with so many people clustered around.

Amazing fountains...... Palace of Peter the Great definately worth the visit. Was with a Viking Tour group, so had headset to hear all the information about the Palace. Really the best way to enjoy the rooms. She also guided us along so we would not be quite so rushed by the "Palace Women" who keep watch in each room. I recommend going as early as possible in the day to avoid crowds. Weather outside was very pleasant, but not many windows open, so quite warm inside. As with all travel in Russia in summer--layer clothing , comfy shoes and a small water bottle in your purse or pocket is a good idea (cannot take in large bags). The Royal style of life was truly amazing. Loved the huge main fountain and the other water features throughout the beautifully kept gardens.

Excellent Gardens - Palace not visited. After an amazing trip via the hydrofoil, we survived a bit of a storm!! ;-), we arrived at Peterhof jetty just as the rain stopped. There were quite a few soaked people wandering around, but we were immediately impressed by the scenery. If you like fountains you will love this place. The care and attention taken to keep the place in fantastic condition has to be seen to be believed. Probably the best gardens we have ever visited.

Gorgeous respite from the city. A beautiful palace and extraordinary garden just outside the city of St. Petersburg. Well worth the travel to see it.If nothing else, just walk around and marvel at the fountains.

Amazing.!. its an amazing place full of history and culture. very nice fountains and garden. be sure to have more than 2 hours to visit this site. inside of building has very nice paintings ,galleries and great culture. Don't miss this beautiful place.

Beware the water feature. This palace is exceptional and the grounds with all the gold features of fountains and garden features are a must see at St Petersburg. A surprise water feature on one walk was enjoyed by all that saw it. Also a fountain that sprays you when you least expect it. Beside Peter's summer house you can get some great views across the water if it's not raining. It was for our visit.Enjoyed it!

Incredible palace. seeing the palace of Peter the Great was incredible. the lives of the czars and their courts within the palace and grounds come to life as you walk the magnificent grounds and fabulous palace. Too bad no photos inside are allowed. No air conditioning and the women in charge of each palace room rush you through. Stay next to your guide to hear the most info. the drive to Peterhof village allows you see life outside Saint Peterburg.

Splendid Site.. Really most impressive, particularly the switching on ceremony of the fountains in the park. Tours in the palace are pushed through, could have done with more time there. The restaurant was welcoming and a change from other places I had visited in the area. Generally an very interesting visit, despite the 33degree temperatures.

Absolutely Fabulous. The fountains are well worth a visit but remember the Russian royals had a sense of humour and it might be advisable to speak to guide as to where to stand if you don't want to get wet
must see. The garden,fountains and every thing a bout here is majestic.If you go to St Petersburg you must go and see here ,of course if you travel in spring and summer.

Wow, they knew how to live!. Gold, gold and more gold! The roofs, the walls, gates, doors gold is everywhere. A just immense palace with unbelievable art work, furniture, flooring and ceilings and outside, magnificent gardens. One quick three hour visit does not allow the visitor to take in such an incredible structure. A must on anyone's bucket list!

Don't miss Peter The Great's small house on the water. We walked the gardens and saw the fountains but the highlight for us was going through Peter's "small" home situated on the water. There is an extra charge to go through and you have to cover your shoes but it is well worth seeing. Such a humble place compared to the grander of the rest of the property. Really gave us a better sense of who he was. You do need to have some info before you go or do as we did and have a private guide take you through. We learned so much! It was also fun seeing the trick fountains with the kids running through.

Built in 1700's - Just an Amazing Place. We had a beautiful day which made it even more spectacular. The fountains are turned on at 11:00 a.m. each day when the anthem of St. Petersburg is played. No pumps are used to run the fountains it's all gravity. All the statues are gilded with gold and it's just to amazing to really describe. The palace, of course, is also very beautiful and the grounds have many more lovely fountains and flowers. It's certainly a place you should not miss on your visit.

Keep an eye out for the squirrels. A lovely half-day outing from St Petersburg. We took the hydrofoil from the embankment, a mere 2 minutes from the Hermitage, for the 30-40min trip and then spent the next few hours happily meandering around the gardens looking at the spectacular fountains, palace buildings, stunning flowers...Make sure you take the short walk up to Marli Pond and Palace - its unpretentious nature is a delight after the extravagance of the rest of Peterhof. On the way back make sure you keep your eyes open for the squirrels, they are very tame and friendly.Try and stick around until 6pm when the fountains are turned off for the day - the brief musical accompaniment is worth the wait.
Loved the fountains .... ... the fountains were amazing. Especially since they operate without pumps! Could have spent hours. If you come in winter, they're inoperative.
Haven away from the city of St Petersburg. Situated next to the tranquil gulf of Finland, this beautiful palace and water fountains are a treat. A must see in Russia .

magnificent. Definitely a MUST. Very crowded unless you have a small private tour which we did. Otherwise I suspect that crowds would have detracted from the overall experience.The amber room was a highlight!

Beware of Pickpockets. It was a lovely day when we went. The sun was out, the grounds were lush with blooming flowers everywhere. It was crowded, but outside it didn't make too much of a difference. It was worth seeing all of the fountains. Meanwhile, there are signs that warn of pickpockets. Take these signs seriously! I had my camera one minute, and the next it was gone. I felt nothing! Other than that, a totally worth it locale.

A Russian Versailles - but smaller gardens.. The queues for the house put us off. We were already tired and really didn't feel inspired enough to wait in the long queues. We saw two for the house.
The central fountains were stunning and the trick fountains and actors dressed up in the costumes of the day really brought it to life.
Lovely. We enjoyed the tour of the grounds and the beautiful gardens. We enjoyed a lunch in the outdoor cafe. Our guide was quite interesting.

Take your time!. Pace yourself--and for this reason I suggest a local tour operator who won't race you from one room to the next. The gardens alone are worth the trip and the fountains are lovely. We were fortunate to visit on a bright sunny day when the palace looked its best. Don't miss it!
Peterhof delight. Separate review done on the trip here.by private car and the magnificent gardens and water features that extend down to the sea. A wonderful setting.

Very nice gardens to be visited when the weather is nice. During our two days stay in Saint Petersburg, we have taken the required time to move to Peterhof, located at about 30 kilometers from the center of town. We were lucky with the weather : after the thunder storm on end of the morning, we got a sunny sky in the afternoon. That was perfect to enjoy the gardens, giving somehow the impression of being in a small Versailles. To visit without rush you need about one hour and a half.

A great summer place to visit. If you have enough time in StP during a summer visit, you should definitely see the gardens of Peterhof Palace. I took Meteor boat trip to the island (which is a bit pricey) and spent an afternoon in beautiful gardens. It was a bliss after 4 days of long walks in StP museums. I haven't been into the palace though...
a nice day. You can spend one full day there and enjoy the park. We met some friendly Squirrel in park. The Fountains are so entertaining specially for children.

Fantastic. Must see. Beautiful gardens, water fountains and Palace. But when we got off the hydrofoil at the cashier, you can only buy tickets to the grounds. You have to buy from the various cashiers located throughout the place. They speak no English and have no idea where the other cashiers are located. You need patience and persistence. But worth it. We took the local transit bus back to town.

Spectacular Palace and Grounds. Loved visiting by boat and entering from below the palace. From this vantage point you see all of the fountains and the canal leading up to the palace. A walk through the grounds is very worthwhile with fountains and gardens in the park-like setting.Walk up to the palace courtyard for a spectacular view towards the gulf. The various plazas can be viewed from there as well as guilded statues.Well worth taking the hydrofoil boat ride from St. Petersburg.
Beautiful Fountains. The fountains are really beautiful, be sure to be outside when they start at 11:00. You will probably see a few Russian brides as well.

Magnificent. The gardens are really fantastic-calm, tranquil and fresh. There are a lot of people but the place doesn't seem crowded at all. The palace is terrific but I still prefer the gardens. The fountains are beautiful, lots of squirrels in the park, the flowerbeds, the old trees - all these create a romantic atmosphere flavored with the salty wind and children's laughter. A piece of advice -the earlier you come, the better there will be fewer visitors. There are usually no queues at the entrance, but might be a queue to the palace. My recommendation is just don't go there-there are many palaces in Petersburg, but the park is unique.One more thing-there are just a ciuple of cafes inside the park-I would rather avoid those, the menu , the service and the prices don't match the expectations. Have your meals at Brynza, a nice fast food cafe at the entrance.Have a nice trip)

A Must-See!. Peter the Great built it, and that should be sufficient to want to see it. However, the spectacular fountains (we arrived just as they were being turned on, at 11am, to music) can be argued to be more awe-enspiring than those at Versailles. The gilding, the opulence, this is the Tsar's Russia at its best. Leave time to wander through the park, the gardens, and do not miss the photo gallery with pictures of damage during WWII. How this palace was rebuilt in so short a time is a miracle in itself.

Huge park, incredible fountains and amazing palace. Peterhof Palace can be conveniently reached by hydrofoils that depart from several places in St. Petersburg (for example on riverside next to Winter Palace). The park is huge and it takes some time to walk through it and see all the different fountains. Right in front of the palace are the most spectacular fountains. To get into the palace, another ticket has to be purchased. This might be confusing since they have different hours for Russians and international visitors; going there with a guided group or someone speaking Russian might be a good idea. Together with the State Hermitage museum my favorite place to go in St. Petersburg region.

Relaxing outdoor experience. We only visited the parks and not the palace, but these are already far more than 100 hectares with 150 fountains and 5 cascades. A very enjoyable experience. Weather deponent - do not leave your umbrella behind!
Gorgeous Palace and Fountains. This is a breathtaking palace and the main fountain is choreographed with music at 11AM daily. Make time to visit this palace!

Rich history. This was one of my favorite spots on our St. Petersburg tour. We had our own guide who was very knowledgeable. The fountains are fascinating. The gardens are formal gardens and very beautiful. Don't miss Peterhof!
Huge Palace with Amazing Fountains. It must have been nice to live in this palace but it is huge. Ornate, over the top, with fountains and grounds to match. An amazing place to visit.
Ingenious Opulence. The opulence and engineering is a marvel. HUGE grounds with the rear fountains as the highlight. A MUST SEE if in St. Pete

Breathtaking. The millions the russian aristocrats spent in building and decorating their palaces and gardens cost them dearly (no doubt about that), but as much as they made the masses of their times envious, they make contemporary russians proud of their touristic riches. Do not miss this jewel! It is for sure worth the fifty minutes trip!

Mixed feelings. We were on a tour, coming from Scandinavian countries.Not to appear as a snob, but both my wife and I have mixed feelings on Peterhof Palace.IF - and a big IF - we had never been to Versailles outside of Paris, Schönbrunn Palace in Vienna, or Neuschwanstein in Germany, this would be Excellent! Having been there, as well as palaces all over the world, this isn't as good. It seems a bit garrish at times, with basically gold-leafed statues and displays.We liked the gardens and fountains the best, and I think the fountains came on at 11 am. (Be sure to get there early to get a good spot!) However, the music that came on at that time was rather blaring, and softer music would have made it more classic, but it still was very good display. It took only about 3-4 minutes for the fountains to come on full-blast.The gardens were great and we enjoyed wandering around it.Note: They do not permit photography inside the palace - kinda annoying and irritating, and no good logical reason for it.You can finish it within 2 hours, but should allow 2-3 hours to leisurely walk and enjoy.
Incredible. I was lucky enough to have a tour as part of a cruise. The gardens and fountains are magnificent. The building is also a must, and it was crowded.

Spectacular!. These gardens are massive and beautiful. There are many fountains spewing water and it was interesting to discover that they are all gravity fed. No pumps, motors, or electrical parts! The gardens are colorful with many varieties of flowers and shrubs. There are lots of people wandering around, but the palace and garden is so vast that they don't seem to get in the way. There are also lots of trees to stand under for some shade or to get out of the rain. We highly recommend stopping here and you won't be disappointed.
Excellent. Excellent to visit especially as numbers are limited in the building. Beautiful interior, exterior and gardens

The most fantastic fountains!. This is a top visitor attraction near St Petersburg. We visited as part of a 4 day stay in the city on an organised trip. I am not a fan of such trips, but it seemed an easy way to visit the gardens. However, to my horror, it did not include the upper garden or the palace! I felt cheated. To have come this far and then only able to see part of it was truly annoying. We had no time to get tickets for the upper gardens or palace either. It appears that tourists are herded into the lower gardens and heaven help you if you want to see all of it. The lower gardens, however, are truly magnificent. They are well worth a visit. We didn't even get enough time to explore them properly! The 'surprise' fountains are fun and must be unique. Obviously planned by someone with a sense of humour! The planting of the garden was good too and we loved the fountain with the gold turtles. I don't know how visitors can actually see all of this garden and palace as it does appear to be so difficult with the ticketing system and the sheer number of people wanting to visit. We went on a Thursday and the queues for the additional tickets were pretty long. It probably needs to do some late nights to spread the visiting hours a bit. Why turn on the fountains at 11am? A bit late. Having said all of this, visitors really must go! This and the whole of the Tzar's Village really epitomise the Russian Emperors' lifestyle and opulence.

A relaxing break from other palaces. We visited here as part of a two day excursion from a P and O cruise ship. Most of the attractions on the Excursion were of palaces etc. however this visit stood out as the best for us being country lovers. If I had to choose one location only then this is it. Not only do you see some of the magnificence of the Palace style but the gardens add to that, especially the magnificent fountains. it was fascinating to hear that there are no pumps supplying the water which is from higher ground elsewhere. Great to see the kids enjoying the random water jets, we were told that the jets are controlled by a man sitting in a little green shed hidden in the trees nearby. One can't help thinking how kids are universal, all enjoy the same simple pleasures in life. For us the hydrofoil boat trip back to the city complimented the overall day out

Saw gardens only.... This is an amazing place and runs rings around Tivoli! Almost to well groomed but opulent! Skip getting a guide as they take you through to fast to soak up the details. Use a printed guide or one on a smartphone....sorry I did not use one to recommend.

Wonderful Gardens & Fountains. We visited Peterhof as part of a tour from our cruise and spent half a day there.The gardens are stunning and we could easily have had a whole day wandering around, exploring the fantsatic fountains which appeared to be everywhere. The weather was perfect which clearly helped. I would recommend being there for 11am when they switch the fountains on for the day. They make a real event of the switch on with the jets of water being switched on one at a time until they finally reach a crescendo. It was busy though so to get a good spot you will need to be there a few minutes before. I would recommend watching from the top of the steps outside the palace to get a great panoramic view.I wasn't so impressed with the palace itself as the tour is very rushed with angry looking women moving you on if you dare to dawdle. Even our guide was being chastised for taking too long. You don't really go for the palace though, you go for the gardens and they alone make it worthwhile.

Beautiful but 2 hours was enough. Had set aside a full day to visit. Definitely recommend the hydrofoil boats as a means of transport. The gardens were similar to Versailles however not quite as grand. Watch out for the sprinklers also!

What an Introduction to St Petersburg!. Surely the breath-taking interiors plus the monumental fountains in the garden are unbeatable? We had to slip covers over our shoes to protect the beautiful floors.There was nothing that displeased me.

Beautiful park but missed the palace opening hour. The fountains are beautiful, definitely one of the best in the world. The golden statues glistering under the sun, what a sight.We started with upper garden, it's a easy stroll, and nothing special for this part. We proceeded to lower park assuming we can visit the palace later on. However, with a huge line up at 1pm (hoping to get to 2:30pm slot), we were turned away saying slots are full when there's only 6-7 people in front of us (we have 50 people behind us!!!) The huge line up was because there is only 1 person selling the ticket! I have to say this is one of the very tourist unfriendly place I've ever been to. We pre-booked taxi to go back to St. Petersburg, so we were unable to wait for another line up for 4:30pm slot. I would have rated this a 5 star, but now downgrade to 3 star due to the inconsideration to tourists.

Worth a walk in the gardens. We visited Peterhof as part of a two day package from our cruise company.We did not go in the palace but picnicked in the upper garden and then visited the lower gardens.The various fountains were wonderful.It was busy but there were plenty of quiet spots & the gardens are big enough to absorb a crowd.We arrived by coach and retuned to the city centre by hydrofoil an experience which would have been better if we had had a window to see out of! We were just unlucky to have the last remaining seats! Get in the queue in good time.
Nice park. Magnificent park. Must see in S. Peterburgh for all who loves walking in the park. It stretches over quite a long bit of land so bring confortable shoes and a bottle of water.

Ridiculous organisation of a beautiful sight. I should start with the fact that the gardens and fountains are amazing! Especially the fountains we will remember for life! But let me do this chronologically. I am not a big fan of guided excursions, in fact in 99 out of 100 times I will prefer to organise it by myself and look around at my own pace. This is where we differ from the whatever body runs this amazing palace. They have done everything so that travelers outside packed mindless groups (no offence to fellow travelers themselves) should feel uncomfortable. We decided to go by public transport, option that is quite cheap (10 times) compared to the hydrofoil. We took the so called marshrutka from Avtovo metro station. This is not really hard to do, even you do not have a clue about cyrilic alphabet, just ask "Peterhof" and everyone will point you to the small minibuses (look for number K424A). The marshrutka stop just in front of the entrance of the upper gardens, which are beautiful but are no match to the lower. I have bought online ticket for the lower gardens (you have to enter the lower gardens to enter the palace) but it proved useless as there were quite many boots selling tickets and no hassle at all. With online ticket one still has to pass through the boots. Then you enter the lower park gardens. At 11 am they start the fountains with music intro. Quite grandeur to watch but still I felt not that thrilled. Lower park is a must see. There are different fountains scattered around the grounds and one could wander for hours. My suggestion - visit as many fountains as you can. I personally liked the Pyramid one. It would have been useful to have a map of the grounds, but they only sell booklets with map for 150 rubles. Consider wandering on your own. Monplaisir palace is nice but pointless to enter. With large open french windows one could see everything from outside. The setting at which it is built was the real key point for me (at the shore). Every small cottage, museum and palace has an entry tickets of its own. That is a pretty good strategy to stop me visiting those "attractions". If they had a all-in-one ticket, I would have probably went for it and they would have earned more money, but who could understand Russian intentions.Grand Palace - here is where the real pain starts. There are two ticket boots inside the east wing of the palace where they sell the tickets, but those boots are open from 12 to 14 and from 16 to 15 (not so sure about how accurate is the time for slot this second session). They actually sell a maximum of 600 tickets a day. The boot is well sign posted, but the opening times table is immensely confusing. If you do not speak Russian you are lost. The queue for tickets is going quite fast but it is advisable if there is more than one person in you group to assign someone to the queue at the entrance (100 m away). This way you will save some time. At around 12:45 after only 45 min of work they closed the boots without any explanation. For an hour there was no single piece of clue when they will resume operations. Some of the Russians suggested that they will start selling after the queue at the palace entrance disperse, but the thing is that the two queues were interlinked and the people waiting at the palace were those assigned to skip the second queue. It looked as a deadlock. I was totally shocked to witness the mentality of Russian tourists who have enormous patience while treated as cattle. Anyway, finally they opened and the most patient were granted access. For foreigners there is another boot inside the palace, but it opens at 14:30. How you get to this boot inside, when you could enter the palace only with a ticket remains a mystery to me. The palace is beautiful but no match to Palace of Catherine in Tsarskoe selo. Once inside the palace you will be assigned to a group for a guided tour. I strongly advise you to return with the hydrofoil as it is a very pleasant ride. Price is around 650 rubles per person one way. With this trip you will have a chance to view the beautiful architecture of SP from the Neva river, but it is not a substitute for a boat ride under the bridges. All in all a must see but the organisation contributes to the low score.

Imperial Magnificence.. An absolute gem. Take time to stroll around the magnificent site, the gardens and fountains are incredible.We were there on a very hot July afternoon but thoroughly enjoyed a unique experience. Must be one of St Petersburg's top attractions, we certainly wouldn't have missed it, walked miles, took many many fantastic photographs. Unforgettable.

Not as Good as the Hype. Perhaps it was just timing, however I did not think Peterhof lived up to its reputation.I visited Peterhof in the afternoon of my second day in St Petersburg, having been to the Hermitage on the first day and Catherine Palace in the morning of the second day. Maybe I had just seen enough palaces by then - having seen others elsewhere, or maybe it was queuing for 50 minutes to enter the building, or maybe it was having to wear protective footwear, or maybe it was insufficient time allocated by our tour to the gardens. Or maybe it was just me!It had magnificent gardens, from what we saw, however I rated Catherine Palace a more interesting building.You will have to go see for yourself. And go early in the day!

A must in St. Petersburg. We were in Russia for 2 days with a cruise. We have only one day in St. Petersburg coz we went to Moscow the first day. We decided to do Catherine Palace and Peterhof. It was a right decision. The Peterhof is a must to visit. I would say it is one of the best place to visit among all our trips. A good place to appreciate the glory and beauty as well as to learn the history of the Russian empire.
Peterhof. Beautiful palace, fountains and gardens; even when busy lots of quiet places.Looks like Versailles. On the Gulf of Finland, only a short drive from the city., .

Breathtaking. Forme, this was the highlight of our time in St, Petersburg. The lower park is one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen, with all the fountains, statues, the palace on one side and the sea on the other. It is really magnificent! The hydrofoil travel adds to the excitement of the visit.

Horrible tourist trap - unfriendly stuff - expensive. It´s not worth seeing it!!. We visited Peterhof on a sunday in august. The boat trip with "Meteor", which begins at the Heremitage, was our first special experience there. Firstly the guy who sold the tickets persuaded us to buy two one-way tickets, because it should supposedly cost as much as a round-trip-ticket - which was a lie, as we checked the prices in Peterhof. So please be aware - tourist trap! Then, while having the wonderful boat-trip, they sell souvenirs (on every trip!) - with a loudspeaker. Fortunately I had my mp3-player with me. To Peterhof: Because of the masses of tourists there we were hearded like sheep through the rooms of the small palace by the really unfriendly stuff (who by the way only speak russian). You may not sit down, you may not stay in a room longer than 5 minutes. Horrible. Definitely can´t recommend it, it´s not worth the stress.In the really beautiful gardens we had a rest. But beware of sitting in the grass! It´s strictly forbidden and there is (again really unfriendly) stuff who will tell you off when doing so. You have to pay to enter the garden, in the garden you must pay an additional entrance fee to see the palace, the birdhouse, the hermitage, monplaisir, several smaller gardens etc. If you want to see all, it will be really costly (even with a student card).All in all I can´t recommend to visit Peterhof at all. It´s a horrible tourist trap which has once probably been a really beautiful location to discover...
If you think "next time", you are wrong!. You have to go there! Incredible palace, gardens, interiors! Quite a big piece of history. The best time to visit would be June.
A great afternoon walk. This is a great way to spend a beautiful afternoon outside. Be sure to ride the hydrofoil from St. Petersburg for the full experience.

Spectacular fountains. We didn't venture inside the palace but spent a few hours wandering around the vast gardens admiring all the fountains. Very busy as it was a hot sunday August afternoon but well worth the hydrofoil trip.

Shuvalovka. After leaving Peterhof (fun to watch the children playing in the fountains), on the way to the train station, we stopped at the ethnic park called Shuvalovka where we were taught how to paint Matreshka dolls. I had wanted to visit a factory but my travel agency (Travel-all-Russia) could not find one for us, but they came up with this idea. I was such a pleasant way to spend a few hours after all the baroque of the palaces. People who like working with their hands would enjoy this attraction.
beutifull. full of people, it in amazing, but over crowded. i went on sunday, so mayb better some other day of the week

A Must See in St. Petersburg. Peterhof Palace and Garden are worth the guided tour. Go early to avoid the summer crowds and plan to spend several hours. The Palace and other building on the grounds are not air-conditioned. During our visit it was unseasonably warm and uncomfortable. This is a very popular attraction with locals as well as international travelers. This is Peter the Great's vision of Versailles with gold gilding everywhere. The Palace was burned down during WWII occupation and was rebuilt with Russian pride in their history. There are two tickets required one for the palace and one for the garden. Take a guided tour and learn about the innovative gravity fed fountains all around the grounds. (During our visit they were not turned on until 11 AM.) Walk the gardens and see the Hermitage Palace on the grounds, to understand how the nobility lived. Take some Rubles. The small shops will not take credit cards or foreign currency. The larger restaurants will accept credit cards.

Stunning even though a little confusing and expensive. The grounds were stunning, like Versailles but the tickets were a little confusing. We purchased tickets for the grounds but only were allowed to see the front grounds. To see the rear gardens we needed to buy additional tickets or the more expensive ticket. It was quite costly especially when you add the cost of the hydrofoil, but it falls in the category of YOLO.

Amazing landscaped gardens. To get here take a hydrofoil boat from Admiralteiskaya (nearest metro station). It takes around 30 minutes. But be aware if you take this boat you will arrive at the pier near the lower gardens, which you have to get a ticket for. If you then want to visit the upper gardens which we wanted to do, you have to get a separate ticket for the upper gardens. But you cannot then re-enter the lower gardens if you want to take the boat back, as the ticket is only one entry. To avoid this take the boat there one-way and then take either the train or bus back to st. petersburg to avoid having to pay twice for the entry tickets. The gardens were stunning, there is a lot to explore and the place has many great photo opportunities.

Beautiful gardens, but we weren't able to see the inside. The upper and lower gardens were magnificent. I loved the fountains and the grounds were stunning. We didn't go into any of the other houses on the grounds, but did spend awhile just exploring the lower gardens.The issue we had was that we entered through the lower gardens. There they just sell you a ticket for the garden, not for the palace. We could not figure out where to get the ticket for the palace, so we left the gardens when we saw ticket booths. But those booths only sold garden/palace combos, and we weren't able to get back into the garden once we left to go buy a ticket inside there somewhere (we never figured out where that would be), so we never got a chance to see the palace. It almost feels intentionally confusing to keep people out of the palace. I was disappointed, but I hear it's their "Versailles" and I've seen Versailles, so I suppose I've sort of seen it. And I also got to see the Winter Palace, so I guess I don't feel too disappointed. It saved us 200 rubles. But to anyone going, if you don't have a palace ticket and find yourself in the lower gardens DO NOT LEAVE. There is somewhere to get a ticket for the palace. You just have to find it.
Outstanding. The gardens and fountains are indescribable. All fo the gold leaf on the stautes and domes is fantastic.

Versailles in miniature. Peter the Great had good intentions to "copy" Versailles. He and his architects succeeded partially so I would not quite compare it the its French model.But no doubt, it deserves a visit.Most important is to make clear what is going on there.You can arrive by hydrofoil.One station is behind the Hermitage and is 200 rubels more expensive than the station across the street ! The same boat the same time.You can choose visiting only the gardens or also the Palace.Two separate entrance fees.If you choose only the estate(gardens) than I suggest to buy only a one way ticket with the hydrofoil. The reason is that if you want to exit the lower gardens to visit more on the other side , you have to leave the gates and you will not be able to return to the boat unless you purchase again a new entrance ticket just to get to the shore.If you buy only one way ticket then you can leave the lower gardens and actually see more gardens and fountains.From there you can return by bus. It was frustrating because we understood all this only after we bought the two way tickets for the boat.On the other hand you can travel there by bus and return by bus or bout.The travel by this hydrofoil is not that exiting as it seems because the rout on the water takes you nearby industrial zone.But the gulf itself is nice.Back to the gardens: there are no maps in the gardens so is better if you know beforehand what is there.Entrance to other sites situated in the garden are also for a fee(extra) For example we visited the Hermitage (a relatively small pavilion situated on the far right side of the gardens.) It was interesting for the way the food arrived on the table of the royalty.It was forbidden to take pictures !Some of the big fountains are situated outside the lower gardens like the Neptune fountain or the Pyramid fountain.We spent about three hours without the palace and the upper gardens.The hydro comes and goes each half hour.Near the shores the local Russians open tables for pick-nick.Worth visiting and then comparing it to Versailles !

Versailles in the North. Burnt down during WW2 and restored to show the pride of Russia against Swedes. Great walk in the park to the sea side, where cruisers will unload passengers to visit the place.The upper park is also great for photos, and we saw many couples taking wedding pictures in bride's dress in the park.The palace was heavily reconstructed from ruins, so never sure what's original or 'new', but then it's a good experience to appreciate what it was it during the Tsar's time.

Gorgeous. Be sure and make it to the fountains prior to 11 am to watch as they turn on and come to life with music accompaniment. As the crescendo increases so does the height and volume of the numerous fountains. The palace itself takes you into court life. Go early to avoid the lines and to be sure to get a spot for the fountains.
Magical. You could spend a whole day just here as there is so much to see. You just don't know what to look at first.

Kiwi Keith sees Peterhof at Mach One !. We took the hydrofoil one way, which was quite worthwhile ,going down the Neva and across the Gulf of Finland. It was Sunday and very busy at the Peterhoff- okay outside in the lovely grounds though. Do not go on weekend if you can avoid it as there will be a staggering number of Russians as well as foreign tourists. The attractions are interesting enough but spoiled by--------The many older ladies looking after the visitors are rude and grumpy. We seemed an intrusion.They hurry you through(45 minutes!) at such a pace that it is not possible to view any room properly. Even our Intourist guide complained, but to no avail. The younger black haired attendant managed a smile and greeting, Thank you.The Ideal visit time would be 3 hours inside and out but after an hour exterior we were back on the ferry within two hours. If you need to choose, then visit the Hermitage Museum.
Grand and majestic. The gardens are majestic works of art, gold statutes everywhere. Beautiful and definitely worth the time.

Beautiful gardens. This is a small palace outside St Petersburg. It has been rebuilt after WWII and keeps many of the objects recovered after they where taken away. The palace is in front of the sea. The gardens are beautiful, full of flowers, trees and fountains. We enjoyed the visit in the palace and the time in the gardens, we enjoyed getting wet and had a great time.

SPB 2-day de luxe St. Petersburg Tour. Excellently organised!Stunning Palace and Garden! A MUST for anyone travelling to St. Petersburg.Great opulence everywhere.Unfortunately for us it was raining on the 2nd June 2014 but SPB Tours - Dasha - supplied us with Ponchos and umbrellas.That was a bonus! - So considerate and meticulous to each of the passengers fortunate enough to be with her also on this tour.Highly recommended also to read up about this place so as to appreciate it even better!

Beautiful Gardens. Even though it poured with rain, you could still view the beautifully manicured gardens. Walking in the rain somehow made you appreciate the gardens even more. A wonderful palace, so spectacular highlighted by the huge area of greenery.

Wonderful. Take a hydrofoil from the Hermitage for 30 minutes of "flying on water" and reach the Peterhof Palace. The show offered the fountains as you enter the main aisle with gilded palace in the background will amaze you in the first few minutes of your visit ... but expect to pay a lot. Everything pays off: the trip (about 1200 rubles round trip for an adult), the entrance to the park (about 500 rubles for an adult), museums (between 350 and 600 rubles, beware, they close on Mondays and the last Tuesday of the month!), access to the garden (about 500 rubles again) ... and the food and drinks for double or even triple the price you would pay in St Petersburg. Provide a meal and drinks cart and study well your visit before coming to avoid surprises and unnecessary spending ... ... that could emputer your schedule for the rest of your stay. The walk in the park at the bottom and picnic near the Gulf of Finland is very nice, though. The place is magical!
Dont miss this!. Beautiful palace and gardens! A must on a trip to saint petersburg - makes you appreciate how grand the russian empire was at its height.

The most splendid gardens in the world!. Take in the fountains when the morning sun lights up the lawns - simply stunning! Give your self time for a leisurely stroll through the quiet woods and relax!

A must to visit.. Another beautiful Palace with plenty of gold and really beautiful restoration. The gardens and fountains were magnificent and a must to make time to walk through. Again, visit early as there were crowds of people to negotiate.

STUNNING. Gold, gardens, fountains, luxury - rebuilt after WW2, this still captures the richness and splendor of Russia. I was lucky to have a private tour of the palace and gardens, even being shown the underground workings of the fountains...the technology for running the fountains without electricity or pumps (like that of Versailles) is amazing.

Overpriced, Overrated and Overpacked. I had heard great things about Peterhof and was really looking forward to visiting it! I was in awe at the ceilings and rooms in the Hermitage and have recently just been to Versailles. I have to say, seriously disappointed. First, we went by hydrofoil, nice enough and worth doing to avoid the bus but upon arriving, you then have to pay to enter the lower gardens, which truth be told, is more or less like Central or Hyde park. You then have to pay to get into the palace, which is SWAMPED with tours - there was only three of us and we couldn't even move forward or backwards we were sandwiched between back to back groups, packed into tiny roped-in corridors, literally on top of each other.The rooms themselves are beautiful and breath-taking but you have no time to actually look at anything because you are literally being swamped by the next group behind you. On top of that, you have access to maybe 1/8th of the palace... the whole 'visit' took about 30 minutes and only included a small wing of the palace, unlike the hermitage, which you could spend days wandering through.Afterwards you are ushered through visitor shops, more shops and one last shop, then outside. Despite all this, I am generally a glass half full traveler so figured I could explore the upper gardens before catching the hydrofoil back. Surprise! Your entry ticket is only good once so to leave the fenced in area to visit the other gardens, which are public and free, you then have to pay AGAIN to get back in, just to walk through the lower gardens to get to the boat. All in all, we spent nearly $200 for 3 people and about 3 of our 4 hours there either in queue or in transit. I would definitely pass on this if you are short on time - way better things to see in St. Petersburg and not worth the trip unless you are just looking for something extra to do.

Peterhof was amazing. Wow - Peterhof was one of the highlights of our Baltic Cruise. We visited as part of a tour group and took a hydrofoil over. We walked through the garden and were enthralled by the gorgeous fountains.
Greatness. I think before any judgment , you should be familiar with Great the Peter and what he has done , It seems that he has shown his greatness and honor in his palace and statues .

An "oversee" garden. On the negative side, there are only the long queues to enter the palace, which are definitely discouraging, BUT all the rest is wonderful. The garden is huge, so exploiting the little train to go around it may save pain to your feet. There is a decent resaurant and self-service, or a few kiosk with simple item to eat while walking. The shadow under the high trees, the fountains and the sea shore are great, as it is reaching it from the sea, by the several ships available behind the Hermitage museum corniche.

Gorgeous and opulent. Peterhof palace was one of the most spectacular palaces we have ever seen. The grounds are magnificent. When our tour inside was through it was time to see the fountains going off. The music played as the fountains one by one went off. You could see straight out to the Baltic Sea. We could have spent hours there. We have great memories and pictures from our time at the Peterhof.

Move aside Versailles. Wasn't able to go inside the Palace but just to look at the garden and fountains was worth the trip to St. Petersburg. Designed by Peter the Great, this palace is beyond belief. This is a must see if you visit this city of canals.
Peterhof Palace. Fantastic old palace based on Versailles with wonderful gardens and fountains. Museum staff keep the groups moving at a brisk pace! Go early or out of season.

Beautiful gardens, beautiful fountains, beautiful day. We visited as part of a 2 day tour of St. Petersburg. While spending more time here would have been nice as it was such lovely weather the day we were there, I don't think we could have managed it without the tour. We were taken by hydrafoil via the River to Petershof, and were there at 11:00 a.m. to see the fountains go on. Just a tip, unless you really really need to see them start with the music playing, they look the same on your still shots at 11:30 and there are no crowds trying to take pictures then! The fountains were lovely - 150 of them I think, and we thoroughly enjoyed walking through the place.

Opulent display of wealth. Every inch of this place is magnificent! The artfully designed floors differ in each room, the ceilings are spectacular, and so is every wall space in between! There is SO MUCH to take in, I wish we had DAYS to spend looking at everything. The fountains & grounds are lovely as well.

Breathtaking!. We took the hydrofoil from St. Petersburg and it made for a very easy trip. The day was very hot, but the fountains and gardens offered lots of cooler areas. We toured the palace as well, but the visit is worthwhile even if you stay outside the palace. Inside was an astonishing quantity of gold, marble, decoration and a glimpse into a world of unparalleled wealth. Truly an unforgettable visit!

Well worth seeing. Peterhof is a beautiful palace and the gardens are quite extensive. Our group was lucky enough to get in early before more groups arrived. The inside is huge and one of the rooms looks like the mirror room at Versailles.The best bit was seeing the fountains start as there is a special ceremony when this happens, which lasts 2-3 mins. Lovely place to visit if an opportunity occurs. Only trouble is, a lot of walking is involved!

Impressive but they really rip-off tourists. The grounds are extensive and impressive, boasting gardens and even a beach and coast overlooking St. Petersburg. I would only pay the basic fee and see these. Every other little thing to visit on the grounds is also charged for separately. I would say that if you want to go with your family, especially little kids, take a picnic with you and enjoy your time on the grounds -- it's lovely when the weather is great. You can also paddle on the shore and enjoy long strolls through the Garden. This is why I am giving it a four. Its also highly impressive that they rebuilt more than 80% of this after Stalin blew it up because Hitler was going to have his birthday bash at this place. I means its massive, so this is an impressive feat by itself.

Nice expenssive and anything breath taking. Of course Peterhof is a nice place to go, a nice walk to do and there is nice fountains to look at. But it is complicated to go, little bit far away and really expenssive for what it is. It is nothing to compare with Versailles (except the intention), nor with magic fountains in Barcelona or every castle in Europe from that era : only a small lovely castle with a nice garden and fountains : nothing special.I hate the fact to have to pay 500 to come in only in the garden. Every plus like the building inside are NOT including, not even the castle itself. If you don't have neither time, neither additional money, you will be happy to walk in Summer Garden which is free, easy to go and wonderful to rest after some visit in center town.

another age another world. Visited here for the first time ten years ago and again in May, 2014. Gardens and fountains are still amazing as is Mon Couer----Peter's smaller palace on the shore. Fun fountains that can surprise and drench you. Be very prepared for massive crowds, lots of souvenir stands as well as food and souvenir stands both outside and inside the grounds.

Amazing place well worth a visit. Went here as part of shore excursion from royal Caribbean cruise and really amazing place. One downside - given volume of people the queues at public toilets were crazy and the park would need to have more facilities

Lovely palace. We missed seeing this in 2012. Took city taxi at 1300 roubles for 3 people. Palace very over the top in gold. Didn't think as nice as Catherine Palace. Very very busy and hot. Warning. If taking a taxi have it come back for you or take a 5 hour guided tour from your hotel. Hardly anyone speaks English so it was very difficult to find our way to where we could get a taxi. Grounds are beautiful with the fountains. Get there for 11 for fountain switch on.
A Great place to visit. Absolutely splendid place to visit and take some time to look at the gardens. Fountain display at 11am but find a good place to view the fountain display.
Very nice, but not in a very hot day. The garden is almost perfect as the one at Versailles. You definitely need a great guide to make it meaningful.
You will never see anywhere else. A must see if you travel to Saint Petersburg. To be able to supply all of the fountains with out an electrical pump is amazing.

A must visit to Perterhof. The palace like all the othe palaces was a example of extreme opulance and the gardens and canal to Baltic Sea were beautiful.
I do not dream this level of splendor

The Versailles of Russia. If you make it to St Petersburg, you have to make it to Peterhof. Very convenient by taking the Peterhof boat that departs from across the Winter Palace in St Petersburg. If you can take a guided tour it would be a plus. Consider as much time for the gardens as the palace itself. Very crowded in the summer, so beware!
Extraordinary place. This place is extraordinary for its history, buildings, park and fountains. Be prepared for many hours of walking with few opportunities to rest your feet.

Lovely walks and fountains. Didn't go into the palace but the gardens are simply amazing, very popular with the locals as well but they are so big you don't feel like it is too crowded and we went during the Russian bank holiday. We had a guide which was great as she told us all about the history and the trick fountains.

Glorious!. We just walked the park, or some parts of the park ;-) it is BIG! there are some hidden fun fountains - beware! Mind the food is so much more expensive there!! take some with yo and have a picnic on the grass :-) Take water with you too!

fountains using gravity. Peterhof is not only tremendous but is filled with fountains that Peter the Great built using gravity and not pumps that are running today! The gold on the main fountain is gorgeous.

Best Best Best... must spend a day here. You will love the Peterhof palace / gardens from the minute you get a glimpse from hydrofloat or when you walk from your bus to the garden complex. the Palace is beautiful with its own charm, luxury and stories. the gardens and fountains will take your breath away. and then you get a glimpse of the the baltic sea which is so blue and calm that you can spend hours just sitting there. inside peterhof, close to the hydrofloat terminal is a cafe, which has really great variety of food and the food is really tasty...i went by bus and returned by hydrofloat. the hydrofloat ride takes 30 mins and i would recommend one use it. keep a full day aside... anything lesser is injustice to this magnificient palace.

Watch out Versailles. We reached the palace via hydrofoil from the city center from the river to a lake or bay, I'm not sure which. In any event, our approach was from the large body of water. Our first view was from water level up a hill along a divided pathway between wooded areas which if you had time you could wander down pathways beneath the trees. Along the main walk going uphill there were periodic small fountains leading to a bigger one at the bottom of a more serious hill upon which the palace was situated. We did not have an inside the palace tour, so I can't help with that. Off to the side at the bottom of the palace hill were more fountains and flowers among the forest of trees that surrounds the palace. This certainly a place where a lot more time than our couple of hours could be spent. Obviously at least a half day is needed with an inside tour. The hydrofoil is definitely the way to go. The outdoors has Versailles beaten and the engineering of the fountains is a big reason for that. Indoors, you'll just have to try both and make up your own mind.

Another Beautiful Palace. This is Peter The Great's winter palace, and yet another demonstration of the over-the-top-amazing decoration of the czars. No pictures are allowed inside. A simpler style (at least outside) than the other palaces, but the inside is stunning abnd the gardens are amazing. Be there at 11 a.m. when they turn on the outdoor fountains, which are breath-taking. Many, many tourists in July, so be prepared for crowds. Another palace where no large bags (back packs) are allowed inside. I only saw a bit of the gardens, which go on forever. And a hydrofoil back to St. Petersburg is a great way to end the visit.

Nicknamed the "Russian Versailles" - so it was!. A spectacular palace with extensive grounds located right on the Gulf of Finland. In fact, ferries go between the dock at the palace and Finland for day trippers. Known for its extensive fountains outdoors which come on at 11 each morning, it's hard to visit this venue without being surrounded by crowds. However, that said, the interiors are magnificent and well worth the trip. We didn't have enough time to do the interior and both the front and back gardens - leave yourself at least 3.5 hours - more if you like to relax and take in the views outdoors. Also, pack comfortable walking shoes. Very picturesque and historic.

a true gem. i was so looking forward to visiting the palace and gardens and i wasnt dissapointed it was stunning the palace is delightful at 11am the fountains and music starts its fantastic, the gardens are lovely with lots of fountains and flowers and even musicians playing

The Versailles of the East. We got the hydrofoil from St. Petersburg (takes about 25-30 mins), so entered the grounds from the river. I'm not a big fan of horticulture but the gardens and fountains are very beautiful - we visited during July and the sun can be very strong, with not much shade so bear this in mind.

Fairytale-like. I traveled to Russia twice in the 70's but this was the first time since then. I had never seen Peterhof. It is one of the most beautiful parks, buildings and gardens I had ever seen. It's a little pricey, and you have to pay for every different place you visit. I'd like one price for everything. I also could not exit the lower grounds to get to the other upper without paying for another ticket to get back in. I had to get back in because my boat left from the lower grounds. I don't think I misunderstood this silliness because I speak Russian and asked security. So that needs to be fixed--like a stamp on one's hand? The "Rocket" ships are the best way to go. Catch them from the dock in front of St. Isaac's Cathedral. The fountains were amazing and I caught good weather.
Peterhof Dazzles. Simply magical ! A not-to-be-missed experience, and travelling there by the hydrofoil from St Petersburg was an added experience.

Incredible gardens. Really spectacular grounds, would have loved to spend longer there. Main entrance is decorated in gold which seemed garish at first but has a really great look from down in the garden. Well worth the trip from St Petersburg.

Magnificent. The Lower Gardens here are the key to this place and are absolutely unique and magnificent. While the Palace and the Upper Gardens also gorgeous they largely duplicate what you see elsewhere. If time allows, go see them, otherwise if you've seen Catherine's Palace and/or the Hermitage you can tend to go in to "palace overload" with everything blurring together. The Lower Gardens, however, are a must see

An Amazing Site. We approached the palace and gardens from the sea. It was beautiful from afar, magnificent the closer we got. The fountains, the palace, the gardens were fantastic. We could have stayed all day had we brought a picnic lunch and a bottle of wine! A visit here is a must.

Beautiful. The sights are wonderful and makes for a great visit. The garden is filled with beautiful golden statues that add the shimmer and glamour to the place. The fountains and the whole layout are amazing. The place with is greenery and breathtaking views is a perfect place to relax and enjoy

Beautiful grounds and Fountains. Loved my trip to Peterhof Palace. The fountains were outstanding. We got there in time to watch for awhile and when it shuts down, there is an anthem played to the dancing fountains and then the water is shut off. Quite astounding.

wow--what a lay-out!. No wonder he was called Peter the Great--I guess if you were friends with him and got invited to his "house", you'd consider him great too! I didn't go into the palace itself but went to the leisure palace, Monplaisir, at the far end of the property. We strolled throughout the gardens/fountains and I just loved the property and peace it brought. I'm sure it is just as nice in the winter! We arrived before the fountains were turned on (at 11am--it's a seasonal thing) so I got a "before" and "after" and it was beautiful. The palace was huge and gorgeous with a church attached. I did go to the Hermitage (the Winter Palace) so that gave me a glimpse of the opulence that I'm sure the inside of Peterhof contained. We did our exploring before the fountains were turned on and I was glad we did because what seemed like thousands of people were gathered around the fountains and it would've ruined the ambiance of the garden area with all those people running amuck! My mom uses a wheelchair so be aware that you can't get into the palace but you can see Montplaisir as it has no steps. However, since we were on a private tour our driver tried to let him in the gate to drive the car down this giant hill to get to the start of the garden area but no go. So if you are on a bus tour, you probably won't be able to either. So I couldn't get mom down the hill in her manual wheelchair without putting her in danger. If you have an electric one--you should be ok. Even walking the paths with a manual chair--it would've been tough as they are gravely/sandy so it would've been a struggle.
What a veiw fron the river.. The trip today from St. Petersburg is short but the view is spectacular. A fantastic palace. A must see monument.

Incredible!. I preferred the outside gardens and fountains much more than the inside tour but both are awesome! Make sure to take the time to walk to the little hermitage and extra buildings on the property.

Must Visit. This certainly was the highlight of the visit to St. Petersburg. The beautiful garden with fountains and all the lovely rooms were beautifully decorated. The ballroom was the most beautiful. Make sure you bring a fan along as there was no air con.

Spectacular place, atrocious management. Take great care when taking the hydrofoil. Make sure that you have return tickets if you intend to return by hydrofoil. Once you cross the barrier from the lower gardens to the ferry port you will be obliged to pay entrance to the gardens again if you find you do not have the correct tickets, no exceptions are made whatsoever. General treatment of tourists and organisation is dreadful throughout the place as seems to be custom in all state owned monuments. Having said that, the palace and gardens are amazing and worth visiting.
