2 tips for Peterhof. The Peterhof is really nice to see. Some tips;I thought it can be interesting to go there by hydrofoil but it was not much interesting and It was expensive (700 rubles). It can be better to go there by metro and bus.The souvenir shops on the street at the enterance of Peterhof are the cheapest in St.Petersburg.

Peterhof highlights. We enjoyed getting to and from Peterhof on the hydrofoil. The boats arrive right at the palace gardens.The day we were at the Peterhof the crowds around the fountains were excessive but we found that visiting the main rooms of the palace was relatively free of tourists.The best part of the visit was walking in some of the quieter parts of the gardens and having lunch on the restaurant terrace.

Mind blowingly beautiful. The fountains and gold statues really take your breath away when you first see them, especially in the sunlight. The park is built in the french style, symmetrical with both sides near identical, for example on one side of the park a fountain has a statue of Adam and on the other side of the park a status of eve.My favourite part of the park was the 'tricky fountains' children believe that if they step on particular stones it sets off the fountains. It's really a ma hiding behind the trees with remote controls, Hilarious to watch.I could have spent days walking through this park, unfortunately I had only around 2 hours as part of a larger tour, I hope to return someday, if you're lucky enough to be going, enjoy!
Beautiful. Peterhof is a perfect place to hang around. The palace, fountains and gardens are all wonderful! The best way to get there is by boat.
So grand. It is well worth the time and cost to see. So beautiful. Recharge your batteries and enjoy this beautiful site.
Versailles with extra bling. Beautiful interiors and a wonderful array of fountains. It even has its own beach and woodland walks.

A golden garden. Peterhof is the summer-palace of the late Tsar peter the great of Russia. It has a magnificent palace and a large garden stretching all the way to the seashore. It´s located a little far outside of the center of Saint-Petersburg, but easily accessible by car, train/bus combination or with one of the boats sailing on river Neva. There is a separate entrance fee to the garden and palace, but I can´t remember how much they are, whatever they are worth paying. The palace is a grand place full of gold, art and history. The garden with the incredible golden fountain is a stunning sight. Taking a walk through the garden or even having a picnic there is a wonderful way to spend a summer day in Peterhof. Definitely worth a visit, when in Saint-Petersburg

Baltic Cruise. We took a boat ride down the river, for about an hour and landed at this wonderful garden wonder. The palace was amazing to see, and the gardens were amazing. The only problem here was that there wasn't enough washrooms so the lineups were very long, which was a total waste of time...

Gardens On A Grand Scale. We visited here as part of our 2 day tour of St Petersburg. We boarded the hydrofoil outside the Hermitage and set out along the river past many key sites before going across the bay to Peterhof. It took about 25 minutes. The quay takes you in at the very end of the garden, and the first thing you see is the long green canal, flanked by fountains up to the imposing sight of the palace at the far end. Wow. For the next hour and a half our guide took us around the huge, but beautifully landscaped gardens. Obviously the main event is the sequence of gravity supplied fountains at the steps to the palace. Simply stunning. The rest of the area has pretty flower gardens, grand building and fountains, and many little attractions built to amuse the courtiers of the time. Clever little fountains to trick and surprise at every corner. It was a hot day but there were plenty of places for drinks and ice creams, and the inevitable people in costumes for those photo opportunities. We stayed until the grand turning off of the fountains at 6pm. We did not go into the palace. We got our bus back to town which took about an hour. This is a must do in St Petersburg, but do not forget your camera!

Very beautiful. This place is very beautiful. I recommend travelling here by bus and leaving with ferry, that way you can also have the chance to explore the upper garden and the other attractions outside the lower garden. Make sure you come here on a sunny day though, as the sunlight emphasizes the beauty of the garden.

Great. We really enjoyed this palace a great reminder of Versailles to see the slender and the work they have done is a credit to there workforce. If we go again this palace will defiantly be on our to do list well recommended for you to see, brilliant.

St Petersburg. We went on Holland America to the Baltics. Great cruise line. Food excellent, service excellent and I really liked that the gratuities were already included We went on a private 2 day tour with DenRus. This was an amazing tour. If you really want to get the most out of St Petersburg I highly recommend you go through them. Others went on the typical tour with the cruise line-which I heard was okay-ours was totally amazing. Liza our tour guide got us to Peterhof and Catherine the Great's palaces before the crowds and these places were breath taking. Total "wow" factorSo check out DenRus. Best decision ever. I know not the cheapest but worth every penny
Must See. Worth the trip to the suburbs of St Pete. Totally reminded me of Versailles. More fountains, possibly even more opulent.

Incredible. It's difficult to add any more information on this site than has already been posted. Definitely worth the excursion to Peterhof. Be sure to set aside enough time to leisurely experience to house and grounds.

A fairytale kind of palace. The Peterhof Palace is an absolute must-see. We took the metro to Avtovo and then a bus from there to Peterhof. You exit right outside the entrance gardens, which are free for all to see and incredibly beautiful, with their flower beds and fountains and tunnels, and of course the front view of the palace itself. On either side of the palace you'll find ticket booths where you can purchase tickets to the lower gardens behind the palace (you must enter the lower gardens to access any of the museums and the palace itself, but it's really worth it). They won't sell you tickets to the palace there, as the tickets to the palace must be purchased at the booth within the lower gardens. In the gardens you'll find countless magnificent fountains, as well as flower beds and a sort of river running from the palace straight to the opening of the Gulf of Finland). I suggest printing out a detailed map of the Peterhof gardens with the museums, statues and fountains all laid out beforehand, or alternatively you'll probably be able to purchase a map at the very beginning of the upper gardens - we got one of those for 30 rubles. Also, the fountains are turned off around 7pm. Inside the palace is gorgeous, and a guided tour is included in the 400 ruble price, although sadly all recording and photos are prohibited there. Be careful, because the ticket booth for the palace is only open from 12:00 to 14:00 and from 16:00 to 18:00 (I think). If there is more than one of you, I suggest one person queuing to buy the tickets and the other queuing to enter the palace, as the lines can be quite long. Having said that, they usually let 10-30 people into the palace at a time, so don't let the line intimidate you!You're probably better off visiting the palace and/or museums before checking out the rest of the gardens, as they can be quite tiring. They're huge, after all! If you're with kids, they'll love the fun fountains on the right side of the gardens. There are two silly ones - the umbrella and the tree - where they can play and get wet, and then there's a path near the chess board cascade where you'll randomly get water squirted at you out of nowhere (be careful if you have cameras on you) - look out for wet paths. You can also visit the palace by means of a boat from near the Hermitage to the Peyerhof mini-harbour. It can take you back to St Petersburg as well. The Peterhof Palace is a place you'll have to dedicate almost a whole day to, but it's really worth the while.
Beautiful gardens. Enjoyed the gardens of Peterhof's Palace. Meticulously maintained. Loved the fountains. Amazed at how beautifully things have been restored after WWII

More than meets the eye. We used a private tour guide Boris Leostrin at leostrinboris@yahoo.com to get there today. In the past we have used the hydrofoil. Overall it seems we got more for our money with Boris. The gardens are magnificent. The engineering is quite a feat considering when this was done. There is everything from surprise fountains for the jokester to children's fun play pads to romantic spots in the beautifully manicured grounds.

Elaborate…. Quite impressive as you view the palace rooms…and the garden with all the elaborate fountains adorned by a variety of fauna and flora will only make you smile and wonder how life would have been for the people who have lived there many years ago. Beautifully landscaped…

Don't miss this Palace. You can spend an entire day here and still not see everything. It is beautiful inside and out. Be sure and see the underneath. All the fountains are done without pumps. There is even a trick fruit display. Sometimes when you reach for a piece of fruit, you get a surprise.
A must see!. Even though we visited in the rain, it did not diminish the gradeur of the site. The fountains and gardens are beautiful.

Superb palace and gardens -arrive before Eleven a.m to see the fountains turned on. Really amazing! Constructed for Peter the Great early in the 18th century - the hydraulics of the estate were modelled by an Italian familiar with the Villa d;Este near ROME - each pipe is calibrated like an organ pipe; the thinner the pipe the more finely pitched the spray; The wider the calibre, the more powerful the column but to reach such a height that goes with it depends on the height at which the water has been stored. The palace -and its storage tanks ( that fill up by underground pressure overnight ) is built 30 metres above sea level so the spectacular display can be achieved. The spectacle therefore starts PROMPTLY at eleven and clearly can not run much past 5 p.m So with a tour of the house taking 45 minutes (NO PHOTOGRAPHS !!) your visit should last about 3 to 5 hours. Second warning: if you go via tour bus be prepared to hunt your bus among the huge numbers that arrive AFTER the turning on of the fountains. There is a reasonably priced restaurant (with primitive toilets in portacabins) down by the Gulf of Finland - Ladies might wish to us the facilities up by the Palace before lunch But there are lovely shaded woodland walks perfect if you take a picnic. Idyllic!!! Wheelchair users will be pleased to know that the steps are close to the House but two matching zig zag avenues are found one at each end of the terrace.

Great day. We had been into the place in previous years so wished to see the gardens this time as the weather was glorious and the plants and bushes would be a little more developed than during a cold spring.We took the boat from St Pete and travelled the short distance starting out from the admiralty on the Neva, it was a cool run and started the day well passing by the reconstruction of what I guess will be the new football stadium for the 2018 World Cup.The gardens were indeed magnificent, the flower beds, the fountains and the trees looking absolutely magnificent. Plenty of shade to hide from the sun and cool areas to picnic. The little cafe (boasting a picture of the Duke of Kent) was fine for snacky food and a drink. The walkers are really good and you can climb the embankment to look at the gulf towards Finland and you will realise just how close Leningrad came to be being occupied.We spent around four hours in the gardens and spent some time sketching the little walled arbours on the embankment and watched the squirrels of course.It is also good to look through the gardens at the forefront of the palace and the beautifully pool larded trees and shady spots. The church (forget its name) just outside the gates is worth a visit especially during prayers if only for the chant inning et al.Good day for couples, families or even individuals I would say.

An Absolute Must See place. Peterhof is better than the pictures in the guide books - and we were lucky that the fountains were working in April as they normally done start until May. The Palace is fantastic and the grounds and fountains are amazing

Pristine Palace. If you can pick a sunny day to explore this palace of fountains and its impressive frontage. A 30 minute trip on a hydra-foil ferry takes you out to the Gulf of Finland and to this summer home of Peter the Great. The rest is for you to explore.

What luxury. These buildings and gardens were spectacular. Opulence now open to the public. It was a very warm day when we visited and the park was very busy with many local families enjoying the massive gardens.

Great Gardens. A very nice lay out of fountains and an external view only of the actual palace. Large crowds always seem to be there. It is very popular with the locals. Be aware that there appears to be only one toilet block and it gets very busy. Don't drink too much water or watch the water fountains for too long. You have been warned.

Very Crowded and Very Big. It is a super attraction: palaces, fountains, gardens, exquisite treasures etc. But very crowded. Therefore next time: not on Sunday and not on a hot day on July. We shall be back in a better whether so we can see more of it!

Beautiful Gardens. We visited Peterhof Gardens on the 22nd July - they certainly have the 'wow' factor. Over 150 fountains, with gold statues - absolutely awesome. The gardens are beautiful, with stunning flowerbeds - another must visit when in St Petersburg.

Last day in St Petersburg and what a finish to our trip!. Words are hard to describe how beautiful this palace is. Both the inside of the palace and the gardens with their fountains are a must to visit.
super. everything is amazing! Palaces, park, fountains... the best place. a good place for children too, I guess

Well worth the visit. We visited Peterhof Palace with Maria from "about-st-petersburg-com" and thoroughly enjoyed it. The palace shows the lavish life styles of the Russian Tsars and the palace has been refurbished since being occupied in WW2.Maria was an excellent guide.

Beautiful Palace, stunning fountain, beautiful gardens. This really is an impressive palace, but plan on at least an hour to get there. We were on a tour and this was our first stop. It is worth the drive, and I think one of the most beautiful places we saw in St. Petersburg. The fountains in the back of the palace are awesome; you are really struck by the golden figures, and we were lucky enough to be there in time for the fountains going off. You will know they are going to go off as the crowd starts to form. The best way to see it is from the gardens, so walk down into the gardens and look back at the palace, you won't be disappointed. After the show you can enjoy a leisurely stroll through the gardens.Again I would strongly recommend a tour or audio tour so you can hear about all the history. All told it takes almost half a day to get out and back, but this was my favorite stop on our first day in St. Petersburg.

Set aside a day for this.. It took me the whole day to explore all of it. Peaceful and picturesque gardens to walk through, as well as interesting points dotted around the area, including the actual Palace. Money does seem to go rather quickly with food vendors doing their usual mark ups and all attractions costing a fee to visit, although guides are provided in most. A nice break from the city.

Awesome place ! A must visit.. Truly amazing place. We went there by boat ( hydrofoil) and were wowed by the gardens, the opulent palace and the fountains. We were short of time but were able to take a walk of the gardens. A must visit place for anyone visiting St. Petersburg.

Be careful with your timing. We went to St Petersburg at peak season. As a result all the palaces were full to overflowing with fellow-tourists and, despite having a tour booked for the Peterhof at 14.00hrs, they didn't let us in till 14.50. As we had to be back on the cruise ship at a fixed time we lost nearly one third of our paid-for time. Our tour guide suggested that September was the best time to visit the city - wish we'd known in advance!

Awesome summer palace. The opulence of this palace rival Versailles. The gardens and fountains are amazing. It is located 16 miles out of St Petersburg in the Gulf of Finland. A little expensive to get a hydrofoil ride and the lines to get into the palace are long. It is worth it

Czars really knew how to live. We went for a couple hours as part of an all day tour but this locations is worthy of a full day. Amazing gardens with fountains everywhere (and no pumps -its all hydraulic) as well as the palace. Do not think it would be as special in the winter without the flower gardens because the grounds are the high point.Took the hydrofoil to get there which was a neat experience.

off the charts opulent. Wow. This is the palace that Peter the Great started in order to "one up" versailles. And if it isn't more opulent, it's pretty close!It takes about an hour by train or 40 min by boat to get there. The complex has both outdoor and indoor attractions. But the fountains and gardens are the greatest! A must see for Petersburg
Wow!!. This is accessible by hydro foil. We only had time to view the grounds and they are fabulous!!! Most impressive gardens anywhere!

Fountain Charm. Yes, the palace is gorgeous, but the fountains add that extravagant charm that makes this place so spectacular at any time of the day. Also, make sure you walk the grounds of this wonderful palace. They are also intriguing; surprises await you!

Better gardens than Versailles. A truly splendid restoration in progress, the resurrection of this palace from the damage of WW2 is incredible the skills and craftsmanship commensurate with the enduring character of the cities people. The gardens in particular have been given a rebirth in line with Peter the Greats original plans. Take the hydrofoil from the city and the day will be worth it. Go early at gates open crowds are big in the summer. Main fountains turn on at 11am with considerable fanfare.
Beautiful. Peterhof is definitely worth a visit, and if you can get there by hydrofoil, it's even more fun. The grounds and fountains are gorgeous!

Wow!!!. We visited the grounds as part of our SPB tour and arrived via hydrofoil which was a treat in itself.Our guide choose some highlights and there were "Kodak moments" every where we looked.If I was going again I's bring a piknik!

Peterhof Gardens, St Petersburg. We visited the gardens of Peterhof as part of a 2 day call from a cruise. The tour was pre booked in the UK via cruisingexcursions.com.After a trip around St Petersburg we took the hydrofoil to the palace. It was very busy but; WOW. The gardens of Peterhof certainly deserve to be seen if you are lucky to be in St Petersburg. Trick fountains, grand ornemental fountains and gold statues. The walk from the palace, past the fountains down to the Gulf of Finland is amazing. This has to be on your to see list. A tour of the palace itself was not done on this visit.

Worth visiting . It's a very beautiful and extensive garden with different,and very beautiful, fountains. Didn't go inside the palace. It's a pity that you cannot lay down on the grass for a rest... Except if you work there, in that case you can even do a pick nik in the grass. Must see place in a visit to st.Petersburg

For Me, Grander Than Versailles. The tour group waltzed right in. Boom! Opulence, grandeur, power. Referred to as "The Russian Versaille", Peterhof is much more impressive---because of its impactful design compacted into every square meter. Ravaged by German troops in WWII, the palace was restored by 1947. The park, gardens and fountains are unrivaled---Incrementally built over time, an encyclopedia of park design with a variety of styles. Spend time to explore!

A St. Petersburg Highlight. We loved the hydrofoil to and from. The grounds are amazing and we wish we would have done the audio tour for it. It gets very busy during the summer months, so plan for waiting to enter. The excesses of the tsars is evident here and worth a day trip.

Crowded but interesting. Beautiful gardens and fountains. Loved the stories about Catherine the Great and Peter the Great. Peter was quite the jokester as is evidenced by the secret fountains. Be sure to see them. The view of the Bay of Finland is pretty nice. The crowds were the only disappointment. The tour was really crowded inside. The gardens are perfect on a sunny day.

Breathtaking fountains!. We spent a day touring the grounds and fountains, then took the hydrofoil back to St. Petersburg. It is very crowded and easy to lose your group-we lost our teenager for 15 minutes-not good. Stick together and enjoy the sights!

An amazing place! Just calling in a Garden, does not do it justice... Visited for the 2nd time, whilst on a Baltic Cruise. We were very lucky on both occasions, with the hot and sunny weather. Sadly to say, we were time constrained, with only a few hours each time.. We were on a private tour ( Alla Tours ). The guide gave us the history whilst we simply soaked in the whole ambiance. You could very easily spend the whole day simply wandering around the Palace and Gardens.If you get the chance, visit by sea on the Hydrofoil, A great experience on its own.

Bad luck. After an hour in a queue to buy tickets to hydrofoils and the horrible horde to het in where everyone is pushing,ready to kick you. It was Saturday hence thousands of people. It was rainy and we wanted to have a lunch, so that we went into this place down the hill to the left of the main palace. Dont ever go there! Prices are as if it were a Michelin restaurant, though it is a buffet... The whole territory used to be accessible, now it is separated from the souvenirs and the city, so if you got in on the pier, you can not exit on top the hill, otherwise you will have to buy the entry ticket again.

Gardens were awesome!. The main palace and the history of the place were fascinating, but the star had to be the gardens. I recommend spending at least half your time at Peterhof in the Gardens. The fountains are amazing, and we spent hours exploring. The museum shop is also one of the few places in the city where genuine Raketa watches can be purchased!

Amazing setting, and Opulence both inside and out. Opulence, indoors and out... the fountains turn on at 11am, and the crowds flock to see them. Try to tour the inside with one of the early access tours. Then you will be out on the back portico to view the fountains, gardens, and see all the way to the gulf of Finland.

Over the top!. worth the visit to see the decadence the Romanoff's enjoyed. The rooms and grounds are beyond description, but worth the visit...make sure you have a guide...you will miss a lot otherwise. The gold rooms are lavish examples of excess.

Half of it is closed off. We arrived by boat from downtown St. Petersburg, which takes you straight into the main gardens of the Palace. However, we were not able to exit the main gardens to see the gardens around the front of the Palace as we wouldn't have been able to re-enter the main gardens. Seems strange to deny people the entire palace gardens when they are so stunning. We were a bit disappointed with the catering facilities also - horribly expensive in the "stolovaya"
Gorgeous. Not really wanting to see Peterhof Palace because we were tired, I'm so very glad our tour director insisted on us going. It is a must-see while in Russia!
Nice place to spend all day. Take a boat to go here and spend all day! If the weather is nice you will like it. Very nice territory, you will get lots of good photos.

Amazing Fountains. The fountains are absolutely beautiful! You could spend a whole day just wandering around the fountains and gardens. You can easily travel to Peterhof using marshrutk (from Avtovo station) -- if you don't speak Russian, ask the driver to let you know when you've arrived. If you look out the windows, there will be a cathedral on the left-hand side. The hydrofoil is also a nice and direct (but pricey) option.

Dramatic Fountains. We arrived by hydrofoil from the river and approached the Lower Gardens and Fountains on foot along the central canal. At 11:00am recorded Russian music played throughout the garden as the fountains began to flow, quite a sight and amazing to think of the engineering and the effect the fountains must have produced on royal visitors of the times. The gardens were lovely and contained many fountain tricks where unsuspecting walkers could suddenly be sprayed with streams of water. Great visit.

Would be absolutely excellent if it wasn't for the lines and atrocious organisation.. Peterhof is deservedly admired by all. The Palace and fountains are a sight to see and over the top pretty. Have a look at the website, there is plenty of information for pre-trip research. We visited with a private guide, who was very professional and managed to avoid the worst of the lines and never the less - I think there must be a better way of managing huge numbers of tourists Peterhof receives every summer. There was a virtual stampede through the entrance and some of the smaller chambers of the Palace. It's an old building and there are plenty of bottlenecks to create a shoulder-to-shoulder cultural experience. Despite the best efforts of all the guides ( who are all very professional and seem to work with each other navigating the awful mess) there is a mass of people slowly crawling through every room with little room to breathe or have a closer look at anything. The park and fountains are beautiful and extremely pleasant despite the tourist numbers.

Grand Palace is grand indeed!. On a rainy Monday morning, our small SPB Tour group visited this most impressive palace. The palace was open just for tour groups so we found the rooms to be quiet and not crowded. Each room in the palace had its Russian lady doge moving groups along so don't expect to linger in a room too long. Besides, this pace helps to keep the tour interesting. Our guide took about 45 minutes to show us some of the lovely rooms inside this grand building after we had removed our outer coats (a must) at the cloakroom (free) and put on museum booties to cover our shoes. I was mesmerized by the Italian Baroque style of architecture which uses a lot of gilt trim on woodwork - on ceilings, walls, around doors, railings and furnishings, picture frames/mirrors. However the floors were done in lovely parquet or inlaid wood which seemed so appropriate here. We saw staircases, State rooms, private royal rooms, dining room, reception rooms. Each room has its own unique eye-appeal. Usually the ceilings have some sort of painting, set off with gold trim woodwork, of the czar's family cavorting in the woods.There is some furniture in the private rooms showing, for example, what a dining room would look like with a set table, or a sitting room with very comfy Turkish style seating and classic window treatment. As a show of wealth, blue delft corner fireplaces in some rooms were put into place to impress royal visitors. Grandfather clocks with gold leaf trim, also displayed the wealth of the czars. I loved to see the use of soft colors like seafoam, rose, and sapphire blue in the private rooms which made them seemed lived in. I think these rooms in Peterhof Palace are more interesting to see than those in the Versailles Palace to which Peterhof is compared. We were also taken to a room where Crimean battle scenes hung on the walls along with pictures of the military leaders. Returning to the cloak room to use the modern washrooms (free), retrieve our coats, and poke our noses into the gift shop filled with Russian craft like Faberge eggs and books, we headed outside. Since it was a rainy day, we just viewed the Cascade waterworks looking down to it from the top landing. One really must go down into the park to be impressed with the cascading water and the multiple golden classical sculptures lining each side. Unfortunately on a tour, each attraction is allotted a certain amount of time and gardens usually aren't given much viewing time. From what I saw, the layout of the waterworks towards the sea imitated Versailles', but not done in quite such a grand scale. The classical gardens are designed to focus on paths set amidst clipped greenery rather than informal flower beds and blooming shrubs. Around the fountain area, I saw that these paths used colored gravel (white and red) to provide a contrast to the greenery. Perhaps on another cruise to the Baltic, we will take a tour of these gardens and the pavillions in them. Peterhof's grand palace simply can't be missed on a visit to St. Petersburg!!

Must visit!. Amazing gardens, great place to visit in the summer. Resist the temptation to see the inside of the Palace and other buildings. Nothing new or special. Save the entrance fee and hassle. Take the hydrofoil but know you will have to pay a fee to enter the gardens which is appropriate. BEWARE if you exit the garden and then try to return to the hydrofoil you will have to pay the garden entrance fee again (YES it's a bit of a scam). Be sure to a lot a few hours and good weather. Not a fun place to be in the rain. Final point: if you plan to eat lunch there, as we did, check out the several options before you decide. There are 3-4 places worth considering for a good enough meal, given the setting.
Versailles. The gardens are a must-visit. We didn't see the inside of the palace -- amazing interiors were starting to become redundant.

Private Tour with Ulko Tours. Beautiful & Magnificent!Some of the footpaths, were not wheelchair friendly, because of the steepness & drainage channels, however, most footpaths were accessible & there was beautiful views, especially out to sea!It's a good job, my Sister was fit & I could walk short distances, with support!

WOW. It is sad to know the Germans destroyed tis place almost totally and equally impressive is how the Russian people put this facility back to its original glory. I can see why the Amber Room is one of the wonders of the world. It must be seen to believe, Maybe someday the original Amber Room will be found. Each room is more beautiful than the next and I can see why the poor Russians revolted against the excesses of the Czar. This is a must see. We Booked Alla tours for this trip and highly recommend them.
Must see. You have seen the reviews and there is not much more that I can say. It is regal, over the top and gorgeous. Don't miss the opportunity to walk the grounds - they are impressive as well.
Amazing Palace. The fountains were the most impressive thing of the palace as well as the history behind every one of them and the different things

Amazing - Don't miss this. There is so much to see and do in St Petersburg that it would be easy (if you hadn't done your homework) to miss a visit to Peterhof. However this would be a horrendous mistake. The palace interior is unbelievably opulent even if the majority of it is not original thanks to the wanton destruction of the German troops during the war. However the gardens are where you will want to spend the majority of your time. Almost every few steps present new and incredible photo opportunities. Try to visit on a sunny day as this immeasurably improves the experience. Walking in the footsteps of Catherine the Great is a great thrill and it is easy to see why this place was a favourite of the Empress Elizabeth. Aim to allow at least 6 hours to do justice to this magnificent palace.

Amazing fountains and grounds. Peter the Great set out to outdo Versailles, and he did pretty well. This is a very busy place in the summer, when the fountains are on. We came by Peterhof Express hydrofoil, which was a nice tour of its own, then were delighted with all the fountains and vistas. We wanted to tour the palace, but the bureaucracy and lines deterred us. And our guide the next day said that the other palaces we visited were furnished much more beautifully. Prepare for much walking.

Favorite palace. Incredible fountains.. This is the best of the St Petersburg palaces and there are many to choose from. Make sure you are there after 11 AM which is when the main fountains come on. Don't waste your time waiting with the mobs for the fountain turn on. Best view is from the bottom after all the crowds have dispersed And you can see everything. I think all the hype around the 30 second musical intro to the fountain turn on is way overrated and best missed!
Wonderful. Book a tour with Petersburg Voyage and go here as part of it. I was looking forward to it but it exceeded all of my expectations. Go and visit you will NOT be disappointed.
Part of the great palace. When you tour around the great palace it is very difficult to like one part or another, the are all so opulent, the throne room alone is 300 metres.

Best Fountains To Be Found. Versailles, step aside. These fountains actually work. The newly added gold leaf lets you see exactly what Peter loved this place. Few works of art can leave you speechless, as does these gardens.

Opulence!. The sunshine the day we were there made all the gold glitter against the blue sky backdrop and the sight was breathtaking. The fountains are truly an engineering marvel. A photographer's paradise!

A must when in St Petersburg. Queues longer than Disneyland and prices more expensive too, but you simply have to see these gardens and the palace. We took the hydrofoil which was a great way to get there fro just outside the Hermitage. Entrance to the palace gardens is a separate ticket to everything else, so you are forever laying g to see things. If you have had and ugh of palace interiors spend your time wandering the gardens and enjoying the fountains. We spend 6 hours walking about. The one extra ticket I would recommend investing in is the grotto tour which shows you how the fountain system works and takes you inside the grotto. Beware the tour is in Russian only, but we figured out what it was mostly about just by looking around. Put this day tour on your itinery!

Peter the greats grand palace - Peterhof St Petersburg Russia. An experience but not to be repeated. Thousands of visitors. No photos allowed in the palace. Almost felt as we were on a conveyor belt & hardly had time to focus & enjoy each room before being told by guards to move along, hurry up. Opulent gold leaf everywhere. Enjoyed the gardens & fountains. Just too many people. This excursion was part of our cruise on the Baltic so the price was probably included in our overall cost.

Peterhof Palace & Garden. This palace has many lovely rooms to be seen. The place is vast. The gardens have lovely fountains. When we were about to go to the gardens it started raining so we saw only some part of it. The Palace was laid by on the orders of Peter the Great. Large paintings decorate the Palace, which are indeed really beautiful.

An outdoors spectacle. I thought we were going to see just another palace but this was so different than what I expected. The fountains are impressive. Be sure to go on a warm clear day or you will get very chilled (Especially if the naughty fountain elf squirts you).
Amazing fountains. Peter the Great was a lover of energetic engineering. The fountains he designed centuries ago are still at work impressing visitors. Bring your camera!
Amazing palace. This is a must see while visiting St. Petersburg, Russia. The Palace is unbelievable and so gorgeous. The surrounding gardens are beautiful too.

Quite extraordinary!. Although you will have to spend a good bit of money to see the fountains and the main palace (they have separate tickets for each attraction and really exploit you), it is absolutely worth going there.I took the hydrofoil which leaves from the back of the Hermitage but you could save money by taking the minibus from the Avtovo metro station and not miss much. Avoid weekends and public holidays when the locals descend en masse. The palace has been reconstructed but you won't be able to tell because they've done such a wonderful job. The furniture is original because it was kept in storage during the war. Each room is exquisite--all the elements blend together harmoniously. I've been to Versailles but Peterhof is more impressive and aesthetically a joy to behold!

Summer palace. Many of us will never see or own a summer (house) palace like this. Extremely opulent staterooms, beautiful works of art. The grand cascade consists of many fountains, gilt statues and waterfalls.A large amount of walking is needed to see the grounds, and the stairs that you climb can be around 200 so be prepared.
unbelievablely gorgeous.. It is extremely crowded at the main fountain area but well worth seeing and visiting. A wonderful walk. My favorite stop in St. Petersburg.

Spectacular Gardens. Unfortunately we didn't have long enough when visiting here on a guided tour. However, the gardens were beautiful with ornate statues and fountains (watch out for the secret one). There were people milling around in authentic costumes but be aware if you want to take a photo they will expect payment - they would hide their faces until you paid up front. Take the Hydrofoil it is a pleasant journey where you can observe many historic buildings from the river. Again, I would recommend a guided tour to ensure you get to see the important sites and get a bit of history of the palace.

Gardens are magnificent--the building OK. Take the hydrofoil here from right behind the Hermitage and enjoy the gardens. The Gardens and fountains are lovely. The palace is impressive, but could be skipped if the lines are long.

Take Many Pictures. This is really something special! The gardens and fountains are beautiful! You have to walk around a lot from fountain to fountain but worth it! We went with our cruise tour and had a great time.

Peterhof palace and gardens. I would definitely recommend a visit to Peterhof. The fountains are magnificent. We were there for the fountains being switched on and the music played was delightful. Visit was very short. Would have liked more time to explore

Fantastic Gardens. Great gardens and good facilities. The lower garden has a intricate series of fountains that are interesting in that they are all gravity feed. Quite the feat of engineering. Allow yourself plenty of time to stroll through both upper and lower garden and along the shore located at the bottom of the lower garden. On this visit I didn't go inside the palace so can't comment on that. The place is popular and crowded, best to go early in the day.

Splendid Gardens. The magnificence of these gardens is matched by the fantastic statues which adorn the gardens. Walking through these gardens it is easy to put yourself into history by knowing the significance of the place.

Beautiful grounds!. We were on Alla tours when we saw Peterhof. The President was also in town at a summit so they were setting up for that event. Music playing and tents all over the back park. It was still beautiful to see the gardens and the palace. The history that was given on the tour really adds to the experience.

Great Place for Pictures!. Took the hydrofoil from St. Petersburg to visit this historic and extremely beautiful palace. Bring a good camera because this is a place to take LOTS of pictures. Got there early for pictures, which was a waste because the fountains weren't operating. Don't waste the time or film because its much much much more beautiful with the fountains operating. The tour inside was relatively easy to get into and was a highlight. Each room was different; they were all awesome. Couldn't understand why they wouldn't let pictures be taken inside; kind of stupid given the number of people visiting & cost to get there. Because we entered/departed palace grounds from the water, touring the gardens on the other side of the palace farthest from the water was impossible. Don't eat at the cafes on site because they are outrageously expensive; two small drinks and deserts cost $35. The couple behind purchased some food...not much...for six and it cost ~$250. Wow. After visiting the palace, take time to walk the grounds; you won't be let down. Really enjoyed visiting Peterhof Palace. Its a "can't miss" site to see.

Peteroff was worth the bus ride. Although an hour out of st Petersburg, Peteroff was well worth the trouble. make sure to get there on our after 11am when the fountains are turned on. Grounds are superb. Can easily spend an hour or two walking them. Lots of fountains and sculpture. Magnificent. The czars knew how to live. No wonder the peasants revolted.
amazing gardens/fountains. The fountains were the most memorable part of the tour but the palace was impressive as well. Very impressive!
Romantic place. the world's most wonderful fountain! It has dozens of golden statues drenched in a huge water display

Excellent Museum and Park. Another example of past Russian decadence. Everything has been lovingly restored since WW2 but it was so busy! On a Sunday morning there were people jams in moving through the building. The refreshment places and numerous tourist stalls detracted from the overall visit. The parks were a joy to walk in and are so large you can get away from the crowds.

Must see place but typical Russian organisation (lack of). We got there via hydrofoil (tip - don't use the main pier in St.Peterberg if it's busy I totally lost my temper there, use the one at the back of the Hermitage). Hydrofoil brilliant way to get there. But getting into the park there is just crazy. Ticket kiosks along a narrow path which just gets clogged with people if it's busy. Someone please show them how Disney do things. And heaven help you if you're behind someone paying by credit card. Anyway once you've paid; and this is only for the park, you then queue to get through the pitiful number of turnstiles. We didn't go into the palace but the garden in front of the palace is well worth the hassle of getting there. You cannot however go to the garden the other side of the palace as you need to go out and they won't let you back unless you pay again. And if you do venture out you can't get back to the hydrofoil jetty! You'd have to pay again to get back. .. Trust me this is true and I even got an official at the palace to eventually admit this was crazy. However the upper garden isn't really that good anyway compared to the lower garden with all the fountains.

WOW!. Beautiful gardens with splendid fountains. We were treated by two groups of musicians while walking through the gardens.The palace was exceptional as well. Thankfully the Tsars spent a lot on themselves so that generations later can enjoy the results years later.

Avoid - it's like Disneyland w/o the rides. First of all there is a line for everything. Way too many people around! Most of the signs are in Russian only, so finding the right line can be a problem already. Once you do find the right line everything is crazy expensive. In addition, almost nothing is really old, but 1990 replicas ... while some of it certainly looks cool, it is just not worth it!

Incredible Gardens and Amazing Palace. One of the grandest places in Russia is the amazing Peterhof Palace – built by Peter the Great in the 18th century. The Palace is amazing because of its extensive gardens and fountains and gold tipped Palace. To get there, catch a hydrofoil from the city (go to the river behind the Hermitage museum). It’s about a 30-minute ride across the bay and you’ll see lots of Saint Petersburg on the voyage. The hydrofoil will take you to the front of the Palace; from there it’s an easy walk through the gardens to the front of the Palace. Along the way you will literally pass hundreds of fountains; even the gardens are opulent. The best time to see Peterhof is in the warmer months, as the fountains are turned off during the winter. For more things to do in St Petersburg, check out my website

A must visit while in St. Petersburg, despite being run by the Russian Mafia.. This review largely pertains to only those travelling independently and not in a tour group. Read on if you do not want to pay twice. My friend and I arrived in the morning on the hydrofoil after purchasing roundtrip tickets. We paid 500 rubles to enter the lower garden and arrived to see the fountains turn on with the music. We then made the mistake of visiting the palace soon after, which was swamped with tour groups. Better to leave it until later in the day. I believe the palace was another 500 rubles.After strolling around the lower garden we eventually left to visit the upper garden. They do clearly indicate that one must purchase a ticket to enter the lower garden. However, we had to come back into the lower garden to get to the hydrofoil. The workers there obviously know there are a number of tourists who arrive this way and must make there way back. A guidebook I had said that if you have your used lower garden ticket with you they will let you back in so you can get to the hydrofoil. I even had my return hydrofoil ticket to show them. The woman would not let us in along with another French couple who were in the same situation. The end result was that all of us had to pay another 500 rubles to get back into the lower garden. It was a fantastic day, but I left feeling bitter that they screwed us over like that. If I had to do it again I would buy a one way ticket on the hydrofoil to arrive in the morning to see the fountains turn on. Then, resist the temptation to go see the palace right away and go see the lower garden. You can have lunch at the cafe. Sometime in the afternoon visit the palace which hopefully should have less tour groups at that time. You can then visit the upper garden afterward and leave through the front gate. Take a train back to the city which should be a lot less than 500 rubles to get back into the lower garden for the hydrofoil. C'mon Peterhof management. You should be ashamed of yourselves for screwing over tourists who come to visit your country. I gave this a 5 because it is such a beautiful place. However, the people who manage Peterhof can suck it.
It`s worth a visit. Wonderful gardens and fountains. Not far from the city, we took a bus from a metro station. In one morning you can visit the hole place.

The best part of our visit to St. Petersburg. These gardens and fountains, along with the palace, were the most beautiful site we visited in this city filled with awe inspiring sites. The park and fountains are simply lovely and lavish! A must see!

go by boat. Peterhof is to St. Petersburg what Versailles is to Paris. If the weather is fine, take the speed boat for a stroll. Don't expect restaurants, though, they haven't discovered yet that people might want to spend some rubles on lunch.

simply stunning, nothing like that anywhere else. You will need at least a full day to check it out. We arrived by the boat from Saint Petersburg and took a guided tour to understand the history behind each building, fountain system etc. It was one of the best experiences of our lives.

Go in summer and don't go to the Grand palace. Peterhoff is a great place to visit, especially on a nice summer day, when the sun reflects beautifully in the guilded fountains. In winter I would recommend to choose Pushkin (also known asTsarskoe selo or Catherine's Palce).I strongly recommend to go there by hydrofoil. It leaves from the pier next to the Hermitage. It's not hard to buy a ticket there (which is about $ 25 per person) and it leaves every half hour. It only takes 30 kinutes to get there by hydrofoil, and you will enter from the beautiful Lower Garden. When you get there, don't go to the Grand Palace (the main one). It's not as pretty inside as it is outside and it's very crowded. Moreover, the ladies who sit in every room will push you to go through as fast as possible and you won't enjoy a single bit of it.Insted, go to one of the little pavilions in the park.For example, Monplaisir was the house of Peter the Great, the founder of your city, and has really cool and unusual stuff like his bedroom and his smoking pipes.There is a real Bath house remaining from 19th century with a sauna, showers etc., which belonged to one of Russian empresses.There are a lot of other interesting little houses, like the museum of yahts, playing cards or bikes.None of those pavilions are ever crowded.

Grand Palace and Spectacular fountains. Such an amazing palace and then the gravity-fed fountains that come on at 11am each day, are amazing to see in many parts of the gardens. A truly remarkable visit.

Gardens @ Peterhof. The gardens @ Peterhof are beautifully designed and landscaped.I understand that the fountains all operate by gravity and require no machines, which adds to their beauty. In my view, these gardens surpass those @ Versaille.

Three out of three...... The last stop on the second day of our 2-day shore excursion was the Peterhof Gardens and we spent the rest of the afternoon at the gardens. Once again, our guide, Alexi, was very informative; his knowledge of the arts & history was extremely helpful. We were thankful he was our guide for both days.The gardens were incredible. Even though it was raining, quite heavy at times, we enjoyed going everywhere and seeing every garden. One more magnificent that the other. Just like The Hermitage & Catherine’s Palace, the Peterhof Gardens should be seen; hopefully with better weather conditions.

Make sure you catch the fountains.. You will be fighting with tour groups, so make sure you know what time the fountain show starts. You can consider the fountain as your first spot, then go on and explore the rest of the palace and garden.

Definitely go here. What stunning rooms with lots of gold and beautifully decorated. The fountains and gardens are worth spending lots of time in as well as the palace it self. Make this a must see when you are in St Petersburg. Try to go with a guide as they get you entry much quicker and by pass the queues.

Gardens and fountains are enough. We skipped the palace, both due to the added cost (another 500 rouble), and to the fact we saw Catherine Palace the day before. (See one palace, and you've seen them all...).I suggest travelling via Metro (Avtovo station, which is worth a visit in itself) and marshrutka (K-424) to the upper gardens, and return via hydrofoil. It will save you over 500 roubles and you get to see the upper gardens as well.

Visiting St Petersburg with Alla tours. Peterhop Palace and Garden is the place you should visit. It is beautiful and the gardens are very nice and well kept after it was destroyed. The gold and green fountains are really nice to see and you need more than a whole day to appreciate the place

Fountains are superb. Loved the gardens of Peterhof however it could turn out to be quite expensive if you're not careful. We deliberately took the hydrofoil to arrive by water and more quickly than by bus. The return journey was 1200R each. we didn't want to visit the palace as we had been to Catherine Palace the day before and so only wanted to visit the gardens but the entrance was 500 R for each of us and the palace would have been 650R per person. The various buildings all seems to be charged around the 300R so plan ahead or you could end up paying a lot of money.
fantastic beautiful palace and gardens. what a place, no wonder they had a revolution, to see all of this decadence and splendour, fountains and gardens wonderful

Great gardens and photo locations. The Peterhof palace and gardens are a good location to visit and especially the gardens which have a variety of fountains (The Pyramid and Neptune fountain not to be missed) and a canal that runs into the baltic sea. The garden is huge and have different fountains and kids had a lot of fun.It is located on the gulf of finland with 64 fountains, many gilded bronze sculptures and a nice cafe on the outside after the visit

Fabulous opulence. Wonderful afternoon spent here in the fabulous gardens and palace giving a really strong impression of the opulence pre revolution. The views from the palace looking down over the fountains are quite simply stunning. Ideally we would have spent longer here but as part of a two day package a couple of hours were as much as we could allocate.

A Work of Art. On a cruise recently we stopped over for three days in St Petersburg and one of our tours was to the Peterhof Palace, this is not to be missed it is such a wonderful historical place to visit. despite being severely destroyed during WW2 the work that has been carried out to restore this is excellent. You need plenty of time to visit if you are going to take in the whole ambiance of this beautiful work of art, architecture and opulence.
Lovely fountains and gardens. The gardens and fountains are beautiful. I came twice because the first day it was raining heavily. Did not visit Palace however the gardens were worth the 2 trips.
Peterhof palace. Amazing terraced gardens with many fountains to surprise and amaze! Seeing it glinting in the sunshine was fantastic.

All that glitters is gold. Unbelievable! Plan to spend a whole day here. We could only stay for one hour and it was like minutes. We didn't see 80% of what is available. But what we did see was absolutely fantastic!

Loved the fountains!. We just toured the fountains with a guide as part of a day-long package, but really enjoyed the variety of fountains and the park at Peterhof. Kids liked the "joke" fountains that spit water as you walked by. Beware if you don't want to get wet!
Garden. The only way to describe this is Wow. Again there is so much history and the chandeliers are out of the world. Very nice
Amazing on a sunny day!. The 100 plus gravity fed fountains throughout the gardens are amazing to see in action on a sunny day - might be different mid-winter!

Worth the trip. Peterhof is a delight for the eyes. It is quite large so plan on several hours if you want to just walk it, all day if you want to see the museums. The first Meteori (hydrofoil) leaves from the Hermitage at 9:30am and the last one returns at 6:30pm.

A royal beauty. This palace was beautiful inside and out. It has been restored to its original beauty with gorgeous silk florals on walls and upholstery in many rooms. The gardens are also lovely with many stories to tell. After our tour, our guide took us to a Russian fast food cafe next door - an excellent choice.

Stunning grounds!. Went here as part of a tour of St. Petersburg, when we stopped overnight on our cruise.We visited on a very busy sunny Sunday. Being a keen photographer I was keen to get some nice shots of the fountains and buildings but it was impossible to point the camera in any direction that was smothered in tourists!We enjoyed a lovely walk around the grounds. The fountains were amazing with some surprises and we were given non stop facts and history by our awesome guide Marina.Certainly a must see as part of a tour and well worth the hour drive out of town.
Magnificent gardens and fountains. The inside of the palace is impressive, but the gardens and fountains are the true attraction. Again a must.

Visit in June 2014. You need the whole day to explore Peterhof but as i had a child with me, i skipped palace and head straight for the fountains. Not only they are gorgeous, there are several so called trick fountains that will provide hours of entertainment for those who travel with kids. Also, it is very easy now to travel to Peterhof by hydrofoils (they are a bit expensive but save you tons of time and are very convenient) which depart from across Hermitage.

Expensive and queues!. We went on a sunny Saturday - big mistake so many people there. You have to purchase a ticket to access the gardens to begin with, then if you want to visit the Castle itself or other museums you must pay extra- Queues were long and staff spoke little English so you didn't know where to queue up. Gardens were nice but few benches to sit on! Bring your own food, its expensive!

Visit free the upper level first... Very nice gardens. Try to reach first the upper level by Taxi or Minibus from Avtovo Metro and then you can enter free and then decide if to pay for the lower level& Palace and to return from the Peer...

Stunning visually, a remarkable and huge attraction. A vast park and building in the style of Versailles but larger. All rebuilt after WW2 and is in splendid condition. Fascinating to visit - depite the crowds..

The palace is nice. The gardens and fountains are fabulous. Ok, you don't get a lot of 80 degree days in St Petersburg. That helped! The palace is Versailles, plus Hampton Court, with a dash of Topkopi. We've seen them, so, it was a bit " been there, done that", But the gardens were great, cool, beautiful, and the fountains ranged from whimsical to spectacular. If you have to choose between this and Catherine's Summer Palace, it is tough. The amber room there( the walls are amber) is unique. Except for that room, indoor photography is allowed. Peterhof has better grounds but no indoor photography. And the winner is??either or both!

Peter's Alternative to Versailles. I cannot imagine what can be more beautiful in the world considering that most of the fountains are still operating with 300 year old pipeline system based on natural water pressure, as teh Cascade goes down to the sea, which keeps the natural water pressure. An astonishing fountain system that has been preserved by the keepers to the best of their abilities at the WWII siege and restored after the war.

More than just the palace. This place needs many hours to explore, and boy it is worthwhile. Called the Versailles of Russia, it does not disappoint - easily my favourite in St Petersburg. Being able to video and photograph the huge fountain features was a highlight. They are all quite different. You can eat on the run from small vending hot dog stands rather than sit in the restaurant which just wastes time. Taking the hydrofoil back to St Petersburg is also rather pleasant. Ensure that you have a small map of the gardens to make the most of the garden visit - explore the upper garden before the palace tour/lower garden as you won't have time to go back

Wonderful. Must say I didn't want to go in the first place, not a big fan of museums and related, but a definitely worth it experience. Once you take the boat that takes you there, you can see all the landscape, the sea and lovely weather (If you go in summer).Once you reach there you can pay a guide or go on your own. Do not forget to take wáter, cause is a very big garden and you must check it all. It has great fontains and lakes. you can stay and chill for a while in the always Green grass.Once you enter inside the museum or palace, you will be amused by all the interior design, all the details well kept. I must mention that the entrance to the attractions are separated, so you have to pay if want to go inside.You shuld take the full day for this experienceIt is amazing!
beatifull. Beautifull, but very expensive. One ticket for gardens, other for the palace, and we needed to buy one more if we woul like to visit the Neptune fountain...
Beautiful view into a glorious and extravagant past. as above-amazing wealthy splendour.Probably on a par or superior in its own way to Versaille.Looking to souvenir photos of same.

A Beautiful walk in the country. This Summer Palace was a wonderful sight of gardens and a wonder of fountains without the use of pumps. The summer house is an interesting look into Czar Peter's personal life.
Russian Versailles. Very beautiful palace and garden, in any ways much better than its french predecessor. One of the most beautiful places you will see in your life.

Must see when fountains are running. Peterhof in the summer is a must see. Take the Meteor hydrofoil from the Neva River next to the Hermitage for a fun and fast ride to Peterhof. The fountains run from late May through the summer, and they are worth the visit. The gardens are expansive and plan to do some walking to see them. Remember when and how this place was built to be really inspired!

Try Winter. You should know that I began visiting Russia in the early 1970's and I have been there 4 times to date . I hope to visit the Urals in due course . In 2009 (FYI trip advisor didn't offer this year to select ) I suggested that my husband and I visit St Petersburg & Moscow in the winter and have a Dr Zhivago experience . And so we did . It was one of the very best trips of our life . Unforgettable . "Mir " was out tour company .It snowed upon arrival and it was a perfect snow . We were told that this is not always the case so we were lucky . We visited the Peterhoff just before New Year's Eve . No crowds at all in fact we were often alone in those splendid rooms . True enough we could not see the gardens but .. When we finished up and went outside there sat a troika for hire .Yes the sleigh drawn by horses . Naturally we got in , pulled the blankets over our laps and off we went around the gorgeous snow covered grounds and into the woods . Even now I get misty eyed remembering it .
Peterhof Gardens only. These gardens were spectacular and the tour was completed nby a hydrofoil ride back to St Peterdsburg
Magnificent. One of the best and more beautiful places you will see in your entire life. It was a rainy day, but we managed to take the best pictures and to enjoy our tour.

Peterhof palace and gardena. a must visit if in St Petersburgh. Grandiose opulence that cannot be matched apart from St Catherine palace. Couldnt decide if it was beaitiful or gatish but glad i have sern it as will never see its like again. unfortunately only one outside toilet fascilities therefore long queues. unsure of entrance fees as was in the package tour of T J Travel (excellent tour company!!!!)

Don't miss this!. The interior of the palace is opulent and it is easy to picture the emperor and empress roaming the halls. The garden is a delight to stroll and the fountains are beautiful and fun. Be sure to walk to the edge of the water to view St. Petersburg off in the distance. As free WCs are few and far between it is useful to note that their is one at either end of the garden. The one not near the fountains is less known and crowded.

Beautiful. Don't go on Monday, the inside is closed. This is really nice, lots of fountains, people dressed in character, Right on the water. The palace and grounds are beautiful. I am not a big museum person this is more up my alley as far as History sights go. I have taken an English Tour, and Russian Tour. Russian Tour a LOT less money, and the visual is nice without knowing what is being said, however the English speaking tour you will learn a lot more. You can get tickets in city at any of the Bus tour places, and they take you their, give you a tour and take you back. You don't stop any where to eat, so keep that in mind.

The gardens alone are worth the trip--but don't ignore the palace!. It really makes sense to attend this attraction with a tour--makes it easier to "beat" the crowds and make the most of your time. Our tour group bypassed a L-O-N-G line of "single" tourists waiting to enter at the non-group entrance, and I expect that it will be worse during the rest of the summe. Do make sure that you're there when the fountains are on--11:00 is when they turn them on..and marvel at the hydrolics involved--all natural, everything gravity-fed and forced back uphill without machinery! The palace is also stupendous, if you're not glazed-over with all of the opulence you may have already seen in St. Petersburg....

Worth a visit, but get there early. We visited as part of a tour group and were not disappointed. Reading some of the reviews, it seems that those people who tried to visit it as independent tourists hit a lot more problems. I recommend you join a guided tour - and one that gets you there early: later on it got very busy! Don't miss going down to the "Monplaisir" palace on the sea shore. The palace rooms are opulent and impressive, as were the fountains (switched on at 11am when we were there). The rest of the grounds are a little more ordinary, but still worth a walk round.

Breathtaking. If you can get a tour guide and early entry. Even when we did this we still had to queue for over an hour as the cruise ships were inside.The gardens and trick fountains were loved by the children.The ball rooms were spectacular.

Totally worth the trip - make sure you see the fountains turned on!. We did a day-trip in the morning that arrived when the palace opened (around 8:30am I think) and was scheduled to leave at 10:45... and the famous fountains are turned on at 11 so my tour group revolted a little and our guide quickly relented and let us stay for the show.The palace itself is interesting (not as opulent as Catherine's Summer Palace in the Czar's village) but the magic is the gardens and the Fountains - make sure you do a proper tour and then make it back to the palace before 11 to get a spot on the railing for the fountain show - there is music to accompany the fountains and it's pretty punctual - the perimeter fountains come on first (one-by-one) and then the big ones start flowing down the hill from the palace to the main gardens - it's really beautiful but people are a bit crazy pushing so make sure you get a good spot, secure all your valuables, and then (honestly) stick your elbows out to protect a bit of personal space or you'll be squeezed in as people push from the back to see.

Terrible crowds-lines of 1 1/2 to enter- if the weather had been hot it would have been unbearable. Beautiful palace but crowds were unbelievable - felt we were rushed through the palace-each room was breathtaking but so rushed that you couldn't enjoy
Peterhof. Try and go there by the Peterhof Express - the hydrofoil service - aged craft, but quite fun to go on. We only saw the (crowded) gardens - but still worth seeing.

Really Superb. Very busy but an absolute must on anyone's itinerary when visiting St Petersburg. The lower gardens and fountains are stunning - words cannot describe. You should look to arrive by water taxi from the city which adds to the enjoyment.

Beautiful gardens.. I was 'palaced-out' by the time I got to Peterhof so I just did the gardens. They are superb, definitely on a par with Versailles. I had a morning here and just wandered and wandered. The fountains are amazing and the wooded walks really restful. With everything in St. P, it is better to get there early to avoid the crowds. Some tourist information: Peterhof is easily accessible by public transport. From Metro Avtovo take the 200 or 201 bus. The busses all have conductors on who will take your fare and also tell you when to get off! Check opening times before you go, when I was there the palace was only open to pre-booked tours in the morning and the general public from 12. Also, get a map before you go. These are available free from most hotels and the Tourist information office. At the Palace you will have to pay for the map - and you do need one!
Rain-soaked but happy visit. It was pouring when we visited, but the rain did not dampen our enthusiasm for the beautiful gardens and fountains.

Fountains galore. The Peterhof Palace itself is grand, but the grounds are spectacular with extensive fountains (64) with gilded bronze sculptures (37) set on terraces before the main edifice. There are also others in other areas. Being there on a sunny day was spectacular, especially after a couple of iffy weather days beforehand. In the palace the Throne Room is magnificent. The only negative: the crowds, as meandering through the palace is is fits and starts due to the large number of tour groups. Still, don't miss it.

Amazing and worth the trip. Beautiful landscape, gorgeous fountains and gardens. Definitely take the trip to this Palace. When you walk towards the sea, make the time to walk to the steps that allow you to put your feet into the ocean. We were on a tour, and saw the small area to do this, but the tour pressed onward. I wish we had just stopped to dip our toes, then run to catch up. My only regret there. There were loads of people there, so it was somewhat difficult to take photos without random people in the shot, but I guess that's what folks use photoshop for. I for one prefer not to, but at this location, it's near impossible to avoid random people.

As facinating as heaven. We took the Quick boat to Petergof (Peterhof) which is 30 minutes away (by see) from St. Petersburgthere are a few companies that you can sail with and the young people that lead you to the jettyare always working for 1 company so better to check prices and timetable with 2 at least!short walking from the pier to the garden. a fabulous garden with many fountains and golden plated sculptures from the dates of Elizabetta the Tzarinathey are marvelous fascinating and amazing! one should not miss it!we did not get to the interior part of the palace as the queue was too long and they don't allowordinary tourists who are not coming with a licensed guide to enter the palace between 12.00 to 02.30 p.m. a fact which is not published in any tourist guide that we saw.Nevertheless we were told that the main attraction there is the garden not the palaceAs in the palace in Pushkin that we saw (with a private guide) the main attraction is the palacedon't miss it!!!!!!!!!!
truly Versailles of the north. beautiful gardens and the fountains complex is really impressive. A must see if you are in Saint Petersburg during summer.
Russian Versailles. Incredible fountains and grounds. 'Especially beautiful in the spring! I loved the history of this era, Peter the Great's incredible interests & abilities.

Better than Versailles. When I visited the palace was closed so I only got to tour the grounds. The grounds are vast with beautiful fountains and gardens neatly positioned throughout. It thought the grounds were more extravagant than Versailles. Take a hydrofoil and when you arrive on the dock you will have the perfect photo opportunity!

Beautiful. As part of the shore excursion through SPB Tours, we were taken to Peterhof Palace and Garden by a hydrofoil ride. The gardens were amazing and extremely beautiful landscaping. We were just in time for the fountain display. Hundreds of tourists were hanging around waiting for it to start and we were not disappointed. Enjoyed our visit there. Not to be missed.

Exceptional gardens. We really enjoyed walking the upper and lower gardens, and watching the ceremonial turning-on of the fountains. We visited with Tailored Tours (see my full review there) and received so much interesting information to go along with this palace! And we returned to St. Petersburg by hydrofoil, which was also fun!

Beautiful but rushed. Went as part of a tour group from a cruise ship and we were queing for 15 mins before it opened. As we went in we had a very limited time to put on paper overshoes and begin the tour as another tour group was on our heals. This part of the tour felt crushed and at all times we felt there was a sense of urgency to the procedure. Photography is not allowed and I felt we did not have adequate time to enjoy the restored splendours of the rooms before we had to move on. The interior is incredible and very reminiscent of some of the Bavarian and French Palaces in Europe. The hall of mirrors is a sight to behold.The gardens are very extensive and we joined the crowds to wait for the fountains to start playing. The wait was worth it and it was a spectacular sight. The palace and commentary is well worth a visit and having a well informed guide is a must.

A great place to wander!. The fountains and gold leaf and quite amazing at Peterhof, but we also enjoyed wandering the paths, seeing the trick fountains, etc. you could spend half a day here taking it all in.

Wow factor. After a very cold start and hydrofoil ride in St Petersburg, we arrived at the Peterhof Palace and Gardens. After the short walk from Hydrofoil, you come across this amazing sight of a Palace, its gardens and many fountains all covered in gold.

World Class Attraction. One-of-a-kind palace and grounds. Restored like new. Incredible exterior. Interior doesn't disappoint either.
Don't have time for 50 characters so trust me on this.
Amazing Gardens. Well worth the trip from St Petersburg, the water fountains in summer time are simply stunning.... no visit to this part of Russia would be complete without visiting here !

Gorge on gild!. I think Peterhof Palace and Versailles are destined to be in an eternal competition for superiority! Unfortunately the powers that be have divided parts of the palace and grounds up into separate pieces, making you pay for admission to each one rather than treating the entire palace and gardens as a whole. Obviously the only reason to treat different spots as separate and distinct elements is to make money, which I think they are making hand over fist. Be prepared for a large crowd of people to be gathered around every picturesque spot, waiting their turn for a photo opportunity. Certainly the large crowds just speak to the quality of the attraction, but it's awesomeness would have been multiplied ten fold with less people. Maybe try to get there early in the morning? Be on one of the first boats. If I could go back and do it again that's what I would do. Enjoy!

Not to be missed. I have been here twice. Once during the day and once for the special evening tour. Totally different and both excellent.So beautiful but do allow time to explore the grounds as well as inside!We did the evening tour with Oceania cruises and it is excellent and worth the price! The palace was closed to all but us.We did the day tour on a Princess cruise and their evening tour was slightly different but from all reports very enjoyable. We took a tour with SPB Tours during the day. My only complaint was we went to the bottom of the steps on the wrong side as when taking photos we were looking into the sun. If that happens to you insist on being able to go to the other side for photos as this is probably your only chance for that perfect photo. Thankfully, I had great photos from a previous tour in the evening.Definitely one of the best places to visit in St P.

Wonderful Escapade. Only few kilometers away from center of town. Amazing palace and gardens (upper garden and lower garden).Go there with a Bus and come back with the Speed Boat starting every 20 mins of the wharf. Arrive again in St. Pit in front of the Ermitage

Beautiful palace and gardens. A beautiful place to visit just outside St Petersburg. The gardens are particularly lovely to wander around. The palace itself is well maintained and well worth a visit. Only complaint is that you tend to be herded through each room as if on a fast-moving conveyor belt so you end up with a sense of what the place is like rather than being able to savour it. And our tour guide's comment "Good advice for tourists: walk faster, see more!" is not my idea of the best way to sight-see.

Palace of Fountains. First getting there , located behind the Hermitage you will find Hydrofoil Boats. Like James Bond from the 60's the boat goes as normal and then you are out of the water. The boats are old but very interesting. When you arrive the view of the palace is wonderful long canals all the way to the place. Then you discover fountains and gardens around every corner. The crown jewel is the gold fountain behind the palace. You should pass on the palace tour and just look from the outside - trust me the gardens and fountains are amazing but the palace is fine but if you are thinking its Versailles in France its not, its nice inside but very plane. Spend the time in the gardens and be amazed by the engineering that each fountain took to build and power with no pumps and how high the water goes

Wow and .. Wow !. It is called a Grand Palace and it is!!!!! The interior visit is quite impressive and has all the qualities of a Palace. It deserves a "Wow" and the visit is much more interesting when accompanied by a guide because there is so much information and stories attached to the Palace. The exterior gardens and very large number of fountains (in the hundreds) certainly deserve a second "Wow"...and more!!!

It's a bit too commercial and pricey. The palace ( including the park and gardens) is huge, I suggest to reserve 3-4 hours if you want to cover all parts of outdoor gardens. I went on weekdays, already filled with tourist and locals, not easy to get a good spot for spacious photo. After the initial entrance fee, you would then have to pay for additional fee of 300-500 rub each of the museums that to would like to get into, I end up skipped them all and had a long walk in the garden and parks.On the far left of the garden, there were some historic photos of the palace, you may find the current water fountains and and most of the building structure were either add on or newly built.

Look for the small and peaceful. The place is just huge, and you have to pay separately for every little piece of it. So, take in the magnificent fountains, traipse slowly through the gardens -- but look for the small and peaceful in addition or in place of the grand palaces. Tour Catherine's small addition to the right of the Grand Palace to see where she really lived while there, and take the little train to see the Alexander Park with the "cottages," where the Alexanders and Nicholases of the 19th Century spent time and where their children played in meadows. It will take at least two trips to see most of Peterhof, so choose what you want to experience within it.

Stunning. Considering this palace has been completely rebuilt after the ravages of WW II it is a miracle of dedication to preserving history. The gold work alone is stunning and the gardens and fountains spectacular- difficult to understand the negative reports.Do NOT miss on any visit to St.Petersburg.

Organized Chaos. We were picked up at the cruise ship terminal by Alona, our tour guide, and Alex, our van driver. After a heart stopping ride on the "freeway" in rain so heavy we couldn't see the road ahead we arrived at the Peterhof Palace. There were 1000 to 1500 people standing in line in the pouring rain and a huge crowd clustered in front of the single open door where a guard was preventing anyone from entering. Our tiny and brave guide said she would go get our tickets and pushed her way through the crowd. We waited in the rain for 15 minutes before she returned with the tickets and told us we had to push our way in. The three of us slowly edged our way through the very unhappy and resisting crowd to the door.Once inside we proceeded to the required coat check area where we found total organized chaos. The women behind the counters were simply overwhelmed by the crowd. After finally leaving our coats and umbrellas we put booties over our shoes and joined the line touring the palace.The line moved quickly and the security guards, gruff unsmiling women, kept telling us to move along quickly. Alona kept telling the guards that we would like to take a moment to see the rooms we were passing through, but to no avail.
