If travelling with kids make sure to take extra clothes - they will get wet !!:-)
Majestic. Some people say that it's grander than Versailles, and while it competes, it doesn't surpass.However, the sheer immensity and number of fountains is jaw-dropping.

Be mindful of the seasons. I can consider myself an insider because I was born and grew up in St-Petersburg before moving to the US years ago. I've been to Peterhof many times over the years, and traveled to the park by boat, train, and bus. When I think about St-Petersburg, the Peterhof park is one of the first places that come to mind. It is so beautiful, with such remarkable balance and integrity, that any other garden or fountain complex pales in comparison. Enough was said on the Tripadvisor about impressions and emotions, and many pictures were posted. I can only add some practical information which is often left out.First and foremost of all, it is a combination of palace with an outdoor park with ensemble of sculptures and fountains. Fountains are seasonal. They are turned on as soon as night temperatures go over the freezing point (typically at the very end of April) and are turned off for the winter in mid-September. During the fountains season, it is a not-to-miss top attraction in the St-Petersburg area. You can't say you've been to St-Petersburg unless you visited Peterhof. In contrast, in winter the significance of this place drops in my mind to the bottom of the top ten or even lower, and can be skipped altogether.The second factor is that the weather is paramount. You have to get there on a sunny day or at least on a day without the rain. It is an easy trip, you do not need to book anything in advance, just get up in the morning and if it is sunny, go for it. If it rains, go elsewhere. The weather in St-Petersburg is not bad in summer, but it is not very predictable.The most enjoyable way to get there is by boat - hydrofoil. The trip starts from the city center, from a dock right in front of the State Hermitage, and it takes only about half an hour to get straight to the park. You do not have to commit to a specific time for a return trip. It is a little more expensive than getting there by train or bus, but it is a lot faster, and it is a fun experience in itself since you get nice views of the city along the way. After I tried all existing ways and means of getting to Peterhof (trains, buses, even a group tour), all my last trips were by hydrofoil, and if I go there again, this will be my means to travel.. The palace is nice, it would be a major attraction in most European countries, but it is a relatively minor attraction in St-Petersburg which is blessed with so many fine palaces. I visited the Peterhof palace a couple of times and I was not too much impressed. It is a relatively small palace and it is not nearly as impressive as some other palaces in St-Petersburg. Peterhof is about the park and the fountains.While a tour is a good way of learning about the history of this place, I find it more valuable just to walk around the grounds and enjoy the spirit and the views. It is so beautiful there that the history in a way loses its meaning and value. A tour would be more of a distraction from enjoyment than a benefit. With this in mind, there is no added value in taking a bus tour (unless you want to get into the palace and would rather do it with a group to avoid waiting in line) or spending precious time on a metro, bus, or train for the sake of saving money. Just get on the boat and spent a day which is worth a lifetime. This is a place which is impossible to forget and which is nothing like what you have ever seen or will ever see. Make sure you have lots of room on your memory card for pictures.Plan to allocate the whole day for this trip if you can. Common sense and experience would tell you that one does not need much time to see a park. Don't fall into this trap because this park is huge, its every corner is worth a visit and will give you memories for a lifetime. The park is THE outdoor royal palace in Peterhof. Try to get there around the time when the park opens to enjoy a little bit of solitude, take pictures of the great cascade, and to not feel rushed. Having said that, since the park is so big, crowds are not much of an issue (except lines into the palace, but I would suggest that you skip the palace unless you have nothing better to do). Be prepared to walk large distances. Food in the park is pricey, if you want to save, bring snack and sandwiches.

Peterhof Palace and Gardens. Peterhof Palace, more than 300 years old, is a lovely palace that has gorgeous gardens, with fountains, and unexpected water sprayed on those who sit on benches in some parts. The Palace was carefully restored after World War II and is worth the trip, but the layout of the gardens with the water system is a marvel.

did not mean to rate this attaction. I accidentally clicked on the stars for this attraction, meaning to give the Peterhof Palace 5 stars. I have not visited the Peterhof State Museum, but I could find no way to unclick my rating on tripadvisor. I trust the tripadvisor staff will remove it.

Another must see, Fountain not to be missed. A beautiful restoration and well worth the time spent getting there. Fountains are operated entirely by gravity - reservoirs fill overnight and empty in the day to operate the fountain. Beautiful Palace.

Check Opening Times before Travelling. We visited with friends in winter when it's quiet. Entry to the grounds were free. What we had missed was the last Tuesday of every month the interior is closed for cleaning. That said we had a great time strolling the grounds and will return in the summer......

Fantastic. The Hermitage is not to be missed. The artwork isn't the only thing to see as the building's architecture is just amazing. It is a huge building, so allot enough time to enjoy yourself without rushing, and be sure to check out the Michelangelo's that make the Hermitage their home.

Very very amazing ! Should definitely be visited !. It was a rainy day when we were at Peterhof Palace. I was so amazed with the view of the Palace and the garden from outside. They were huge and very well designed ! A large pool in the middle of the garden, lots of gold figures and fountains around and inside of it. You need more than 2 hours to see all. Our trip date was 2012. So the closer option below was March 2013.

Even has its own orchestra. Where to start with this amazing place. From the minute you enter the grounds to the moment you leave the Hermitage is one giant sensory overload. Don't try to do this in one day it isn't possible. Spread your visit over 2 or even 3 days. get a breakdown map and plan your trip.If you only ever go to one museum in your life it has to be this one.

Peterhof Palace (Petrodvorets) - St Petersburg, Russi. What can I say.....another amazing palace in Russia. This one probably the most spectacular from the outside; the grounds, gardens and fountains are amazing. You can spend hours walking the garden and the many fountains. Unfortunately, no photos are permitted inside the palace. After touring the interior, you could spend many hours enjoying the gardens. The day we visited was gorgeous, sunny, warm but not hot. The Baltic Sea can be seen as you walk along the pathways. If you visit, plan on spending several hours touring the grounds and fountains.
Wow. The ground alone are amazing here. It's photo op after photo op. Everything is so well done and beautiful to look at. This was one of our favorite spots in St.Petersburg.

Simply Spectacular. Peterhof is amazing and not to be missed! Due to the G20 closing the Neva River, we had to take a tour bus to the site. We just picked one of the tour companies outside Gostiny Dvor. It turned out to be a wonderful afternoon. The bus was comfortable and our guide spoke excellent English. It was interesting to see some of the countryside especially the housing communities close to Peterhof. We toured the palace first. Yes, it is very opulent and lavish. Yes, it is much like other palaces throughout Europe, but I thought the tour offered a unique perspective on Russian royalty. The portrait hall was interesting and something I hadn't seen before. The gardens and fountains are beyond description. It was a beautiful day and the gold and the water just sparkled in the sunlight. While I can't say it is more impressive than Versailles, I was immensely impressed by the planning and care given to each section. Since the G20 was being held in Petersburg, we were told the crowd was light that day. That being said, it was extremely difficult to walk around and take pictures at the main fountains behind the palace due to the amount of people. We were still there quite late in the afternoon and that time afforded us the best views and pictures of the fountains. I was disappointed not to be able to take the hydrofoil to the palace because I'm certain those first glimpses of Peterhof from the Gulf of Finland must be simply spectacular!

Better than Versailles and more attached to history. We visited Peterhof Palace during our stay in Russia. The gardens are impressive and offer more beautiful sights than many other European palaces. Pictures are not allowed inside of the palace but if you are a fan of baroque architecture and Russian rococo it might be clever to buy one of the books they sell. It's advisable that you book a guided tour beforehand though in Russia you'll find someone who can speak any language easily.Try to visit the palace the day fountains are activated. The scene deserves the waiting time and also provides some highlights regarding Russian engineering and architecture.The place is safe and people are friendly. You can get there by train from Saint Petersburg, however you should mention that you want to visit the palace and not the town (same name)

This is what I expect of a Palace. Incredibly cheap for entrance compared with a major site in any other major city. Golden opulence abounded, but my personal favourite was the large collection of Impressionist and Post Impressionist paintings. You need a full day, minimum in this building

Russian opulence at it's best. Peterhof palace is amazing. There is nothing to see inside the palace but It's really impressive from outside. If you are lucky and get a sunny day, simply gorgeous. It takes few hours to see as you have to walk the gardens. They are more impressive than the one at Catherine palace From the end of the garden you can have a view of St-Petersburg. The history of this site is very interesting. Enjoy the walk!

Forget the Olympics.... If you don't want to watch Winter sports, this museum is incredible. The opulence and pure tonnage of gold are only surpassed by some of the Vatican's over-indulgences. Visit this spot as part of a Viking River Cruise from Moscow to St. Petersburg and see what real luxury and comfort and fascinating scenery is all about!
Beautiful. It was years ago and by that I mean 1972! But Peterhof was one of my favorite stops on that trip. Just beautiful.

Stunning Peterhof Palace and Gardens. Peterhof Palace and Gardens were amazing. The scale and size of the gardens from the entrance down the fountains on tiers was breath taking. The view across the gulf of Finland was spectacular. The gardens were so well maintained. I liked the man sitting next to the dancing fountain catching the children trying to run through without getting wet. The expression on their faces was funny.We. Returned on the hydrofoil. A good experience at the end of a good day.
Amazing. Peterhof is a must see for anyone visiting St. Petersburg! The palace is beautiful, but the gardens and fountains are amazing.

The palace is not good but we liked the gardens!. The palace has a few rooms and you pay a very expensive ticket.Then you pay a different ticket for 2 rooms where you can see 4 costumes of the king!The ladies at the tickets tried hard to make us buy the audioguide,maybe they keep some money from that,i can't explain it otherwise!Don't waste your time with the palace or with these 2 rooms(i think they are called "treasure rooms").Visit the gardens that are amazing!!Very clean,there are places to rest in the shadows,we really enjoyed that!!

One of the most amazing places in St. Petersburg!. If you're going to St. Petersburg, then Peterhof is one of the places to definately visit! The palace is really beautiful, but for me the garden and fountains were even more astonishing. Definately spend at least 2-3 hours there to see everything this place has to offer.

Extravagant and stunningly pretty. Going in the summer made for a crowded experience, but the visit was well worth the trip out here. The fountains and gardens are exceedingly beautiful. There are a few "layers" of access, with a charge for the gardens and extra for the interiors and museums. I only saw the gardens. If you want a nice spot to sit, head way out to the docks. There are some benches you can sit on and take in the ocean breeze for a bit.

You need to go here. Either by boat or bus this is a complete must. I went there and there were still repairing all the damage done in the second world war, hope its finished now. You really need a tour guide for this otherwise you'll loose sight of the importance of the place and the things that happened there...really amazing.

Peterhof and the Gardens will take your breath away!. From the spectacular Grand Cascade the gounds hold the largest fountain ensembles in the world. The palace contains a remarkable collection of art etc. Take the train ride to Alexandria Park. The grounds and gardens are beautiful.

Impressive palace even though summer is probably a better time to visit. We went in winter and all the impressive fountain everyone rave about were closed :( However given it's off peak, we get to spend alot of time on our own admiring all the rooms without being rushed out by the crowd. Guess we will make another trip in summer to catch the beautiful garden

A splendid item of park and fountain architecture. The Peterhoff park of fountains is A MUST SEE for those who come to SPb in Summer. It covers an immense area and stretches right to the gulf of Finland. The fountains situated here are magnificent states of art that are worth to be seen on a sunny day. They strike you with rich golden decoration, ancient mythology heroes depicted in the sculptures, bizarre compositions and "tricky" fountains that turn on when you step on them (this will surely be a lot of fun for kids).
Magnificent. Even though we arrived in a downpour, the fountains are absolutely gorgeous! More beautiful than anything we have seen in Europe.

Beyond Opulence. Opulence beyond anything you can imagine. Beautifully resorted and maintained. Gardens could use some work. But seeing such opulence makes you understand why the peasants revolted! A must see when in St Petersburg! Along with The Hermitage & Catherine's Palace

PETERHOF. It is some 30 Kms out of the city - some 40 mins drive by taxi. But the buildings and the gardens are masterpieces. The tour inside this palace is very interesting and unforgettable! Don't miss it.

Unbeleiveable Museum.. The collections of art are mind boggleing. With the skill of our Alla guide, and the use of the individual earphones, we felt as though we could wander and still hear everything.
Just Beautiful Day Visit. Great place for photography and beautiful presentedDo not miss this place on your trip.Amazing sculptures

Jaw dropping amazing. Nothing had prepared me for the excess that is Peterhof. Peterhof alone is worth a trip to Russia! Really incredible especially the gardens! The most over the top gardens I have seen anywhere. I took a day tour that was a rip-off especially since I had to then take the ferry home in order to have sufficient time to explore the fountains & grounds. In hindsight, I recommend booking advance tix but taking the ferry from st petersburg to & from.

oh oh oh... Peterhof. No one lives like this except for maaaybe the Hapsburgs in Austria. Buckingham Palace may as well be Motel 6, folks. No kidding. You just HAVE to go. That's all there is to it. When you arrive and SEE this place after you walk the incredible grounds.. you just have to pinch yourself. I know I could NEVER have dreamed up a place like this. Who lived to think of these fairy tales? I dunno... BUT GO!

Stunning palace. One of the many stunning Russian palaces. This one offers several in fact as there are more to see (smaller obviously) in the grounds. Peterhof was destroyed by the Nazis in WWII after their 4 year occupation but, amazingly, has been restored to its original beauty. It's really something to see such opulence in its new condition when we are used to seeing the rather faded versions in the UK. Fortunately, most of the contents were evacuated before the occupation and are now returned to Peterhof or displayed at L'Hermitage in St Petersburg (an essential visit). A series of "wows!" will be heard and felt as you tour this amazing place.It was very quiet in late December and the room guides were unobjectionable.Fountains obviously not working in Russian winter but it is plain to see these would be stunning. We enjoyed walking through the grounds and by the sea.The palace is not so far from the city and I find it interesting to see a big of non city living after 6 days of visiting Moscow and St Petersburg. Handy for a last day visit as you can reach the airport without having to go through the gridlocked traffic in the city.The restaurant is good value and the food was good. Waiting staff friendly and efficient. Clean and comfortable surroundings, with an option to eat outside in warmer weather. Didn't try the loos but am confident these would have been fine too.

Would have been perfect if.... When we went in September, they were just dismantling a huge stage, seating and sound equipment on and around the Grand Cascade. It was just after the G-20 conference so there must have been some sort of a gathering at Peterhof for the G-20 attendees. Anyway, the large fountains were not working and there were many workers milling about removing large equipment. The most scenic way to reach Peterhoff is by sea using the hydrofoils from St. Petersburg however one can go by tour bus. It was not very crowded as it is a huge estate and parkland, many flowers, fountains, pathways to wander through and around. Peter the Great built this palace and his daughter Empress Elizabeth added on to it. Enjoy the "Joke" fountains where unsuspecting visitors will get wet! It is written that Peter the Great would take his guests to these fountains and would think it very funny to get them soaked, especially those he might have disagreed with. Sounds fun to me! I won't tell you where they are but you should discover this for yourself. One fountain that people waited for was a series of fountains along a path that people ran through. Ask around for the time this fountain turns on - children and adults had fun running through it.
Beautiful gardens and fountains!. Oh wow, this place was really beautiful. It reminded me of the palace at Versailles and I guess that is what Peter the Great modeled it after. DO NOT MISS!!

a bit disappointed. It is nice but if you only have few days in St Pet; better to skip it unless you have never seen such European Palace.if you've been to Versailles and such in Paris, maybe better you stay in town and check the museums.the way Russian handle entrances and visits too are not very enjoyable as you have ladies in each room being mean to you and tell you to move from room to room fast...

a full day of beauty. Big diversity on things to see all beautiful and well maintained. Lots of walking hard time understanding status of interior of church: gold paint? woman were not helpful answering questions there either in English or Russian.
See all the palaces. Another great palace to see.All the history is fantastic.Great to see each palace and compare the differences.

#2 Attraction in St Petersburg. This is a must see. The best way is to go on your own and take the fast boat from right near the Hermitage. You get dropped off at Peterhof and then can tour both the grounds and their many interesting fountains and pay the fee to tour the palace.This is an all day adventure if you take the boat. The grounds are worth at least a couple hours and the place tour takes an hour. Buy a set of the postcards to get the best views of the wonderful rooms.I almost did not go after seeing the Hermitage and Catherine's Palace. Peterhof is far better than Catherine's if you only have time to visit one and the boat ride there showed a bit of the countryside.

Go when the fountains are running, and spend some time here!. Peterhof is absolutely spectacular, and I'd put this on my list of must-see attractions for St. Petersburg. Note going there cheaply from the city involves the subway and small buses, so if you are not adventurous enough to figure them out see if you can arrange a group of travelers and ask your hotel to come up with a taxi. I also think if you go in the summer boat rides are available so check that too, although I believe they're expensive.I recommend spending at least four hours, if not an entire day, because it's not just that the fountains are amazing, but the grounds are gigantic. You can walk down to the bay and see Finland (hmm, or at least we thought it was Finland), not to mention a good bit more of various coastlines including a nuclear power plant, and then go to the left or right on bridal or formal paths and see more wonderful fountains and ponds and foiliage. My son says whenever he sees estates this opulent, his first question is why Russia didn't have a revolution earlier.We went on October 16 on a cold but sunny day, and we were blown away the fountains were still running--my son's Russian girlfriend says they usually shut down earlier. That turned out to be terrific timing because it was almost deserted, and it was charming to have the place to ourselves with lots of fall foliage still out.My son's girlfriend made one recommendation about Peterhof--don't go when the fountains are first turned on in spring--apparently the place is a total zoo. Unfortunately, she made another recommendation which we ignored because it was cold, and that was to absolutely not go to the restaurant in the park because it was an unbelievable ripoff. We looked at the menu outside and figured if we ordered a soup and coffee each it was pricey but not awful, so we dragged her in. When we got our bill, it was for $100. We were charged for pats of butter and lemon slices for tea, $15 for a small bottle of sparkling water because it "came from Italy" (hmm, couldn't find that brand on an internet search), and so forth, so we were just appalled. I decided to pay in cash because I really didn't want to give possible scam artists my credit card, and I counted the money twice and gave it to the waiter. He disappeared and came back about five minutes later and said I was short 500 rubles. I used to count money for a living so it's quite unlikely I was wrong, so I handed him even more money and resolved never to give cash to waiters without counting it out in front of them so I'd have witnesses.So bring a picnic. Other than that, Peterhof is just spectacular and more than worth the trip to get there.

Peterhoff and it's incredible history. Peterhoff was spectacular! The statues in gold which adorned the outside groundshad a history all their own, as we learned how the Nazi's came and over took Peterhoffand the destruction they later did to it. All that we saw now, was complete restorationof a beautiful palace. It was beautiful and the grounds were grandiose and serene! Don't miss this enchanting palace!

magnificent palace. its an absolute delight and moreso the countryside which you pass through while on journey to peterhof and the place called petergof.. the first sight of the palace and its amazing mountain leave you in awe and completely in love with the place.not to be missed

do they ever stop letting people in??. It is a lovely place, but we were there in the bucketing rain. No enjoyment seeing the fountains, all down to the Gulf of Riga. Not their fault.The museum guards are all ex-Lubjanka prison guards, methinks, judging by the sour expressions, and even the violent push to get more tourists into very small crowded rooms. No place in North America, or Western Europe, would have fire regulations that allowed for sardine packing.

Versailles of Russia. We had a day tour here. We werent able to enter the palace because of so many tourist, but we were able to go around the garden. The garden is so humongous and well built. Different areas have different motiff. It is clean and well maintained. Please wear comfortable shoes because you really need to walk a long distance for you to go around the garden. For me Versailles of France is better, but it is worth seeing this place

beautiful suburb of St-Petersburg. The most beautiful suburb of St-Petersburg with splendid palaces and parks with fountains but the best time to visit is from May till September only. You can reach it by excursion bus or by municipal bus from metro stations AVTOVO or LENINSKIY PROSPECT.

Chandeliers and love!. We enjoyed seeing a home that was filled with the love of family. The lay out was different from the other palaces. I loved the huge library. The displays of every day life and the artifacts that went with that helped you feel like you lived with the family

Amazing museum. Amazing museum, but too crowded. Get there early to try to avoid the crowd (althought I don't think it is possible). Even so, it worths the trip. The museum architecture is amazing and the art collection is great!

Amazing fountains, beautiful palace. Beautiful garden, with an amazing fountain in fronto of the palace. Very easy to visit without a tour guide, but bring the exact money for the ticket if you don't speak russian. We had a little difficult to buy the tickets and after talking with 4 different people I found out that the problem was that they did not have change (which I could live without it). Worh the trip.

Breathtaking in scope and beauty. We visited The Hermitage in September while in St. Petersburg on a cruise. Instead of taking a cruise-line sponsored tour, we booked a private tour through Essential Europe, using Alex's Tours & Travel in St. Petersburg, and our guide, Christine, whose knowledge of all things St. Petersburg and of the Hermitage in particular made the time most enjoyable and productive. The Hermitage has so much to see, in such a compressed time, that having a knowledgable guide made the best use of the limited time. Treasures galore; one could spends days and weeks and not see and appreciate all that is on display. Well worth the time and effort to brave the crowds.

Possibly the best place in the world to eat an icecream... What can one say about Peterhof that has not already been conveyed with an abundance of superlatives, probably not a great deal. I will add that it is possibly the best place to eat an ice-cream on a sunny summer’s day.The grounds are what you would expect to see from possibly the greatest Russian Tsar and an obvious landscaping genius. I travelled there with a couple of new found friends firstly via Metro, train and foot, then just for the experience via Hydroplane. Unfortunately it rained while I was on the hydroplane, but that is another story. The Hydroplane made it super easy to get to and did not cost the earth, but was much more expensive than going via suburban train.It was easy to get to and easy to get around, even for a novice visitor with a sore foot.The palace is stunning, breathtaking and even the mandatory surly babushkas seemed somewhat happy in there. The grounds are a marvel and are simply wonderful in the full splendour of summer. I would love to visit in the autumn just to see how they are during that time of year, maybe also in winter, possibly spring too. Take a day, or two to experience this and the surrounds, there are a number of nice palaces nearby and a beautiful old wooden church. Peterhof is well priced and even the food was not bad considering the environment and captive market.Children will love the park and especially the trick fountain. Everyone else will just love the magnificence of it. Bring a good camera and take pictures early, then just relax.To eat an ice-cream there should be on everyone’s bucket list.

Best place to spend a summer day. We had wonderful weather and a wonderful guide to see this beautiful and fun garden. Masha of SPB tours was our guide. The size and grandeur put it ahead of Catherine's Palace, if you have to choose.
Peterhof. The Castle are large and beautiful, but the fountain outside on a downhill are just spectaculore . Golden figures, water and flowers, fantastic.
Impressive. Beautiful Palace, full a golden statues and elegant fountains.Walking around the grounds is a great way to spend time here.

Simply the best. This is unique experience while visiting St. Petersburg. Its worth it to buy the tickets thru hotel concierge. You pay more but you avoid the lines which are really long and you save time and energy not having to stay in those especially if you visiting first thursday of the month when the entry is free.

Gold, gold and more gold. If you like gold this is the place for you! Lots of fountains - with gold and very like Versailles in many ways - but the inside was absolutely covered in gold - and lots outside too.

Would have been 5 but for crowded palace. This place is phenomenal , the inside is literally covered in gold in most rooms, lots of portraits of the family and really nice to see all the different rooms and features. The only let down is how many people they allow in at one go, we were left in some rooms for far too long twiddling our thumbs whilst the group in front were mucking about, no photos allowed inside but we all tried and got some sneaky ones. The staff aren't helpful and seem to view us as a nuisance.The gardens and fountains are absolutely magnificent, glorious and probably more worth seeing then the palace, lots of room outside to slowly enjoy what you are seeing and lots of photo opportunities, be aware of pick pockets who usually try and distract you with a card trick , well worth visiting though all in all
Glitz, Glitter....and Wonderful Art!. You have to see this place to believe it. It's hard to believe that it was almost totally destroyed in WW II. They've brought it back to life. Don't miss it!

Marvellous.. Spent a couple of days in St Petersburg whilst on a cruise on the good old Marco Polo, decided on an excursion to Peterhof for one of the days. What a good choice it was. On getting on the bus we were met by our tour guide the delectable Natalia, who throughout the entire trip provided us with an interesting and factual commentary. The Palace itself was superb, the rooms so richly decorated and full if interesting items, the only problem was the it is a VERY place and you tend to shuffle from room to room, sometimes not really having time to admire what you are looking at.This movement is enforced by aggressive looking female room stewards, who would get onto Natalia if we lingered too long in any one place, But it is a marvellous Palace, well worth a visit. The gardens are just as fascinating, the fountains are brilliant, especially the Grand Cascade. The flower beds are also stunning. The only problem on our visit, was that the G20 summit was being held the following week at the Palace, so there were scaffolding towers for lights and cameras all over the place and a huge media centre at the top of the sea canal, so trying to take a photo without these in was a problem. Miss it at your peril.

A very fine palace with outstanding gardens. Lavished in gold and splended architecture this is atruly spectacular palace with wonderful gardens and probably one of the world's finest fountain displays.

Worth the drive. Alot of it was destroyed in WWII and it's constantly being restored so as a result shoes are covered before entering, medium to large bags have to be put in storage and you get ushered through the rooms by angry middle-aged Russian women.The majority of the rooms are fairly interesting with some nice preserved artefacts, others are hit and miss.My only annoyance inside was being forced through the gift shop at the end of the tour.Outside, the gardens were nice, nothing spectacular even with the fountain display.We took a hydrofoil back which was a lot of fun, not sure on the price as we were on a tour.

Visit the city of fountains!. Be prepared to spend a day in this gorgeous park, especially if you go on a nice hot sunny day in the summer. Peter the Great loved to entertain his guests, so he built not just a beautiful summer palace, but also a park with hundreds of fountains - from huge golden Samson to small funny fountains that WILL MAKE YOU WET! Play with the fountains, stroll along the alleys, visit the palace - there is a lot to do! The best way to get to Peterhof is to jump on a speed boat near the Hermitage, ABOUT 15-20 min ride.

Really cool. We arrived peterhof by hydrofoil which was really cool. Apparently the time to arrve is when they turn on the fountains, we missed that part but i was still incredible. The whole fountain production has no pumps, it uses gravity and a valve that opens ans closes each day to turn the water on and off. We didnt go inside but the walk around the gardens and up the stairs was worth it! A must see is st petersberg!

Wonderful gardens and very nice palace. The most important thing to see here I think are the gardens, very huge and rich of attractions, you can loose yourself in these beutiful gardens with a lot of nice fountains(unfortunately in winter time the water is off and someone has the statues already in boxes for preserving them from cold and rain...) and other small palaces; there's also a nice view of the sea.The most impressive fountain is the one very big with the golden statues that you can see in front of the palace, fantastic!!! Inside the palace is very nice and regal but similar to the other ones(inside I think is better Katherine's one), the two rooms more different and very nice I think are the Chinese and the Japanese ones.It's a bit far from the center but you must spend a full day for visiting the palace and all that is around it ;)

Beautiful even without the fountains. We visited St Petersburg out if season by a couple of weeks so the fountains were not on. But the house is still stunning. We got there via metro then local bus which was really efficient and cheap too.The house is stunning absolutely beautiful. We enjoyed taking in the grounds of the house the waterfalls (which weren't on but you could see them). I would love to visit again in the summer but if your in St Petersburg in the autumn or winter it's defiantly worth it!!!

Stunning! . No question about it, it's a must visit destination in Saint Petersburg, loved every aspect ,loved the dream it took me through, thinking about past and those days where everything was just as pure as it should be!

Great in any season!. We were lucky when we visited Peterhof, just outside St Petersburg, the fountains had been extended for a couple of weeks. We thought we were to miss out, but no. An outstanding place to visit with fountains of every type, shape etc. we were shown many trick fountains as well. Standing on the Gulf of Finland for this Aussie was a great feeling, so far, so different. Highly recommend visiting when all the water features are operating. Having a guide just made the visit that much sweeter.

Tremendous!. We traveled to Peterhof by hydrofoil. Walking from the small pier through the park and along the canal, you can see in the distance the multiple fountains with the palace as a backcloth. Absolutely spectacular! For me, this was one of my favourite sights in St Petersburg.When we visited - late August - the weather was sunny and warm and the gardens and park were in full bloom. It is well worth walking through the park and discovering the many different fountains...the Sun, Mushroom, Roman, Pyramid, Eve, to name but a few. Each has its own attraction.As to be expected, there were very many fellow tourists but there was more than sufficient space for most people to feel comfortable.The Palace is a very large structure with many, many rooms. The decoration in each is eye watering and there is so much to see and admire. You can spend a whole day simply exploring the interior and, as with the park, I felt there was sufficient room for everyone, though it was very busy.This is a destination you must visit.
Water, water everywhere. Get place to take a two hour stroll on a beautiful day. Fascinating display of wealth and whim. Hidden trick water fountains make this a fun place for the whole family.

Now this is a PALACE!. Eight of us hired a car and driver for the day at a reasonable price though Bookit.com. First stop was Peterhof. It is a bit of a drive from St. Petersburg. We hired an English speaking guide and it was worth every penny. We learned so much about what we saw. The palace is more than beautiful. It is opulence in every way. Gold baroque style is everywhere. Paintings and furnishings.and silk wall covering plus the history will be overwhelming. We were there in October and the fountains were turned off but the outside garden areas were still lovely and full of statues. Try to visit when the water is running. Amazing thing to see.

Felt ripped off. Going in october so locer park is free but there are no fountains on and u get the bus as the hydrofoil isn't oneThe palce is 500 rubles and u can't take phots you also can't buy indervidual postcard there is an adio guide but that is 500 rubles on top of admissiob. The palces is short impresive but the atmostphre is bad lots of bery grupmy russuan laides tutting on the whole ok But the palce is a bit of a rip off and feels it

Built to rival Versailles. Another amazing St Petersburg palace. Really interesting place - it looks massive from the outside but in fact the interior rooms are quite small - a nod towards the climate here I think and how difficult it would have been to heat big rooms. Every room is beautifully decorated and maintained as it would have been originally, each room has a fascinating story and history. We all remarked on the short bed in the male bedroom - they used to sleep sitting up for their blood pressure so never lay down flat! The grounds are absolutely stunning - you can walk right down to the shore of the Gulf of Finland. At the end of October we had some snow on our visit and it was bitingly cold already, so I can only imagine what the depths of winter are like here! The fountains were all still in action and on a day with clear blue skies the gardens looked beautiful. I would like to revisit in the height of summer!

Spectacular Fountains. We were looking forward to Peterhof Palace as one of the two main places we wanted to see in St. Petersburg, unfortunately it was the only day on the 18 day trip that it rained, and it rained hard while we were there. I have never been anywhere that was more crowded, you literally could not turn around and the restrooms were totally inadequate for the amount of people they had there. It was a good 20 minute wait. You have a coat check and another purse check and eventually you get to where they give you little booties to wear so you do not scratch the floor with your shoes. The inside was beautiful and the rooms were exqusite. The staff in the rooms were not helpful and in some cases quite rude but the palace itself was beautiful. It is hard to believe that when the Nazi’s left it they blew it up and it had to be totally restored. I was really upset that they did not let you take pictures of anything inside the palace. The Highlight of the visit of course is the Stair Stepped Fountains. The Gold statue of Sampson in the middle is magnificent and the hundreds of sculptures and fountains are breathtaking. When we came out of the palace it had stopped raining and it was great. The Fountains start exactly at 11:00 and the first five minutes they play very exhilarating and patriotic sounding music that is tremendous. I wish we could have stayed longer. DO NOT miss the fountains if you go to Peterhof they are un-believable and something you just have to see if you possibly can in your lifetime. Pictures do not do it justice, you have to be there and experience the music and the water and the spray of the fountains.

Spectacular Fountains. We were looking forward to Peterhof Palace as one of the two main places we wanted to see in St. Petersburg, unfortunately it was the only day on the 18 day trip that it rained, and it rained hard while we were there. I have never been anywhere that was more crowded, you literally could not turn around and the restrooms were totally inadequate for the amount of people they had there. It was a good 20 minute wait. You have a coat check and another purse check and eventually you get to where they give you little booties to wear so you do not scratch the floor with your shoes. The inside was beautiful and the rooms were exqusite. The staff in the rooms were not helpful and in some cases quite rude but the palace itself was beautiful. It is hard to believe that when the Nazi’s left it they blew it up and it had to be totally restored. I was really upset that they did not let you take pictures of anything inside the palace. The Highlight of the visit of course is the Stair Stepped Fountains. The Gold statue of Sampson in the middle is magnificent and the hundreds of sculptures and fountains are breathtaking. When we came out of the palace it had stopped raining and it was great. The Fountains start exactly at 11:00 and the first five minutes they play very exhilarating and patriotic sounding music that is tremendous. I wish we could have stayed longer. DO NOT miss the fountains if you go to Peterhof they are un-believable and something you just have to see if you possibly can in your lifetime. Pictures do not do it justice, you have to be there and experience the music and the water and the spray of the fountains.

Awesome place. We came from above and saw the gardens on both sides because it was Sunday and he bus could drop us without causing a major traffic problem. The fountains are awesome. The interior of the palace is also beautiful, but I really do not want to live in such a place. Nice to look and leave. We had to wait a long time for our turn to walk through the palace. Beware - there are steps inside the palace and lots of steps outside in the garden. Also, you need to walk from and to the bus. But really worth the visit.
The Hermitage. Worth a look but crowds were horrendous and a bit rushed as part of a tour. needs time to enjoy. Will visit again

Peterhof Garden and Palace. What a lovely place to visit. We went twice in 3 days as we could not do it justice in one visit. The first visit was by hydrofoild from the river bank and was in its self enjoyable, the second as part of our tour on our visit to St Petersburg prior to cruising to Moscow.

Almost Heaven on Earth. We took an optional tour to the Peterhof garden and Pushkin Palace from our river cruise [from St. Petersburg to Moscow] in Russia . If we did not opt for this tour we would have missed the highlight of our tour. It was a gorgeous day to start with. Sunny and balmy. Beautiful blooming flowers everywhere. Bigger than life size gilded cherubs and nymphs spewing fountain water and mists. Arranged on the side of a hill . Beautifully laid stairways and gardens and more fountains . Peter the Great had a wicked sense of humor in some of the designs of fountains. One was to dunk his guests from hidden fountains spray nozzles. One was again to dunk his guests when they wanted to go to a central umbrella covered island.  I can not explain. It is something to behold and experience . Words can not express the joy of being there. Even photographs and videos can not do justice unless a professional does them well.The garden is big . It stretches up to the Neva river near the Gulf of Finland. In a clear day one can see St. Petersburg from the edge of the garden.It is an ideal place for couples to frolick.

Amazing gardens and Palace!. The Palace: impressive outside and worth discovering the inside with different rooms of different design, picture taking is strictly forbidden, you should record in your brain. The rooms are so magnificent that you won't struggle at this.The gardens: Very big, like a "nature-walk" for the visitor, clean and healthy, very impressive statues and architecture, definitely see the seaside too. Both of those are definitely a "not-to-miss"... and even if you're there for a few days only, definitely spare half a day for this place.The Access: Two ways there: Either you take a ridiculously expensive guided tour from city center (like around 2500-3000 rub per head) but you don't struggle for the transportation, Either you choose the adventurous way we did; and do the following:From anywhere downtown, grab the metro and go to the station Avtovo on the red line, and from there, take the minibuses on which is written "Fountain" and "Petergof" in Russian. Pretty easy!Cost of the travel? 28rub for the metro and 70rub for the minibus, making it approx. 200rub return. Don't even bother taking the outrageous hydrofoil from Hermitage (1100 rub return)

Celebration of Water, with more than a bit of gold thrown in!. Peter's version of Versailles is certainly a monumental place, and the restorations have been carried out to a very high standard, considering the level of destruction there was.We visited the parks only, as we had seen more than our fill of palaces already!The view from the Upper Terrace down towards the Gulf of Finland is amazing, complete with the fountains and their gold statues.The little gold boat used to ferry guests from one end to the other is on show at the far end. The Parks were very busy with both tourists and locals, and many families seemed to be enjoying a day strolling and playong around the Trick Fountains in particular.Some of these involve you getting lighly sprayed with water as you walk past a certain point in the grounds, others have kids trying to run past a folly without getting wet etc.Great sense of humour shown by Peter! Loved the chessboard fountain and the group playing percussion instruments at the base of it.My favourite part was getting to the far side and seeing Mon Plaisir on the edge of the Gulf of Finland.This was Peter's real "home" here, and is a much more modest building, but with views truly to die for, all the way out into the Gulf.Worth going here just to see this! A lovely day out, and a pleasant break from visiting all the artworks etc in palaces!

Another stunning and gorgeous palace. Peterhof is some distance from downtown St. Petersburg, and requires transportation like a tour bus or hydrofoil or a tour guide and driver. It's a beautiful palace, and the terraced grounds, fountains, and gardens are even better. This is another "don't miss". Allow the better part of a day, since the tour itself is an hour or more and the transportation is another hour in each direction. There are local restaurants in the vicinity that are very good and very "local Russian".

Stunning. The building, statues and fountains are superb - glittering with gold! The fountains do not operate from October to Spring and are an important element of the experience. The palace is beautiful - though it doesn't take long to get around.

Take the hydrofoil. Peterhof is some distance from St. Petersburg and the quickest way and most interesting way to get their is on one of the many hydrofoils - it takes about 30 minutes - and you get a partial tour of the canals and Neva river. We spent about 4 hours and spent all our time touring the gardens which are magnificent. Beware that all additional sites at Peterhof both in the gardens and the Palace tours cost extra.
beautiful!. We enjoyed this much more than Catherine's palace. If you have to make a choice, we recommend Peterhof.

better than Versailles. it is worth spending there an entire day or even more. The gardens, the fountains, the interior left an impression of splendor and grandeur impossible to forget. Absolutely breathe-taking and very well maintained

Fountains everywhere. We took subway and bus to go to the palace. The location is far away from city centre but still convenient. I think it takes about an hour to get there from city centre.The palace and the fountains are very nice to see. However, you have to buy tickets for the different museum separately - and there are 31 museums there.

All that glitters is not gold (nor old). Terribly destroyed during the war, the palace has been rehabilitated to its former golden glory; all is very new though and is a testament to the restorers' skill. Best to read (or be briefed by a travel guide) on Peter the Great and on Catherine the Great first before visiting - and how they lived their magnificent lives and loves in the palace and gardens - and then let your imagination run riot against the glittering rooms, the fine landscape and the marvellous fountains - and the great bay of water that beckons and serves as the route to the lands of Europe that so inspired Peter and from which Catherine sprang!

Show of Wealth!. We went to see this palace by the hydrofoil (no traffic jams!) that takes you right to the lower parks. As soon as you buy your tickets, you see the first view of the great palace and the cascading fountains. Superb view. The palace from inside is stunning to say the least especially the staircase and the ballroom. I did not understand why photography was not allowed inside. They have allowed it in Hermitage and Catherine Palace (except the amber room). The upper gardens entry is free but we could not see them as getting back to the lower gardens was not allowed. Best way to reach there and return is by the hydrofoil. Must visit.
Beautiful gardens. We visited the gardens and the waterfalls and the outside of the building were beautiful. There was certainly a lot to see. Would have liked to spend longer here.

Fabulous!. This Palace and it's gardens are just unbelievable. I mean ,really, gold statues in the fountains that just are dazzling in the sunlight. Vast gardens that slope gracefully down to the water's edge so that Peter's guests could be transported to this summer Palace from St. Petersburg by boat. And the Palace itself, so vast and ornate, and filled with treasures. Absolutely put this on your "must see" list when visiting St. Petersburg! You will be amazed!

Magnificent Grand Cascade, Fountains and Golden Sculptures. The Peterhof Palace (Russian: Петерго́ф) is an amazing place to see and is also known as the Summer Palace. It was founded by Peter the Great in 1714. The Palace is 19 miles from St. Petersburg. We arrived around 9:30 am at the south gate of Peterhof Palace’s Upper Park. Although the Peterhof Grand Palace opened at 10:30 am, our guide pushed us to go fast when we were in the Upper Park in order to avoid the long queue at the entrance. The Upper Park is a quiet retreat and beautiful garden unlike the shining uniqueness of the Lower Park that attracts all tourists. It is a large garden with fountains, sculptures, pools and trees. We really enjoyed the morning walk through the Upper Park before we met the crowd at the gate to the Grand Palace and Great Cascade with the famous fountains.We were the first group at the Peterhof Grand Palace entrance. The Grand Palace contains 30 rooms and not as delicate compared to other palaces such as the Hermitage and the Catherine Palace. The Chesma Hall, Picture Hall and Chinese Cabinets are the highlights of the visit. What bothered us the most was that the ladies on duty always pushed us moved on. It was really annoying, and I never had such bad experience before. One more thing that I didn’t like was that photos and videos are prohibited inside the Grand Palace. I would like to give it 5 for the rating, but for the reasons above I can only give it 4. After the Grand Palace, we went outside and looked down on the Lower Park where we saw the magnificent Grand Cascade fountain group and many golden sculptures. It is a pity that we did not have enough time to walk through the garden down to the Gulf of Finland, but we could see it from the terrace. We were lucky it was a sunny day during our visit and gave all the golden decorations the chance to show its best to us. There are so many steps on both side of staircase; you are better off having comfortable shoes to enjoy those golden statues, ornaments on the fountains, and the rest of the attractions on the Lower Park.

Add a few extra days to see what this city has to offer.. Simply amazing. The size, the colors and the history make this so special. We went in june with a formal tour group. Two reasons this is important (one may not apply to you, the reader). I dont speak Russian. So having a translator was make or break for us. Secondly, the crowds and lines were insane! And our tour guide got us in and through without having to wait, yet able to give us a very informative tour.

Peterhof. A must-see if you are in St Petersburg. Just 30 minutes by hydrofoil to this palace of Peter the Great on the Gulf of Finland. Well maintained grounds, fountains, and palace. This was one of the best attractions I saw while in St Petersburg.

Glorious and completely over the top.. Words are inadequate to describe the magnificent spectacle of the fountains at the Peterhof. We visited on a sparkling summer day and were dazzled by the major golden fountains in front of the Palace. The Palace itself should be seen to see how life was lived at the summer cottage! However leave time for exploring the gardens and the many smaller and ingenious fountains and water features. As well as the larger spinning balls and fan shapes there are some secret fountains for the amusement of visitors including some activated by secret stepping stones.

Tsarist splendor at its best. This enormous palace was viewed on a warm sunny summer day. There are big crowds, but most people seem to be in a cheerful holiday mood and enjoying themselves. Truly beautiful structure with a lot of elegant detail on the buildings, and a lot of gold. Parking can be a bit of a problem with the crowds. Multiple lavishly decorated and furnished rooms and displays. There is so much gold, detail, wealth, beautify and history on display there, truly awesome in size, amount and variety. The palace grounds are almost as spectacular as the palace itself. Take time to look at all the paths, plant life, views, fountains, and small buildings on the grounds, as well as lovely views of the Gulf of Finland. There are some "trick" fountains which catch people by surprise - a very refreshing shower on a hot summer day, taken with shrieks and good humor by those in range of the sprays! The entire complex was truly an engineering marvel by Peter the Great, especially for its time in history. As with any crowded venue in St. Petersburg, be aware that there are pickpockets and large compacted crowds. There are places to eat on the grounds, and the very light snack I had was OK but not great typical Russian "pie" of a baked crust with potato and mushroom filling. Wear good walking shoes and plan to walk a lot - this is a huge property. Amazing that one royal family could accumulate wealth and goods to this degree, and that so much of it has survived and/or been restored. Well worth the time to visit.
Russia"s Versailles. Beautiful! Must see! The guide showed us the best place to take pictures! Really nice! Just pay attention to pick pockets!

Did anyone say fountains?. A visit to Peterhof starts with the specatcular canal that leads from the Gulf of Finland to the palace. The gardens/woods are beautiful but you are drawn to the massive display of fountains, all gravity fed. Beyond the fountains the gardens extend in all directions, be sure to see Mon Plasir near the gulf.

A wonderful day out. When your brain is in meltdown from the stunning splendours of the Hermitage take a day out and visit Peterhof. I suggest taking the metro and local bus there; the bus will drop you right outside the Upper Park, and take the hydrofoil back to St Petersburg. Just remember the Palace is closed on Mondays, but the Lower Park and fountains are still open. And the fountains are the main attraction, all in working order and set in beautifully maintained gardens. A very relaxing way to spend the day.
Stunning Peterhof. Stunning and beautiful. Time visit for when fountains turn on in morning. Allow time to stroll and enjoy beauty of grounds

Magnificent gardens!. My favorite stop in St. Petersburg! The palace is gorgeous, but the real attraction for me was the magnificent gardens and fountains. It should not be missed when visiting St. Petersburg!

Competition for Versailles. The gardens and fountains of Peterhof simply defy description. The fountains rival those of Versailles and unlike Versailles, these fountains, which have water reaching 50 feet into the air, do not have pumps nor is the water recycled. The expanse and the beauty need to be seen.

Peterhof. This was my favorite place to visit in St. Petersburg. Too bad there was no admittance into the Palace. Access was only in the gardens, which were well manicured. It was overwhelming to see how life was at that time. Very opulent!

Stunning Grounds. We took the hydroboat to Peterhoff and it was a great route to take. The garden grounds are stunning and they transport you back to an era of elegance. The palace is fasinating also however you do begin to overdose on over the top opulance. I highly recommend this.

The garden is unmatched anywhere!. We have been to a lot of palaces and gardens, but this one still blew us away. The scope, the array of different features, including water features, fountains, sculptures, and the overall design, color, and symmetry are unbelievable. There are even quite a few practical jokes built in (who know that Peter was such a joker?) We had a guided tour and were happy we did, but this is one site in St. Petersburg that you could enjoy even without a guide.

Peterhof Palace and Garden. The grounds especially are beautiful. Because we saw so many different museums and palaces in St. Petersburg, at this point it is difficult to remember the paintings and rooms, except for the extensive grounds.

More fountains than you can imagine!. We heard that Peter the Great was inspired by Versailles when he planned Peterhof. The fountains are spectacular. In addition to touring the palace and Peter's home, make sure you leave plenty of time to tour around the gardens to see many more fountains beyond the fabulous fountains around the palace. There are other buildings around the property that are of interest, too. Taking the hydrofoils to get there is a speedy way to get to Peterhof.

Get there early. The tour busses will disgorge vast throngs of people. Get there before they do. You have to check coats, bags etc. and it's a single LONG line if you get there with or after the busses. The place is the Czars' entry in the competition for conspicuous consumption.... you have to go the Versailles (Paris) or Sans Souci (Potsdam outside Berlin) to decide for yourself who was most over the top. The grounds and gardens are quite enjoyable themselves and an excellent antidote for the stress of being herded through a palace of gilt. The grounds provide great views of the outside of the palace. Most of the interior is restoration since the place suffered mightily in WWII.

Beautiful, inside and out!. Many tours only offer the gardens, which are indeed fabulous, but the inside should not be missed! I had a private guide for this, so I cannot quote prices. The interior of the palace was amazing.... The fountains are amazing. Basically, it is an amazing place. We had a light lunch at the cafe in the gardens, which was tasty. They offered soups, fish, meats, veggies...a very decent variety.You should not just settle for the garden tour here.

Holy Moly. The statues, fountains, and art work are beyond imagination. Make sure that you have a lot of storage on your ScanDisk because you will need it. I would recommend a guide, because of the many interesting features at Peteroff.
Magnificent!. The fountains, the grandeur. Also that Peter the Great can be quite a jokester, with his trick fountains!

Best seen with a small group. We traveled to Peterhof with a small group (13) with a guide and trip leader and had access to the grounds via a small entrance off to the side. This allowed us to wander through much of the garden with few other visitors. Of course as you approach 11 am (when the fountains are turned on), the crowds grow and the jostling for prime photo spots start. We were there in early September and the weather was perfect and the gardens in full bloom.

Incredible. The Peterhof was the busiest building we visited as it was in the morning and was timed to see the fountains show at 11am. So may people but well worth the squeeze. The fountains in all their glorious gold looked stunning. The building is beautiful with sumptuous rooms to visit. The gardens are laid out in a delightful way with plenty to see.

Peterhof Palace and Garden. What a wonderful place to visit. This was number one on my list and did not disappoint me. So much to see inside and such a large variety of fountains and gardens. So well maintained.

Golden Leaves and Statues. On a fine autumn day when the leaves on the trees in the gardens below the palace have turned a golden yellow, the freshly gilded fountains and statues don't look out of the place. Of course the baroque palace and grounds are wonderfully over the top and the whole place has been restored to the nth degree but when you first see the cascade leading up to the palace and first climb the staircase within the Palace your breath is just taken away. The only word to describe the experience is 'wow'! One of the most beautiful places I have even been to.

Gorgeous. This is a must if in St. Pete. The fountains are gorgeous and worth the trip. I personally love the little house on the lake/pond where Peter the Great spent personal time, which is just off the Gulf of Finland. The gardens are also very serene and peaceful. If you go, plan to spend a great amount of time and don't expect this to be one to rush through. Do something most Americans don't know how to do, slow down and relax, take it all in. The cathedral and palace are beautiful and a very good picture of Russian royalty.

Beautiful palace and gardens. If you only have time to see one palace in St Petersburg area, you have to choose this one! The exterior of the palace may not look as grand as Catherine Palace but the interiors are way better than Catherine Palace, and the gardens and fountains are really awesome! Be sure to visit during the summer and early autumn so that the fountains are all in operation.

Don't waste your time and money at Peterhof!. It's crowded, tacky, and not worth the money. I don't know how anyone can compare this to Versailles. It's such a cheesy, tasteless display of Russian wealth. The statues and fountains are crowded with people all trying to get the same picture. Most of the statues are only interesting because they are gilded and not particularly because of anything artistic. If you do decide to go, make sure to eat before you get there because the food at Peterhof is disgusting.

Peterhof palace and garden. Firstly I would recommend travelling to Peterhof on the hydrofoil, not because it is cheaper and/or quicker but because it offers a different perspective of the city and its waterways. It also offers a relaxing waterborne journey.On arriving at the jetty there is a ticket office for the gardens - make sure you keep your ticket, you will need it to get back to the hydrofoil jetty for your return journey! We did not intend going into the palace so we only bought tickets for the gardens.The lower gardens are very extensive and really only leave time for the less extensive upper gardens. Both gardens have a plethora of fountains. For the lower gardens it is sensible to have the a somewhat systematic approach because their sheer size means you could spend a lot of time retracing your steps in an effort to see everything. We were delighted with the musical groups which are found playing at different points around the gardens. At the end of the path from the jetty we found a small group playing xylophones and at the Roman cascades a large group playing wind instruments resembling flugelhorns.The upper gardens are more formal (rather like those at French chateaux) and , of course, more fountains. There are superb views of the palace which complement those from the lower garden from which you see the front at the top of the slope on which it stands. On leaving the upper garden to re-enter the lower garden (to return to the hydrofoil) you will need your ticket!Our systematic approach led us to explore the eastern side of the lower garden, then the upper garden and to visit the western side of the lower garden on our way back to the jetty to take the hydrofoil. It was on this side of the garden that we found the Marly Palace - more a luxurious garden lodge than a palace. There is an entry fee payable at a smaller lodge 50 metres from the palace - it is well worth seeing. It has a large rectangular pond in front of it and a smaller one to its northern side - here we saw someone fishing and were lucky enough to see him land a sturgeon! From the Marly Palace we walked along the shore to return to the jetty.This was a great day out and quite a full day without going into the Peterhof Palace itself.

Peterhof with Alla Tours. We pre-booked a two day tour of the city with Alla Tours following a recommendation from an acquaintance. St Petersburg was one of the cruise destinations of a Baltic cruise aboard the Carnival Legend and was greatly anticipated by our tour party.We didn't know what to expect but reality exceeded any we did have. The tour itinerary included a hydrofoil trip to the palace which is located some distance from the city centre.Once you arrive at the palace the statues in the grounds alone are worth the trip, together with the fountains forming a visual treat.

Peterhof: A must see place in St Petersburg Russia. Peterhof Palace and Garden just a wonderful place to visit when you are in St Petersburg. Beautiful architecture, open space with a blend of history. Eye catching design with mind cooling open space. I just loved it there.

Go Early. Went here by hydrofoil and wished we had arrived earlier as the last boat back left at about 4 and we did not have enough time to see it all - the fountains are spectacular but time spent in the palace might better be spent in the Monsplaisir and lion cascade or Marly palace. But a MUST SEE!

A trip full of memories and beauty to return home with.. Went by boat, pretty easy to find get tickets across from Hermitage. Trip going was very pretty traveling by boat, just part of the experience. Once there beauty awaits.If you love outside you're in luck.After museums and indoor festivities it was lovely. I was able to wander gardens and fountains but walk the halls of golden guilded rooms.

like a colourful Versaille. A trip by hyrdofoil makes it easy to get there. The fountains are lovely, and unlike Versaille they run on a more regular schedule, all fed by gravity. This is one of the must sees in St Petersburg.

A Dream Palace. It has been my dream whenever I hear people telling me Winter palace. It is like you are in a fairytale land!I arrived in early morning. The feeling was grand huge and beautiful. Standing in the middle of the square makes ones feel important!

Absolute Place to Visit!. There is several boat trips to the Island and takes about less than an hour ride. But the tour time takes you almost 4 hours! Its huge, beautiful and made you wish you could stayed a night ( which is impossible)Quiet, serence surrounding and a dreammy place.Try not to use the public toilet, it is really unbearable! Entrance fee to the palace is inexpensive.

A Highlight of St. Petresburg. Although located approx 45 min driving time from St. Petersburg (faster if one takes the hydrofoil shuttles from St. Petersburg harbour direct to Peterhof which run about every 30 min and cost about 1200RUR (US$35) per person for a round trip ticket), no visit to St. Petersburg can be considered complete without a stop at the Peterhof. A truly magnificent place modeled after the gardens of Versailles, complete with statues, fountains and the occassional water shower that catches unsuspecting visitors who step on a hidden pressure plate. As the beauty of Peterhof is in the elaborate outdoor gardens, which can be seen and apreciated only by walking through them, weather is a key factor in timing a visit.

wonderful. A truly wonderful palace and grounds especially as it was a ruin after WW2.The fountains were tremendous too.Disliked the cost of having to pay 3 times to see the Peterhof and its upper and lower gardens.
Spectacular grounds and fountains. These gardens and buildings are beautiful, and all the fountains work on gravity. The trip to Peterhof is highly recommended. Give yourself at least two hours.
Must See ..... The most spectacular place to see.... Do not miss this as the gardens exquisite and the water features are incredible.

An Outstanding Creation of Water Display.... Peter The Great built this complex of palaces, fountains and sculptures after visiting similar sights in Europe. The fountains themselves are a wonder to behold. Called The Great Cascade, the display of 75 water jets and step streams are magnificent. Be sure to walk down towards the sea to see Monplaisir, Peter's get-away petit palace. Near the small garden in the back is a bench sitting near a bed of large stepping stones. One large corner stone was installed that secretly turned on the water jets under the stones. Peter liked to play a joke on his guests and have them sit on the bench and he would then step on the stone, giving his guests a good soaking.

Simply stunning architecture. The beauty of Russia is often in its architecture and this palace does not fail to disappoint. The garden beginning leads to the wonderful palace that needs to be seen to be admired. Reasonably priced and not to overcrowded to enjoy the ambience of the place. Worth an afternoon visit.

Fountains galore!. The inside of the palace was like others with mirrors, gilded wood, etc. The fountains were quite spectacular. Many gilded statues and water everywhere! You can catch a hydrofoil boat back to the city (winter palace) which adds to the experience.

Magnificient Cascading Artifical Waterfalls. Garden of Peterhof Palace is one the place of other two place worth to see in St. Petersburg. The most handicap of the site is the statues placed in the pools and water cascades are facing north. So it's very hard to take pictures of them because sun beams are hitting lenses of your camera and creates shadows on the facade of the statues. But well-maintained pools & golden color glittered statues with beautiful water cascades are breath taking experience. Boats running on hydrofoil departing from St. Petersburg are recommended to reach the site. The price is around $20 for each ride. Visit for gardens only is about $15. For the palace additional fee is required.

Make a day of it.. There is so much to see here that you should really allow ONE DAY so that you can not only enjoy the fountains but also the Grand Palace and the smaller buildings spread throughout the gardens. Go when sunny and take the hydrofoil as it allows a fantastic view upon arrival in the lower gardens. Besides, that is how Peter and co arrived - from the Baltic - and it is designed for arrival from that perspective.No guide necessary to get here and besides why would you want to be rushed.

Spectacular water show. We visited the Peterhof gardens which are quite spectacular and no visit to St Petersburg would be complete without a visit. Words can hardly express the magnificence of the gardens surrounding this beautiful palace. We spent so much time exploring the grounds that we did not have time to see the inside of the palace. There are over 100 fountains which are all different in design and are outstanding works of art. Watching the water cascading was breathtaking and the views and location will provide a memorable visit.

Beautiful palace with incredible garden. After a short journey lasting 4o minutes or so we got to this incredible garden. There was large queue for the house so we decided to spend more time in the garden with wonderful array of musical fountains. Fountains also come on every hour from 11 until 2 when advice of a guide can keep you dry as these fountains suddenly come on covering many of the streets.After seeing so many beautiful buildings (Palaces, Museums) it was a lovely way to spend warm afternoon. The walk through the park was really pleasant and informative.

great place to visit in summer. Take the boat to get here, it is the most comfortable and fast way. Thus, you will be able to enter the park the way the tsars did. Enjoy the fountains and alleys. As for the palace I would rather visit the Ekaterinensky palace in Pushkin.

Peterhof visit. Visit early MayFound that there were quite a lot of restrictions of access. Not allowed into building. Upper terrace roped off for some ceremony so no view of Cascade from there. No Cascade fountain display.A point to note: the bathroom facilities do not cope with the crowds even for early May. Our ladies queued for 35 mins. This seriously detracted from our visit time.Guess it just wasn't my day to visit. No fault of the tour guide.

Worth a trip out of the city. The Grand Palace rivals most palaces around the world with its grandeur and opulence. Worth a visit - the gardens outside and fountains tip this tourist destination in the 'not to be missed' bucket. Don't miss

Amazingly breathtaking. The palace while amazing is nothing compared to the magnificence of the fountains and gardens that lay outside. The naturally flowing fountains will amaze you - and the surrounding gardens and chapels provide a gorgeous back drop for photos and fond memories. Unmissable.

A Masterpiece. An unbelievable architectural and design masterpiece. Fountains are turned on at 11:00 am with music accompaniment. If you have a private guide, ask to be taken early, before the large groups.

Not so crowded in September, still not great. We went with a private guide, didn't have lines to wait in or anything. But, half the building was closed (G@)), and the part taht we did see, you guessed it, was as we walked past, beause the room attendants don't like you to stand still. I do understand this about some of the rooms, trying to keep the humidity constant and so on, but other rooms are huge, and I don't see a problem with tourists standing still for a bit. Guess I am not Russian! Do be aware you have to get new tickets for every building you'd like to see, apparently you can't get a 'combined' ticket. The palace is of course gorgeous, and impressive, but it is a downer to realize it is not the original one, but a somewhat recently built tourist attraction! The gardens are amazing, but all very structured, and no walking and/or sitting on the grass allowed. I liked best the small building overlooking the harbour where Peter the Great had his office, a kitchen, etc.Also, don't miss (especially if you are traveling with kids) the "joke" fountain garden close to this building, where he liked to have fun at the expense of his guests!

Amazing. About an hour high speed from St Petersburg and the most expensive sight we saw but worth it. The grounds are vast and beautiful. Fountains breathtaking. The palace is incredible but smaller than it seems from the outside. Plan for a whole day to see it all with the travel. A lot of walking.

Peterhof garden. Fantastic garden with splendid display of water fountains. You will need at least 4 to 5 hrs there to enjoy and absorb the beauty of the gardens and palace.. Will definitely go back again and do a special half day trip there.

Hope that it's a sunny day. It was a warm, beautiful day when we visited the Peterhof gardens, and it was spectacular! The sunshine glittered off all of the fountains and the gold statuary. We just gaped seemingly forever. There were a lot of people strolling about and it just seemed like paradise. Ok, you can't control the weather, so go even if it's not a pretty day - it's still impressive.

Breathtaking. The magnificent displays were awesome! The amount of gold that was everywhere made one feel as if it was a fantasy land. Everywhere one looked was beautiful and each area more beautiful than the next!

Another Disney like re-creation.. Shame it was destroyed in the war. But has been essentially re-created. My beef is that their are more visually stunning places in Vegas! But this place had mega history to distinguish itself.
The grounds are immense. I went in early fall when grey and cold. Summer must be spectacular.

A lovely walk in the park. If you haven't been to Versailles the grand palace will impress - but it is really the fabulous grounds and fountains that make the day. Bring a nice picnic and forego the mediocre and expensive cafés.

It was Good to be Tsar!. One of the most stunning preserves around, especially the fountains. This place sits just about on the Gulf of Finland and the Tsars would arrive by boat from St. Petersburg and sail up a short canal to dock just outside the palace. At the dock now are many beautiful gold statues surrounded by fountains. There is a fountain ceremony at 11 AM when they are turned on. Lots of crowds to see that spectacle. One interesting fact is that the fountains are all gravity fed with no pumps involved. And yet they shoot up 20 to 30 feet into the air.

Immense and Beautiful!. This has got to be the largest repository of art in the world! Over 3 million pieces but less than 10% on display and even in two days we could not begin to see it all. We were fortunate enough to be in early on a guided tour before the largest crowds. At the end of the day, the crowds were enormous. Bring comfortable shoes and be prepared to walk! Well worth the time spent there.

Stunning. The palace and gardens are definitely worth a visit. The interior of the palace was very lavish in places and quite stunning to look at. The fountains were numerous and very spectacular. The park also had some very friendly red squirrels that drew much attention.

I can still hear all the water features!. We enjoyed the beautiful gardens of the Peterof Place, the Palace was exceptional, but the gardens were similar to Paris...except these are operational! The statues are kept so well, and the stories were part of the thrill.

A definite must see!!. Wow !!!! Is the only way to describe Peterhof palace and gardens.We caught the hydrofoil from near the Winter Palace to Peterhof. Took about 40 minutes. Really easy. Comfortable trip.You then buy tickets to the gardens at the dock as you get off the boat then walk up to the palace and buy tickets for palace entry inside. Worth every single cent. Divine, sublime and incredible!!We then wandered the gardens for 2 hours before the hydrofoil back to St. Petersburg.Well worth the money.
