Spend more time if you can. For our two days in St. Petersburg we hired a private guide for the two of us. Since we could make adjustments to our guided tour we decided to skip Catherine's Palace and use most of that additional time at Peterhof Gardens. So we ended up spending about four hours inside Peterhof Gardens. This was an amazing visit and a wonderful decision on our part. We were able to take our time and visit as much of the gardens, buildings, fountains and grounds as we wished, without being rushed. We had stopped at a pie restaurant on the way to Peterhof and brought lunch with us, for a picnic lunch at Peterhof. There is a LOT to see at Peterhof and if you can arrange it, this is the way to go!P.S. Catherine's Palace is definitely an amazing and beautiful building. But Peterhof is distinctly different and unique and worth the extra time.

You Need An Entire Day!. We visited Peterhof Palace as an optional excursion on a recent Viking River Cruise. It was breathtaking. Unlike Catherine's Palace, you are not allowed to take pictures inside the palace and I found I liked that. I was just taking it all in, instead of trying to get pictures. And I didn't have other camera-crazy people standing around and bumping into each other. They keep you moving--don't want you lingering too long and you are closely watched as you move from room to room. You must check your coat and large bags, so don't take anything valuable in that you can't carry on your body. Our guide got us down below the fountains before they started up and I think that's a much better view, looking back up at the palace, than from the patio looking down at the fountains. I was pleased that the fountains were not turned off after the music, etc, was over. So everyone had plenty of time to get pictures and/or video. We had some free time and my husband and I walked around a part of the garden and were able to see a few other fountains. but we didn't have time to do the entire gardens. I could have spent the entire day there! A highlight of my Russia trip--maybe tied with the Hermitage for my favorite place!

Loyal Living in Russia. We spent 3 days in St. Petersburg, Russia as part of our river cruise to Moscow. We went to Peterhof Palace in our own by taking the local bus, metro and hydrofoil. The hydrofoil dick was right across from the Hermitage Museum. The boat rude costs about $35 US and took about 35 minutes. We then paid $15 US to visit the lower gardens. If you want to visit the inside of the palace and other building, you pay extra. The grounds were wonderfully maintained. In early October, the weather was a bit cold. Thus, if you plan a visit this time of the year, make sure you have layered clothing. The fountains were open and adorned with many gold plated statues. The scenery was great and our strode on the garden grounds was very relaxing. We had coffee at the restaurant on site and spent a total of 3 hours there.

Beautiful Palace. We visited this palace on the way to the airport on our last day and had a guided tour of this museum. It was interesting to think that the G20 leaders had met there two weeks earlier. The wow factor for me were the fountains. My gripe was that I did not have enough time to see the grounds properly - you need more than two hours!!

The Hermitage. This Museum has every artist's work in it known to man and that is just scratching the surface. The Museum's size is unbelievable. You could spend weeks in it and never see the whole Museum. Make sure you plan on doing a lot of walking when visiting this Museum.

Peterhof Palace and Garden. The gardens and fountains at the Palace are beautiful. The people working inside the Palace are anything but nice and do not care anything about allowing you to enjoy the actual rooms. Their sole purpose is too keep you moving as quickly as possible.

Gardens and fountains. It is a little bit expensive considering that it costs about 3000 rubs ( 70 euros) to get the flying dolphin from the front of the road at the hermitage museym (1 h travel) and to pay the entrance tickets only for the gardens, but is worthwhile! You need 2-3 hours to have a good taste of the gardens and the fountains that are amazing. We didn't get at the palace because it costs extra 550 rubs (13 euros). I think that anyone visiting the Saint Petersburg must visit Peterhof.
Fabulous. Even if you have to book this as an excursion, usually along with Catherine's palace, it's well worth it. The rooms & fountains are very impressive.

If you only visit one palace, make it this one. It's either 45 minutes by road or 30 minutes on the hydrofoil. On balance, road is probably better. The hydrofoil cabin smells strongly of diesel, it's noisy and airless, the windows quickly steam up, and the views from the windows aren't anything special once you leave the city boundary. But once at Peterhof, the upper and lower gardens are a sublime mixture of nature and art, and the palace had a much calmer feel than some of the more over-decorated Ramanov houses. Well worth the visit.

Russian Beauty. This Park was beautiful. The fountains go on at 11:00 am with music, which is quite spectacular.Lots of steps so make sure you have on comfortable shoes. The gardens are well kept and beautiful. The flowers change with the different seasons. Worthwhile visit.

Sumptuous Palace from Peter the Great, a must see in St. Petersburg. I visited this wonderful Palace with my husband. We hired a guide via the hotel. It was a bit expensive because she didn't drive and the package included a driver. By car it took around 30 minutes. It was worth the money, since we learned a lot about Russian history during the trip to and from the Palace as well as during the visit to the premisses and gardens.It is a wonderful place to visit. The palace is sumptuous, made to show the power from Russian Czars. peter The great was, as the name says, one of the most famous of them and you can see that in all the rooms, decoration, furniture and all objects. the garden is an attraction in itself.Peter seems to have good sense of humour and in some parts of the walk his guests could be surprised by a spurt of water from a hidden mechanism he ordered to be installed. Huge fountains with golden statues in the back yard and all over the place.Some Russians choose the place for wedding photos. We have seen one couple with family.

Stunning. We were able to visit the Palace and Garden with our private guide. The palace is stunning as were the gardens. The numerous fountains are out of this world. I couldn't get over the trick designs.

A must see day trip!!!. Yes you will be swarmed by lots of other tourists but Peterhof is not to be missed. Yes you will be charged extra for everything but its really worth it to get an idea of Russian Imperial Grandeur!

Outstanding--Hard to believe this all a part of the Russia, once hated in the west.. St. Petersburg is unbelievable. No wonder it is becoming such a cruise ship haunt. Matter of fact, it looks to me as if all these Baltic coastal areas are going to be prime visitor attractions for many years to come, a lot to see in this realm.  I could go on and on about St. Petersburg. We visited the Yusopov Palace, this is a wax replication of the famous Monk "Rasputin" being poisoned there. The area is loaded with palaces and castles most of which were turned into museums after the Bolshevik Revolution in 1918. You remember the revolution don't you, when the have nots took over from the haves, called communism today? No wonder the peasants were unhappy, it is hard to believe the extravagance that existed then while surrounded by poverty. Except, they don't admit to that bit of history today. St. Petersburg was built on the Neva River Delta by Peter the Great in 1703 and it became a rival to all the cultural centers in the world. In 1714 Peter moved the capital of Russia from Moscow to St. Petersburg. Incidentally, he named the city after the apostle not himself.We took a tour on the Neva River. Great. But when we visited the Great Palace, about an hours drive from St. Petersburg. It was Peter the Great's "Peterhof Palace". Absolutely beautiful. We were there when they fired up the many fountains, all at the same time, at 11:AM, to the accompaniment of "The anthem of St. Petersburg". It is the most beautiful palace or castle I've ever seen. And yes, all that gold is gold leaf. One will also find the associated Peter and Paul Cathedral on these palace grounds.

An Experience of a Lifetime. Can you imagine more than three million works in one place! This is the Winter Place, the former residence of the Russian Emperors. With a Gate One Tour, we were able to gain access before normal opening hours. The pictures we took were even more impressive without the crowds. The famous Council Staircase with it's fantastic marble is just striking! This is one if the largest museum's in the world, there are six buildings, paintings, sculptures,jewelry, antiques, and more art of different country's than you can imagine. It is a wondrous place. A must on your bucket list!

Amazing Fountains. We were able to see the garden in the off season. It was cooler than normal but the fountains were a sight to see. We were able to see Gulf of Finland from the top steps which gave perspective as to where we were. We found it a little ridiculous that we were not able to 'stop' in the Chinese rooms but it was fascinating to see where the Czar's lived in the summer months.

Peterhof Palace, St Petersburg. Queuing for entry was a bit of a drag, but once in the palace was fabulous which leaves me short of words to describe the fountains and the garden - so, "blooming lovely" with the spring flowers and truly memorable for the "gold" fountains, including not just the tiered cascade and canal to the Gulf of Finland but many other fountains around the palace grounds. "I'll be back!"

comfort tour st petersburg. , we arrived by hydrofoil at 11am the fountains are switched on to music in front of the palace, the walk around the park was lovely each path led you to a different shape of fountain and the rep told us a different story about each one which was quite amusing

Beautiful but too crowded. The day I visited it must have been 32 degrees and it was sweltering just walking round the grounds. Your first glimpse of the main fountain feature to the front of the Palace is just amazing. All the gold statues, stepped fountains and long avenue of water. The grounds are extensive and fountains appear in all shapes and sizes, both formal and interactive (some of which the children will just love). There is a leafy avenue which springs to life spraying a fine mist of water over all those walking in the vicinity - which on the day I visited was very pleasant indeed. I didn't go into the Palace itself. There is a little market at the entrance to the attraction selling an assortment of Russian goods. Very picturesque, but so very crowded in the peak season.

Definitely a "Must See" -it's not that far to get to either. This is another beautifully restored palace with amazing grounds to walk through. I agree with another reviewer about the unhappy "minders". I laughed when I saw that. Getting back to the palace, the best way to go is by hydrofoil, even though it's not a hydrofoil as you probably know them. Don't break your neck to get to the fountain show at 11:00, it's nothing special other than just turning on the fountains which stay on for the rest of the day. The rooms inside are beautiful. Beware of the touring times. They are limited for non-Russians. We found it much less crowded to go to the 2nd touring time at 2:30pm. The line to get into the 1st touring time was way too long so we spent the time wandering around the grounds. The smaller houses/pavillions are interesting. Make sure you plan your potty breaks carefully, because bathrooms are scarce and far away from the main areas. They are clean, though. Not a lot of food places either. But definitely worth the visit, it's better to spend a whole day there, you won't regret it.

Incredible, Worth the Drive. This is a wonderful place to visit. The Palace is pristine. The gardens are beautiful. The walk through the gardens down to the Gulf of Finland is a once in a life time experience. The history and the recent work that has gone into restoring this palace must been seen. A must stop while in St. Petersburg.

Beautiful but a long way to go!. St Petersburg suffered greatly during World War 2. The Palaces were devastated by fire and today the restoration is proceeding, but obviously at a slow pace. Beautiful art and decorations, but very little a/c when I was there, so it was really too hot inside. It appears to me the Russians are cutting some corners in the restoration. The "minders" are some of the most unhappy women I have ever encountered. They should at least welcome the visitors that end up paying their salaries, rather than treat visitors as the enemy.

awe inspiring. This was one of the highlights of our magical trip to the city of St Petersburg, a must see trip for both the palace itself and the lovely gardens. Wrap up well if you plan to work down to the sea!

Favourite. This was the first palace we visited on our tour and it was our favourite. The interior of the palace was wonderful and the gardens with those amazing fountains was out of this world. We could have stayed there all day!

Amazing views. We only saw the grounds due to limited time, no chance to see the palace, but even that was amazing. Great park with nice walkways, picturesque fountains and magnificent views.On the hindsight the service is quite a bit lacking to say the least, but I understand this is typical for Russia from my experience during my week's long visit to Moscow and St. Petersburg. Tips:Try to catch an early hydrofoil as it's less crowded on the morning. First one leaves at 9am.Be sure to catch the 11 am fountain show. Overall a nice experience albeit lacking service.

Peterhoff, St. Petersburg. We took the Hydrofoil to Peterhoff, as we were short of time, and only intended to look around the gardens, as we were told it was free to go into gardens. Turned out to be 450rub, and then to go into Palace is extra. Gardens are just beautiful though. Didn't go into Palace as had to get back, and managed to find our own way back by public bus and metro. Just over an hour to get back, but 160 rub to get back, vs 1300 to get there (2 of us). Need best part of a day to see it all!

Another must see in St. Petersburg. We were very lucky to be able to spend the day at the Peterhof Palace into our trip to St. Petersburg. What a stunning Palace and we enjoyed the experience very much.

One of the nicest parks. My wife and i took the hydrofoil (costly at 1100roubles per pax return) from St Petersburg to Peterhof.Upon alighting from the hydrofoil, we then needed to pay 450roubles per pax to enter the Lower Park (where the fountains are located). It was a pleasure stolling in the Lower Park. There is also free wifi within the park grounds!We then ventured out to the upper gardens which we found even more pretty. However, unknown to us....the ticket to the lower gardens is only for 1 entrance and the gatekeepers only grudgingly allowed us to re-enter after we showed them our hydrofoil tickets. We didn't have enough time to see the Palace itself (a seperate price).In all, a rather expensive daytrip but the parks are really worth a look..prettier than everything else we saw in St Petersburg.
Magnificient Emperor recidence. Only gold, tasty art and great parks. Very romantical place to visit. It is a must, when visiting St. Petersburg area.....

Should be on your list of 'Must-See's'. Spectacular! Even though it was windy/rainy, it was worth it to walk in the gardens before the indoor tour. Just spectacular.We were part of a guided tour which really boosted the enjoyment and understanding.

Fountains and Gardens. The Peterhof has hundreds of fountains to capture the light in the streams of water, watch out for the hidden ones! Such an amazing display of Russian culture and extravagance. Don't forget to dip your toe in the Bay of Finland. Worth the drive to visit.

Amazing Palace. We took the hydrofoil from St. Petersburg which is a peasant 30 minute trip. This palace was built similar to the style of the Versailles. The gold fountains are absolutely gorgeous. The rooms of the palace have been restored brilliantly. Definitely a highlight not to be missed if you are in Russia
Excellant. I thought Catherine's palace was wonderful but this one with its wonderful views and gardens is breathtaking.

Very pretty. to get here is a bit of an effort as you have to catch the hydrofoil which bumps up the cost of the excursion. A great experience though although I was pushed for time. The fountains are switched on the a fanfare of (piped) music at 11am. Staff not very helpful

Take a walk in the park. I can only speak to the outside, as the palace was closed for G-20 prep the day we were there. Even so, walking the grounds is enough to give one a sense of Peter the Great's vision. Don't miss being there at 11am when they turn on the fountains, complete with playing the Russian national anthem -- very moving.

fountains after fountains. You have to pay just to visit the gardens and more payment for each museum. It can be very expensive. We just paid for the gardens. There is no map or instructions to wander the gardens.
It is a very beautiful and impressive garden with lovely fountains and musicians to entertain.

Rivals Versailles. When I heard this place was built to rival Versailles I laughed because it was hard to believe any royalty could be more ostentatious than the French. I stand corrected. There is so much gold decorating the place it is staggering. The summer palace incurred serious damage in WW II but has been restored to its original state over the past 50 years. The furniture is all the same period furniture but little of it original. The grounds and gardens are staggering in scope and beauty and the gold on display among the numerous fountains is amazing. If you visit St. Pete, it's worth a trip out of town to visit the summer palace of Peter. My only complaint with the place is the bottleneck created by requiring that virtually everything must be checked and not allowing sufficient space in the checked area to accommodate the overlapping crowds angering and leaving. It is pure chaos and really could be managed better with a little bit of thought by the property manager.If you found this review helpful, please check below.

Versailles in Russia. If you like Versailles, you'll love this. Beautiful gardens. Multiple fountains. On the Gulf of Finland. Much of this was destroyed in WWII, but beautifully restored. This is outside the city, but worth the time.

Fountains and gardens worth the trip!. Take the hydrofoil (half an hour, about $16 each way, on the river outside the Hermitage) for best access and fun trip! Gardens with 150 fountains (fueled by gravity alone, which is astounding) rise upward from the Gulf of Finland. Allow 2-3 hours to take it all in. Access to the palace is at certain times so be sure to check that out first when you arrive. But do enjoy the gardens and the other buildings on the property, including the "Hermitage" which was constructed near the water so Peter could entertain guests at dinner. the individual dinner plates and center part of table rise up by pulleys from the floor below. The building is surrounded by a moat. Even though not much was in bloom in September, the gardens were well-manicured and the avenues wonderful! Reminiscent of Versailles!

Wonderful Museum, International art. The museum would take years to go through to see it all, so spend as much time as possible here. You will see the original famous works of Van Gogh, Monet, Sisley and the like. Be sure you take a tour with an English speaking guide as the Russians do NOT speak English. The building itself is gorgeous and very ornate. If you are in St. Petersburg, do not miss this experience.

A must see. With it's lovely gardens and the palace is amazing. The queues were bad on the day we were there so if standing for a long time bothers you it may pay to prearrange a rest area while you wait for the group. It can also get quite hot inside so I suggest layering your clothing to accommodate for this. Queuing to enter is uncovered so be prepared if rainy. Worth it though.

Well worth the visit. Again this was one of the guided tours from our tour company, wish we could have stayed longer. The gardens and fountains were spectacular . Don't miss this one if you are in the area.
Stunning. He loved fountains and they are everywhere. Absolutely stunning to see. The grounds of the palace are as beautiful as the palace itself. Put on your walking shoes when you go here.

St Petersburg's Treasure.... This place is absolutely gorgeous (in my opinion, better than Versailles)! The walk we had through the upper and lower gardens are really verdant. Lose the crowds at the lower south side on the Baltic, where it pretty relaxing and serene! Pinch yourself while you sit! We spent so much time leisurely walking (2+ hours) and enjoying the gardens that we didnt have time for much else. Its a beautiful place, probably the thing we enjoyed the most in St P, next to the River Neva cruise at sunset!

One of the world's most beautiful gardens. I most enjoyed the gardens that surround this palace. It is enormous and so well planned that it's hard to take it all in when just being there for a few hours.

Loved every minute as soon as we stepped through the gates!. So grand and beautiful, the buildings and the grounds, the fountains, everything about this place! An absolute must see. You really feel like you are somewhere special walking through the palace or visiting the Tzars residential church, even walking through the grounds. I was awestruck by the magnificence of the place and then saddened about the fall of the royal family, they created such beauty. We didn't realise how big the area is, so block a day out to see everything.

Wonderful. The gardens are exquisite,.,all different.Take some nuts...or buy from the stall as there are red squirrels and thy will eat out of your hands..so sweet.The aviary is not worth the star cash...and take cash, as although the Hoover craft takes you there, you also have to pay when you get off !

A dream came true for me !. I wanted to see Russia and Peterhof since I was a little girl, and 41 years later it came true. I was wowed by Peterhof and the gardens. The fountains were on everywhere and everything was so beautiful, that it was like a fairytale. It was so incredible !!!!

Not to be missed attarction in St Petersberg. This is one attraction that cannot be mised while visiting SPB. No matter what your plands ar edurin a visit to SPB, make sure you visit Peterhof Palace & Gardens and the Hermitage museum.

Beautiful, a "must see" when in St. Petersburg. It is easy to understand why Peterhof is one of St. Petersburg's most popular attractions. Words and pictures truly don't do it justice - you really must see it. Your first glance at the Grand Palace, with its gardens and fountains, will be breathtaking.I would recommend allowing a day, if you have the time, to spend here. You will want to see the Grand Palace, Gardens, Fountains, and the other buildings - including the Marly Palace and Peterhof Hermitage - that are located here. Be aware that you will be charged separately for each attraction - a ticket for the Grand Palace, a ticket for the Gardens, a ticket for the Marly Palace. The ticketing system can make the visit quite expensive - though worth the money spent. It is also the reason I rated this Very Good rather than Excellent - quite honestly, I just got tired of paying to go into every single building. Would have preferred to pay more for an all-inclusive ticket.The façade of the Grand Palace is beautiful and the interiors are lavish - in part because they had to be reconstructed after WWII. The gilded Ballroom, Painting Hall, Peter the Great's Study, and the Throne Room were favorites. If you are not on an organized tour, the audio guide is very helpful.After visiting the Grand Palace, do take the time to visit the Gardens and Fountains. They are beautiful - and you will feel as though you simply can't take enough photos of them and that the photos you do take will never do them justice. The grounds are extensive and it's lovely to just enjoy the walk. As you walk, you will see the other buildings located on the property - the Marly Palace, the Peterhof Hermitage and others.Dining options at Peterhof are limited which is important to know if you plan to spend the day here. There is a restaurant - it was located fairly far from the Grand Palace and difficult to find. We ate at one of the many stands that offered hot dogs and hamburgers - and ate on a bench in the park.Peterhof was very easy to get to from St. Petersburg. We took the hydrofoil which leaves every half hour from right in front of The Hermitage. It is a 40 minute ride on the Neva River and will drop you off right at the dock at Peterhof - which is a 5-10 minute walk to the Grand Palace. If you buy a round trip ticket, it is less expensive.Visiting Peterhof, like visiting Catherine's Palace, really gives you a sense of how lavish and opulent the tastes and lifestyles of the Russian Tsars were and, as a result, provides some context to understanding the history of the country. It was definitely a highlight of our trip.

Amazing-Fantastic -Unforgettable. I went there in a private car with my tourist guide in the morning to avoid rush on sunday.It was magnificent historic palace.My guide explained me very nicely.One has to be in a queue and disciplined inside a palace .It is necessary also.One cannot break a queue and go foeward.Its like one way trafic,but good .It takes its own time to finish and come out.But it gives you satisfaction when you are out.Photo not allowed inside.Then you are free outside to view beutifull garden,park,fountains,trees,statues,and what not.It is certainly different from inside the palace.You can have a bath under fountain with the small children.Its quite exciting.So,you should have additional pair of undergarments and clothes to wear.Must to see although away from st.petersburg.For photography its an ideal place. I enjoyed it.

Fascinating Place. No visit to Russia is complete without seeing The Hermitage with it's fascinating architecture and abundance of riches including paintings by famour artists which is just a fraction of what was on view. Fantastic.
Absolutely gorgeous. Gorgeous place and appears to have a lot of newly weds who visit the grounds for their photos. Very beautiful place with gold statues and water fountains.

Fantastic!. There is so much to see at Peterhof-the 200+/- fountains alone, the impeccable gardens, the statues, many buildings...it is really a magnificent place.
It is really impressive when you have someone explaining its history to you as you walk around.
It is a very well visited place, so rather busy but still enjoyable.

Worth the 40 min bus trip and 6 km walk in the gardens. I was and still ama amazed by this Palace and its 150 fountains. You need to see it to believe and really assess how great this palace and its gardens are. I read about it in the DK Top 10 book but there is nothing like seeing it with your own eyes. It is worth the bus trip and the 6 km walk in the gardens. It is unforgettable !!!!

High expectations, not met.. We went there by boat. The place is very beautiful and well maintained, that's good. The gardens are so pretty, you can just walk there and enjoy. We visited the main palace and I think it's just a tourist trap. We did not book a guide because we just wanted to quickly see the inside, we saw ~15 rooms, 2 of them we were not allowed to stop and enjoy because of..... not sure why... Humidity of our bodies degrading the room??? We were stuck between two huge groups of people and I did not really enjoy anything in there. It was expensive too and the administration is not very helpful and not nice.Just stay outside and enjoy the gardens and fountains.

super. We visited in the morning doing a 2 day tour with DenRus. we arrived in the morning & were in possition to see the fountains turning on. The gardens are magnificant kept in excelland conditions. The day we visited was a glorious sunny day and the views to the Baltic were great. It was very crowded and the only fault i could find is the toilet facilities were a little on the cruid side but well worth a visit.

Versailles in Russia. Spectacular. A Versailles in St. Petersburg. Guilded fountains and palace grounds second to none in the world. A magnificent palace and, on the estate, at the Neva river waterfront, the modest quarters of Peter I, Peter The Great, who built Modern Russia and Peterhof.

Simply Amazing - Inside and Outside. This palace is almost indescribable. The opulence of the palace is far beyond what one would think of as a "summer house". Everything is beautifully restored. But the real treat is the gardens, especially the lower garden with the gold fountains. This must be experienced to be believed. Pictures and video are amazing, but to see it is to experience it.

nice, but a bit complicated getting there. The park is beautiful, the fountains are great, the grounds are great to stroll around in, but getting there gave us a true glimpse of bureaucratic rules not too easy to navigate in. Couldn't buy return tickets from the ticket office outside the Hermitage (and they ONLY accepted Cash, so had to spend 45 minutes finding a Cash machine in the surrounding streets), finally got tickets to a boat leaving 1½ hours later, arrived at Petersburg and had to wait in another line buying tickets for the park (everybody had to buy tickets for the park, no other reason to take the boat!) ... and then realized that we had to buy tickets for the return trip to St. Petersburg ... and had to wait in another line and say when we wanted to go back (without having any clue about of the amount of time we'd want to spend at Petersburg ... 2 hours, 3 hours, 4 hours???). Nice to be there on a sunny summer day ... but you won't be the only one who got the same idea, be sure of that! Pretty crowded there ... but all in all an okay day spent a bit away from the city.

Worth the trip alone. This palace is situated about a half hour trip from the centre but is well worth a visit with interesting exhibits from the time of peter the great in the palace and lovely gardens with spectacular fountains and views out to the baltic sea.make sure you leave plenty time for your visit as its very busy but well worth spending time to see the gardens and the palace

A Unique Experience. First, there is the palace with all its treasures and history to see - absolutely wonderful and absorbing. Then, there's the garden, stocked with every type of fountain and water display you can imagine - and what's more, all in gold!When the bell rings to indicate the start of the water flow, the fountains and cascades come alive and each one is a fascinating unique experience to watch.The garden is well stocked with greenery, plants and shrubs, and the tea rooms offer very welcome refreshments.If you're staying in St Petersburg or the near vicinity, Peterhof is an absolute must to visit!

Jaw dropping!. This is just fabulous!
We visited the day after the G20 summit, which was visited on the previous day by all the leaders.
The gardens, the fountains and the summer palace were just fantastic

Whoa!. Amazing place, lots of fountains. It gets quieter if you go to father areas of the park.
Make sure to arrive early as you will spend whole day there. Food is available to purchase but expensive, it might be a good idea to have you own for a picnic.

Peterhof in Winter. The fountains in the gardens were shut off for the winter, and much work was in progress. However, the interior was really worth seeing, although we had to check our cameras at the cloakroom, for photography inside was forbidden. November does not seem to be the time of year to see the Palace at its very best, but it's not a disappointment ... we still admired what was to be seen, and made a note that a further visit, in the summer, would be much more worthwile

Spectacular. We arrived at Peterhof at the perfect time, 11 am , to watch the fountains turn on. The St Petersburg City Theme plays as the fountains begin, first on the hill, then throughout the garden. The grounds are beautiful, but unpaved. This could be a bit challenging in a wheelchair. Out wonderful guide, Sergie, from Alla Tours was very helpful. The view from the look out over the bay is amazing. We later learned that Peters daughter redecorated, so very little remains of his original work is intact. Catherine's home is spectacular, the amber room is well worth the trip. Staff was very helpful in getting us to elevators and very nice wheelchair accessible bathroom. We learned that in WWII the Russian women buried the statues, so many survived. Others were never found and replaced with replicas. Seeing the opulence, it is easy to see how this behavior of the Tsars sparked the revolution. So much money spent on luxury while others starved. The drive to Peterhof is a nice chance to see the Russian countryside. BTY the fee was covered by our tour fee.

Be careful about hours. Apparently there is Russian only admittance from noon to 2:30. We were bounced amongst multiple lines until a friendly young russian who spoke english explained the situation. The actual museum staff was neither friendly nor English speaking (understood that it is their country, would be helpful to have some non-cyrillic signs explaining the admission policy.)

Magnificent. Absolutelly amazing. Starting with the travel from Sankt Petersburg by hydrofoil, continuing with the amazing Lower Gardens, the Grote and the Grand Palace everything is magnificent. We saw it during a sunny September day, perfect temperature for such a great place. The fountains are breathtaking and all that gold knocks you off your feet....

Lovely grounds and fountains. The fountains and gardens are stunning and the scope is just huge. They really give one a feel of how much power and wealth the tsars of Russia had. It is amazing that Peter the Great could create all these fountains without using electricity.We got to Peterhof on the Hydrofoil which was very quick, but there was nothing to see on the trip except water. So going back we took one of the much cheaper Matruska busses and then a subway train from Avtovo station. It was quite easy to manage and on the way back we saw some modern suburbs of St. Petersburg, which we would otherwise have missed.

stunning fountains masterpiece. If u come to Peterhof by boat - u could start opening this amazing place from the very beginning. You will be slowly preparing yourself to see the beauty of russian engineers and architectures. Yes, it's better to come in June for a whole day during white nites period. Yes, u could come there with children as they can play with tricky fountains "catch-me-if-u-can". Yes, you could spend there 1 whole day and never feel your self tired. One can watch for a running water for a hours. During sunshine u could even see rainbows in drops. Trust me, u will have unforgettable time. Tip: take some extra clothes to your children and use waterresistant cameras

The building is worth a visit too.. Don't just visit the gardens. Seeing how the building was bombed out during WWII and restored is so worth going inside. And of course the gardens are a sight to behold!
Tour of the Hermitage. Absolutely enthralling. So much art to see and wonderful decor. Our guide said it would take l0 years to review every single item in that palace.
St. Peterhof Palace. We saw it on a sunny day. The palace stood out in white and gold painting. The gardens (around 2 miles) were fantastic with waterfalls and fountains.

Great Palace and Fountains. Fabulous place and grounds. The highlight is the Fountains. Be sure to get to the fountains before 11 am. This is when they turn them on. It is very majestic with music to match. Get yourself in a good position for a beauttiful show.Have your cameras ready.I don't understand why the tall people get in front oblivious to the short people behind them . I am 5 foot 1 and didn't realize what was about to happen. Of course the 6 feet tall people were on the front line and us shorter people behind them. So find your spot early.

Better than Versailles. Absolutely stunning Palace and gardens. The switch on of the fountains was magnificent and the gardens alone could offer a lovely full day. We were so lucky to visit in beautiful weather and just a few days before the G20 summit. Walking through the G20 conference room was a memorable experience. The rooms in the palace are truly beautiful. We were on a guided tour and consider this the best way to see it all and understand the use made of each room. A very early arrival time is recommended, before the crowds arrive.

An incredible palace. We travelled to Peterhof independently and caught the hydrofoil from outside The Hermitage at 9.30 am. It was easy to buy tickets although we needed cash (even though they displayed visa and mastercard signs). They also required the right amount - no change. This was a great way to arrive and we had plenty of time walking around the stunning gardens before the fountains started at 11am.Again we had to pay an entry ticket to the gardens (with cash) and from that point on every building or attraction required further payment with cash. So bring plenty if you want to see everything! We chose to go to the main palace next and had to buy tickets inside the main door. I think everyone else there was with a guide or big tour group so we had to fight our way in through the groups to get inside to buy tickets. We could not find a separate entrance from those not in a group. Our guide book had said get there early to avoid groups but this was not the case. The buildings shuts in the middle of the day which means a lot of people get there early.But once we got inside it was easy to buy the ticket and we were able to leave our bags in the cloakroom. Cameras are not allowed inside the main building.The building is simply stunning. Each room is more incredible than the next and all well worth seeing. There was a sign in English in each room which let us know what each room was. We didn't pay for the audio tour (500 roubles each) so can't tell you what it was like, We bought a book at the end of the tour in the shop which covers each room in detail which helped a lot.There are guides in each room who help keep the crowds moving and helped our small group of 4 get around the large tour groups.We then had a wonderful time in the gardens and played in all the trick fountains. The gardens are enormous and full of beautiful fountains. We walked around them for hours. I would recommend bringing a picnic lunch as the food options are expensive and reasonably limited.We had no trouble buying a return ticket for the hydrofoil which was discounted if we showed the first ticket and had a great trip back.Peterhof was a highlight of our time in St Petersburg. A must see.

Peterhof Gardens. This was part of the Tour with SPB and followed our good lunch locally. Fabulous gardens well maintained by a large visible staff. Beautifull fountains, statues and acre upon acre of set out gardens. we did not go into the palace but it was stunning from the outside. The chequer waterfall was really nice.Om completion we made our way back through the grounds to the pier and took the Hydrofoil back to the Hermitage Pier to pick up our transport back to the ship. Overall another great venue and well worth a visit.

Outstanding palace and gardens. The palace is beautiful (from the outside, I didn't go inside), and the gardens are simply unbelievable. The multitude of the golden fountains in the central plaza, and the vast area with other fountains, lakes, channels and perfectly aligned vegetation makes the place a perfect spot to spend a beautiful day walking around, having a picnic or just relaxing.

Spectacular. We did a tour with SPB Tours who were excellent. Visiting with a guide is a must, as they explain the rooms and gardens to you. The palace is filled with fabulous gold leaf embossed rooms that are not only huge but very opulent. A lot of people just go for the gardens and fountains, but the palace is a must. Why go all that way and miss out on the beauty of the palace?

beautiful but expensive visit. To visit you have to take an hydrofoil, then pay access to the gardens where you can view the beautiful fountains. But then you have to pay entrance to each building which makes the whole thing very expensive. If you have limited time in St Petersburg skip it and concentrate on the town.
Nothing Like It!!!. If come anywhere close to St. Petersburg and don't come to see the Peterhof Palace, you should have not even bothered with the trip. Enough said.

Worth the ride. Inside and Out this place is beautiful. A must see for anyone traveling to St Petersburg, Russia. The fountains and gardens are spectacular. Inside the palace you will find amazing decorations

Huge gardens. 200 acres of beautiful gardens surrounding a very impressive palace and living quarters. This is well worth the ride to the country, especially when followed by a hydro-boat ride return.

ELEGANT HOME OF ELIZABETH AND CATHERINE THE GREAT. We took a very tightly organized tour of the Peterhof Palace and Gardens in outskirts of St. Petersburg, Russia. This was the castle built in the circa 1750 for Elizabeth and later lived for over 30 years by Catherine the Great. It is gilded gilded gilded. These Tzarinas lived much too high on the hog considering the surrounding poverty of the vast majority of the people. The gardens are very elegant and have a distinctive flavor with numerous fountatins. We were here 5 days before the G-20 meeting hosted at the Peterhof by President Putin. Security was tight. There were grim faced ladies in each room ordering us around and swatting at us with batons if we got too close to a roped line. Still the beauty of the place rates it as a solid 5. No photos were allowed on the inside of the palace but outside was a different matter. We have attached a few of the building and gardens.
the fountains. we were not in the palace just the gardens they are amazing to see and to think they are fed from springs 13 miles away
Great fountain cascade. Using the old fashion technigue to guide water in and use gravity to create such a beautiful fountains, it is quite amazing. It is a must see to experience the art work..

Meant to be a show place, and it is. Peter the Great wanted to show the world what he could create, and he did. This is a show off palace built as much to prove a point about power and wealth as for any other reason. Anyone interested in great royal palaces must see this.
peterhof. magnificent grounds. stunningly beautiful. opulence on the highest level. intense crowds but for the most part well mannered and pleasent.

BEAUTIFUL! A MUST-SEE ATTRACTION!. A really attractive, opulent garden with beautiful natural fountains! Irina our guide was so interesting and knew her history. There is so much to see and to listen to the beautiful singers was an added attraction! Be careful of pickpockets and you are often warned. All the sellers accepted Euros/Dollars, which was lucky for us! It does take a lot of time walking, so wear comfortable shoes and enjoy the experience!

Opulent. Wow, I agree, all I could think about was the ridiculous money these czars spent on themselves. It's stunning. The opening ceremony of the fountains was very nice but not exactly bellagio quality amazing. We didn't go into the buildings but walked the gardens. Be prepared to walk a bit. We took the hydrofoil to get there and that was half the fun. Nice excursion, like Versailles Nasty public restrooms, some snak stands are around the gardens and some small cafes near the port

Fabulous Gardens. Visited the gardens only. The gardens are absolutely fabulous with beautiful flowers and many spectacular fountains. Best viewed on a sunny day to enjoy all of the gold on the fountains and statues. The fountains are not operating in the winter, and the hours vary, so be sure to check the schedule before you go. Well worth the drive from St. Petersburg, or you can take the hydrofoil.
Wow. Wow. The Peterhof fountains alone are worth coming to St Petersburg for. No wonder there was a revolution if the peasants could see how much had been spent on this place.

Gardens only. We did not go in the Palace, just the gardens, so do not know what the palace is like but if it is anything like the gardens it will be amazing. At 11 a.m. every day they turn on the fountains, which are just magnificent. I loved this place, but unfortunately so do all the other tourists in town, it gets absolutely packed for the 11 a.m. turn on of the fountains, so be aware of this.

So pretty. Just enjoyed ambling around the grounds. We didn't visit the interior of any of the buildings, ad a lovely day walking around the gardens, even though it was very hot there's plenty of shade. Amazing fountains, beautiful surrounds.....catch the ferry back to the city. A great day out.

Bling!. Sadly, I only saw the gardens on my tour and not the house.But "Wow!" those gardens were quite an experience. On a rather overcast, grey day the lavishness and opulence of the gold statuary was particularly striking. All those fountains and all the gold provides quite a lush, visual feast. It's a lot to take in but it's totally stunning.

Well Worth The Trip On The Hydrofoil. Peterhof is about 45 minutes by hydrofoil from St. Petersburg. It was not included on our tour but we purchased tickets on the hydrofoil and visited on our own. We caught it on a beautiful summer day in late August and the grounds and fountains were remarkable. Try to catch the initial flow into the main fountains at 11 accompanied by music.

Under maintenance during my visit.. The palace was undergoing extensive maintenance during my visit (probably for the G20-conference that's taking place there at this moment) so I only got to see a small part of the palace and since my visit was in the winter (well, march in Russia can still be considered midwinter), I didn't see anything of the garden. But what I saw was definitely worth another visit if I would ever come back in St. Petersburg! Do note that the palace lays outside the city and that it's quite a long drive to get there!
Take your camera!. Breathtaking vista of golden statuary and fountains, ornate Palace inside and out, views over the Gulf of Finland, an absolute delight for the eyes.

Delightful. I enjoyed the beauty of the gardens. The flowers themselves didn't bowl me over, but the layout and the gardens and sculptures were grand. The views from above were beautiful. There was a delightful tiny spot where kids run through a fountain hoping to beat the sprays of water. It was nice just to see local kids enjoying a fountain like kids do. We were on a tour from a ship so I don't know about the accessibility of the gardens, but it was definitely a lovely sight.

fabulous, fun palace and garden. The fountains are incredible. Take some time to walk through the garden. Be sure to visit the trick fountain, which was so much fun. They've done an excellent job with that. They were expanding the fountains and water features when we were there. It's worth the drive to get there.

Magnificent. Come early and you will see the fountain/music show! also, make sure to charge your camera because you will want to take pictures of everything. This is a very romantic spot, you will see many wedding parties here celebrating

Well worth a detour. World class gardens, perfectly manicured ( though they obviously do not spray for mosquitos ). A lovely collection of guilded statues and fountains. It is very popular with locals and tourists alike. We visited on a Saturday, and it was mobbed.Part of the fun is getting there on the hydrofoil, which leaves from behind the Hermitage Museum. You can also take the metro to the Baltic Station, and then catch a Jitney in front of the station - less expensive than the hydrofoil, but it takes longer.
You have not seen a palace until you have been here. Other palaces are nice but this one is over the top. Remember to walk around the gardens. You will feel very "royal".
Impressive fountain garden. The engineering exellency of this garden is very impressive considering it was built almost 300 years ago!

Magnificent Fountains. A must see for the beauty of the cascading water and impressive fountains! The opulence of the palace and beauty of the gardens makes us envy the lives of the Czars. Although opulent, all appears I'd good taste.

Stunning. Approached by water on the hydrofoil from the city centre taking 30-40 minutes. Lovely trip in itself just getting there.Serene surroundings.Arrived before the fountains were switched on at 11am so it was quite something to see all the gold statues in the fountains and then see the fountains start. If you fancy an umbrella, buy it here - didn't have time and was sorry as I never saw any as nice as the ones on sale there. And you may need it, it does rain a lot in St Petersburg !

A Treasure. Only visited the gardens, but they were breathtaking. The palace exterior was stunning, but the fountains and views in the garden are etched on my memory. Again too many tourists to totally relax and enjoy.

G20 prep didn't stop enjoyment. Was at the Peterhof two days prior to the G20 2013 conference. Even though we had to peer around cables, translator rooms, and lots of scaffolding due to the prep for the conference, it was worth the it. We were able to see some of the rooms set for the conference which was quite interesting. It is hard to explain the beauty of Peterhof. Over the top in gold but with a wonder garden which is not to be missed. The famous fountains start at 11 am along with music. Don't miss it. The garden is worth the trip alone. I would recommend a guide so you can get in early. Groups are limited in size due to humidity from people's bodies in the Chinese rooms. No stopping for very long, the room guards keep you moving along. Also no photos. Not sure if it was because of G20 or if that is the norm. Plan on spending at least an hour in the gardens.

A St Petersburg must do!. We visited St Petersburg for 2 days as part of a Baltic cruise, and it was definitely the highlight of the whole trip - despite the persistent weather! St Petersburg has a fascinating history in which the powers have seriously invested - from Peter the Great and his successors through to modern times, where palaces, churches etc devastated by WW2 have been painstakingly restored to their former glory. The Peterhof Palace and Garden is a prime example of this - absolutely stunning (as described in many other reviews) and all the more so, considering the work required to restore the palace, fountains, statues etc to their former glory following WW2 damage.
Beautiful!. This palace's only competition would be Versailles. It sums up the grandeur of Peter the Great. The use of green is beautiful which is not seen very often on baroque style.

One of the many palaces of the Czar. Opulence is the norm in St. Petersburg but the Peterhof Palace surpasses all the others. The gardens in particular are unsurpassed and along with the Hermitage, this is not to be missed.
Peterhof and Garden. We arrived by Hydrofoil, then walked the gardens and ended at the palace with gold and fountains and a wonderful view! What an experience!

Worth visiting. During my stay in St. Petersburg I visited the Peterhof Palace and Garden. It is much cheaper to go there by bus or minibus rather than travelling by hydrofoil. The fountains inside the garden are beautiful and worth visiting. Some reviews said that the catering service there are expensive but I think the price is more or less the same within the city when you eat out.If the weather is good it's a great place for taking beautiful photos!

What a place - I've never seen anything like it. We didn't go in the Palace itself but did the fountains and gardens - both of which were fantastic. They were getting ready for the G8 summit when we were there but it wasn't too busy and you could catch the hydrofoil back into St Petersburg from the bottom of the gardens. I'd love to go back and see inside the Palace.

Beautiful palace with stunning gardens. The palace is breathtakingly beautiful, very opulant, especially when you see how ordinary Russians live. The staff in each room are not friendly, however those working in the shops are! We were not allowed to stop to get a better look of anything and photographs are not allowed at all. The gardens are absolutely gorgeous, famous for it's many fountains. There are some 'trick' fountains designed to catch out unsuspecting visitors. We saw the palace whilst on a trip organised by Princess Cruises.

Fountains and Gardens on a sunny day, a real pleasure!. When visiting St. Petersburg, Peterhof is a must. The palace built for Peter, in the city built for Peter the Great. The grandeur is stunning and you can imagine him gazing at the views of the sea and enjoying his passion of sailing.The fountains are simply spectacular and the gardens beautiful and a treat to wander through. We spent a few hours here, had something to eat and then took the hydrofoil back to the city. A great day!

Russian Versailles... Only better. You cannot tell you have been in St. Petersburg, Russia if you did not visit Peterhof. If you have limited time, sacrifice the palace in favor of the gardens and their fountains. Try to get there before 11am but not too early. The fountains sleep until 11am and wake up with the sound of the beautiful music of the city's anthem. This is the best moment to take a video shot of Samson - the central figure of the main cascade of the fountains. The tall streams of water are especially impressive when you realize that there are no pumps involved in this show. The water is thrown up only due to the forces of gravity since its is directed underground from the hills nearby. The sculptures of the fountains are covered with pure gold that has been recently renewed. This gold is so shiny that the sculptures look like brand new. The palace and gardens are located next to the Finnish Bay of the Baltic Sea and the view from the palace balcony towards the sea is just beautiful. I have been in Peterhof for the first time long time ago during the Soviet times and now the place looks much better after series of restorations. Must see.
what a garden. We only had the time to see the garden and the outside of the palace, but what a garden with all those fountains, from impressive to playfull.
Peterhof palace and garden. If you have the chance to go to St. Petersburg, this tour should be included. Beautiful place to visit.

Such Fun!. What a sense of humour Peter the Great must have had to install all those secret fountains, which squirted his unsuspecting guests! The gardens were a delight and created a lovely rest from palaces and museums. We travelled there on the Hydrofoil which was quick and very smooth. We were very lucky with the weather which is essential, although I imagine the gardens would look beautiful in winter.

Lovely Gardens. Located at the Gulf of Finland is the Peterhof. We just visited the gardens since we were palaced out. It's a lovely space with many fountains and canals. Worth a visit. Take the hydrofoil to and from to avoid St. Petersburg's horrible traffic.

Be prepaired to spend the day. The Czars of Russia did not go anything small. The grounds both in the front and rear of the palace are huge. My wife and I have been there many times, and I still do not thing we have seen it all.

Well worth the cost. Organised trip - approximately £100 for the two of us. English-speaking guide and mini-bus from the city. Drive was under an hour - entrance fees all paid by the fee.Guide knew her subject and did not try and rip us off.No photos once you are inside but to be honest no camera, when you are shuffling along insode that wonderful building, could capture the grandeur. Once outside then snap away. Amazing gardens.We took the fast boat back - in honour of Michael Palin and to allow us more time to wander around. A great day out!
Pererhof Museum. Worth the time and crowds to see ; just something you will always remember, such beauty! The residence was founded by Peter the Great in the 18th century.
The Hermitage Museum. Unbelievable paintings and interior of rooms; room after room of beautiful paintings, furniture, gold and amber. Fountains and grounds and,flowers are something to see.

Gilded to the Max!. Spectacular palace and gardens, but any item that could be gilded with gold is covered. The entry system used is chaotic and the epitome of inefficiency. Tourists (mainly Americans) are randomly selected to surrender their "large" purses and tote bags. Females standing guard in most of the rooms do not tolerate any movement toward an object or leaning against a door frame. If you're short on time, go to Catherine's Palace instead. Less crowded, same type of interiors, and a little less gold gild.

No Hermits, just great Russian Art. A must do when in St. Petersburg. Plan to spend a minimum of 3 hours on tour. Every minuter was worth it. Monet, Rembrandt, Picasso and the whole gang of noted artists were on display. I took photos liberally as was allowed by the stern matriach's of the corridors. I believe and few could have been KGB retiree's.
Peter, Oh, he was Great!. Exquisite garden grounds were captavatingly beautiful. Lucky to have gone at spring time when every flower was in bloom.

Highlight of St. Pete. Start with the Palace. It is well worth the fee. Once done there, it's time for the gardens--they are spectacular. If the fountains are off, wait for them to come on. It is a sight to behold. The stairs are challenging, but there is a ramp to the lower garden area. It is quite long, but easier than the steps. The checkerboard waterfall is not to be missed. It takes at least 3 hours to do it all, but it goes by quickly. If you have time for one sight in St. Pete, this is the place to see.

Beautiful vista. All the statues were gold gilded, amid fountains where water shrouded each statue. The sunlight danced around the water and gold and took your breath away, all with a distant view of the harbor.

Beautiful grounds and palace. Wish it would have been possible to take a photo of the grounds from the palace but the tour was absolutely worth it. Be sure to be there when they turn on on the fountains around 11a.m. Allow enough time o really appreciate the magnificent grounds

Amazing sights and a memorable experience. We spent half a day at Peterhof on a recent visit to St. Petersburg and could have stayed much longer. Be sure to arrive by late morning to see the ceremony of turning on the fountains, with full pomp and martial music playing. The gilded fountains throughout the gardens are magnificent. The lines for the main palace were very long, so we opted instead for the much smaller Mon Plaisir palace. It was Peter the Great's favorite place to stay when at Peterhof and is very charming. Do beware of pickpockets, as they were visibly present and working fast as the crowds gathered to see the fountain ceremony.That issue aside, I heartily recommend a visit for once-in-a-lifetime views of gilded castles and sumptuous gardens.

Must see Peterhof Palace and Gardens. A visit to Peterhof Castle and Palace in St. Petersburg, Russia is a must see. The extensive grounds filled with fountains and flowers are sights to behold. As one strolls through the groundsone must have a knowledgeable guide to really appreciate the beauty of the place. One note of caution, beware of the pickpockets, they are very creative. They dress like tourist complete with headphones and cameras waiting for you to be engrossed taking pictures.

Totally Amazing in Many Ways!. There is no place on earth, that I am aware of, that are as stunning in its visual presentation than here. The fountains, all gravity fed with no pumps, dominate the vistas. The pure size of it is overwhelming. Be prepared for crowds, it's popular. You can actually take the hydrofoil from St. Petersburg. You will do a lot of walking, but can avoid the many steps if you plan accordingly. Time wise, I would suggest you dedicate an entire day. There is just so much to see that you really don't want to skip anything.

Lovely gardens and fountains. The gardens and grounds of Peterhof Palace are full of delightful vistas, fountains and statues. We did not tour the interior of the Palace, but the outside is magnificent, embroidered with gold and white. A wonderful example of Russian noble extravagance.
Not-to-Miss. At one level, this is a magnificent palace with gold plated statuary and fantastic gardens. Read up on it before you visit to understand the scale and scope of this "retreat".
Stupendous. Overwhelming collection of art and the gardens and fountains are gorgeous. The Russian czars knew how to live!
WOW. this place is not to be missed - the fountains rival any I've seen and the gardens were lovely - the opulence is beyond description and must be seen for oneself

Magnificent Beyond Belief. The gardens at Peterhof Palace are glorious. There is so much to see, but for the most part you can take your time and enjoy a pleasant walk under the trees. The statues are beautiful. This is a MUST see if you are in St. Petersburg, Russia. Be sure to allow at least 1/2 a day. You can either take a bus tour or you can take the boat from across from The Hermitage to arrive at the palace. I have done it both ways and would suggest you do one way by boat and one by bus. That way you see the best of both worlds.

Excellent Museum. We visited the Hermitage in August and found it fascinating, albeit extremely crowded with tourists, so quite hard to see the most popular rooms, like Michael Angelo's paintings. However, what we did see was overwhelming in beauty and history. The best time to see the rooms and exhibits would be off season when there would be less tourists.

How to get to Peterhof. Best option to visit Peterhof, especially is by hydrofoil (from Hermitage museum to Peterhof). The time of drive is about 45 minutes, and it costs about 900 RUR.If you take the train or bus, how someone suggest, it is more cheaper, but it is necessary to change buses, to look for the right bus, you will loose your time. It will take about 2 hours, only in one direction.The complex of Peterhof is something "Must to see" and it is better to save your time for sighting, not spend of time on ride! I think that good traveling is the balance between the time and money.

Awesome. Reached by boat or hydrofoil, this was Catherines summer residence and had all the opulence of her palace. The gardens are even more spectacular as are the fountains and follies. Absolute must for any visitor

The Russian Grandeur. Beautiful palace to visit but what makes the visit unforgetable are the gardens and fontains. The Russian Grandeur with style and luxury is really involving you. Best way to go is by hidro speed boat leaving opposite the Hermitage. Walk all around the gardens and park!
The height of decadence.. I loved everything: beautiful grounds and rooms, golden statues, cascading waterfalls, pools. Another place to be revisited!
Vacation palace. Water fountains were exquisite and loved to hear about the waterworks altogether. Gardens were lovely. Palace was wonderful. I would like to call it home...

Versailles in Russia. The fountains of the Peterhof Gardens are spectacular especially on a gorgeous summer day. The fact that they are outside a gold-encrusted onion-dome-topped palace is not bad either.

The Hermitage in July. We had the wonderful opportunity to visit this great museum as part of the shore excursions on our Baltic cruise. It was suggested that we had to see this place on our trip and it was great advice! It was equal to the Louvre in Paris as far as I was concerned. The art work as so fantastic and there was so much to see that it was almost information overload. There was just so much to take in. Each room was beautifully decorated and some of the rooms so ornate that it made your eyes sore, trying to take everything in. It was an experience I would not have missed for anything in the world. I highly recommend The Hermitage to anyone who is thinking of going to St. Petersburg. The only downside of the tour was that we didn't have enough time to see and absorb everything. Our tour guide said that if we spent 2 minutes looking at each exhibit in The Hermitage, we would spend 8 years there! Unfortunately we only had a few hours. St. Petersburg is beautiful and The Hermitage is a once in a life time experience!

Impressive Gardens Punctured by Gold. The grounds of Peterhof are well-maintained and impressive. The Disney-like fountain Peter invented himself with no motors is amazing. The palace was like the other Tsar palaces (opulent), but punctuates the gardens as no other palace we've seen.

A "Must See" when visiting St. Petersburg. Not all Palaces are equal! This Palace has been the standout in our European Vacation. The Gardens and Fountains cannot be described.We traveled over on the hydrofoil which provides an excellent incite into the scale of all things Russian. We were very fortunate with the weather and the day was warm and clear.

A lovely strool in the garden. Gardens designed by tzar Peter the first give you a perfect change to travel in time. Hundreds of fountains, all cleverly working without pumps because of nearby higher-positioned lake are a wonderful place to walk, relax and enjoy. A small picnic we had on the coast of the Finnish gulf, drinking the typical tee and enjoying the view. What a wonderful place for a great day!
Fountains. Didn't go in the houses but enough gilt outdoors here - worth the walk round all the fountains and waterfalls. The sit down cafes seem to be 'outside'

Rivals Versailles. The interiors are spectacular, but the gardens and the fountains are remarkable, all done without any mechanical pumps. This is where they have G20 summits and other gatherings of world leaders. Not to be missed while in St. Petersburg.
Stunning but crowded. Gardens are wonderful especially the secret fountains. The palace is also lovely. However avoid August when the place is heaving but not as much as the Hermitage

Baltic Cruise-Emerald Princess. We flew SAS roundtrip from Newark to Copenhagen on August 6, 2013. The seats were very tight almost like Spirit Airlines. We stayed for two days at the Bella Skye Hotel which we booked on line. We had gotten a 48 hour Copenhagen pass. Trip was easy by train to hotel. Although hotel is outside the city, commuting was relatively easy and breakfast and view were excellent at hotel. We enjoyed our stay in Copenhagen taking two canal rides free with pass and going to the Royal Palace and Tivoli. Dinner was very expensive. Be prepared to pay double to triple US prices. We took no tours in Copenhagen and found it very doable by maps and asking people directions who all were friendly and spoke English. It is amazing how many bicycle riders are in the city.This was our third cruise, Princess to Alaska, Azamara to Greece and Turkey, and then this cruise. We were a little nervous about returning to such a large ship since we enjoyed the intimacy of the Azamara and loved the dinners and free excellent wine. However, we really enjoyed the Emerald Princess. We had an oversized balcony, I think they are largest on floor 9 and ten, and we thought the room was well designed. We signed up for anytime dining, and that also worked out very well. A few nights we had to wait ten minutes but we were always able to get a table for two if we wanted it. We also think the balcony was well worth it since leaving Stockholm and sailing among the small picturesque islands was beautiful. We also thoroughly enjoyed the guest lecturer/historian who gave an insightful talk prior to each port. Overall I found the entertainment enjoyable and the Princess theater excellent.We like to do things on our own so signed up for no cruise tours. However, we knew we needed a tour in St. Petersburg so signed up for STP. Since they offered a package for other cities we used them for Stockholm and Helsinki as well. Our first stop was Oslo. One of the reasons we selected Princess was that it went to Oslo. I had been to Oslo 40 years earlier but my wife had never gone there. We managed to find the tourist office (not that easy) and bought a one day pass. Our first stop was Vigland Park to see the sculpture garden. I had missed this on an earlier visit and to my wife and myself, this was one of the highlights of the whole trip. Unbelievably beautiful setting and sensational sculptures. We then took a train to the ski jump. Train trip offered a great feel for the Oslo countryside. Unfortunately, there was over an hour wait to top of ski jump so we did not wait. I do not remember anyone mentioning this problem. We then headed back to Oslo and took the ferry to the islands with the museums. Please note there are two stops, and we were told you could walk between all the museums. Actually, it was a lengthy walk. I suggest to get off at the Kon Tiki museum which is also next to the polar expedition museum. I found these more interesting than the Viking museum.We then went to Aarhus the second largest city in Denmark. It was a pretty city. We went to a recreated old town which I found touristy and not that interesting. I would have liked to see some artisans actually doing crafts which did not exist. We then went to their modern art museum. There is a rainbow roof which is quite unusual and gives excellent views of the city, and the museum itself was good.Our next stop was Warnemunde. We decided not to get up very early to go to Berlin which is 3 hours away. From the people on our cruise who went, I heard mix reviews. Some just opted for transportation to Berlin and they felt they were not left off in the best part for touring. We enjoyed our walking tour of Warnemunde which is a nice seashore resort and then we took a local train to Rostock and saw a football match. Fun for us to be among all the local German fans.We next went to Stockholm, and since we had limited time opted for a STP tour. I would have liked to have done a little more than what was planned for us. We did go to the Wasa museum which is tourist site number one and the Town Hall very impressive and had about thirty minutes to browse around the old town. All was good but I think they could have included another stop. As mentioned earlier, leaving Stockholm was very impressive.Our next stop was Helsinki and again we had an STP tour. Unfortunately, it rained very hard most of the tour. I do not think Helsinki has that much to offer in a short period but nothing looks good in the rain. We never got off the bus at the open market since the rain caused the stalls to close. Our guide gave us an excellent feeling for life in Helsinki for a young person. There was also a modern church of interest.I felt STP did a good job for the two days in St. Petersburg. We were unlucky that it rained the first day. As a result we did not get to take the hydrofoil to Peterhof but took the bus instead. At Peterhof, we were scheduled to view the fountains and gardens but did not take the walk in the gardens to the sea since it was pouring. Lunch was not good the first day. Also, we spent a lot of time in traffic the first day and seemed to repeat our route too much. We also had a very long wait to get back to our boat through customs after the tour the first day. The second day was jam-packed and everything seemed to run much better. The weather cooperated, the palaces were amazing, and our guide did an excellent job guiding us through the Hermitage museum. Since our group was limited to 16, I felt we moved at a better pace and saw much more than some of the larger cruise boat tours. I appreciated the knowledge our guide had of both Russian and art history. I found the tours very informative. We also got to see the Russian subway which was very interesting.Our last stop was Talinn in Estonia. We decided to walk the small medieval city ourselves. We visited their historical museum which I thought was ok. The city was quaint and worth a stop.Overall, we had a delightful two weeks, got a feeling for many different cultures, and learned a lot. I think the Baltics are great for someone interested in art, history or boating. I think the Princess did a great job on arriving on time at each stop and departing the ship was very easy.

Back in time. Another favorite of ours. Just thinking of the way they lived in those days with all the luxury and gold and beautiful fireplaces and the beautiful furniture. We loved it.The garden were lovely.

Spectacular gardens and fountains. We toured the lower gardens (not the palace) on a recent visit to St. Petersburg. The weather was warm and sunny, which made all the gold leaf statues glisten. We spent about two hours in the gardens along with a private tour guide we had hired for the day. Our guide was extremely knowledgable about the gardens, fountains and statues as it was clearly her favorite tour site. Only Hermitage or Catherine's palace have more gold leaf!Excellent photo opps throughout the gardens.

Need more time. We made the mistake of not giving ourselves enough time to see everything, we only saw part of the gardens and nothing of the buildings really, what we saw was fantastic though, highly recommend it.
Beautiful gardens. Beautiful and interesting palace - allow plenty of time to see the gardens and fountains & walk down to the sea.
Toured the Gardens, but not the palace. It took over 2 hours to walk the grounds of this incredible palace. The fountains were the highlight, over 144 of them, I think.

Not Worth It. During World War II, Germany managed to occupy Peterhof, and Hitler was so happy, he apparently sent out invitations to the cream of the crop of the fascist world for a huge party to be held there. Understandably enough, as this one story goes, this irritated Stalin no end, who proceeded to bomb the heck out of it. The other story is that the occupying Germans destroyed it. Either way, what you see today is a 70 or so year old re-imagining----not even a re-creation---of what had been there before. So putting the building aside which is really a more recently built tourist attraction, what you have here is a pretty park, with a lot of fountains and secondary buildings. These fountains were not designed with the intricate artistry of, say the Italian fountains in Rome or Florence, but rather with particular attention to: a) how the squirting was directed, b) large size and c) gold statues. If this was downtown, sure: why not; but for a day trip, not worth it to me.

Wow!. The palace is nice, but the gardens are wonderful. Just make sure that your tour has sufficient time to wander around the gardens. Try to plan it for a sunny day too. A rainy day at this place would really ruin it more so than other places.

A Truely Breathtaking Experience. The main palace is closed on Mondays and the last Tuesday of the month and we were in town from Sunday at noon until Tuesday. We had to do what some advised against - go on the weekend in the summer. We were glad we did. It was very crowded both inside the palaces and on the grounds. Foreign persons and tour groups can only enter the palace from 10:30-12:00 and again from 2:30-4:15 so we were obviously inside with hoards of tour groups and a few other foreigners. We got in line at 2:15 and it was not too busy. The line was 20 times longer when we left. There are stands with descriptions of each room in Russian and English. We enjoyed the time inside. It is over-the-top beautiful and fully restored.We also toured Monplaisir Palace which was also beautify and definitely worth the price of admission. Purchasing a ticket here, if you do not speak Russian, could be tricky. There are several options, different prices for foreigners and Russians, student discounts, 3 different venues, combination tickets, etc.. The price card on the wall was only in Russian and the sales person did not speak English. Be prepared by knowing the price of the ticket you want and pointing. I believe (but I could be wrong) that you are supposed to be in a group with a guide (assigned free at the entrance). We did not figure this out until we were inside and given a few glares when we lagged behind the groups that quickly were led through the rooms. This is about a 20 minute experience. You can drop back to an earlier group if you want more time. Worth the admission price just to look at the floors and other woodwork. It has a good website with virtual tours so you can get a preview and some history before the visit. We spend a long time just walking around the grounds. It was crowded but mostly with Russian families who were much more relaxed than the folks from the tour busses. We enjoyed the beautiful fountains, landscaping, snack bars and people watching and during this part of the visit we were glad we went on a sunny weekend in August.

Unbelievable!. We were fortunate to have a sunny day to visit this imperial palace. We have seen many European palaces, but this one is over the top. No wonder there was a revolution. Gold and masterpiece art everywhere, not to mention the impressive grounds, lakes and fountains. It actually connects to the Baltic Sea and it is there that Peter The Great spent most of his time in a smaller house. If you miss this attraction, you might as well have stayed home and not visited St. Petersburg.

WOW!!!. The extravagance and beauty of this visit is easy to explain. One's eyes could not take in all the beauty there was to see. Whether in the palace or in the garden, the "WOW" factor was always present and the feeling was that we were in a wonderland. Very exciting to see and a must for anyone visiting St. Petersburg!

Magnificent Gardens. Definitely worth a visit. The views are magnificent and the fountains spectacular. I went on a private tour which I highly recommend. Due to time restrictions we didn't go inside but the gardens , the fountains and the views made the visit worthwhile.

Gold, Glitter and Water Music which is Not Handel's. Do visit at 11 Am to see the start of water flowing in the gold statues which makes up most of the garden's fountains. The flow is choreographed to classical music. Try to get a place next to the fence at the lower level or at the front of the two buildings on the lower level with the covered porch.  The inside of the palace is as beautiful as the Hermitage. Enjoy

A must. Excellent collection of world-famous paintings and sculptures in one of the best museums in the world. Don't miss the stunning hardwood floors, every room is a wonder; peak out of the windows to admire the view of Vasilievsky island and the St.Paul and St.Peter Fortress and Cathedral across the Neva River

Avoid the weekend crowds. Do not go there on summer week-ends - the crowds are diminishing the pleasure of otherwise extremely attractive park with its gorgeous fountains. I loved the wind band, better than some concerts I've been to!
