The park would be a beauty any season, fall would be my favorite time - when fountains are still working, the park is golden and red and next to no people. It is kids-friendly, with plenty of food and ice-crean stands, funny kids fountains where they can get wet after stepping on a "secret stone". We did not make it inside the palace - the open hours were very inconvenient and the line was too long, but I heard it was restored to it's former splendor after decades of neglect by the Soviets. Definitely worth the visit!
Lots to see. Need to be very fit to do this tour but it is good to see, the gardens have lots of fountains and resemble Versaille

Go there by Peterhof Express. The Peterhof is beautiful and the garden is definitely worth walking around to see all the fountains. If you haven't already bought a tour package, go find the Peterhof Express super cool russian fast boats near the Hermitage Palace and get to the palace in about 30min! This is a faster option than a coach bus since the traffic in St. Petersburg is quite bad.

Splendor on the Baltic Sea. The palace and garden are a tribute to beauty and ingenuity. The gardens are majestic and manicured to perfection. The fountains are magnificent and amazing as they are all gravity fed. Be sure and take the time to watch them as they begin to flow at 11:00 a.m. The palace typifies the opulence of Peter the Great and provides insight into the life of the Czars,

Better if you dont go on Sundays. I liked the garden very much with all the fountains. The comparison with Versailles is not needed to love this place. The problem as almost in every museum in the city is the amount of visitors: too many.

Magnificent. Only had time to visit the Lower Park of Peterhof, but oh what a walking tour! The Grand Cascade with the Samson fountain, Greenhouse, Roman fountains, Cascade "the Chessboard", Amusement fountains ( oaklet, umbrella, bench), stunning view of the Gulf of Finland. I could have easily spent a full day just in the Lower Park! One of the most beautiful places I have ever seen!

Preserved beauty. I have been places and seen castles but nothing I have seen so far outbeats this one. The interiors are fascinating. They are well preserved to show its natural beauty and history. Each room is unique and different from the other. When you move from room to room, it is one fascination after another. The fountain garden was spectacular too!

The Fountains are really Spectacular. The grounds are very impressive, the restoration is going slowly but the quality is excellent.That said, the fountains are spectacular! The waterfor the fountains is supplied by some natural springs that feed into a reservoir, and are then shipped by pipeline, without any motors approximately 31 miles to the Palaces. The water is turned on at 10:00 a.m. every morning and turned off at 7:00 p.m. You can see the fountain height increasing at 10:00 a.m. All the fountains and water features on the entire palace lands are supplied through this gravity and water pressure system. When you see a fountain going 35 feet into the air without any motor to propel it, well, that's spectacular engineering. The water is released into the Baltic Sea which incidentally is approximately 35% fresh water. The Palaces are worth a visit just for the water show.

Brilliant. What a wonderful place to visit. There is so much to see inside the palace that like The Hermitage it cannot all be seen and taken in at one visit. Very popular so be ready for the queue. The gardens are exceptional and you can wander for hours and not see all of them.
Fantastic Gardens. Simply breathtaking Beautiful garden fountains best seen on a sunny day. Be mindful though there are very few toilets

St Peterhof Palace in August. Visiting St Petersburg must include a visit to the Peterhof Palace, especially in the summer months.Be sure to stay for the fountains performing their 5 hour routine. The water flows from a lake (quite a distance seats) about 70 metres higher than the Palace and is gravity fed only only.A lot has been said of the Palace's use of golf and the many paintings and sculptures. Best to get there early in the morning to try to get ahead of the large tours.One bit of advice is not to leave your jacket in the cloak room as it will take quite a while to retrieve afterwards.It is very easy to take pictures and, if a sunny day, beautiful pics of the water fountains leading away from the Palace.

breathtaking Palace. taking the boat from St Petersburg to Peterhof is a nice way to see the many forts, palaces and villas around the city. Arriving at Peterhof, purchase a ticket to enter the gardens of the Palace, and then follow the short path. The view of this palace is breathtaking, with magnificent gardens, fountains and outbuildings. Find the tree fountain, but beware of the water suddenly springing from the benches, catches many people out! Be wary of the ticket women who passes you through the gate. If you are a foreigner and have not told them when purchasing your ticket, she will make a lot of fuss and tell you and everyone nearby that you must go back and pay more! Perhaps the only down side to this attraction, foreigners are made to feel, well, like foreigners!
Lovely outdoor experience. You have to see the fountains here. Nice walk through the park to the hydrofoil boat ride back to the city.

Limited entrance to palace. Be aware that number of tickets to palace is limited! Big queues are forming in the morning, ticket office is open just from 12 to 14, and overall it is not worth waiting. Just enter the lower park and enjoy!
Nice. It was a nice drive to see this palace. It wasn't as grand or ornate as the other palaces, but it was worth the time. Great history and beautiful restoration.

Eat your heart out Versailles. Peter the Great visited Versailles as a young man and said to himself "I can do that." And did he ever. He personally designed the water system that feeds all the fountains. They are all done by gravity and can run all day. A little man comes out at the end of the day with the waterwheel key to turn them off at the end of the day while the national anthem blares loudly - it's all very Russian and pretty funny. Be sure to find a couple of the "trick" fountains, also designed by Peter. Also be sure to take a look at P-t-Gs little brick house down by the water. He really didn't like to live in palaces so he built himself a normal house and lots of workshops to fool around with all his projects. The plantings are lovely, the fountains are amazing, the woods and boulevards are serene: the whole experience is just wonderful. A total must-see.

Not to be missed!!!!. We were lucky to have a gorgeous sunny day to see the Peterhof Palace and Gardens. Plan plenty of time because the grounds are so beautiful and the fountains are extraordinary. It was a fantastic experience.

Breathtaking. On visiting this stunning palace it's quite easy to see why a revolution occurred. We'd never seen anything so ornate, or so covered in gold. Moreover, the gardens are really beautiful with numerous fountains and statues. This is definitely worth a visit, or even two.

CHECK OPENING DAYS. Before venturing onto the ferries ensure you check opening days and times. The gardens were open on Monday bit the palace was closed all day. Well worth a visit and a nice journey too. Stunning gardens
wonderful. The palace itself is beautiful, full of rooms ornamented mirrors, artwork ... and the garden with its fountains is a must

Fountains!. I took the hydrofoil - the easiest way - which takes about 30 minutes (be sure to check which line to return to and if you have a specific time you must return) but is the most expensive ($21 for a student). The trip is absolutely worth it - the grounds are a total knockout with beautiful gardens and many fountains, which are the draw here. We skipped the actual palace (only certain times are available for entrance to non-tour groups). We had a guide (who came with us) -its worth it if you can afford it. There's no signage or explanation, but the fountains are enjoyable without extra info. There are also some good sights and churches in the town (also where the guide came in handy). If you have time for only one excursion, this should be it (unless you have your heart set on seeing the amber room at Pushkin). The hydrofoil is easiest and quickest, but most expensive, route to get there. Canbe done in a half day if you get there early enough.
Awesome. The fountains are the highlight. The grounds are beautiful. Lots of walking and steps but the views are incredible and the fountains might make you forget Trevi in Rome.

Fountains and gold. The palace is a remider why the Tsars are no more. Oppulance shows itself in every room. Just when you think you've seen everything you go out into the gardens to see the most impressive fountain display. It is a must see.

The Peterhof Palace is stunning!. We travelled here (about an hour outside of St Petersburg) with a group. Even so, the crowds were daunting and at times, overwhelming. The building is beautiful and worth seeing, the gardens and fountains are spectacular. Although we arrived by bus, it is also possible to arrive by hydrofoil from St Petersburg and that must be a lovely trip indeed.

Exquisite fountains. While we did not go inside the palace itself, we did spend a great deal of time enjoying the elaborate and plentiful fountains in the gardens. They truly are amazing particularly considering the devastation they have seen over the years and the history of the preservation of some of the fountains is quite impressive. There are incredible views walking toward the water's edge and looking back toward the palace. Unfortunately we did not have as much time as we would have liked to spend in the gardens and were only able to see the main highlights but I think you could easily spend a few hours marveling at the fountains. Because Peterhof is quite out of the way, it is possible to catch a hydrofoil from the gardens directly across the water back to Petersberg.

Remarkable place. Rude people.. Wow. What an amazing spot. No tours available in English once you are there. that doesn't stop you getting gyped into a golf cart tour though. We agreed to do a tour with one of the guys who spoke English and then after some discussion between two of the drivers we ended up on a cart with someone who couldn't speak English and raced us around part of the site at break neck speed. We didn't tour the palace as we didn't have time but the grounds were amazing

Beautiful!. We took a hydrofoil boat to the grounds and arrived just as the fountains were turned on, it was an amazing sight! We toured with Alla tours from our Cruise ship. It was one of our favorite spots on our cruise.

Oh man!. What a remarkable place. Initially we were disappointed to arrive so late (645pm) but as we stood on one of the lower bridges, looking up at the palace, there was a recording of a tenor (?) singing something stirring as the fountains were shut off for the day.....wow! The gardens are lovely as is the artistry of the fountains. Plan to spend at least half a day there: fountains, flowers, sun and shade. Take the hydrofoil from St. Petersburg.

Nothing succeeds like excess!. Just incredible architecture, opulence and landscaping. We took the hydrofoil from behind the Hermitage and it was a lovely trip. We were lucky with great sunny weather, but you would really need an umbrella if it was raining.There are acres of park land and some nice cafes and restaurants. On the other side of the palace is the town, with plenty of food and drink options.The palace is swarming with tourists, but you just have to get in there and be one of them , take the amazing photos and marvel at the decadence of the Tsars.

The parklands and fountains are lovely. We travelled by hydrofoil from Dvortsavaya (behind the Hermitage) for 1100 rubles per person return. It’s an easy way to get there and back– boats runs on the hour and half hour and take about 35 minutes to get there. There are few photo opportunities on the way as you pass between fairly unattractive industrial river sites before crossing open water. You will also be given a sales spiel by someone hoping to interest you in DVD’s, calendars and fridge magnets!It costs 450 rubles each to get into the lower park. Any entries to palaces and museums are extra. We arrived just in time for the fountain start up on Saturday at 11 am to some fairly dreary Russian music. The fountains cascading down from the checkerboard terrace to the Gulf of Finland with gold statuary are fabulous. Initially there was a bit of a crush – with all the tourists gathering in the one place. However after the fountains started up the crowds gradually dispersed and it was all quite manageable.We didn’t go into the main palace – first of all because photography isn’t allowed, and secondly because we’ve visited other sumptuous palaces in Europe and didn’t think this would offer anything we haven’t already seen.The parklands are beautiful – with some glorious water features. However, in many places there is a run-down feeling – especially some of the outlying buildings which are in very poor repair. Also, because of the captive audience you will be subjected to dreadful food concessions or very ordinary restaurants. My recommendation would be to pack a picnic, or wait till you return to St Petersburg to eat!

The Fountains are Awesome!. Yes, by all means visit the palace too, but the highlight of the visit for me was the fountains. Never have seen such a display, and to think they are all gravity fed! After visiting Catherine's Palace, the palace here was nice, but there was not as much open the the public yet. Amazingly ornate though, and worth the visit also.
Exquisite gardens. At 11;00am the fountains go on simultaneously, Water gushes out of shiny gold statues. It's impossible to describe how awesome this is. It's a must see!

Summer Palace - simply perfect!. The Tzars and Tsarinas had great taste in palaces! This is an amazing and wonderfully magical place. The restoration of this palace has been incredible and the golden statues and fountains are simply beautiful. The interior of the palace has been refurbished to a level which makes it appear as the original. Silk covered walls with fabulous furniture and exquisite ornaments prevail. (However, be aware of the big cues in the summer months but they do move along quite quickly.) The gardens down to the sea are worth a visit too and snacks are available as you make your way through the tree lined paths. This is an essential attraction when visiting St.Petersburg and affords the traveller a view of the lovely suburbs of this incredible city.
A must see. When we went it was raining. This did not spoil the beauty of this place. We did not go inside,but the fountains and scenery was awesome and a must see if you go to st petersburg.

A Must See - Wear Comfortable Shoes. The Fountains are Amazing. The Garden area Huge and the interior tour is beautiful. Note: 1.Buy TWO tickets at the dock one for the Garden and separate ticket to go inside the building and see the interior. (Def do the interior tour of the building its very unique to see how it was decorated) 2. The interior tour is only done in English, but you can break away from the group tour and just walk thru on your own. 3. They do NOT let you take Pictures of the interiors.4. Wear comfortable shoes, it has huge gardens paths to walk around and see fountains other than the main ones. 5 Also Buy a Round Trip Hydrofoil ticket. I walked all the way to the boat to go back and was told I only had a one way ticket....and had to walk 5 minutes back to the booth which is located at the FAR end of the dock. 6. Interesting Fact I Learned, the building and fountains were almost totally destroyed in the war and the entire place has be re-constructed to what it used to look like....check out the black and white photo book in the gifts shop at the end of the tour to see the pics of the destruction.

Worth the visit (!!! I ONLY visited the gardens!!!). ... so I cannot tell about the Palace. But the reason why I wasn't in, is that the queue was HUGE (it was Saturday, so I could have expected it). I took a Meteor boat there (big queue for the Meteor ticket, then had to wait more then an hour to take the boat.. again, Saturday, if you can avoid, do so). The trip to Peterhof is not charming at all (I wanted wind!!!!!), like a fast ferry, takes about 45 minutes.The gardens are impressive, it's large, full of fountains... I guess the question is how much have you seen this kind of stuff all ready: my canadians friends very fascinated. I have been to a lot of garden palaces in France, Germany, and found a lot of them more charming. But this is personnal. It was REALLY crowded. Russian girls seem to dress up for hours to have photo shoots there, which for me was an funny thing to watch. Overall, I liked it but did not loved it, maybe also because I was on my own. If you have only a couple of days, then spend them in the Hermitage and walking around.

Worth a visit. We were lucky enough to be at Peterhof when the fountains were turned on for the day. The "turn-on" was accompanied by stirring Russian music. This was my favourite thing about Peterhof.

Wonderful! Palace and Gardens are Outstanding. Peterhof should be on everyone's "must see" list. The inside tour is terrific but is overshadowed by the grounds. We timed our visit so that we watched the fountains coming on stream (around 11 am) which was very cool. Seeing the opulence of the Tsars is a real contrast with the abject existence of the serfs. Makes you wonder why it took so long for the Revolution. Although we didn't do it, we heard that the hydrofolio from downtown saves time and is a good experience.

Golden Palace. Wow! This Palace almost everything in gold is worth every visit. We had a tour guide, who was not very pleasant at all, cold, and recount stories as if she read it from the book! she was quite boring! But the visit itself was worthwhile. The tour guide suggested to visit the "wonderful garden" which to our taste was very ordinary, she also suggested to take the ferry boat insteadof the bus we came with for the beautiful scenery..but none of that we saw!

Masterpiece of Russian Artistry. Wonderful, beautiful, fun, interesting, just fabulous. The grand colonnade of fountains that lead to and direct your eyes to the Baltic Sea with the surrounding gardens is a true masterpiece. We enjoyed the ornate baroque interiors of the Grand Palace but not as much as the fountains and the gardens. We toured the gardens and the grottos to learn more about the remarkable engineering and history, the inner workings of the tremendous variety of fountains, along with the extravagance and playfulness of the time period. It was great fun, we spent most of the day after a long drive there (interesting to be on a Russian Freeway), exploring the palace, gardens & lunch. We took the hydrofoil back to the city, a perfect way to visit, drive there to see a different view of the area then a quick hydrofoil back to the city.

Huge, Beautiful, Must See. This place took awhile to get to, but was absolutely magnificent. The admission fees are so cheap. Adult Russians- about 9 dollars, Adult Foreigners- about 14 dollars. Children are cheaper of course. You can spend the entire day here. This is probably the most astounding place I've ever visited for it's size, detail, and the fountains...fountains and more fountains...all remarkable. It was like being in a magical kingdom, and the stress from normal day life was non-existent. Best tip I can give you is to wear the most comfortable shoes you own when visiting here.
Palace, Gardens and Gold. The place is huge and offers lots of nice sights. Great place to walk around. Easily accessible if youre staying in SPB by marshrutka.

Peter the Great was agoraphobic. I found the grounds to be the highlight of this site. You have to remember that Peter the Great built St. Petersburg out of marshland and water, much like Venice. He was the first Russian ruler to go to the West to learn whatever he could. He brought Western-like ideas back to Russia. He had been to the Court in France and patterned Peterhof after Versailles. But this palace is modest compared to the Hermitage and Catherine's Palace. There is much less baroque flourishes and gold, but it is still grand and beautiful. The fountains are varied and fascinating. Make sure to walk around the grounds to see Peter's beach "cottage". This is where he went to escape all of the people in the Palace. It is actually a quiet spot next to the water and has lovely gardens and aviaries nearby.

Mini Versailles. This Palace is amazing and beatiful and should be on top of everyones visit to St. Petersburg. As nice and beautiful it is, Versailles in France is still the number one Palace when it comes to glamour, luxury and Size!

A stunningly beautiful. It's a must in saint petersburg, the best way to go there is by hydrofoil early in the morning, the palace is beautiful and the fountains are different than usual and very Special.
Beautiful. Beautiful gardens and also the fountains were really fantastic, we saw them turn the fountains on and it was quite magical.We didn't go inside as photography is forbidden

Superb weather - superb gardens. We chose to travel there and back by hydrofoil from the jetty at the back of the Hermitage. It is not the cheapest way to get there but it was stress free and a pleasant journey. We only went into the lower gardens to see the stunning gardens and fountains. We had read that if we went in to the upper garden we couldn't get back in without repaying so we avoided them. The fountains are superb - some are fun ones and some are classical style. Go see the 'water road' on the hour where people stand for a 2 minute shower - very noisy and wet - great fun to join in or watch others getting wet. There were visiting pipe players on our day there - very good. We also enjoyed a more peaceful time sitting on the grass banks overlooking the sea. We did feel that everywhere seemed to have an extra admission fee but to be honest there was so much to see in the gardens it did not matter. People on our tour went via a coach and had a guide but it sounds like we enjoyed ourselves more and we could stop whenever we wanted and not be marched around.

The Summer Palace not Dampened by Rain. Our tour had us at Peterholf on a rainy day and it was still amazing. The fountains will be something that we will always remember. Again a guide is excellent as you get a much richer experience touring the grounds with someone who knows that the Adam & Eve fountains are separated (so they can avoid temptation). We did not have a chance to wander into the palace and heard from friends who have been that it would have been worth it. Really was one of the highlights of our trip.

Gardens. I have been to a number of the grand palaces in the world including Versailles- these are the most beautiful gardens and grounds that I have ever seen. We walked around for about three hours and saw the 'turning on the fountains' ceremony. The gold statues and checkerboard waterfall were beyond gorgeous. We took a hydrofoil from St. Petersburg to the palace. There is a dock right on the graounds of the palace.

Gotta see it. I've never been to Versailles, but hope to someday. In the meantime, the opportunity to visit Peterhof was too good to pass up.Keeping the various palaces, museums, churches, etc. of SPB straight can be daunting. Finally, I understood that Peterhof is the complex of palaces and gardens originally begun by Peter the Great. Located at least 30 minutes outside the city, Peterhof sits on the shores of the Gulf of Finland. Approaching the main building, the "upper gardens" set a formal and quiet tone. These resemble a park with rows of tightly-trimmed trees, rather than fancy show gardens. The interior rooms form wave upon wave of glitz, gilt and glamour. Our guide provided excellent commentary, but my head was spinning from everything there was to see.Once outside behind the main building, we could see the "lower gardens" flow toward the gulf. Peter created a series of spectacular fountains that remain powered by gravity, rather than pumps. The engineering is remarkable, but the beauty of design is fantastic. You may enjoy the architecture and interior design the most. For us the highlight was the landscaping. Either way, there is plenty to knock your socks off at Peterhof.

Please let me live in a house like this!. Positives: The architecture is amazing! I have never seen anywhere like it. I love walking around the gardens.Negatives: We had so much rain that day, It put a real dampener on the atmosphere and spirits of visitors. Peterhof's palace is packed with visitors and having 'wet' visitors made everything worse. Also we couldn't take pictures in the building, and I found that I preferred to be outside in the gardens than in the palace due to the amount of people crammed in.NB Beware of pick-pockets!

Beautiful. If you have more than a day or two in St Petersburgh, this is a beautiful place to visit. It takes about 30 minutes to get there by boat/water taxi. Bring a jacket. Dressing in the costumes (at the Adam fountain) was a really fun thing to do. Great pictures!

More beatiful than Versailles. Peterhof Palace and Garden is something almost indescribable!Although it is not so big as Versailles, gold is everywhere (it is richer and most sumptuous than Versailles). I've never seen such a place as this in all the world - from most than 40 countries - where I've been through.St. Petersburg has a lot of very interesting places to visit. But from all of them, Peterhof, for me, was the best!A problem: when we've been there, it was very, very crowded! But, even so, it was an unforgettable experience!!!
Favorite Place in St. Petersburg. This place was amazing. There were so many beautiful fountains and so much history. The grounds were immaculate and the palace was breathe taking.

beautiful exterior walls. Looks imposing as one approaches the palace ,only to find its is newly painted gold and blue ,pretty newly painted gold fountains.disappointed unable to see inside apparently was destroyed in the war.
Some Kind of WOW!. Move over Monaco, this is opulence to the max. Just outside the spectacular rooms of the palace are the fountains through the gardens. It is all breathtaking.

Peterhof pavillion and garden perfection. This is a must for travellers to St Petetrsberg the fountains are the most fabulous I have ever seen, with a visual sweep down to the bay of Finland. Peter the Great loved pranks and his hidden fountains that when you walk over them suddenly start spraying water are just so much fun. The engineering feat was amazing all done with natural gravity. The Peterhof itself is not as large as the Catherine Palace, but the restoration was beautiful. The Peterhof was bombed to bits with the German occupation of St Petersberg, so the work that has been carried out sine is spectacular. We went on a a Cunard arranged trip from the ship, but there are several companies that also arrange trips to this wonderful palace. the journey there was good too very interesting driving through all the Dachas( summer homes) passed down through families.

Fantastic!. There are some magnificent views to be had whilst at the Peterhof Palace and Gardens - something for everyone!Certainly go and have a look at all of the fountains - I won't go into too much detail but some of them offer a nice surprise!You could spend all day here, weather dependant. It's nice to look around, however, from memory, you're not allowed to sit on the grass as they are trying to preserve the beauty of the gardens and this could encourage litter etc. There are benches etc, however, so all is not lost.
Exquisite. There are no words to describe Peterhof that would give the place justice! You have to go and visit if in St Petersburg. Just be prepared for the crowds and the high cost!

amazing. The weather was perfect for a stroll in a park. Beautiful gardens with all these small cottages, palaces and fountains. My children enjoyed tricky fountains that are hidden in different parts of the park.

Beautiful!. This palace was my favourite. The inside is full of gold and interesting to see. The gardens are breath taking and are worth the visit alone. We went with a tour guide who was able to give the history of the place.

Peterhof Palace and Gardens. Absolutely brilliant. Another opulent palace in a beautiful location. The palace and gardens are wonderful. You can understand why the Czars of the times spent a lot of time here.

must see!. If you ever go to St.Petersburg, you must see this place! At 11 o'clock sharp the main fountains start to work and the music plays and it seems like heaven on Earth! We spent there 2 hours just walking around. It is amazing!

Magnificent. Truly one of the outstanding tourist attractions in the world. The palace has been restored to grandiose proportions. The gardens are extremely well maintained and extensive with multiple fountains and water displays. The only downside is that during the high season there are so many tour groups that one cannot pause during the in palace portion of your visit. There is always another group pressing from behind. Also as you will be told there are only 60 days a year of sunshine in St. Petersburg. Be prepared for rain which is a frequent occurrence. It is a fairly long walk from the gardens to the bus areas especially if it's raining. Come prepared.

Prepare to get wet!. Water water everywhere! This was truly the most extensive display of fountains and the gardens were a real delight. WE took the hydrofoil to reach the gardens. A great way to travel!
hard to think there could be that much gold leaf!. what a beautiful palace and garden. We were there on a rainy day and it was still glittering! A definite highlight -

Awesome ......allow some hours to check this one out!. Overall this Palace, after hearing its history, is one that shows opulence and a complete show of might and power.....and of course this situation at the time of build, does mean that ordinary people suffer . But then after its destruction during WW2 , the absolute resolve to rebuild, is a resolute effort to declare....we will Not be robbed of our heritage.....and this in itself gives the people a sense of National pride. We need to congratulate this nation, which has been through much, and still stands tall. The gardens are spectacular as well with water features and gilded statues creating an awesome spectacle........a must see! So in a nutshell, this Palace is spectacular both inside and outside.The gardens are also spectacular!

Expensive visit but a great place to see. You'll need a full day just for the gardens and palaces/pavilions spread throughout the gardens. Unfortunately you cannot enter the palace without paying for the garden ticket first, so try to visit it on the same day if you can't afford a double visit to the park. It's one of their numerous money-making tricks, including extra payment to get permission to take photos inside the palace.It's opulent and beautiful and really gives you an idea of the glorious past of this city together with its oppression of its people to achieve this. The visit to the grotto is recommended (costs extra again) as it gives good background on how Peter the Great came up with the concept and engineering of the numerous fountains at Peterhof.You can get the "rocket" hydrofoil from/to Peterhof directly to/from the banks outside the Winter Palace. I wouldn't suggest a visit to both on the same day though as both locations deserve their own day.

difficult to get to and not sure if worth it!. The palace is beautifully restored and picturesque, however, I'm not certain it is worthy of a visit.There is not much there other than the amber room.. and I suppose the fountains if you go in the summer months. (I went in the winter)Getting there was also difficult! via the train from st. petersburg, but was quite an adventure.. busses from the train station are equally as badly indicated as the train itself! maybe I should just have gotten the tour bus from nevsky prospect!!

The gardens are magnificent. We visited the gardens with a small tour group. The outside is magnificent. The fountains and statues are spectacular. There are lots of fountains and the grounds are very well maintained. It is a wonderful place to wander around if you like gardens.
A lovely scenic stroll. We spent about four hours walking through the gardens taking in the fountains. This is a really nice way to spend an afternoon - but wear comfy shoes!

A real 'must see' - just fabulous!. Beautiful gardens full of fountains and gold statues; a canal with bridges leads up to the palace with a golden swan for transport. Musicians played classical music in the grounds.The palace is being refurbished to its former glory and is quite spectacular both outside and in. You need to buy a ticket to the garden before you can buy a ticket to the palace - all well worth it!
Bring umbrella, tennies. The weather turned bad for about 15 minutes; you'll enjoy it more if you've got comfortable shoes on.

Magnificent. Excellent and extremely beautiful house and gardens. The statuary in the garden us magnificent. On-site restaurant made it easy to grab lunch and have more time for touring. The Sea of Finland is beautiful.

Magnificent Gardens. We visited during June 2012 on a gorgeous sunny day. The gardens were quite busy with tourists like ourselves who had arrived by the hydrfoil, a great way to get there. Beautifully maintained gardens with many statues, fountains and huge old trees. The fountains and statues were truely spectacular. The Palace was mind blowing with lots of gold. Fabulous art work and furniture. Incredible wealth being very evident. Hard to imagine the place covered in snow during the long winters. . Bring good walking shoes to really enjoy the gardens. Be very carefull of pickpockets as one of our group had her wallet stolen from her bag while strolling in the grounds.

Unbelievable!. Amazing beautiful fountains and gardens. We spent a couple of hours here on a two day tour. Could have spent much longer. Do be aware of pickpockets though for one had my friends purse unzipped before our guide made her aware of the situation.

Peter wanted to rival Versailles - and he succeeded!. Walking through this beautifully restored palace evokes a feeling of awe. The architecture from floors to ceilings, furnishings and art are all stunning. The splendor continues outdoors throughout terraced fountains, gilded sculptures, wooded walkways leading to manicured flowering gardens and gravity-flowing water features. Note: Individuals are not allowed to take pictures inside the main building, so be prepared to buy a souvenir book!
Hydrofoil ride makes it better. Lots of fountains and very little flowers. Interest but very crowded. Not really sure it was worth the 4hr we spent.

Absolutely Gorgeous!. We traveled with our tour group to see this stunning palace. The gardens and fountains are just a sight to see if staying in St. Petersburg. We were so fortunate to have had a perfect sunny day. We took time on our own to do the extra Grotos tour which takes you underneath the fountains to see the inner workings. Well worth it! You also get to have the opportunity to take photos directly from behind the middle of the fountains looking down and out as well as at the bottom from behind the fountains. What amazing photos we took that you can't get otherwise!

Peterhof Palace and Garden. To walk among the palatial Gardens at the Peterhof is an amazing and breathtaking adventure. These Gardens and its extravagant statues and features gives you insight into the man who created his vision now for the world to see.
The highlight of our trip!. Don't miss this! It was the high point of our three day visit to StP and worth the drive. Exquisite and beyond description!

Wow - breathtaking! Tips for Wheelchair users!. My sister and I visited this beautiful Palace as a shore trip from a P&O Baltic Cruise. It easily earned a place in my Top 10 of wonderful places to visit - the fountains and the gardens were breathtaking and you really need a full day here to do it justice. The interiors are equally as breathtaking and have been restored to perfection. A must-see on a visit to St Petersburg!Top tip for wheelchair users:Just about every palace and museum in St Petersburg has the most beautifully restored parquet/inlaid floors and paper slippers/shoe covers are required to be worn by all visitors. Having hired a brand new wheelchair on board The Arcadia, we were (very fortunately) allowed to go around the Palaces because it had new, clean, light coloured wheels. People who had older, black rubber wheels on their chairs were being refused entry. You do not argue with Russian matriarchs working in Museums and Palaces!!! If you plan to visit with a wheelchair, I would highly recommend making some white towelling or cotton wheel covers that can be slipped on to protect the floor from being marked by your wheels.The beautiful gardens are easily accessible with gently sloping zig zag paths and the fountains - hundreds of them - must not be missed!The male staff were very helpful and allowed us to use the goods lift between floors in Peterhof, Catherine Palace and The Hermitage but there is generally little awareness/consideration for the needs of wheelchair users in smaller places and churches. Hope this helps!
The Versailles of Russia.. Beautiful gardens, stunning palace and water features, we travelled up the Neva River by hydrofoil, which we enjoyed.

Peterhof Palace St Petersberg. The building, the rooms, and the grounds were all equally spectacular. The use of gold highlights was extensive even on the statues in the gardens outside. Certainly the best I have seen.

Don't miss this attraction. If you are in St Petersburg, you must see this attraction. It was designed after Versailles which I also visited 2 weeks later, and compared in design and beauty. Unfortunately, it was a rainy day so not as much fun to visit the gardens. Remember your raincoat, hat & umbrella to enjoy it fully.
Superb. Great visit and very enjoyable.....just wonderful and relaxing......getting there is easy too would highly recommend

Great afternoon out of St. Petersburg. We spent a wonderful afternoon at Peterhof Palace and Gardens. We took the hydrofoil from behind the Hermitage which is a great scenic and short (at least shorter than driving) way to get there. The palace was closed, but we spent the better part of an afternoon just exploring the gardens. The palace is closed more often on the last week of the month for extra cleaning days. This is a pricey trip, but definitely worth it!

An exceptional display of fountains. Best enjoyed with a guide.. You couldn't possibly absorb all of the beauty and history of this site without the assistance of a knowledgeable guide. Not to be missed.

Beautiul - Both Inside and Out. It's incredibly easy to get to Peterhof (take a hydrofoil from the Winter Palace), and as soon as the hydrofoil pulls up you know you're seeing something incredible. My husband and I debated using a guide for Peterhof for days, and we eventually decided why not, let's use a guide to see both Peterhof and Catherine's Palace (on different days). I'm so glad we did! It seemed that people who visited without a guide were wandering around aimlessly. To my knowledge there are no audioguides, and the rooms within the palace don't have information of any sort. We visited slightly later in the day (toured the palace around 3) and I think that was a good time for it. Most people travel in huge tour groups that are bussed in earlier, so when my husband, guide, and I were walking around it was as if we had the entire place to ourselves. The grounds are so beautiful and you can spend a day there easily. There are so many different fountains, pavilions, and other attractions to keep you occupied. This part of Peterhof you can certainly do on your own. Be mindful that there are separate tickets for each part of Peterhof. The lower park/fountains is the area that you walk through when you arrive at Peterhof from the hydrofoil, and then you get another ticket for the Grand Palace, and another ticket for any pavilions My guide had taken care of all our ticketing, but there were several tourists wandering around by themselves who came over and asked us where to get this ticket or that ticket. I recommend visiting Peterhof without hesitation! On a nice day, plan to hang around and wander the gardens more than usual. If the weather isn't cooperating, just seeing the palace is worth the trip. It truly is exquisite and if you're traveling to Saint Petersburg, this is a must. And again, while the grounds can certainly be done on your own, I without hesitation recommend getting a guide to truly appreciate the palace.
Stunning. We visited Peterhof Palace and Garden as part of our T J Travel Tour, we found the gardens, fountains and gold statues stunning, a must see if in St,Petersburg

Versailles in Russia. The Peterhof Palace was inspired by Versailles. Some could say it is a replicat to a large extent. You are not allowed to take pictures, not even without a flash. A lady in each room is watching and will get on you agressively if you do take picture... beware. You don't mess up with Russian watchladies. Make sure to be there for the start of the fountains at 11:00am. It is accompanied with music and is the most wonderful fountains I ever saw. These fountains work with gravity, not pump!

Beautiful gardens.. Beautiful gardens, well maintained. Traveled with my adult daughters and an 11 year old grandson. Lots of flowers and flower beds. A lot of walking. My grandson enjoyed it for most of the time but about half way through he started playing his game boy. The boat ride to get there was fun.
STUNNING. One of the most beautiful sights I have seen in a life filled with travel. Make sure you get there in plenty of time to watch the amazing Turning on the Fountains ceremony.

Spectacular gardens and fountains. Definitely a must-do on any trip to St. Petersburg. There are plenty of hydrofoils that take you direct from the riverbank in St. Petersburg to Peterhof, but be aware that the first ones are scheduled to leave at 10am. They usually leave about 10 minutes late, it takes 30 to 35 minutes to make the crossing across the Gulf of Finland, and there is a decent queue at the other end to get tickets in. Which means that making the 11am "Fountain Launch" show is rather tight. Next time I would look at train options and get there a little earlier to get a good position.There is also a system of ticket buying for the Grand Palace which I still don't completely understand. Effectively, foreign tourists can only buy their entry tickets between 12 and 2, and then again from 4.15 until 6.30, with Russian locals and tour groups allowed in between. Not sure how they get their tickets, because they actually close the ticket booths from 2 till 4.15. A little confusing, but the end result, the tour through the Summer Palace, is spectacular and not to be missed.Food options a little disappointing though, so be prepared!
Amazing fountains. This garden and palace are well worth a visit. The fountains are incredible and the palace amazingly opulent. The trip on the hydro foil is also worth while.
A must see!. We didn't go in the palace but th gardens and fountains were wonderful, There are no pumps and the statues are covered in gold. It is well worth the visit.
Beautiful!. The palace is beautiful and the gardens are a real bonus. We got to see the 11 AM fountain activation - just gorgeous. Allow plenty of time to stroll the gardens.

the palace and gardens. The palace was beautiful all the architecture and the gilding a mamoth task, the layout of the rooms such spleandor and opulence. Then you go into the gardens. Nothing can prepare you for the sight that greets you AMAZING.....

OK if you are Russian.. A beautiful building BUT we had to wait for 90 minutes because we were not Russians!
Russia needs to import modern PR consultants.

At least half a day. You will need plenty of time here if you want to explore the interior and gardens. You could do this without the need for a guide - in fact you woul have more time without a guide. Get them before 11am so that you can see the fountains come alive - accompanied by the St Petersburg national athem. Also arrive early and try to get nside before all the large tour groups.

Gold gold gold and fountains. Gardens, fountains and the palace itself are all wonderful.We went in the afternoon and the walk through the palace was slow and crowded with tour groups. So if you are independent, be prepared to be patient. It does make you stop and look around at the incredible details. Its been restored wonderfully after being bombed in war and it is opulent. You are not allowed to take any photos inside palace :(Outdoors be sure to go to the back of the palace also for more gardens and fountains. A lovely day out f rhe weather is nice. We took a hydrofoil from outside the hermitage. It takes 30 mins each way and costs 1100 roub return each. They run every 20 mins or so.

A must see in The suburbs of Saint Petersburg. A magnificent Palace of tremendous size in the suburbs of Saint Petersburg on the Gulf of Finland. The only drawback is that photography by tourists is forbidden within the palace. The I renal and external architecture is magnificent befitting a royal residence. The gardens are more elaborate than at perhaps any other palace in the world.

PETERHOF PALACE AND GARDEN. Its a very large palace - we didn't get to go inside but enjoyed the gardens and surrounds - make sure you don't miss any of the "mystery" fountains but go on a hot sunny day!

Garden is incredible!. Really an amazing experience to see this garden that was originally built so long ago and then rebuilt after the Nazi occupation. We were there on a gloomy rainy day, but it was still awesome. We were also able to witness the trick fountains in use, which was cool.

An enjoyable day out. The Church a must see!. After arriving by hydrofoil, you pay 450R to enter (about £9) again, like most places in StP, each 'attraction' is priced. AVOID THE FIRST SET OF TOILETS - there are 4 or more others (regular public toilets) within the area.Due to the queue for the Great Palace, I happily chose to miss it. I did, however, visit the beautiful Church attached to its left hand side. 400R for the pleasure and each visitor is required to wear the foot gloves (provided). I instantly felt as though it was a very special place. The interior is ornately decorated with gold and irrespective of language, it is easy to distinguish people/images in the beautiful art work- the last supper, Mary, the disciples, baptism in the river Jordan and so on. Because there was little information in English, I would have loved a separate guide or audio guide for this short visit (without having to obtain one for the whole attraction).Plenty of fast food, ice creams and drinks available.WEAR CLOSED SHOES-gravel paths make open toed shoes or sandals infuriating to wear.700R for mini train the whole way around, although if you're Russian it'll probably be cheaper!

Massive gardens, be ready for lots of walking. Lovely gardens filled with fountains and gold statues, but really really extensive so allow plenty if time and bring lots of water to drink. There are sections of structured gardens interspersed throughout glades if trees over grass. It would be perfect to explore on a segue but nobody seems to have started this business yet. It is 450r entry to the gardens and 1100r return on the hydrofoil which seems pretty expensive, as the palace and other buildings are additional cost again. Still worth a visit though.

great place to spend a sunny day. I realy recommend to go there on a sunny ( or just warm and pleasent day), cause the sun will make sparks and reflections and all the fountains will show you all the grace they have. And if you are brave enough try going there without excursion, by bus(complicated way), or by meteor-boat (less complicated), just to have the opportunity to walk there as you please, and enjoing the place at your speed. I hope this tip will help you, have a nice time in Peterhof!
Peterhoff. Beautiful grounds. Wish we had more time to explore and relax in this area. Great place for a picnic lunch.

Another marvel. Build by Peter the Great, this palace and its adjacent gardens with water that is flowing and blowing everywhere, are a tribute to the ambitions of this Tsar. An even greater tribute to the Russians who restored the palace to its original state after the Germans left it all but ruined in 1994.Best way to get there: take the fast boat that departs in front of the Hermitage.

4 Aussies. Beautiful gardens and amazing fountains. No wheelchair access was available inside the Palace on the day we visited. However the weather was a perfect sunny day to stroll the gardens. The gardens have so much to see. There are many sculptures, an assortment of pavilions, at least three aviaries, attractively designed terraces, fun fountains and lawn areas edged by colourful flower beds. There were numerous paths through established groves of shady trees with even a resident squirrel.

Peterhof Garden is beautiful. We were at the Peterhof Garden on a rainy day in July. The fountains are abundant and beautiful. I have been to many countries and seen many beautiful gardens and these are the most amazing gardens / fountains I have ever visited. Even in the rain the gardens are a must see.
Peterhof. My favorite part is the fountains. This is Russia's version of the gardens of Versailles. Great place for a walk and respite from busy streets and buildings.

Peterhof. Trying to tell someone about the beauty and size of Peterhof, is like showing someone a picture of the Grand Canyon. Unless, you truly experience it, pictures and words don't come close to its beauty.

A beautiful place to visit in summer. We arrived by boat (as the Tsar's guests would have arrived). A beautiful palace with plenty of gold everywhere. The fountains are a must - very impressive. Be sure to visit late morning for music and opening of the largest fountains. Wait until the crowds have moved away for best photo opportunities.

A visit to St Petersburg must include Peterhof. We visited in the first week of May at the beginning of the season. Even this early, after winter, the crowds made full enjoyment of the magnificent interiors difficult. I dread to imagine how crowded it must be in mid summer. Most visitors arrive in a party or join a tour at the palace. A good tip is to go with a small party, travelling in a minibus rather than a large coach party. Official guides , that you will get with a tour are an absolute must, as the depth of their knowledge is vast, and they can make it come alive. Being with a small party means that you can be more fluid and agile whilst progressing around the palace. You can book a tour with a small operator online before you leave home, so if you are going on a cruise take this option, rather than the cruise company's tour which will be twice as expensive, you will not need a visa as long as you are on a tour, this applies to all the others on the cruise itinery and will give you relief from trudging around with sixty people on a bus.The interiors are truly astounding, having been restored over the last thirty or forty years from the burnt out shells left behind by the Wermacht. The restoration has provided work on a huge scale by generations of craftsmen and is of superlative quality. If the congestion of the interior puts you off,the exterior with its magnificent fountains is just as opulent as the inside, and the gardens are vast offering the opportunity of a good walk. It was raining when we visited and even then the garden was inspiring with excellent photographic opportunities,incidentally photography is permitted inside which is refreshing.Despite the crowds it is well worth a visit and is uniquely beautiful.

The gardens are incredible. No visit to St Petersburg is complete without making the trek to Peterhof. The gardens are incredible, surpassing even Versailles. The fountains are impressive, and it's lovely just to stroll around the grounds and imagine what life must have been like for the ruling family. Don't miss.
Loved Visiting Peterhof. You have got to read Catherine the Great before you go. You will love visiting Peterhof. The gardens are gorgeous and the palace is spectacular

Fantasy Land. Loved this place, could have spent the entire day. Am an avid gardener so this place was great for me. Take the hydrofoil, great experience. Beware of pick pocketers, signs every where warning people.

You will not regret!. Peterhof not leave anyone indifferent. Coming here once, want to visit this city again and again. Such a variety of fountains I have never met. Looks great. And each has its own history. In Peterhof you can enjoy not only the fountains, and a lot of monuments, architectural buildings, museums and numerous parks worthy of attention. And You can visit the coast of Gulf of Finland! Park with fountains is so large and diverse, that the whole day is not enough.Those, who just will want to go to Peterhof - necessarily will go! You will not regret!

Wow!. Peterhof is amazing! Its not called the Russian Versaille for nothing - the gardens are huge and are filled with fountains. We visited by Hydrofoil that we embarked near the Winter Palace (Hermitage) - the easiest way to get there imo. Plan an entire day to visit as it is trick to do it in less than that.

Fabulous Fountains.. I loved the water displays and the fact that although the Germans destoyed the palace they did not ruin the fountains and the Tsras little water jokes! Although the palace was almost destroyed by the Germans (the photos of the destruction are shocking) it has been restored to as it was. The contents were removed before the Germans got there and safely stored-very canny people the Russians

Very crowded, but beautiful. This attraction is about 30km away from the heart of St Petersburg, and the best way to enjoy the Peterhof as a free-and-easy tourist without catered transport is to take the marshrutka at least once, and the hydrofoil at least once. I took the marshrutka to the Peterhof (R70), and then after my visit took the Hydrofoil back to St Petersburg (R650 or R450 for students), however the reverse is entirely possible and equally recommended too.The marshrutka is a private numbered bus that goes a specific route and you pay the driver a fee in cash to go to a certain place on its route. I took the metro to Avtovo Metro station, got out and took the Marshrutka which took me directly to the Peterhof Upper Park (free).Take note that the correct Marshrutkas to take are numbered: 224, 300, 424, 424A. Look out for "ФОНТАНЫ" and "ПЕТЕРГОФ" on the bus to confirm, or tell the driver you're going towards "Petergof Fontany" - yes pronounce it THAT WAY.This may sound complicated - so why take the the Marshrutka one-way + hydrofoil one-way, over taking the hydrofoil both ways?! TWO REASONS - you pay much less and you get to see so much more.The platform at Avtovo station is considered one of the the most beautiful of them, with its ornate glass pillars and a mosaic dedicated to the Leningrad Blockade.Around the base of the dome in the hall, it says "Eternal glory to the brave defenders of Leningrad who vindicated their city!"Look out for the glass-cut columns at the platform. Physicists worked with artists to ensure that light that shone through the transparent glass cuttings were reflected within the facets without ever reaching the concrete pillars it was wrapped around, thereby effectively rendering the pillars invisible!Meanwhile, the benefits of the hydrofoil to/from the Peterhof is that you get to see the Gulf of Finland (and Finland itself from a distance), and convenience - you get delivered to a dock just behind the State Hermitage in St Petersburg where you probably will be staying.Now for the actual review of the Peterhof! If you took the Marshrutka like I did, you'll have to walk through the Upper Garden before finding the ticket booth to pay the entrance fee for the Lower Garden. The Upper Garden was decent and pretty, but can absolutely not be compared with the awesome beauty of the Lower Garden with all its gravity-powered fountains!Many museums within the Peterhof estate have different closing days, and in any case it's extremely expensive and time consuming to visit all the attractions in the Peterhof, as they all charge separate admission fees. If you have limited time or money, be sure to visit at least the Upper (free) and Lower Gardens (R450, or R250 for students), as well as the Grand Palace (R550, or R300 for students).Things to note:- For some reason, the Upper Garden (free) is towards the south, and the Lower Garden in the north - don't get confused!- The hydrofoil pier is at the northernmost tip of the Lower Garden - you cannot access the pier and take the hydrofoil without going through the Lower Garden and paying for its admission.- If you intend on taking the Hydrofoil to the Peterhof both ways (there and back), do not leave the gates of the Lower Park, as you will not be allowed any re-entry (this is also stated on the website). However certain sources say that the guards exercise discretion on this - I would not bank heavily on that! In any case, as the Lower Park is vastly superior to the free Upper Park, you won't miss much by remaining in the boundaries of the Lower Park since the other main attraction, the Grand Palace, is within the confines of the Lower Park.
Better than Versailles. This is a copy of Versailles but I think it is better than the originak- if the French people will excuse me for saying so!
Fun boat ride, beautiful fountains. We took a fun boat ride, it's quite a way out from city. The grounds and fountains are beautiful. We had lunch in a rest on the property, this was nice.

great fountains and gardens. very Russian but worth seeing, eateries a bit naff but the house and gardens superb! and well wort the effort. travel by boat from st pete, busses can be a bit grim, slow, and scarey!

Too bad it rained. After a ride with the Hydrofoil we opened our umbrellas and walked through some of the gardens with dozens of fancy fountains. Then we arrived at the main building - what a nice place to go to live in summer! Then all the fountains started up and it was a view to behold.
Beautiful fountains and gardens. Wonderful history, fountains are spectacular! Worth a 1/2 day easy. Can take a hydrofoil boat from St. Petersburg in 1/2 hour.
Russian Royalty. Absolutely beautiful! The palace, grounds,statuary, and the fountains are wonderful. I wished we could have stayed longer.
Fountains everywhere. What an engineering marvel. Fantastic and beautiful. A must see for anyone visiting St. Petersburg. Take the hydrofoil back to the city proper.

Peter the Great was indeed Great.. We found Peterhof to be wonderful. Peter the Greats foresight was amazing and to accomplish his dream and build what he has is amazing Take a guide to learn the history . Disappointed no photographs allowed

Over the top, but good fun. Went to this attraction as part of a Baltic cruise - after two days of cold, grey weather suddenly the sun came out at Peterhof and made this garden all the more magical. Try and spend more than a few hours here and bask in the "fabulousness" of the gardens and fountains.

Peter the Great's palace. Drop dead gorgeous! This is a bona-fide palace, built to rival Versailles. Take a guided tour and you get to walk through the private chambers of the Tsar and his family. The gardens are beautiful and the fountains are awe inspiring. This is a jewel of an attraction and is worth the time and effort to visit. Te fountains are turned on at 10 am, be there to see them start up!

Don't miss this. You'll be blown away by the fountains and the statues. Don't buy a tour ticket for the inside unless it's done in English. It's nom fun standing in a room listening to a 20 minute lecture in Russian Non Russians are charged a lot more to get into the lower garden than non Russians. Pay it, it's worth it..

Breathtaking gardens. as part of our cruise, we spent 3 hours in these beautifully kept gardens, due to the time allowed, we could only see some of it, but what we saw was superb, well worth a visit, the water fountains where lovely, and thoroughly enjoyed our visit, so sorry we didnt have longer, but would definitely come here again.

Beautiful! Especially on a sunny day. Another sight that lives up to the hype in this amazing city.Top tip: if you are not Russian arrive between 10-12 and go straight to the entrance queue. Skip in front of the groups and asked to be let in. I suspect you pay more for this advantage but it's worth it.If you arrive by hydrofoil and want to leave the lower park you will need your boat ticket to be allowed back in. With the Peterhof Express you can buy a single and then get a discount on your return ticket. If you buy a return then you have to book the time of your return too and you might regret this.It is fascinating to see how Peter the Great built such magnificence, but loved to live more simply.Do go into the Hermitage here, very quirky!

Peterhof Palace. A side of history we never learned very much about. Alexander guided us through the place. Pointing out the highlights in a few hours that you could spend months and never see it all.
Peterhof. The grounds are huge. Over 180 fountains & we saw a ton of them. The palace is just beautiful. We only saw the outside. I would have liked to go inside too.

Well worth the visit. The gardens were extensive and beautifully laid out. It might be better to see these at their best a little later in the year when the warmth has brought things to life for spring. But they were still worth seeing.The guide felt these were better than Versailles but I did not wholly agree.Peterhof was amazing with its gold fittings and wonderful decoration. We loved it.

Well worth the trip. Whether you come by boat or road, prefer gardens, architecture, history, or water features, there is something to please everyone here. It is like a mini European trip. The building is still being restored with care and attention to detail but that only enhances not distracts from the experience. Bring your appetite as the food court near the pier is worth visiting.

Amazing garden!!. Spent 1 hour here as part of a cruise excursion tour so didn't get to go into the palace. However the garden itself is worth a visit by itself. Lots of nice fountains and architecture. Great for a day out with the family.

Impressive. Peterhof Palace is one of those places that will be very crowded (even when it is pouring rain). Seriously though, do not miss out on visiting. In nearly every direction you look there will be fountains and gold. Massive and beautiful gardens await you as well. It's an incredible (albeit opulent...) site to see, don't miss out!

Great experience in a spectacular setting. We went to St Petersburg last year, and loved the experience, the friendly people, the history and especially the wonderful architecture. There was so much to see, but we felt we had barely scraped the surface, so when we had the opportunity to visit again this year, we jumped at the chance!We had an organised excursion to Peterhof, and travelled by coach to the palace returning later by hydrofoil.We explored the upper garden terraces first, which are formally laid out in front of the palace. Then we toured the palace itself - opulent ballrooms, exotic Chinese rooms, the spectacular white dining room, portraits and mirrors, gilded staircases and huge chandeliers - this really is a place of extravagant excesses !! The fountains and water features are switched on at 11am each day accompanied by classical music which is really rather impressive. There were crowds of tourists awaiting the magical moment where the fountains and waterfalls start their display, but that didn't spoil our visit, in fact the sense of anticipation added to our enjoyment!!The lower terraces, woodlands and sea front walkways were next on itinerary - we were here when the weather was extremely hot (31 C) so we enjoyed the shade of the trees and sea breezes - it was easy to understand why Peter loved this place and built his palace here.The journey back to St Petersburg was by hydrofoil - fast and very comfortable, and great for seeing the real St Petersburg. The locals were paddling and swimming in the River Neva and sunbathing on the river banks although we were told that the river was polluted and it was not recommended to bathe.The city is currently undergoing a huge regeneration programme, where all of the old concrete communist apartment blocks are beng replaced, the historical buildings are being repaired and restored, and major road and bridge maintenance works are being undertaken, mainly paid for by tourism revenues I think.St Petersburg is a magical place and well worth visiting if ever you get the opportunity.

Do not miss! Simply beautiful!!!. In the summer Peterhof may be crowded, but that is NO reason to not go! This place will amaze you! The fountains, the sculptures, the buildings, and the gardens! We had only 2 hours to visit and it was not enough as there are museums to go to and in the summer different events take place in the gardens. I would even recommend to have a picnic here!It is a +30min drive from downtown St. Petersburg and the taxi might be expensive. Therefore I recommend to take a small fairy from downtown (The Neva river, right by the Heritage Museum) which takes half an hour and at the same time you get to enjoy the sea. We bought tickets for about 20 Euros per person there and back.

Beautiful and shiny. It can be a bit over crowded here, but I much prefer the feel of ths park than being couped up with thousands of tourists in the Katherines palace in Pushkin. The fountains are world renowned. I know there are a lot of things to do in St. Petersburg downtown, but I would highly recommend a visit here, if you come in Summer.

Must See place in St. Petersburg. Really don't miss this place while in St. Petersburg. The garden itself very amazing & wonderful, full of fountains and statuts. Ofcourse there is a museum to visit inside the palace but I didn't visited it. The upper garden is for free and lower garden you should pay a fee to eneter which is the best part of it! and at the end you will be beside the Finland Gulf can you rest for a while or take an entertainment boat. Getting there would be easily possible & affordable by bus or marshrutka at the Avtovo Metro station.

Over the top. The Peterhof Palace out-blings every other Czarist palace or cathedral in St. Petersburg. The grounds are spectacular, with a host of golden fountains. The inside is nauseatingly opulent, with gold caked on or dripping from almost every surface. It's a real tourist draw and is likely to be exceedingly crowded. The guards are a bit on the scary side, constantly yelling at tourists and tour guides alike. This is a difficult-to-impossible attraction for anyone in a wheelchair, as there are a lot of steps and a long, uneven path from the parking areas to the Palace.

Could spend days here enoying all the pieces. There is something for everyone here. There are so many pieces here they say that if you spend on 8 seconds at every piece you will be there for 9 years! Plan ahead and think about what you want to see so you can focus on those sections of the museum. One of the top museums I have ever seen.

Unbelievable!!. This is one of the top sites to see when in St. Petersurg. The grounds are spectacular. Perfectly manicured and the fountains are like nothing else you have seen. We spent the day just walking around outside and had such a great time. This is a picture takers paradise.

Gorgeous and gaudy !. We arrived by hydrofoil in time for the morning switch on ( 11a.m.) of the fountains-really impressive. Peter the Great certainly brought back much from his travels in Europe. The grounds are wonderful and the interior is jaw dropping . Again crowded and hot on our visit, but, absolutely wonderful.

Don't miss it. This place was just amazing. We walked around the grounds for quite awhile and they were beautiful. The palace was just stunning and our guide made us feel like I was looking in at the family who lived there.

Such a gorgeous and serene place. Wow, talk about Gardens galore. The water fountains are unbelievable and just gorgeous. The amount of water that flows through them is intense. I really wish we got to view the Palace and grotto but our tour with SPB (we had a private tour with 2 hours to spare at the end even) didn't allow for it. Wish we could have. Wonderful to see though. The park is really pretty and the kids, local ones can come here and enjoy it as well. You can get really gorgeous pictures here and it is just serene and peaceful.

Just amazing!. The interiors of the Summer Palace have been restored with such care, it was an incredible experience to see the majesty in which the royal family lived. The fountains and gardens were also breathtaking......

Russian Versalle. This is a wonderful system of parks, fountains and palaces. The gardens are sofisticated and very well decorated with flowers. Wonderful fountains and richly decorated palaces. For me it's much better manteined then Sans Souci :)

Everyone has to see it. I live close to this place and sometimes I go there by bicycle (tandem) with my wife. Any words can not describe the beauty of the place so you better come and see it by yourself. You saw Versailles? I did, but... Peterhof is much better.

Spectacular gardens and waterfall.... We were there on a sunny day. it was beautifule. should reach there before 11 am, because that's when they turn on the fountains. simply beautiful and large garden with a lot of places to wander to and relax for a day.

Just saw the gardens, very impressive!. We were told by our guide that the palace was not anything spectacular, so we just visited the upper and lower gardens. The water fountains were amazing with the colors and gold. It was a very hot day and it seems like EVERYONE was out at the fountains. It is impressive and shows off how much money the Russian Tsars had, I suppose.

Great stroll and unforgettable impressions. In my opinion, the best place of this kind. Brilliant! Stunning view of the palace with Great Cascade. Lots of different fontains. There are joke fontains. Children like them very much. It's nice to get there by boat.Quite expensive

Beautiful park. U can go there by bus or car. But best is by boat which going hourly from Vasilileostrovskiy place or at the exit of Ermitaje from Neva river. It will take around 40 min to get there. And u can see all sights of Petersburg. Advise to go from first line road as on second located toilets which is smell... and restaurant very close to there..Ticket office to the main museum located at the exit As I was waiting all cue and back againt ti get it. No system. There is no exchange office so take all money in rubles.it can be windy there and comfortable shoes are preferable. Take moskito cream it can be helpful

Come early!. Its about 40minute ride by car from moika river. But the trip was worth it. Coming without a guide is still ok as the place is pretty tourist friendly so you can enjoy the museum first before strolling around the park. I had an awful guide so i recommend to go without them and just enjoy a nice full day. I heard going by hydrofoil will be faster but i didnt try.

Beautiful. This was the highlight of our trip to St. Pete. Don't miss it. Worth the time/cost/trouble of getting there. Unfortunately the dining options are subpar - just mediocre fast food. Unfortunately photography is not allowed inside the building. Allow half a day for the back and forth, and for exploring the grounds.

Most beautiful fountains anywhere. We had previously toured the palace, which isn't necessary if you have been to Catherine's Palace. It is similar, but Catherine's, to me, is much nicer. The thing to see is the fountains and gardens. All the gold statues in the fountains are so beautiful. Don't miss it!

Unbelievable. My family and I took the hydrofoil ride to Peterhof, which was a ton of fun. As a note, which our tour guide told us, when boarding the hydrofoil she recommended sitting in the central part of the boat because the front and back tend to smell worse, her words not mine. Anyway Peterhof was spectacular, the fountains, well maintained gardens and the palace itself. The upkeep is just unreal. Lots of trick fountains throughout the grounds, which are fun for the kids. I never went in, but it is still worth visiting because the outside is well worth it. If going by car, expect a roughly 45-60 minute drive from St. Petersburg.
Must go!. The Gardens are unbelievable! And, when you learn that the whole place was burned and destroyed by the Nazis, your amazement with the work done there goes to the top.

garden and fountain. yes but do not forget to visit the sauna build for his daughter, just great idea and initiative inside, fantastic shower in shape of chandelier... great garden and nice promenade in the park. Also the palace must be visited as fully refurbished in 2013...

the very russian beauty. this is a place you must go !the garden is incredible, Versailles'inspiration with wonderful fountains. the palace is majestic, colourful. you can walk around the park, until the coast to appreciate the viewthe best is to take a boat to go from St Pet. but it is a bit expensive (1 100 rub for 30min, boat every 30 min). my advice: come early to the pier to take the front place (VIP area) in the boat, you'll have a nice view of the trip and it won't cost more !the park fee is 250 rub if i remember.stay at least 3-4 hours

A place not to miss!. Visited here whilst on a Baltic Cruise. It is amazing. the treasures and Art are truly magnificent. there are good views accross the River Neva, and the Peter and paul Fortress. It is very hot inside as there is no air conditioning.It is very busy so best to go early as we did. A day is not really long enough......you need weeks to see it all. If time is limited, this must be done

Spectacular, even if you don't go inside.. If you can take the hydrofoil out there, I would recommend it. The gardens and fountains are gorgeous. We didn't go inside the Palace, but it's worth the trip.

Gorgeous grounds and fountains. I had no idea what the Peterhof Gardens were like. Our All tour took us here, and our guide Anya led us through this fairyland. Fountains ranged from small trick fountains for children to run through to the magnificent gold leaf Samson fountain. We didn't have time to go through any of the buildings, but the grounds and fountains are fantastic.

enthralling. It was a brilliant morning when we visited this place.The water features & fountains sparkled like jewels against the flowerbeds & lawns & trees.One can't decide which is better,the inside or the outside of the palace.Just unforgettable!

Spend your time in the gardens. The gardens are where you want to spend your time here. Don't waste it inside the palace unless you have time to kill. There's additional gardens behind the palace which most people aren't aware of and other than the geometry weren't very spectacular when we there in June.

Go with a tour. After reading some of the reviews that hated this place, I would start off by saying don't attempt Peterhof without a guide. This visit was part of an excursion through Norwegian Cruise Lines for us. As a result, we didn't have to wait more than a few minutes in line, we had English commentary and good access to the fountains. It didn't hurt that it was also a beautiful day in St. Petersburg. This Palace is lovely as are the fountains and gardens. It is far less crowded than Catherine's Palace or the Hermitage. If you ever studied anything about Imperial Russia in school, then this is a must see.

Amazing Gardens. Beautiful gardens and fountains. We didn't go into the Palace having visited Catherine Palace the day before. Beautifully manicured gardens and statuary. Made it via hydrofoil for the 11 am ceremony where they turn on the fountains.

This will cost a fortune but it's worth every Rouble.. Don't expect a discount on the hydrofoil with the leaflet. You need to book online for that. 650 Roubles out and 450 Roubles back. 450 Roubles for the lower park and 550 Roubles for the main Palace. You queue a long time to get your ticket and then a long time to get in. It's very crowded and you will be moved along at a fast trudge. It is however splendid and I am sure you will remember its magnificence for the rest of your life. The Russians get an audio tour given and the Brits can get one for 500 Roubles. Give yourself at least 5 hours to visit the Palace and get round all the fountains within the lower garden. It's pointless spending all that money and not making the most of it. We spent close to £100 or $150 for the day and if you want to do the other museums you will need a lot more time as most have queues and don't forget even more money although they do take credit cards.

A place in heaven. I have visited Peterhorf Palace twice and I was twice amazed by its decadent and grandissime beauty. all inside and outside of the palace deserves a close look. I joined a group with a guide as you need few years of reading if you want to learn all about this magnificient place.

Nice day trip. Peterhof provides a nice day away from the city. We took the hydrofoil there (for the experience) and the bus back (for the price). Didn't go into the palace but the gardens are nice. They don't let you sit on the grass though!

Picture perfect palace and park. Few queues here. Also, movements between rooms are well controlled to avoid overcrowding. The downside is that you are not allowed to take photos inside. Even though restoration work continues, the rooms that are currently available to the public seriously rival Versailles and Schronbrunn. The gardens are probably the best in Russia (as they were designed to be!) and you should allow time to visit these but, with the possible exception of the Grand Cascade, don't expect anything on the scale or grandeur of Versailles. Worth considering watching the ceremony to switch on the fountains at 1100 – good atmosphere but crowded. Various cafes in the main palace building and gardens (albeit with basic food selection and somewhat on the expensive side). Restrooms in main palace and cafes. Bags greater than 20 x 30 inches must be checked in.
WOW! Awesome mosaics!. A must see! The mosaics are outstanding. Don't miss this church when in St. Petersburg! Full of history and a sight to see!

Wow it's hot. We went as part of a 2 day tour of St Petersburgh while on a Baltic cruise. Our guide got us in before it opened wow what a stunning place but it is really hot no air con and when it fills up it is stifling

Wow. Go on a day when it's not raining as the fountains and gardens are fabulous. The interior is opulent but not as overwhelming as some of the other palaces. Still definitely worth going inside since you've made the trip.
