Versailles in Russia. We spent a day in the Peterhof. You get there by the Meteor hydrofoil which takes 30 minutes each way. They go every half hour and you don't need to book. The Peterhof is set in a lovely park and you pay to get into the park and then again to visit the house (castle I should say). As elsewhere in St Petersburg large queues build up of groups, if you are not in a group you can go to the front and enter as individuals. This can be hard to do for those of us brought up in queuing cultures. The house was destroyed in the war (actually by the Russians as the Germans occupied it) and completely rebuilt after. They did an amazing job of restoring one wing which is what you visit. You can see the damage done at an exhibition in the park. There are a couple of nice cafes in the park where you don't have to queue because they are so expensive. The inside of the castle is covered in gilt, but you are not allowed to take photos. You also have to wear a blue plastic cover on your shoes.

NOT TO BE MISSED. Peterhof is definitely one of the highlights of a trip to St. Petersburg. I would definitely recommend not going during the high tourist season as it is difficult to see anything. Our guide recommended April as the month that it isn't too cold and there aren't too many people. Having said that we wouldn't have missed this city even if we did have to fight the throngs.Peterhof is a magnificent palace with high ceilings, long corridors and gold leaf decoration. The many objects d'art are beautiful and don't forget to leave plenty of time for the gardens which are reminiscent of Versailles. We were in St. Petersburg for 2 days off a cruise ship and it was no where near enough even though we took a private car and guide. We used Hop On Hop Off in other places in order to save for what was for us the ghighlight of the trip. We weren't sorry.Definitely leave 3-4 hours for the Peterhof and try and take the boat in at least one direction if the weather is good. It's not only faster than driving it also gives you a chance to take in everything that you've seen and to prepare for the next one.

Awesome,but too large!. Magnificent palace, but too many rooms that all seemed to look alike after a while. spend no more than 1 hour inside, then tour magnificent grounds, it is very crowded and there is no a/c on hot summer days

stunning fountains and gardens. It is best to take the 30mins boat from Saint Peterburg to this palace compared to taking train. There are a lot of tour groups especially from 10am and you could be stuck between groups when the palace interior is open from 10.30am onwards. I think the gardens and ground here are more gorgeous than Versailles and Schronbrunn Palace, both of which however have better interior.

Good crowd control improves visit. This was our second visit to Peterhof. Visitors are not exactly welcomed by the stern-faced women who staff the various rooms, but at least, unlike at the Hermitage, crowds are controlled enough that you can actually see the rooms in the palace. The women will not let one group through until the group before them has exited each room. They are constantly admonishing the guides and asking for their badge numbers if anything doesn't suit them -- a bit of authority that goes to their heads -- so it's not exactly a happy place. You will be scolded quite literally if you THINK about touching anything. It is beautiful beyond words, however, and worth the time and effort required. The gardens and fountains are beyond gorgeous, and I wish I had not been on a guided tour and had had more time to spend there. We were on a bus tour and had limited time. The hydrofoil is probably better.
Beautiful place. This was a great place to go. The gardens & grounds are beautiful. Lots of walking but well worth it.

Beautiful!. A nice hydrofoil ride from St. Petersburg. Gorgeous grounds and fountains to explore. The main palace is worth a visit, too, just beware of the lines. Try to go right before the 'foreigner' entrance time starts so you don't get stuck behind all the Russian tour groups.
Gardens a delight, castle capturing. Good idea to allow at least four hours to fully appreciate this amazing place. Captivating views wherever one turns.

Magnificence. A long trip from the city due to traffic but worth it. The house and interiors have all been rebuilt following their total destruction during the second world war. They are replicas of the original and outstanding. The many fountains operating (from 11 am) are amazing to see working and hopefully your tour allows you enough time to see as many as possible. The return journey by hydrofoil was much better than the road.

The gardens are well worth a few hours.. I only had a couple of hours here going round a little of the gardens but did not have time for the palace, the plan is to return, St Petersburg has so much to offer

Perfectly restored. Peterof the Russian Versailles was the Palace of Peter the Great extended by his Granddaughter Empress Elizabeth and was the official residence of Nicholas 1st. It was destroyed during WWII but has been perfectly restored. The gardens are amazing and at 11am everyday the fountains are turned on and they are amazingly spectacular. The gardens are beautiful and are maintained extremely well. The cascading fountains are everywhere throughout the gardens. Photos are not allowed inside. This is to make you buy a book at the gift shop. This is not expensive but it would have been nice to have my own photos. Everywhere else in St Petersburg photos were allowed but there was a charge of 3 euros to take photos and 9 euros for videos. This was a nuisance and what the idea of it is I do not know. There is no airconditioning so be prepaired to be hot as the crowds are huge. There is a lot of walking and a lot of stairs. Supervision in all attractions is high with retired women watching everything you do. But St Petersburg was my favourite city in the Balkans, a joy to visit. Catherine's Palace as equally beautiful although more sparcely furnished than Peteroff. This Palace has been as equally well restored after also being destroyed in WWII. Our other attraction seen in St Petersburg was the Church on Spilled Blood. This Church as built on the site where Nicholas 1st was assassinated. It is amazing with the stunning array of mosaics on the life of Jesus I have ever seen. It also had a beautiful gold alter screen. It was a true delight to behold. This is in its original condition and perfect in every way. Our whole experience in St Petersburg will be a cherished memory for the rest of my life. I thoroughly recommend the city as a must see!!!

Wow!!!. Absolutely spell-binding. The most spectacular gardens I have ever seen - all the more impressive when you learn that there are no pumps involved and all the fountains run on gravity! Truly impressive.

only had time for the garden. we got the bus out to the peterhof and brought a ticket to the gardens only. we were there early and spent all day in the gardens only. we got the hydrofoil back to the city when we couldn't walk another step. it was well worth it as it drops you off in the centre of the city outside the hermitage. Probably I would get the hydrofoil out and back if I had of known how easy it is. A little more expensive but worth the time saved.

Simply breathtaking. We walked around the grounds in shock with our eyes wide open and our jaws to the ground. This palace and surrounding gardens was built by orders of Peter the Great. The Palaces and gardens are referred to as the "Russian Versailles". It is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. There is a good reason for this. The grounds are beautifully manicured and all the fountains are relaxing and amazing to watch. The most amazing thing is that there are no pumps running the fountains. It is all gravity and plumbing that create the pressure to shoot the water that comes from the natural springs in the Upper Gardens. We walked through all the gardens and saw all the fountains.We did not have time to go inside since we spent a few hours walking around the grounds since they were absolutely beautiful. If you want to see the inside as well you should plan a full day there.What a treat to see.

Peterhof is Magical. The best way to visit Peterhof is to take a hydrofoil across the Gulf of Finland to the jetty at the end of the Marine Canal. The pier we used was in front of the Hermitage palace entrance at the river side. The palace is beautiful but the biggest attractions are the gardens and the fountains. The best time to visit Peterhof is of course the summer season, when all the varied buildings in the park are open to visitors and the famous fountains are in operation. We were lucky to find golf cart tour service that we used in order to get a better appreciation of all the area and attractions. The downside of the tour it was that was in Russian. Nevertheless, we saved time and planned our visit in detailed after the overview tour.
Great gardens!. If you love sculptured gardens, gold and more gold, then there's nothing here not to like. The palace inside is just a really big plus.

A trip to Peter the Great Summer home. It is worth taking the hydrofoil boat from Ermitage embankment; +/- 1h. You enjoy a breathtaking view on Gulf of Finland. Then you see a fantastic garden and moreover a palace equivqlent to Versailles or Sans Souci. A lunch at the orangerie will give you some rest before journeying back to St P. If you are lucky your boat will stop at St Isaac, a must see church

One the best attraction of St. Petersburg. Peterhof is composed by an amazing palace with beautiful gardens and stunning fountains.It is a breathtaking experience to walk through its gardens and to enjoy the fountains. The palace is also woth visiting.Nothing approaches Peterhof outside Versailles (in France).

Wonderful - beyond greatest expectation. The gardens and the interior of the Palace were absolutely 'out of this world'. It was utterly breath-taking. I cannot put into words how I felt about this visit. We saw the fountains start at 11.00 am. Unfortunately I had forgotten my camera, but I am taking away so many memories of this incredible spectacle. There is a lot of walking involved so it would be difficult with those with walking difficulties.

Fantastically Grand. This is possibly the best attraction in St Petersburg.Fantastic water features and the palace tour is the best of all the tours on offer. Quick boat ride for 30 km on the Finish Sea is an ideal way to get to this venue. highly recommended.
Great place. Visited the peterhof gardensMagnificent fountainArrived by Metro and bus it's about 100 rubels much cheaper than boat which is 550
We only saw the gardens and fountains but that was enough. An incredible spectacle and a beautiful place to roam despite the crowds. Crowded but this is summer and it is a major attraction.

Vast Gardens and Fascinating Water Displays. The hydrofoil trip to Peterhof also affords a visitor to see other areas of St. Petersburg along the river on the way to the gardens. The fountains and water displays are amazing and when the sun is out the reflection off the gold painted figures is a remarkable sight. The gardens are very large and one can spend a few hours simply walking through the woods and gardens. Locals come to have picnics and enjoy the outdoors in these vast gardens. There can be mosquitos around so if you are sensitive to these insects bring a bug repellent.

Grand and Glorious. Stepping off the hydrofoil and walking up to the palace was like stepping out of a time machine. The beauty and majesty of the palace and gardens was awe-inspiring. More time is needed to fully enjoy this beautiful treasure.
Awe inspiring Must see it.. A classic St. Petersburg tourist site. Beautiful and nothing approaches it outside Versailles. Spent a few hrs. there in July, 2013.

Russian Versailles. Russia is a truly amazing country to visit, especially now as it develops its post-Soviet personality. One of its true gems from the Czarist times is the Peterhof Palace, designed and built for Peter the Great in the early 1700's. After his visit to France, he attempted to compete with Versailles, and although his palace is smaller, it is every bit as opulent. The highlight is, of course, the massive cultured gardens with many small palaces and fountains, and the canal running from the main palace's cascading fountains right out to the Baltic Sea. If you are impressed by golden sculptures, this place will blow you away! Because no electrical pumps are needed to pressurize the fountains (gravity does the work), the fountains run every day in the summer from 11 a.m. till closing (more frequently than Versailles!). This is a treasure of St. Petersburg not to be missed.
Lovely place.. Enjoyed the boat ride there, the amazing gardens and fountains and the palace itself. A photographer's delight.
Peterhof. Great place to take long nice walks, have a picnic and enjoy the view. The boat trip to get there is nice too!
Beautiful. Amazing trip to Peterhof, go via boat from Hermitage. The fountains shut down at a certain time so keep that in mind. There are also good places to eat.

Beyoud belief. If you do nothing else in St Petersburg, you must do this, it is one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. We did not go into the castle, but would love to do that at a later date.

Better than versailles. This palace was built with the intent to rival versailles. Having been to Versailles, I highly doubted this would turn out to be better, boy was I wrong! The palace is magnificent, but what is really breathtaking are the gardens, this are the most luxurious gardens I've been to. What really surprised me is that the fountains work only by pressure. Many russians say that they have to see peterhof before they die, so this attraction is not to be missed! Make sure to take a panoramic picture of all the fountains.
magnificent. This is not to be missed at any price. Leave yourself plenty of time to take it all in and make sure you have enough memory space and a spare battery for your camera.

A WET DAY. We visited the gardens only and it rained and rained but it all still looked amazing like a film set.with the house as a backdrop to the most opulent gold fountains in the front its a view to wonder at even in the rain . there are so many gold fountains in the grounds and all just stunning, don`t be put off if the weather is wet.The gardens and palace are away from the city so we went by hydrofoil ,there is one outside the Hermitidage
What a view!. Never saw anything like that place! Fountains just unbelievable. Garden is so pretty. Would love to go back there again.

Extreme Opulence!. The palace itself was over the top as expected, full of gold and riches reflecting the history of Russia in terms of the excessive wealth held by the lucky few. Definitely worth a visit. But the highlight were the gardens - after the chaos of the palace filled with large tour groups, there were various spots around the gardens where we could walk alone. The fountains are stunning. Make sure you plan your visit around the start up of the main fountains - 11am the morning we were there. It's worth battling the crowds to see them come to life to orchestral music. A trip back to St Petersburg on the hydrofoil was a relaxing way to finish the morning.

Must see!. This was the first stop on a private tour and we immediately understood why upon seeing it. Russians are very proud of this Palace and they have every right to be. This place is stunning and packs a great deal of history into each room. The gold leaf on everything is worth the visit alone. The fountains are fascinating as there are no pumps involved. There is a little cafe outside which serves different types of Russian pancakes. This is worth a visit as our kids raved about the chocolate and banana pancakes. It is a nice break after a beautiful walk around the grounds.

Fabulous Fountains and Gardens. We spent about two hours walking around and looking at the fabulous fountains. We also went to the music hall and listened to the men's group singing A cappella. It almost brought everybody to tears because it was so beautiful.

A beautiful attraction worth the effort to visit. We were part of a cruise ship tour so we had 'skip-the-line- tickets, a big plus as there were large crowds. The castle itself was beautiful and interesting but the gardens with their gravity fed (i.e. no pumps) fountains were fabulous! Our tour had a lunch served in the old bathhouse which was a really nice privilege. The lower gardens were cool, inviting and offered up many spectacular views.
Floored by it Magnificience. All you see is gold gold gold. Acres of sprawling garden. Tiring but amazing beautiful Palace. Loved every bit.

Must visit. This is one of most beautiful parks in Sankt Petersburg surroundings. I can recommend to use water transport to get there (from State Hermitage). Do not forget to visit internal space near Samson - you can see how water system works here.

Glorious - golden palace - elegant and lavish. Expect to pay top dollar for hydroplane ride - but once there, this palace, the fountains and gold statuary will blow your mind. Makes one wonder how much labor and taxes were piled on the peasants to enable the Tzars to build a magnificent palace like this. So glad it is now a museum - an incredible wonder for all to visit.

Incredible fountains!. When I studied Russian history I never though this palace was so amazing! But seeing it was just breath-taking. As you come to the palace thee is a huge amount of vendors selling many items at pretty good prices. The palace itself is beautiful but its the gardens and the fountains that will amazing you. and all of it without pumps, only gravity. You cannot miss the Tree Fountains where walking on certain stones triggers the fountains; or the Dog and Duck fountain. This is such a spectacular place with great views of the Bay of Finland. Certainly, Peter the Great built a fantastic place.

A beautiful, relaxing morning at Peterhof. We really enjoyed our tour of Peterhof. We went here as part of a guided tour through Red October Tours, so we had our knowlegeable guide, Helen, with us to explain things along the way,and early entry tickets to avoid the long lines. The rooms of the palace are beautiful and lavish, but I enjoyed the fountains and the stroll through the gardens even more. We were very lucky with perfect weather for this tour. Helen had brought nuts for the red squirrels that are very tame and gentle and will eat out of your hand. At the end of our enjoyable morning we took the hydrofoil back to St. Petersburg, a fun way to see the city from yet another perspective.

Little hard to get, but definitely worth of visit. First of all, let me say that this is truly amazing place. Must see if you are more than day or two in St.Petersburg. When you look at the pictures, you konow what I mean! But getting there is not that easy. We took hydrofoil and there was really long line and when we finally get in, it was packed and diesel smell got us all little sick. When we get to the pier in Peterhof, we were surprised to see that there was another ticket booth to get in. Lady in the first ticket counter didn't tell us that and we thought that Peterhof entrance is included in hydrofoil ticket. From the pier is about 10-15min walk to the palace and only toilets are few smelly porter potty. But still the palace is absolutely awesome.

Peterhof Fountains and Gardens. Strolling through the Garden is a must. Allow at least three hours so you are not too rushed. We took a hydrofoil (there are several leaving from around Hermitage area) and it was a 30min ride. The Gardens and Fountains are spectacular.

Must See. Gold, gold and more gold. What a life these Tsars had! The interior has to be seen to be believed as it is hard to describe but the great halls, the silk wallpaper and sheer beauty of all of this must not be missed.

Magnificent. Rebuilt after 1945 when the evacuating Germans destroyed so much of the building.
Many of the rooms are just spectacular. Plastic shoes are worn throughout.

Beautiful, but an adventure. We took the Peterhof express hydrofoil from St. Petersburg to Peterhof. The ticket line took no more than 10 min, and we were boarded immediately, which was great. We were perplexed why they would only sell us one way tickets (with no explanation). We later realized why... The hydrofoil wasn't running on the return trip. When we returned to the pier around 4:30pm, it was closed up with no explanation, and the single security guard didn't speak English. A nice couple who were also touring gave us directions to the bus stop. Note, cash only for both the hydrofoil and the minibus. The bus was about a quarter of the price of the hydrofoil so a good value.You can buy tickets to the Lower Garden of Peterhof at the ferry pier upon arrival in the morning. Lines weren't too long and they accepted credit cards. The lower gardens are extensive and very interesting. We particularly enjoyed the fountains and waterways, some of which are very unusual, including a chessboard waterfall, a pyramid fountain, and numerous other fountains and landscaped gardens. For children, there are several trick fountains which spray water triggered by a hidden person, which our five year old child enjoyed. There are various WC's and ice cream / sandwich shops scattered throughout the park. It would take several hours to stroll around and see everything, so either budget time or pick and choose your sites. The main rooms of the palace were on a separate ticket and were restricted in terms of time of entrance. For foreigners (non Russians), a sign said that tickets went on sale from 2:30 - 4:15pm. People began queueing at 1pm, and we decided not to wait. We later stopped by around 3:30pm and the queue was relatively short. We waited 15 minutes and were able to get in. Credit cards are accepted. The tour is self guided, with no signs or materials in English. Museum staff are very strict -- no bags can be brought in over a certain size; coats must be left in the coatroom, and plastic slippers must be worn over shoes. You are not allowed to linger in a particular room - we were told to keep moving when we stopped to take in the sights. (We were also told not to sit on steps outside the palace when we paused to check our guide book.) That being said, the palace was lavishly decorated with incredible marble and wooden floors, sculpted plasters, and antique furniture and china sets. Considering the devastation of Peterhof in WWII, the renovation is incredible. The fountains behind the house are also amazing and worth a close look.As mentioned above, we took the minibus back to a Metro stop, and then continued via Metro to our hotel. Despite our confusion about the hydrofoil, it wasn't too difficult to return to the city in the end. We would recommend visiting, particularly on a nice day. The gardens would be difficult to enjoy in the rain.

wonderful place. A wonderful place but we were surprised/disappointed there was no information at all in English in the rooms of the palace. We did not travel with a group so did not have an English speaking guide . For individual travellers would advise they buy a guide book before the tour. This is not necessarily easy to do as the shop is at the end of the tour!! We bought the guide book then. Better late than never. An other option is the audio guide which costs £10 per person on top of admission charge. A bit steep.

Wow!. Puts many of Europe's palaces to shame in terms of opulence. Stunning fountains and gardens and good availability of food and refreshments. I found the individuals dressed as royalty and charging 100 rubles for a photo extremely irritating.

My favourite place outside of St. Petersburg. Words don't do this place justice. You have to see it. We went by Hydrofoil from St. Petersburg to Peterhof, Its about 30miles out I think. It took just over 30 mins. Cost $ 25 each way.Just a little tip, as we were really stuck for time we took a banana etc and enjoyed a quick lunch on the Hydrofoil out as we had a packed day. It was a most relaxing trip. Comfortable seats and toilets on board. The golden fountains are totally amazing as is the building itself. They require you to put very light cloth slippers over your shoes, which they provide, to protect the wonderful floors.Again very crowded, hot and as the buildings are very old there is a lack of any air at times. Some rooms get clogged up and delays can happen. But its the most fantastic place. I understand the fountains don't operate all year round, ie Winter time, but do in the summer months. They add so much to the whole experience. One of the nicest places I've ever been.
Great gardens. The gardens and the fountains are outstanding not very sure about the palace itself, the lines are toooooo long and the fares and fees are a bit expensive

You won't be disappointed. Recently visited in Peterhof in June the sun was blazing and the gardens were absoultly stunning, as many have mentioned previously the fountains are worth the admission alone. The overall sense of opulence no wonder the workers revolted. It was very busy when we visited and be prepared for plenty of walking but well worth it we were on an organised tour as we were on a cruise ship that was docked for 3 days guide was very knowledgeable and answered all questions if possible try to visit in the morning when it should be less crowded and be aware of pick pockets as someone from our cruise ship had their wallet stolen.

Beautiful. The Pererhof was around a 40 minute boat trip from St Petersburg. We didn't get into the palace - it was incredibly busy and we spent so much time wandering around the gardens, we had to rush for the return ferry. Incidentally, the ferry is every 30 minutes, on the hour and half hour. Although there are several ferry companies, boats are very busy, get there in plenty of time. If the ferry is full, you can book your tickets and wait for the next one.The gardens are beautiful, with fountains and lakes scattered throughout. You can walk for miles, but don't notice as your attention is taken with the surroundings.There are lots of red squirrels and pigeons - they are pretty much tame and will come over to you for food if you sit down; the squirrels will actually come up and take food out of your hand.There are toilets located throughout the gardens, along with food and drink kiosks.

Worth the trip .... We went to Peterhof on a beautiful October fall day. Most of the out buildings were open. Lots of locals enjoying the beautiful gardens and grounds of Peterhof. We weren't thrilled with the separate admission fees for every building but still went in several. One very caring guide to Marly House made the visit special. Her obvious enthusiasm and love of Marly House was palpable. The palace visit was okay, but a bit rushed and controlled compared to other similar sites. One special event was the troop playing the single note horns (in a range of sizes to create an amazing sound) outside in the gardens. We went by hydrofoil from St. Petersburg ... nice way to get there. Just make sure it is open on the day you decide to go. Another group was sold the expensive hydrofoil ride only to get to Peterhof on a day when all the buildings were closed. Bad business for the hydrofoil company not to warn people of the closures.

The gardens alone are worth the price of admission. Amazing gardens and natural pressure fountains are worth the price of admission. We never even got into the palace! Wear comfortable sandals and be prepared to get wet in the trick fountains! Good fun for all! Very crowded, try to get there early if you can. As with most places in St Petersburg, be aware of pickpockets. There are signs everywhere. We found the security guards quite friendly and helpful. Take the Hydrofoil over, its so much nicer than battling the traffic and heat in a bus!

zenith of opulence. Synonymous with an almost unbeleivably privledged lifestyle, literally beyond anything that a 18th century peasent, (or even 21st century office worker) could even dream about. It is a crowd puller no doubt; and because we knew this, we indicated to our guide that we only wanted to see the upper and lower gardens, leaving the Grand Palace and Monplaisir to another occaision. Indeed it is the gardens we were desperate to see. In fact, as it turned out, the great weather made this an excellent choice.Peterhof is situated about 18 miles from the centre of St Petersburg.Tickets purchased, we firstly made our way to the Upper gardens, passing the golden onion domes of the royal church. The upper gardens (free) reflect the french influence ; mathematically precise ponds with inch perfect statues, borders trimmed to perfection, and vast open walkways that led to beech hedge pathways.These gardens are attractive, mature and yet slighty clinical in structure.The garden in front of the house, facing the river is the zenith of opulence.Life size gilded statues adorn the fountains of this beatuiful cascade.Only when viewed from below , by the 1/4 mile long ornate canal, does one really take it in.Throughout the lower gardens there are "Novelty or trickery fountains"; mostly involving getting some unfortunate very wet - apparently Czar Peter was something of a practical joker - with an unlimited budget to do so.These fine gardens are not just novelty traps for the unwitting; ther are some beautiful floral displays and lovely walkways away from the coach party hordes.We spent some 3 hours here and it could easily have been 5 or 6. Our visit was early on a Friday, and there were already a number of brides being photographed in the picturesque landscape; i would image that on summer weekends the gardens would in some locations be very full. This was the highlight of St Petersburg for us. Unmissable gardens.

Fountains everywhere.. What spectacular gardens and canal from the palace to the sea. Apparently Peter had a contest with another crowned head of Europe to see who could buld the most fountains. They are powered by gravity, the water coming down from the mountains. A lovely place.

Sneak to the left. We followed tripadvisor advice and took the 10 am hydrofoil (650 r one-way), arriving at Peterhof in time to get our tickets into the grounds (450 r) and get through the gate to see the fountains begin at 11:00 am. As soon as the opening display concluded, we skipped the crowds thronging the main staircase and headed east (left if you're facing the palace with the docks behind you), going directly to Monplaisir, the small home that was Peter's actual residence. It was delightful as we were on our own--the crowds had gone to the Palace. We're not fond of crushes, so we basically ringed the park, seeing all the major sights except the interior of the Great Palace. The fountains, as everyone notes, are spectacular. In addition, though, one of the most interesting things was the outdoor photo exhibit behind the Marly Palace (basically almost as far to the end of the grounds as you can go), which showed the grounds, fountains, and palace, during and after the heart-breaking war damage. Powerful photos that made you appreciate the extent of the reconstruction. Even without going into the main palace, we spent an easy three hours on the grounds. We took the hydrofoil back to St. Petersburg (450 return, so 1150 rubles total--cash only, like most things in Russia). Wonderful experience all around!

Peterhof Visit. Think Versaille in the Baltic. Enormous Palace and Gardens with Fountains being a highlight. Fountains are the highlight and many have tricks Peter the Great's time. Highlight for me was viewing the pictures of what was left after the WW II seige and what was rebuilt and how. A miracle of preservation and restoration.

Peterhof Palace and Garden. What an amazing place to visit. You get a glimpse into the Russian royals and their way of life. Until you visit this palace and the gardens with their fountains, it is inconceivable that people in Russia lived this way of life, while the populous starved. You get a true realization of why there was a Russian Revolution.

Russian Versailles. The palace is beautiful on the outside, and the tour through the Grand Palace is nice (no photos allowed on the inside). We went with the Red October Tour Company, which was certainly an excellent way to go. Our guide knew the "ins and outs" of the palace, helping us navigate the crowds. We were bussed to Peterhof from St. Petersburg (we were on a cruise ship), but our tour included a very relaxing hydrofoil trip back. The inside is restored, providing a glimpse into the life of the tzars. The gardens and fountains are extraordinary. Make sure to factor in a lot of time just walking through the grounds of the property. Well worth the trip.

A Marvel of Fountains. Although the palace is magnificent and certainly worth visiting, the gardens and fountains of the Peterhof make a visit there an unforgettable experience. The magnificent stretch of fountains out to the Baltic is still one of my favorite memories, but don't just see this part and leave. There are interesting and even trick fountains everywhere that will delight both young and old. Pay the extra cost to visit some of the minor buildings, especially Mon Plaisir, and take the time to wander down the paths. We were there on an especially beautiful, sunny day and enjoyed every minute. Just be prepared to walk.

grand palace, glorious gardens. St Petersburg has so much to offer that and this is one of the gems. The palace is beautiful and the grounds and fountains (naturally flowing without pumps) are remarkable. Don't miss this extraordinary sight

Amazing Gardens & Fountains. The opulence of the Russian Royalty is unbelievable! The palace is beautiful but the gardens and fountains steal the show. It is very crowded so try to get here for early entry so you can see the palace and gardens before the opening of the fountains. It is a sight to see!
Like a small Versailles. beautiful place... a lovely visit, well maintained gardens and houses. Worth a visit. Ferry is fairly quick and goes pretty often back and forth

Fountains galore. The palace inside is wonderful. Lots of art and decorations. But the best is 11am...standing on the main balcony and looking out through the gardens towards the Bay of Finland as all the naturally powered fountains come on. Get out to the balcony by 10:45...it gets crowded. Then, walk down the main stairs and take a picture of the fountains looking up at the palace!
Soo Beautiful!!. Peterhof Palace and Garden was soo beautiful. It was just great walking around the gardens another must see especially for a photographer!
wow. just a beautiful place--the gardens are amazing,the fountains beautiful and the trick fountains are just plain fun.peterhof palace had beautiful paintings and objects to see.

Breathtaking...even with the rain.. We arrived in St. Petersburg to be greeted with the monsoon season. Luckily, this was only for the first day. Peterhof Gardens are breathtaking and even more so when you consider that they are all done with gravity and no modern pumps, just 18th century technology. We did not get into the Palace since we were going to Catherine's Palace on the same day and they are a bit repetitive. Maybe next time.
Incredible!. A must see for any visitor to St. Petersburg! Peterhof is beautiful and shows the opulence in which the czars lived. The hydrofoil ride there is a lot of fun!

The Hermitage, St Petersburg, Russia. This is a beautiful museum to visit, the former Tsar's Winter Palace. We visited here during a recent cruise aboard the Arcadia, and this trip had to be done in an organised party - we weren't allowed to explore on our own.Our tour group was allowed in before the museum opened to the public at 10.30am ...... along with other tour groups! Be warned, you may have to queue for a long time. If it rains, you can't take your umbrella inside (apparently), dripping water everywhere, so good idea to take a plastic bag if its raining to pop your umbrella into. You're also NOT allowed large bags, but a handbag is acceptable.Inside, there are so many objects to see - I understand 30,000 (though not sure if they're ALL out on show). Apparently spending 1 minute at each would take you 10 years! There are many, many opulent rooms, each one vast, with decorated ceilings, beautiful floors and even the doors. The main staircase is a wow!It was very hot in a lot of the rooms, with everyone wilting. Take a fan.We visited the gold room which I found disappointing. 2 groups are allowed at one time and a museum guide accompanies you. I was expecting royal jewels etc but displayed is a wealth of ancient gold jewellery from around the world, along with gifts presented to the royal family from India, China etc etc. There is nowhere to sit and rest here, though an occasional chair was to be found which was apparently for the guide! I sat down regardless, which wasn't noticed. It was hot down in these rooms and my husband felt quite faint at times. Most in our group said they hadn't enjoyed these rooms and preferred the general Hermitage/Palace rooms. Worth seeing, but I found it tedious.Back in the main museum I viewed artwork by Rembrandt and Leonardo da Vinci amongst other notable artists, and even took pictures of them (very strange we were able to photograph them)!I didn't remember all the guide said to us as there was sooo much to see, but I'm so glad I was able to visit a place I've thought about since my childhood.Warning ....... there were literally 1000's of visitors there, and became very, very crowded after 10.30am when the doors were opened to the public. If going on a visit, get there early!See my website http://balticcruise2013.weebly.com/ for my pictures (be warned, there's many to bore you)!Conclusion - you MUST visit the wonderful place!!! It's a definite wow!
Gardens That Take Your Breath Away. The site is absolutely beautiful and to see the trick water areas that were installed is fascinating.

How the .001% lived!. Dazzling palace ... and a must visit!!! There can be crowds these days (what recession, right?), but even with the crowds, it's an amazing piece of architecture. They truly "rebuilt" it to its former glory ... and perhaps even surpassed its former glory!

"Be there when they turn the fountains on". Find your place to see the spectacular show of fountains spouting off, when the water is turned on (11 am). It is not to be missed. Even though rebuilt and restored, the palace is worth the visit. There can be long lines for everything (bathrooms for sure). Get there as early as you can. Be prepared for lots of walking. Breathtaking! Great place for purchasing quality gifts and mementos of your trip.

very beautiful fountains and garden. it's amazing : there's no engine for water that jump in diffrence hight from diffrent golden fountains.it's beside two diffrent garden in front and backyard of palace.Remind you Versilles Palace in France but I can't say which one is more beautiful!! When we were there the wheather was too hot !! and we were shocked cause we wait for better codition .

Insightful Tour. We booked the tour while on our Norwegian Cruise Lines travel through the Baltics so we paid NCL and our bus was waiting right on the dock. A lot has to do with your tour guide and we had a very pleasant Russian lady who was our group guide for the day. She had done her homework and took great pride in doing an excellent job in answering questions and giving us insight. Peter the Great's palace was kept up quite well and although there was an abundance of tourists we got to see and hear about the royalty during that time visit the many rooms in the palace and learn about the history. The gardens and fountains were just beautiful and it is a great place if one is a photo buff to take pictures (unfortunately I am not) I just took in the sights and made many mental notes. If in St Petersburg Russia this is one sight not to pass up. The tour was about 2 to 3 hours on the grounds and museum. The only thing we were warned about were that there were an abundance of pickpockets so plan accordingly.

Peterhof. We travelled by Hydrofil to the gardens and waited patiently for the fountains to be switched. It was spectacular and well worth the wait. The gardens were extensive and well maintained. An enjoyable exerience.

Versailles in Northwest Russia. Residence of Russian Tsars with marvelous park and premises.Park with 100 of fountains copies the Versailles gardens, is worth to see more than the palace. However it is interesting as well, but in comparison with the Winter Palace in St. Petersburg or Tsarskoye Selo in Pushkin, it is smaller and less decorated. You need 2 tickets if you want to see both attractions, park and the the palace. When you decide not to visit the palace, you can enjoy relaxing stay in the park with a lot of facilities: tourist trains, water attractions (lakes with ducks, fountains for playing, etc.) bird cages, small kiosks with souvenirs and refreshments and the sea side beach. Recommended to come by boat directly from the centre of St. Petersburg and come back via public transport (marshrutka) or train to save on the way back.

Most gorgeous palace I have ever seen. This attraction is out of this world. It is the most gorgeous place I have every seen, Make sure and see the fountains get turned on at noon outside in the garden. They turn them on every day from May to September.

Spectacular fountains.. A bombed-out shell after World War 2, the palace has been faithfully rebuilt and restored. It's therefore in almost pristine condition and breathtakingly beautiful. The fountains in the gardens (268 of them) are spectacular. Again a hugely popular attraction but the staff regulate the flow of people through the palace allowing only one group at a time to pass the rope barriers to each room. Refreshment facilities score 4 out of 10.

Among impressive sites all around the city, this was the best. Among all the impressive sites throughout the city, this was the best. The grounds, fountains and gardens were fantastic, really beautiful. It was extremely grand, the palace, the fountains and we had very good weather and walked around everywhere. We also saw multiple brides on the Saturday we were there which my daughter enjoyed seeing

Wonderful park - great palace. We went with a big group of music exchange students. So we had some Russian experts to give us details. All very impressive! The waterworks (without any pumps!) start up in the morning and lasts to the evening. They are fed from a basin that fills overnight wigh water from the surroundings.Lots of history about the Tsars. Don't miss the bath house and kitchen museum at the shore.

Impressive. This was my favorite sight during my visit to Russia. Reasonably priced the hydrofoil ride sets up a great visit. Upon arriving you walk up the canal to the cascade of fountains and the front frontage. It is very grand. While not large in comparison to other european palaces, the interior is very nice and worth the time spent waiting to enter. In comparison this was the nicest palace to visit while in St. Petersburg. Of course the fountains and the view of the gulf of Finland from Peters cottage really top it off. If not the; this is one of the best palaces in europe.

A most attractive place with fascinating fountains. My wife and I visited Peterhof which means Court of Peter and is about one hour drive from the city of St Petersburg. It is the summer palace of the imperial family known for its numerous fountains of different designs from different countries. Spread over 15 hectares, the surrounding gardens are attractively landscaped and very well maintained. The fountains get water from a distance of 14 KMs from a natural reservoir 70 ft above sea level which goes into the Gulf of Finland which is close by. The palace has the residential area of the royal family. The gardens have 64 statues of different Greek Gods very attractively sculpted. A place worth visiting while at St Petersburg which is one of the most attractive cities.
Amazing fountains!. We were there in time to see the ceremonial turning on of the palace fountains. Even though it was crowded, it was worth it.

Wonderful. beautiful gardens, innumerable fountains, nice trip by hydrofoil to reach it; however, you are charged for visiting every single building in that place, which means that you end up not only paying a lot of money, but also waiting several times in line!!

Nice but. It is extremely crowded and better to do with a guide. You pass from one room to another, you can not hang around and look. It takes almost whole day. It is possible to eat quite acceptable closer to the exit.

Absolutely wonderful. This beautifully restored palace (often referred to as the Russian Versailles) certainly is an attraction that's not to be missed when visiting St Petersburg.The palace interior, the gardens and the fountains are absolutely superb.Photography is not allowed inside the palace, but photos may be taken in the gardens. The magnificent Grand Cascade fountains were switched on at 11.00am, with musical accompaniment. All very magical.

Fountains like you've never seen!. When you get to the back of the palace, you will be overwhelmed by the sight of the canal and the fountains. There are so many and have been there for hundreds of years and still using the same process. The gardens are well kept and very beautiful.
MUST GO. It is huge and nice, this is a must go place.But make sure check for their opening hour, some of the fountain may close during non-peak season or weekdays.

Wow... Great palace... good pics... Great park. This place was about a 40 min car ride from the city center. The grounds are immaculate and the palace was incredible. I have never seen so much gold. Behind the palace there is a huge park. Great place for young kids to run around in. There are even some water fountains that they can play in. If you go here with young kids this is a great place to visit toward the end of the day when they need some run around time... instead of Shussshhhhing them in museums all day. The tour of the actual palace is Ok... it took forever because of all of the tourists. you can't just walk through quickly. It takes some time. My kids were VERY grumpy when we were done, it was packed and they are not allowed to touch anything. Behind the park here there is a ferry station. You can take a Hydrafoil boat/ferry to Hermitage museum.... The boat ride is about 30 mins long and is a nice break in the day to relax in some comfy chairs.

Peterhof Palace and Garden. We arrived by hydrofoil which is probably the best way to arrive - best views of the magnificent gardens and fountains with golden statues....you just have to take pictures, it is all so pretty! The palace decor is as opulent as it gets- liked wearing little slippers over my shoes to protect the wooden floors. Fabric coverings on the walls as well as the most equisite patterned damasks for the beds and upholstered pieces on the furnishings were magnificent . Catherine the Great had "great taste"- her home is gorgeous!

Rivals Versailles. Built by Peter the Great as his summer palace it is located about one hour south of St Petersburg. Inspired by Versalles which it easilly compares to, it is yet another example of what you can achieve given unlimited wealth and an over the top imagination of how to spend it. The size and expense almost defies description.Rules crowded but not as much as the Hermitage, watch for theives and pick pockets. photographs allowed everwhere apart from the amber room. Buy a postcard or guide book if you need a picture of this room. Outside well laid out formal gardens.Worth the visit absoloutly.
Worth a visit. We took the hydrofoil; which was a lovely way to arrive and depart. There is a lot to see, so allow plenty of time. We were there for hours.

My favorite!. This palace is SO beautiful. The inside is amazing, but the gardens are just as spectacular. It does feel like Versailles with amazing gardens probably even more spectacular than Versailles. You will not be disappointed. I wish we had more time to spend here. It was a highlight of St. Petersburg!

Nice palace. The highlight of this trip is the lower gardens. They are full of fountains with different shapes. The garden is very green and big. There is food and restrooms so can easily spend an entire day here. It is very easy to get here by boat. You can take them from the pier next to the hermitage and during the summer they have boats every 25 minutes.

Peter the Great's Summer Home. This is a gorgeous summer home of Peter the Great, situated on the Gulf of Finland some 40-60 minute drive outside of Saint Petersburg. But make sure you give yourself enough time to enjoy both the palace and the gardens. The house probably takes about a half hour to 45 minutes, and it would be better with a tour guide so s/he can describe the rooms to you. The gardens can take a couple of hours, and they are nice to take at a leisurely stroll.In the palace, all visitors are given "booties" to wear so not to scuff up the floors. Then all are led up to the second floor (or first floor as called in Europe) and taken through the rooms along the front and back of the house but only in the center. Then, the tour ends in the bookstore and gift shop, of course. I suggest you use the bathroom here; otherwise, you will have to go back towards the parking lot and pay for the bathroom there.The palace is worth seeing. Many historians and architects painstakingly rebuilt these palaces from the ground up following the Great Patriotic War/World War II. These palaces of the tsars were nothing more than burned out shells in 1945.The gardens are immaculate. We arrived before 11am, and the fountains were not yet turned on. Suddenly music plays over loud speakers, and then the fountains in front of the palace come on, each set taking a turn. Had I known that I was going to see them turn on, I would have recorded it. Throughout the garden, there are several types of fountains. My favorite is the fountain of the bulldog chasing the three mallard ducks. It has sounds of ducks playing, too. This is a wishing fountain - get the coin on the duck or dog's back and you will have good luck. There are trick fountains children love to play on. And maybe dip your toes in the Gulf of Finland.And of course, if you are finished with your tour, you can purchase food at the stands between the parking lot and palace gate. The Russian pancakes are delicious! Then, take a stroll through the vendors to pick up a souvenir if you'd like.Even though the Russians disposed their tsars nearly 100 years ago, they still make sure to present them in the historical sites. This is one to see.

The private home of Peter the Great. This is a beautifully restored and maintained building that once was the home of Peter the Great. It is located in a wonderful wooded gardens of several hundred acres that eventually back up on to the sea. The gardens are decorated with many fountains and statues and it is a wonderful place to visit.The palace is not camera friendly, not photography was permitted inside the building anywhere.At around 11am in the summer months, the run the "cascade" which are the main fountains directly in front of the castle. It is a good thing to see and very entertaining. The full experience of the fountains lasts around 15 minutes. You need to get a good spot lower down 15 to 20 minutes prior to the show starting.I fully recommend this to anyone who wants to see a beautiful example of one of the Russian Czars palaces.

Gorgeous surprise. The restful upper gardens were a tease of what awaited us when we got around the palace to see the grandeur of the lower gardens. Both gardens are enticing in their own way. The upper being more relaxing with nice walking paths, benches to sit and rest,lakes, fountains and plantings. A nice nature setting. Then you walk behind the palace and are awe struck by the magnificence of the lower gardens! Nothing can prepare you for the brilliant, lustrous,palatial grandeur of what you see. We walked out to the Baltic sea and looked back toward Peterhoff. I'm glad we did. To see all of the fountains and know there are no pumps used to help the water flow is amazing. It's all gravitational flow. Would like to come back and spend more time in the surrounding area and see the town.
Definitely worth a visit. The palace was beautiful and so were the gardens. It's a little way out of St. Petersburg but worth the journey.

Lives up to expectations. Spectacular experience--more impressive to me than Versailles. And photography is invited! Don't miss the palace chapel (extra admission, no photos), the richest (in terms of gold) and most extravagant baroque church ever constructed. Hard to get to. Public transport is very cheap, but time-consuming (an hour and a half in rush hour). Hydrofoils are quick but expensive and don't believe the hype about views: there are none, except of the flat sea and flat land.

One of the Grandest of the Grand. Only Versailles surpasses the opulence and beauty of Peter the Great's Palace. Fully restored after almost being totally destroyed in WW II, it is truly a gem with buildings, furnishings, grounds, and fountains in full splendor. It would not be worth a trip to St. Petersberg and miss this.

you need time if you decide to go. We went there by hydrofoil. If it quite an attraction. We would have liked to spend more time there wandering the grounds. If you decide to go make sure you have time to explore.

Lovely place to visit and spend a few hours. We took the hydrofoil from behind the Hermitage to visit Peterhof, not a cheap option, 650 roubles each way per person but were not sure enough of the language and bus service to do it any other way. It was another 450 roubles each to get into the Gardens which were really lovely and nice to stroll around. The Palace itself looked absolutely lovely but we could not face the thought of waiting in a huge line of people to go inside and it was very warm so cannot comment on the interior.We had a drink sitting outside the cafe/restaurant overlooking some nice gardens, it was very relaxing.Would recommend but perhaps if you have the facility to print tickets, to book your inside visit online to avoid the long queues.

A BEAUTIFUL Place - an EYEful ! ! !. This ONE of the must see attractions in the world . . . Peter the Great attempted to outdo anything he had viewed previously, and apparently he did. The fountains, gardens, buildings, paths and general grandeur are "all world" and a definite must see Peterhof Gardens (and Palace) when you visit St. Petersburg (Russia).As others suggest, probably the most reliable, and efficient way to the gardens is by hydrofoil from The City. We traveled by bus, and this was tedious due to heavy traffic, road construction, and generally limited route possibilities.There are crowds in the peak months, and sure enough you do not want to visit on a rainy day, so plan your trip to St. Petersburg accordingly.

My husband's Trip Favorite. Lovely, pleasant and relaxing actually. Beautiful and amazing, yes, but in a much easier way to "digest" than other spots. A wonderful stroll and break from touring - but an important place to visit. Simply gorgeous and calming at the same time.
Fantastic. This is impressive both in terms of scale and experience. Remarkable architecture, well organised for tourists, beautiful, historic and a must if you are in St Petersburg.

OTT in every way.. Be there before 11am to catch the turning on of the fountains, complete with musical fanfare. Words cannot describe the sheer grandeur of this place. It must be seen, inside and out, with your own eyes. It's sad that photographing inside is not allowed, even without a flash, which isn't needed anyway. However, the extensive grounds, with many other buildings, pavilions, guilded statuary and fountains every few yards, is very photogenic and even peaceful in parts. The view out across the Baltic sea makes a good resting spot.Tip: because photography is not allowed in many of St Petersburg's stately homes and museums, I purchased a 160 page, full colour book for 149 rubles (about $6 NZD) about the city and it's environs. Helps keep the memories alive!
Magnificent Peterhof. Fountains, terraces and over 100 sculptures in a park like setting. A masterpiece of architecture using the natural formation of the land to create the most picturesque park.

Beware if you are in a group from a cruise ship on a Monday. A beautiful ornate historical palace without a doubt but visiting here was the low point of our trip to Russia and the Baltic states. Peterhof is apparently officially "closed" to the general public on Mondays - but that is the day that they seem to take bookings for group visits. If there are several cruise ships in St Petersburg the Palace is overcrowded and unpleasant. When we visited it was raining heavily. You are not allowed to take umbrellas or coats in with you and these have to be checked in to the cloakrooms first - so there were hundreds of people standing in pouring rain waiting to shuffle in to start this process. There were no facilities for the disabled to wait under cover. The waiting time was lengthy we were told as as the Palace is "closed" there were fewer cloakroom staff on duty. You then have to queue to put on plastic overshoes. As another reviewer has said the room attendants do not let you linger and seem to be all powerful. You just have to keep moving along with the crowds. There now seems to be annoying new trend for some tourists to have to have their photo taken in front of the major interior furnishings & exhibits so this often limits your passing view. The worst part of the visit was re-visiting the cloakrooms to re-claim coats and umbrellas as you have to go in the same direction and through the same small doors and corridors as those coming in to start their cloakroom check-in. It was absolute chaos with multiple nationalities getting increasingly unpleasant and abusive, pushing and shoving - a solid mass of people being swept along. I lost my husband at one point in the process and then discovered that he had been helping an American tourist who was having a panic attack in the midst of the crowd. Our small cruise ship had arranged for us to have "early entry" and viewing before the main groups were allowed in (at additional cost) but this was never going to happen with the vast numbers pouring into the Palace. If anyone had a good experience that morning it would be a miracle.
A wonderland of fountains. Although we did not go into the palace we spent all our time walking around the wonderful park gazing at the awe inspiring fountains and other features

Personification of Opulence. The Summer Palace of Peter the Great and his descendants is the epitome of elegance and opulence. The palace itself is extremely ornate and cultured, not unlike other grand residences, but the gardens are unique and breath-taking. The Grand Cascade, a series of waterfalls and fountains culminating in a superb pool with a sculpture of Samson, is the most elaborate fountain I have ever seen. Besides the Grand Cascade there are many other fountains on the grounds.

Not to be missed, if you have time.. If you are visiting St. Petersburg, you must find time to go to Peterhof. The quickest way to get there is via Meteor Hydrofoil. They depart at regular intervals from 2 points in St. Petersburg centre. One close to the Hermitage/Winter Palace, and one further up river and within walking distance of the Field of Mars.
beautiful. the gardens and fountains are beautifully restored and too amazing for words. A walk around the grounds was a beautiful sight

Grandeur of the tsars. My tour group had an appointment at Peterhof, so we had a short wait to enter the palace and walk through the rooms. Unfortunately, it is not permitted to take pictures inside and the group has to keep moving as there is always another group following behind. The rooms were beautifully restored and furnished. We enjoyed walking through the gardens as well and admiring the fountains. Across the Gulf of Finland, you can see Finland!

Fantastic afternoon. Approximately, a 1/2 hour drive west of St. Petersburg this summer Palace is worth the trip. The day we were there the house was closed but that didn't deminish our visit at all. The grounds are emmence and beautiful. The park below the Palace all the way to the sea is enchanting. The main attraction are the multiple fountains that are extrememly well maintained and are located directly behind the palace and lead you to the park. There are many beds of flowers. We were there when the tulips were in bloom. Even though there are many visitors the park is so large that you can feel comfortable and relax as you walk.

Great place to visit. These are truly beautiful gardens and especially the many fountains there are a joy. The trip to and from Peterhof (we went by the hovercraft one way and the minivan on the return) is also very enjoyable. Don't miss this gem

Wonderful place -- must see!. It is one of the most pleasant historical cites close to St. Petersburg. Wonderful park with unique fountains and impressive grand palace. Choose a sunny warm summer day to plan your visit! And by the way u can get there from St. Petersburg by sea!
A must see !. Peterhof palace is one of most stunning palace in the Europe. It is quite far from city and but definitely worth a visit . You will need a day including travelling at this stie.

Beautiful house, church, fountains, and gardens. The house and church, the fountains and gardens, were beautiful. The gilt was overwhelming, and I can understand why people revolted against the Tsars' excesses. Now, at least, they have a beautiful place to attract tourists.We were there when they turned on the fountains, and it was breathtaking. Walked through the gardens and were constantly amazed.
Great Place. Great Place to visit. We took the Hydrofoil to Peterhof and it was fast and easy to get there. I recommend it!

Peterhoff Place & Garden. This was wonderful. We had lunch there and it was excellent. Service was good and wait staff very attentive. The grounds were magnificent and well maintained. Lots of walking but well worth the time.

Stunning and peaceful at the same time. With beautiful weather, the gardens were gorgeous and so was the Palace! Walked leisurely through the sites and the gardens taking in the history and the restored beauty of years past. St. Petersburg is a stunning reminder of the deep roots of the Russian people and their recognition of the shoulders on which they stand from years past.

Gorgeous. We arrived in the morning, while it was less crowded and still cool (ish), which was perfect. We then got to get our spot picked out for the turning on of the fountains, which was quite impressive. The lines are long, the crowds are vast, but there is so much to see and do, it is more than worth it.

my new love. oh my god, i'm in love with this place! when i saw the gulf-of-finland i nearly cried, it was SO beautiful, now i get why Peter loved water and slept in a house near the water!! there's a great deal of fountains, of course you should come here in the morning and see how they start working with all the music and royalty. there're many food spots and the souvenirs are the cheapest here. by the way, the toilets are free, clean and there're A LOT of them, so you won't have to spend an hour waiting for your turn.wishing you to see this place on a sunny and warm day!

A grand summer palace. Beautiful gardens and fountains. A perfect picture opportunity for the many newly weds we saw there who had come for their photos . Lavishly decorated grand ballroom, dining rooms and the living quarters, it showcases Russian opulence at its best.

Incredible!. This was the most breathtaking site in our 2 day tour of St Petersburg. I will not describe it-spoiler alert! Just to say that if you love gardens,history and architecture you will not be disappointed.

Wow!. You could spend quite a bit of time here. besides the main palace and grounds with the beautiful fountains and ponds, there are other areas to see and lots of walking trails tha beckon. I wish we had had more time here, but we did it same day as Catherine's Palace and it was too much for one day.

Heaven on earth. Have to see. The place is gorgeous! the best and easy way to go is, we think, by hydrofoil from the pier at the back of Hermitage. Buy a round trip ticket, it takes 30 min to reach there. Preparing lunch with you is a good idea. We did not get into the palace building, just the garden. To get good pictures, must go when it's sunny, check the weather. might want to see before going? take a look at https://picasaweb.google.com/100092841543065224921/StPetersburgRussia2013

Guest Control Leaves a Bit to be Desired. So the sign on the entry door says tickets sold inside. But when we tried to enter to do so we were pointed to the end of a long entry line (even being understood that we needed to get the tickets first).So into the hour long line and we finally made it in. Asked about tickets and were shunted off to the right. OK. Waited in another line to deposit the day packs, a second line to acquire and put on shoe protection, and finally a third line for entry into an anteroom. Where, of course, we were turned back for not having the tickets.So we trudge all the way back to one small, and somewhat hidden, ticket window where the lady refused to sell us tickets, pointing to a sign saying something to the effect that no foreigner tickets to be sold for the next hour.Long story short, a sympathetic supervisor who had just pointed us to the ticket window noticed our unusual combination of dejection and frustration and, with the aid of two other supervisors (at least others seemed to jump when they spoke), forced the ticket lady to issue tickets. Then, quite surprisingly, she bulled herself and us all the way to the front of the huge line to where we had earlier been turned back, said a few words, and we were in.We had to join a Russian speaking tour (English is foreign, remember?) but that was ok as we were entranced by the place itself. If not for the kindness (uncharacteristic of traditional Russia) of those supervisors I would have been forced to give only 1 or 2 stars here.
Wow Wow and more Wow. The Palace stood behind the fountains is a sight to behold. Then at 11am the fountains start to play to music. If you get the chance to go to Peterhof do not miss the display.

Beautiful, but unbelievably crowded. There's no question that this attraction is absolutely breathtakingly beautiful. However, that beauty was greatly diminished by the unbelievable crowds. which prevented us from going inside any of the buildings.The 100+ fountains with the gold statues are really something to see. I can't say enough for them. Peter the Great had quite a home!But we got there before it opened on a weekday morning, and the lines to get into the main building were already going half way around the building. The estimated wait time to get inside was more than 2 hours at that point. We decided not to go in, because we didn't want to spend too much of our vacation waiting in a line. And people told us the next day that once they got in they really couldn't see much or get around without stepping on other tourists.
Wow!. Absolutely stunning gardens and palaces, a great day out, and I can reccomend the Orangery for Lunch

Massive Palace and Gardens. This is another palace that captures the essence of the czar period. Amazing the wealth required to build and maintain. The degree of workmanship that went into each of the very large and diversified rooms.As impressive as the palace is, the gardens are more spectacular when one realizes that all 150 water fountains of various designs and sizes are all gravity fed with no pumps of any kind.A tip on travel to the location is to take the hydrafoil that docks right in front of the Hermitage Museum rather than any kind of ground transportation that can get stuck in traffic.

Splendid waterworks. Loved the cool shade of the parks, as it was very warm weather. Kids were playing in the trick fountains, enjoying themselves. The fountains are an amazing engineering achievement. Watch out for the tourist-trapping girls who offer to pose with you on photos, they demand good payment.

The gardens and the nostalgic Baltic Sea view the best. The gardens and the nostalgic Baltic Sea view the best ....it was a rainy summer day and it gave us a real impression of Dovstoyevski's and Peter the Greats nostalgia dn greatness. The fountains are fun and humorous with eclectic taste. My favourite part of the visit was the gardens and view full of illusion. The palace is ok, if you are short of time or budget just visit the garden and go to Catalinas Palace.
Wow. Have seen lots of palaces and grounds, but this place was really a gem. We didn't go inside (very hot day), but were well impressed with the fountains and grounds.

So Many Fountains, So Little Time. With our group leader only allowing us to go through the gardens, I became obsessed with counting the fountains and enjoying the park's ambience. We had taken a hydrofoil from St. P's and loved the rural feel of the magnificent gardens. The levels of the garden added to the picturesque quality. Lots of stairs, but worth it.

Peterhof the spectacular. This place is the most amazing places and has to be on any bucket list - just to stand and look at the most amazing colours and fountains is just sensational - just go and be blown away but go early May the weather is fantastic

Beautiful, but avoid the groups!. This wonder built by Peter the Great certainly deserves a whole day to be visited! The access from St. Pete is very easy, and my suggestion is to go early in the morning, visit the interior of the Palace and then spend the rest of the day in the Gardens. By the end of the gardens, near the Finnish Peninsula, there's a nice restaurant and resting point. Inside the palace it is VERY busy, and the combination of some narrow rooms and the annoying groups is terrible. And, of course, its Russia, so expect TERRIBLE staff, no english speakers, those awful russian ladies that take care of the rooms can make your visit very unpleasant. Of course they need to be very attentive because there's always idiot people who touch the things, but they don't need to be so rude.
The Fountains; Oh My, the FOUNTAINS!!!. Take the time to visit the gardens and fountains of the Peterhof. It's busy but pretty amazing - a visual sensation.

Place of peace. In the evening, about an hour before closing, only Samson fountain is working. So if you wish to enjoy full fountain view you better arrive earlier! Also during “white night” period the closing show of the fountains with fireworks is not something you would wish to stay for since it is still a full-bright daytime and you would not see anything exceptional except some pink-blue-orange mist around.

Nice palace to via hydrofoil. The best way to visit this site to take the hydrofoil which cost 650 rubbles and price reduces if in a group. The palace is closed in afternoon from 12.30 to 2.30 . So take early cruise or 3pm one. The hydrofoil departs right from behind hermitage exit. There are 3 to 4 companies selling tickets. The journey takes just 30 minutes. Once you reach you buy ticket for gardens around 400 rubbles. Also you can book your return ticket . It takes min 3 hrs to see the palace including the palace. Then you see the beautiful fountains and beach. The palace has a long queue for buying tickets costing 550 rubbles per person. Then there is another line for going inside the palace. So if you are more than one stand separately in both lines to save time. The palace is worth seeing. Inside they have cloak room to put camera etc. no photography allowed. Rooms are beautiful. It takes 1 hour min to see all rooms. On exit the museum shop is superb. Once you come out again long walk back to the hydrofoil. The hydrofoil is dot on time so don't be late. Worth a visit.
Breathtaking. I could have stared at the water fountain for hours... Spectacular... The beauty is second to none...

Beautiful Gardens, Incredible Fountains, nice hydrofoil boat ride. The Peterhof Palace is a nice break from touring the city center. You can take the 45 minute hydrofoil boat ride, or drive about 1 hour from St. Petersburg. The gardens are unbelievably beautiful - with peonies, roses, lavender, sculptured hedges and trees, expansive forests, and of course the famous fountains and sculptures. Take a picnic or buy lunch at the nice cafe. We toured the very small Monplaisir (My Pleasure) Palace, instead of the Grand Palace, and really enjoyed the afternoon. It would be a great place for kids to run around!

Great but not Versailles. If you've been to Versailles you might want to skip this one.
Also, the toilet facilities are just abysmal.
We had a picnic by the water and that very pleasant.
The hydrofoil trip is good too.

Glorious, peaceful and pure!. We took the hydrofoil to and from - nice 1/2 hour boat ride. Did not visit the palace, but did tour Monplaisir - Peters preferred residence. The gardens are so beautiful and peaceful, and the air is so pure you feel wonderful just breathing it! There are several food stands and a restaurant, but we brought a picnic lunch and ate under the umbrellas near one of the many magnificent fountains. Wear a bathing suit or something waterproof if you want to stand in one of the " tricky fountains" and get soaked - fed from mineral springs that are good for your skin, as well as your soul! Take nuts and feed the small fluffy red Russian squirrels by hand - the highlight of our trip for my daughter!

Fountains and Gardens worth a trip. Wwe toured the inside of the Perterhof Palace but the real attraction is the garden with its fountains. Be sure to note which fountains are turned on at what times. When we were there, the right side (looking out from the palace) fountains were on. So we hiked out through the gardens on that side, returning to the Palace by the 11am time that the main fountain at the palace went off. Quite impressive!
Amazing fountains. It's not just the palace that amazes, it's the exterior as well, with superb fountains in the gardens. Make sure you get a hydrofoil back to the city!
Not worth for the ticket price. Not too many things to see inside. The rooms are quite small with lots visitors. No English instruction. Compare to the price of ticket, the quality is relative poor.

Spectacular Waterworks. We loved seeing Peter the Great's Summer Palace, learning about the design of his fantastic gravity fed fountains, and simply seeing the spectacle of his creation on the shores of the Baltic. This palace should be at the top of your short list for a visit to St. Petersburg.

Peterhof Palace and Garden. Wow factor here. To see all the wonderful fountains and gardens was just an amazing experience. Had a set meal lunch here which was very good. There were people dressed up in period costumes and you could have photographs taken with them. Loved the joke fountains which caused lots of laughter.
GEORGEOUS PALACE. Another must see in St. Petersburg. Beautiful extensive gardens. Try to visit when in full bloom. You can spend hours in the gardens alone.

No wonder there was a Revolution. We visited Peterhofs by Hydrofoil,walking up along the lovely Canal.It was a perfect June day.We only saw the exterior of the Palace very imposing,as we had come to see the famous Fountains.Never have we seen so much Gold the Fountains are covered with it and there are over 150 ofthem.It is truly amazing and well worth visiting,I wish we had the time to go inside the Palace.

Beautiful Palace. The Palace is lovely and well worth a visit. As a gardener I was very disappointed with the garden.. The tulips were at their best but the grass/lawn was uncut and spoilt the whole appearance. The whole garden was unloved.. A poor selection of food available to buy.

Better than Versailles.... I love Peterhof and would go back for the day in a heartbeat. The fountains are amazing, the location is perfect (on the sea), and the gardens are grand. I like it better than versailles if you don't consider the palace. The grounds just seem more grand and the fountains just simply better. The palace is lacking and just doesn't feel right knowing that it was mostly new since being damaged during the war. But, it was still a great palace, just not what I was expecting. Take time to walk the grounds, you will find much diversity of gardens, fountains, and architecture; it is quite surprising. And to come out on the Baltic Sea in the summer makes it that much more grand.

Excellent side trip from St Petersburg. After visiting Catherine's Palace a couple of days before this, the interior of Peterhof was nice but not the must-see. Certainly the interior style is different, but if you are pressed for time, spend it outside in the gardens instead. Peterhof was destroyed in WWII, so what you are exploring now is the rebuilt Peterhof.We came here with a tour company, which of course required that we follow the prescribed itinerary rather than exploring on our own. Note that even with a tour company, you can get stuck in a long line to get into the interior. We waited in line outside (hot!) for 55-60 minutes. Our tour guide said that this was very unusual, so your experience may be different. You will need to check your bags at the beginning of the tour. It seems well organized and our tour guide said there would be no problems (there weren't). Not that unlike Catherine's Palace, there is no photography whatsoever allowed inside Peterhof.TIP: If you need to visit the washroom prior to the interior tour, I suggest doing that prior to getting in line. There are facilities inside, but if you are stuck in line for a while just to get inside...

Great gardens and fountains. We had perfect weather, so it was a great day to walk around these gardens. The fountains are really neat, and pretty. The palace is quite beautiful too. But, I liked the gardens best. There's a chessboard looking grounds in front of one of the fountains. There's a really impressive cascading fountains in front of the palace. All the fountains operate without pumps, just by natural springs and pressure. Go check it out if you are in St. Petersburg.

Beautiful fountains. We took the hydrofoil to Peterhof and I really enjoyed the trip both ways.The gardens and fountains are beautiful to visit and are a must see when in Saint Petersburg.Visit the trick fountain!Really fun.Lots of "cool down"areas which the kids really enjoy.For the keen photographer,paradise.

Most amazing fountains/grounds, perfect day trip. We arrived just in time for the fountains to all start, choreographed to music blaring. It was very crowded so we were pushed through the rooms by staff but it was an amazing palace with the MOST beautiful view of the waterway to the sea.

Terribly overpriced and crowded. I was very excited to go to Peterhoff on a hot June day. However upon arriving I was very disappointed. I was not disappointed in the beautiful palace that is Peterhoff. What I was disappointed About, was the huge crowd that had accompanied me.
