It was like being at Disneyland in California on the most Popular day of the summer. In the palace I could hardly move amongst the crowd. There were huge to her groups of Chinese and Germans and Russians each following a guy talking loudly. It was impossible to enjoy the palace. The Russian ladies who sat in each room scurried you along and didn't even let you finish the commentary On the handset before they pushed you out. It would make sense to charge you a combined price to see everything at the palace and the palace grounds. But remember this is Russia and nothing makes sense. You have to pay each time you entering new part of the parking palace. By the time you leave you spent at least $100. And that doesn't count the amount of money you spent to get there on the hydrofoil. Don't get me wrong, the palace was remarkable and so beautiful and I'm glad I saw it. But fighting the crowds was one horrible experience. Probably the most negative experience I had while in St. Petersburg. They really need to find a way to filter the people through the grounds in a more sensible manner. Having a combined ticket would help as well so that you only paid one time instead of five times. Someone in the tourist ministry of Russia needs to get on top of this. There are many things wrong with Peterhoff but the first thing is that they need a combined ticket so that you don't have to pay it every date second thing is that they need English translations at each part of the monument so that you can have some way of knowing what you're looking at. They also need to have a brochure at the gate so that you can actually tour yourself around instead of following a tour guide. that would keep the amount of large groups to a minimum. After spending a week in Russia I get the feeling that they don't like people walking around museums alone the preferred if you're in a large group with a turn. That's not the way I like to travel.

peterhoff gardens. our tour took us to the gardens of Peterhof. Amazing the detail of the fountains and gardens for the time they were built. Hard to believe the use of gravity to power the fountains. Our visit was in late May and weather the day we were in the gardens was overcast but not raining. The gardens are large enough to have many people without feeling crowed. We arrived by hydrofoil and left by our tour bus. Our next stop was Catherine Palace.

World Class. The Hermitage is one of the most significate museums of the world. The building itself, was the winter palace of the czars and is architecturally stunning. Out it's windows, there are views of the Neva River and Peter and Paul Fortress , Palace Square, the Spit of Vasilyevsky Island and much more.It houses the largest collection of the significant Immpressionist's , I have ever seen in one museum. One can not begin to see a fraction of the museum in a one time visit.

Pricey, over rated. The lower garden fountain are amazing. The palace, beautiful. Upper garden beautiful. It's a clearly beautiful palace, but it is pricey. 450 rubles to access the lower park. If you come by boat, it means you have to exit the lower park to access the upper park. You won't be able to come back in the lower park if you don't have a return ticket. Forget about taking any picture in the palace its forbidden and they are ladies in each room that are checking on you. The palace is not that busy, so forget about sneaking one behind.. and why is it that we can't take pictures.. really? Finally it was very difficult to communicate there as it seems no one spoke any English.

Peterhof. we did not inside the palace, but walked through the garden, which was very nice. The only negative part is - its expensive to get to the place (without public transport, we used ferry) and then extra pay of >10 EUR just for the garden... Its nice place to see, but 30 EUR per person was a bit too much for what you get ;)

A very beautiful palace and gardens. We were on a river cruise and visited as part of a group, going by hydrofoil. Very nice to see a palace on a slightly smaller scale than others, appeared more homely. It was very crowded as most places were, but the gardens can absorb more people without it seeming oppressive. Weather was not very good at the time of our visit, which was not conducive to waiting about. Had a very nice coffee and bun at the cafe in the grounds.

From shambles to grandeur. Bourgeose grandeur of yesteryears have been meticulously recreated to its finest last details in both the Lower and Upper Gardens. The exotic fountains in the Lower Garden gush out not with the aid of any pumps but due to the gravitational pressure from the waters of the Upper Garden. An ingenius idea conceived centuries ago. I strongly recommend that all visitors should go around the photo exhibition at the entrance to get a first hand knowledge about the devastation of Peterhof by the Nazis and the subsequent arduous efforts of restoration. I am certain that any viewer's heart will melt at the sight of the photographs.

A must!. Took the hydrofoil...what fun! Arrived early, before the crowds. Great photo opportunities. One must be VERY careful of pick pockets. But great to see the fountains and gardens. The site is clean and well kept.
Peterhof. It was a beautiful day and a beautiful experience. We enjoyed the gardens and a nice lunch at the Orangerie restaurant.

Beautiful to walk in. We deliberately visited the gardens and fountains on a day when the palace was shut. We expected the crowds to be less but in fact it was very crowded. Once you get to the lower gardens the crowds thin out and you can start to enjoy the beautiful fountains and statues. Walk along the Gulf of Finland and look back on the Palace and grounds, it shows just how remarkable it is. Expect to be there for four hours. Also, we caught a bus to Peterhof which was inexpensive and fast. We caught the hydrofoil back to avoid walking all the way back up to the front of the palace where the bus stop is. The hydrofoil turned out to be an uncomfortable 45 minute trip - overheated inside, smell of fuel and not much to see along the route. Not cheap either. In retrospect, we would have just as soon walked back up through the gardens to get the bus back.

Fantastic gardens but the house interior is too much hassle to be worth visiting. Considering the palace was mostly destroyed during the war, the Russians have done an amazing reconstruction job. Fortunately they had shipped the room interiors to Siberia for safety. The gardens are amazing, with new vistas been revealed at every turn. The interior of the house is also very impressive, but very small by comparison to the Hermitage. However the way the tickets are sold for visiting the house and also the fact that they keep everyone in groups going around the house, means the whole experience of visiting the house is a lot of time consuming hassle. The Russians know how to create artificial queues with style! So if you have seen the

Not just beauty. Many visitors to this beautiful property have no idea what an engineering marvel it is.The myriad of fountains are not powered by a single pump nor any other mechanical nor any other artificial device.They operate strictly by gravity. The water flow from higher to lower ground, is not obvious enough too understand by most who visit. This, as well as the magnificent gardens and the fountains themselves make Peterhof a must see if you are in the area.

It's massive. Feels like a park than a palace and hordes of tourists around the main fountain just behind the palace building in the lower pavilion area. Lots of tour groups and families with young children when we went, but most were respectful when trying to pictures, so it was all quite civilized. Prepare to spend good 3+ hours if you wish to see all the features in the garden, more if you are planning on visiting the palace museum also.

Even the second time is stunning but take the hydrofoil to avoid rush hour traffic. I visited here in 1973 and my memory of this place was fantastic...well, 40 years later it's even better!!! The grounds and fountains just can not be described accurately and do it justice. Do yourself a favor and make sure that you get out by the fountains before 11AM so that you can experience the Russian National Anthem being played as the Fountains come to life.I learned some new things such as the Germans actually occupied this palace but never Leningrad known today as St. Petersburg. We even saw the german built bunkers on property. All in all this is one of the top sites in ll the world so don't miss it. BTW you can take a hydrofoil across the bay to The Hermitage which get's you right back into town.
A real must!. Take the boat instead of the bus or metro. Use the locally rented out pen guides and you can skip the expensive tourguide. :-)

lots of gold, fountains and bling. The tour inside the palace is worth the time and money as it's over the top with expensive and exensive wall coverings, furniture and opulence The huge expansive gardens present a view to the river amongst golden statues of mystical creatures, figures and water fountains. It's worth the one hour bus ride outside the city

A visit to Peterhoff. Have just got back from visiting Peterhoff Palace and gardens. We went in May and found it very very busy. The Palace was fairly uninteresting and I felt there was no time to linger as we were herded through the rooms by the officious curators, the gardens however were fantastic with beautifully manicured lawns and spectacular fountains. The market area between the entrance and the car park was very noisy and slightly intimidating, but well worth a visit

Do not miss an opportunity to visiti this!!. I'd been given a steer on Peterhof before I travelled so was keen to see. Although it was not on the itinerary on our visit, our group all wanted to go - and it was the highlight of our visit to Russia. You will be overwhelmed by the opulence of the Palace - it outshines St Catherines - and the gardens are stunning cascading down to the gulf of Finland. DO NOT MISS THIS!

Gorgeous Gardens. The palaces are pretty and typical examples of royal ostentation but the gorgeous gardens with fountains and cascades make this well worth a visit. Probably would not be so much fun in foul weather.

Mind-boggling beautiful. This place was such a highlight and so beautiful, but did not like photos. But that was OK because my husband bought a photo book that was very reasonably priced so we could bring it home and study the outrageously beautiful rooms at our leisure and remember the FEEL of seeing it with our mouths open gasping at the beauty.

Renewal. We did not get in the palace although some groups do. One does not understand the system of who get a turn to go into the palace. we did see a lot of the gardens which have been painstakingly returned to the original. The guides will quickly tell you that the Nazis burned these buildings. Again, millions put into buildings that the general population would have no use for while they live in less than ideal situations. Still is very beautiful to see and it is amazing at the detailed work that has been done.I believe this is a place where government officials hold special events for visiting dignitaries.

The Palace busy - the Park gardens beautiful. Definitely a must see - the Peterhof [Palace] has some lovely art & furniture etc but when busy the guides 'push' the groups around so may be rather rushed. For me the Park - gardens & fountains - were far more spectacular & pleasant to spend time wandering around in. Just be warned that we experienced a cloud of bighting midges under the trees near one of the large fountains & I had not used a repellant!

Peterhof Fountains. The fountains and gardens at Peterhof were a site to see! Incredible is all I can say. Pictures do not do this place justice. Our Alla-Tour guide did such a great job in coordinating our visit. We took the hydrofoil boat ride which saved lots of time. Highly recommend visiting this site while in SPB.

They charge separately for everything!. Peterhof is Peter the Great's Versailles - and it is magnificent. We had a fun ride on the hydrofoil from downtown St. Petersburg, but after paying for the park entrance, it turned out that we would have to buy additional tickets to see the insides of the buildings. Having just spent two days in the imperial splendor of the Hermitage, we decided to skip the gilded interiors and walk around the beautiful "lower park" and see the fountains, etc. Unfortunately, as in some areas of France, the Russian keepers of Peterhof do not permit guests to walk or sit on the grass in the park.
Over the top opulence. Eye popping, to say the least. Gilt, gilt and more gilt. Even in the magnificent gardens. Almost indescribable. If you're in St. Petersburg, you can't miss this one.

Beautiful fountains. I didn't plan anything in St. Petersburg expecting my friends who live there to show me around so I didn't expect much from Peterhol, but at the end, I fell in love with this beautiful summer palace! Stunning fountains and beautiful gardens, I spent so much times walking around.

The House is closed on Mondays. Keep in mind, the house is closed on Mondays, although the grounds were magnificent, We took the hydrofoil from St. Petersburg there which was very time efficient. But when we got there to buy our tickets we were told it was cash only and there was no change available (they do need to work on their people skills if they want visitors to their country).

Impressive from the first sight. At the very beginning, even from outside the Palace, this place is absolutely stunning. Inside it, every garden and fountain are inviting you to come closer and even take part of it. All along thr property, there are surprises for people of all ages, from that "joking fountains" until the beautifull aight of the Baltic sea. Magnificently built, and well cared, really worth a visit.
fabulous fountains!. the fountains and grounds are spectacular. They regularly change the flowers in the gardens. Be sure to check out the "trick" fountains for some fun!

Magnificent Fountains. The fountains in the Peterhof Gardens are splendid. On a beautiful day the crowds will come out, but the scale of the gardens easily absorbs the multitudes. We took mass transit (subway and bus) to the palace following the decorations on the website. While it took at least twice as long to get there, we looked on it as an adventure and a chance to get a little better sense of the people of St. Petersburg. The cost saving over taking the hydrofoil was dramatic.

Royal. Tucked away from the city, you'll have to board an Hydrofoil behind the Hermitage museum( single ticket : 650p, return ticket: 450p, round trip 1100p, duration 45min) or take the bus (far cheaper) to reach this marvellous place. I loitered for hours in the park enjoying the scenery of the numerous cascades and fountains. the weather was amazingly nice on the first week of June that I couldn't have felt better elsewhere.Take your time and make the most of the Romantic atmosphere....Entrance fee to the lower park: 450p

Take the hydrofoil. The museum was closed on the Monday that we visited but the grounds are spectacular. Highly recommend the map and multi-language guide pen. It works very well and was only ~$11 equivalent.

Amazing.... The Palace and Garden are once again, one of those must see sights. A visit to St. Petersburg is not complete without it. The amount of art work is overwhelming beautiful. The Amber Room, is not to be missed, unfortunately, you are ushered through very quickly.

Incredible Place. Wow, took the hovercraft to the Palace, plenty of space to look around and not have lots of crowds. Gardens amazing all the fountains, did not have time to inside the Palace but the outside is worth a visit on its own

Great gardens/park. This is truly a wonderful park. Would love to see when there aren't 20,000 visitors (maybe an exaggeration, but it sure seemed like there were tour groups everywhere). We didn't have enough time to truly explore, but when the weather is nice (as it was for us), it makes for an amazing experience. Didn't get into the palace, but I am finding that all palaces essentially look the same now.

Fountains, Fountains and more Fountains!. Even if you're not into fountains the Peterhof Gardens are a sight to behold. Probably more fountains than you've ever seen in your life , or maybe hope to see again. But the gardens themselves are something to see. However not much fun if the sun is not shining.
Fountain Lover's Paradise. It was very pretty and the fountains are spectacular. The Gardens are nice, but expect to walk and bring bug spray. the park is a bit swampy, so there are mosquitoes

Must do. A great way to get out of St. Petersburg. The palace is easily accessible from the front of the Hermitage. A pleasant ferry ride will take you roundtrip from there. The gardens and fountains are stunning. The palace is huge and incredible. Take your time, just walk around the gardens away from the crowds. Take it all in.

Peterhof. Take the hydrofoil round-trip from in front of Hermitage - you will enjoy the fresh air and the approach to the Peterhof that much more. Be aware that the Castle is closed on Mondays, but that didn't stop us. We much enjoyed the fountains, the lower park and the jaw dropping gold statues. Try to go at a time when you think there will be fewer people. It can be crowded, but the park is enormous. Be sure to walk along the ocean on your way back to the wharf. A stunning half-day trip.
It was so beautiful. You can't begin to describe the beauty of these gardens and fountains and OMG the palace. It's a must see

peterhof Palace and Garden. magnificient gardens. It was a beautiful warm day and the locals were out as well enjoying the amenities. Saw a few wedding parties, enjoying the gardens as part of their festivities.

What a sense of humor!. The gardens and palace are luxurious, but what catches most tourists is the sheer quantity of fountains at every turn. Fountains twirl and rotate, follow tree branches like Christmas lights, and cascade from urns. My favorites were the "tricky fountains." It helps to know that this was the summer palace. Think on and surrounded by water when you think of St. Petersburg. Now imagine dignitaries in suits and elegant gowns. Among the many benches and river rock patches are hidden switches. Sit or step on one and the fountain rises around you. Oh, you didn't want to cool off right now? So sorry, our mistake.As I understand it, in addition to being incredibly intelligent, Peter was fascinated by things mechanical, electrical, and intricate. You will be surrounded by same, including samples of the beautiful Faberge eggs with surprises inside, which he gifted to his wife and mother every Easter. Bring your sense of humor, creativity and awe, and have fun.

This is a don't miss. The palace has been restored with great detail and is beautiful by any standards. We would not have missed this for anything! The grounds are also amazing. Visit Mon Plaisir, on the Peterhof grounds, which is Peter the Great's quiet space/place by the Sea.

Big and Gold. This place is massive. The gardens were very pretty when we visited in late May. If you love fountains this is the place for you. We caught the ferry across from outside The Hermitage. Very easy to do and the trip gives you a glimpse back into the Soviet era.

Ahhh, beautiful. The grounds with their many fountains are so lovely and the Palace itself is stunning. The history surrounding the Palace is fascinating as well. I think Peterhof was my favorite place in St Petersburg.

Palace overload. If you do the 2 day tour you will have palace overload by the end of day two so don't forget to take a photo of the venue entry ticket before you enter each attraction. otherwise it will all be a blur when you get home

Best place to visit in St. Petersburg. It was ruined during World War 2 by Nazis. However, they fixed it very well. Gardens are amazing. Palace is beautiful both inside and out. Classic Russian rudeness you would feel at this palace as well. Staff is not friendly and highly rude.

Mind Blowing. What a stunning place to visit, the gardens are absolutely beautiful it took us 3 hours just to walk around them. We took the hydrofoil as it is the best way to reach Peterhof, I suggest you take your own water a snacks as the prices are high once you get there.

Magic place. It is my favorite place in St.Petersburg. Peterhof is nice any season but the best time is summer when you may enjoy numerous magic fountains. There are many other attractions: Grand Palace, Monpleisir, gardens.

Most beautiful. Palace is a busy place with lot of tourists visiting its park and gardens with lot of fountains working with gravity give stunning view peterhof express cruise is also nice through Baltic Sea

WOW. Get there for 11am when they turn on all the fountains to music, a bit of a scrum but really beautiful, walking through the gardens with a guide was really informative and the palace absolutely stunning

Beautiful and impressive. A nice escape from the city. Be prepared to pay for entrances to ALL the displays. At the tills in the entrance you must pay the highest ticket price if you want entrance to palace as well as all the other exhibitions otherwise you will be disappointed you won't be let in!

Decadence reached a peak here. This place rivals or even exceeds Versailles (outside Paris). The opulence inside is amazing, and the grounds are equally impressive. You wear paper booties to walk through the place (to protect the floor). Again, no tours in English. The Amber room is an amazing (can't take picture there, which makes no sense) re-construction

Gorgeous !. This is one of the most beautiful places in all of St Petersburg. My wife was very impressed with all the gardens but my favourite had to be the fountains. A great display and when you consider they do not run on electricity, makes them that much more interesting. The palace is huge and we had a great weather day to walk the grounds and take it all in. A must see stop in St. Petersburg.

A splendid garden, even with large crowds. Bring a good camera and possibly a tripod, lest you regret not capturing all the wonderful fountains, statues, hedges, and so on to be found in this beautiful garden. The palace is also breathtaking. This is a bit far from downtown Saint Petersburg, but really is not to be missed.

Ideal escape. Nice palace with fountains, go on a sunny day to escape Petersburg. Can see Petersburg across Gulf of Finland from gardens of Peterhof. Be sure to catch the Russian military band that struts through gardens occasionally. Interior of palace not as fun as gardens and fountains, with very long lineups in summer.
Visited July 2010 with private guide.

A must when visiting st Petersburg. Just got back from our first visit to st Petersburg and found that this was one of our favorite things we did on our trip. The weather being perfect made the gardens and the fountains a perfect blend. We took the hydro foil boat back to st Petersburg avoiding any traffic issues.

Lots to see.. Large gardens with lots of statues and the Tricky fountains.Must have been good fun,for the Tzars seeing their guests get wet.We were lucky that the rain held off mostly?Very well kept again more time would have been good.
Peterhof. Would go in June instead of May so the gardens would be blooming. Beautiful summer home. Worth the visit.

Go on a sunny day. We picked our best weather day and took the hydro foil to Peterhof at 10 am. We arrived in time to find a spot before the fountains were turned on for the day. The gardens were crowded but there were lots of quiet spots as well. We had lunch in the fancy restaurant in the park and the food was great but the service was not good at all. Taking the bus surely costs less but if you don't have tons of time the hydrofoil is the way to go.

Gorgeous. The water features are amazing as are the statues and the gardens themselves. Get there by hydrofoil for an easy and restful ride. There's a nearby restaurant and just outside the entry gates, some cheap eateries selling burgers and blini's etc

Gardens Galore. Take your camera! The gardens are unbelievable. Lots of walking but something to see around every turn. Allow plenty of time like 2-3 hours to explore. We didn't have that much time and we had to rush through but they are amazing. We arrived opening day for the 2013 summer season so we got to see all the pomp and circumstance. Russian army, singing, it was amazing.

Beautiful grounds. We visited the gardens as a part of a s grand two day tour of St. Petersburg. We were in a small group with a guide. We took the hydrofoil from the Hermitage area...a 30 minute ride. We actually brought lunch onto the hydrofoil, so we were able to eat on our journey, giving us more time to tour the gardens at the Peterof. (NB: Restroom available on the hydrofoil.) It was a good plan. Our first look at the Peterof was from the water and docking area. It was a sunny day and there were lots of flowers in bloom...the palace and fountains could be seen in the distance....great photo spot! Our guide led us throuh the gardens and provided the details, history and many anecdotes (We used individual audio devices while touring). She also set a pace that kept us moving, but allowed for plenty of photos and even stops at a gift shop kiosk. (NB: They take rubles, euros, or dollars. No credit cards!) Seeing it with a guide made it feel much more relaxed...she made sure we didn't miss anything and that we knew what we were seeing. Although there were plenty of people there, it did not feel like it was overly crowded, the grounds are extensive and there was plenty of room. The gardens, fountains, and palace were beautiful and impressive, iIt seems like the kind of sight you could visit without a guide, but having a guide made our visit more informative and enjoyable.
This is a must see place. Been there on th opening day, great place. One have to see it, the inside is like other Russian musseums, and the garden is fantastic, nice place for you and your love one.

Peterhof should be on your Bucket List. Imagine you are a European ambassador sailing into the harbor to visit Peter the Great. Arriving on the hydrofoil, you get an amazing view up the parade to a glittering palace on the hilltop. I was impressed, as I suspect, were many of the ambassadors. The gold statues in the fountain are a "must see" and unique to this location (at least, unique in their grandeur). Be prepared to climb that hill from the sea (100ft or so) or catch a bus to arrive from the land so you can descend to the water...

Amazing Gardens/Fountains. They were just what I expected. I was lucky enough to be there on a sunny day so my photos have blue skies in the background. The fountains are incredible and the gardens are beautiful. We weren't allowed to take photos on the inside but it was a pretty cool place inside and ou.

The Palace was great but the fountains were playful and stunning!. The palace tour was wonderful athough the museum it self has some weird rules about not stopping in some of the rooms and NO photography of any kind is allowed in the palace. After visiting the palace we went for a walk around the grounds and discovered all kinds of interesting fountains. Take sometime to enjoy the grounds and watch out for the pick pockets.

Try to make it on a sunny day!. We were lucky enough to make it to this place on a sunny day...since they say there are only an average of 65 days of sunshine per year in SPB! They are also restoring a lot of this place as well, trying to bring it back to its pre-WWII glory. There is a lot of the restoration complete, the guide explains a lot. It was very pretty inside, and outside as well! The fountains were beautiful and there we many nice photo opportunities. We took the hydrofoil back to SPB to save time, you can take it to the palace as well. Traffic in SPB is outrageous!

Outstanding Garden and Fountains. We visited the Gardens with our tour group. The beauty of the fountains is amazing. The gold glitters in the sun and the entire experience is difficult to describe. You just gotta see it!We walked the grounds and viewed the fountains from above. My only disappointment was that it was very, very crowded.
Outstanding. After seeing Catherine's Palace we toured the Bathouse at the Peterhof, it was exceptional. The gardens are surprisingly special.

A great escape from the city. I took the boat from outside the Hermitage, so it was only a 30 minute journey. The grounds are beautiful. I only had a couple of hours there, but I wish I had been able to stay longer and wander around the grounds more. It was very relaxing, with a lot to see. I paid to see the museum, which was a bit of a waste. There is no information in English. I think they have tours that are included in the price, but if so, the English ones are infrequent. Although the building is beautifully ornate, for the price they charge for admission, I wouldn't recommend it without a tour being included.

Don't Miss!!. Versailles in St Petersburg, but with more extraordinary gardens, highlighted by the astonishing fountains, gravity-fed by mountain lakes 20 miles away. Don't miss the tour of the giant, subterranean pipes that feed the fountains. The palace itself is quite reminiscent of Versailles, if anything even more over the top in its use of gold leaf, mirrors and intricate parquetry on the floors. Be sure to walk the grounds to see the "trick" trees, benches and other items that suddenly splash the unwitting visitor with fountains. Also be sure to walk over to the modest palace on the water that Peter preferred.
Another fabulous place.. Just so different to things we usually see, Again crowds of people and nowhere to sit. gardens were lovely with the flowers just coming into bloom.

Just fantastic. We didn't go inside the palace, but just the gardens with all the fountains are worth the visit. The outside of the palace is very impressive. Too bad we didn't have time to visit inside. Maybe on another trip.

Go early and enjoy the gardens. We got there before opening hours of the palace, so we could enjoy the gardens and it really paid off. As it gets closer to opening time, hoards arrive in coaches and hydrofoils to see the fountains start. The palace itself is riddled with gold -- which I am sure is how they wanted it at the time it was built -- but has been well-restored given the WWII battles which raged there (so we were told). The trees and plantings are magnificent. They were in full spring greenery with flowering dandelions in the grass plus tulips in their prime and magnificently pleached trees. Surprisingly good food concessions for a mass destination.

Stunning. The park and fountains are well worth a visit even if you don't have time to visit the various buildings on the site. There is an entrance fee for the park and each building also has its own entrance fee.
A must see. This place is grand and beautiful. Numerous gold covered fountains and the grounds were spectacular.

Versailles in the Baltic. Wonderful gardens and fountains....we did not go into the palace because the grounds were immense and we wanted to see it all...4 hours of walking...very worthwhile, especially on a sunny day!

Wow what a palace. This is definitely somewhere you need to visit when in St. Petersburg, we arrived by the hydrofoil, there are not many places that you can visit using this mode of transport and walking up to the canal and the fountains is amazing.

Gardens are out of this world. We took a water taxi over to the estate and walked the grounds and palace. The water was placid, but the garden and estate were very alive. The fountains were grand and the palace was ornate. There were a lot of people, but there were so many trails and lush scenery that you could easily get away from that. I would definitely recommend for the experience and photo op.

Peterhof Palace. Lower Gardens are beautiful and breathtaking - but if you want to see the Palace go with an official guide to get in at any time- we went solo as we don't like being stuck with a guide for hours and prefer to do our own thing - this was a mistake here as they only allow Russians and those with a Russian Guide in before cetain times. Very unfriendly service so don't expect too much help with any query. We went over from St. Petersburg by Hovercraft - expensive but quick and comfortable.

Fountains and gardens Galore!!. We traveled to Peterhof by hydrofoil What a fun way to arrive. The tour was wonderful.Lovely fountains and gardens all around. Even some trick fountains that will squirt you ifyou're not careful about where you sit. Some benches are booby trapped. One walkway haswater tubes running on both sides, and a man turns on the water at 1 o' clock in the afternoon fora few minutes. Walkers beware. The kids found it loads of fun.

Marvelous Palace and Gardens. This is most certainly a worthwhile stop. While we enjoyed Catherine's Palace's interior more, the gardens of Peterhof can't be beat. The palace is incredibly beautiful and the gardens rival Versailles. The fountains, gilded gold statues, and large gardens are superb. The view of the waterfront is stunning. Recommended: - the fountains start at a set time each day, ensure a good viewing spot. - Take time to wander the gardens and go down to the waterfront.

The waterfalls were magnificent. About 11/2 hours out of St Petersberg (depending on traffic) and an interesting drive, lies this palace. It is smaller and more intimate than the Winter Palace in St Petersberg. It is still very grand inside and the church at one end and the gloden spires at the othere are very impressive. You got to a more intimate view of how the rulers lived. I particularly liked the Chinese rooms. When we arrived the fountains were not turned on but during our tour they were and with all that gold and water it is a magnificant sight. Took a walk down to the Baltic and the looked back at the whole ball of wax - boy those folks really knew how to live. Just outside the gates there are a few touristy shops and I thought their prices were pretty keen - BUT - it was the start of the season. As you queue up you get hastled by "sellers"
Amazing gardens. This is a must see on your visit to SP. Beautiful gardens and unbelievable palace. Go with a tour company and a small group, not a ship tour.

Simply beautiful. All the oppulance and splendour that you would expect from pre-revolution Russia.. We visited St Petersburg as part of a cruise; because of this we only had a limited amount of time to see the sights. We wanted to make the most of it and decided that the Peterhof palace and gardens were the place for us. Due to the fact that you need a visa to go it alone in Russia, we joined an excursion - along with the rest of the world so it felt. The palace is beautiful. The authorities have really taken care of it and the interiors and exteriors are well worth the entrance fee. We were lucky with the weather, a sunny blue sky certainly shows off the palace, fountains and gardens in their best light. There were even people dressed in costumes wandering about which added to the atmosphere - don't take photos of them unless you want to pay through the nose.In my opinion it is best to go as part of a tour as there no signs or information in English inside at all. Without the aide of our guide I would not have had a clue about who lived in these amazing rooms. The palace gets very busy... very busy. We were literally packed in to the rooms - shoulder to shoulder. Each group has to queue to get in to the next room. But I guess that there is no other way to see this and that it is a case of put up or shut up.It is a fantastic palace, but beware; there are no toilets inside the house til the end, you will be expected to cover your shoes with plastic over shoes, the rooms are about the same heat as a furnace and you are not permitted to take any drinks inside! As they say, forewarned is forearmed!

Many fountains!. Due to time constraints we only visited the gardens of Peterhof and got there via the ferry which goes from the Hermitage area of the city. The return ferry cost 1,100 rubles per person and the entrance to the gardens only was 450 rubles per person. This was quite an expensive trip for what could be seen but the gardens were beautiful, and we were lucky enough to have sunshine so we got some great photos!

Fabulous gardens. As everyone else says the Peterhof is absolutely stunning. I've therefore listed a few tips below to make the most out of your visit.- The quickest way there is by hydrofoil. It's easy to find (opposite the front of the Hermitage) and doesn't involve changing. However this is by far the most expensive. 1100rbls return or 650rbls for a single- If you go by hydrofoil you will be caught by all the people trying to sell you their tickets. We just went to the dock which already had a boat there and purchased a ticket from them.- If you want to be really organised, look at how many cruise ships are docked that day. You can guarantee lots of cruise ships means it will be busy!- If you have any interest in walking through the gardens, then go on a nice day! You could even bring food with you and stop and have a picnic.- You have to pay for the gardens and then again to get into the house. If you go by hydrofoil, you can't avoid the garden entrance fee, as you arrive at the bottom of the garden. So make the most of your ticket!It's an absolute must when in St Petersburg, we just enjoyed strolling around the gardens and wondering down paths which looked like dead ends but brought you out to amazing fountains.

A lot of Peterhof was not open when I attend at the end of April. Peterhof is well worth a trip outside St Petersburg to see this magnificent palace. Unfortunately a lot of it was closed for renovations when I was there and the trees had all been severely pruned and had no leaves on them. This was a good example of the tourist's dilemma. Go out of season and you miss the crowds, but may not see everything. Go in season and join the queues with thousands of others.

Gorgeous. Everything in St Petersburg seems to have the wow factor - and this palace and gardens does not disappoint, simply stunning. Our visit was made all the more lovely as we arrived at the turning on of the fountains in the lower gardens, which is set to music, absolutely wonderful!

A lovely walk through the palace & gardens.. We visited Peterhof on a private tour. It's such a beautiful place. The palace is lovely inside & out. I could have spent more time there wandering all the gardens. The fountains are grand and beautiful. The grounds are amazingly well kept. It's a must see when in St. Petersburg.

Fabulous palace and gardens. Well worth the trip out to the Peterhof. Take a tour, or go from St.Petersburg on the hydrofoil. The fountains are fantastic, and there are lots of them. If you go with a tour make sure you break away at some point and go to the far corners of the park. There is a lot to see and our guide was only going to take us to about half of the garden. She thought it more important to spend an hour in a cafe...I prefered to see the gardens.

Number one sight in St Petersburg. Do not miss it.The best (and most expensive) way to get there is by boat, departing next to the Hermitage Museum (another not to be missed sight). It costs 1100 rubles round trip and takes 30 minutes, avoinding the always messy St Petersburg traffic.

Fabulous. Built for Peter the Great, who obvioulsy had plenty of money to spend on a house. Now deemed the Russian Versailles. we were fortunate to visit here on a lovely warm sunny spring day, when the light was superb. The house is stunning both inside and outside, with opulence and grandeur everywhere, but it is the gardens and fountains that set it apart from other palaces. The natural pressure fountains are everywhere and run constantly (unlike Versailles). Throughout the gardens there are lovely fountains and statues everywhere. We would have loved to have spent longer here. We were part of a tour and had a pre booked entry time into the Palace - not sure if you can just turn up and pay. So check before you travel.

Top attraction. We traveled by Metro and then city bus to the Peterhof Palace. It is important that you try to attempt to figure out the hours for this place as it defies logic. We arrived on a Monday morning only to find that the main palace museum closed at noon. They have an odd schedule for each of the museums on the grounds - some open on certain days and hours and others on completely different schedules.However, just touring the grounds is a worthwhile adventure!

Unforgettable!. We visited Peterhof Palace and Gardens in June, 2011, (the TripAdvisor calendar didn't go back far enough) as part of a Viking river cruise tour. The house and gardens are both amazing, but the gardens alone are worth the visit. We were fortunate to visit on a lovely weekday, so crowds were relatively small and the gardens were comfortably accessible. It helped to visit as part of an organized tour. The fountains are indeed gravity-operated, or so we were told. They are certainly impressive. If you have the opportunity, do not miss this memorable site. It was my favorite of all the places we saw on our Russian trip. Be prepared to walk and to climb some stairs.

water, fountains, history and spirit of 18-19th centuries. One of the best places I have ever visited is St. Petersburg's most famous and popular visitor attraction, the palace and park at Peterhof. It’s really amazing place for those who enjoy nature, water, fountains, and spirit of 18-19th centuries. It’s located in the suburbs of the city and many many years ago it impressed even the Russian queen Elizabeth, who ordered the expansion of the Grand Palace and greatly extended the park and the famous system of fountains, including the truly spectacular Grand Cascade. You will find a lot of surprises in this place, water will unexpected flow on you sometimes, but you will see how beautiful this park, I think that you will not find place with so many amazing fountains and queen spirit in the world.

Russian Versailles. I fell in love with Peterhof at first sight! Gorgeous fountains, alleys, ducks ... There is no better place for walking! The main thing to keep in mind - take very comfortable shoes along with you. We were there in the summer and were very lucky with the weather. Of course, there are always awful crowds, but you can find very quiet corners in the huge park. One minus - a huge queue to visit the palace.
Go there in summer!. The museum is beautiful but the gardens are a really big part of the charme of the whole palace. If possible try to avoid peak season, too many people on your pictures

A Must See. We visited Peterof yesterday, and wow. We took the hydrofoil which was expensive (650R each way) but a great time saver, only 30 minutes as opposed to 90 minutes by train and bus. The ticket box on the pier had most signage in Russian and it wasn't clear what our 450R entry fee was for. It ended up this was just for the garden, we paid another r550 for the palace. The fountains were turned on at 11 am, so we joined the throngs of people to watch that. Our mistake was to head to the palace straight from there. It was crowded with tour groups, only groups of about 50 let in at a time. To be honest, I could have missed the palace and not been disappointed. But the gardens, with spring flowers, green fields, fountains and statues was amazing. There was so much to see and enjoy there, it is huge. There were little golf buggies driving around but I'm not sure how you hire one. Most signage is in Russian, so makes it difficult if you don't have the language. It was an exhausting day, not lots of places to sit in some parts of the garden, but well worth it.

Majestic and fabulous!. If you'd visited this place once, you wouldn't have forgotten it's immersing in the green fountains, wide parks, gold domes and of course spectacular view of the Gulf of Finland!

Avoid spring weekends. We didn't go inside the Palace, having just come from the (reportedly) more impressive Catherine Palace. Our main interest was in the fountains and other water features in the parks surrounding the palace.We were lucky to have a good day, but unlucky to arrive on the day of the "White Nights" festival, a Sunday in mid-May. The place was choked with the day's honorees, police personnel and their families. There was a ceremony and performance going on at the cascade and main fountain, so we couldn't really get near them -- which would have been more frustrating if they were running. We had read that they were supposed to start the previous day, so we postponed our visit -- but apparently not long enough. (It was interesting seeing *many* high school- and junior high school-age kids from the local police academy in their very military-looking uniforms)Most of the other fountains were running, and the extensive grounds, on the Gulf of Finland, are very pretty.
Top day out. Make sure its dry, otherwise you'll not walk the gardens. Hydrofoil is the way to get there. Quite expensive day out, but well worth it. Get there when it opens to avoid queues.

Beware pickpockets. The house is a 'reconstruction' and utterly bling - but I loved it. The grounds are wonderful - but pickpockets are very active here. Two people in my group were robbed while taking a photo in the grounds!

Beautiful gardens. We only took the tour outside although you can tour the house as well. It was raining on the day of our tour but the rain couldn't take away from the beautiful fountains and gardens. It is amazing that all the fountains are gravity fed and have no pumps.
Beautiful. You are in for a treat with all the water features ,beautiful gardens ,grounds and Palace watch out for the trickery

Water water everywhere!. Have only toured the gardens not the palace.The most amazing sight are the cascades in front of the palace,approach from the lower level then climb the steps to view from above.there are many other fountains to see also,some beautiful,some quirky

All that glitters... Make a day of a visit to Peterhof - going by hydrofoil is easy and convenient and takes away the hassle of St Petersburg's traffic jams. It really is spectacular inside the palace but the gardens deserve plenty of time to explore. Try to go when all the fountains are working (after the end of May). Unfortunately the quick lunch offerings were awful so take some splendid Russian pies!

My Favorite Day in Russia. I spent about a week in Russia, and the day I spent at Peterhof was my favorite. The complex is very large with lots to see including the palace, the fountains and various other buildings all over the grounds. The fountains are very impressive (they're what you see if most of the photos). At first, I was disappointed because I didn't see them when I entered, but they're behind the palace (FYI). The palace interior is extremely opulent. It'll be hard not to be impressed as you tour it.A few tips:1. The website isn't crystal clear on how to get there, but this is the route I took. I took the metro to Avtovo station. Once there, I crossed the street and took minibus 424. It's marked with the number and it has text on the side saying "Peterhof" and "Fountains" (yes, in Phoenician lettering, not Cyrillic). The minibuses are private and not the world's nicest so it feels a bit shady to get in, but it was fine. It dropped me off right at the gates of Peterhof. It was clear which stop has a palace in front of it, but the one downside to all of this is that the driver didn't speak English so it wasn't easy to ask, "Is this my stop."2. Pay attention to the hours. I tried to get into the palace around noon, but I was told it was closed to foreigners until 2:30 PM.3. Just because it's spring, doesn't mean you'll see flowers. I went in early May, thinking things would be starting to bloom, but apparently Russian plants take their time and don't move as quickly as plants in the U.S. northeast. Leaves were back on the trees, but flowers hadn't bloomed and bushes were still leafless. To see the grounds in their full glory, I'd suggest going later in the year.
Delightful place. We visited for 3-4 hours on an organised trip. Specially enjoyed wandering round the gardens on a glorious sunny day - the fountains are tremendous.

just awesome!. Peterhof is a wonderful place to see! When I was there, I spent about 10 hours walking and staring at beautiful fountains, thinking about imperial russian family. You'd better come here without any excursions because it's more interesting to discover everything by yourself. I was so impressed with the architecture of the palace, with the HUGE garden with thousands of trees and bushes, even with its squirrels which are very friendly :) if you visit St.Petersburg, Peterhof should also be included in your own "must see" list!p.s. do not forget to buy some snack for the squirrels!

Beautiful palace with great garden. Peterhof Palace was an interesting place to visit. It was completely refurbished after WWII but if you didn't know that it would be impossible to tell. All the details have been recreated down to the elaborate gilding. The gardens were extensive. Being early May, there wasn't much blooming, but it was a relaxing pleasure to stroll the paths among the trees with fountains and streams.

Very Nice Palace. Very nice palace. You can reach there by road or by water. I would recommend trying out both. You may reach by waterways and return by road. There are lots of beautiful fountains. Considering there is beauty in its large gardens it will require lot of walking. Consider hiring battery operated buggies.

The most outstandingly beautiful palace and gardens. We went to Peterhof palace and Gardens the last day of our trip to Russia exhusted but when you see the beauty of this place you get a little of your strength to see this Grand place l wished we had more to see more than the Gardens and Palace they were breath taking especially the foundains that you always see in the photo's when l came home and showed my pictures my friends wished they had gone with me

Weather lottery - only go if sunny. If it rains (or God forbid, still snows!) then it's not the place where you want to end up because the magnificent views really only come to their own in the sunshine. I can imagine this is a wonderful place in the summer but in Russian spring, it was somewhat unpleasant. And the palace itself isn't anywhere near as much of an attraction as the fountains

Beautiful fountains. Only visited the gardens, due to time constraints, but traveled to Petehof on the hydrofoil which was an experience in itself! Lovely gardens to wonder around, and the house is beautiful. Unfortunately no flowers out in May, but the fountains were worth the visit.

Nice palace but completely under reconstruction. In May 2013, we visited this palace. Beautiful interiors and park surrounding the palace, but unfortunately the whole exterior of the palace was covered by large sheets for reconstruction work. Since the palace is supposed to be very pretty, this was a sad fact to find out upon arrival. Entrance tickets to the park are very expensive with 500 rubles pp, and another 550 rubles pp for the palace. One of the more expensive places to visit (Catherine palace is half price!). All in all, worth going there but if you can, check whether reconstruction work is finished since the view will be better. Do not arrive by the expensive hydrafoil boat (650 rubles one way per person) since it is not really worth it. The view is not that amazing and you don't see the palace upon arrival at the dock. Restaurant Standard on the park grounds is really nice though, with good service, nice food and a beautiful view.

stunning. About an hours drive from st petersburg but well worth the travel. We visited both palace and gardens. We came as a tour group so had the privilege of timed entry, so no queues for us! The palace rooms are just amazing, the restoration work is unbelievable, one skilled worker, responsible for the restoration to the chinese room was awarded the medal of lenin for his skills. Although we managed to see all of the palace we did not get round the gardens, they are huge. One tip, is try to get there early as it gets very very busy. i think if i came back i would travel by hydrofoil, for a different experience but also to allow more freedom of time to see the spectacular gardens
Huge and opulent. Gold everywhere. Huge fountains and never ending lawns. See the gulf of Finland from here and learn all about Peter the Great, one of history's most successful and admired rulers.

Masterpiece of Restoration. A showstopping display of gold doors and walls, painted ceilings and marquetry floors. Russian history in the throne room and magnificent fountains in the formal gardens. It may be grander today than in the original build!
The Russian Versailles. The gardens are a delight to visit. A lot of fountains dotted around the ground give the place majesty (open in May)

beautiful park, stunning buildings. Not much to say other than a really beautiful palace overlooking gulf of finland. a must see! The fountains are spectacular and the whole area has a sense of calm and tranquility even with all the "glitter"

Expensive but when are you going back?. The palace is breathtaking inside, quickly overcoming the disappointment at the covered cascade (is all of St Petersburg under restoration right now?). I worried as I was taking a teenager who'd spent the morning in the Hermitage rather reluctantly. However he thought it was fabulous from the fountains to the completely over the top gold everywhere inside. The interior is worth the rather pricey entry - stunning. And if you ever want a history lesson on why the Russian Revolution happened, the 13 year old got it within 30 seconds of mind blowing opulence. The gardens are fun - lots of fountains, vistas, and buildings, with an abundance of cafes to rest weary feet.Nb. Take a rain jacket. The weather can turn fast and it goes from 20 to 5 degrees fast at this time of year.
Serenity. Summer gardens make visitors feel peacefull and dignity. I liked gardens architecture and lanscaping. The park was personally designed by Czar Peter in 1704.

Spectacular!. What a fantastic place to visit on a sunny day - the day after they turned the fountains on for the summer! Make sure you take the time to walk around the gardens and see ALL the fountains, not just the main ones in front of the palace.The palace is spectacular! Beautiful baroque rooms - make sure to look at the parquet floors as well as the ceilings.I understand you can visit by hydrofoil from St P but we couldn't find one that was open for the season.

Majestic and Wondrous. I have often heard that this place is similar to Versailles, but that is not a solid comparison. This place is magnificent in every way! We took a hydrofoil between to from St. Petersburg to "Петергоф" (Peterhof), which was interesting because we took in the sites of the "non-tourist" sections of town. Upon arrival, we simply gasped in awe of the Grand Palace sitting atop the hill. The gardens are remarkable. We were glad we brought an umbrella because, as is common for June in Russia, a quick shower rained upon us for about 20 minutes before the sun reappeared. The sunshine radiated on the rain-soaked, golden statues. It was strikingly beautiful.

Great place to spend a day. It is so famous it really doesn't need much reviewing. Large park with fountains and palaces. You can arrive by boat and leave by train or bus. Take a snack with you as places with lots of tourists tend to have more expensive and lower quality food.
Maybe great place, but we didn't nailed the season of our visit.. Maybe great place, but we didn't nailed the season of our visit. Palace was under construction and half of the trees were packed.

A MUST SEE!. We visit Peterhof Gardens every time we in St. Petersburg. The quickest way (and good fun too!) getting there is by hydrofoil from the Hermitage peer which takes about 30 min. If you are planning to see the palace, go with a tour or buy tickets online to guarantee access. A place well worth the trip from St. Petersburg - beautiful gardens, spectacular Grand Cascade and the most impressive architecture. Don’t miss the other small places like Peter the Great's cottage and Monplaisir on the property.

Magical garden. We took a private day tour to visit Catherine's Palace and Peterhof with TJ Travel. To beat the crowd at Catherine's Palace, we decided to do Peterhof after lunch. When we arrived at Peterhof, the palace itself was already over-loaded with tourists. Instead we decided to visit the garden first. Magical to look down at the famous fountain and garden from the palace! Having visited Catherine's Palace just in the morning, the Peterhof Palace itself was really quite basic and understated by comparison, just like Peter himself. The beauty of this place was really in the garden.A place definitely not to be missed!

Restorations !. Don't go there now, the main palace building is open but there is too much restoration and construction inside that is why some rooms are closed... And no fountains activated yet because of the weather which just started to be warm.In summer I think it really worth !!

Spectacular. The grandeur of the numerous gold-plated statues and fountains are a sight to behold and a visual feast for photographers. We walked the entire span of the gardens and also had our lunch here. Definitely worth the trip (costs and travel time) from the city.

Highlight of my Trip. I was in St. Petersburg for 2 days, on a cruise ship. I would defnitely go back as there was so much to see. The Peterhof Palace is one of the things that stand out. We took a bus there and back, I think I would have loved to take the Hydrofoil boat there and I definitely would have like mre time here. The Palace itself is spectacular but what reall stands out are the gardens and fountrains. I would have wanted much more time to wander around the gardens and see more of them, This is one Palace not to be missed!!!

Don't visit before May. We went last week and the exterior was under scaffolding whilst the interior was also being renovated. The fountains were turned off and garden was covered with snow. Whilst it was nice to see, not worth visiting until May when scaffolding will be down and fountains turned on.

Beautiful gardens. Peter the Great's summer palace. It has some of Russia's most beautiful gardens. I recommend going there by boat from the Hermitage. You will avoid the traffic and get a great view when you disembark in Peterhof.

A Magical Place. A visit to Peterhof Palace and Garden should not be rushed. We were thrilled by the marvellous fountains, the flower gardens, and the palace. We had read about Peter's love of horses and were very appreciative of being able to see the stables where these prize horses were housed.

Peterhof under Renovation. We knew the fountains would not be working, but our guide seemed not to know that the entire palace exterior was covered up for renovation. The staircase is covered up leading to the inside rooms, and the first few rooms are also covered. Had we known, we would not have gone inside. We felt a bit ripped off. If you go within the next 3 months, you might want to make sure it's totally finished. Also, they are using some strong smelling chemicals for some of the work, which was hard to take.
PETERHOF. Peterhof is all I expected and more. The gardens were beautiful and the statues fantastic. Fortunately it was restored and can be enjoyed by many.

Beautiful place just VERY family unfriendly!. Beautiful beautiful place but please please do not even consider it if you have small children who need a buggy or a nappy bag! We're made to leave both at the door including nappy bag with daughters water and banana in it! Also many of the fountains are not accessible by buggy so missed out on huge part of the trip! Had to wear plastic covers over shoes which is fair enough to reserve the beauty of the rooms just not very easy to not slip when carrying a small child! would definitely go again if we visited Russia again just as long as our daughter was older! Make sure you visit the bathroom before leaving the house to tour the garden and fountains as they will not let you re-enter to use them once you've gone outside!
Beautiful St. Peter's palace. Another must see visit.we arrived by bus went back on jet foil.great experience.st peters palace and park absolutely outstanding park breathtaking a must do not miss

Well worth the trip. we decided to take to the water to get to the Palace and it certainly added to the trip......this is a trip outside of the city that is well worth making. the gardens and the water features are stunning and the interior brings the life of the Tzars to life in a way that no other place did for me. the table settings, the grandeur of the rooms, the furniture made it a very special trip. At weekends it becomes a Russian family destination so expect loads of families but cant recommend it enough. you know when you have been won over when all your photos are of fountains...and more water!!!

A must visit for its stunning parks and fountains. A must visit in the St Petersburg itinerary-a stunning palace of fountains,lovely parks and quiet time its compared to Versailles for its beauty and opulence.Try getting a ferry ride to Peterhoff as the pier is equally enchanting.Grab a bite,stroll around the parks,watch the lovely fountains..its a great option for a day trip.I had visited in autumn and it was wonderful with all the changing colors but summer is definitely the best time to visit as it was quite cold and windy there.

Palace of fountains. wonderful and a must watch place in St.Petersburg..there are fountains everywhere and it has rich green and calm atmosphere.this place looks best in summer (june-august).these fountains are world famous and top rated.well planned and well maintained garden.

big palace, garden....Fountains are everywhere. Main fountain & golden men portrait are very attractive...and I love the color of the palace...pink & gold, I guess it only exist in Royal Russia? :)I also love the see & walk in the huge garden with sea breeze. Fountains are everywhere！

One of the best in St Petersburg and in whole Russia. If you are thinking about going to Russia first thing you should go is St Petersburg (forget The Transsiberian!) And if You are going to St Petersburg one of first things you should do is Peterhof Palace and Garden. This is not only one of the best museums in whole Europe, but as well you could soak in the atmosphere, the spirit of this magnificent place.It's one of the best in Europe classical gardens. Here you can take one of the guided tours on the garden, fountains and palace, get some costume experiences, visit many smaller attractions, including several "fun" fountains - there are much more than one palace and one garden.And the whole complex is are huge - so, reserve at least whole day for that!This will suit to any kind of tourists - romantic couples, group of friends, solo explorers, definitely photographers and, of course, families.The complex has an entrance fee. Best time to visit is probably autumn, - when summer heat is over and crowds are not huge.

This was Possibly my Favourite Attraction In Russia!!!. I went here last year, with my boyfriend (who is Russian), and his parents (who are Russia and live within Russia). They gave me an English-speaking tour guide who was full of information regarding the area. We went around the end of May, so it was warm. It was beautiful. Most of it was outdoors. The Fountains have been restored and glimmer. I think there was one which I had seen which looked worn out but will eventually be restored in due time. There are NO pumps controlling this place; which is even more amazing. It wasn't overly crowded. Nothing can really prepare you for how lovely it is. The Floor is a checkered-pattern (at least for the biggest Fountain), and you can even go inside. My tour guide tricked me into grabbing a bowl of fake fruits in a room inside the Fountain (a prank), and I got squirted! You can see how the fountains run on the inside. It's very dark and a bit hard to walk through but still neat. One thing that made me giggle was this little fountain where fake dogs pranced around chasing a duck. It even made the noises of the ducks and the dogs. Kids played in a sprinkler nearby activated by a staff who would spray them randomly. We also checked out some surrounding buildings and got to see a lot of Russian culture. Some Russian people also followed us around because my tour guide was doing such a good job explaining everything (he spoke both Russian and in English for the sake of my boyfriend's parents). You can also buy souvenirs around the area. It's a great piece of Russian history and if you get the chance, DO IT!!! You won't regret it!!
Stunning. This is a beautiful place, the gardens looked stunning in the warm May sunshine, with the sun glinting off the gold fountains and water. A must see!

Epic fountains. The fountains are pretty epic, really. I didn't go inside the palace as I was feeling stingey (they make you pay more), but I think it's still worth going to see the fountains (if you're there in summer. They're only turned on in the summer). However, a warning: I was 'pick-pocketed' here and lost my camera, so hold on to your things when you're in crowded areas. I recommend getting a ferry there, from near Nevsky, rather than one of the buses.

Imagine you are walking in the Tsar's foot steps. Visiting this palace in the winter, with the frozen fountains, absolute quiet and beauty is a dream come true. Have not been there with the summer crowds, but have walked down the steps to the frozen Bay of Finland, and imagined the Tsar looking out as we did. Not to be missed.

City of fountains.. It is the best way to get to this place by hidrofoil from the center of the St. Petersburg. You will arive after 30 min in to the moust amaizing park with 100 of fountains. Some made out of gold, the other morble. No pumps poweer this place. All gravity feed fountains will amaize you with buty and skale. Reed greek mitology befor came to this place as every fountain have the story to tell. Be aware. Peter were trikster and some fountains will surprize you and you will get wet)))
Russian imperial sights. One of the best excursions I ever been to. You should go there in summer to see everything working. It is beautiful and absolutly mustsee place in StPet

Lovely experience. This Palace is only about 1 hr drive from the city and positioned on the Baltic sea.Enjoy A walk through the gardens to the sea front,as well as amazing at the fabulous opulence of the Palace. Do not miss the following !!! Be at the front entrance of the Palace overlooking the canal and gardens facing the sea by 11am to see a beautiful display of the water fountains in action while being serenaded with classical music.Well worth a visit

Grand...as was Peter!. the french keep on comparing this to versaillespoor themversailles is just a pale copy of the splendour hereI was specially impressed by the gardens (if you dont walk, dont come here!) and particularly the fountains!! dont miss the grand cascadeof course not in winterwe had a private guide with chauffeur and it is worth the cost (reasonable) as there are so many splendors that you dont know where to look (and dont have to queue)one of the most amazing places I have seen

Peterhof Palace and Gardens. I loved this attraction. One of the highlights of my trip to Russia. Just don't take any pictures of the paintings. There are people all around watching you..It is just beautiful to see.

Beautiful outside stroll. This was so incredible. Next to the Hermitage this is a must see. Even though it was raining we threw on our plastic panchos and had an amazing time. Our private tour guide made sure to keep us moving so we wouldn't get off of schedule. If we didn't have her I would have wasted so much time in amazement just staring at things and taking too many pictures. There is a LOT to see in St. Petersburg so make sure you take it in and keep moving. I am so glad we put the majority of our trip budget into a private tour in St. Petersburg. With all there is to see, the lines, and hoards of people, slackers, etc I can't imagine how much harder it would have been. I figured I was only going to be there once in my life and I did not want to miss anything or wish I would have done things differently.

We travelled under our own steam - Check out St Peter & Paul’s Church as well. Getting there: Take the metro to AVTOVO’ station (line 1 - red line); 27 rubles (54 pence) from any part of the metro system. Line 1 is the oldest metro line and has some beautiful stations; Avtovo is one of the best.Exit the station, cross the road to the minibuses opposite, the ones you want display the following signs ‘ФОНТАНЫ’ which means ‘fountains’. Note the minibus goes past the fountains, it is not the final destination, so make sure you let the driver know where you want to get off the bus, have Peterhof Fountains & ФОНТАНЫ on a piece of paper, (we don’t speak Russian and it’s unlikely you will be any clearer to the driver than they are to you). It cost 48 roubles (97 pence) each.When you get off the bus, instead of going straight in, turn back, cross the road and walk about 200 metres to an amazing church, well worth a look (St Peter and Pauls).Getting back we took the hydrofoil from within the Lower Park, 500 roubles each (circa £10.00) which drops you off in St Petersburg close to the Hermitage. Note that if you are taking the Hydrofoil back and want to leave the lower park you need a ticket for readmission (not your admission ticket) or you may have to pay to get back in.Entry to the upper park is free; 300 roubles (circa £6) to get into the lower park and then you pay to get into all of the other individual museums and buildings on the site. The Grand Palace costs 520 roubles (circa £10.42). Note that on wet days some of the buildings do not open.A must are the over 150 fountains including over 60 in the Grand Cascade which are switched on to musical accompaniment at 11 AM each day. Note that the fountains only operate from May to mid-September; we were lucky and were there on the fountains final day. They are switched off to get them ready for winter; I understand the Parks still open and that when the fountains are off entry to both parks is freeThe palace is beautiful but you only have access to part, they move you through quite quickly and you are likely to be through in 1 to 11/2 hours.Most of the heritage sites including Peterhof Palace close on at least one day per week, some close for half days, usually the morning. Check before you travel!If you wanted to do everything it would take several days and cost a lot! But it is the most impressive site we visited while in St Petersburg and there are plenty of impressive sites to choose from.

Must see.. This is a beautiful sculpture/fountain garden right on the Gulf of Finland which has been completely reconstructed after being destroyed by the Germans during the war. We ate lunch at the outdoor cafe that serves "pancakes" (crepes), which are delicious. The fountains are absolutely amazing.

Wonderful summer Palace and fountains. A very nice place to visit.....there is a lot to see...first of all the big Palace and of course in summer time amazing fountains!!! Every time i visit Petergoff i get lots of nice emotions and impressions !Its not expensive at all! Its a reasonable price for such wonderful place!There are lots of nice restaurants and caffee where you can eat tipical russian food and just enjoy your day after visiting all those museums.Must say also that i enjoy going to the Petergoff by boat from the harbor near hermitage and it makes everything even more exciting!

Beautiful even if fake. One has to remember that the Palace was completely destroyed during WWII. It was rebuilt from scrap and the result is quite astonishing. The walk in the park is trully enjoyable. Try to understand the trick at the "miracle fountain"...

Spectacular!. Peterhof is definitely worth a visit! The Palace and museum were unfortunately closed on the day we were in St-Petersburg (we knew in advance) but nonetheless, Peterhof is very impressive. The grounds are beautiful with its many unique fountains. We enjoyed a pleasant walk with a knowledgeable guide from White Nights Travel. It was a most enjoyable history lesson as we marvelled at the amazing and unusual fountains. A visit of Monplaisir, Peter I's favourite abode provided a glimpse into the czar's "cottage"-like dwellings and magnificent seafront terrace.But nothing quite compares to the Grand Palace and its Grand Cascade. It is without words.

Marvellous Peterhof. It was one of the most beautiful tour in my life and absolutely one of the most fantastic palace to be visited, especially during the winter, when you can really understand the life in Russsia hundreds year ago. I strongly suggest to visit the marvellous gardens that in the winter time as well in the sumer time are fantastic.
great. It was feeling that I'm a king of Russia. My childs wew impressed. We had a reat holidays and now we are planning another trip to Russia

Amazing, amazing, amazing!. You'll think you've died and gone to gold heaven! Everything you see is exquisite craftsmanship, but just when you think you've seen enough gilt to last a lifetime...go outside to the gardens. The gardens are just lovely, especially the vista from the Grand Palace to the Marine Canal. At 11:00 am each day they start playing music and turn on the gravity fountains one by one until all of the valves are fully open. It is an awe inspiring site! I would go back in a heartbeat. I did caught by the Joke Fountain. Beware of the seat around a tree with the roof over it. When you sit down and then get up to leave water starts poring over the roof. You can't miss getting wet, but fun!

Grand Palace at Peterhof closed. My husband and I set out today (24th January) to visit Peterhof, and were disappointed that the Grand Palace was shut. We had tried to look carefully at the confusing web information, and knew that many of the smaller buildings would be shut, but neither we , nor our concierge staff would have thought the Grand Palace would be shut. The building itself was totally covered over. The only thing open was the Palace church, which was magnificent and a small museum which cost us 700 Rbls each. I hope this saves someone else from the same disappointment. I would suggest spending time at the Catherine Palace at Pushkin, which today anyway was open and was a lovely place to spend time.Apologies for giving this a "terrible" review - I had to give a fake rating to get my review accepted by trip advisor program. I'm sure the attraction would be 5 star if open!
Real treasure. Travel by speed-boat from center city. Quick and scenic trip and you are in the world of Tsar's summer life.

parco dei sogni. best season to visit: may-early septemberfor all agestransport to arrive: pubblic bus #200, commertial mini busbuy a map near entrancearrive in the morning to spend all the day in this magnificent village among quite alleys with squirrels, joke fountans, baroque palaces, shore of Baltic sea (take a boat to come back to the city).Take a snack with you (also can buy in place)A place one can not forget!

impressive. Beautiful gardens, fountains and ponds. Impressive gold sculptures. Went in may - beautiful weather, sunshine, green scenery. Definately my highlight of St,Petersburg trip. I have been to Versailles and can say that Peterhof Gardens impressed me both similarly. Must when in St.Petersburg!!

very pretty! the gardens especially. come here on a nice day with blue skies and leaves on the trees! (especially fall leaves)! it is a lovely spot for a walk. the fountains are very pretty. the palace itself is also cool - but it is similar to what you see at the Hermitage. (you might feel a bit "Tsared-out" after all the luxurious opulence). Anyways, i definitely recommend coming here! if you come by water-shuttle, be very careful about timing. We didn't have as much time as we would have liked, because of the last water shuttle of the company we used leaving at a ridiculously early hour. I could easily have spent an additional two hours!

More fountains than Versailles. Lovely huge park. More fountains than Versailles after which it was modelled so be sure to allow time to go about the park. Come or go or both by the hover boat that leaves from near Hermitage Museum. Rooms look like what a Russian Palace should look like. Charges for both the palace and the park and some Russians just pay for the park to walk around and picnic.

A grand place to visit.. Similar to Catherines' Palace (same designer) but the furnishings are different. The big draw is the ornate and amazingly engineered fountains and gardens and the lifestyle to be imagined. Another don't miss attraction. Very crowded but worth it. Allow some time.

The Best !. I have visited there three times during the last 10 years. Every visit has lasted over 4 hours - till my legs could carry me no more :) Sooo much to see. Next time I´m going to take a guided tour to the treasure gallery - I have not seen it before and it can be visited only on a timed guided tour.
Beautiful palace. Beautiful palace, large common area, nice pastries van beside the palace which sells most delicious chocolate eclair.
great fountains. The gardens are fantastic to spent a few hours just wandering about and looking at all the fountains.

A spectacular place to visit. The fountains and grounds are just beautiful. We walked around for quite some time and there was always something to look at. The whole grounds and fountains were beautifully maintained and it was a real pleasure to visit. We didn't go into the palace as we had already visited others. We arrived just before 11am and it was very entertaining to see the fountains start. We enjoyed our visit very much

Versailles East. Beautiful. The palace is beautiful inside and out but the gardens and fountains are most impressive. Check the times when the fountains turn on and get a good place to view. A lot of walking and many stairs but a great site to visit.

I hate my guide for taking us here. Avoid like the plague in the winter - the place is miserable. The guide kept telling me "but it's amazing in the summer" - perhaps the rating will have been very different then but it's more like time wasted in the snowy months

Peter and Peterhof were GREAT!. Tsar Peter the Great was quite an engineer and you will be so impressed to see the amazing fountains he designed and had built at this beautiful, beautiful place. You won't believe that no electricity or other power source is required to shoot water to amazing heights. The grounds are lovely and open onto the beautiful Baltic Sea. You will see this place featured on many ads for trips to Russia and you will remember it forever.
Great buildings!. High quality of architectural projects, good city and... lot's of tourists. Good place to take a rest
