Wonderful. We spent the afternoon viewing Peterhof Gardens and Fountains. This seems to be a popular place with the local population and justly so. The gardens are superbly crafted and the fountains flow beautifully. The grandest fountain is the Grand Cascade. It just flows down in multiple levels in a glorious manner.

Breath-taking.... On advice from others, we didn't do the inside of the palace, but did take the opportunity to walk through the gardens. Amazing! The fountains are absolutely spectacular! In fact, I wish we had had more time to spend looking at the fountains, but our guided tour didn't allow us too much time. In any sense, this is one of those places that pictures aren't going to capture the true feeling of being there.A must see!

Well worth the journey to reach it!. Travelling there by road is tiresome.....by boat from outside Hermitage ( the Meteor) makes the trip very special. The gardens, and especially the Fountains, are a lot more interesting than the Palace itself, for which there are long queues even outside peak season

Bloody marvelous. This brought back fond memories of my visits to Verdaiilles...However, it adds another dimension to the experience and building rivarly...Beautiful building houses historical gems of art, sculptures...Stunning fountain which I had the privileged of witnessing the display with a tear in my eyes...The gardens are magnificent. I lost myself in this experience...

Beautiful palace but no photos, the gardens were all boxed up. We went in December so I know that was our first mistake (but were here). The entire outside of the palace was covered in scaffolding and most of the statues and fountains were boxed up for the winter. We walked around the park but there wasn't much to see as all the surrounding buildings were closed. Inside the main palace there were 4 rooms under construction but other than that everything else could be seen, no photos were allowed however and I couldn't get anyone to tell me why not.

Amazing palace!. The garden/park beats out every other man made garden, it has a nice feel of wilderness to it. The boat trip to the Peterhof is a lot more expesive than going there by bus, but it is also one of the best sights in St Petersburg.

Beautiful.... Only a short boat ride (45 minutes) from St Petersburg is the wonderful former home of Peter the Great.Here, he could watch the great merchant vessels entering and leaving St Petersburg itself.It's not just another great palace, the gardens are wonderful with a breath taking display of fountains.Take a little time in the gardens near the entrance too, there is in exhibition explaining how they buried all of the statues and treasure during the war to prevent the Nazis from stealing them.Fascinating.
Summer highlight. This was by and far one of the top sights of my summer in Europe. Beautiful gardens and facilities. Best photo opp in St Pete. Loved all the fountains.
gorgeous. one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen! Try to go there on a sunny day because the view is unbelieveable

Fountains!. We loved it really much, it is amazing place to go, but you need to keep in my 2 things -1) it is really a lot of walking - huge park.2) the best way to travel there - is by hydrofoil. It takes only 30-40 min from to city-centre to get by this means of transport. otherwise, it is 1 hour 30 min by bus or car. So, book min 1 way there, then come back by bus. Or, if you have money - both ways!)))

Stunning fountains. After exploring the house be sure to save time to savor the stunning water fountains and gardens. Definitely make your way out to see the Baltic Sea if you did not come by hydrofoil.

Fantastic gardens. When we visited it wasn't clear that due to capacity they weren't selling any more tickets to see inside which was a little annoying so go with a tour to guarantee access. Or buy online. We visited in July 2011.
Fountastic. The gardens, fountains, grand cascade, Mon Plaisir and the main palace all 'not to be missed'. Travelled by hydrofoil from central St Petersburg. A full day is scarecly long enough.
Would live to live there!. Took o many photos there. Again, the opulence in everything from the grounds, the golden sculptures and everything in sight. What a life for royalty.

Another must to see there in Petersburg neighborhood. I visited in September 2011. I heard that this Palace is a must see of this beautiful city full of Russian history, reading a lot of it and being surprised about what I saw. Please choose to go there by train / bus becase is half cheaper than if you choose an organised trip. I stayed around half of day visiting the Palace, 2-3 nearby Parks and sorrounding neighborhood. Do not exclude it from your itinerary.
must see. A trip to St Pete's without a vist to the Peterhof gardens would be incomplete! The place is WOW! On the Monday - the palace is usually closed

Beautiful Palace and Gardens. We arrived at the Palace on a hydrofoil with TJ Tours. We did not enter the palace but walked around the huge gardens. There were numerous fountains of all sizes, statues, and sculptured flower gardens. Looking over the flower gardens, through the fountains, up to the palace sitting high on a knoll was outstanding. We were warned of pick pockets in this area especially while tourists were taking pictures.

Beautiful Palace!. I highly recommend spending an afternoon here. The inside of the palace was a little bit like being in a herd of sheep but the outside is beautiful and the grounds are stunning. I'd bring a lunch next time though. The cafe on the grounds was rough.

Best water show I have seen and all naturally powered. My lasting memory is of the little joke fountains, the seat where as soon as you sit the water comes on, the pagoda where the water falls around the edge as soon as you enter, don't miss these.We were with our Russian in-laws and it was a shock to see the difference in price between what the Russians pay and what we pay. I liked the bath house in the villa by the water side very much. The whole experience was good even on our visit it was raining all day. Make sure you have good shoes.

Spectacular. The main palace is beautiful, but not to be missed are the other small palaces on the property, such as Monplaisir, which can be viewed in about 15 minutes or less. It is a treat to walk through the gardens and fountains, with musicians playing large horns rather like a handbell choir the day we were there. We went by hydrofoil early in the day, and even though there were great crowds we were early enough that we didn't have to wait in line.

Peterhof, why not?. A very uncomfortable and very delayed hydrofoil took us to Peterhof, once at the island there is a 15 min walk or more to get to the actual palace. Once at the palace we were welcomed by a marching band and fountains. It takes about an hour to see the palace and i can say it is not Versailles but still is very beautiful.Worth checking it out while in St. Pete.

Gravity fed glorious fountains!. A comfortable hydrofoil trip down the Neva River and across to Peterhof. The layout of the gardens strikes you first with the inherent beauty. There are many fountains operating at different times,and on a hot sunny day they are refreshing and spectacular.These fountains are all gravity fed and do not rely on pumps nor mechanics.Peter the great had a whimisical nature for there are a few trick fountains and water features that delight the kids and wet their parents!The buildings and accessories shine with gold trim and this venue shouts it's opulence.The gardens and walks are lovely and there is a liberal use of wood in furniture and fittings.Take and use a camera like the rest of us.

Overwhelmingly beautiful. You can understand why there was a revolution after seeing these palaces but the architecture, fountains, and take time to explore the expansive grounds...the many additional fountains and buildings with indeed overwhelm you! Plan to do a lot of walking! And you have to!

Worth every Rouble!. Visited here as part of a river tour and had to pay extra for this visit. It was worth it. The fountain switch-on at 11 is great, best viewed from the bottom level. The palace itself is interesting but very similar to Catherine's Palace. We had a limited time to see the fountains dotted about the garden, it is no too big to see most but you might have to get a move on if you want to see them all. Not sure if this Palace is open in the winter but if the fountains are not running it would not have the same wow factor.

Water with a view. I have never seen any garden like this. Every fountain is powered by gravity. Give yourself at least two-to-three hours to explore. Make sure you see Catherine's fountain in honor of her dog (it even has sound). We also loved the children's trick fountain and the Sun fountain.We were lucky and had great weather. This is not the norm. Bring an umbrella because if you have to buy one there it will cost you $40.00 USD. Ouch.We had a private guide which made all the difference.
When excess is never enough!!!. Spectacular setting - amazing water features and gardens - huge grounds so spend some time exploring

easy to do on your own. from ploshchad vosstaniya metro station we took the red line metro and got down at the 4th station baltiskya... crossed over to the baltisky rail station... the suburban train counter was very easy to find... bought obratno... return tickets to Novyj Peterhof for just 72 rubles... went to the platform and got on the train waiting...our options were trains to Oranienbaum 1 (Russian: Ораниенбаум 1), Kalische (Russian: Калище), Lebyazhye (Russian: Лебяжье) or straight to Novyj Peterhof (Russian: Новый Петергоф). ... we had already printed out the schedule of these trains from www.tutu.ru site and so were able to get down at Novyj Peterhof... after a comfortable, picturesque journey of 45 minutes... after getting through the electronic turnstile at the station, we boarded a bus with board ‘ФОНТАНЫ’ which means ‘fountains’...Numbers are 350, 351, 352, 356. Fifth stop was ours – Peterhof Parks. we reached there before 9, had the whole gardens to ourselves, wandered through the upper gardens... unfortunately that day they allowed only groups to enter the palace... so we bought tickets for the lower gardens alone and enjoyed the 165 odd fountains... by 11, huge crowds ahd come in the hydrofoils and we watched the ceremonial start of the samson fountains... after a whole day at the park, went back the same way... it was great to do this on our own... the hydrofoil costs 1000rubles one way and they start from petersburg at 9am onward... you lose precious time our only grouch in the park was they have only portatoilets... which stank to high heavens

Fabulous. Just the building at the entrance was mind blowing. Seeing the fountains in operation is like a dream sequence, and amazing knowing there is no electrical system running them. Check out Peter's fun garden sprays.

Wow! Now I Know Why the Russian Revolution Occurred. With opulence like this and an abundance of peasants, I see why Lenin was able to turn Russia into the USSR. Do what the locals do: don't bother going into the palace, but enjoy the grounds. They take several hours to enjoy. Be sure to walk by the Gulf of Finland, so that you can envision how Peter the Great entered the palace, with all the beautiful statues and waterfalls before him.We took the Metro (Avtovo station - it foretells the opulence!) and take a minibus. The trip on the minibus is neat: you get to see many of the Soviet-style housing projects en route and some of the newer, more upscale developments. To be honest with you, the outskirts of St. Petersburg remind me of Co-op City in the Bronx, or Forest Hills in Queens.

Peterhof. Peterhof (Peter"s Court) is the summer palace of Peter the Great built originally in the early 1700's and severly damaged in WWII. Peter built it, Elizabebeth the granddaughter renovated it and added much of the gold gilding and further renovation was done under Caherine the Great. Damage during WWII lead to major reconstruction. Today Peterhof is a UNESCO WORLD HERITAGE SITE. The Russian Baroque grand design was influenced by Versailles. No photos are allowed in Peterhof although I did see some people taking pictures on the sly.Security is all about and they did not seem friendly. Slipper bags to put over shoes are provided to those entering the palace.The major rooms are the Ballroom, Blue Dining Room and the Picture Hall. Much gold gilding of molding makes the rooms seem rich and opulent.The gardens are spectacular. Entrance to the gardens is an additional charge of about $18 US. The marble Grand Cascade is the focal point with the Statue of Samson in the central fountain. There are trick fountains which activate when you approach, sit down or touch something. The Sun foutain rotates once activated. People in period costumes walk about and pictures are available at a cost. Peterhof is about an hours bus ride from St. Petersburg. There is a hyrofoil which leaves from the Hermitage which will also take you there. A doubledecker bus leaves at the Baltic Train station. It is pay toilets only at the palace.

Overlooking the Gulf of Finland. We opted to catch a hovercraft outside the Hermitage and not go as part of a guided tour, this proved to be a good idea as most tour guides rushed people through Peterhof, when there is so much to see.The jouney up the Neva river took about 30 minutes, it is also a nice way to see St Peterburg as well. When you arrive at Peterhof after a short walk you see the stunning palace through the gardens. The fountains were incredible and so many of them. The tour within Peterhof was interesting but so crowded with large tour groups and unhelpful staff. I was somewhat surprised to hear that the palace was largely destroyed during WWII, not by the invaders but by the Russians themselves to prevent the Germans occupying it. The external walls are all new although the contents and some internal walls are authentic.The grounds are extensive and was really nice to walk around. Located in the grounds was asuperb restaurant which served good food washed down with a couple of beers at reasonable prices. A trip to Peterhof was a great day out.

Really luxury place of former russian royalty. I have grown up in Peterhof, spent my childhood there, worked as English speaking guide and it was the first place where I took my Norwegian husband when we came to Russia this spring.This place must be visited by all tourists, especially those, who did not have such a luxury royalty like it used to be in Russia. This place includes over 20 palaces and their number is growing every year! Everybody wants to visit Great Palace, that is why lines for going in are so big, that it can be a nightmare to get there. So I strongly advise everybody to pay attention to smaller palaces, it is a lot of them even on the territory og the Lower Garden, for example "Mon plaisir", Peter the Great's favourite house just on the cost of the Gulf of Finland. "Royal Baths" is also an extremely interesting place. But my all favourite is "Cottage Palace" - the private residence that was built for the family of Nicolas the First. It is located in the Alexandtia park, so you can take one stop by buss, or to have a nice walking tour there. It was built in Gothis style in 19th century and is the only one that was preserved when Nazis bombed and destroyed the city, because they had hospital for soldiers there. It is an extremely cosy and nice place, where you feel yourself like at home, not like a big and cold Hermitage! Strongly recommended!!!The park and fountains are amazing! Versailles is nothing in comparison with that, Peterhof's fountains are working every day during the season, from mourning til night, with amazing musical opening ceremony! A lot of gold and splendour!The prices for food and souvenirs there are very high, but this is a tourist attraction, so people pay these money, that is why prices are made like this. And don't forget about pick pockets - it is a highly over crowded place, so no wonder that they make their job there!

Versailles on Sea. A gorgeous palace built overlooking the Gulf of Finland. We didn't go inside but the outside and the stunning fountains, gardens and waterworks were well worth the visit. Lots of gold bling

Beautiful place. We went there by boat. It just takes 30 minutes from the peer in front of L'Hermitage to here. Though you have to pay a tourist fee that is the double than for locals. We visited the gardens and the Palace. This is such a beautiful place. We had nice weather.At the Palace, we were trap in the middle of a couple of big Japanese groups, so it was very crowded. Also, assistant people keep yelling at you, because you have to walk with the group, you cannot stop and look the place. So, my advice is to visit this palace in the afternoon where not that much groups are there. After of before visiting the Palace use restroom in this area because there are not too much restrooms in the compound. The gardens and the fountains are beautiful. When we were there Autumn was beginning and see the leaves in different shades of brown was beautiful.Outside the gardens is located the Church of Peter and Paul, and it is as beautiful as the Church of Spooling Blood, and no busy at all! If you leave the gardens you have to pay a ticket to come back, but if you show your boat card, you can come back for free.

Golden magnificence!. Built as a serious competitor to Versailles, as are the other two main palaces of St Petersburg, the Peterhof or Summer Palace stuns with its beautiful gardens, golden statues and opulent interiors. Approximately an hour's drive out of central St Peterburg, the palace sits on the Gulf of Finland and has extensive views of the water.We went in mid-summer to find huge crowds inside and out. Be prepared for noisy tour groups and the constant throng of people. Don't expect to be able to quietly contemplate the interiors or to sketch - the rush of pedestrian traffic is too great. At the entry, you are required to put on overshoes to assist in protecting the wonderful geometric parquetry floors - keep your eyes on the floors in every room.When gasping at the magnificence of this palace, essentially built by taxes levied on the serfs of Russia, consider the fact that the building was a burnt out ruin when German forces retreated in 1944. Rebuilding is nearly complete after 67 years though it is not possible to see any of the original structure. All of the wall panels and decoration were removed in the three months before the Germans arrived and so were able to be restored to their original positions.Overall, amazing.
Beautiful place. Newly renovated makes it nicer and we appreciated having to wear booties to protect it, nice that the government is so supportive, local guides were very good
Very impressive. The site covers a large area and has spectacular golden statues throughout the grounds. We were lucky enough to have a sunny day - really saw it at is best.

A gorgeous day out.... I spent a morning walking through the gardens around the Peterhof. The photos in front which chronicle the destruction by the Nazis, and the reconstruction the war orphans, was particularly fascinating. We arrived in time to get a good spot in back, and to witness the opening of the fountains which apparently happens at the same time every day. (10 am?) The fall foliage reflected in the pools was lovely - arrive before the fountains start if you want to photograph the beautiful reflections in still water.
Brilliant Fountains - Incredible Palace. A true display of the opulence and riches of the Tsars. The fountains and gardens add to the richness of the Palace.

Amazing Gardens!. We had already been to Catherine Palace in the morning on a rainy day so when we arrived at Peterhof we had probably seen enough of palaces! As we entered Peterhof we were told no photographs could be taken (we obeyed this rule but many people didn't), we were disappointed to be told this only when we got there. Also we had headsets on but our Guide's microphone batteries went dead and she had to speak without this aid. As we were at the back of a group we couldn't hear her as the group behind were being spoken to by their French Guide and all we could hear was her so this spoilt our time there. The rooms again were incredible but we had probably seen too much 'incredible' that day. We absolutely loved the gardens and would have liked to have spent more time there (even in the rain) but our Guide rushed us through and we had to keep running to catch up. There was some confusion as we arrived as people were having to leave larger handbags and coats in an open cloakroom area. There were attendants there but it wasn't very safe and there were queues to do this. We were also supposed to get time at the end to visit the shop but we didn't. Most of these faults were to do with our tour guide not Peterhof. So am amazing place to see but maybe not 2 Palaces in one day. The staff inside were a bit grumpy, I was told off for holding onto a handrail going up stairs!

very good. I am writing to give you an update on out trip. My wife and I enjoyed the trip to Europe and the cruise. The cruise was perfect. The off-shore trips in Tallinn, St. Petersburg, and Helsinki were all perfect, in terms of length and also for all the amenities and services. THe tour guides were very knowledgeable. The best was a young man in St. Petersburg, called Dimitri. This person is extremely well prepared and very good in meeting the needs of the clients. My wife and I, he two of us, had him with a minivan and driver for ourselves. The day was planned brilliantly. Others who took the ship's tours had to wait for as much as 45 minutes to get on the coach with 30 people. We took 5 minutes to clear the port and on our way. WE will recommend to anyone.So, thank you very much for everything.
Grandeur in the European Style. Magnificent garden areas. Another place that calls for a bit of stamina. Some of our party did not see all the gardens which is too bad. It was fun and interesting

A place you should not miss. If you are spending more than 3 days, you should visit this. I went in fall time. All the leaves were changing colors and so pretty.The fountains and statues are amazing. You should visit the palce to see the Luxury living styles of the Russian Kings
House of Peter the Great. Peterhof Palace is the House of Peter the Great. It huge! We enjoyed strolling its garden with watching the beautiful fountain.

It seemed like all of Russia was there on one Saturday afternoon!. We enjoyed the interesting bus ride out to Peterhof, as our local city guide was very informative about St. Petersburg, its history, the Siege, buildings we passed by, Peter the Great and the history of the palaces close by. Once we arrived at Peterhof it was an absolute zoo! There were dozens and dozens of big buses jostling for position in the coach park, as this was the busiest weekend of the summer season when 13 cruise ships were docked in St Petersburg, and all of their tours seemed to have descended on Peterhof at the same time! We only saw the outside the palace, the main fountains and gardens. So many people! Too much really! It's an incredibly popular place for Russians too, which is nice, but it really felt like all of Russia was at Peterhof that one afternoon! A few local residents told us that it's always busy and popular there in the summer! Take your umbrella and a light raincoat! Intermittent heavy showers kept occuring, which lent a magical air to see hundreds, if not thousands, of open umbrellas parade up and down the steps beside the Grand Cascade Fountain. The gold leaf everywhere is unbelievable, even more so to learn that it is re-applied every year to keep Peterhof sparkling and gleaming for tourists! If you're on a private tour, or travelling independently, I wonder if it's best to arrive at Peterhof as soon as it opens?? The view across the Gulf of Finland is nice to see, imagining Peter the Great sitting there, contemplating the progress of his Russian navy!

Over-priced. For the amount of effort, and the costs involved, Peterhof seemed pricey. In a city and country where prices are already high, Peterhof set a new standard. Case in point: the Orangerie restaurant, recommended in a guidebook for its set lunch at mid-range cost, set us back $30 for two for a bowl of borscht, two small meat blinis, and one tea, for which milk was an extra cost. When we tried to visit the main palace, we wound up being directed to this other site--Catherine the Great's private apartment. For about $17 each, we got to tour 7 or so small rooms and watch a brief video in Russian.But for a kindly disposed security guard who made sure we didn't miss the upper gardens--she insisted they were free--i was ready to write off Peterhof as a poor experience. However, the fountains are an over-the-top sight, the grounds provide extensive, pleasant walks, and there happened to be a band playing for part of the afternoon on the grounds.If they could improve the signage, provide reasonable food options, and streamline pricing, I would recommend visiting. As it is, I suggest knowing in advance what sites you plan to visit, so you acquire your ticket(s) upon arrival, and don't face scheduling roadblocks at the palace, which is what thwarted us,Also, you can save huge by taking the minbus from the metro to Peterhof and back. The hydrofoil is expensive, and if there's fog as we experienced, you don't see much on the ride over. Not only is the metro fast and efficient, the station signs are in russian and english, and the minivan ride gives you a glimpse of suburban St. Petersburg.
Peterhof. We were there for the beginning - to open the day. Music played and the fountains were turned on. Very dramatic. An elegant place. Can you imagine? People actually lived there?

Worth to go. We took a hydrofoil to Peterhoff. It was very eye catching when you first got off the boat. It actually reminded me of Versailles. The fountains were very entertaining. The rooms inside were very beautiful. However, other than the main entrance area and the palace itself, the rest of the place was just alright. It just looked like any other park, not much to see. However, it is still a place I will recommend to people.

Awesome. As the weather was so beautiful, we spent all our time outside in the gardens. The gold fountains are gorgeous, but there are many other fountains that are also beautiful. It was worth the money to go into Peter the Great's small private house on the Bay of Finland. It's built on a human scale and is very lovely.
must see. nothing to dislike we went on the hydrofoil brilliant allthough it started o rain when we got there.the gardens and fountains were superb well worth a visit if you have limited time
Sheer Beauty!. A trip to St Pete's without a vist to the Peterhof gardens would be incomplete! We went in an organized tour but actually can be done on your own too.
What a Palace!. It's like a wonderland of beauty! Everywhere you look there are gardens and fountains. It truly is a place to come see because words just don't do it justice!

Boat to Czar's dream. Almost completely rebuilt from ravages of revolution and nazi burning. Most of garden in perfect shape, guided statues and easy to get to April thru oct. take hydrofoil on your own from one block west of hermitage for45 minute trip back and forth. Forget expensive tour or bus. Tis is shorter and you enter the grounds with fabulous perspective from the sea. Needs bigger gift shop and restaurants.

Amazing but you pay seperately for everything. We took the Peterhof Express boat from St Petersburg which arrives at the back of the Palace. You pay to enter the grounds - there is no map provided so its worth printing one from a website before you go. We then couldn't find the entrance to the Palace and nothing is written in English, none of the staff speak English. All the buildings on the site have a seperate charge so it can get very expensive.

Very nice palace and gardens. Rude staff.. The palace is imponent. The outide is beautiful although there is no much inside. The gardens are nice. The staff inside the palace is very rude. Simply no manners. As a tourist I would suggest to visit only the gardens. They are veri nice, relaxing, extensive. You can spent the whole day there.
Gardens are a amazing. We only saw the gardens here but still walked for a good two hours. The water features are beautiful and was a very enjoyable afternoon.

Certainly worth the effort to get there! It's a fairy tale!. We hired a guide/car to drive us there and were glad we did so. We didn't realize much of the palace was looted/destroyed in WW2 - the restoration of gold leaf, parquet floors and furniture to bring it back to Peter the Great is spectacular. Additionally, take time for the gardens and the fountains. Kids should bring extra clothes - lots of places to "play" with fountains shooting up unexpectedly. One of our most favorite places in St. Petersburg.
A must see. We trook the bus tour and found the guide and tour to be excellent. If we retrun we will take the high speed boats from the Winrer Palaace.

Peterhof Palace and Garden. It's Saint Petersburg Versailles located outside the city. We went by boat (500 rubles per person - 30 minutes)and returned by city bus and subway. We thought that was nice. The boat leaves from the Neva station right in front of the Admiralty (across the street from the Ermitage) and sails through the Neva, a channel and then through the Gulf of Finland. You arrive at a dock at one of the entrances to the gardens (where you have to buy your tickets to get in). The gardens are beautiful. You have to pay extra to enter the Palace. We returned by bus (leaving the palace from the opposite side of the gardens). It's only about 300 meters from the palace to reach the street where you can catch a bus (70 rubles per person) which will take you (after some 40 minutes) to a subway station (26 rubles per person), from where you can reach downtown Saint Petersburg.
Amazing palace and gardens. This palace and gardens is such a worthwhile visit. The garden walks together with the incredible palace combine to make this a most memorable location to visit

Gold everywhere!. This palace was rebuilt after its destruction during the 2nd world war and what strikes you is the accuracy with which the refurbishment has been done. There are photographs of the rooms in the 1920's, and they look just the same now. The gold ballroom is wonderful, one can just imagine oneself twirling around on the arm of a handsome prince with candlelight twinkling in the many mirrors. It was crowded but not as bad as it would have been in the summer. The gift shops are very good.

Photographers Delight. water action everywhere and particularly resplendant in the Autumn. Peter 2 never slepted over at this opulant palace but bunked up in a self designed property of Dutch design located down stream . Well worth a visit to feel in inner mind of this liberalist, but be aware of his idiosyncratic fun fountains on the way

Magnificent Palace in beautiful gardens. You approach the palace full on, entering through a small set of gates. The size of the building hits you....huge! Well maintained and internally you will not be disappointed. Gold, crystal, mirrors, Amber...it is all there ....a great show. The gardens are beautiful and well worthy of a walk around.

Stunning. The gardens with the cascade and fountains and the innumerable golden statues have to ew seen to be believed. We were lucky to have a sunny morning for our visit to this and to Catherine's Palace, it would not have been the same in the rain. September is a bit late in the season but the crowds are so fewer
Don't go in the autumn. I think the gardens would be more wonderful in the summer but unfortunately my experience was somewhat ruined by the poor weather.

Elegant palace. Visit when the fountains are operating - you would miss the grandeur of the place if you go out of season ie in the winter, when they do not operate. Walk down to the shorline, to see the view up from the Gulf of Finland.
Don't miss it!. The place is WOW! A real beauty next to St. Petersbourg! Amazing architecture of the palace and really very beautiful gardes with golden fontains everywhere.

Spectacular museum. The UNESCO site of Peterhof is quite spectacular. The gold leaf painted roof tops can be seen from a distance. Amazingly, we were informed the gold has to be re-applied annually! The museum itself is very interesting and the workmanship involved in the restoration is notable but the grounds are truly amazing. The view from the palace down to the river is beautiful and Peter the great's desire to reproduce the gardens of Versailles in Russia is commendable but I'm sure he knew that! We visited on a lovely sunny day in July and the effort was well worth it.To avoid the problem of applying for a visa, we travelled on a cruise line tour, which was pricey but convenient. Of course this means all tour buses arrive at a similar time but our guide ensured we were first in the queue. Independent visitors would be advised to arrive as early as possible to avoid huge crowds. There are many photographic opportunities to be had with costumed models, at a price!All in all a remarkable place.

GARDENS AND FOUNTAINS ARE WORTH THE VISIT. OK, his wife Catherine of Catherine's Palace was a better decorator...but this is worth a visit. The trip to the site is a bit long, but we came back by hydrofoil which was less traffic and easier.The fountains and the grounds are spectacular...walk around them and through the parks. When we visited, there were 4 men singing in a building on the grounds...very nice touch. Of course, they wanted you to buy their CD, but the choice is yours.

Beautiful. I went there in early October. It was easy to get there by taxi bus from St Petersburg. The cost was about $10 for four of us.The fountains were still on and all of the leaves were changing. It was do pretty. I had a Russian couple purchase the tickets for me because they will charge you almost double if they know you are foreign. I spent most of the day there walking the gardens an seeing the sights. The architecture was beautiful but in need of some repair. The gardens were immaculately maintained. It was a very relaxing day.

Out of this world!. If you are in St. Petersburg, this is definatley one of the "must" sees. It is out of this world. The palace is absolutely fantastic, I have never seen so much gilt and gold. We were lucky enough to go with a cruise, so as we arrived in St. Petersburg on the Monday - the palace is usually closed - we were therefore treated to a private viewing with other cruisers, it was fantastic! Most visits are timed to arrive in time for the fountains starting at 11am, and they are out of this world - definatley the highlight of the day - cannot recommend this visit more! Amazing!

I Wish I Was Rich. The palace and gardens are a great way to spend a 1/2 day. The fountains and walkways are kept very clean. There are tons of interesting nooks and crannies to explore. Now I know what I want my yard to look like when I make my fortune.

Definitely worth a visit.. The Summer Palace is amazing, some may call it over the top. Nevertheless, it's worth a visit for historical reasons and to see its lavishness, workmanship and beautiful grounds. Keep in mind that capitalism is alive and well here, you will be charged for each and every building on the property. I don't recall if it was at Peterhof or at The Hermitage, but we were told there was a fee to take pictures too. It's amusing and a little ridiculous. I'd rather pay more up front than have to stand in several different lines in order to purchase separate tickets to enter different exhibits.

A MUST-SEE attraction. Peterhoff Palace is a place that no visit to St. Petersburg should miss. It is totally awe-inspiring. The craftsmanship of the restoration is absolutely fantastic. Do try to be by the fountains at 11am. At this time, the St. Petersburg anthem is played culminating with the fountains being switched ON. Pure Theatre and not to be missed

Wonderful. I haven't been inside the palace - I had limited time and the queue looked horrifying. But the garden with all the fountains are great and the views are absolutely fantastic. Also if you go to Russia -you should buy souvenirs near the palace - there is pretty big market with better prices and choice than in St Petersburg itself. BTW thanks a lot to our guide Olga -she is young and fun

stunning!. Spent the whole afternoon here walking around the garden, very beautiful. was a sunny day which made the experience more worthwile. highly recomend visiting. if you are thinking of going, make sure to check before you go if the fountains will be on.

Wonderfully Impressive. The Grand Palace of Peterhof is not particularly large, but it has an imposing facade and some stunning and lavish state rooms inside. The grandeur and scope of this majestic estate is just mind boggling. The fountains of Peterhof is one of Russia's greatest attractions and the Grand Cascade with its 64 different fountains and 200 gold leafed bronze statues just breathtaking. A visually stimulating experience and not to be missed.

excellent place to visit. I like going into the palace to see everything as well as the gardens and a lot of tour companies only take people to the gardens to see the water features but the palace is also well worth a visit. always enjoyable. if you are going, be sure to go when the fountains are running.
Fountains galore. Peter the Great loved fountains and was mechanically inclined so arrange for them to work by gravity, and installed fountains all over the palace grounds.

Peterhof in April?. Thinking about getting there in April? We were there. Note that April is not the season the be there -- you won't the the flowers, gardens, fountains, etc. It's still wintertime. Entrance to the parks is free.That said, it's still very beautiful. Lots of snow all around. Fountains were all off. We had a wonderful walk. A good taste of how it is during summertime.How to get there: we took a train to Oranienbaum from the Baltisky station. You have to pay attention to the names so you get off at the correct station (New Peterhof = Новый Петергоф).At the New Peterhof station there are buses going to the park but we decided to go walking (we had a map!). It's a nice 30 min walk.

Possibly the #1 outdoor attraction in Russia. This was not on the itinerary of my tour. There are many things to see in S.P., but to leave this out, that is a crime! I was not sure what to expect as i did not do my research (again, thinking my tour would take me to all the worthwhile places) and WOW, was i impressed. I only had 1/2 a day for travel and to enjoy the sight. Traveled via hydrofoil, which leaves at the river behind the Hermitage. Keep an eye for the schedule, so that you do not miss the last boat back. Wear comfortable walking shoes. Bring a picnic lunch. If the weather is nice, this is worthy of a full day. Bring your camera and plenty of time to stroll the gardens. A very romantic place, so, if you have someone to squeeze, bring them along to share the romantic sights. Enjoy.

Peterhof Palace & Garden. Well Peter The Great was determined to go a step further than Versailles and I think he did when it came to the gardens, the fountains and his smaller residence located on the edge of the property looking across the water. This was his favorite place to be. The fountains are very ornate and it is just spectacular to see them operating. We waited for an hour in the hot sun for the fountains to be activated - definitely worth the wait.

Wow.. Peterhof was beautiful, even on a cloudy, windy, cold day like the day that we visited. Something to do on a day when you need a break. Pack a lunch and wear comfortable shoes!This place has been (and is still being) restored to its former glory, after being ruined in previous wars. The care and attention to detail that Russian workers put into this place demonstrates their pride in this national treasure. And they should be proud. Golden statues, fountains, hedges, manicured gardens, beautiful buildings...We saw most of the lower gardens (paid entrance, accessed through main gate in upper gardens or by hydrofoil) and upper gardens (which are free and worth seeing, accessed by bus), and visited Peter the Great's cottage. We didn't see any other buildings, but that was enough. A person can only take so much grandeur in one day.I recommend taking the hydrofoils to the Summer Palace -- saves time, even if it is pricey, and is an experience in itself. There are about 3-4 companies who offer hydrofoils to the lower gardens. All of them have different prices. You'll find them along the Neva River, near the Hermitage, on both sides of the bridge.
Brilliant gardens and fountains. Beautiful gardens with fountains and flowers. Look out for the "fun" spots and be prepared to be sprayed with water as you negotiate the obstacles.

a must. go there with the boat, and when you get in the park you are amaze by all the fountain and gold statues. Be aware that every thing is written only in russian so don't bother to ask your way around

Don't miss it. It is stunning location full of history. Totally restored. Gardens are like any other. If you want to see how the Zhars lived you can't miss this place.The pavilion known as the 'Hermitage', were all raised during the initial construction of Peterhof during the reign of Peter the Great. The Lower Gardens also contain a large greenhouse, and in the Alexandrine Park stands the palace of Nicholas I.

Peterhof Palace and Garden. It's very likely that when travelling to St Petersburg, Russia, one of the attractions you are likely to visit is Peterhof Palace. Definitely well worth visiting albeit it a good hour trip from the city. If you like to see lots of gold leaf this has it.

Get there early. We went by hydrofoil, which is the fastest and nicest way to get to the palace. The bus journey is dreadful. If you are going independently, make sure you find out what time the non-organised groups are allowed to visit the palace, as you will be refused entry until the allotted time for individual ticket-holders. No matter how much I pleaded, they would not let me through. The palace is spectacular, but the grounds are equally amazing - do take the time to wander around.You will understand when you see such opulence, how such lavish monarchies were doomed to failure as the contrast between the lifestyle of the people and the monarch was so enormous.
It is mandatory to visit this palace in St Petersburg. It is mandatory to visit the Palace. One of the most beautiful I have seen in the world. The gardens, the fountains are amazing

Excellent experience, Must see. We been travelled a lot with my husband, but Saint Petersburg is one of the most beautiful places I ever saw. Peterhof Palace opened to us with its excellent design ideas, stunning beauty of the fountains and unique spirit of Russian culture of that time. Its amazing how organically blended rich in colors and ornaments baroque and classicism. We had truly an amazing time there. Vivat Saint Petersburg, Vivat!!!

If the weather is nice, this is the best outdoor attraction there. The palace is located outside St Petersburg (about 35kms away). We went there with a private guide and because of this, we didn’t have to stand in lines to get into the Palace. As it was summertime and we are nature lovers we enjoyed a lot the famous PARK with its many cascading waterfalls (that works just with the gravity force- no pumps), the colorful gardens, several interesting fountains and statues. After walk around we had a nice ice cream in one of the bars at the entrance. My advice: If the weather is nice and dry, this is definitely one of the best attractions when visiting St Petersburg.
Nice!. It is impressive. Good also for families with children. You can go by boat from center of st. petersburg or by mini bus. Boat is more comfortable.

Opulent Peterhof in St. Petersburg, Russia. If you're just going to be one day in St. Petersburg, Russia then choose to tour Peterhof Palace and Garden. The tour guides are incredible and they have the credentials in arts and history. You can learn so much more just listening to them as they take you around the Palace and the Garden. Yes, just beware of pickpocketers especially when they are not from your group (if you're in a tour group) and seem to be listening to the tour guide. I've been pickpocketed in Copenhagen and I was told how professional pickpocketers are in Russia. So beware even more. The gift shop inside the Palace is a bit expensive and you can get those same souvenirs for a cheaper price. Some are even on "sale" in some outside stores.

Stunning. The rooms were stunning to see full of beauty and luxury. There were not as many rooms as Catherines palace but in my opinion these were much better. I'm not a great fan of gardens but these were well laid out and breath taking. The fountains were stunning and the switch on at 11 worth seeing. When we were there the fountains along the canal took some time to get going so the affect wasn't as wow as probably planned.
Never seen one this beautiful. It is a must to see..... The garden is so big, The main fountain with all the gold statues are absolutely beautiful and lavish,

Nice Palace, But Beware of Pickpockets in the Garden. The palace is outstanding. But there's a reason they have signs warning visitors in the gardens about pickpockets. At 11:00 a.m. there's a big hoopla about starting all the fountains at the same time and everyone stands around in a crowd waiting until some guy raises his arm and all the fountains go off. Apparently, at exactly that moment, every professional pickpocket in St. Petersburg is there reaching into the pocket of baggy-pants tourists whose arms are raised with their cameras (and all of their attention) locked on the fountains. We were warned--even while standing there--yet one of our tour group had his wallet stolen. I recommend skipping the 11:00 ceremony; go after that so you can see the fountains running (they are stunning) and not have to worry so much about your stuff getting snatched.

A Beautiful Display of Fountains, Palace & Gardens!. An architectural delight that combines the use of Water, fountains, the Palace structure and gardens. A photographers delight and not to be missed on your trip to St. Petersburg. Almost every direction was a picture postcard scene.
Peterhof. One can only imagine living in a palace with gardens and fountains like those in the Palace area. I have never seen such beautiful work both naturally and architecturally.
Wonderful place for a walk in a good weather. One could easily spend one day walking and admiring the fountains in that park. I recommend to go there by bus and take the boat back.

This is a must see amazing. Peterhof is absolutely amazing, from the moment you set down from the hydrofoil, walk through the tree lined avenue leading to the gardens. I do not think anything can prepare you for the beauty that awaits when you reach the magnificant steps with it numerous fountains and gold statues which adorn the entrance to the house. Pictures on the internet do not do it justice, you have to view it for yourself. Walking through the garden it was amazing to think of the royalty whos house and gardens this was.If you visit St Petersburg you must visit Peterhof

Wow! Nice house.. Ha! This palace and gardens are breathtaking! Yes, it's similiar to other European palaces and gardens but I think I was taken aback by all the gold statues and fountains and the sun reflecting on them. I had such a lovely time walking around the grounds. Slightly disappointed with the inside (small and short) but still glad I spent the money to go inside. Take a picnic and sit on the grounds and just watch the world go buy. I took the hydrofoil there/ back and it was a little pricey -- but it was also quick and easy.
Be there by 11!. Dramatic to see the fountains come on, along with music, at 11 a.m. Be ready to walk a lot! Very impressive - but I still like Versailles better! Sorry, Peter!

Must See. Of all the places we visited on our recent NCL cruise of the Baltic area, Peterhof was the true highlight of the trip - a must see for anyone going to St P. The palace and gardens are beyond description. Be prepared for a truly stunning and memorable experience.
What a summer palace!. This is well worth the £20 return trip on the hovercraft type boat. The fountains and statues are fabulous.
A Royal playground. Beautiful palace, lots of history. The gardens are breathtaking with all the fountains. Make sure that you wear comfy shoes!

Exhibit of marvelous restoration work. Lots of gold there. The palace, statues and fountains are fabulous, but in need of better maintenance. The park is large and there are several palaces. If you arrive by boat from the city and exit the lower garden to see the upper garden, you must pay the entrance fee again to get back to the boat.

Should be at the top of everyones list - Versailles on the coast. If you only have one day in St. Petersburg, visit Peterhof.Arrive via hydrofoil, if possible (1000 r for return - departs from back of Hermitage). Tickets for gardens on sale at Peterhof jetty. I'd recommend going inside the palace (550 r) and the audio guide (500 r) since no english information. I'd also recommend a map of the gardens even though there are sign-posts. If the weather is good, you could spend a day in the gardens.

A palace that is All Wet. Peter the Great had his palace built along the sea coast and included 1500 acres of garden around the main building. The fountains are worth the whole trip in themselves. Simply walking around the park takes some real time. Don't rush!

Tsars lived a great life. See it to believe it. After visiting this you will realize why the Russian revolution happened. The Tsars flaunted their wealth and lived a great life. The garden is soo beautiful and the fountain soo unique you will not regret the 1 hour trip from the city center and the entry fee :)

Russia's Versailles. After Peter the Great visited Versailles he was determined to build a palace and grounds that would surpass its French counterpart. He was successful in building a spectacular palace with magnificent gardens highlighted by spectacular fountains.
everything in SP is a must, this is a double must. photos can't match being there and walking the palace and then the gardens, luckily on a good weather day!
A must see. What an amazing place. This is not to be missed. Use a guide though, there is so much hsitory that you will miss a lot doing it out of a book.

Fairytale gardens in Russia. Take the RED line underground and admire the beautiful stations along the way - each one architecturally and artistically more lovely than its predecessor, then marvel at the gardens, golden fountains and palace of the Tsar's palace, the Peterhof. Or you can take the hydrofoil from the back of the Hermitage, also a tremendously worthwhile experience. The Hermitage has an even better art collection than the Louvre in my opinion! and the most stunning building as a setting for showing off all its fabulous treasures. St Petersburg is an easy place to get around without a guide (just as well, since most people do not speak English).

Breathtaking.. Take time to wander around the gardens every turn brings another fountain or statue. History says it was modelled on Versaille in France. In sunlight the gold statues glisten and look out for the rainbows in the fountains and waterfalls.

How the other half lived in the Czar period-"guards" still present!!. What amazed me was how different Russia was to what I expected, I expected KGB guards etc on every corner but St.Petersburg lifestyle was quite modern in all ways. The "guards" [ladies] in the Palace are a different thing! You get moved a long very quickly and God help you if you touch something, beside an alarm going off briefly she will shout a warning at you, which was funny in someways especially if 2 of you dared to even touch a rope. The palace is very nice [OTT] and even though we arrived early to see and hear the music when the fountains started it is a very busy place with photos being taken right in front of you even when you are also in the middle of photographing, most annoying. You need good walking shoes and after a while walking the grounds got to be a bit boring. Another thing I was really disappointed in was when we stopped for lunch in a "summer palace" which was gorgeous with lots of features however I learnt it was only built 3 years earlier, so photos deleted!! We went on a tour arranged by ship [Ocean Countess] and couldnt fault the trip, the Russian driver and guide were good and informative-especially when driver advised of free vodka/coffee in a souvenir shop! Dont usually drink vodka but it was nice. and after a few you forget you feet/leg/back/hip were killing you. Glad I did trip to St.Petersburg but wouldnt bother again. Peterhof palace is not suited for wheelchairs, people with mobility problems as there are so many steps/stairs. to climb. Fortunately it was adry day when we were there but wouldnt fancy walking the grounds in the rain and there's no shelters as soon.
Beautiful. A place well worth the short trip from St. Petersburg, the Palace and Gardens are extremely enjoyable.

a truly golden , gilded sight. The Tsar palace on the Gulf of Finland west of St Petersburg is truly breath taking. The grounds and the gilded, golden cascades fountains in the front is unforgettable. I highly recomment the boat or hydrofoil ride out and maybe then the bus to the Metro for the trip back. The palace is impressive, but the Golden Cascade stairs and fountains in the palace front is the highlight of the days trip.

Wonderful day out. This is an easy and really enjoyable day trip from St Petersburg. We went on the hydrofoil and its a nice relaxed trip there and back. The grounds and fountains are so beautiful. We waited until about 3 pm to go into the palace as all thequeues and crowds had gone and we got peace to really enoy it.

Well worth the trip. Whilst the interior of the Catherine Palace is far more impressive, the interior of the Peterhof is still worth seeing. The gardens and fountains are spectacular but to do them justice you need to allow at least a couple of hours and ensure you have a map - particularly as the group organised tours will leave you on your own to visit the gardens.
Fountains. Arrive by sea and walk straight into a stunning display of fountains which go on and on and on. All of them are brilliant and the combination of all of them is exceptional.

A must to visit while in St Petersburg. This is one of the most magnificent palaces I have visited. The palace itself is beautiful but the main attractions are the gardens and spectacular fountains! I have visited Peterhoff as a part of the private tour booked through the hotel, and it was worth the $$$. Our tour guide has told us amazing stories about the history of the place and how it was built, and evolved through different rulers of the country, how much it suffered during the WWII and how long it took to restore. Walking around the gardens was an absolute pleasure; I could have spent hours wondering around and just enjoying the atmosphere. Make sure you do give it plenty of time, as there is so much to see, and unfortunately we had to rush and did not make it into smaller museums around the parks. This has impressed me much more than Versailles in France.
Visited as part of a tour with Alla. A great place to visit following ride on a hydrofoil. Really beautiful opulent gardens and stunning fountains.

a big WOW!. Magnificent landscape and magical "golden" atmosphere. You should arrange a full-day trip to discover all the major highlights, the main Palace, the Samson Fountain and Sea Channel with all its golden statues and the Lower Gardens. Other highlights not to be missed are: The Chessboard Hill Cascade, The Orangery Fountain, The Sun Fountain, The Pyramid Fountain, and The Adam and Eve Fountains. Check your dates before planning your trip because the statues are covered after the summer season.

Exsquisite. A must visit, the only negative being the massive amount of tourists and queues to enter the Palace. The lower gardens are impressive to say the least, golden statues and fountains, the canal leading to the baltic sea, just amazing. The palace itself is also fantastic, which such a rich history.Wear walking shoes! And pack a side of patience!

Amazing extravagance. Hydrofoil to Peterhof not running because of bad weather but regular boats good and not but a few minutes longer. Beautiful estate and fountains. Gold adornment more than one can imagine. Long lines of tour groups so need to know how to get in when just twosome and spare the lines. We moved through with audio at our own pace. Like most large ornate palaces with the exception of the gold touches everywhere. Ate at restaurant near entrance and had nice lunch. Can exit to eat and reenter but may need to ask the guards.

Fount-as-tic!. The gardens in this place feature the most magnificent fountains, all that work by gravity. One would never believe it.The interior is a replica of the original building that had been destroyed by the Germans.Some of the items are original. Many are not, but are chose to look very similar to the originals.We went on a tour. It took us one hour 35 minutes to drive from St. Petersburg center city to Peterhof because the traffic was so bad. On the way back, we drove around the countryside, and it took only 55 minutes. More miles, but much less time.You can get to Peterhof via hydrofoil. i don't know the cost but the half hour trip has to be far better than sitting in traffic for so long!

AWE-INSPIRING!. Visited Peterhof with private guide; walked the grounds and were simply overwhelmed with beauty of the fountains and landscaping. If you go, be sure to take in the small Mon Plaisir palace at the seashore. This small summer palace of Peter I, is a wonderful alternative to the huge palaces. Peterhof is a must see.

A Must See!!!. I would advise anyone visiting Peterhof to travel there by hydrofoil and not on the bus. The view from landing on the jetty is awesome and would be missed if arriving by road. The gardens are stunning and the fountains amazing. Just a word of caution. There are 2 hydrofoil companies operating from outside the Hermitage which is where the boats leave from. The "blue" one being slightly cheaper. We chose this company and asked what time the last boat back was. We were told 6pm, however it actually left at 5.40 and we were stranded on Peterhof! The very kindly people on the "red" company let us ride back with them for free as we had no money to purchase another ticket. Pay the extra and travel "red".

Loved it!. I liked this palace even more than the Hermitage because it had actual furniture and the small pieces of real life used by the royals. The rooms are incredible and there are also beautiful gardens which are not to be missed.

Behind the Fountain Tour. This is one of the highlights of our trip. We arrived early and toured the palace before coming outside to see the Grand Cascade Fountains begin at 11AM. After this we went into the grotto behind the fountain to see the inner workings. We also learned about some of the jester fountains on the estate

Peterhof - a must see!. My husband and I got the ferry from St Petersburg which takes about 40 minutes to a terminal right outside the Palace. This is probably the easiest way of getting to Peterhof which is 60 Kms out from the city. It is a beautiful site. The process of ticketing, however, is complicated and expensive! Instead of selling tourists a single entry ticket to access all the buildings and gardens, you will be hit for a separate entry fee for every different area of the Palace which could add up to more than AUS $100 to see the whole site! Try to time your arrival to coincide with the "turning on of the fountains" - at 11.00 am in August (but times may vary). It is a special sight when there is a huge fanfare of classical music followed by the gradual operation of all the tiered fountains facing the impressive golden statues at the front, main entry to Peterhof. It isn't as grand as Versailles, but it is a wonderful way to start viewing this beautiful Palace. The Palace itself is outstanding and it is highly recommended to lease an Audio Guide (but you will need to leave a 2000 Ruble refundable deposit). Be prepared, however, to be inundated with hundreds of raucous tour groups all with their own guides shouting each other down - the noise level can get quite distracting at times. Like many churches, monasteries and palaces throughout Russia, photographs and video recordings are forbidden within the Palace but you can download internal photographs of the Palace from the Internet. The Palace is undergoing a huge restoration program which will be a work-in-progress for a long time yet. The extravagant Reception Hall and the State Rooms are truly spectacular. Also, the gardens are very extensive and serene. The bistro restaurant (on site) has nice food but might prove pricey for some people. Highly recommended!

I Love Travel SPb. Our guide took us out to Peterhof, on the way she pointed out many monuments and interesting sights. We arrived at lunch time and once inside the grounds were taken to a Cafeteria for lunch where we purchased our choice of food. Very reasonably priced. Then we had a guided tour around the amazing gardens and fountains. Even more incredible is the fact that they operate without the use of pumps, all done with Gravity. This stop is a definite must see if coming to St Petersburg

Take the boat to Peterhof. Taking the express boat to the palace was a great way to see st Petersburg from the water. The palace and gardens are stunning. Plan on spending a half day here. The park food is pretty good and you can take your time seeing all of the attractions. We took the minibus back to the city center which provided a view of the suburbs and the amazing amount of apartment and shopping center construction.

Beautiful, historic!. This gracious, perfectly arranged palace and garden is breathtaking! History can not possibly be repeated in such a fabulous manner. Impressive, to say the least. DO NOT miss an opportunity to view it!
Can we Stay Here for Days?. I would have loved to be able to stay here for a week, just strolling the grounds, having picnics, reading a book by a fountain. What a beautiful site!

trip to summer gardens of Peterhoff. Peterhoff (Petrodvorets) is a must visit place when you are in St. Petersburg. We went there from the centre of Petersburg by what is called Meteor (fast boat). The trip takes 35 min and cost around 12 Euros (some make 40% for trips after 15h00). The admission to Peterhoff gardens is also around 12 Euros, but from 17h30 it is 50% less, however keep in mind that they turn off the fountains at 18h00 so you have 30 minutes to see the great Samson, and at 18h00 they play a nice music before turning off. If you want to see the summer palace and some small museums around it is better to come in the morning. back to the city you can take the same fast boat or mini vans (marshroutka) to the nearest metro (less than 2 Euro).
Ever been to the grotto?. Breathtaking fountains but the highlight was getting to see the grotto and the inner workings of the water system.

Magnificent palace and grounds. This site is another example of how much wealth the Russian royal families had, and how they tastefully put it to work. The palace has room after room filled with antiquities, artwork, amber, gold, and other forms of wealth that it takes one's breath away. The upper gardens are nice, but the lower gardens are simply beyond description, with all types of fountains spewing water to grandiose heights. The view from the center of the top area of the lower gardens is, I believe, directly to the Gulf of Finland, a mere 500 meters or so from the Palace itself. It is an absolutely unbelievable vista.This is another site which is not to be missed, but should be seen with an experienced tour guide.

Treated like a 2nd class citizen throughout. How would you like to pay more because you don't speak Russian, rely on intuition and helpful fellow tourists for navigation and stand in a queue for hours without having any conviction that it's ever going to move? Oh, and as a bonus, be shouted at by the staff? If that sounds like a dream come true, this place is a must-visit

The Best of the Best. Of the three palaces we visited (Peterhof, Pavlovsk, and the Catherine's Palace) this was the most impressive to us. The fountains were going and the sun was shining. It was most impressive. Definitely a must see if you are in St. Petersburg.

Lovely gardens. We only toured the outside of the Peterhof, the gardens and fountains are exactly as pictured in the guide books, we took the hydrofoil there which was interesting. It was a wet day but this did not mar the views from the garden
The Fountains. Peterhof was closed for restauration - the gardens was beautiful with all the litty alleys and fountains - "n little peace of heaven in the busy city

Breathtaking!. I love everything about this palace. Love the garden which is breathtaking as well as the grand interior made of gold. There are a lot of rooms as a palace should, we took about 1.5 hours to cover the rooms opened for visitors and the garden.

Unbelievably beautiful. This is a no miss experience. We were lucky that it was a nice day. Plan to spend a whole day there-gold statues, fountains everywhere. We got there by Hydrofoil from just in front of the Hermitage.
Most beautiful garden in world. I come from iran. I had great time in garden all things was good. I never forget st petersburg. I cant say anything u must see peterhof garden.

Incredible!. Wow -- what a magnificent palace and gardens. Even in the rain, it was unbelievable. We did not go inside, but rather toured the terraced gardens and left from the boat dock at the far end. A lovely garden to wander (if it wasn't raining it would have been wonderful).
Fountains of beauty. Water, water everywhere...even falling from the sky. Amazing feat of engineering with locks and gravity keeping the water flowing in hundreds of fountains. Lots of gilt? Guilty.

World's best fountains. My wife and I visited the gardens on a tour. Unfortunately, the weather was poor. I had been here before. The statues are stil bright gold. The water spills and shoots from everywhere. The grand cascade is spectacular. The fountains are even impressive in the rain. I wish I could have seen the fountains in the sun light again.

Beautiful, you have to visit once in your life...at least. Although we were already a bit used to palaces and churches, we visited on our third day in St Petersburg. If you see how this was restored..you can only be silent with so much beauty around. Try to visit this with your personal guide and you will have the chance to see the grottos and much more...

Nothing special. A little hurt for wallet that foreigners have to pay for admission 2-3 times more than the citizens of Russia-it's like uncivilized countries normally do ...Of course, the fountain with gold statues are worth seeing. However, apart from the size of the park itself is nothing special to show.The biggest disappointment was the palace museum. Again, you pay 3 times more than the locals and in return you receive a photo forbidden and lack of any description in English! There are about 20 chambers but not overthrowing you on the knee. Bury, Ermitrage in the center is at least cheaper and 10x better-everyone's cultural taste would be satisfied in Ermitrage.

A must see but try to pick a dry day!. As part of a ship's trip to St Petersburg we had an excursion to Peterhof Palace. The weather was awful literally pouring & we had to wait about 30 mins in the open air for the palace to open with the result that despite umbrellas etc we were pretty soaked through in quick time. That said this is a well worth visit. Inside, the palace is very ornate with much gilt in evidence particularly around the extravagant architraves on the internal doorways. Considering much of the palace was reduced to rubble during WWII an amazing restoration job has taken place. Wonderful wooden flooring with exotic designs has been fitted & because of this it is necessary for all visitors to wear plastic slip-ons over shoes to prevent any damage. Although the palace is wonderful inside it is perhaps for its gardens & very many fountains that it is famous. Unfortunately, during our visit there was as much water coming down from the sky as was going up in the air from the fountains. Surely, on a fine day this would be a truly memorable visit.

The Fountains of Peterhof. Oh my word! The ingenuity of Peter the Great is evident everywhere! I appreciated the Palace, obviously, but the gardens are the true attractions. Incredible parks and walkways. I especially loved the 'hidden' fountains that only spring to life when a certain pebble is stepped on!

Had no idea how great this place is. Fountains and gardens that were unexpected for me, it was listed on my tour and I had no idea how amazing the sites would be. Our tour was there for just a couple of hours, but we could have spent 2 days there.

Lovely Place on a sunny day. Buy tickets in advance. We had a guide. Tickets are required for each historic building. We only bought tickets to the palace in advance thinking they would admit us to the other buildings on site. It takes time to get to this site. Allow most of the day to travel and tour. Beautiful gardens and fountains.
Beautiful palace and gardens. The place is truly stunning...especially the gardens with all the fountains. Beware of pick pockets in the garden area....one older gentlemen near us was robbed.
Extraordinary. Be here at 10 minutes to eleven o'clock. Feel the sound of the anthem at 11.00 am, be quiet... and enjoy what is coming up.Perfect show.

Tour by land or by hydrofoil. We journeyed via hydrofoil to enjoy views of the port. The Palace fountains showcase amazing fountains and golden statues in elegant gardens. The tour of the Palace offers a glimpse into the life of royalty and their decline as well as to the ravages war took on Russia.

A Great Palace.. A beautiful palace displaying great wealth. The fountains are awesome! They were built in an era long before electricity. The working of the fountains were designed through gravity only. It was very crowded the day we were there, but well worth the wait. The reflecting pool that ran from the fountains below the palace to the Gulf of Finland was breathtaking.

The gardens are amazing!. There is a free part of the park in front of the palace and a paid for part at the back. You must visit the bit at the back. The fountains are incredible and it is such a lovely place to sit or walk around. They have hydrofoils docked at the end of the park to take a ride out on which is great fun. The best time to go is when the sun is shining to get the most out of it!

Versailles of the North. well, we visit this palace and garden on our own using public transportation. it is not really difficult, just use the Metro, stop by Avtovo and take the trolley bus. there are numerous buses you can use. just take any buses that have the sign "peterhof Fontana"the palace is the usual Rococo palace with all its gilded furniture. Splendid but not so special. The main feature is the park. both the upper and lower park are amazing. we came by public transport which is best since we entered the upper park (which is free of admission), and then go to the palace and the lower park afterwards. we left by the boat on the peers at the end of lower park (a bit pricy but after 5 hours of walking, we wanted a less-hassle trip back). The boat took us to straight to the main part of St Pete next to Hermitage. The lower park itself is a amazing and HUGE.... there's a lot of fountains aside of the main Samson one.

Beautiful gardens & fountains. Located outside the city, 30/40 minutes by bus has the most beautiful sights of St. Petersburg. These Palaces and gardens are sometimes referred as the "Russian Versailles" A lot of cascades, falls and fountains.
wild fountains. lucked out with a lovely day hydrofoil is the best way to go therebeautiful gardens and lots of fountains plus some surprise water features did not go inside palace
Worth to visit. Breathtaking fountains and palace, but overcrowded during the season Better to go when fountains are working

Brilliant Day-Trip From St.Petersburg: Breathtaking Time & Time Again. I've been to Peterhof before but it's still my favourite day-trip when visiting St. Petersburg. There's nothing quite like the splendour of the main fountains. The sight of all the gold, statues, and water is breathtaking.GETTING THERE: There are boats that leave just across from the Hermitage. They're quick, but more costly than other public transport. About 500 rubles, with some discounts for students/seniors.GETTING THERE CHEAPER: public transport to Peterhof is quite easy and can be done for under 100 rubles. Get to Metro AVTOVO (27 rubles for metro). Exit the metro (only 1 exit) and cross the street using the underpass. Look for the mini-bus loading area (70 rubles). There will be many going to Petehof. They will be labelled Peterhof or Fontanyi (Петергоф Fontany) and they usually have workers outside announcing "Peterhof" because they're so popular.Mini Buses to Peterhof from Metro Avotovo: 224, 300, 424, 424-AACROSS THE STREET: when the mini-bus drops you off at Peterhoff, you can walk about 5 minutes to see St Peter & Paul's Cathedral, another remarkable building. Then spend the rest of your day at the Peterhof Fountains and Gardens.....you won't regret it!TIP: make a day of it & bring a lunch. There is food available to buy there as well, and plenty of spots and benches to rest and have a snack.TIP: if you're an early bird, get there by 11:00h. This is when the fountains are officially turned on each day to some triumphant orchestral music!I suggest doing this experience on your own, not on a tour as I did my first time. The tours are more rushed & take away from the restful atmosphere of this beautiful spot.

Another toss up.. It was nice, but the crowds, the tour groups, etc. make it very hard to see the place. I would suggest going with a tour guide so you can learn about the history of the place and the artifacts inside. It's hard to get anywhere because there are so many people there.

The Marvelous Fountains are a treat to watch. The availability of golf cart helps in reviewing the whole area.The Gold colored figures,the different types of fountains and the fact that no pumps are used for the water spouts are indeed a matter of skill.The whole layout compels one to keep staring.

beautiful collection of palaces. A must see:A beautiful collection of palaces in a beautiful location and the fountains are stunning.In August it's busy - a long queue put us off visiting the main palace so we visited the "Mon Plaisir" palace instead - more intimate, but equally interesting.I've visited before in May, and that time of year was much better regarding crowds: August is packed out.Eating:There are several cafes where you can get a snack.Toilets:Not great on this point - the main block was closed and there were some temporary ones - not the most pleasant of smells in the warm summer weather.Getting there:It's way out of the city - we travelled by the meteor hydrofoil from the centre of St Petersburg - not cheap, but one of the most convenient ways to get there and much better than braving the provincial trains. A tip is to travel back to the city before 4pm, as the queues can then begin to build up for the return hydrofoil.

Peterhof Garden and Fountains. A beautiful afternoon and an easy walk filled with the fantasy of unbelievable riches - gorgeous fountains, magnificent statues. One caveat - make a restroom visit before you begin, as there are few (widely spaced) available as you tour the garden.

The Grandeur is Spectacular. One cannot not imagine in his/hers wildest dreams the Grandeur that Peterhof is. One has to visit it in order to fully appreciate it. Not even Versailles is a good comparison, for it is even bigger and more luxurious than the french palace.
I was lucky to arrive for the fountain show which begins at 11AM everyday.

Magnificent Palace and Gardens. The palace and gardens were amazing and well worth the visit. The time spent reviewing the devastating damage in WWII and the work done to rebuild this property was well spent.
Something out of a beautiful dream. you wouldn't think there was a place on this earth as beautiful as Peterhof. Go and see for yourself.

The Russian version of Versailles. I've never seen such lavish extravagance. Beautiful fountains, guilding everywhere, expensive interiors and exteriors. This place can be touristry but well worth visiting.
Great. If you like Versailles, you will certainly like this. Lots of gardens, fountains. Also some nice 'surprise' fountains for the children.
Peterhof Gardens. Arrived by boat and walked through lower gardens. Grand Cascade was spectacular. A definite must to see.

Peterhof. I made friends with some Russians and they invited me to come see their country. What a gift I received. We visited Peterhof on a beautiful day and saw it in all it's majesty. The fountains were magnificent. We saw several brides in their beautiful white dresses. You could walk for hours, so come prepared to stay awhile. When I commented on the size, I was told, that in order to hinder other countries from attacking Russia, it was built to demonstrate power and wealth and strength. It would do that. The fountains are breath-taking, the gardens are beautiful, the statuary is amazing. It is well worth the excursion.

Gardens are beautifully kept. I have visted Peterhoff several times over the years. I have to say, its been getting better and better. This time we took the Meteor boat from outside the Hermitage. A 30 minute ride and we arrived at the lower gardens, no lines, no hassel. The fountains on the lower garden to the right have been beautifully rebuilt. And the main fountain leading to the palace is unmatchable with freshly gilted gold leaf.
amazing oppulance. we visited on a group tour with an english speaking guide. We thought the restoration to be first rate and all in all not too crowded.

Peterhof. Hi all,we've visited Peterhof in July. I love Peterhof gardens, it was great. But we were little disappointed from castle. Its really nice, but totally unwelcome for foreign tourits. But from beginning - Peterhof Palace is opening at 10:30, but its only for groups. Individuals can get in only after 12:00. We arrived at 10am, so had to wait till 12.You as foreign tourist have to pay more then domestic one. And at sales point there is no information, that entrance to Palace is only with guided tour in russian, so we didnt buy electrinic guide in english in advance. After all we didnt have time to get out and wait in all queues again to get it.We better went with russian group.
