Understand nothing, only looking around :)My advice - you can take tour in english from city center to avoid all queues or to buy with your ticket also english guide at the sales point (which is separatelly form entrance to Palace)

Peterhof Palace and gardens. We walked inside and out of this residence. Not gilt and gold, but beautiful in its own way. We walked the entire gardens and wished we had more time to stay in the Hermitage and not do all the gardens.l

Brilliant place for photos. You will be enchanted at the view. Golden statues, water fountains, a never ending garden..You have to pay for entry to the compound & garden first, and then separately to the palace. That seemed to be a ripoff though

Stunningly opulent.. A 45 minute boat ride from opposite the Hermitage takes you to the jetty thence a walk along the canal as the palace slowly comes into view from its imposing position. At 11.00am the fountains are charged to the background of the 1812 overture, prettyy impressive ! Fabulous park like grounds amidst a lavish backdrop, hardly surprising the peasants resented this lifestyle of the ruling classes !

Petergoff. Wow. I never knew St petersburg would one of my top places to visit but I would go back again and again. the palace and Garden was one of the Highlights of our visit. Olga Binetskaya was our tour guide and she was great. We used TJ travel and together they planned the best day ever. We had 3 people on our tour and she was able to show us the amazing churches, palaces and even the Hermitage. Olga was like a friend.
Gorgeous!. Probably the prettiest gardens you will find anywhere in the world. The palace is stunning and the combination with the fountains and the grounds make this a must see site.

No better place on a sunny summer day. Peterhof was nearly destroyed by the Nazis but has been totally restored and is knock down gorgeous. The gardens and fountains are extensive. Don't miss the special tour of the baths (extra charge). Have an early lunch at one of the cafes. Get your daily exercise by strolling the garden paths. Especially if it is a sunny day, take your camera and lots of film.

Gardens. We did not go inside the Palace as we had already been inside Catherines Palace and we didnt have the time. The gardens however where an inspiration. The day was perfect- blue skies and the fountains were fantastic.It was perfect.

Iconic Crowded With Great Gardens. Stroll the gardens. Gawk at the fountains and learn about their marvelous plumbing and water source. Make special note of the two Chinese decor rooms that you are supposed to just walk through without stopping. Carefully observe the great silk wall coverings. Remember, Peter lived on the ground floor, not where all the showy stuffis.

#1 attraction during Summer.. It is difficult to explain. Better to see. Better with guide. With professional guide. It keeps a lot of time and open many secrets of this place.And them just walk around.The best way to get there from St.Petersburg center is high speed boat called in Russian - Meteor.Just 30 minutes one way.Enjoy!
Beautiful Garden. The gardens are worth the visit. Beautiful water fountains and manicured gardens. You can see the gulf. There is a souvenir market, and cafe which serves great russian desserts.

Trumps Versailles!. Many compare Peterhof Palace and Garden to Versailles. Peter the Great’s desire to make Russia a sophisticated European power led to this baroque garden, inspired by Versailles and designed by a pupil of Jean-Baptiste Le Blond. Most say that this palace and gardens are better than what is found in France. Our Russian tour guide stated to us that all of her French clients concede this place trumps Versailles. We guess that says it all! It pays to have a Russian tour guide take you around the grounds. My husband and I made most of an afternoon at this delightful place. Having our Russian tour guide really helped us understand what was there. The 150+ fountains are beautiful and the buildings are unique, but knowing the background and history about them made it a thoroughly enjoyable and educational experience. An example of the benefits of having a guide was knowing the reason for the fantastic shower in one of the buildings. A second example was the trick fountain. She explained how it operated.Despite the throngs of tourists at Peterhof Palace and Garden, we felt relaxed. Maybe it was the backdrop of the Gulf of Finland or it could have been the 300 acres / 121 hectares grounds. Or was it the glorious fountains that are fed by underground springs? Whatever the reason(s), we spent more time here than at the incredible Hermitage.A massive restoration effort has made Peterhof Palace and Garden a “Must See” place while in the Saint Petersburg area. Do not miss this fantastic UNESCO World Heritage site.

Beautiful and full of interesting history and stories. This is a very large and beautiful garden with many many fountains. One can spend at lest half day in the garden. We didn't have time to visit the inside of the palace. But a long waiting line there is a problem. Ideally, one can visit the place twice: one for outside and one inside to avoid the long line.

Excellent park and garden.. It is better to go there on a sunny day! The fountains and the Place beyond praise. Pay attention to the fact that you'll have to pay extra entrance tickets to the Low Park even if you have already bought tickets for hydrofoil.

Grotto excursion. Do not miss it.. They sell tickets to the Grotto from 10 o'clock. The ticket office is in the same place where palace tickets for individuals are sold. There was an enthusiasticyoung guide with a story behind the fountains: how they work, what happend to them and how they been restored. Plus some unexpected fun as Peter the Great loved to entertain his guests in most unusual way. he used the grotto as a hall for his guests during summer heat.

A Must See. The gardens and fountains are out of this world. They are so beautiful. Fountains everywhere. If possible take the hyrofoil there, the trip is beautiful and faster than taking a bus. The rooms inside the palace should not be missed.

fountains flowing to the sea. Peterhof was one of the best side trips that we took. It was about a 45 minute bus ride out of St. Petersburg. It was horribly damaged by the Germans during WWII, but now it is almost completely restored. I don't think we could take photos in the palace, but the grounds are the show. Incredible cascading fountains that flow down to the Gulf of Finland. Fantastic gardens filled with statuary, fountains and flowers. You run out of superlatives when describing this place. A must-see.

Underwhelmed. I will be in the minority but I have to say I was underwhelmed by the experience. Yes, the fountains are pretty but once you see one, it seems you've seen all of them. You have to pay to use most (or all?) restrooms. Seriously, is this 2012? Raise the ticket prices the same 25RUB and at least put up some free portapotties and add some trash bins for a real shocker. There are guards all around and don't you dare sit on the edge of a fountain. Visitors swarm the place unbearably on weekends. It takes a while to get there unless you use the hydrofoil. Avoid the Nevsky Prospect hawker tours unless you have good references from prior visitors.

Well worth the visit, but!. We visited the Peterhof Palace and its gardens on an organised tour by P&O cuises. The tour had the advantage that we were admitted into the Palace before the opening time for the general public. Although the Peterhof was concieved by Peter the Great and was built to rival the great palaces of Europe, what you see today all dates from 1945 and later as the Peterhof was destroyed by the Nazi's in the 2nd world war who used the palace as barracks. The walls are authentic but even a large portion of the roof and of course all the interior decor was destroyed during the war and restoration work is still in progress. There are however simply too many people allowed into the palace to allow you to appreciate the restored building. No photography is permitted inside and should you stop to view some particularly interesting item you are quickly ushered along by one of the many Russian ladies who stand by each internal door for this very purpose. When we left the Palace the queues of people waiting for the general opening streached as far as you could see!The gardens are really excellent and we were lucky to have a fine sunny day for our visit, we returned to St Petersburg via the hydrofoil.

Peterhof. If you really want to see and enjoy this then be sure and get there early! It gets extremely crowded and once the crowds are thick the pick-pocketers are out so be careful! The fountains and music start at 11:00am during the season. See the Palace first and then walk around the grounds. It's a beautiful relaxing place to stroll. They do have some grounds work going on but nothing that takes away from your visit.
Wonderful Peterhof. Wonderful stately home with fountains unlike I have ever seen. Shame each building had its own separate entry fee.

Peterhof Palace and Garden. The palace as well as the fountains and gardens were wonderful. This was definitely a must see. Several tours that I looked at took you through the gardens at Peterhof, but, not inside. Make sure you find a guide who will take you inside. We used Ulko Tours and our tour guide, Mariana, was wonderful. She was knowledgeable about each room in the palace and the history of those that had lived there. The palace was very busy on the day we visited. Our guide purchased tickets for us, helped us with the coat check and finding restrooms as well as excellent commentary on what we were seeing. The restoration of the Peterhof Palace is beautiful. There are gift shops located in the beginning and at the end of the tour route. There were also vendors outside of Peterhof selling souvenirs they were carrying. We found the outside vendors to have fair prices. I purchased a "Church of Our Savior on Spilled Blood" wood box -- it wasn't really a box, but it played music, twirled and depicted in wood what the "Church of Our Savior on Spilled Blood" looks like -- for $25 US. It was selling for $50 US in the gift shops. We had lunch in the cafe at the Peterhof garden, with reservations having been made by Ulko Tours, and it was delicious -- 4 courses, and the service was wonderful. We walked through the gardens and fountains and then took the Hydrofoil back to The Hermitage to finish the rest of our tour of St. Petersburg.
beautiful. Great walk in the garden, saw 2 wedding parties there. The fountains are a must to see. Took tour bus there, hydrofoil back. What fun!

Very impressive. Some people said it is more than Versailles. In some extend I can agree because it links to the sea then you can take jetfoil back to harbour near Hermitage Museum. The view is awesome

Highlights of St. Petersburg, Russia. On July 9th and 10th, 2012, my wife, I and two friends took a 2-day Ulko Tour of St. Petersburg. We visited Peterhof and its fabulous fountains and gardens, the Catherine Palace, Peter and Paul Fortress, the Hermitage, St. Isaacs Cathedral, the Church of the Spilt Blood, and the Grand Choral Synagogue. Our tour guide, Marianna, was fantastic and brought a special flavor to all that we saw. Although I had been in St. Petersburg on business a few times before and had some limited sight seeing, I learnt so much more from Marianna. We also had an excellent driver who was able to negotiate some very tight spots. My wife and I highly highly recommend this Elko tour as well as our guide, Marianna, to anyone contemplating visiting St. Petersburg, Russia.Art & Sheila Strosberg, Foster City, CA, U.S.A.

Peterhof Palace Gardens. Brilliant, so beautiful a sight. Wonderful fountains and goldwork surrounding them on various levels, just gorgeous. This sight took away our breath. The backdrop of the palace is magnificent and the whole thing is just marvellous to behold.
Amber galore. This palace is amazing. The fountains alone outside in the gardens are spectacular. Worth a visit to go! They have good prices on the souvenirs outside the palace I found as well.
A great place. I was there already 2 times and will come back! A huge place to see and for rest.With the next visit I plan to see the palace. Must be a great place as everyday very busy

If you have time to tour beyond the city of St. Petersburg, this is the place to go.. Peterhof Palace and Garden is outstanding. The interior of the Palace is beautiful, but what I loved were the magnificent fountains behind the palace. None of the fountains work with pumps. They are fed from springs. They were designed by Peter the Great in the early 1700's and still work today. We were accompanied by a tour guide and went to and from Peterhof on a hydrofoil which was fun too.

Water, Water, Everywhere. The summer palace is beautiful laid-out with lovely gardens that have a fountain in each section. It is a photographer's dream. While there are a lot of people, there's plenty of room for walking. Don't think of sitting on the steps of the palace because a guard will be there immediately telling you to stand up. Definitely worth the trip to see such beauty.

Beautiful even when crowded. Peter the Great's summer palace is beautiful, inside and out. It is relatively small (compared to the Hermitage) but very richly decorated and perfectly restored after having been destroyed by the Nazis.
The fountains are magnificent, worth the trip; and the extensive gardens also very nice. This is a wonderful half-day trip from St. Pete.
Well worth it. A great trip by hydrofoil (from in front of the Hermitage). The gardens and fountains are amazing. Take advantage of the toilets whenever you see them as they are few and far between.

Fireworks, at High Noon?. For those not having visited Saint Petersburg and all its Romanov palaces personally, there might arise the problem of getting them confused. The answer to that is to remember, the Hermitage is green, Catherine's Palace is blue, and the Peterhof is gold (or maybe just bright yellow). The Russian tour guides will tell you that most of the weather in this northernmost Russian city is cloudy, damp, and cold for all but 30, seldom-consecutive days a year. We were blessed and congratulated on having ushered in two beautiful springtime days when we arrived a week into the month of May. Just two weeks before, the last of the winter's snow had melted. In direct reaction to this mostly intransigent climate, the Russians love color--bright and beautiful, often to the point of gaudy. Not just the palaces, but elsewhere, inside and out, lots of pastels, not to mention and inordinate fondness for gold leaf, colored marbles, and painted stucco.The Baroque Peterhof Palace is slightly older (1714-23) and slightly smaller than either Catherine's Rococo abode (1733-52) or the Winter Palace (Hermitage) in beautiful downtown Saint Petersburg. I read that somewhere. You'd never notice in actually visiting the place. In sheer acreage, the Peterhof trumps them all, and indeed, the site is as much known for its upper and lower gardens, its Grand Canal, its dozens of fountains, its monumental statuary, and a smattering of smaller palaces built by later monarchs, as for Peter the Great's imitation of Versailles. But, it was quite a step up from his first Saint Petersburg "palace" which was a log cabin overlooking the Neva (still preserved today).Inside, the Peterhof is much more varied and interesting than Catherine II's monotonous infatuation with gold leaf on white. There is some of that, to be sure, but the frequent use of other shades, reds, greens, blues, and rich, wood paneling adds depth and variety to the rooms, allowing them to exist as separate entities. Though the palace was undeniably a male bastion, the influence of Peter's second wife and heir to the throne, Catherine I is noticeable, though its difficult to separate the various eras represented in the interior accouterments. Later tsars, emperors, and empresses all left their mark inside and outside what was, in essence, the Romanov family estate, at least in the summer time.If the Grand Palace is fascinating for its rich decor and history, the grand gardens (my term) are nothing less than masterful, easily rivaling those of Versailles and virtually any other such royal indulgences anywhere in Europe. And, had they been in a more favorable climate, they might well be considered the most beautiful. The upper gardens are rigidly French, the lower gardens much more relaxed and informal with ponds, canals, fountains, and the riverside adding a pleasant aqueous element. Yet this was all part of the norm for 18th century imperial plantings, so much so that it's the surprising, humorous, and trivial that becomes the most memorable.Palatial visits are not for everyone. They represent only one aspect of Russian cultural history and one that can become almost sickeningly pretentious, extravagant, and overindulgent. In modern parlance, they represent how the "two-percent" of their time existed. The rest of the cultural heritage is presented by colorful Cossack dancing, babushka (Matryoshka) dolls, borscht, and picturesque horse-drawn sleighs gliding across broad, nighttime vistas of pristine show. Of course every country is prone to such generalizations and stereotypes. Tourists are both the cause and the victims of such trite displays of pride and prejudice. A whirlwind one or two day visit is far from enough time to cut through this pretty veil. Saint Petersburg is very much the essence of that veil.--A tip for those conte﻿﻿mplating a visit to Saint Petersburg: combine your visit to the Peterhof Palace with your visit to the Hermitage. The Russians have linked the two by high speed hydrofoil service almost doorstep to doorstep allowing effortless travel the considerable intervening distance. It runs from the Neva River entrance to he Hermitage to the a dock near the entrance to the Peterhof Grand Canal. You'll never experience a smoother, faster ride on/over the water anywhere. I noticed a girl applying lipstick as the craft skimmed along at 50 mph.

Make sure you've mapped out your walk with toilet facilities in mind. I am still incredulous that such exquisitely manicured and tailored gardens could have the worst toilet facilities that I have ever experienced. I would have preferred a spot behind a bush for a pee rather than the worse than disgusting temporary toilet which left me retching for an hour afterwards....

Stunning gardens. The gardens here are far more extensive than we had imagined, and loads of visitors were enjoying the unexpected, and expected, water spouts, the gilded statues, the various plants, and the structures. Besides being a most impressive historic site as Peter the Great's summer palace, it seems to be a significant place for russians to have an outing. The trip via hydrofoil is relatively quick and comfortable.
Imperial Russia. Not as gigantic as Versailles, but much more regal. The palace takes you in the world of imperial Russia, it is as if you went back in time. And it so beautiful.

Absolutely stunning. Absolutely stunningA great place to visit by hydrofoil especially. The fountains are amazing as is the palace. Watch out for the ‘attack women’ who act as guards in the palace rooms - Niete!

Better than Versailles!. You must see the inside of the palace and do early entrance. It is far more magnificent than Versailles. I also recommend reading about Peter the Great before you go to the palace. The fountains on the grounds are the most impressive you will ever behold.

The Russian Versailles doesn't disappoint.. Again, difficult to add anything original to the other reviews. Magnificent building, amazing interiors, pictruesque fountains and statues, well tended parks and gardens, a glorious view to the Gulf of Finland. The fountains come on at 11:00 a.m., incredible sight to see. I particularly enjoyed Monplaisir, Peter the Great's favourite residence, smaller, more intimate, you can imagine him in his study looking at St. Petersburg in one direction, and Kronstadt in the other. Pictures not allowed in the interior of many of the buildings ... so drink in the sights to relive at a later date. Not to be missed!

Very impressive!. The gardens and the palace are worth seeing. The foutains in front of the palace are impressive. We had a guide and this allowed us to see all the 'inventions' that Peter the Great (an ingeneer!) installed in the gardens.

Amazing buldings, fountains and parks. We liked it all and it is a must to go there.
We were lucky and got in as "russians" for 100 Rbl each, while foreign tourists must pay 450 Rbl.

Excellent architecture, very good, but not great gardens.. The architecture here is amazing, with the golden roofs and towers. We did not go into the palace, but the exterior is wonderful The gardens are very good, with the main fountain area being the best.....golden fountains, nice architecture, etc. The rest of the garden is just ok. Worth a trip, but a fair way out of town. We took the hydrofoil back to SP, which was cool

A Russian country gem. Almost as bling-filled as Catherine's Palace,seeing the Peterhof was a wonderful adventure. The highlight is the gardens and fountains that reach down to the Gulf of Finland. We didn't see the indide of the Peterhof but the grounds were fantastic..

Not to be missed. A wonderful palace with marvellous gardens and of course, fabulous fountains. Worth the drive out of town to see. A pity that no photos are allowed inside. Some good stalls outside, for those shoppers amongst you! I got my best tourist tat here!

Wonderful. Fabulous architecture, fabulous features inside. The fountains in the gardens are wonderful. If you are staying in St. Petersburg, consider making the trip by hydrofoil - it cuts the journey down tremendously. The hydrofoil stops at the bottom of the gardens so no very, very convenient.

Peterhof in the Rain. Even drenching downpours didn't dampen our enjoyment of the gardens of Peterhof. Protected by our slickers, we dodged umbrellas and enjoyed every part of the garden - from upper to lower, and the many stories our guide, Tatianna, of SPB shared with us. She brought it to life.
beautiful. The fountains and grounds were lovely. We toured the Monplasir palace and the gardens around it. We were sorry the Peterhoff palace wasn't available.

Spectacular. For the full experience, take a hydrofoil from the City there, and walk through the park on the way to the Grand Palace. The Inside tour of the Palace is worth it, not so much for the smaller Pavilions that get hot and stuffy with people

Peterhof Gardens. Highlight of the trip. An elegant palace with magnificent gardens, fountains, statuary, flowers, and even a small pond you can walk across - if you know the rocks which are safe vs. the ones which activate sprinklers; I didn't and got soaked - but smiling.

Stunning Peterhof Palace and Garden. This summer palace of Peter the Great is truly a sight to behold.We went mid week and had a very professional Russian tour guide.The weather was over 30c and the queues in the palace were long and very sweaty! Although the wait to get in,and then to get around the palace was irritating , it was so worth it!The rooms in the palace were overwhelmingly beautiful and palential, with the history of the place interesting and bloody!The gardens and fountains were truly a staggering sight to behold. Our lovely giude showed us around places in the garden that we wouldnt have seen should we have done the tour independantly.If you visit St. Peterburg, dont miss this place. There are so many amazing things to see in this amazing city, but make this one of your priorities!

minibus to go and hydrofoil to come back. Another MUST SEE in St Petersburg! Beautiful and astonishing! it is very easy to get to Peterhof. No need to join a tour, you can easily explore the palace, the garden, and the gulf. It is best to take the metro (3 metro stations) then minibus to the entrance of Peterhof, then walk around to the gulf of Finland to take the hydrofoil and be back to the Hermitage. We noticed that the entrance ticket is a lot cheaper after 5PM or so (forgot the exact time), so if you are visiting St Petersburg during the white night period, you should definitely go there at the end of the day to enjoy less people and beautiful evening (feels like afternoon) scenes.
Must see!!!. It is something must see!!! So beautiful I can't explain. Before go check day off.You can spend all day there just waking in the parc. To get there take a fast boat from Hermitage.

Gayle D949. We went in a small group and avoided the crowds. The trip from Saint Petersburg takes over one hour. The gardens and the fountains take your breath away. lthough it was raining it was well worth the visit

Magnificent splendor. if you have half a day to spare in St. Petersburg, take a tour of Peter the Great's summer palaces. Yes there is more than one.Peter built his summer getaway on the Baltic coast.Once again plenty of gold adorns his palace and gardens. The gardens are magnificent..I would say the whole complex he built outdoes Versailles in its splendor and location.Again there are masses to contend with but because there are gardens..there is room "to breathe". Enjoy the walks, dream the dream that Peter lived here. Once again go with a registered personal tour guide..easier to get it and they will inform.

Versailles of North. Lovely gardens, impressive golden figures and fountains and numerous traces of excentric way of life of Peter the Great. Gardens are huge, well maintened and a lot of fountains that often will have the goal to make you wet as a part of touristic charme.Very crowded but make sure you don't miss it. There is a special boat tour regularly starting from Peterhof to San Pete and other than nice cruise it offers some rest after long walk so make sure you enjoy this way of transportation after the tour!

Beautiful and dramatic palace. Amazingly ornate state rooms, beautiful gardens and fountains. True expression of the grand history of the Russian imperial family. Expect significant queues in the peak summer season but if you have a good guide they will find a way to get to the front !!

Lovely gardens and palace. We arrived at Peterhof Palace by ferry as part of a two day guided tour of St. Petersburg. The gardens are beautiful and very well maintained and the fountains, modeled after those in Versailles, are specatcular. We did not have the chance to visit inside the palace, but the garden and exterior made the visit well worth making.
Most Beautiful Place Gardens. Most beautiful palace gardens that we have been through, as compared to the Versailles in Paris and the Schonbrunn Palace gardens in Vienna
Peterhof is pure gold!. Everything is gilded here, including the fountains. There is a lot to see;;;;beautiful rooms, many fountains, even the floors are worth some photographs.

Overcrowded. This is a pricey day from the cost of the ferry to entrance to the gardens and then an entrance to the palace. The gardens are beautiful and makes the visit worthwhile. The Palace was completely overcrowded with intense crowds of day visitors. One cannot stop and enjoy any of the rooms - you are basically pushed through by the masses. Unpleasant and claustrophobic experience.
must see. I have never seen such beauty before. Every wall made in to amazing work of art. This is where you want to be with your personal guide

Peterhof Palace one of St. Petersburg's top attractions. Peterhof Palace is the Versailles of Russia. If you have time to take an excursion from St. Petersburg, this should be your choice. I took a boat from the front of the State Hermitage Museum to get to Peterhof. The price is reasonable and the trip takes 40 min. (There are other boats.) The main problem with Peterhof is the long line to get into the palace, and your ticket into the gardens won't get you into the palace. The optional recorded tour you can take is lengthy. Consider skipping some parts. Peterhof Palace and Gardens is a world class site.
Worth the boat ride. We took the high spped boat and spent 3 hours here. amazing and reallt telling about why there was a revolution- definitely worth seeing.

bring food, water, camera. Make a day of it. Get early, leave on the last bus but don't take the mashrutkas... they are cargo trucks for sacks of potatoes and people. Very unpleasant journey even at the best of times. The gardens are great, get a tour. Plan a picnic lunch.

peterhof. We were on a river cruise & went to see the palace. It is amazing & as you cant take pictures inside my husband bought a dvd but we cant make it work. Luckily it wasnt expensive. Also the cruise ship was able to get us in early before the crowds which was so lovely to not have to battle. When we were leaving the place was so crowded.

Unbelievable. This is a spectacular palace to see. Lots of gold everywhere and the gardens are breathtaking. We took quite a lot of photos here! It was very busy there but as we had engaged a guide for the day, we didn't have to wait in the lines and she knew exactly where to go. Built on the style of The Palace of Versailles it is a beautiful but busy place to visit. Allow 2-3 hours at least.

Don't Miss it. This amazing Summer Palace was the residence of Peter the Great, Catherine the Great, and others. Photos are not allowed inside, so we purchased a set of postcards from the giftshop showing many of the magnificent rooms. It was a quick 45 minute bus ride from St. Petersburg and well worth the time. In fact, this is the place shown whenever St. Petersburg is mentioned, with it's grand palace, beautiful gardens, and numerous fountains. An easy walk through the grounds pass aviaries, the Gulf of Finland, and many different fountains, some "tricky." They only turn on to spray unsuspecting guests when someone walks nearby. The main fountain area, powered solely by gravity, goes on at 11:00 to music.

The Palace, Gardens, and Fountains. This is a beautiful, fairytale place. The stunning beauty will awe you. When you see the destruction of the palace during WWII, you are stunned to see how the palace was so lovingly and artfully put back together.

Worth the trip!. This palace is located about an hour by boat or 45 mins by bus from St Petersburgh, but it is an absolute must see! The palance was built by Peter the Great in order to impress the foreign visitors, and it is truly impressive!! White and gold palace surrounded by stunning gardens and numerous fountains will take you back to the 18th century and provide plenty of setting for a perfect photo.
A sight to behold. The golden figures and water fountains in the gardens are incredible and the gardens lead straight down to the River Neva which leads into the Baltic Sea. Wonderful

Using hydrofoil is quite complicated. We found it most difficult to buy tickets as everything at the ticket counters was only in Russian language and the pier in Peterhof did not have signs for the ferry company names - so people were queuing up in wrong lanes - and that caused quite a chaotic situation among the tourists who did no speak any Russian.

too much to take in!. Fabulous palace & ngardens. Rooms ornate & golden
Gardens with cascades, summerhouses, statues .
More Gold leaf than anywhere else!
Hyrofoil was best bet to get there with sailings every 20min at a cost of 1000 roubles return

Peterhof. Fantastic location starting with the walk from the hydrofoil with the view to the palace through the fountains. The downside is that they push you through the palace very quickly and every part of Peterhof charges so the day can be extremely expensive. You need to work out which parts to visit first as an individual you could end up paying between 150 and 450 roubles for each building.

Pleasant place but only with sunshine. Nice place, lots of green around not very well cared for, though. The hydrofoil shuttle from St.Petersburg should be preferred to bus service (it takes only 20 min to get there - one way) and let it be even a one-afternoon visit. Worth visiting!

Gold, gold and more gold. We booked a private St. Petersburg tour which allowed us to spend a good amount of time walking around the fabulous, must-see gardens. The multitude of gold covered fountains and statues are awe inspiring. How fun it was to watch unsuspecting tourists get soaked by the "trick" fountains. Watch for the guy sitting on the bench with sunglasses--I think he's got a remote control device to turn on/off the fountain.

A wonderful sight. The Peterhof Palace has a beautiful garden and magnificent statues. The fountain area and sculptures in front of the Palace simply gleam in the sun. It was a bit dull weatherwise when we arrived but it did not rain, and we managed to get some sunshine before we left the Palace. We did not go into the Palace as it was not an option but the grounds are really lovely. This is definitely worth a visit. It is just outside of St Petersburg and you get to see some of the countryside rather than just the city of St Petersburg.

A must for anyone visiting St P for the first time. Truly spectacular- please see the photos in the upper gardens of what it looked like after the Nazis destroyed it. Says a lot for the Russian willpower to see it these days.

The Versailles of Russia. Both the palace itself and the incredible fountains of this palace are definitely worth a visit. The palace isn't huge (apparently only about 30 rooms) but the rooms are stunning. It's surprising to learn that this palace was largely and almost completely destroyed by the Germans in WWII and what we are seeing today is the result of massive restoration efforts for which Russia is to be commended. The site is now a UNESCO World Heritage site. Fortunately the sun shone for us the day we visited and the gorgeous fountains and beautiful gardens were simply magical. One great technological achievement of Peterhof is that all of the fountains operate without the use of pumps. At the entrance/exit to the Palace are lots of souvenir and food vendors. We were part of an organized tour so didn't have to worry about parking or lining up to get in.

Not to be missed. Located outside the main city in Pushkin we took the boat to reach the park. Alighting from the ferry there is a nice stroll up towards the palace along a "canal" where you reach the fountains. These were all in full flow and what is more amazing is, as a previous writer commentated, they are gravity driven and with approx 200 individual fountains makes it even more amazing. Look for the fountains that are activated by human presence, designed to soak the indiviudals as they pass by. We were lucky, the day was sunny which certainly drew the crowds.We did not actually visit the palace but the walk around the gardens and viewing the fountains is worth the time.

Relaxing place. Very big park with a lot of fountains, Peterhof Palace is located in Finland Gulf which we rode a comfy boat to access it. The day we visited it was rainy, but felt amazing in the middle of this big and green garden. Nice and big sculptures here among the fountains. You go through the garden and you will find the fountains. It makes your journey a bit mysterious. Like those stories of princes and princesses that walk in big gardens...

Wonderful Gardens. We arrived here to visit the gardens only in the pouring rain, our guide gave us rain ponchos and off we went. The rain could not spoil the magnificent fountains made of gold and beautiful grounds we saw. these gardens a bit out of the main town but worth the drive.

So Much Gold. This is the famous palace of Peter the Great. There is gold everywhere inside and out.
The fountains and gardens are amazing as is the house. The fountains all operate from gravity flow - no pumps at all.
If you are in St. Petersburg this is a must see.

Amazing Palace and grounds. Very much worth a visit as the palace, fountains and gardens are breathtaking. We had already seen the Hermitage (Winter Palace) and we didn't bother lining up to see the inside of the palace but I don't believe it's worth it as the rest of it is great and doesn't cost any extra. We did do a tour of the grotto beneath the fountains which is all in Russian but worth it to see how it all works and gives you some photo opportunities of the fountains themselves that the ordinary visitors don't get. You pay for this at the ticket office at the top and to the right, and the tour begins halfway up the stairs to the right of the main fountain as you go up. Hydrofoil ride over there was also worth it.

Fountains and gardens were amazing!. What a great start with getting there via Hydrofoil. The gardens are so different everywhere you look as were all the fountains. The area is so well kept and clean. The main fountain area was just breathtaking to see with all the gold statues, urns everywhere, gardens and two buildings on each side of the bottem part of the fountain area that even had fountains on their roof! Lots of people but you seem to just forget about them and just enjoy the beauty. A must see!

Rushin' around Russia. Hubby and I took a two day tour of St. Petersburg Russia with Den Rus Tours. One of the lovliest sights we saw was Peterhof palace and gardens. The weather was gray most of the day but the sun emerged while touring the flower gardens and grounds. The artesian fountains, waterfront scenery, manecured lawns, large pools and sculptures gave us a different picture of a country that can be monolithic and gray. Den Rus did an excellent job, cramming this and many other stops in to two activity packed days.

No dining, too expensive. We had to eat dodgy hot dogs and ice creams, as apart from that there was only 1 restaurant type place. A simple cafe would've done. Plus there was a problem finding non fizzy water. My advice - bring water with you, as well as a few sandwiches

Wonderful. It was really nice to visit Peterhof. The gardens are amazing. I really didn't like that you have to pay to entrance for the upper gardens. Also to enter the Palace you have to pay 550 rubels and when we got inside they didn't have any audio guide in english!! That was really bad for us because everything was in russian. We just walked through without knowing anything and going to the russian groups. I just didn't understand why the workers didn't help us. I was really mad about it. To eat, the best option is that you bring from home some sandwiches and make there a picnic. Besides that it is a must in St. Petersburg and has really nice things.

Peterhoff gardens. Absolutely lovely, a lot of walking and it was pouring with rain. Our tour operator, Denrus , had provided red ponchos and it was easier to recognise our group of 9. A stunning location to visit.

Lovely place. We travelled to Peterhof by hydrofoil as it takes only 30 minutes to get there. I visited the palace first time in the 90's and have to say a lot has been done since then. I have one criticism though, it is not advertised anyway that one has to pay even to get to the park area. It was quite a surprise to arrive by hydrofoil and then start queuing for tickets to the park. The ticket included only submission to the park, if you wanted to visit the buildings one had to buy a separate ticket for each place separately (there is no combination tickets awailable). However the gardens are very large and beautiful so there was plenty to see anyway and didn't even have time to go inside the buildings. We also took a train-ride inside the garden which proved to be a bit of a disappointment as it took us outside the gardens and not inside like we all thought. This is a must see place thoug, don't miss it.

Experience leaves a bitter taste. As one of the locals explained to me, "foreigner pay double" - while in Saint Petersburg I barely ever got the feeling of being truly welcome, Peterhof's double charge left an especially bitter taste in my mouth. Absolutely nothing to diminish the status and the beauty of the place but the flagrant inequality is disappointing.

Fantastic scenery. Go visit for sure, our first visit to Russia, and it wasnt boring at all, bought an excursion out from the cruiseship, and it was an whole day trip, but worth to see all those great things in St. Petersburg.
worth a Visit. the cascades are spectacular. Those speaking English are not well catered for OR have to pay a huge premium for a guided tour

Too much to see!. There is just so much to see that even if we had spent days here we would not have fully appreciated all that was on offer. Having booked a 2 day tour of the city, part of the deal was the mueum opened early on a Saturday to recieve us, when we left the queue's made us realise what an excellent option this was. the art work is stunning, just so much to see, a really vast collection of some very notable artists

Well worth the trip out of the city centre. This Palace is a little way out of the city but well worth the trip! Be sure to be there before 1100 hours to see the waterfalls & fountains being switched on which are a testument to engineering of the day - no mechanical pumps just nature! The Palace itself is packed with paintings, portraits, furniture and carvings despite the Palace having been raised by the Nazi's during the war. Our guide was very clear on this point when challenged about the use of the word Nazi, she stated you cannot hold the German Nation responsible for the acts of the Nazi movement which was an ideal of that time. The gardens are well worth a stroll around weather permitting

the russian versailles. Choose the hydrofoil: the departure is not far from hermitage. You need 20 min to go. The palace is wounderful. Take care for the opening hours if you want visit it.Choose a sunny day the gardens are splendid

woooooooooooooow. I loved the garden and foundations. We had took a fast boat in front of hermitage and spent a whole day. There was a heavy rain, waiting return boat on the pier and we had got all wet, inspite we had raincoats and umbrella. But it worth.

Pricey for what's on offer. The whole place is divided up into cost centers so you have to pay a separate fee for each bit - it totals a pretty penny!The water fountains and gardens are lovely but the palace really only has two rooms of exhibits so you can easily give that a miss.They are still refurbishing bits so don't be surprised if you can't get to everywhere.We went by boat and came back to St Petersburg by train but be warned it's quite a walk to the train station.

Amazing Fountains. This redone palace has truly amazing gardens and fountains. It has been so precisely restored that it almost has a Disney feel - I guess in the good way. There are tremendous crowds in St Petersburg at all venues- so I would encourage if you can using a small group tour company - they can get you in and out and deal with the crowds-

It's History........... The numerous fountains and acres of lush gardens certainly make for a beautiful presentation. Gold is the word for the constancy of sculptural decorations and statues. Opulent, grandiose, and any other superlatives can be used to describe this once a upon a time, residence.

Beautiful gardens, badly organized visits and entrance to palace. one big mess, we only enjoyed the gardens. rude Russian people with lacking of good information made our visit (for my mom that so wanted to enter the Palace) a frustration!

Peter the Great's summer palace. The palace is beautiful with the gardens and statutes even more so. During world war II most of the statues were buried so that they would not be taken. The largest most prominent statue in the garden was taken and it was never found so an exact replica is in its place. Worth going with a tour guide if its your first visit to learn and underscore Russian history and dynamics of the czars.

Fountains galore. Truely over the top gardens,but exqusite- there were more fountains than you could count. WE were there on a sunny day so the reflection off of the water was magical.Took about one hour coach ride from St Petersburg but well worth the trip. Dont bother about going into the house here as Peterhof is famous for its gardens. Go to Catherine's Palace for the interior gobsmacking rooms

beautiful. You need a whole day here. Inside the palace is fabulous, but the gardens are even better. there is a nice restaurant that you can eat at and be served, take a break with your kids and then continue on

Gardens and fountains great, palace good.. Absolutely amazing. The tour inside the house is pretty good, but the real attraction are the gardens on the gulf of finland and the spectacular fountains leading up to the palace.

Peterhof. It is a great place to visit with wonderful gardens and fountains. The only problem: I took one of English speaking tours and was slightly disappointed as tour was 1 hour shorter then it was advertised. As the result, after touring the Palace we basically run around the Upper Gardens. I wish there would be a time to enjoy it and also visit Lower Gardens

Beautiful park but horrific service and staff. It is a most to see, but if you are going to see the Grand Palace expect a really bad service and a price, that does not match the experience. The attendants are rude and not service minded at all, and the information about the place and how to get the best experience is lacking. Expect a long line to get in. The park however is beautiful.

there are so many big and impressive gardens around St. Petersburg. was very impressed by all the statues covered in gold and a lot of fountains there. We came there by bus but return by ferry to land in front of the Hermitage.

Nice trip from SPB. We took the ferry from Hermitage, it took about 1/2 hours to get to Peterhof, the return ticket is 1 000 Rubel, the entry fee to the park is 450 Rubel, it worth the price. Beautiful garden and there are nice places to seat down for a coffee or a tea,
Peterhof. Beautiful! This getaway is the dream vacation place for anyone. Not much to see inside the buildings, but very impressive.
Peterhof Palace and Garden. Beautiful garden, A must to see. Rooms renovated realistically. Beautifully adorned rooms. Grounds wonderfully well kept. Historical background fascinating.

Brilliant gardens.. We arrived just before 11.00 hours when the fountains start. The sheer grandeur of the Palace and gardens takes your breath away. Very tiring with all the wa;lking but definitely a 'Do not miss'
A Must See. This was the best destination (we thought) in our touring of St. Petersburg. The interiors of the rooms left me breathless. The gardens are unbelievable. It's like being in a dream.

Great display of variety of fountains in beautiful park. Come during fountains season to walk in the park and visit the palace and the various pavilions. Definitely take a ride in the tourist train to visit nearby Alexandria park. This is the only way to see it without having to buy entrance ticket again.Hard core fountain lovers should not miss the fascinating Grotto tour. Come by marshrutka shuttle and leave in the evening by Meteor speedboat that will take you to the center of the city/ Board the ship early to select best place near the window.

Incredible gardens. We spent our time visiting the gardens and not the interior of the palace... we had already seen the interior of other great buildings. The gardens and fountains are incredible and you could stroll for hours. Lunch is available at a cafeteria here but is a bit expensive. This was one of the top sights for us while in St. Petersburg.
Beautiful gardens and fountains!!!. This palace have amazing gardens....the views are awesome...more than a hundred different fountains!!!

Gold Gold Everywhere. Those Czars sure were lavish. The place is crawling with gold and fountains. Each fountain is gravity fed, and can run almost 8hours continuously with no pumps etc. This is a fantastic place to take pictures.

Perterhof. Visited this with the girlfriend during the one blue sky day of our weekend.All i can say is WOW, get there if you can, go by Metro, then bus, and leave on the Hydrofoil. Make sure you see as much as you can, you will need a full day as well...get your walking shoes on and enjoy this magnificent palace
Stunning. The palaced it beautiful and the grounds are a gardener's dream. Definitely a place to put on the "must-do" list.

Excellent palace and gardens. We travelled from St Petersburg on the Meteor hydrofoil located behind the Hermitage (1000 rubles per person return). Entry to the palace is via the lower park (450 rubles per person park entry). The lower park is beautiful, with many fountains and photogenic vistas. There is catering within the park. The Peterhof Palace sits at the top of the grand cascade in the Peterhof lower park. Entry to the palace itself is slightly unusual. There is a general queue to get in to the building. Some people will be part of tour groups and have tickets already. If you are not part of a tour, you still need to join this queue, and can buy tickets once inside (follow the WC sign!). Tickets are 550 rubles per person. All of the information beyond the ticket office is in Russian only, so I would suggest an audio guide (500 rubles and a 2000 ruble deposit - these can be shared to reduce the cost!). The interiors are fantastic, and many of the artefacts were sent away for storage before the German invasion, so have survived the pre-emptive destruction by Stalin during the war. The tour takes about 90 minutes. We queued for about 20 minutes to get in. We also visited the bath house. This building is related to the Monplaisir villa. Tickets are bought just outside (360 rubles per person). The building looks interesting but tours are compulsory and appear to be in Russian only!

think having cash before going there. 500 rubles 1 way, and not 2 ways ? 450 rubles entrance for foreigner - 250 for Russian ? visit of the bath 350 for foreigner, 250 for Russian, NO credit card are taken for those boat trip ? when entrance to the Park and fountain can be paid by card ?? taxi to go back outside the Palace 1800 rubles ! So make calculation before you leave, as gasoline and your own car is really much cheaper than those so call speed boat which are just a reap off if you are 2 or more!

Fountains, gardens and Gold. We visited on a damp day, not much in the way of shelter if busy. The palace is a well restored and interesting place, shoe coverings required to protect the floors, a little slippery though. Be on the bridge at half ten for the fountain start up. Gravity fed and to the loud playing of the national anthem. An truly impressive sight. Well worth a visit.

It was pouring rain when we were there, and we still loved it!. The fountains, the art, the landscaping--all beyond description. We ate in the cafeteria-type restaurant and weren't impressed, but it was adequate for the needs of the mid day. Don't miss this if you are in the area!
Pterhov is Peterhof. Need to praize all thosw people who work hard to bring this beauty to life!

Beautifully reconstructed palace with many original features. This imposing building sits at the top of the grand cascade in the Peterhof lower park. We travelled from St Petersburg on the Meteor hydrofoil (1000 rubles per person return). Entry to the palace is via the lower park (450 rubles per person park entry). The lower park is beautiful, with many fountains and photogenic vistas. There is catering within the park. Entry to the palace itself is slightly unusual. There is a general queue to get in to the building. Some people will be part of tour groups and have tickets already. If you are not part of a tour, you still need to join this queue, and can buy tickets once inside (follow the WC sign!). Tickets are 550 rubles per person. All of the information beyond the ticket office is in Russian only, so I would suggest an audio guide (500 rubles and a 2000 ruble deposit - these can be shared to reduce the cost!). The interiors are fantastic, and many of the artefacts were sent away for storage before the German invasion, so have survived the pre-emptive destruction by Stalin during the war. The tour takes about 90 minutes. We queued for about 20 minutes to get in.

The Versailles of Russia. What an incredible example of the opulence of the czars! The palace is a definite must to visit. It is said that Peter the Great was actually trying to build a better Versailles! The formal gardens and famous fountains with the gold-plated Grecian type sculptures are particularly impressive when the "water show" begins every hour. The water fountains shooting from the water statues is a sight to behold. From the back of the palace, is a great view of the canal leading to the Baltic. Although much of the palace was destroyed in war, it has been rebuilt. The original artwork was rescued from destruction and is on display. The room of mirrors and the amber room were among my favorites. Believe it or not, the books, and souvenirs available in the gift shop were quite reasonable.

It was good to be the Czar.. Seeing is believing. Outside of Versailles, the most unbelievable palace we have ever seen. All the gold, the opulence, the fountains, the gardens, no wonder there was a Russian revolution!

Beautiful, stunning. This is an amazing feat of engineering. The building inside are beautiful, just don't linger too much or the stern Russian ladies will swiftly move you on!!The ground are also stunning, so many fountains, and on a sunny day it is just amazing. Get the hydrofoil there which is faster and has better views on the way.
Magnificent Palace and Gardens. The Peterhof is breath taking! Reminded me of Versaille. If you are anywhere near it, do yourself a favor and go see it!

A feat of engineering!. The fountains which are pressure powered without any pumps are incredible & in abundance. The water features with gilded statues are what dreams are made of. It was a joy to walk around the Peterhof although there were a lot of tourists.

Easy to do without a guide. We were ready to find our own way around and this was the perfect adventure. We hydro-foiled to the garden (one way 500 rubles, return with the same company was 300 rubles). There was a 450 ruble charge to get into the gardens. Each museum has a separate cost. We had seen many palaces: we declined the museum tour crowds. It was a brillant sunny day. We walked and admired the fountains and the grounds. Four hours later, we agreed this was just what we needed after all the guided tours. Beware of crowds as busloads and boatloads of people are dropped off throughout the day. We learned about the gardens on-line so we knew enough to appreciate the history, renovation efforts, and beauty.

Water and more tricks.. Come in by hovercraft and watch the fountains start up at 11am.
Good walking shoes and enjoy the fun of getting wet with tricky fountains!
A wonderful display. Fountains, gold and beautiful gardens. This was a lovely way the spend a day

Nice gardens and fountains. Didn't go into the palace in Peterhof but the fountains and gardens are beautiful. Simply cannot believe that the fountains only use gravity no pumps required! Nice place to have a picnic lunch and relax in the gardens.
Opulent. Amazing - gold leaf on the outdoor fountains - now that was opulence!!
Beautiful!. Don't miss this site! We loved the gardens and the amber room.

Better than Versailles ;). I was asked, "How does it compare?" a lot. My title is a joke ;) in truth because there is no point in comparing the two places. Peter the Great drew inspiration from Versailles and you can see this influence throughout. But I feel something gets lost in the comparison. Peterhof in its own right is a fantastic place. I learned a lot about Russian military history just by asking questions of our host while at the various fountains. It is a fantastic place, an oasis by the Baltic and to think the Russians rebuilt it after the Nazi invasion makes it all the more extraordinary. (Note: we only visited the gardens, not the interior during our stay).

A glorious experience !. With Viking River Cruises ( aboard the Viking Rurik which was a very comfortable base ) we travelled from Moscow to St Petersburg along the Russian waterways. Moscow has many interesting attractions ( Red Square, GUM , Kremlin, St Basil's Cathedral and much more) but the traffic jams are a nightmare and we were glad to leave that City behind. The voyage part of our holiday was interesting although the scenery is surprisingly flat and heavily wooded. St Petersburg , about a third of the size of Moscow , is a fantastic city and a highly recommended destination. The rivers, canals , stunning cathedrals, galleries and museums are all wonderful but the highlight for us was a morning spent at the Peterhof Palace and gardens. Look it up on the Internet - it really is glorious and an experience you would never forget ! Dunelm.
How the other half lived. fountains are superb. gardens are vgood. toilets are a disgrace.take a gas mask.

Gorgeous fountains. We enjoyed our visit - I was struck by the fact that Peter the Great had relatively simple tastes including a very small retreat near the sea on the larger grounds of the palace and gardens. We were fortunate to have a van, driver and guide so while we took the hydrofoil to the site, we returned to the city by van. This enabled us to see many dachas, other communities in the outskirts of SPB and some of the recent building boom in that city. The Peterhof is 29kms from the city, so it's only worth it to visit if you have at least half a day.
SPeechless. This is simply amazing! The fountains are grand, and even more amazing that they only use gravity. I wish we had more time to spend here!

The highlight of our 2-day visit. Visit these beautiful gardens on a dry, sunny day! You will not be disappointed, far far better than Versailles that they were modelled on. Make sure you go when the fountains are turned on.

If you like gold, you'll love Peterhof!. GOLD GOLD GOLD GOLD GOLD GOLD GOLD. Did I mention the GOLD? This was sort of the Russian monarchy's answer to Versailles, a sort of gold-plated one-upmanship. Fantastic grounds, much more comfortable than Versailles' ominous orchards. It had a great deal of charm, especially the fountains that shoot out randomly. Kids will love those, and they should bring trunks and a towel. While they're at it, they can also run to take a dip in the Baltic. While it's not as warm as the Gulf of Mexico, it's sunnier and warmer than most California beaches. Plan on a lot of walking. Wear appropriate shoes with appropriate socks. This is not a day for fancy things or shortcuts. You will be hiking. We arrived by way of the "Orienbaum" train, stopping at the Novy Petergof stop. Other trains will go there - best to look pitiful on the boarding dock so a conductor will get you headed towards the right train. The ride out was bumpy, warm, and interesting from a world traveler perspective. If you would prefer something more than wooden seats and open-air cooling, then you should not take the train, you pampered sissypants. There are minibuses you can take from metro stations. If *that* isn't good enough for you, you could ride the hydrofoil both ways and pay double for admission. Beyond that, rent a helicopter, I don't know. I love train rides and sweating it out with the locals. I'm a he-man mountain trooper when it comes to that sort of thing.OK, so maybe I should have taken the shuttle from the Novy Petergof station to the Peterhof itself. It was a LONG walk, with little remarkable to see along the way and there aren't any directions on how to get there. The stupid Lonely Planet guide blithely assumed that not only would we get the right train (we almost didn't), but that we'd stroll along nicely to the Peterhof along some kind of yellow brick road. Kids, I'm here to tell you that the road isn't marked and we had to ask for directions along the way.On the plus side, walking there did give us a chance to have a moving experience at the Peter and Paul Cathedral, which I would not trade for all the world. If you're a religious person, you need to go there.Back to the grounds themselves. The upper garden, to the south of Peterhof, is free and has some delightful fountains and bushes bent to make arched arboral tunnels. Very romantic and fun! The catch is, if you want to see them, you'll have to arrive on the outside of the Peterhof. If you showed up by boat, you'll have to leave Peterhof and come back on bus or train. If you want to return by boat, you have to do it from inside the Peterhof grounds, and they don't have the concept of "all-day access" in Russia. Food on the grounds is either hot dogs and burgers from stalls or from pricey restaurants. Russia seems to be a land where food is fuel, so if you're holding out for culinary treats, you're in the wrong place. Just eat the "grill dog", it's relatively delicious and a good value. My wife says it was a really good dog, so there you go. It's not bad, that's for sure.If you're not into gold or fountains or taking a dip in the Baltic, then all that's left is the interior. I've already seen Versailles on the inside, so I opted out for Peterhof's version of lifestyles of the despotic and gaudy. As it was, the massive fountains were great fun and well worth the price of admission. We had an entire day at the cathedral and gardens... can't imagine what we'd have done if we tried to wedge in a palace tour.Note also that non-Russians have special times for tours. Be wary of that.The ride home on the hydrofoil was way more expensive than the ride up on the train, but we got to relax and not worry about which stop to get out at. We went straight back to the metro after that before our legs totally gave out. Great fun, but don't plan on anything else that day, mmmkay?

great fountains, big queues. Getting out here was pricey on the hydrofoil. The fountains were truly spectacular flanked by the palace. Gave up on entry to the Palace after friends had waited for hours and various ticketing issues. Overall this attraction is not well set up for non-Russian speaking tourists as yet. We imagine it will improve over time.
Nice place. I liked the parks in Peterhof and the Bolshoy Palace, but the place itself was crowdy.
Beautiful!. Beautiful grounds and great history. We loved it all.

Don’t let the guide take a shortcut.. Besides the impressive interior of Peterhof Palace, there are also the beautiful fountains to be enjoyed. The tour of Peterhof starts with the interior of the Palace and then you get a tour of the gardens and the fountains. The largest and most impressive fountain complex is the one right at the tourist exit of the Palace, but if you are early, there is no water yet. The fountains do not operate before 10:30 a.m. Instead of waiting, the guide may take you first to look at the other fountains at one end of the park. As soon as the fountains start to spout at 10:30 a.m. they walk back to look at these other fountains. We noticed that (I have been to Peterhof before) many guides do not take a path back to the main fountain, but walk at an angle in the direction of the quay to pick up the hydrofoil back to the city. So you will only see the main fountain complex, which by now will be operating at full strength, from quite a distance. It is actually just an extra 5-10 minutes extra walk to take a route going by the main fountain before going to the quay. But these Russian guides don’t really care.In a country where the average salary is $1000/month, these guides pick up several dollars per person in tips from their 20-30 large tour groups daily. Some guide more than one tour a day. They look smug and the extra mile is not there.If you come on a later tour, there should be no problem. After completing the interior tour, the major fountain complex will be spouting water as you step out the castle, giving you a dazzlibng display. And you will be right there.

Beautiful. You can spend all day if you really explore the grounds and gardens or make a quicker trip if you only want to see the main fountains and central formal gardens. The hydrafoil makes getting there easy. Take a look at the church in the town just outside the gates of the park.

Good 3/4 -1/2 day Tour. This large palace is a short boat ride outside the city. The boats and tickets can be found across the street from the Hermitage's exit. There are many boats during the summer and it seemed as one arrived the next would pull up. During the winter the hours are much more infrequent. The trip is about 30 minutes. There are buses that are the cheaper option to get to Peterhof but why waste your time? You still have the Hermitage to tackle.The palace is best seen on a sunny day. The gardens are half of the attraction. The ticket does not include the church. The upper gardens are free but you may have to buy an another admission ticket to get back into the lower gardens and to get into the boat for St. Pete. There is some discussion of a way to get in and out without paying again but I did not pursue this avenue. There are also some grass areas that are forbidden to walk. There are security personnel with whistles to alert tourists to stay off. It is amusing to watch the befuddled tourists and it reminded me of a lifeguard at a swimming pool. The gardens are well kept and there are many places to find a quiet spot and have a picnic. There is also a cafe that has simple fast food items and a higher scale restaurant with some genuinely good food but expensive. Swimming is allowed by the docks of the boats. The palace itself is in good shape. There is no photography allowed inside the palace. There are also times when the palace only allows Russian tourists. This occurs about mid day. Plan accordingly and visit the Peterhof website before you go. Tour groups seem to be exempt from this policy and also get a direct entrance over the solo tourists. A tour is nice but then you don't have the time to wander around the gardens and eat at your own pace. As with most palaces in Europe there are strong influences of French and Italian style and art and architecture. During White Nights there will be hordes of tourists.
Fountains and palace. This is a long walk around massive gardens filled with perhaps 30 exotic fountains and a beautiful Palace. It takes some energy but so worth a visit.

Incredible. The gardens with the fountains are quite extraordinary, so much to see in the grounds.The Palace itself was wonderful, very extravagant and a bit to gold to my liking, also the problem of having to wait in line for a very long time, whilst groups took priority!!

The real story to us was the post-war reconstruction. We went to Peterhof with a private guide (thanks Irina S. from Tours by Locals) via hydrofoil. It was crowded, but as she did throughout our stay, Irina somehow got us close the front of the line. There were crowds throughout, so the guides could provide only limited commentary in each of the many spectacular rooms -- and they are truly spectacular. What impressed us most was the degree to which Peterhof was destroyed during World War II and the huge undertaking to restore as much of it as possible in the decades that followed. One's judgment of the Soviet system notwithstanding, the restoration is a great achievement and clearly a present-day source of Russian pride.

Amazing and amazingly overcharging. So, you have to go to the Peterhof. But, get ready for long lines, uncommunicative (in English) staff and charge after charge.Make sure you pay attention to the times that things are open.

Must see this!. You must see this an allow lots of time to all through all the gardens and see all the fountains, we were lucky enough to go with a private guide and wow the history is great! A lot of the signage is not in English so a guide of a book really helps. We found that throughout St. Pete.
Wonderful gardens. These are amazing gardens. We were on a guided tour and saw all of the highlights with a good explanation of everything as we went. Loved the main fountain and the trick fountains.

Beautiful. Don't miss it!. Such a change from all the inner city sights. The gardens were absolutely breath taking. Make sure you go when the fountains are running (Mid-May to mid-October between 11am and 5.30ish PM). There are 140 water fountains in total! The palace and gardens are around 29km out of the city so we caught a shuttle bus there (50Rub) and the hydrofoil home to the Hermitage stop.Definitely worth the trip.

A must for a hot summers day. I love the gardens and fountains, a great place to visit on a hot summers day and to get out of the city. Go by hydrofoil and enjoy the boat trip. At peak periods the queues to get tickets for the palace and upper gardens can be daunting. Although the Palace interior and upper gardens are well worth visiting however if the queues are too long then the lower gardens are still worth the visit.
Peterhof Palace. We loved, loved, loved this place, give yourself lots of time to walk around the gardens, its worth it!

Get ready to do a LOT of walking. This will take you the whole day to see the entire grounds. Fountains are fun - especially the trick fountains. Grand Palace is not at great as The Hermitage, and the guided tours were only in Russian, so for 550 Rubles you might want to skip -- however the grand palace does have the best souvenir store in all of Saint Petersburg in my opinion.
All time. Simply the best gardens I've ever seen. The fountains are amazing.
Wonderful garden and palace. We find this palace and garden a magical place. Rival Versailles and Shonbrunn Palaces

Fabulous Gardens. On our 2 day tour to see as much as possible in St. P, we only got to see the gardens at Peterhof, and they were worth every minute we spent there. Beautiful landscaping, statues, and the Palace as a backdrop make this a Don't Miss attraction.

Absolute Splendor!. My husband and I visited the grounds of Peterhof as part of a small group tour with russiantourguide.com. Our guide estutely lead us in what always seemed to be a highlight without the crowd. We started at the Dragon Fountain on Chess Hill, walked through the Roman fountains to the Monplalair palace along harbor wall. Walking through a beautiful alley, we arrived mid-way on the canal for a beautiful view of the Great Palace. After some time at the Samson Fountain and Great Cascade we headed around to the Upper Park. It is only from the front that you can see the enormity of the Great Palace! It was very interesting to view the exhibit of photos showing the palace & grounds in ruin after WWII. What an amazing job they have done in restoring things! I was told to skip Peterhof if you've seen Versailles. I love Versailles, but I am so happy I got to see Peterhof as well! It is exquisite!

Be Careful and watch your valuables !!. I will not get into detail of place, it is magnificant, as many reviews outline. However there were two couples from our cruise ship that had stuff stolen here in the grounds. One had their passports stolen by a pickpocket and another was attacked by a group and their backpack taken from them. There are many locals wandering around in the grounds and you should exercise precaution of your valuables. Imagine being in Russia without your passport and not able to get through passport control at the docks.

Rivals Versailles. When Peter the Great set out to beat his cousin at Versailles with his garden and fountains he was very successful. A beautiful spot situated on the Gulf of Finland so adds a specular backdrop.

Wondeerful!. The Peterhof Palace and especially gardens are great - offer you to take some clothes for changes if you decide to have fun in "joking" fountains. Beside Peterhofs Great Palace visit Monpleasir, Catherine rooms and Marli. Also Peterhof town has not very visited but beatufil church of Peter and Paul - just walk out of the Palace gardens (from the Upper Garden) and visit it and the small lake behind it.
Crowds. Beautiful but in my opinion the top level is better than the bottom. You can look down on the fountians without getting swept along by the crowds.
HUGE AND GORGEOUS. Just make certain that you have lots of battery in your camera. Click away. A tourist attraction that is a must to see!
The 32 Golden fountains. We only went in the gardens, and these were breathtaking. We have some wonderful camera shots, and there is gold everywhere. Suggest you wear a good pair of ashoes.

Nowhere on earth. Peterhof is extraordinary park of fountains and palaces! No other place on earth like this. Indeed, Petr I was a Great! The hydrofoil is best way for come to Peterhof (just 30 min). It can be found in front of Hermitage. The first hydrofoil starts at 9:30 and then every 20 minutes. The cost around trip for adult 1000RUB ≈ 30$, children - half price.If you planned 1-day trip, visit to the Grand Palace and Palace Mon Plaisir and enjoy the fountains and the atmosphere. It is not possible to visit all places during one day. Entrance to the park cost 450RUB ≈ 13$ per adult. The tickets to palaces are separately. There is not many restaurants in the park.
Beautiful Gardens. The palace has great street appeal. Inside the rooms began to blur together but the gardens and fountains behind the palace were lovely.
Oppulance at it's best. Worth seeing. Drive there, hydrofoil back to the city. Huge beautiful grounds.

Terrific, but be prepared to purchase multiple tickets. We took the hydrofoil from St. Petersburg, which was quick and painless.Gorgeous grounds and fountains. The massive tour groups clog up the entrance to the box office, so be prepared.We were solo travelers, so were able to slip by the meandering groups once we got inside the main palace.Strolled in the gardens, and ate our lunch (pies we brought with us from Stolle) on one of the (very few and far between) benches on the grounds.Every part of the complex seems to require a separate ticket. The Grotto is well worth the extra cost for the photo opportunities alone.We caught a "marshrutski" shuttle bus (a short walk from the land-side entrance to the park) and then the Metro to get back to town, which was cheap and fairly easy.
This is Amazing. You could spend all day here and not see everything. If you like water fountians you have just died and went to heaven.

Beautiful Palace. Took a tour bus to the palace and all the tour buses arrived when the palace opened so it took 60-90 minutes just to get inside. No bathrooms on the outside of the palace so you have to wait until you get inside.....and it's only one small bathroom for men and one small bathroom for women so plan accordingly. Two hours later, there was no waiting line to get inside so it might be best to go a few hours after opening instead of trying to get in during the tour bus rush. Inside the palace, it's very ornate and full of history from room to room. Definitely a top attraction in St. Petersburg. Reading information on the Romanov's ahead of time might help you understand some of the rich history.

Spectacular Fountains. We got to the Peterhof Palace and Garden early and just in time to view the fountains starting. So beautiful! The whole garden is amazing & we did find the trick fountains. There was an extra fee for going into the Palace; just pay and go, you will not regret the walk through there. My only complaint, not enough time. We were on a tour, I would suggest going on your own and then you can take all the time you need.
Worth the trip. It's a long drive, but spectacular palace and grounds. I would think the boat trip (hydrofoil) would be a more fun way to get there.

great side trip. Wear good walking shoes. The lower park area will take you at least two-three hours to go through. Make sure you bring rubles as no one takes credit cards. Trick fountains are really fun.

Beautiful!. The fountains really are amazing - we had heard so much about them and they didn't disappoint. We didn't go in the Palace as we were exhausted after walking all round the gardens but it was enough just to see it from the outside. Make sure you go on the hydrofoil, much the easiest way to get there and good views from the boat en route.
Gorgeous must-see place. St Pbg is full of masterpieces which they have renovated very well, this is a huge place!

One of those special moments in one's lifetime.. My husband and I were not only lucky to be visiting this beautiful palace but we arrived on the day when they were turning on the fountains for the first time in the year. There was much celebrations with bands playing and school children dancing & singing while we waited. Peterhof is not only beautiful, it felt like a very happy place. I highly recommend it.

Gold fountains everywhere. And each one nicer than the next. We didn't actually have time to go inside, but we really enjoyed the grounds
We also enjoyed the hydrofoil ride to the museum, as well as the subway on the way back to town.
Go early. Beautiful- the gold leaf is amazing and the gardens are nice. Make sure you find the hidden water sprays that catch tourists off guard.

Beautiful but difficult to navigate!. Whilst this is definitely a must see do your research ahead of time. It is extremely easy to get to Peterhof via fast hydrofoils which leave every half an hour from the river just below the Hermitage museum, on arrival you will pay to visit the lower gardens ( which will get you in to see the fountains and main building) However purchasing tickets to the Palace Museum itself was a nightmare. We found that entry was limited to Russian residents only until 2.30pm, we were given conflicting advice of where we could buy palace tickets and as there are absolutely no signs in english at Peterhof in the end it all proved too difficult and we missed the palace altogether.

The fountain of life. We arrived in time to see the turning on of the fountains at 11.00 am together with the marvelous music. The fountains and 160 acres of grounds to this palace were breathtaking. We walked most of it and we were tired at the end but we were so happy to have had the experience.
Peterhof. travelled to the site by hovercraft. We saw a small military parade while walking the grounds . Another amazing site offered by TJ Travel
Personal favorite. Personally, I like Peterhof best of all the places. It puts Versailles to shame. The famous fountains are turned on at 11am duringnthe summer months only.

It's up to you. If you want to visit Peterhof you choose between 2 variants: to book an excursion or go on your own. The first normally includes a return bus tour and a visit to several fountains and one of the palaces, which means you won’t have time for anything else. And Peterhof comprises a huge and beautiful territory. As for the 2nd variant, you can go on your own by bus, train or boat; this is cheaper and you explore the park and palaces as you like – no haste or skipping places you’d like to see. But be ready to queue up for tickets! Tip for independent visitors: Come by bus or train and return to the city by the last boat (book the tickets beforehand). Then you are guaranteed a memorable day full of culture and leisure!
Worth the trip. I have never in my lifetime, seen a more beautiful garden
fountains galore. a huge garden, hundreds of magnificent fountains in a georgeous garden

Could have spent the whole day!.
