Gave myself a day to recoup from jetlag and thought it best to get a guided tour on my first excursion even though I could have taken the hydrofoil right outside my hotel (Courtyard Marriott). The boat ride is 30 min. The driver took 1 hour to get to the palace but we saw a lot of Saint Petersburg on the way.The tour guides get to go through the main palace 1 hour earlier, if I remember 10am then the general public 11am. So its less crowded but we didn't get to loiter because of the other tours and each room has a "watcher" to be sure the line flows.The palace is very spectacular and the gardens even more so. Unfortunately during WWII the Germans either took or destroyed most of the art and furniture that was there. There are many buildings and gardens that you can purchase admission tickets separately. Look at their website. Also there is an occasional concert there so see if you can attend!We spent the early part of the afternoon in the lower garden strolling with the gorgeous fountains and flowers and then left about 2:30pm. So I didn't get to really stay and enjoy the garden or get to the other buildings but the tour guide was excellent. If you want a tour call Marina Wilson (see my review).

Wow. We were told that Peter built this after seeing Versailles and the latter pales by comparison! We had an amazing experience - the castle was closed as it was the last Tuesday of the month. Thousands of people milling around the gorgeous grounds and somehow, our guide had arranged for us to be admitted. Just two couples and our Art History PhD guide - and the people cleaning the rooms! It was a surreal experience in a magnificent location.

Versailles of Russia. Like the winter palace, the summer palace is equally gorgeous. Very well maintained, the rooms, the fixtures have you really absorb in the royal grandeur. And the gardens!!! boy oh boy!!! they are a treat to the eyes!! Walk till the end and u coem to the river which flows into the Gulf of Finland and in turn Baltic Sea... awesome...
Beautiful Fountains. Fountains are all gravity fed. Remarkable. Bring comfortabel walking shoes.
Best garden in Europe. Rivals Versailles for splendor and beauty. Two hours strolling the gardens are very pleasant and a nice getaway from the hustle and bustle of St. Petersburg.

Beautiful than Versalles, more expensive though. NO ENGLISH!. Fantastic place. We can smell the richness from that period. You pay around EUR 11 to enter in the complex with acess only to the gardens, which is huge and seems to have an end. Inside, all the informations are in Russian. There are a lot of attractions/museums inside and you have to pay for each one. The problems is that you can not read what you´ll find inside the buildings as you don´t have any info in English and ppl don´t speak any other language, but Russian. It means, you will see: Adults 700RUB... if you have some extra money with you, pay for it and see what happens... or go with a guide. I wouldn´t use the speed boat again. It will cost you 500RUB, when the van charges you 70RUB. I used both.
Wow!. Unbelieveable fountains and gardens. All the grounds were beautiful and the fountains that are more than 40 are all run without pumps.
Go at 1100. The music starts and the fountains behind Peterhof begin to trickle and by the end of the music the most scenic fountains in the park on full blast. It was a great sight to see.

Amazing Gardens. The gardens in the Peterhof Palace are amazing. The workmanship that went into buidling the fountains is awe-inspiring. Just make sure to have a knowledgeable guide or guide book so you can understand the stories behind these beautiful fountains.

A place you should not miss. Everything is beautiful and well kept. The only thing I don't like is that they charge foreigners much more expensive. The ticket for Russians to the Grand Palace is 300R while we foreigners pay 550R.
Peterhof. Absolutely beautiful! GCT planned a wonderful itinerary for this Russia Revealed trip.

Amazing gardens and water features. It is a bit far by boat, so we went by car. We spent 5 hours in the garden which has has stunning vistas, water features (fountains, waterfalls and even a mechanical dog chasing water spouting ducks), flower beds, large and small flower beds. And there are of course the palace, smaller buildings, churches, all with lots of gold. Gold is very much part of the Russian make-up: if you don't like it, then don't go to Russia. We loved it and found it worth every single one of the 18,000 seconds we we there. And we didn't even do the palace or the interior of any building!

Amazing fountains. A beautiful palace, make sure you allow yourself enough time. The hydrafoil is the quickest way to get there. It takes half an hour but you have to be there half an hour beofre your hydrafoil; so if you get there at 4.25 you will be on the 5.00 hydrafoil. This is worth knowing as the fountains are turned off at 6pm.

Breathtaking! You will never see anything like it.. Words can't describe how gorgeous the Palace and grounds are. The airfoil boat over is fun and fast. Be prepared for long lines and do your homework to see which day is best. If you get tour groups in front of you, forget it, you will wait several hours. Crepe restaurant at dock is good.
2 Day St. Petersburg Experience. This is a very expansive area to see. The gardens are spectacular. I can understand why Peter the Great expecially loved this place.
Surreal. What one person creates in the name of themselves is truly amazing and disturbing.

Crowded and expensive. Wasn't a big fan of Peterhof. While it's an impressive palace with lots of gold for some, the crowds and cost ruined it for me. 600 RUB each way for a boat, 450 RUB for park admission and another 550 RUB to get into the museum (much less if you're Russian). Packed with cruise ship tours, but seems the way to go. If you try and tour on your own in the museum, you get 'locked' out, so just cling onto one.

Peterhof. One of our group was advised to visit Peterhof, not knowing what to expect, we caught the hydrofoil to the island, and once we saw this magnificient palace we were just amazed... truly worth a visit.The Palace was closed, but the gardens and fountains are truly worth the visit.
Definitely worth a visit. Everything was just great - the inside tour, the walk through the park, and a great view of the various facilities

Stunning restoration and utterly beautiful. This was our second visit, the first in 1986 and there is more to see. all the tours try to get you there for 11am when they turn on the fountains and cascades and as a result there are huge crowds trying to guess where they will get the best view of the waters gushing as the taps are turned on. But they are on then for hours so you can see it all except the first gushes if you wait and it is still stunning.The gardens are pleasant and some quite beautiful. Do not miss Mon Plaisir, Peter the Great's favourite and charmingly small "palace" cottage. It costs extra and numbers allowed in at one time are restricted, but it is quite the most intimate of all the palaces and during the World war II siege it was a Wehrmacht German army barber shop. The cottage lies next to the water of the Bay of Finland and the views around are lovely. The surrounding town is also charming but tour buses rush through it.
A must to see.. The beauty will take your breath away!! Our guide was so very knowledgable and set a pace that allowed us to fully appreciate all that we were seeing.

Marvellous, but watch out prices.... The place is wonderful, definitely a masterpiece. It's a shame that foreign tourist are milked money after money and are not entitled to a guided service, while there is a guided tour of the palace in Russian any 10 minutes... And by the way foreigners pay 550 rubles embarrass of the 300 paid by Russian... And if foreigners want an audioguide in English out costs extra 500 rubles... And all the signs are written in Russian only...Now, I speak Russian, but I was with friends who do not, so I felt it was unfair and not tourist-friendly...

Maybe favorite part of the trip. Gorgeous. Lovely boat/day trip out of St.Petersburg. Again, stunning of course. Similar but not as decadent as Versaille, or so I'm told. Huge lines to go inside. But my favorite part was roaming the grounds and imaging a different time period.

a must for visitors to St Petersburg. an excellent trip to the palace on the Gulf of Finland (Baltic Sea) where you can marvel at the splendour of the palace and the gardens; the real highlights are the spectacular golden fountains. not so good is the distinct lack of refreshments within the palace/gardens and only tacky snack bars in the car park

Wonderful palace and grounds. Try to arrive early as the lines form quickly. Wonderful to see what Peter the Great built. The palace is remarkable, and the engineering feats of the fountains are impressive. Be sure to take the time to walk around the gardens after you tour the palace.
Jaw Dropping. This is a must see palace with its jaw dropping beauty and opulence. We travelled with SPB Tours and Natalia, our guide, was fantastic. See my entire review under the Hermitage section.

We would go back. We organised an English speaking guide, driver and car from Australia and we were so pleased we did. Our guide, Lisa, explained everything we were seein and as there were only two of us she had time if there were any questions. The tour took 5 hours from leaving St Petersburg until our return. The gardens and fountains are great.
Dazzling. This was the highlight of my visit - especially wonderful as all the fountains were in use and it was such a brilliant day

The fountains of Peterhof. My adult son and I had visited St Petersburg two years ago at the end of March and beginning of April for a week. This trip during the White Nights was to visit both Peterhof and Tsarkoe Selo. The fountains of Peterhof were astonishing especially when they were turned on at 11am to the strains of Bach. The Grand Cascade was an amazing experience with the sunlight reflecting off the golden statues and the rainbow lights in the largest fountain where Samson wrestled with the lion. I found,as always, that a book on the attraction was invaluable as this one had an excellent map and gave good historical information:particularly helpful when one has about three words in Russian. No success in entering palace: never did work out the entry system!

Beautiful as Versailles.. 45 minutes from the city of St Petersburg, worth the trip. Situated in the country in a wooded park. Spectacular structure of classical russian style. Gold and richeries all over. Beautiful gardens and fountains. Must see.
Peterhof. Another still fantastic palace and graden. We walked 3 plus miles in the garden alone looking at the beauty that we were enveloped in.

Fantastic. We got there in time to tour the palace and then see the fountain display. This was followed by a long walk around the beatiful gardens and down the canal to the Baltic sea.
Really worthwhile going to.

Beautiful Gardens. The gardens and fountains are beautiful. Fortunately we visted Peterhof on a lovely sunny day but because we didn't have much time and had to join the queue to get into the Palace before returning to our ship, we were rushed around the gardens and probably didn't get the full benefit of their beauty. The Palace was very busy and very warm because of the heat outside but top marks to the lady who was ushering visitors through the rooms for giving me her chair when I took unwell.
Excellent place to visit. The palace is wonderful and the gardens and fountains even more so. It's very crowded but you are still able to take great photos.
Peterhof palace. ABC, another bloody palace. Beautiful interior, but too muvh of the same old restored furniture and portraits. A pity that the Nazis did so much destruction and theft.
Loved the fountains. Loved the fountains and the gardens. Such a nice park to walk around in.
Peterhof Palace and Garden. Beautiful but a little crowded a that stage but even then, it was an adventure

Smaller of the Palaces but Well Worth the Visit. The gardens are lovely with spectacular fountains and lovely interior. This is the smaller of the Tsar palaces and less impressive compared to The Hermitage. Bring an umbrella as it is known to rain. The crowds can be a bit pushy but stay your ground. The signage also needs improving for tickets and getting to the main entrance. There are seperate fees for the garden and interior.

Top Sight in St Petersburg. After our visit in June we consider this the top sight to see in St Petersburg. The 170 fountains that have been functioning for 200 years via gravity is an engineering accomplishment and just plain gorgeous. 4 months ago they finished redoing the gold gilding on all the out door statutes and the entire place - inside and out - is in extraordinary condition. If you are there just briefly make sure you get to Peterhof!

Peterhof Worth the Ride into the countryside. Did not get into palace but was assured it was very similar to Catherine's Palace which we toured in depth. Garden fountains are magnificent but bathroom breaks are an issue. Don't drink a lot of coffee before doing this tour. We went four hours before a loo break at lunch.
The best place from St.Petersburg. Very nice, you have to see it!But many tourists!Nice park, nice buildings

Amazing.. Peter I is one of the most important rulers in history and this palace reflects his greatness. Everything from the fountains outside to the beautiful rooms in the inside is absolutely attention grabbing. :)

Beautiful fountains and gardens. We visited the gardens and fountains at Peterhof, and Mon Plaisir, which was Peter the Great's personal home. The grounds were spectacular, and I was very happy to see the simple home which Peter loved.

Good day trip - some tips. This is a good day trip, but it does get very expensive quickly. I recommend taking the hydrofoil out (600rubles pp) and taking the bus+metro back. Definitely do the Grotto visit as it was quite fun, eventhough the tour is only in Russian. The Grand Cascade is beautiful. A lot of the staff / ticket sellers do not speak English, so communication may be a little difficult. There isn't much to eat on the premises (but there are a few cafes), so consider bringing lunch with you. We stopped at Cafe Stolle on Nevskiy Prospekt on the way to the hydrofoil and bought pies for our lunch. There is a toilet inside the Grand Palace outside the ticketed area - so you could still go to the loo if you aren't going inside the palace itself (assuming there is no queue to get in to the palace of course) Definitely only go on a sunny/clear day - rain would make this day trip terrible.

Great garden; so-so palace. The fountains in the garden are impressive and is worth the price. However, the palace appears to be like a newly renovated show flat, without much historical interest left, which one could choose to skip..Overall, this is an expensive attraction.

My personal favorite!. This was my personal favorite place to visit in the St. Petersburg area. It takes about an hour to get here. I loved the fountains and gardens and wish I had more time to explore. On the downside, the crowds were overwhelmingly thick, both inside as well as outside. Words cannot describe how ornate, lavish, opulent, and amazing this place is!
Fabulous visit with spb. taken to Peterhof by hydrofoil, which was brilliant. The gardens are quite wonderful and the trick fountains great fun. We visited the 'little palace' which was fascinating.

Versailles palace of the North. Travel by hydrofoil from the pier by the Hermitage. The gardens and fountains are magnificent we went back a second day as they were so huge and spectacular. Go early to avoid the crowds and go on your own you can go straight in and work your way through the tour groups. Inside the palace is spectacular and well worth the entrance fees.

A taste of imperial Russia. The opulence of the Grand Palace is stunning, and the grounds with their gilded fountains are gorgeous. We saw five or six wedding parties getting their photos done, a bonus since it was exactly our thirtieth anniversary. There are costumed actors with whom you can have your picture taken for a few hundred rubles, which we did.You pay a small entrance fee to the park and then buy tickets separately for each palace or other building as you enter those buildings. We chose only the Grand Palace, and also took a mini-train ride around the grounds. The narration was in Russian, of which we understand only a few words, but it didn't matter. The chance to rest our weary feet and see parts of the park outside the gates was worth the small fee.

Another amazing Palace. An amazing palace with lots of fountains in the garden. You can get there by taking the hydrofoil near the Hermitage. The frustrating thing is the tickets. You need tickets for just about every single area. The Peterhof website is incorrect when I looked at it before going. It said that the Lower park was free but when we got there it wasn't. Despite that, it was still worthwhile seeing it.You need at least half a day to visit Peterhof.

Very nice. Its definitely worth going there and seeing the palace and other buildings there and the fountain etc. But in comparison to Ekaterininsky Palace, this one looks more like a house lol. You can really feel the difference between a palace build for a man and a woman :D
Another must in St. Petersburg. I will not ell you, go for yourself and enjoy as much as I did!

Must visit when in St. Petersburg!. For us, this is the no. 1 attraction in St. Petersburg and is one of the 2 must visit places when in St. Petersburg. Also known as the "kingdom of fountains", the numerous golden statues and the grandeur of this place reminds us of the Palace de Versailles in France. One should have a complete half day to enjoy this place as it is also out of the city center.
Mind blowing!. So impressive! Loved all the gold statues and fountains, and inside was magnificent!

Go on an nice day - extensive grounds. We enjoyed walkking the well kept and extensive grounds - we didnt go inside the palace museum. The buildings, fountains and statues all around the grounds are attractive, but just spending a few hours on a nice day to walk around is the ideal way to enjoy this place. We went unguided, just bought a hyrdo-foil ticket outside the Hermitage (1000 R return each), about a half hour boat ride. The immediate palace area was crowded, but once you start wandering you get away from the crowds and its pleasant.
great half day tour.. you can take a cheap english tour in Nevsky Avenue. A wonderful exprience.

Fountains everywhere!. Well worth a visit we only did the gardens as the palace was very busy but there is so much to see outside it was still worth it. The fountains are spectacular and the garden is beautiful to stroll around in.The best way to get there from St Petersburg is to take the Hydrofoil from the Neva riverbank at the Hermitage.

spectacular Peterhof. what a wonderful place and if like us you are Icky enough to catch it on a sunny day you are in for one of life's highlight experiences. Need to be reasonably fit to cover it all but well worth it and best approached by hydrofoil.

Beautiful, even in the rain!. It was raining the day we visited, but the fountains were still awesome. The gardens were mostly a forrested area with small "destination spots" and each one was photo worthy. We ended our visit with a Hydrofoil ride back to St Petersburg, however because of the bad weather th windows were fogged and we had no view of the outside. This ride was the only part of the day that was a waste of money and time.
Magical Fountains. Spectacular - a top "must-do" in St Petersburg - recommend taking the hydrofoil for easy access.
Awsome Tour. Peterhof Palace and Gardends will be remembered as a beautiful memory

beautiful palace, fountains, gardens and greenhouse. Last May 29, my family of four (2 adults, 2 small children) got the Half Day tour (5 hours) of Peterhof or Petrodvorets. We were picked up at our hotel, Novotel, in St. Petersburg at 9 am and arrived Peterhof Palace after 1.5 hours.Our tour guide accompanied us inside the museum. Pictures were not allowed. Jackets and backpacks were requested to be deposited in designated areas free of charge. We had to wear cloth slippers over our shoes to protect the wooden parquet flooring.It is better to go to the water closet (WC) after the tour of the museum due to the volume of people in private tours and cruise shore excursions.After the museum, we went outside the balcony and got the best view of Peterhof fountains. We walked to the gardens and saw the greenhouse. Everything in the garden was beautiful (fountains, trees, flowers). We spent a total of 2 hours in Peterhof Palace and gardens.
Focus on the park. The bukdings are stunning; but if you've seen the Hermitage and Tsarkoe Salo, these are no different. But the park is amazing and worth the trip on its own.
gorgeous!!. peterhof was nowhere near as busy as catherine palace but, in my opinion, a bit more magnificent.
Superb.. We only visited the gardens but it was such a sunny warm day that to go into the Palace would have been a sin.
The glory and the golden history. Peterhof Palace is a legendary place to see and relax in .
Lovely. Tremendous territory with lots of flowers, green trees, water and sculptures. Beautiful Cathedral and brilliant castle!
bring a camera. one of the best examples of fountains and gardens ever
Peterhof. Spectacular. Gorgeous interior and fountains and garden spectacular
Absoutely Stunning. This is not to be missed. It is great to approach this in a hydrofoil. Try to go on a sunny day.

WOW. This place is just too wonderful. The fountains, the gardens, the history. You can get there by hydrofoil which avoids a boring sort of coach trip. It also helped you to appreciate the complexities of Peter the Great. Just do it!

Just fountains, no flowers, this is a Garden?. Gardens only 4 hour guided visit- 1 1/2 hours to drive there, 15 minutes comfort stop, 45 minutes breakneck rush to see all the fountains, hydrofoil back, waiting 30 minutes on boat for others to arrive, 30 minutes sea crossing, 30 minutes bus back to boat. Less than 20% of time actually in attraction.And it was cold, windy and trying to rain
Comparable to Other Great Palaces and Gardens. The gardens were planted with tulips although late in the season. So in addition to the beautiful fountains, the flowers were an added bonus.
Great gardens but also very nice interior of the house. We booked with hautnah tours and it was the best experience ever. Highly recommanded

Was lucky to be there on glorious sunny day. By all means pay the extra cost to visit the interior of the palace. In my opinion, the rooms here were more impressive than those at the Hermitage. Too bad the large tour groups sometimes made it hard to move about in narrow hallways. But it's not cheap: Separate tickets for hydrofoil from St. Petersburg, the garden grounds and the palace interior amounted to 2,000 rubles or about U.S. $62. But well worth it when you consider it's a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for most people.

Peterhof is magnificent!. We were awestruck by the opulent interiors and gorgeous fountains! Interior pictures were not allowed, so a collection of photo postcards was a worthwhile purchase, for me. Our guide, Kira, placed the rooms within historical context.
BEAUTIFUL EVEN IN THE RAIN!!. We traveled by Hydrofoil to this beautiful garden. Even in the rain and wind it was great- especially with our ALLA tour guide- Polina

Kudos for all the restoration!. It's definitely a must see! Make sure to bring a fan (it can get quite hot & stuffy if there are too many people). Bathrooms were clean and the flow here was much better controlled than at other venues that we were at.

Opening of the fountain. always a great time to walk along those fountain and park, was for the first time in the Bagna area.. to be visit definitively - amazing instalation made by Tsar for some treatment and fun probably.. enjoy

cruise excursion to Peterhof. Spectacular and ostentatious beauty viewed throughout the palace and gardens. The many colourful rooms displayed the very best that old Russia had to offer. Each room we viewed was unique in design, colour and furniture. Well worth the hour or so that we spent in there. There is a nice souvenir shop in the palace, as well a string of souvenir "shops" closer to the bus parking area located a few hundred feet from the main site.Blaring music marked the opening of the impressive garden fountains, which I managed to get photos of amongst the throng of people. Quite a bit of walking and some stairs involved during the tour. Not sure if wheelchair access is available. Negatives of this tour were the large number of visitors that made basic things like restroom visits and cloakroom checks an ordeal. The ladies on our tour bus had to wait 15 minutes in line for the WC.
Fabulous. stunning grounds and great fountains and trick rock streams!! the view of the baltic sea is great and you can see st peterburg from there too. Well worth a visit.

Peter the Great was a genius. This is a not be missed attraction.. Make sure to be there when the fountains are turned on. It is a huge spectacle again with the help of our guide, Sergey Fedorov, we found good vantage points for everything.. Wear comfortable shoes, as you will walk a lot on unpaved surfaces

The fountains were more magnificent than expected.. Take time and walk around to all the fountains. We took the Metro to the minibus that was waiting right outside the Metro. Ask your hotel staff as they are very helpful. This was an easy way to see this peaceful park and palace.

Worth the Trip. We are visiting our cousin and his family who are currently based in Moscow and we let them draft our itinerary for our trip. One of the things on the list is Peterhof Palace in St. Petersburg. They arranged for a taxi to pick us up from our hotel and take us there. It was a 40-minute drive from our hotel (Holiday Inn Moskovskiy). We arrived at about 10:20 a.m. and we realized it was perfect because they open the fountains at 11 a.m., so we were able to catch the spectacle. Then it was time for some decision-making. Tour the immense gardens or take a tour of the Grand Palace? We decided to tour the Grand Palace first. Not knowing any Russian and not having a local guide, we found it hard to figure out where to get tickets. This place has separate tickets for each museum in the complex (ticketing booths are situated near the museums). To get tickets for the Grand Palace, you need to get in line at the entrance of the palace. The ticket booths are inside. You can also rent equipment for an audio tour in English. The audio tour greatly helped us in making sense of all the rooms and exhibits in the palace. As we were coming out of the palace after our tour, we were surprised to see how long the line going to the palace has gotten in the hour or so that we were in there! It turned out that our decision to tour the palace first thing in the morning saved us a lot of precious time! We spent the rest of the day touring the gardens and taking pictures. Make sure you are wearing comfortable shoes --- the gardens are immense, but very beautiful! A leisurely pace is best to fully appreciate the wonders of the place. There are some trick fountains in the area and you may end up wet (not too pleasant in the cold), but it is a joy for the kids! Overall, it was wonderful and memorable. We can't stop looking at all the lovely pictures we took!
Peterhof Gardens and fountains. Everything is absulately whow!! The gardens and fountains is lovely. Lots of walking, but it was such a lovely day, that the walking was such a pleasure!

Ready to get wet?. We visited the Peterhof Palace and Garden on a beautiful sunny day. As you may know from other reviews, there are many fountains in the garden, including some 'tricky' ones that will splash water when you pass by. If you are ready to get wet, I think it would be fun to try some of these fountains.

Worth visiting. After over an hour by bus, we had to line up another hour because of the long lines of people who also wish to go inside. Before going in we were made to wear covers for our shoes so as not to damage the wooden floors. All the waiting was worth it after seeing the various rooms where Peter the Great loved to stay. The gardens outside were also beautiful and amazing that the many fountains are all gravity fed and water flows without a single pump.
good. lovely gardens and fountains, go there by hydrofoil on a nice day,

Only go there if u have a lot of time, a lot of patience and you know Russian (at least the history). Yes it is beautiful, the gardens are lovely the fountains are lovely, the palace and churches are beautiful BUT if you go there on your own (not with a tour/ tour guide) you may have to put most of the stars off the site. Getting a boat ticket is already not easy (people keep on pushing you from the back), getting on the hydrofoil is also not easy as there is literately nothing called "quene". The boat is around 30min.... Once you got your entrance ticket, you then realize that is not an all-u-can-eat-ticket. The site is under a pay-as-u-go ticket system ie wherever you go you still need another ticket, without any knowledge of Russian you probably dont know until you got rejected at the entrance.... If you are visiting the palace, be prepared to hear something like “Go, DON’T STOP, Go” in a really rough tone - unfriendly staff. I heard someone asked the “babushka” (the palace “guard”) why they then tell you something like “climate control”. Apparently some of the rooms are so nicely decorated with wood panels and that any breathing may cause treasures to get rotten!!??.... No English sign/ interpretation, you are on your own...Buy a little guide book on the boat (they have also a small booklet in English for 100p, or better, get it at the bookstore (Singer House on the Nevsky Prospekt) before your trip, half of that price.
Peterhof. Visited on the weekend that was also city's anniversary. Tens of thousands of blooming tulips and the fountains are incredible

Lovely Gardens. We spent the afternoon walking the grounds of Peterhof. We did not go inside the Palace due to time restraints. But, the gardens were absolutely gorgeous. Do not miss seeing this sight! Donna N
Paradise. The fountains and gardens are amazing, the palace is beatuiful
Beautiful. Mgical like a fairytale, its importand that the weather is nice. A lot of tourists though.
Breathtakingly Beautiful. I had thought Versailles was magnificent until i saw the fountains at this place...overwhelmingly stunning...wow!

gardens gardens. we visited only the gardend its funny to say onle, because its so big, and we visited also the upper gardend, and decided not to enter the palace - too much! you can not absorb so much in one visit!

A Palace and its Fountains. The best display of a palace amidst a cascade of enormous fountains.This is another building to depict the time of Peter the Great. It is lush grounds with large flower beds, all designed by master landscapers that captured our vision. Each garden has a name anywhere from Venus to Baccus. This site is about 30 - 45 mins by hydrofoil from the Hermitage in St Petersurg. In the park there is a minature of the whole grounds and palaces. Inside the mansion there is a display of antiques etc. nothing for us to compare to the outside grounds where we spent most of our time.
If you wish to have it as a modell for your own cottage, then you must see it !. Far away from the city centrum but worth to see. Allmost a allday visit ?
Really beautiful summer home. The historical protocol from before meeting the Emperor to dining and the bedroom set up of the emperor.
breath taking.. be there for when the fountain turn on. truely amazing. especially when you think it is all done with no electric. the fountains were years ahead of their time.

Visited the gardens and fountains. This was one of our favorite stops on our whirlwind tour of St. Petersburg. We visited the outside gardens and fountains. The gardens is a huge, park like setting. We were fortunate to visit on a clear blue day. You can walk through the gardens to the water and take a hydrofoil straight to the Hermitage/Winter Palace

Must be seen. You cannot miss this if you go to St Petersburg. We took the hydrofoil from the river bank crossing the street from the Hermitage. You pay cash (so do have cash with you otherwise the cash point is 15 mins away from the pier) and it takes you 40 mins to arrive there. Upon arrival you will have to pay again for entering the park and again for entering the palace.
My favorite.. Well worth the time to get there! Breathtaking fountains, wish we had more time to walk the grounds

Fountains were just opened when we were there.. We were fortunate to visit on the 1st day of the fountains for this year. The grounds of the Palace are beautiful and the fountains unlike any I have seen anywhere else. Fountains are trees, ducks, dragons ... everything imagineable. Beautiful, peaceful setting.

Breathtaking. We were in St Peter during four days of clear skies and sun and the experience of visiting the gardens is one of a kind.
Be sure to arrive before 11:00 o clock to see the fountains with music
amazing. lots to see. take some euros for the toilet. easy walking. video and camers

A must see place. The palace itself is beautiful and intimate. It is rather warm inside as the large group moved slowly. But the garden is magnificent. An excellent place to stroll to breath in the Baltic air and take photos with more than 100 fountains.

Not to miss.... You can easily spend a day in Petergoff. The place is magnificent especially when fountains are working. There are english tours leave from Nevsky daily offered by the Eccelectica Tours - very good price too (http://www.eclectica-guide.ru/rec/rec.php). The tours are done by minivan 8-10 people max. The quility is very good.
A must see. Absolutely amazing palace and grounds. Do not miss this while you are in St. Petersburg
Beautiful place. It's a huge space, very organized, clean with beautiful architeture.
Great place but closed. I think it's a great place but the main Palace was closed. Not that anyone could tell you why
Terrific fountains. The fountains of Peterhof are amazingly beautiful but I'm not sure it's worth the visit unless you are in SPB for at least 3 days

great place for walks in the summer. A unique palace and park reserve on the Gulf of Finland. You can say a lot about this wonderful place, but its worth a visit and see. Be sure to visit: The Grand Palace, Grand Cascade Caves, Lower Park, ekaterinsky case. You can get on a boat mereor.

Zar's luxury. Beautiful palace,. Senior guides are horrible, bad behaviour. unless they change it's way to deal with tourists no one will be back. They got angry even if you stop 1 minute to see something in detail becuase you "stop" her route

Beautiful despite of winter, hope to come back on summer. Known as the summer palace of Peter the great, and recognised as a world heritage by UNESCO, this palace and its gardens are beautiful!!.We went during winter, and the fountains were not working. For this reason the entrance to the gardens was free. The interiors of the palace are beautiful, very similar to those from the Catherine's Palace. They are fully restored not only with russian style, but including chinese and french style. It is like seeing everything new with the splendor of past times. i hope to come back some day and visit this place during summer. I imagine that you will need more time to spend in the gardens, probably, but I think it is worth.We went there on our own. We were afraid that we were going to be lost. But at the end it was very easy to get there: Take de Line 1 of the subway towards AVTOVO, when you get there get out from the station and in front of the building take a shared taxi (# K224 or others) to Peterhof (60 RUB per person). The driver would tell you where to get off. The whole trip from the city centre last 1,5 hours.

A must during the summer. It's like a well preserved time capsule of old european-style royal gardens. With gold leafed fountains and amazing sculptures. On a hot summer day, with fountains in full swing it is very refreshing and relaxing.

LOVE IT. No words to describe the beauty of the Palace and its gardens. For me that's definitely in TOP-10 visited sites globally and TOP-3 in Europe. It was heavily bombed in WW2 so not all the garden is restored but good enough to have fun. It's also amazing for children. Fountains are open from around May to September. You can go there by train, bus and boat. I'd recommend the boat at least one-way. Bus (unless it's tour one) and train - for those who either know Russian or familiar with Russian transport system.

Wonderful French-style garden. Peterhof Lower garden is really a gem of St.Petersburg. The garden is currently in a very good shape. Western part is now being restored. Fountains are quite impressive, shining with gold and sparkling with water. This is a place not to miss on a visit to SPB. But plan for at least 2 days - just the garden will take half a day, and palaces are also worth seeing. There are many of them, but each has a long line of visitors, so be prepared.Upper garden is not in a very good state, so you can safely omit it from the visit schedule. With that decision, the best way to arrive is by hydrofoil departing from embankment across Exchange (Birja) building. Return the same way. After 14:30 tickets are discounted by 100 RUR each (regular price is 500).Peterhof offers also magnificent views of Finnish Bay and the city across the bay.
Splendid. We had never seen anything like this marvellous palace and its fine gardens. You do need a guide to explain things to you if you cannot read Russian.
Stunning on a sunny day. The grounds are vast, the fountains numerous and varied and the views spectacular.

Most exceptional palace outside of Versailles in the world. On a warm and sunny day when the golden gilded statues in the gardens will be shimmering, one can not help but be awestruck by the magnificence of the gardens alone. If you like gardens, now is the time to see the tulip beds crowned in Red. The cascading waterfall leading into the bay of Finland are very impressive. The gilded multi-turreted buildings in typical russian style are not to be missed. You can get there by communal taxi or by waterboat from downtown St-petersburg. This sight is not to be missed.

Versailles on the sea. The fountains are great...don't get wet and surprised by? The small palace right on the bay tells a great story. The interior is OK and the Amber room is fine but somehow a little disappointing
Tsarist exuberance. After looking at these elaborate grounds It is easy to see why the peasants revolted
What a sight. It is absolutely gorgeous. The gardens are amazing. The food and service are bad.
beautiful park and palaces. choose a sunny day, wear comfy shoes :) great way to get there is a meteor boat ride. 40-50 min from the center of St. Petersburg.
A must visit. Due to the time of year the palace was probably not at it's best but is well worth a visit, pure opulence! One down side the audio guide is expensive.
breathtaking. Must see for everyone travelling to Russia! The fountains and gardens are so beautiful.

Avoid in the Winters. My biggest mistake was to visit this place in the winters. I can only imagine how pretty it must be in the summers but that is where my satisfaction with the place ends.Cold, wet and windy is how I will remember the place. Though there were a lot of tourists I am not sure how many were awestruck since the fountains were not working and the trees were covered.So if you do go, it MUST be in the summers.
Peterhoff Palace. The fountains were amazing, but the weather did not co-operate for us. It is amazing what was built so many years ago.
A lovely day in the Country!. A historical tour of epic proportions. Absolutely breathtaking.

What a beautiful place!. The only dislike was the poor system to enter the palace with confusion reigning over ticketing and the cloak room. We ended up queuing for awhile and then being told we were in the wrong spot (along with about 20 other travellers, Russian speaking amongst them). We ditched the idea, and just enjoyed the gardens, and we're not disappointed with this decision. The boat trip out there is great too! Definitely worth allocating a day to go out here.

Petrodvorets. Irina, my Russian friend in Miami, recommended I visit Petrodvorets outside Saint Petersburg. So I rode the Metro (subway) for twenty minutes and then hopped a mini-van for a thirty minute ride west of the city.Peter the Great (1682 – 1725) built a home here on the shores of the Gulf of Finland to oversee the construction of his naval base. Eventually the area was developed with gracious white palaces, sculpted gardens, a series of dancing fountains and energetic cascades.Also called Peterhof, most of the original area was destroyed by both the Soviets and the Nazis. But the reconstruction is splendid. The weather is fine for my stroll and everyone is in a cheerful mood. I meet dozens and dozens of visitors - a lady from Uzbekistan dressed in native attire, a group from Brazil – the guide holding the familiar green flag, a few delightful local high school kids, and the ubiquitous camera carrying, fast afoot East Asians. At one spot, three Asian girls are posing for photos. I hear “Neung, song, sam!” This is the unmistakable “One, two, three” in Thai. Naturally, I stop for a chat. With my broken Thai, and their excellent English, I learn that two of the girls are visiting a friend who is a university student here. The best event of the day was a musical surprise. On one of the garden paths, I encountered three Russian men and their percussion orchestra: xylophone, marimba, vibraphone. No Russian folk songs or jolly dances for these guys. It was all Vivaldi (Four Seasons), Bach (Toccata and Fugue) and Chopin (Nocturnes)! The lead player took the melodies, including all the grace notes and arpeggios. The second man added the base chords and the harmony. The third musician provided the tremolos and rhythms. The grand garden setting and the flow of the music was velvety and beguiling.For my final stop, just across the road from the entrance to the park, is the early Twentieth Century SS Peter and Paul Cathedral. The multi-colored brick exterior and the somber interior of the church lends a spiritual contrast to the splendor and extravagance of the Petrodvorits palaces.

In spite of a wet end of Spring weather, I really enjoyed the day and the visit. It started early (opening) with a speed boat which took us from the embankment close to the Hermitage to Petershof palace. During the trip I prepared the visit with my guide,a experienced multi lingual Russian old lady I had hired through the Concierge of Kempisky . The hydrofoil trip was already a discovery and a fast and comfortable way to reach the place and be really concentrated on the subject : you have only one beautiful place to visit and discover.It is well organized and from the river you discover the Palace as well as its garden. It was not crowded and we could take the time to visit all the building and discover all the collections, walking in a beautiful garden from the palace, to pavilions, or chapels. It is impressive and I really enjoyed the company of the guide who really loved this place and knew about History and the side stories and also who could open, thanks to its accreditation, all the doors and all collections which were not all opened . In some parts of the palace it was as a private visit thanks to the guide.Taking our time and getting all the explanations, it took us nearly a whole day we stopped to have a light lunch (fast & efficient - reasonably priced) .It is not Versailles but on many a point it looks like and even some name are decisively French and related to Versailles. In fact it could also have been called Louishof..By the end of the visit we had some Sun and the view was even better and the trip back to St Petersburg a good way to keep an excellent souvenir of this visit.
must see. I took a mini bus trip from st. pet with a very nice and funny woman guide. a lot of good information, beautiful gardens. amazing palace.
Capital of fountains. A must to see in summer. A "million" of fountains, a place more beautiful then Versalle.

Pleasant day suburb trip. There are so many palaces to visit in Russia, it is hard to pin down which ones to visit with so little time on hand. We picked Peterhof in the end as it was recommended by a Russian and also it provides an opportunity for us to see beyond the city. We took a ferry to Peterhof and did enjoy our time there as the gardens are beautiful. The palace is very crowded so it leaves us with very little time and space to appreciate it. Have to be careful about which exit you took as the guards may not allow you in once you are out. Try another entrance if you are refused entry. The fountains are beautiful. The gardens is a must for exploration as there are a number of naughty hidden-staff who will 'shoot' water at you when you are engrossed in some exhibit in the gardens. Bring an umbrella as the weather at this place is very unpredictable. When it rains, it is really cold. Do remember to watch your timing for the last ferry back.
Beautiful!. Perhaps we expected more, but it is indeed very impressive

summer delight. In summer only, as winter too bleak and freezing and no water transport, the palace is magnificent with ornate buildings, well laid out gardens, fountains and an ambiance that defies description albeit to say that it is serene, calming and a throw back to times of opulence that you can relive
Fabulous day out. Grandeur & splendour is all around. Enjoy the "improved" version of Versalies! Worthy experience & huge park!
Going there in summer is a must for anyone coming to St.Petersburg. Going there in summer is a must for anyone coming to St.Petersburg

If you thought the Hermitage was great....don't miss this.. Only about 40 minutes by metro and minibus from St. Petersburg, the palace and gardens of Peterhof are a must see. The cascading fountains are a marvel and if the sun is shining, the reflections from the gold statues are dazzling. The sea channel leads you to the Baltic where you can catch a boat back to town. Wandering through the gardens is a delight and watch out for the water surprise if you venture too close to what seems to be a beckoning bench!Yes the Hermitage has it's deserved reputation, but the trip to Peterhof will have you in awe for days.

Just Stunning. It is the most amazing place, unfortunately we didn't see inside the palace but the gardens are something out of a fairytale. It is impossible to put into words the magnificence of the design, the statues, the gold. There are secret gardens and trick water fountains that surprised the children with sprays of water when they walked by. They loved exploring the massive grounds.

Beautiful. The bus ride is interesting on its own as you get to see many levels of russian living. The grounds are beautiful and the tour of the palace is very interesting but the shear number of tours going through is annoying as everyone talking makes it challenging to hear the tour guide. Enjoy the russian experience and get a BBQ'ed shish kabob and a beer at the food kiosk by the bus parking area.

Any visit to SPB is incomplete without visiting the wonderful Peterhof. it's a slightly out of town but definitely worth visiting if you have the time. Most wonderful gardens and architecture. Try not to take the ferry from the centre of town and instead go by mini-bus; you will save a good bit of money!

A palace to see either in the winter or summer. Quite spectacular. There was a lot of snow so we did not see the fountains but the view of the baltic frozen and all the different buildings in the park provided a rich experience to see so much guilded rooms.
Palace and Gardens must see. The Palace is very Grand with art work and decor. The Palace is full of Mirrored walls, you must take a walk through the grounds its so beautiful
Beautifull. No other words can describe this building or its contents. You will not have enough time to explore this beautifull Palace.

All that glitters is gold. This palace is a marvellous day trip by hydrofoil from St Petersburg. The gardens leading to the Gulf of Finland rival Versailles. This palace needs a full day to do it justice.

jawdropping. Because of the rain we took a bus instead of the hydrofoil to get here.This place was fabulous even in the rain,the statures of gold ,the fountains ,canals and the palaces.Our tour guide did not have passes to any buildings,only to the grounds . We ate at the overpriced cafeteria(the food was below average). My favorite attraction in St. Petes.

What a spectacular display!. We were in awe of the fountains and--more interesting--the technology behind them. It's hard to believe that the fountains are driven solely by gravity-induced water pressure.
Awesome. Try to go on a sunny day and the beauty of the fountains will exceed your expectations. Do not forget to visit "The Special Treasury" museum.

100% must see for all St.-Petersburg visitors. 100% must see for all St.-Petersburg visitors. The architecture is perfect, recently renovated. Park is accurate and nice. There are a lot of books and brochures describing this place - but forget it - just visit.

Fantastic. This is a must-see when visiting St Petersburg. The highlight here is the gardens and fountains; we chose to skip the palace itself. The fountains are a great achievement of engineering, and the variety and extensiveness of the grounds are very impressive. A visit here gives you a good look at Peter the Great's ideas and grand plans for Russia during this period of history. You could spend a short time here just admiring the main fountain, or spend an entire afternoon strolling through the gardens and enjoying the view. While it's comparable to other royal European palaces, the natural plantings and quirkiness of some of the features make it very unique.We hired a private guide for the day who gave us detailed history (and lots of details about the ever-present symbolism) and allowed us to avoid the lines wherever we went.

A panageric to absolute power and wealth. We went for a half day tour to these magnificent Gardens and Palace though we didn;t have time to enter the Palace. The Gardens are magnificent with 4000 acres to see. There are statues arboretums, themed areas, trick fountains, sea views, a canal, magnificent terraces, dwellings not to mention a wonderful entrance fronted by a small palace, bridges. The palace resembles Sans Soucci Palace in Potsdam but everything in Russia is on a grand scale with all the extravagant detail you see in Russian palaces.I have a disability but the wheel chair toilet had no facilities. I had a frame so did not have to call for help.The trick fountains were fun and if you had children this provides a distraction. The canal was built by Peter so guests could arrive straight under the palace. We had an excellent tour company and guide that explained the quirky History

Gorgeous, definitely Paris of the East". Gardens and fountains are jaw dropping beauty. The palace is unbelieveable in antiques and its better than any museum in the west. This is a must see for any visitor to St. Petersburgs.

A must see. The second time I've been to this place, it is absolutely fabulous. Make sure you have your camera with you, the fountains and palaces are just stunning. The main fountain show starts usually at 11 am, there are a lot of people around, but it is worth seing. The easiest way to get there is by speed boat, but if you have a few people going (we were 5) it is cheaper by a cab, just make sure you ask the dispatcher what is the price going to be over the phone otherwise a cabby can be too gready.Not too many food options and the quality is not the greatest, so if you are picky,just take a snack with you, the are plenty of spots there for a picknick.If you have small kids with you, you might want to take spare cloths for them, as there are a couple of fountains were kids like to get wet.

Best of all the St Petersburg palaces. A short distance out of St Petersburg but definitively worth the effort by car or boat. The palace is incredible, make sure you visit the Treasury the highlight for us - not so over done. The gardens & fountains are really beautiful

For me this is the #1 must-see in St. Petersburg. Peterhof is just stunning! The palace is immaculatley reconstructed since World War II. this is among the most amazing places I've seen... The decadance isup there with St. Peters Basillica... OK, maybe there's not quite as much gold arouns the place, but it's still stunning! The gardens and fountains are also not to be missed... Make suer to travel by hydrofoil from St. Petersburg (the port is behind the Hermitage).
must see. It's a great place and you must see it. It's much better (larger and nicer) than similar places in Europe.Logistics there is badly organized, including lines, food, restrooms, etc.

Worth the trip. A chance to get to the country and enjoy an amazing display of waterworks and gardens. I did not pay the extra admission to see the insides of the palaces. The cost was high and the lines were discouraging. Strolling the grounds and taking photos was very satisfactory.

Peterhof Palace. A beautiful palace with magnificant gardens which we visited on a beautiful sunny day. Can have very long queues for admission late morning, & into the afternoon. The rooms were magnificant with a beautiful staircase. The gold domes looked fabulous in the sunshine!

One of the major palaces of the Tsars. Not to be missed, this is one of the great palaces of the Tsars and an integral part of Russian history. We were fortunate to travel to St Petersburg in December, at Christmas time, when there are few tourists. We had a private guide and basically had the palace to ourselves as most of the rooms were empty except for us. The quality of the restoration is exceptional.
The must place to visit. Lovely tourist site with very chilling atmosphere. The grand palace is great and the garden is very beautiful with cozy atmosphere.
Beautiful!. Must get a ticket to see the grotto, not many people know about them, they are under the fountains!

Really worth to be visited. You will need 3-4 hours to enjoy many beautiful corners of this museum in a park. The best way to get Peterhof by the boat from Winter Palace area, the trip is very enjoyable ant not expensive. It's good to came in a morning and witness the moment when all fountains start to operate at 10am
Russian Versailles. Splendid in summer, don't waste your time for ueues for the palace, just walk in the park, which is awesone
Nice place by speed boat. Have enough time and choose sunny day for it....also history of the this place very interresting....so go to guided tour

Spledid Place. We were very fortnate that the guide had permission to take us on a Monday, the place was closed to the large public, so we had the palace nearly to yourselfs, the gides even helped to carry up the wheelchair, and we were permitted to cruise through the estate
Good gardens and views. I did not go inside the palace but the gardens are defenatly worth a walk

An Expensive Activity. The grounds are spectacular.The cost of visting the Grand Palace was too high(I paid 350 Rubles-only occupied 2 hours of my time-no information in the palace in English).The audio guides in English were an extra 500 Rubles.I felt their staff rushed me.On the positive side,fine Baroque paintings by Pietro Rotari and Jan Hackert;great decorative art.

Gorgeous statues, a really lovely day. We visited in May 2011. It was truly a highlight of our trip to St Petersburg. Luckily it was a sunny day so the statues looked amazing as they reflected the sunlight.It was very busy so I would recommend to visit as early as possible.We travelled via hydrofoil which was a good option. The one downside was when we bought a drink from a bar in the gardens we got ripped off, we were able to read the Russian alphabet and knew what price we should pay but they charged us extra, it was not worth trying to argue as clearly we could not speak Russian!I would highly recommend a visit to the Peterhof, we did not go into the palace but just thoroughly enjoyed walking the gardens taking photos, it was truly a lovely day.

Beautiful. Very beautiful. Try to go on a sunny day though--much nicer. Tip on getting there. Do not take train, bus, or car. Take a boat from Hermitage straight to the Park entrance. Much faster than going by land. If your tour agency insists on you taking their bus or car there, they are trying to cheat. You will pay extra for car and driver and spend more time in traffic. NOBODY goes there by land if navigation is open.

Amazing!! A must see!!. Peterhof is absolutely stunning. I had thought that nothing could equal Versailles, but, in my humble opinion, Peterhof does! We booked our 2 day shore excursion through Allatours and we took a hydrafoil over from SPB to Peterhof. I will post photos soon.
Skip the Palace -- Walk the Gardens and Grounds. No need to go inside -- far too much to see and enjoy outside -- the fabulous fountains, wonderful gardens, etc.
Meticulous re-construction.. The workmanship that has gone into re-constructing this palace is amazing, but why use pozidrive screws?
Beautiful gardens.. Beautiful Gardens and Waterfalls, everything was so manicured and lush. Just walked around and admired the growth, even recognizing a lot from home.
Amazing palace and place. Great palace, gardens and situation on the Baltic Sea. Even though the fountains were turned off for winter the gardens were lovely to walk in.

Must see in St. Petersburg!. I would give this place beyond excellent. This would be my one must see place in St Petersburg! The gardens and fountains are just indescribably impressive and beautiful. It is just amazing! Go!!

don't miss it!. If you have time for only one excursion outside of the city itself, this is the place to go. An incredibly pleasant hydrofoil ride takes you directly to the palace gates, where a leisurely visit is rewarded by astonishingly beautiful sights both inside the buildings as well as around the expansive grounds. A few caveats: this is an expensive day where everywhere one turns there is an additional admission charge, hardly anything is clearly marked in English, rather few persons in the ticket booths speak enough English to make it clear what is covered, and service in the palace restaurant can be spectacularly rude.

Absolutely Amazing. This is one of the most amazing places I have ever seen in my life. The building themselves are a spectacular sight to see, but the fountains are just spectacular, Thankfully we visited before they shut the fountains down for the winter, it would have been a huge disappointment to miss Peterhof. We only set aside a half day to visit Peterhof, and I wish we had spent the whole day. Hopefully the distance from St Petersburg does not disuade anyone from visiting here, it is defintely "the" favorite site from our trip.
Peterhoff. Fountains are beautiful but I did not pay extra to go inside. I figured it would be about the same as the Hermitage or Versailles in paris

Possibly one of my most favourite places in the world.. This is an absolutely amazing island of royal mansions, gardens and fountains. I visited it several times and would like to go several more. Best time to go is summer because most of it's splendor is outdoors, even that the interiors and museums are equally breathtaking. It's a day trip. Very highly recommended.
Incomparable. Make sure you see the fountains come on; also, leave enough time to walk the entire grounds.

A total knockout. We went to Peterhof as an optional excursion on a tour, purely because if we had not we would have had nothing to do that day.If we had not made that decision we would have missed possibly one of the world's most spectacular Palaces and its outstanding gardens and fountain system.This place is absolutely perfect and deserves more time than an excursion allows (about 2 1/2 hours) This is an attraction where a full day at least could be enjoyed strolling through the magnificent gardens after having been through the Palace and enjoyed the oppulance which was the Peter the Great's era. The Amber Room, the ceilings and floors of any room, the main stair case, the Throne Room are all masterpieces in their own right.Whatever you do, if in St Petersburg, do not pass up a visit to Peterhof on any account. That we almost missed it would have been an absolute crime

The most beautiful group of statues and water fountains we have ever seen. The visit to Peterhof is a must. You arrive by boat o the pier and begin by the garden and the canal views. As you get closer to the palace you begin to see the sophisticated fountains and the magnificent statues. Only these would justify the visit but you still have the palaces and the gardens...
The fountains are amazing!. Visit this palace not just to see the rooms, but also the fountains. They are amazing. Unfortunately you can't take any pictures inside.

Beautiful Grounds. This Palace is a short distance from St. Petersburg by boat. However, be aware that you will need to take a bus on the way back. This bus will take you to a subway station and you will need to connect to another subway to get back to St. Petersburg (depending on where you are staying in St. Perters). However, it is worth a visit. It is an absolutely amazing palace and the grounds are just gorgeous! The gardens, fountains, restaurant, etc are all so beautiful! The site is also very clean and well maintained. It is a very big site, but every step of it is enjoyable! If you have a student ID, you get cheaper tickets all over Russia, and this place is not exception.

Beautiful. We saw the gardens but in brilliant sunshine in autumn. the colours were amazing and the yellow gold leaves accentuated the opulence of the gold fountain statues. It may be the best time to visit because the crowds were still big even out of the main tourist season.
Spectacular fountains. Had read about the fountains at Peterhof. We took the hydrafoil from the Hermitage, quick and very reasonable price. The fountains are absolutely amazing. Don;t miss them!

Loads of fountains!. Only had an afternoon here, so only did the gardens, they are fabulous, fountains etc galore, very spectacular. No English menus in the cafe though, thankfully my colleague spoke Russian

Well worth a visit to the park. There's no need to add much to what other reviewers have said about Peterhof. It's well worth a visit. Go by hydrofoil (half-hour each way) and be sure to get a return ticket. From what everyone says, there is no need to visit the palace, but the grounds with all their fantastic gravity-fed fountains are well worth just wandering around in for as much or as little time as you like. You can easily do this on your own. No need for a guide or tour.

A must see. The gardens and fountains are impressive. There are about 150 fountains so be prepared to walk a lot. There is also the small palace of Peter the Great who lived with his second wife in quiet comfort while the larger palace was built. Go early because in late afternoon the fountains are turned off in preparation for closing. You'll also have to walk a gauntlet of souvenier booths all of which appear to sell the same things.

Beautiful oppulence. The fountains in the vast gardens of this sumptuous palace live up to the hype - they are truly outstanding. Go on a warm day and plan to spend the whole day here wandering the gardens. But be warned the additional attractions cost extra and the restaurants can eat your arm for payment - take your own food or use the hot-dog style kiosks.TIP: Catch the fast boat from Dvortsovy bridge next to the Hermitage. It will save you time and a lot of hassle as it drops you right at the front door so you arrive, just as the Tsar and guests arrive!

most beautiful garden axis in the world. The palace is beautiful and luxurious and its interiors resemble those of Catherine the Great's Palace in Tsarskoye Selo.But truly breathtaking is the central axis of the palace gardens,comprising a beautiful channel (dug on the orders of Peter the Great,who used to come,from St Petersburg, by sea, and wanted to arrive by boat directly into the palace ) surrounded by fountains,gold plated beautiful statues and gold plated Empire-style superb vases. This bunch of luxury masterpieces is typical of the Russian Czars and is unique and most beautiful in the world.The gardens of Versailles are also breathtaking but less luxurious than those of Petrodvorets. The Russian Czars were richer than the kings of Europe and,therefore, their palaces and gardens are more luxurious - and ... most beautiful in the world.

Peterhof very worthwhile. We took the metro to Atovo and then Marushtka 224 right to the gates of Peterhof. It was only 21 doubles for the bus and the ride there was interesting. The gardens and fountains at Peterhof are relaxing and beautiful.

An engineering marvel. The fountains at the Peterhof Palace must be seen to be appreciated. And the fact that the water is propelled by gravity alone, no pumps makes them particularly amazing. We only had time to see see the Lower Garden and to walk around the outside of the palace. Bring your walking shoes and be prepared to get a little wet. There are many features nestled in the wooded acreage. Look up to admire the copper and guilt roof. If you tour the inside of the palace as well plan to spend the day.

Wow! Absolutely awesome. We had gone to Catherines Palace and Pavlovsk Palace the day before, so I was burned out on Baroque architecture. However, the interior of the palace was impressive. It was restored after the Nazis destroyed it when they retreated from Leningrad in January 1944 and there are pictures of the damage and the restoration. The furnishings, by and large, are original since the curators evacuated them in the retreat in 1941. Some of the larger statues and parts of the wall are original and our guide pointed them out to us. To me, the most impressive part of the palace was the lower gardens. The Grand Cascade was absolutely over the top. The rest of the gardens were impressive, with trick fountains and pavillions, an avairy, statues, etc.

A Must-See Attraction. This is one of the major historic sites. Well-worth the visit. The gardens are absolutely beautiful! Relive the history as you walk through the palace. Tip: Go with a tour guide who can explain the significance of the artifacts.

Well Worth a Visit, Tedious Logistics. Nice park, with a very ornate and well-restored Grand Palace.A number of factors make this an experience that is less than five stars. One is the lack of modern tourist management. Getting into the Grand Palace involved some 45 minutes of queuing, and tour groups kept jumping the queue. On the inside it was extremely crowded, so viewing the rooms at leisure was impossible. Some ropes for the queues and capacity/time management by selling tickets for given time slots (perhaps on the Internet, in advance) would help a lot.Furthermore, every single attraction in the park (there are many) requires a separate ticket, and one quickly feels nickled and dimed.

beautiful trip, relaxe outside of Piter as a beak in your city trip. The Peterhof gardens are well maintained, we were really impressed by their beauty. There's a lot to see there as well, unfortunately all information is in Russian, so you don't really know what you see. A must-see if visiting Piter, and a nice trip out of town, fresh air, the sea the sun... absolutely recommended!

Worth the visit.. We only visited the gardens, but - they are magnificent and a great trip out of the city. We took a metro and minibus (404) to the site, which is a significant saving on the hydrofoil price. This jounery doesn't take that much longer and after dropping you off, you get to see the Upper Gardens plus you will see the great Peter & Paul Cathedral along the main road - this is an unexpected, brilliant Cathedral which you should visit.

Splendid gardens and fountains. The place is easily reached by hydrofoil from the town centre, and once you get there take 2-3 hours strolling through the park scattered with all kinds of golden-glittering fountains. Back to town by maschrutka will make it a special outing all-round.

So beautiful!. Peterhof is really beautifull and wonderful, to see it with "the right eyes" we must be there at least a day to see eveything well. It is very well preserverved the palace or the gardens. If we are coming from the city of St. Petersburg by hydrofoil be carefull because not always the firm/company of the hydrofoil ensures the return. It happened with us, so we decided to request the services of a hotel tour guide. Was nice because we had a taxi only for us, but of course was more expensive, on other hand we did not care with buying tickets and we had a nice guide, although we could not stay all the day and it a pitty because in Peterhof you need time to see and live the experience.When we see Palace of Versalhes or Palace of Herrenchiemsee (a "copy" of Versalhes) we can not say that we have seen the most beautifull barroc palaces.

Do not miss. If you go to St. petersburg this is a "must do" my recommendation, take the hydrofoil one way and go back to the city in a bus or collective van so you can experience riding with Russians, they are kind and helpful and it's more fun.The Palace is very nice, the gardens and fountains beautiful, I liked the fountains even more than Versailles, so do not miss it. Audioguides in English. Go early to have more time and it's not so crowded.

Palace shut on Mondays. The Monday closing of the Palace 'for cleaning' was not in any literature but was also ignored if you were on a cruise. The gardens are simply amazing however - take a picnice and go to the far west of the gardens to enjoy a beautiful view across the Gulf of Finland enjoying your lunch away from the mega-crowds

Not to miss. The Peterhof gardens is a must-see. It will take most of a day, but is definitely worth it. The gardens are much more impressive than for example the Versailles gardens. I would only skip this if you only have a very limited time in St Petersburg, or if the weather is poor. You have to pay separately for the palace and the aviary, but we were happy just to stroll the gardens.We went by speedboat, which was very convenient. One-way with Peterhof Express was 500 rbl, return trip 800 rbl, and takes 45 minutes. You have to decide at what time to return when buying the two-way ticket. The Peterhof Express boats leave to the left of the bridge by the Hermitage. There are other companies too, not sure where they are located.

Excellent day out with splendour of Russian artefacts. We did a guided tour as part of a group tour. Amazing inside and fabulous gardens outside. Unlike the Hermitage you can't take photos inside. On a day with nice weather you could probably spend longer than 3 hours.

Phenomenal. It takes about an hour drive from the city St. Petersburg but well worth the trip. The grounds are spectacular to wander through. The main place is huge and then 20 smaller pavilions and palaces to see as well as 174 fountains. the Samson fountain is awesome, gold gilded. The view is out to sea. Catherine's Block is a Palace in itself. Whoever came to visit new who was in power. There was no shortage of cash spent for the Summer Palace and grounds.We took a tour by Den Rus out of St. Petersburg, awesome!!

Peterhof 07/2011. have visited Peterhof in St. Petersburg as part of the land excursion program of a Costa baltic sea cruise. It all depends on the tour guide. We had young lady teacher with extraordiunary historical knowledge, so the visit went very well. It was very hot that day and waiting outside in the sun was uncomfortable, but many groups ahead. Place is completely restored and shows the wealth of the zars and unfortunately the moneay which was pressed out of the ordinary people to pay for that. We also visited the park and the dutch building at the seashore. Spend about 2,5 hours there. It is really worth while to visit, was very pleased.

Beautiful Gardens, Well-done Restoration, A Bit Expensive, How About Transportation?. We spend half a day in the beautiful gardens, listening to sounds of water flowing and to the live baroque or xylophone music played by musicians. Didn't go inside the palace since the gardens were so relaxing and attractive.Restoration is well done, the main fountains flow into the sea which is interesting to see. Peterhof is of some distance to St.Petersburg. There are ferries from across the Hermitage to Peterhof but we were 4 people and rented a car with a driver to go to Peterhof, which was almost the same price with the ferry. Also the ferry leaves you quite below the gardens and it's a bit of a walk. Keep that in mind. We've heard there's a bus too but didn't risk since we had little time.

Magnificent and a great perspective on Tsar life/wealth; hiring a guide is necessary. The sheer opulence of Peterhof is overwhelming! From the beautiful natural fountains to awe-inspiring, extravagant interiors, it is a sight to see! You will realize why there was a revolution upon seeing the displays of Tsar wealth at Peterhof. While I don't think it is quite as extravagant as the Winter Palace in the city center, it is worth venturing out for. To enter, you must have a guide, which you will understand upon arrival. There are slews of guided tours in the palace and it's pretty much impossible to get in without your own guide. Further, nothing is labeled, in Russian or English, so you won't understand or learn anything without a guide. We hired a personal guide and driver for a full day tour of both Peterhof and Catherine the Great's palace. It was pricey (~$475 for two people), but that included entrance fees, guide and driver and we felt we got a lot out of the personal tour. If you're looking for a private tour, I'd highly recommend St. Petersburg Tours. We went with Irina and she was great, with impeccable English!

I'm Glad I Went, But It Wasn't Essential. Peterhof was a huge testament to the seemingly limitless wealth of Russia’s rulers. In retrospect, it's a demonstration of royal excess. The Russian rulers weren’t satisfied with having a few palaces, so they kept building more and more. Even in Peterhof, Catherine the Great built a hermitage (translated, a “retreat”) so she could get away from the main palace, which itself was the summer vacation home from St. Petersburg. Seriously? You need a retreat from your retreat?Further on the theme of excess, the grounds were filled with manyt expensive-to-maintain developments: grassy areas, sculptured gardens, and lots and lots of fountains. If you’re the ruler of Russia, how much time are you going to have to enjoy the bottom dozen least-interesting fountains at your summer home? I did like some of the whimsy on display in the fountains, such as the trick fountains and the dragons at a fountaintop.It's always funny to see the 18th and 19th century concept of “nature,” fully on display here. Nature was something to be managed, not to be left in its original state. Viewed from the modern perspective, Peterhof would have benefited if more land remained undeveloped and the attractions were consolidated more closely together.Much of the property has been nicely renovated after Nazi Germany looted and ransacked the place, but clearly it’s a work-in-progress—especially when compared with places like the Church of the Spilled Blood, which is positively gleaming after its comprehensive renovation.I lowered Peterhof’s grade due to the oppressiveness of the multitudinous pay-as-you-go options. They really need to provide an all-you-can-eat option to enjoy everything at Peterhof, rather than nickel-and-diming people at many different minor attractions (which each required at least 2 people, the ticket seller and ticket-taker—another example of the overstaffing problem).I also lowered the grade because different attractions were open and closed on different days. If you really wanted to enjoy everything, you have to select your visit day carefully. As it turned out, the Grand Palace was closed on Mondays, the day I went. I probably couldn’t have rescheduled, but still, it pays to research the options in advance.I also couldn’t tell if my ticket to the Lower Garden allowed me to exit, go to the Upper Gardens (and pay more), and then reenter the Lower Gardens so I could get back to the hydrofoil at the dock without paying another entrance fee. The ticket probably told me, but it was in Russian, and English-speaking help seemed scarcer here than in St. Petersburg. In all, I was a little baffled trying to navigate everything.Despite all this, I enjoyed walking around the Lower Gardens. The Grand Cascade was a sight to behold, even after the Vegas casinos have tried surpassing it nearly 3 centuries later. Even some of the lesser-celebrated fountains, such as the pyramid fountain and the Roman fountain, impressed me greatly. I also just liked walking around the less developed parts and seeing a bit of (cultivated) Russian landscapes. The views across the Gulf of Finland were nice, although I’m sure it would be nicer on one of the rare sunny days.I took the hydrofoil to Peterhof from the dock right in front of the Hermitage. This was a nice way to see the city from the water and was a quick (35 minutes) and convenient way to get back and forth. However, it was an expensive option—800 rubles (nearly $30) for the round-trip—and if you can’t exit and reenter the Lower Gardens for one fee, then taking the hydrofoil further limits your options. Considering the total costs, I’m not sure the trip was a great value. Some friends recommended Pushkin, a different summer royal retreat, as an alternative. Its highlight—a room covered completely by amber, even though it was recreated after Nazis looted the original—sounds mighty nifty.

Lush gardens!. While the palace is rather small (and super crowded), the gardens are amazing. Really regret coming here on an organized trip, as there was simply not enough time to explore the beautiful gardens! Do make it a point to visit this place for half a day - have a picnic in the gardens if you can!

Don't miss the most beautiful garden in St Petersburg. It was in late May and there were lots of beautiful tulips in the garden. I don't remember much about the inside of the palace because photos were not allowed and it was less impressive when compared with Catherine Palace. The beauty of Summer Palace lies in its garden . A stroll in the garden will definitely take you longer hours than the time spent inside the palace (which is quite small). As I was with a group tour, there was limited time to spend inside the garden. I did not go to the sea side at the far end in front of the line of fountains but instead, walked down the stairs and turned right where there were more gardens (big and small) to explore.
