I returned by walking up the stairs on the slope and turned right. There was a road leading back to the entrance of the palace/garden. It was spatacular to see the lines of fountains and the golden statues glittering in the sunshine...and even more beautiful with colorful flowers in season. Going in late May is a good choice.

gardens lovely but whole experience over priced. While the gardens and the fountains are well worth seeing the whole day was very expensive. We went by hydrofoil ($20 each), then entry into the gardens ($16) and then after queing for over an hour to buy tickets for the palace, charged 560 roubles (Russians only pay 280). Once inside the palace it is very clear that independent foreign travellers are not accommodated at all - no audio guide, no guided tour and no signs in any language other than Russian. Audio guides and guided tours were provided to Russians.The Palace itself is over the top- the decorator must have been on drugs -if you've seen Versailles or any of the UK stately homes or castles don't bother paying the exorbitant entry fee here.If you do want to see inside the palace I would recommend going as part of an organised group - a shame as this is not my preferred travel style.

Fabulous gardens. To be honest, it's the gardens that are the true star here, even though the palace itself is impressive. The sheer size of the place is a bit overwhelming, but it's interesting to see the various styles in the state rooms (from restrained neo-classicism to over-the-top baroque - the ballroom is a riot of gold leaf) and fantastical oriental-inspired rooms. After a while, though, the profusion of gold-leaf can get a bit oppressive.The gardens, though, and especially the grand cascade of fountains that lead down to them, are fantastic and worth a visit all on their own. We were only able to spend a short time in the gardens (spent too much time at other palaces!) and I know that we could have wandered around looking at the various fountains, houses, follies, and gazebos for hours. Even thought things are not quite in bloom, the size and scale of the planned gardens makes for a lovely walk--I can imagine how beautiful it is when things are blooming and fully-grown in mid-summer.Peterhof does get crowded, as most reviews have noted, and the crowds can be daunting and a turn-off if you are trying to really look at things. Every photo has dozens of people in it, and it's nearly impossible to pause and really appreciate thing without being buffeted by a tour group trying to move past. But, that's expected at such an attraction, and it doesn't really diminish the experience of looking at the palace rooms and gardens -- it becomes a party-like atmosphere as you descent to the lower gardens, especially if there are weddings going on (there were two when we arrived). Of particular note inside is the picture gallery room -- hundreds of paintings of women in various dresses and costumes. Well, it's mostly the same woman over and over, but the idea of "wallpapering" a room with various portraits to show that you had an artistic bent is interesting. I was most interested in the history of the palace, and the long process of restoring the nearly-destroyed palace after WWII. The palace was mostly bare down to the brick walls, with collapsed floors and looked more like a bombed-out shell than anything resembling the palace it is today -- the restoration work is immaculate, and at least some of the artwork and decorations are original (saved by being removed to Siberia--I think--before the city was taken). Not all the rooms are clear as to what is original and what is a reproduction, which can be a bit frustrating if you don't have a good guide to walk you through each of the rooms (and if you are interested in that sort of thing). Our guide told us that more rooms are open in the winter, when there are fewer crowds. Plastic/felt booties are required in the palace, and no photographs are allowed inside. A coatroom is provided to leave bulky coats and backpacks. I wish we'd had more time to walk through the gardens, and see the various other buildings, and I would definitely return to Peterhof to see other rooms within the palace when they are open. It's a fabulous day trip, well worth the effort and expense to tour from St Petersburg.

Worth seeing. Even in the middle of May the gardens and palace were very busy and negotiating the lines and language barrier, if you don't speak Russian, was a little difficult. My husband and I managed it on our own, but on reflection we would have been better off taking a tour. Our trip involved finding and purchasing tickets for the hydrofoil, buying tickets for entry into the garden and buying more tickets for entry into the exhibits. The lines for the exhibit tours were very long and slow moving as almost no useful ticket information is posted in the ticket sales area leaving each person in line to try to ask their question to the ticket sales person. Tours in each language are at set times, the tickets for the tours are available at any time beforehand, but make sure you give yourself plenty of time to stand in line (I expect a guided tour would help avoid this little problem). Also, print a map of the palace and gardens to take with you as we were not able to find one on site. Having said that, the gardens were wonderful, we enjoyed ourselves just wondering around aimlessly. This palace complex really completes the triptych of opulence when combined with the Hermitage and Catherine Palace.

Peterhof - Remarkable history and restoration. As with many interesting tours, the visit to Peterhof was remarkable. First, we were greeted by a short band playing dixie. Then as we toured the palace, gardens and fountains, we found there truly is an exceptional collection and vision that Peter the Great started and the legacy is left is the historic palaces, gardens, and artwork. There is also a short summary of the restoration work that went into the palace as it was the scene of battles during WWI. It's remarkable and a tribute to those who worked to restore the palace (and the restoration work continues to this day).

Too Expensive for what it is - there are better Palaces in/near this great city. I spent 9 nights in St petersburg and this was the most disappointing place we visited. Having already been to the Hermitage, Catherine's Palace (Tsarskoe Selo) and Yusupov Palace this palace just isn't as good. The roof was undergoing repairs, the fountains weren't running and I'm sure its a wonderful sight when they are but the gardens are massive, there are no sign posts, they don't give you a map and the only one's I found were either side of the palace but more round the front than on the park side. The only outbuilding in the park that I went to was some museum with the Chinese gardens but they wanted another 320 roubles to get in.Its expensive in comparison to the others 400 roubles entry and a crazy 500 roubles just to rent an audio guide! I didn't bother with the audio guide to find there is no information in English in any of the rooms. There's a lot of tour groups too so if you come here independently you've got to time it right. The treasury was another 300 roubles to get in too.Food wise they say there's lots in the grounds but I wouldn't have wanted to find them when I was hungry, lets put it that way.Having said all this, the golden statues are beautiful as are the two golden domed buildings either side of the palace. The gardens are nice & I'm sure much nicer when in full bloom.Its not a bad attraction but there are much better ones in St Peteresburg and I felt like they were ripping me off at every opportunity.

Skip the palace. Although the gardens are nice we stood half an hour in the pooring rain at a line wich didn't move a centimetre for the palace. People were soaking wet and they couldn't care less, no one was let in during the time. Finally gave up and returned to Petersburg having seen only the gardens.

A trip to remember! :). Although the weather was not the brightest, the whole place shone and gleamed and I wanted to never leave. I am not only recommending it for adults, children can go there too! There is a park and ducks and fountains and birds and.......OH! So beautiful! There are even sprinklers and if you go in the right place it starts showering you-with water, and joy.

Just amazing!. Petergof is one of the Saint Petersberg's gems. It is famous for its fountains, but admirable fountains are definitely not all that Petergof can offer to a tourist. There are a lot of Palaces belonged to different Russia Emperors: Mon Plaisir built for Peter I the Great, Peterhof Grand Palace created in Peter's times and reconstructed for Elizaveta Petrovna per sample of Versailles Park and a lot of others. The interiors of Palaces provide one with ability to get into the past ant to see how people lived 2-3 centuries ago. There are also a lot of outstanding museums on Petergof's area e.g. the museum of bath describing the certain aspect of casual emperor's life. So, it is better to allocate the whole day for trip to Petergof, otherwise you risk missing something.

Gorgeous and magnificent place. I've been to the Peterhof twice and will definitely visit the park not once or twice, but many times. It is a must place to visit when you are in St. Petersburg. The Peterhof park was designed and built per sample of Versailles park and these palaces and gardens are sometimes referred as the "Russian Versailles", but in my opinion it surpassed all examples. The architectural ensemble is so gorgeous and magnificent, it has regal splendour.It is possible to get to the Peterhof by bus (or car) or by boat from the Gulf of Finland. But there are always long ticket queues at the entrance. So, if you do not want to waste time, pre-book tickets or participate in an excursion group.It is worth to allocate the whole day for this excursion, as one can make a day taking a walk in the gardens and won't see everything.

A sight that you cannot miss. The easiest (and nicest) way to reach Peterhof is to take a hydrofoil from the pier in front of the Winter Palace. The earliest one leaves at 10:00 a.m.; the latest one back from Peterhof is about 5:30 p.m. The hydrofoil takes you across the Gulf of Finland in just 30 minutes and brings you right to the edge of the Lower Park of Peterhof. Peterhof is a Unesco World Heritage sight, primarily famous for its gardens, so I suggest you see the gardens first and foremost. When you enter the park (buy entrance tickets at the booking office at the exit from the pier), walk straight along the Sea Canal in the direction of the Great Palace (you will see it straight ahead on the top of the hill). Stop on the bridge closest to the palace to take a famous picture of the palace with the Great Cascade in front of it. The fountains of the Great Cascade start working exactly at 11:00 a.m. It is a beautiful ceremony accompanied by the music of the anthem of St Petersburg but expect the bridges across the canal and the area around the Great Cascade to be crowded with visitors who come to see it.The eastern part of the Lower Park is its most picturesque section, so if you stand facing the palace, turn left on the bridge and walk along the alley that continues down to the Adam Fountain with the marble sculpture of Adam. Continue down the alley till you come to the statue of Peter 1, and turn left to walk towards Peter’s small Monplaisir Palace on the sea coast, passing the Sun Fountain on the right and an aviary (home to some exotic birds) on your left.Take a picture of the beautiful Monplaisir Garden with Monplaisir Palace in the background, and walk across the garden and through an arch in the palace building to come out onto the terrace with a nice sea view. Consider visiting Monplaisir Palace (Peter I’s favorite) and the Royal Bathhouse (flanking the garden on one of its sides) featuring bathrooms of various kinds that Russian Empress Maria used in the 19th century.Walk back in the direction of Peter’s statue; after you’ve passed it, there are two “trick” fountains on both sides of the alley that you walk through. You will easily spot them by the screams and laughter of the people stepping into the fountains and getting soaked as a result. These trick fountains are great fun on a nice day but cover your camera before you step into one of them.Continue down the same alley past two identical Roman Fountains on either side in the direction of Chess Hill Cascade. This section of the park is one of its most spectacular sights. Turn right when you reach Chess Hill and walk towards Triton Fountain. There is a self-service café in the pinkish building next to the fountain –it is nice to have a cup of coffee sitting outside on a fine day.There is a ramp next to Triton Fountain that will take you up the hill slope to the Great Palace; alternatively, you can continue down the alley as far as the Great Cascade to take a closer look at it, and then climb the staircase right to the palace entrance. The palace is normally overcrowded during the high season; join the line if you feel like visiting it and buy entrance tickets in the booking office inside (the one outside sells discounted tickets for Russian citizens only). No photography is allowed inside the palace but the gift shop downstairs sells all kinds of books, booklets, and postcards. If you want to see the most of Peterhof, save a whole day for your visit – it is definitely one of the must-see sights for anyone coming to St Petersburg.

Incredible. This was built by Peter the Great as a response to his visit to Versailles. he must have been very impressed with Versailles and was obviously a very competitive man. He certainly did not want to be outdone. I thought the Palace and the gardens were absolutely magnificent and are the equal to if not better than Versailles and Schönbrunn Palace. We came in by hydrofoil - which I highly recommend. I recommend this method because it is a unique way to get from the city to the Palace but also because it makes a tremendous impression on you as you enter from the water. The sites along the way on the water are not so magnificent but it is still a fun ride. We had a wonderful time here and highly recommend the Palace to anyone in the vicinity of St Petersburg.

AMAZING!!!!. Peterhof Palace and gardens and particularly the fountains is one of the most breathtaking places I've ever visited. If you're ever in St. Petersburg, Russia, do NOT miss this amazing place. It's huge, though, so make sure you wear comfortable shoes.

One of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. The Peterhof Palace is unbelievably beautiful. From the inside out, you can hardly believe your eyes. The exterior is a rich yellow gold. Inside, the rooms of the palace are exquisite with many of them trimmed with gold detail. The many portraits of Russian royalty which hang in the rooms really bring the palace to life. An unexpected surprise are the beautiful fountains which populate the grounds of the palace. It is worth the long walk around the area to see all of the fountains and gardens.

On May, 9th in Peterhof.. Peterhof is our favorite place in St.-Petersburg which we visit annually on May, 9th.On May, 9th in Peterhof trial inclusion of fountains (c 10-00 till 15-00) is spent.  This day near the Big palace the celebratory actions devoted to a victory in the Great Patriotic War are carried out. In the Bottom parkPass performances of folklore musical ensembles. More than 150 fountains Are simply magnificent, and everyone is good on the. My favourite: a fountain of "Samson" and a fountain "Pyramid". The majority of palaces are opened for visiting (a palace of Monplezir, a palace of the Gauze and etc.). To visit the Big palace and all palaces of the Bottom park for a day simply it is not possible. Every year we take excursion, in one of the palace. These May days spring flowers in numerous beds and park flower beds blossom. Fountains and May flowers – it is fantastic after long winter.

Don't miss to visit Peterhof. If I have friends comming to St.Peterburg I tell them don't miss to visit Peterhof! The best time to go there is during summer or fall. The fontaines are working until the middle of octobre. The garden is big enough to walk around for more then two hours. If you are speaking russian you can take the marshrutka mini van at Prospekt Veteranov to arrive be your own at the castel and the gardens. For guided tours, daily, you can inscribe you direct in front of the Gostiny dvor in St.Petersburg. Guided tours starts about 10 or 11 am. Let's enjoy this pearl inscriped as an UNESCO heritage on the board of the gulf of Finland.

Worth the day trip, watch the limited times to buy a ticket for foreigners, skip the train ride. Limited signs in English. Funny little ticket office for foreigners (not Russians) inside palace. Only open 10am to 12 then 2.30 to 4.30. Very strange. Miss these times and you wait.... Again, very strange. Palace and gardens were great though. DONT go on the train/ bus thing..... It was terribly boring and not inside the palace grounds either! You need most of the day there. "park food" shop was horrible. Audio guide is worth getting but expensive.

Great palace and spectacular gardens. One of the most impressive palaces i have ever seen. The palace and gardens are inspired on Versailles. It was badly damaged in the war but they have recovered almost everything to its original state, it's amazing how faithful the reconstruction was.The fountains are also a marvel, specially considering it's all done without pumps.I suggest you buy a return ticket by boat (hidrofoil) near the Hermitage.Keep in mind this attraction is pricey but i think it's worth it.Also be prepared for crowds and waiting in queues. :(

Overpriced, not worth it. Okay, so the palace is quite grand, the gardens are nice and the fountans are impressive. However, for this you must pay. If you ae a foreigner then you have to pay A LOT!As a non-russian resident, if you jut want to visit the palace and grounds it costs 870 roubles (as of May 2010). If you want to visit the other attractions in the grouds (The little Hermitage, Monplaisir house etc.) you will have to pay considerably more. When you think that the Hermitage in St Petersburg costs 350 roubles you get an idea of how overpiced it really is.What I found really furstrating though was that all the money that non-Russian speakers have to pay is not put into improving the facilities for those same visitors at the palace. While all Russians get a guided tour of the house included in their ticket price, we get nothing. There is no signage in any language, no tour available and the audiguide costs another 500 roubles! As such, we ended up wandering the rooms of the palace with no idea what we were looking at.There are a great many other palaces in St Petersburg which are just as impressive, less overpriced (although dual pricing for foreigners remains a problem) and have a great deal more information and explanation available to non-russian speakers. Go there instead!

Petrodvorets (Peterhof) - Peter the Great's Palace. This palace is of mind-boggling opulence of the Imperial St Petersburg. Be sure to take the hydrofoil from outside on the riverside Winter Palace (Hermitage) to save time as the traffic is very congested if traveling by road. The hydrofoil travels on Neva River which is NOT very scenic but the best method of travel to Peterhof Palace. Petrodveorets was built in the 1700's was to rival the court life of Versailles and to show European royalty that Russia was not to be left behind! This summer palace consists of 300 acrea of gardens, 66 fountains, 39 beautiful statues and twelve miles of canals all built by French and Italian architects. Most of the palace was destroyed in the German siege but the palace was rebuilt after the war. Thank you to Red October USA for arranging our wonderful day tour and guide for a well-spend day trip in the Petrodvets area and a tour along the Gulf of Finland. We had a wonderful time and you can just imagine Peter the Great strolling along beside the fountains and in the parks. This is a NOT to miss part of your shore time while in St Petersburg.

Wonderful place but a few drawbacks. We travelled to Peterhof on the hydrofoil, because we wanted to approach it from the sea. We booked a return ticket because it was cheaper and we reckoned it would save queuing up twice. The crowds at the terminal outside the Heremitage were frightening. There were no orderly queues at all and it was a complete free for all. Tour groups which had booked in advance were given preference. Particularly obnoxious were a group of Spaniards who seemed to have at least 6 elbows each. Anyway, after missing one boat because we obviously did not have the right approach, we fought our way onto the next one and somehow managed to get a seat. Upon arrival, we bought our tickets at the jetty to get into the gardens. No problem.The gardens at Peterhof are absolutely marvellous, and in my opinion much superior to Versailles. We spent a lovely 4 hours or so wandering around the gardens and viewing the fountains. We had originally wanted to go into the palace, but the queue was about 1/2 kilometre long so we gave it a rain check. We also wanted to visit the fountains in the upper gardens, having approached by the lower gardens. We were obviously not the only ones with the same idea, and the lady at the gate connecting the lower gardens and the upper gardens had learned her lines off by heart "No come back". Translated, this meant that if we left the lower gardens to visit the upper gardens we would have to pay the admission fee again to get back into the lower gardens. Which we would have had to do, because the hydrofoil leaves from the jetty adjoining the lower gardens. So beware - if you want to see all the gardens and fountains, you have to choose to travel either there or back by bus, or pay to get in twice.  It is advisable to bring along your own refreshments, as the few refreshment stalls were very crowded. There is also a restaurant, but we waited for 20 minutes and no-one came to our table so we left again. (But it had the only clean toilet in the whole park) Nevertheless we had a lovely day and were glad that we made the trip.

Amazing fountains & statues. As others have said already, get the hyrofoil outside The Winter Palace, the quickest & easiest way to get there. Not scenic after a few minutes but gets you there without any traffic problems. When you arrive immediately go to the cabin and book your tickets for the reuturn trip at your desired time as that time slot could be sold out if you leave it to chance to book later. The gardens and outside of the place etc are very spetacular. Look for the trick fountains and visit one of the little palaces - Montplaisir" was quite lovely. With time restaints we didn't get to the grotto or to visit the palace, so I can't comment on them . Peter's Verseille was very impressive though and worth the trip out.

Gardens are Awesome; Palace Not so Much. I think that every reviewer comments about the gardens and the fountains. They are spectacular. No doubt about that. Well worth the time and money. The tour of the palace, at least as compared to the Winter Palace in St. Petersburg, I found a little disappointing and so I wouldn't recommend it. With the exception of the first few rooms, it was a bit mundane after awhile.A number of sources say that the boat trip from the Winter Palace is very scenic. I disagree, unless of course you find industrial sites along the shore scenic. That said, I still think the boat is a great way to get to Peterhof, just don't call it scenic.Some tips: * Try to have a map handy of the gardens. They are very large and it is easy to overlook some very impressive water features if you don't know they are there. We ended up taking a picture of an information board and constantly referred back to it to get our bearings.* If you go by boat, make sure you have a return ticket *before* you leave the lower gardens to see free upper gardens. If you don't, then you'll have to pay to see the lower gardens twice, which I suspect wouldn't be that cool.

Don't miss the experience!. When visiting this definite must-see St Petersburg suburb, book a tour to the Grotto (at the Grand Cascade). Frst, you'll learn about the amazing mechanics of the Petergof's fountains (no pumps or hydromechanical devices at all - can you imagine that?!), and see parts of it with your own eyes. Next, you'll get a "first-hand experience" of Peter the Great's hillarious personality: the guide will make you test Peter's famous "joking fountains" on yourself. You won't forget that!

Magnificent Gardens & Beautiful Palace. We travelled out to Peterhof on the hydrofoil which departs from just outside the Winter Palace. This turned out to be a very quick and convenient way to travel without getting stuck in traffic.We didn't have a guide, but as we had only limited time available we decided to get a cycle rickshaw tour of the gardens. This was rather expensive but turned out to be a good investment as I doubt we would have been able to get around to the major sites in the time available without it. Luckily my wife speaks Russian and our driver was able to tell us a few interesting facts about the park and the palace. The only misgiving about the tour was that we had agreed on a price for a specific amount of time. Our rider was quite happy to go on after the agreed time obviously thinking that it would mean extra money. I called a halt to the tour as soon as I realised it and found that the asking price now was some 1,000 RUB more than had been agreed as the maximum up front.The garden is very well maintained and the fountains are all in working order. Some parts of the garden is quite impressive, particularly the area just below the palace. And some of the fountains are actually quite funny also.We also visited the palace. It was nice but by no means a must, so if you are on a tight budget or just don't have the time then it is not really a big deal if you give it a miss. The first problem was to find the correct entrance. We followed a sign that told us where the ticket office was only to find a closed door with lots of impatient Russians lined up outside. The sign outside told us in Russian that the palace was closed and was due to re-open in a little while. This turned out only to apply to Russian visitors and that the entrance was only for them. All foreigners were to use the "entrance" that was marked "exit" and for them the palace was actually still open. Probably makes sense to someone... I think the main reason for the strange arrangement and the obvious discrimination against the locals is simply that foreigner visitors are charged a much higher entrance fee.Inside the building we had to make our way to the entrance via the area where all big bags and coats had to be deposited. We were allowed to use our camera inside, however, no flash photography was permitted. We also had to put on some shoe covers for our stroll through the two palace floors.The trip around the palace took about 30 minutes, and we could probably have done it quicker if it wasn't for us stopping to take some photos.Peterhof is a good place to visit during the summer and at least the garden is a must for visitors to St. Petersburg. Not sure if the place is open during the winter, but can't really see that there will be much to see in the garden at that time as none of the fountains will be working and of course no flowers. The palace itself was fine, and I enjoyed the visit but would happily have given it a miss if necessary.

Only one word: WOW!. What an extravagant display of royal wealth! Nevertheless, the best part of Peterhof is its enormous gardens and the hundreds of fountains. If you have only limited time available, see only the lower and upper gardens, as the palace itself is splendid by itself, but not a par to the magnificent gardens (not to mention the considerable higher cost to enter). Some tips for your visit:- Use the hydrofoils (700R pp) or the train to go there, don't use transfers by travel agencies, they cost considerably more.- Ticket prices are 300R for the lower gardens and 520R for the Palace.- Allow at least 5 hours for strolling the gardens, they are really immense! Don't be intimidated by their size, every corner is beautiful.- At Adam's fountain there is a small shop that rents nobility costumes for both men and women. It is great fun to wear one and stroll around, the pictures were priceless. Cost is 600R.- Get some snacks and water before you go, there aren't many places to buy them while you are there.Overall, Peterhof palace and gardens definitely worth a visit.

Beware!. First of all, let me just say that Peterhof is awesome! The fountains are superb and if you get a sunny day the grounds are a joy to walk around.Now the bad news - make sure you hang on to your belongings whenever in a crowd - I know it sounds silly, as most people are vigilant, but there are professional gangs out there who come to these places because they know visitors are easily distracted. This is what happened to me - we were in a crowd watching the fountains. There was some jostling as people tried to avoid getting wet, and within 5 seconds I realised my purse was missing! They really are that quick!If you want to avoid holiday misery then please make sure you take a bag which you can hold in front of you - no rucksacks or shoulder bags.I would recommend Peterhof to anyone, just beware of the scumbags who try to spoil your trip!

Spectacular Palace and Grounds. This palace and grounds were truly spectacular and should not be missed. We visited Peterhof on May 24, 2008 without a guide. We took a roundtrip hydrofoil trip (700 R per person) and left at 10AM. The hydrofoils leave near the dock across from the Hermitage Museum. The trip took about 30 minutes. Before entering the palace grounds we had to pay an entry fee (300 R). We walked up the path towards the palace we could see the fountains and they were just coming on for the day. They were lovely! We then wanted to see the palace and looked for a place to purchase tickets. A sign said to buy tickets inside but we already saw a queue. I decided to bypass the queue and go inside and find the place to buy tickets. The sign pointed to the right and I walked past two coat checks and the ticket window was in the last room before entering the tour. Tickets were 525R each. I walked back out to get my husband and we joined a tour just getting started. The palace was truly amazing and was made more special because alot of the furnishings and decorations were present. After the tour, we made our way to the front gardens to see the fountains. Just walk past the person monitoring the gate. You can get back in with your ticket you bought when you first entered the grounds. After reviewing the front gardens we came back into the main grounds and decided to see the trick fountains. If you are facing the palace from the main grounds, the trick fountains will be in the grounds to your left. The park is so lovely and the walk is very enjoyable as you discover the many fountains and gardens. There were some other buildings to tour but we opted not to. Hydrofoils leave every 30 minutes. I think the last hydrofoil left at 5:00PM but I am not certain. Check the schedule posted. Enjoy!

Worth a whole day. These beautiful gardens are worth a whole day. There are cafes, or take a picnic. The standard visit is 300 rubles for the lower gardens, but I wish I had also visited the upper gardens.Except in rough seas, take the half-hour hydrofoil. Note that the hydrofoil companies do not co-operate, and you must return on the one that sold you the ticket. Because tour groups get priority, independent travellers may be left on the quayside when a tour group takes a hydrofoil. For this reason, avoid the 5pm rush, and leave very early if you have to catch an evening show.

Beautifully maintained, gaudy royal splendor. I had already been to several Petersburg area palaces, so I wasn't expecting to be as impressed by the extravagance of Peterhof as I was. The grounds are enormous, covered with dozens of paths, gilded buildings, flowers, trees, and fountains. O the fountains! Be sure you come here in the spring or summer when the fountains are running, because this is Peterhof's big claim to fame. And there are, indeed, fountains everywhere. Huge, complex structures featuring big muscly Greek Gods in absurdly dramatic poses. The buildings are impressive too, but the really pleasing part of visiting Peterhof is just to quietly stroll the wonderfully maintained grounds. This was probably the cleanest and best upkept place I've ever seen in all of Eastern Europe.My only big criticism is the cost. The admission tickets were VERY expensive (especially for foreigners). And they wouldn't discount the tickets at all even though we were students (students at a Russian university, no less). And I kicked myself for not bringing an extra roll of film. I needed to buy one while we were there, and of course this also was overpriced.I've heard that the bus to Peterhof from Petersburg follows a lovely route, but we took the hydrofoil and found it splendid. Clean, quick, and comfortable.
